HEADLINE: Tax Plan Spurs New Sugar Battle in Florida

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Feb. 16

 BODY:
After failing to get rid of Federal price supports for sugar, environmentalists in Florida are now battling it out with sugar cane growers over a proposed tax that would raise money to help restore the Everglades.
Environmental groups, attributing degradation of the Everglades to fertilizer-laden runoff from sugar farms, say the tax would allow the Government to buy sugar fields, yielding a double benefit: reducing pollution and using the land to restore the natural hydration cycles needed to preserve the imperiled marshlands of South Florida. 
 But the way they are proposing to pay for the land -- by raising about $350 million over five years from growers through an assessment of 2 cents per pound on all Florida raw sugar -- has set off a new round of acrimony in their long, bitter war with the sugar industry.
Supporters of the assessment are focusing on the Federal Government, seeing a window of opportunity in a Presidential election year. Trying to win public support for it, if not in Congress then through a ballot initiative, they have mounted an advertising campaign that puts political candidates and officeholders on the spot.
"Next time President Clinton and Senator Dole visit Florida," one television advertisement urges, "ask them what they've done to make Big Sugar pay to clean up our Everglades, so our taxpayers and our kids don't have to."
So far, Congress has proven reluctant to disregard the powerful sugar industry lobby, which gives millions to Republicans and Democrats alike.
Last week Mr. Dole, the Senate majority leader and a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, included in the Senate farm bill $200 million for the Everglades. But the tax proposal, sponsored by Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee who also is running for the Republican nomination, has foundered in the face of bipartisan opposition.
Environmentalists may soon be getting some high-level support: Administration officials say President Clinton is considering throwing his support behind a 1-cent assessment on the sugar growers.
The growers have responded to the campaign for the sugar tax with their own barrage of advertisements, warning of "environmental extremists" who want to kick farmers off their lands, causing the loss of thousands of jobs. They say it is absurd to tax them and then use the money to buy them out.
"We don't want to see our taxes raised or our lands seized," said Robert H. Buker Jr., a spokesman for the United Sugar Corporation.
Florida officials said last week that they would try to buy 32,000 acres from a sugar company and use the land for water storage, if they were given enough Federal aid.
The acquisition of agricultural and other lands has long been part of the strategy to restore the Everglades, but the officials say the acreage from Talisman Sugar Corporation, southeast of Lake Okeechobee, is the first major piece of contiguous property currently in sugar production that has come up for sale.
A coalition of environmental groups say that at least 130,000 acres of sugar fields, about one-fifth planted sugar acreage, are needed to help bring the wetlands back. They advocate that the land be bought as it becomes available, as in the Talisman case, or through compensated takeovers by the state.
But Federal and state money for the land purchases is hard to come by. And groups like the National Audubon Society and the Everglades Coalition say that taxpayers should not bear the burden of paying most of the restoration and cleanup costs.
"We don't suggest taking the whole sugar production out of business," said Eric Draper, vice president for policy for the National Audubon Society in Florida. "Let's just use some of the profits they make off the Everglades to help pay for some of their mess."
A main point of contention has been determining what is the growers' fair share of the cleanup cost, which is estimated at $700 million to $1 billion. The sugar companies say hat they have agreed to pay up to $322 million over 20 years and that that should be enough. Critics say the industry should be responsible for at least half the total cost.
The Senate farm bill passed last week lowered the guaranteed minimum price for sugar by 1 cent a pound but kept the guaranteed price. Growers say price supports and import quotas protect them from cheap sugar imports and insures a reasonable price to consumers.
Supporters of the assessment maintain that it takes back only a fraction of the benefits growers get each year from the Federal program that guarantees a minimum price for sugar. That price, propped up with limits on imports and domestic production, has been about twice the price paid on the world market and costs consumers an extra $1.4 million a year, according to a 1993 report by the General Accounting Office.
The environmental groups had hoped that without price supports more land from sugar fields would become available for the state to buy and return to wetlands.
Most elected officials in Florida have sided with the sugar growers on both the price support and the assessment issue. Sugar is the third-largest cash crop in Florida, after citrus and tomatoes, accounting for about 10 percent of the state's yearly agricultural revenue of more than $5 billion, state officials said.
In a letter to the Committee to Ensure Florida's Economic and Environmental Future, the umbrella group for the Everglades defenders, Gov. Lawton Chiles questioned the wisdom of the tax and said that "history would record us as fatally shortsighted if our actions caused the displacement of sugar (a relatively clean agricultural crop) with an environmentally more damaging land use."
The Governor also said that the $350 million it would raise "appears to be more money than necessary" for land acquisition.

HEADLINE: With Fare Up, Subway Use Drops Sharply

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
After years of working to make New York City's subways cleaner, safer and faster, the Transit Authority reported yesterday that subway ridership in 1995 reached its highest level in 21 years, but then began a sharp decline after the November fare increase.
There were nearly four million fewer riders in December 1995, the first full month after the price of a token increased 25 cents to $1.50, than in the previous December, a 4.3 percent decline. 
 The fare increase, however, had a more drastic effect on bus ridership, which fell off nearly 11 percent from one December to the next. Bus trips tend to be more discretionary, with only 30 percent of riders using buses to go to work.
The decline in subway ridership after the fare hike had been expected, and was similar to dropoffs that often occurred after previous increases. Transit officials said they were confident enough in the new popularity of the trains to predict that this dropoff, like previous ones, would be temporary.
 "When you increase the fare, you're going to lose fares, that's historical," said John Cunningham, a spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Transit Authority's parent agency. "We expect to recover the ridership, because that's also historical."
The ability of the subway system to draw thousands of new riders last year -- some of whom came from the bus system -- cheered subway advocates, who saw it as a promising new trend.
 "We've been hemorrhaging riders for so long, so it's great that the last two decades of reinvesting in the subways has reversed the longtime trend of losing riders," said Gene Russianoff, a lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, a mass transit advocacy group. Riders interviewed yesterday agreed they had noticed significant improvements underground that they think are revitalizing the subway system and attracting new riders.
"When I was 12, the cars were a lot dirtier," said Chris Martinez, 16, a high school junior who lives in the South Bronx who has been riding the subways for four years. "There were more homeless people taking up the seats. The trains didn't run on schedule and there were roving gangs of kids. Today, the cars are slightly cleaner. I notice there are more riders and there's no graffiti."
Julia Gittens, 25, a resident of Lefferts Gardens in Brooklyn who works as a paralegal on Queens Boulevard, said she had noticed improvements in lighting and renovations on the platforms.
"They repair the light fixtures when the bulbs burn out, now," said Ms. Gittens, who has been riding for eight years. "In the past, they wouldn't replace them and the platforms would look dark and gloomy. Back then, I refused to ride the trains. Some of the cars are a little cleaner."
Ridership on the subways began a long decline in 1970, when there were 1.3 billion riders a year. The figures leveled off at a billion a year through the 1980's, dipping to 995 million in 1991. But that year, the cleaner cars and improved performance of the trains, the result of increased capital spending that began several years earlier, began to have an effect, producing a four-year ridership increase.
Historically, the flux in subway ridership has often reflected the strength of the city's economy. The more jobs available, the more people ride the subways. When the economy declines, ridership decreases. In 1990, when New York and the country were in a recession, ridership decreased by nearly 4 percent.
"Employment in New York City has always been a strong barometer of subway ridership,"said Harvey Poris, deputy budget director of the Transit Authority. "So many people who work in New York take the subway to work."
But from 1992 to 1995, employment increased only 1 percent while subway ridership increased 9.7 percent, with the biggest rise on weekends. Transit officials credit this surge to the new convenience and safety of the subways for riders making discretionary weekend trips. The transit system has also campaigned to attract tourists underground.
Some of those riders are even coming from the buses, which have traditionally been populated by riders fearful or disdainful of the subway. Transit officials said the city's clogged streets and slow surface speeds are prompting many to switch modes of transportation.
"The perception is that the subways are safer than they were and they are obviously quicker than buses," Mr. Poris said.
The bus system continues to be plagued with problems. More than 45 percent of the 3,600 buses in the fleet are outdated and break down often, causing long waits and occasional disruptions in service.
The fleet also faces stiff competition from the many illegal vans that run along major bus routes in the boroughs outside Manhattan, taking passengers away from the city's buses.
Buses were once the primary mode of transportation for city shoppers. But with the explosion of shopping malls in the suburbs and an increase in car registration in the city, buses became less attractive for many as people, particularly as speeds declined.
"You can walk east-west quicker than we can take you," said Alan F. Kiepper, the Transit Authority president.
The divergent fortunes of the subway and bus systems have led some critics to conclude that the Transit Authority has improved the trains while neglecting the buses.
"The T.A. has treated the buses like orphans," Mr. Russianoff said.
"There has been a bias toward subways. To be fair to them, it was because the subways were near collapse in the 1980's."

HEADLINE: P.A. Must Move To Build Rail Tunnel

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Priorities at the Port Authority" (editorial, Feb. 7) reminds the agency "that it was formed in the 1920's to build a rail freight tunnel under the Hudson, a job not yet done." 
 This would be the first new rail tunnel under the Hudson since 1910. It would reduce heavy truck traffic on overcrowded highways, improve safety, encourage economic development, make our air cleaner and link New York City, Long Island and New England into the national rail freight system.
 
RICHARD C. CARPENTER
East Norwalk, Conn., Feb. 7, 1996

HEADLINE: Clinton Points to Competition As Way of Curbing Inflation

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WILKES BARRE, Pa., Feb. 16

 BODY:
Wading deeper into the campaign debate over economic growth, President Clinton said today that "a lot of people" now believe that global competition can help hold down inflation, lessening the need for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
In a speech at a fund-raising dinner in New York on Thursday night, Mr. Clinton offered a vigorous defense of Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker whom he had wanted to nominate as vice chairman of the central bank in an effort to help foster a debate with the more cautious monetary policies of its current chairman, Alan Greenspan. 
 Mr. Rohatyn withdrew his candidacy this week in the face of Republican vows to block his nomination, leading Mr. Clinton to denounce those threats on Thursday as "outrageous political treatment."
But because any comments by a President about interest rates and the Federal Reserve are so sensitive, and because the Republican Presidential candidates campaigning in New Hampshire have repeatedly harped on the need for greater economic growth, Mr. Clinton took the chance today to "clarify something" about his earlier remarks.
As he toured the scene of damage caused by floods last month in the Susquehanna River basin here, and pledged $10 million in additional Federal assistance, the President said Mr. Greenspan and the Fed had done "a very good job" in bringing interest rates down since 1993 and helping to foster growth.
"The point I was making last night is that there is now a debate, a serious debate in the country, about whether there is a maximum growth rate we can have over any period of years without inflation," Mr. Clinton told reporters traveling with him. "The conventional wisdom is that it was about 2.5 percent -- that's from 1970 to 1995, that's what we averaged."
But, he said, "there are a lot of people, including a lot of people -- Republican executives in the manufacturing sector -- who believe that global competition will keep down inflation, and that higher productivity, driven by technology and Americans working more effectively, will permit higher growth rates in the next 10 years than in the last 25."
Mr. Clinton added, "What I was trying to do with trying to have Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Rohatyn on the Fed was to have that discussion in a nonpolitical context."
The White House has already let it be known that Mr. Clinton intends to reappoint Mr. Greenspan.

HEADLINE: Stocks Off Third Day in Row as Blue Chips Retreat 48.05

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD 

 BODY:
Pulling back from their record highs for the third straight day, stock prices fell yesterday on investor concern about declines in bond prices and fears that this year's rally had pushed values too high.
In heavy trading, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 48.05 points, or nearly nine-tenths of a percent, to close at 5,503.32. Since the declines began on Wednesday, the Dow has lost 97.91 points, though for the week the total decline is only 38.30 points. 
 But the troubles of the Dow did not spread to the broader markets. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell only 3.34, to 647.98, while the Nasdaq composite index rose 0.17 point, to 1,090.71. The American Stock Exchange's market value index also rose, climbing 1.48, to 561.84.
On the New York Stock Exchange, there were 1,239 declining issues and 1,063 advances, a ratio of about 7 to 6. Trading volume on the floor of the Big Board was heavy at 445.6 million shares.
And, despite having its first three-day decline in two months, the Dow has still turned in handsome returns of late. For the month, the Dow is up 2 percent, while for the year, it has posted gains of 7.5 percent.
Traders and analysts said that the decline in the Dow was largely driven by the bond market, which fell sharply for the third consecutive session yesterday, weighed down by talk of selling by large funds and by concerns over the supply of securities.
The 30-year benchmark Treasury bond dropped more than a point, pushing its yield up to 6.24 percent. The yield was under 6 percent as recently as Jan. 19. Bonds fell despite a flurry of new economic data confirming that the economy is slowing down. Such data are usually viewed favorably among bond traders because they raise hopes that the Federal Reserve will soon push interest rates lower to try to stimulate the economy.
In the stock market, analysts said that the effect from the slide in bonds was amplified by investor concerns that the heady set of record-breaking trading days this year had pushed stock prices too high.
"People are pretty edgy about the sharp run-up we've seen," said Hugh A. Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation. "It only required a small excuse to get some profit taking started, and we've gotten that from the bond market."
In addition to investor concerns, traders and analysts said that the decline was also caused by the mathematical dictates of computer-driven program trading because of yesterday's "double witching" expiration of options and futures contracts.
These expiration dates always result in heavy volume as professional traders, in a flurry of purchases and sales, try to reposition their portfolios by heavily trading equities regardless of the price.
While institutional investors scooped up shares in many of the recent witching sessions, traders said that they stood back yesterday. In part, that had something to do with trader psychology: with the direction of the market uncertain, few professional traders wanted the anxiety of holding newly bought shares over the holiday weekend.
"There was not a great deal of institutional buying to offset the expiration because of the weakness in the bond market," said Jeffrey Tabak, managing partner of Miller Tabak Hirsch. "Nobody wanted to be a hero at the beginning of a three-day weekend."
Investors sold a variety of stocks, including a number of names well known to consumers. The big losers among the Dow industrials were Eastman Kodak, down 3, to 74 1/4, and Sears, Roebuck down 2, to 42 7/8. They were followed by Exxon, off 1 1/4, to 81 1/2, and Texaco, off 7/8, to 80 7/8.
Stocks in companies in basic-materials businesses also declined, a sign that investors may be worried about the economy. International Paper fell 1 1/8, to 37 1/2, while Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing slipped 1, to 66 1/2.
Shares in drug companies also came under pressure. Eli Lilly dropped 1 3/8, to 62 1/4; Pfizer fell 7/8, to 68, and Merck lost 7/8, to 68 3/4. The decline came as a Federal judge granted preliminary approval for a $408.9 million settlement of a lawsuit against drug makers that was brought by pharmacists.
Hewlett-Packard was among the big winners. The stock jumped 9, to 95 1/4, after the computer maker announced that earnings grew a greater-than-expected 31 percent in robust demand for personal computers. The company earned $790 million, or $1.50 a share. Analysts had expected Hewlett to earn $1.36, according to a survey by IBES International Inc.
That led the way for other computer stocks. I.B.M. rose 3/8, to 118, after an analyst with Soundview Financial Group said the computer company would do better than expected in 1996 as its sales growth picked up. Digital Equipment jumped 1 3/8, to 69 1/2. The company ended talks with Cirrus Logic on investing $335 million in Digital's plant in Hudson, Mass.
Airlines and other transportation stocks also showed strength. The Dow Jones transportation average rose 1.44 points, to 2,034.83, still below its high of 2,094.29 on Dec. 13. UAL, parent of United Airlines, was among the big winners. It rose 1 3/8, to 178.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Zoning Forbids Wide Variety And Low Price

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
EACH weekend, hungry hunter-gatherers venture forth from the city, climbing hills and crossing rivers, eventually returning in triumph with meat and vegetables. Plus a few humongous boxes of corn flakes or Pampers.
These urban nomads travel in Dodge Caravans and their journey is a lot easier than their ancestors', thanks to bridges and tunnels. But their foraging persists because in many areas, especially in minority and blue-collar neighborhoods, the local stores don't stock enough merchandise of reasonable price and quality. 
 Before the 35,000-square-foot Fairway store opened in West Harlem in November, Sylvia Murphy and her friends trekked to New Jersey to buy meat rather than push their luck in the local supermarket. Now many of them have joined customers from elsewhere in Manhattan, as well as New Jersey and Connecticut, in a sort of commercial mosaic inside the big orange store at 133d Street below the West Side Highway. But for how much longer is in question.
Acting on regulations they admit are outdated, Buildings Department officials contend that the store has run afoul of a 10,000-square-foot zoning limit for retail establishments. The store's owners say it is exempt as a wholesale center that also welcomes walk-in traffic. A meeting is set for next week to address the dispute, which could result in shrinking or even closing the store.
Mrs. Murphy is not happy.
"As soon as we get something in Harlem they find something wrong with it," she said, as her friends in the seniors' room at the Riverside Park Apartments, near West 135th Street, nodded in agreement. "Just because I live in Harlem, I don't want to feed my family garbage. I want the best, just like any other community."
SHE is not alone. The City Planning Commission estimates that New York City residents spend $3.1 billion a year outside of the five boroughs -- not including spending on food. The supermarket chains know this, which is why they built sprawling stores just over the George Washington Bridge and the Nassau County line.
These food megastores barely exist in the city because of 1974 zoning rules intended to keep manufacturing from being squeezed out of industrial areas. Cheap labor overseas or in union-free states lured the factories and eroded the local industrial base anyway, but the zoning laws stayed behind.
"This was probably the least successful public policy adopted in the history of the city," said Joe Rose, the chairman of the Planning Commission. "The result is all this underutilized land that is prohibited from being used for retail purposes, which the city's economy desperately needs."
That leaves officials at the Buildings Department in the awkward position of having to uphold antiquated regulations.
"We interpret and enforce," said Charles Sturcken, the chief of staff at the department. "This is something where zoning seems to be behind the times, to the detriment of the city."
The Mayor's retail initiative has provisions for zoning changes that would allow stores up to 200,000 square feet. Now undergoing an environmental review, it should come before the City Council in the fall.
The Mayor might cut through the red tape for the Fairway store, but at the risk of upsetting the large group of Hispanic store owners and their customers he has to woo to be re-elected. Many of them are still seething over the city's support for the big Pathmark supermarket in East Harlem.
NONE of that helps David Sneddon, an owner of the Fairway store. He thought he and his partners had complied with appropriate rules. He suspects they are victims of smaller supermarket owners who feel threatened by their arrival.
He doesn't know what the politicians are doing -- he's too busy working 12-hour days. But he said that if the zoning issue were not resolved he might follow the old habits of his customers and head to Westchester, where they had been looking for a site before opening their West Harlem store.
He admits that problems remain with parking and getting a traffic light near the store -- where cars roll off the highway and pause briefly by a stop sign. A few people have complained to local officials about the huge flashing sign atop the store, too. Some nights it looks like a navigational beacon for planes headed to La Guardia (or on a retaliatory strike by New Jersey food stores).
But residents of Riverside Park Apartments, a huge housing complex that makes the nearby store look like a corner bodega, say the lights don't really bother them. They'd be worried if the place went dark.
"We have more important issues in our community," Mrs. Murphy said. "The drugs. The schools. That's what they should be complaining about."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Radical Overhaul Proposed For Social Security System
A Federal advisory panel will soon recommend a radical change in Social Security, saying that billions of dollars of worker contributions should, for the first time, be invested in the stock market. The panel is also discussing whether some of the payroll tax revenue for Social Security should be diverted to individual accounts, so workers could invest it as they wish.
Such discussions would have been unthinkable just a few years ago, considering the extreme reluctance then of politicians to alter Social Security. [Page 1.]
 
 
Dow Average Falls 48 Points, Or 0.9%, for 3d Drop in a Row
Stocks fell on investor concern about declines in bond prices and fears that this year's rally had pushed values too high. In heavy trading, the Dow Jones average fell 48.05 points, or nine-tenths of a percent, to 5,503.32. Since its declines began Wednesday, the Dow has lost 97.91 points. Other stock measures managed to rise, however, and despite the recent drop, the Dow is still up 2 percent this month and 7.5 percent in 1996. [39.]
 
Treasury prices fell sharply, and the yield on the 30-year bond jumped to 6.24 percent, its highest level since November. [38.]
 
Mexico Regains Some Ground
The Mexican economy contracted sharply in the fourth quarter, but less so than in the third quarter, and Mexicans took that as good news. The economy in the latest quarter shrank 6.6 percent from the last quarter of 1994, while in the third quarter, it plunged 9.6 percent. But the peso has stabilized and the stock market has gained strength of late. [36.]
 
Canada Resolves Lumber Dispute
Washington and Ottawa reached an agreement to resolve a 13-year dispute over lumber trade. The agreement would significantly curb imports of softwood lumber from Canada, where producers can get it from provincial governments at below-market prices. [36.]
 
Factory Output Plunges
Output at factories, mines and utilities in January took its biggest drop in five years, and once again, bad weather was cited. [38.]
 
Clinton Pushes for Growth
President Clinton again broached the idea of the Federal Reserve lowering interest rates to produce faster growth. He said "a lot of people" now believe that global competition can help hold down inflation, with a less strict interest rate policy. [36.]
 
Prudential Discussing Settlement
Prudential Insurance is holding talks with state regulators to settle accusations that its agents misled customers in at least 28 states. But it denied a report that it was prepared to pay as much as $1 billion to settle the allegations from state regulators. They have accused Prudential of luring customers into replacing their policies at added cost. [37.]
 
Hewlett-Packard Beats Estimates
Hewlett-Packard earnings soared 31 percent in the latest quarter, far more than expected, to $790 million, and the company's stock jumped 10.5 percent. Analysts said the company's performance had been strong across all product lines, especially servers, which are computers shared by multiple users across a network, and printers. [37.]
 
Comsat's Profit Tumbles
Comsat's operating profit plunged by one-third in the latest quarter and the satellite company hired an investment banker to look at a possible restructuring. [37.]
 
Saudi Family Invests in Midtown
Just a month after Bear, Stearns agreed to buy an entire block in midtown Manhattan, a co-owner of the property, the al-Babtain family of Saudi Arabia, said it would buy the site. [47.]

HEADLINE: Region's Governors Draw Own Blueprint for Welfare

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

 BODY:
A single mother with two children getting by on a $577 monthly welfare check in New York City would, under Gov. George E. Pataki's new welfare plan, have her cash benefits reduced to $424 and be forced off the rolls within five years.
A woman in the same situation in New Jersey would continue to collect $424 a month, and her benefits would end in five years as well, under Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's new plan. And a single mother in Connecticut, which under Gov. John G. Rowland has already enacted the most stringent time limit on welfare benefits in the nation, has 21 months to find a job before her benefits of $533 a month expire. 
 The governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are not waiting for new Federal legislation to begin making sweeping changes in their welfare programs. They are among 40 governors moving ahead with ambitious plans that combine time limits with a new emphasis on finding entry-level jobs.
Those are two core ideas behind a bipartisan agreement the nation's governors reached last week at a meeting in Washington, an agreement they offered to help break the impasse between Congress and the White House on welfare reform as well as the Federal budget. States still have no idea how much Federal money they will receive for Medicaid and welfare and how much flexibility they will get to design their own social welfare programs.
The agreement, which would need approval from Congress and President Clinton, would break with 60 years of Federal guarantees that poor people will always be entitled to benefits. States would receive lump sums of Federal money, block grants, to create their own aid programs. The agreement would set a five-year lifetime limit on benefits, not including food stamps, but states could exempt up to 20 percent of welfare families from time limits and set stricter limits if they wanted. One of the few limits on states' flexibility would be a requirement that they maintain welfare spending for programs from cash assistance to job training and work programs at 75 percent of 1994 levels.
To help win support from Democratic governors for the proposal, the agreement also included $4 billion for child care and a $2 billion contingency fund to help states faced with a sharp increase in welfare cases resulting from a sudden downturn in the economy or a disaster.
The agreement gives the Republican governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut what they are looking for to reshape welfare programs throughout the region.
"If it were accepted by Congress and the President," said William Waldman, the New Jersey Commissioner of Social Services who helped design Mrs. Whitman's new welfare proposal, "this would be a perfect launching place for our program. What they agreed to gives us the flexibility to make all the changes in the program that are different from the current Federal entitlement."
But advocates for the poor and some Democratic state legislators worry that time limits are likely to be a fixture of welfare programs in the three states. That means, they say, that tens of thousands of families will ultimately lose their only source of income for shelter, food and clothing.
Maria Foscarinis, executive director of the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty, said there would not be such cause for concern among advocates if there were some assurance that enough jobs would be available. "The danger is that people will be left both without assistance and without jobs," she said.
In addition, she and other advocates say, a new Federal framework poses the risks that states will ultimately have too much flexibility, and could further cut benefits or set new hurdles that will keep benefits from reaching deserving families.
Without new Federal welfare legislation, New Jersey and other states are required to seek Federal approval before making significant changes in welfare policy. For example, New Jersey obtained Federal approval three years ago to stop paying more money to women on welfare who had more children.
The New York State budget director, Patricia A. Woodworth, said the governors' Washington agreement would ease the path for Mr. Pataki's plan, if he could win approval from the reluctant Assembly, which is controlled by Democrats.
The most significant difference between New York and New Jersey is that Mr. Pataki wants to cut benefits while Mrs. Whitman is keeping levels the same. Mr. Pataki is also looking to limit welfare to individuals and childless couples to 60 days. Mrs. Whitman has proposed a five-year lifetime limit for both families and individuals.
Both governors are also recommending that welfare recipients who find jobs be allowed to keep more of their earnings, as an incentive to return to the workplace. And they both intend to support only those training programs that emphasize job placement.
"What we need to do is get people back to work," Ms. Woodworth said.
Around the region, advocates for the poor have focused on the time limits, saying that the goal is to force many women raising children alone to take jobs that do not exist. In New York, advocates are particularly concerned that Mr. Pataki's plan to cut benefits for families by a quarter will make it impossible for many families to pay rent, forcing them into shelters.
"We are setting up these women to fail," said Liz Kreuger, associate director of the Community Food Resource Center, a nonprofit organization in Manhattan. "And then we will penalize them by taking away their entire income support structure for themselves and their children and we will say that it was their fault. If you don't make a commitment to provide real jobs at real wages, then we are the ones guilty of terrible welfare fraud."
The region has recovered only a little more than a third of the 900,000 jobs that were lost between 1989 and 1992, according to John L. Wieting, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. In New York State last year, there were 72,000 new jobs created, including 25,000 in New York City. In New Jersey, 37,000 new jobs were created. And in Connecticut, the number of jobs continued to decline, with a net loss of 700 jobs.
State officials dismiss talk about the lack of jobs, insisting there are plenty of entry-level positions.
In Connecticut, Mr. Rowland won approval last year from the Legislature and the Federal Government to begin imposing a 21-month limit on benefits through Aid to Families With Dependent Children, the state and Federal program mostly for single parents. And the state is pushing direct job-placement programs over education.
"If there is any training, it is short-term," said Claudette Beaulieu, a spokeswoman for the Connecticut State Department of Social Services. "The shorter the better. We used to have people in community college programs for years."
Connecticut does offer one of the nation's most generous cash incentives to encourage families on welfare to find work. Welfare recipients are allowed to earn up to $1,049 a month and still keep some of their benefits. And the state just started a marketing campaign directed at businesses, encouraging them to hire welfare recipients and providing a toll-free telephone number for information on how they can go about it.
For single adults and childless couples, Connecticut has enacted much tougher time limits. Anyone who is classified by the state as "employable" is limited to six months of benefits. Mr. Rowland proposes in his new budget a two-month time limit.
Connecticut officials say that their tougher welfare standards have led to a reduction in the caseload to 21,800, from 24,800 last July. They also say that a rise to 17 percent from 12.7 percent of families on welfare who have found jobs in the last six months suggests that women on welfare are getting the message that they need to find work to support their families.
Of all Mr. Pataki's proposals, his plan to reduce the monthly welfare grant is causing the most immediate concern among advocates for the poor, who contend that the current level is too low for families struggling to pay high rental costs in the city.
Steven V. Banks, the coordinating attorney of the Homeless Family Rights Project of the Legal Aid Society of New York, said, "If the Governor's proposal is implemented, thousands of families will be evicted over the coming months and create a flood of homelessness."
In Westchester County, Mary E. Glass, the Commissioner for Social Services, who was Mr. Pataki's social services commissioner when he first took office but did not work on his new proposal, is also worried about the impact that the proposed cut in the monthly benefits will have on families already struggling to pay rents with $577 a month.
"I don't really have a problem with time limits," said Ms. Glass, who oversaw the implementation of Westchester County's workfare programs, one of the most ambitious programs of the kind in the state. "But we are concerned about the cutting of benefits because of our severe homeless problem. Seventy-five percent of the families receiving assistance pay more for rent than what we allow.
"We are fearful that could jump the homeless numbers to extraordinary levels. It is a very, very serious problem."

HEADLINE: Plan Would Have Social Security Put Some Money in Stock Market

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
A Federal advisory panel appointed by the Clinton Administration plans to recommend a radical change in policy for Social Security: investing billions of dollars of payroll contributions in the stock market.
The panel, whose proposed recommendations appear in a confidential draft of a report to be issued this spring, is also discussing whether payroll tax revenue for Social Security should be kept in one big pool, as it is now, or whether some should be diverted to individual accounts, so workers could invest it in stocks and bonds of their choosing. 
 Such discussions would have been unthinkable just a few years ago. Politicians have been extremely reluctant to change Social Security because any misstep could provoke explosive reactions from the program's 43 million beneficiaries.
But this year the issue has surfaced in political debates. It provoked a bitter exchange last month between two candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination, Steve Forbes and Senator Bob Dole. When Mr. Forbes suggested that a portion of younger workers' payroll taxes go into private retirement accounts, Mr. Dole ran television advertisements denouncing the idea as "a radical untested plan that would end Social Security as we know it." But since then, Mr. Dole himself has expressed interest in the idea.
Gene B. Sperling, deputy assistant to President Clinton for economic policy, said tonight that the Administration had opposed efforts to "privatize Social Security," but would review the recommendations.
Since the creation of Social Security in 1935, money paid into the program has been invested exclusively in interest-bearing Government securities, mainly long-term bonds. But the 13-member advisory panel says in its draft report that the United States could obtain a higher return on investment and increase retirement savings for the baby-boom generation by channeling some of the money into the stock market.
"Stocks have outperformed bonds by a significant margin over long periods of time," said Edward M. Gramlich, professor of economics and dean of the School of Public Policy at the University of Michigan, who is chairman of the panel, the Advisory Council on Social Security.
The draft says that, while stock investments would entail "a slight increase" in risk for Social Security, the risk would be manageable.
The council, appointed in June 1994 by Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, includes business executives, union leaders and pension experts chosen to represent self-employed workers and consumers in general.
Panel members have significant disagreements on such questions as: How much Social Security revenue should be invested in stocks? Who would manage the investments? How many private investment options should be allowed?
At least 8 of the 13 panel members say the investments should be in mutual funds or another portfolio of securities linked to a broad gauge of market performance, like the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks.
"Very few investment managers can beat the index year after year," said Marc M. Twinney Jr., a council member and actuary who was pension director of the Ford Motor Company until he retired last year.
The Social Security trust fund now takes in more money in taxes and interest than it pays out in benefits. But Federal officials say the program will not be able to pay all the benefits earned by members of the baby-boom generation because, under the latest estimates, the trust fund will be depleted in 2030.
Robert M. Ball, a Democrat who was Commissioner of Social Security from 1962 to 1973 and is a member of the advisory council, said today: "Some of the trust fund money should be put into the stock market. I want to do it to get a better return for the Social Security system. Historically, long-term Government bonds have had a real return, after inflation, of 2.3 percent a year, compared with 6.3 percent for stocks."
Under the approach favored by Mr. Ball, up to 40 percent of the money in the Social Security trust fund would eventually be invested by the Government in a broad selection of stocks intended to mirror the overall performance of the market.
Some critics say Mr. Ball's proposal would concentrate too much power with the Government, giving Federal officials leverage over private companies. But Mr. Ball said he would prohibit the manipulation of investments for political purposes and would require the Government's money managers to purchase the same mix of securities as used in a standard index of the market.
Mr. Ball's proposal, supported by five other council members, would keep the level of Social Security benefits envisioned in current law. It would not change payroll taxes for workers, but would increase income taxes on benefits for some retirees. Other council members want to create an investment account for each person covered by Social Security.
Under the approach favored by Mr. Gramlich, the Government would require each worker to contribute a small amount each year beyond their current level of payroll taxes. "The accounts would be held by the Social Security system, but individuals would be free to choose whether to invest their accounts in stock index funds, bond index funds or some combination," he said. People would have perhaps 5 to 10 investment options, he added.
When a person retires, Mr. Gramlich said, money accumulated in the account would be paid out in the form of an annuity, supplementing regular Social Security benefits.
Mr. Gramlich said individual accounts would give people an enhanced "sense of ownership" in Social Security, increasing confidence in the program. "At present," he said, "the system seems like a black box to most workers."
The creation of such accounts would fundamentally change the nature of Social Security. Some benefits would still be guaranteed, but the remainder would depend on personal investment decisions and market performance. People making identical contributions could end up with very different benefits.
Economists disagree on how stock markets might be affected by the huge infusion of money. The financial services industry would presumably benefit, but banks, mutual funds and insurance companies have just begun to study the issue.
To improve the financial condition of Social Security, Mr. Gramlich would slightly scale back retirement benefits for high-wage workers and would gradually increase the age of eligibility for full benefits.
Still other council members want to give workers even more control over their retirement money. Under this approach, Social Security would pay a modest flat benefit, about half of the average benefit now paid to retirees, and 40 percent of payroll taxes would be diverted to "personal security accounts."
A panel member who favors this approach, Sylvester J. Schieber, said: "Our proposal would give people the widest choice of investment options. People could invest their Social Security money as they invest the money in their individual retirement accounts. Beyond the floor of protection provided by Social Security, we should let people participate fully in this economic miracle that we call America. It's paternalistic to assume that people cannot take action in their own self-interest."
Mr. Schieber is research director at Watson Wyatt Worldwide, a management consulting concern that specializes in employee benefits.
Edith U. Fierst, a lawyer who serves on the council, criticized Mr. Schieber's proposal, saying: "It could be disastrous for women, especially nonworking women, because they would have no entitlement to income from the personal savings accounts of their husbands. This would be a particular problem for women who divorce or outlive their husbands."
In its draft report, the council pleads for early action to revise and supplement Social Security. "Actions taken now to cut benefits or raise taxes can generate revenues right away, these revenues can be invested in equities right away and these investments can raise benefits for younger workers," it says. "The younger the worker, the more there is to be gained from early action."
The council supports the current practice of automatically increasing Social Security benefits to keep pace with inflation. It rejects any suggestion that retirees with large amounts of other income forgo their Social Security benefits. Such a "means test" would discourage savings as people approach retirement, it says.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ROUNDUP;
Toward Bitter End in New Hampshire, Candidates' Favorite Issue Is Each Other

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 16

 BODY:
Rolling off their contentious televised debate, the Republican Presidential contenders took their quarrels over trade, taxes and negative commercials to the streets and airwaves of New Hampshire today, as their increasingly bitter contest entered its final weekend.
Steve Forbes, who just a week ago was dominating the Republican contest, seemed to be drifting off the screen. Polls showed Mr. Forbes trailing in fourth place, behind Bob Dole, Lamar Alexander and Patrick J. Buchanan, and Republican Party leaders and voters said he was becoming less of a factor, hurt by the same flat-tax plan that had helped him win attention in the first place. 
 At campaign stops, on talk-radio programs and in a last-minute deluge of commercials on television and local radio stations, the other leading candidates focused initially on issues, particularly the question of trade barriers. But as the day drew on and a blizzard overtook the state, that talk was drowned out by complaints about the way their opponents were playing the game.
Mr. Buchanan said that Senator Dole was running a "failing campaign," and that Mr. Dole "feels that for the third time he is going down. And it is not a pretty sight. And it's almost pitiable in many ways."
Mr. Dole turned his attention on Mr. Forbes, asserting that he was "trying to destroy me" with his advertising campaign and scoffing at Mr. Forbes's complaints about the attacks he had endured. "Forbes reminds me of the guy who shot his parents then pleaded for mercy, claiming he's an orphan," Mr. Dole said. "Here's a guy who goes out and spends $20 million on negative ads trying to destroy me."
For his part, Mr. Alexander, the former Tennessee governor, noted that Mr. Forbes had pulled his negative advertisements off the air, and said: "Senator Dole should follow Steve Forbes's example and take his negative ads off television."
The exchanges came as a variety of polls suggested the contest had evolved into a tight three-way race involving Mr. Dole, Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Alexander, with none of the candidates assembling a particularly large bloc of support.
The emerging dynamic that seems to be defining the final days of the campaign, party leaders and pollsters said, had positioned Mr. Buchanan with a solid if limited bloc of support from conservative Republicans, with the remaining candidates scrambling for the rest of the vote. Mr. Forbes no longer appears to be a significant factor in that dynamic.
Against that backdrop, Mr. Buchanan focused his attacks on Mr. Dole throughout the day. Party leaders and independent pollsters said it was unlikely that many of Mr. Dole's supporters would switch to Mr. Buchanan, though such attacks might serve to drive Mr. Dole's voters to either Mr. Alexander or Mr. Forbes, which would ultimately increase Mr. Buchanan's chances of victory.
With Mr. Forbes's position waning, he has exercised the same influence on the shape of the political debate he had in Iowa. There, his barrage of television commercials framed the contest around his flat-tax proposal.
Here, however, pollsters and political leaders say voters are wary of the idea, because it would eliminate the deduction of mortgage interest. "The biggest investment that most residents of New Hampshire have is their home," said John P. Stabile, the Republican state chairman.
And in the absence of the overriding issue of a flat tax, it has been Mr. Buchanan who has come the closest to setting the tone of the debate here, with his attacks on the free-trade agreements negotiated by the Clinton Administration.
Mr. Buchanan today said the trade deals "are killing the jobs of American women like nothing else." Both Mr. Dole and Mr. Alexander engaged the issue directly. "The problem is with an administration that is reluctant to stand up for the American worker, and Bob Dole will not be reluctant to stand up for the American worker," Mr. Dole said.
Mr. Alexander also defended his support of the trade agreements. "I will resist trade walls around the country," Mr. Alexander said. "I will resist protectionism. I think that is putting America last."
For his part, Mr. Forbes turned his criticism to his fellow Republicans in Washington, attacking the performance of Congressional leaders. "In business you can't cut your way to economic growth," Mr. Forbes said. He said the emphasis by Congressional Republicans on balancing the budget was "a cul-de-sac the Republicans got themselves into this year."
The debate Thursday night left none of the candidates with an obvious advantage, but instead set the tone for the disputes that were played out today across the state among the candidates. Thus, much of the day's discussion consisted of rancorous exchanges over what the candidates were saying about each other.
Mr. Buchanan seemed particularly barraged. He attempted at every turn to attack Mr. Dole in two radio interviews. But his efforts were derailed by questions about his past writings and his position on Larry Pratt, the Buchanan campaign co-chairman who was forced to step down this week after reports linking him to white supremacist and right-wing militia groups.
Mr. Buchanan said he was upset by Mr. Dole's advertisements calling him extremist.
"We've decided we've been tolerant and patient long enough," Mr. Buchanan told Jerry Williams of WRKO radio. Mr. Williams was sitting in a temporary studio set up in the Bedford hotel where most of the press is encamped covering the primary, speaking in front of an audience of 50 reporters. Mr. Buchanan was not there; he had called in, saying he did not have the time to show up in person because he was making his commercials responding to Mr. Dole's attacks on him.
"I'm working on an ad responding to Bob Dole's allegation that I am anti-woman," Mr. Buchanan said. "You know, my finance chairman is a woman, my campaign chairman is a woman, the architect my Louisiana triumph is a woman."

HEADLINE: In Iowa Town, Strains of Diversity

DATELINE: STORM LAKE, Iowa

 BODY:
At the Toui Lo market, one of two Asian stores here in Storm Lake, Laotian women were shopping, picking over jumbo tiger shrimp laid out in cardboard boxes or selecting bags of rice off the shelves. At the Lamp Lighter motel, across the street, Sunil and Geeta Patel, a couple from India, checked in guests while Hispanic maids cleaned the rooms.
Meanwhile, at a restaurant next door to the motel, Patrick J. Buchanan spoke at a noontime rally this month and sought out a local newspaper reporter to denounce a local meat-packing plant for hiring what he said were illegal aliens. Then, he demanded that English be designated the United States' official language. 
 It is no coincidence that Mr. Buchanan chose this small farming and university town set amid rolling prairie in northwestern Iowa to make his nativist appeal. In the past 25 years, Storm Lake has undergone a startling metamorphosis as immigrants have flocked here to work in two packing plants.
In 1970, the town of 8,591 people had 22 minority residents -- mainly faculty members and students at Buena Vista University, including two young blacks who had been adopted by a white family. Today, town officials estimate that Storm Lake's population, now 8,769, is 10 percent minority, mainly recent immigrants from Mexico and Southeast Asia.
The transformation of Storm Lake, bringing with it cultural clashes and strains on government services, has not always been easy. And it demonstrates how small towns in the rural heartland are facing the same issues in absorbing immigrants that are confronted by places like New York, Miami and Los Angeles.
Signs in public buildings here are now often printed in Spanish and Lao as well as in English. Crime has increased, though there is a debate over whether that is attributable to the newcomers. The school system, where 24 percent of the students are members of minorities, has been spending an extra $100,000 a year for its English as a second language program, and has a difficult time finding bilingual teachers.
"They're taking over the place," said Gwen Ehlers, 45, from nearby Newell, who attended Mr. Buchanan's rally. "They have to broadcast school cancellations in three different languages. When you go to the clinic, their languages are posted all over. They're catering to them."
Norman Olberding from nearby Odebolt said, "I listen to Storm Lake radio every morning, and the first five minutes is nothing but crime news with a bunch of names you can't pronounce."
To be sure, there are many in town, like Rev. Duane C. Queen, pastor of Lakeside Presbyterian Church, who believe that the new arrivals have injected vitality into Storm Lake, teaching a culturally isolated community valuable lessons about different customs and religions as well as different foods.
"It's easy to be in a Caucasian community, wherever it may be, and say you have no prejudices," said Mr. Queen, whose church is near the 3,000-acre glacial lake that gives the town its name.
There have been smaller, though more tangible, gains from the immigrants. "Our soccer teams have improved markedly," Mayor Sandra Madsen said.
To many displeased with Storm Lake's makeover, the real villain is I.B.P., a food-processing company that opened a hog slaughterhouse in 1982, taking over an abandoned meat-packing plant. Unlike the previous operator, which had employed highly skilled, unionized butchers, I.B.P. uses low-skilled, lower paid, non-union workers. In Storm Lake and the surrounding areas, where unemployment rates consistently are under 3 percent, such workers are not easily found.
"It's not a pleasant job," said Dana Larsen, editor of The Pilot Tribune, the local newspaper. "It's all production line, lots of knife work. Cutting hogs is not the type of work I think a lot of people want to do."
To counteract the local labor shortage, I.B.P. has recruited employees in areas far from northwestern Iowa, including parts of Texas, where it has found Hispanic workers. The recruitment effort, plus word of mouth in Hispanic and Asian communities, has resulted in the influx of immigrants, although I.B.P. officials stress they check the relevant documents of job applicants and do not knowingly hire illegal aliens.
"Laotians like to work but don't have any skills or anything like that," said Khampradith Thongvanh, a refugee from Laos who came to Storm Lake in 1976, after Communist takeover in Laos. "But they are hard workers, and we have I.B.P. that hires anybody. It doesn't matter if they talk English or not. People start to know about the packing plant and start coming from California or Texas -- start to come here because it's cheap and easy to get a job."
Now, residents are warily eying a small group of Somalis who have taken up residence to work in a turkey slaughterhouse. As Muslims, the Somalis will not handle swine carcasses. Storm Lake residents are asking themselves whether the arrival of the group represents the advanced elements of yet another immigrant influx.
While I.B.P. officials emphasize how much they contribute to Storm Lake and the local economy in taxes and an annual $36 million payroll, some residents are not mollified. Several years ago, Spencer, a city north of here, refused to grant a zoning variance to another meat-packing company after citizens protested at public hearings that they did not want their town to become another Storm Lake.
"It was the worst thing they ever did when they let I.B.P. in," Mr. Olberding said. "They absolutely ruined this town."
Mr. Queen hears such talk and shakes his head. When he thinks of recent immigrants, he thinks of people like Mr. Thongvanh, who worked as a janitor when he first arrived here, is now an interpreter at the I.B.P. plant and has two sons attending the University of Iowa. In 1988, when he became a citizen, Mr. Thongvanh took the middle name of Barry, which friends say is in honor of his favorite singer, Barry Manilow.
"I just wish people would get to know these people they have such strong feelings about," Mr. Queen said.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Vaughn and Red Sox Agree on a Rich Deal

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
A contract dispute that had Mo Vaughn talking about playing in New York two years from now ended yesterday when the Boston Red Sox and their multitalented first baseman settled their economic differences and agreed to a three-year, $18.6 million contract.
The contract, which also includes an option for a fourth year, makes Vaughn the richest member of the Red Sox ever. The $6.2 million annual average value of the new deal exceeds the $5,380,250 average of the contract Roger Clemens signed in 1991. 
 But the average falls mere dollars short of catapulting Vaughn into the top 10 of all time. Lenny Dykstra of Philadelphia is 10th with an annual average of $6,225,000. Vaughn's contract calls for an annual salary of $6.1 million plus a $300,000 buyout of the option year (salary $6.75 million). Under the language for the option year, Vaughn can refuse the extra year if the Red Sox exercise the option and still get the buyout.
"It's a great relief," Vaughn said at the Red Sox's spring camp at Fort Myers, Fla. "I wanted this to be done months ago, but that's part of the process."
Because it had not been done, Vaughn was unhappy. The Red Sox, he thought, were not treating him right with what he viewed as their hard stand on a multiyear deal. And at a series of banquets in New York in recent weeks, he talked about how he would enjoy coming to New York to play when he became a free agent after the 1997 season.
Vaughn, who is from Norwalk, Conn., and went to college at Seton Hall in New Jersey, undoubtedly would become as popular here as he is in Boston, where he is involved in youth and community work. If his popularity in the Boston area was a factor in determining his value to the club, his standing was enhanced when he was named the American League most valuable player last season.
He batted .300 and reached career highs with 39 home runs and 126 runs batted in. The only low point in his 1995 p'rformance came in the first round of the playoffs when Cleveland Indians pitchers held him hitless in 14 times at bat.
Vaughn, 28, and the Red Sox had been scheduled to present their salary differences in an arbitration hearing Monday. Vaughn, who had a $2,775,000 salary last year, had submitted $6.1 million and the Red Sox $4.2 million. After a couple of days of grueling negotiations in Fort Myers between General Manager Dan Duquette and Tom Reich, Vaughn's agent, the two sides settled on th't $6.1 million as the cornerstone of the contract.
"The last three years he's been our team m.v.p.," Duquette said at a news conference. "So it's fitting that he should get the best and the most handsome contract."
In another signing, Chipper Jones and the Atlanta Braves agreed on a four-year, $8.25 million contract.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: PATRICK J. BUCHANAN;
Some See Clinton as Voctor in G.O.P. Debate: Buchanan, Beset by Many Critics, Still Unbowed

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 16

 BODY:
 Patrick J. Buchanan's toughest opponent in the Republican Presidential campaign here in New Hampshire may well be himself. Columns, comments and acquaintanceships, past and present, seem to be rising against him.
Even in his own element, talk radio, Mr. Buchanan today found himself fighting off longstanding accusations of racism, anti-Semitism and fascism. 
 "These are the cuss words of a dying establishment," he said during a radio interview here, trying to turn those accusations into proof that he was fearless in risking the anger of the powers that be with his tough talk on trade and domestic policy.
But the questions kept coming, as they have throughout his career as White House speechwriter, columnist, television commentator and two-time Republican Presidential candidate. Where his supporters see courageous politics and prose, critics have long found code words intended to excite a fear of foreigners, Jews, homosexuals and blacks.
Mr. Buchanan has a political gift for crystallizing complex policy muddles over issues like trade into sharp-edged debates. In doing so, though, he habitually uses his blazing rhetoric to develop us-against-them nationalist themes with which he questions not only his opponents' judgment but also their patriotism.
In a debate here on Thursday night, he turned a plain-spoken explanation of his trade position -- stiff import tariffs, for one thing, and American withdrawal from the World Trade Organization -- into an attack on Senator Bob Dole for having supported the North American Free Trade Agreement.
"I plead guilty, Bob, to wanting to protect American workers making 10 bucks an hour in South Carolina textile mills from having to compete with Mexicans making a buck an hour," he said. "That's just not fair. That is un-American."
The accusation that Mr. Buchanan harbors anti-Semitic sentiments has arisen intermittently over the years because of columns like one he wrote in 1977. In it, he called Hitler a racist but also described him as "an individual of great courage" with "an intuitive sense of the mushiness, the character flaws, the weakness masquerading as morality that was in the hearts of the statesmen who stood in his path."
On a radio show here this morning, the host, Dan Pierce, asked Mr. Buchanan, "Are you anti-Semitic?"
"Oh, for heaven's sakes!" he replied. "Listen, we have Jewish supporters," he said, and went on to list several by name. "We've got rabbis on the board of our campaign. We've had Jewish friends our whole lives."
"Pat Buchanan's writings and Pat Buchanan's broadcasts have been on the air for 25 years," he said. "Many, many of those editors that edited those columns were Jewish folks. Do you really think that they would put in their papers something they believed was like that? It's absurd."
Mr. Buchanan said he knew the motivation for such attacks against him. Without naming anyone, he said, "There is a terror down there in Washington, D.C., that Pat Buchanan will succeed."
The value he places on loyalty is a thread that has been woven throughout Mr. Buchanan's writing. He invoked it again today in explaining on radio why he had chosen not to dismiss outright Larry Pratt, who took a leave as a Buchanan campaign co-chairman on Thursday after the disclosure that in advancing his battle against gun control, he had associated with members of the white supremacist Aryan Nations and right-wing paramilitary groups.
Mr. Pratt, who himself has not been known to make racist or anti-Semitic remarks, said on Thursday that he loathed white supremacism. And today Mr. Buchanan said: "I don't dump people over the side the way they do in Washington and wipe my hands of him and say goodbye. He's got a right to defend himself. And when he gives me his word as a brother Christian, I take him at his word."
But no sooner had Mr. Buchanan addressed the question about Mr. Pratt than his campaign suffered another embarrassment: Today a county chairwoman of the Buchanan campaign in Florida acknowledged that she was also a leader of the National Association for the Advancement of White People.
Officials of the Buchanan organization accused the woman, Susan Lamb, of deceiving them, and severed their relationship with her.
In a telephone interview, Ms. Lamb denied that her group was racist. "The goal of the organization," she said, "is equal rights for all and special privileges for none." For instance, she said, it opposes government set-asides for minority contractors.
But since the campaign has asked her to resign, she said, "I will do so; I will do anything I can to help Pat Buchanan's campaign."
Mr. Buchanan is widely remembered for the us-against-them theme of his speech at the 1992 Republican National Convention, where he declared that "there is a religious war going on in this country for the soul of America" and called forth the image of soldiers quelling riots in Los Angeles: "As those boys took back the streets of Los Angeles, block by block, my friends, we must take back our cities, and take back our culture, and take back our country."
Mr. Buchanan has long seemed apprehensive about unfamiliar cultures. In an interview with The Sunday Telegraph of London during the 1992 campaign, he complained of having walked through downtown Washington one day when "these guys were sitting on the corner playing bongo drums."
"I mean, this is the town I grew up in," he said.
On the campaign trail now, he calls for making English the nation's official language and imposing a five-year moratorium on all immigration. In describing illegal immigrants, he can be particularly harsh. "I'll build that security fence, and we'll close it!" he shouted at a rally in Waterloo, Iowa, last month. "And we'll say, 'Listen, Jose, you're not coming in this time!' "
Mr. Buchanan has joined strong stands on social issues to an economic populism, connecting the two by portraying himself as the champion of the most vulnerable. "I want to represent in Washington those people who don't have representatives," he said in the debate here on Thursday night.
He said he offered "a conservatism of heart that speaks up for the forgotten Americans who have no voice in Washington, that speaks up for the right to life for the innocent unborn, whose silent screams often go unheard in this country."
"It is a new conservatism," he added, "that speaks up for the working men and women of America whose jobs are being sent overseas in trade deals."
His economic message has a strong nationalist strain. "We've got to put America and Americans first, that's what I'm saying," he said on a radio program here on Wednesday. "And many countries like Japan that we've defended have become rivals and competitors, and they've really attacked and successfully taken out American industries.
"Mr. Hashimoto in Japan, he's looking out for Japan first. The Prime Minister of China looks out for China first. What is wrong with an American President looking out for America first?"
While his campaign opponents describe him as protectionist, Mr. Buchanan dismisses such labels as out of date, arguing that his rivals have not yet realized that economic competition has supplanted the military tests of the cold war.
Mr. Buchanan himself was a passionate supporter of free trade just a few years ago. "I was a dedicated, devout free-trader," he acknowledged in an interview in December. But as the cold war ended, he said, he began to realize that "there's only one guy here that's practicing free trade; the rest of them are seeking national advantage."
It is typical of him that he argues his new position with the same ferocity that once characterized his arguments for the old. Why so little ambivalence? His 1988 memoir, "Right From the Beginning" (Little Brown), may offer a clue.
"The problem with the Buchanan Dinner Table Debating Forum was endemic," Mr. Buchanan wrote of the family discussions in which he engaged while growing up in Washington. "Every one of us was opinionated; and we were all taught not to back down. Whatever our positions lost in logic might be recovered with invective. If you never quit an argument, presumably you never lost."
