HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
Club Hopping Around Hip Austin

BYLINE: By SUSAN SPANO 

 BODY:
SEVERAL months ago, while I was reading "The Texas Monthly Guidebook to Austin" on a New York subway, a man nudged me and asked, "Are you really going there?" When I said yes, he told me he'd once lived in Austin, and he got so fired up describing its virtues that he almost missed his stop.
This was not the only testimonial I heard before I spent five days in Austin in early December. Home to both the state university and capital, Austin is considered something of a hip, progressive Lone Star anomaly. I have more than a few New York friends whose voices grow heartsick when they start reminiscing about their days in Austin -- cooling off in a big public swimming hole called Barton Springs, living cheaply, drinking Pearl beer and staying up late in clubs to hear musicians like Joe Ely, Lloyd Manes, Jerry Jeff Walker and Willie Nelson. 
 Of course, Austin has changed since the 70's. It boomed in the 1980's, went bust and then came back to life in the last few years when computer companies like Dell and I.B.M. settled in -- giving gifted young Austinites 9-to-5 jobs and the city the nickname: Silicon Prairie. The population has almost doubled from that of 1970, soaring to 512,000 in 1995; Austin's hippies are mostly grown-up yuppies now, and sprawling suburbs have hemmed in the fine old downtown.
At any rate, I could count on good company for the trip, because my friend Constance Ash wanted to come along; she used to hang out in Austin with her husband, Ned Sublette, and his band. While I checked out a few hotels, she'd stay with another friend of ours, Lissa Hattersley, a singer who recently moved back there after living in New York for 10 years. Once I got to town, I'd call yet another Austin connection of mine, Joe Holley, with a real Texas pedigree: born and bred in Waco, he used to write speeches for former Gov. Ann Richards.
Constance and I flew to Texas on T.W.A. (for $313 round trip, with a change of planes in St. Louis), then hopped into a white Buick Skylark we rented at Alamo in the Austin Airport (for a five-day rate of $133). The center of Austin still has the feeling of a small town, which is why we had no trouble finding our way to the Southard House, a bed-and-breakfast on the city's west side where I'd reserved a $75 room called Lady Esther for two nights. The room was on the second floor of a handsome pink frame house built in 1890, with a small private bath, carpeting, ceiling fan, two curtained windows, television and quilt-covered double bed (from which I'd later hear squirrels doing acrobatics in the rain gutters).
Right away we phoned Lissa, who drove to meet us from her apartment in the Hyde Park neighborhood, north of the university. The three of us went to Guero's Taco Bar on South Congress for Mexican food, passing over the Congress Avenue Bridge, home to Austin's famous bat colony. The bats had already flown to Mexico for the winter; their instincts were correct because a cold front had just passed through Austin, making us all thankful for our coats. At Guero's we found a table near a cardboard figure of President Clinton (who'd been to the restaurant himself recently), snacked on a basket of nachos dipped in limey green and hot red salsas, toasted our reunion with margaritas and then tore into our entrees -- mine was a bowl of queso flameado, consisting of green peppers and melted white cheese, which I spooned onto hot tortillas (for $12, including the margarita and tip).
Then we walked a bit on the Town Lake Hike and Bike Trail, a marvelous 8.5-mile path that lines the north and south sides of what Austinites call Town Lake, but is really a drowsy, winding loop of the Colorado River, impounded by a series of seven dams in the hill country to the west. The bare trees were filled with noisy grackles, but on a little tongue of land licking out into the river a young man with a fiddle sat on a rock, making sweeter sounds.
Afterward, we warmed up at Little City, a downtown coffee bar so minimalistically chic that it would fit right into SoHo in Manhattan, though I slipped outside to snap a picture of a sight that is pure Austin -- the State Capitol, which sits in dignity at the north end of Congress Avenue. Then it was on to the Continental Club, a hole-in-the-wall classic on South Congress, with a beery smell and portraits of Elvis and Gene Autry on the walls. A band called the Syndicate was playing polkas and it was happy hour so there was no cover charge (though two more margaritas, one each for Constance and me, and a beer for Lissa cost $11).
THAT first evening in Austin proved to be a pattern for those that followed. We'd rendezvous for dinner at restaurants like Mars on San Antonio Street (where a huge bowl of Thai noodles with vegetables, chicken or shrimp costs $6.95 to $10.95) or El Sol y La Luna on South Congress, with cozy booths, chili pepper lights, colorful paintings on the walls and a menu featuring Latin American specialties. I had a Shiner Bock beer and a delicious dish called enchiladas Zacatecanas and split a creamy flan with Constance (with my share of the bill coming to $10).
Then we'd check out some music. One night we landed at a club called Cedar Street ($2 cover) around midnight and stayed until 2, listening to a group called the Eight and a Half Souvenirs, with a sound Constance and Lissa described as Retro Jumped-Up R & B. The club was packed with chicly dressed University of Texas undergraduates who occasionally retired to the Cigar Room for a smoke, draping themselves on a couch and one another.
While in Austin I did a good deal of hotel-hopping too. It wasn't that I didn't like the easygoing Southard House, in a leafy, old-fashioned neighborhood called Clarksville, near the shops and cafes of West Sixth Street, the 500-year-old Treaty Oak on Baylor Street (poisoned by a saboteur in 1989 and then nursed back to life, thanks to treatment financed by Ross Perot), and the Whole Foods Market, a huge natural-foods emporium. I just wanted to find a nice room for less than $75 a night without moving out to a Super 8 or Motel 6 on I-35 north of town.
However, for my second two nights in town, I settled for another $75 room on the ninth floor of the the Radisson Hotel on Town Lake, with a picture window overlooking the Congress Avenue Bridge plus a king-size bed, coffee maker, ironing board, television and free parking. The hotel was modern and relatively likable, but distinguished above all for its downtown location, near a vintage guitar and amp store called Black Market Music on Howard Street, where I played a G chord on a Gibson Flying V2, and the trail around Town Lake. One numbingly cold morning I ran there, stopping to pay my respects at the statue of one of Austin's most venerated heroes -- the late guitarist Stevie Ray Vaughn.
I also wandered into the Driskill Hotel on East Sixth Street, built in Romanesque Revival style of native limestone by a cattle baron in 1886. Lyndon B. Johnson used to keep a suite at the grand old hotel, though I never dreamed of staying there -- in December a single cost $125, with special rates offered to Government employees and members of the American Automobile Association. I'm not a A.A.A. member, but at a phone booth just off the lobby I called my father and had him fax the hotel a copy of his A.A.A. card, which is how I managed to spend a night at the Driskill in a huge, fifth-floor room for just $69. Actually, the room showed signs of wear. There was a rip in the curtains, light scuff marks on the walls, and slightly frayed patches in the carpet -- so I wasn't sure I'd choose the hotel the next time I visited Austin. But I did vow to call A.A.A. when I got home, because any club that yields hotel discounts like the one I got at the Driskill is a club I want to join.
AUSTINITES like my friend Joe seemed proud of their city but hesitant to boast. So when I met with him or Lissa, I found myself enumerating its attractions like the handsome campus of the University of Texas; a lovely little museum in Hyde Park dedicated to the work of the German sculptor Elisabet Ney, who moved to Austin in the early 1890's and made the heroic statues of Stephen F. Austin and Sam Houston that guard the entrance to the State Capitol; and the glorious red granite capitol building itself, with a dome seven feet higher than the one above the Capitol in Washington. Dedicated in 1888, the edifice was completely renovated after fire struck its east wing in 1983, so that now its oak and mahogany wainscoting, terrazzo floors, and custom-made hinges and doorknobs veritably gleam. The Texas legislature (which convenes every other year) wasn't in session when I took the free half-hour tour, but I saw portraits of all my favorite, hard-driving Texas politicians, from the state's first female governor, Miriam (Ma) Ferguson, to the late Representative Barbara Jordan and Lyndon Johnson.
The museum in the 1857 General Land Office Building next to the capitol tells the story of the state's wild, distinctive past with displays of Santa Ana's silver spurs, taken by Texans at the Battle of San Jacinto in 1836, and the pen used by President Polk when he annexed the Texas Republic in 1845. And while taking a free tour of the beautiful Greek Revival Governor's Mansion on the southwest side of the capitol, I saw Stephen F. Austin's desk and heard more than a few jokes about Ima, the lamentably named daughter of Gov. James Hogg, who served from 1891 to 1895 -- told by the wry young guide in a U.T. letter jacket.
Joe drove me out to the hill country one bright, cold Sunday morning, telling stories all the way, like the one about how Ann Richards once made him put his head on her pillow in the Governor's Mansion so he could see the view of the State Capitol she woke up to every morning. He also taught me to how to properly pronounce the name of the river that ribbons through the gently rolling countryside, covered with winter wheat, juniper trees, and mesquite: Pedernales is how it's spelled, but Texans call it the perr-derr-NAH-lis, with the last two syllables as in in Alice.
We stopped first at L.B.J.'s cozy little boyhood home in Johnson City, about 50 miles east of Austin, where he grew up with three sisters and a brother named Sam Houston. From the visitors center in the Lyndon B. Johnson State Historical Park outside Stonewall we could see the rooftop of the L.B.J. Ranch, where Lady Bird still lives, but we passed up the two-hour bus tour because we wanted to get on to lunch at the Hill Top Cafe, a Cajun Greek roadhouse about 10 miles northwest of Fredericksburg. At the restaurant, owned by a musician who used to play with the Austin band called Asleep at the Wheel, I ordered roasted Greek chicken and a Shiner Bock on tap, but Joe made the best choice -- Texas-style boudin, also with a Shiner Bock, about $15 a person, including a tip.
We rolled back into Austin at sunset, when I reconnoitered with Constance and Lissa for a last drink at the woody bar in the Driskill Hotel. Constance had had a great time in Austin and had even taken to drinking martinis, so of course Lissa and I joined her. Perched on high bar stools, we compared lives and laughed too loudly. We probably would have started to sing, too, had someone brought Lissa a guitar.
 
The bottom line
While in Austin I spent an average of $116 a day, with $71 of that going toward accommodations.
Getting There
To reach Austin, I flew on T.W.A., (800) 221-2000, from New York for $313 round trip. At Alamo Rent a Car, (800) 354-2322, in the Austin Airport, I rented an economy class car at a five-day rate of $133; gas cost $4.
The city has a fleet of free trolleys, called the Congress 'Dillo, (512) 474-1200, that ply four downtown routes, but I wanted access to places farther afield, which is why I rented a car.
Information
Contact the Austin Convention and Visitors Bureau, 201 East Second Street, Austin, Tex. 78701; (800) 926-2282. The bureau's Music Liaison Office, (512) 404-4575, can supply information on the city's music scene. Another information source is the Texas Department of Transportation, Travel and Information Division, Post Office Box 5064, Austin, Tex. 78763, (800) 452-9292.
Places to Stay
The Southard House Bed and Breakfast Inn, 908 Blanco Street, (512) 474-4731, fax (512) 478-5393, has 16 rooms in three historic homes in the Old West neighborhood of Austin. All of them have private baths, with prices for two ranging from $69 to $169, including breakfast.
The Radisson Hotel on Town Lake, 111 Cesar Chavez Street, (800) 333-3333 or (512) 478-9611, fax (512) 473-8399, has 281 rooms that, without discounts, range from $85 to $115, single or double occupancy. The hotel also offers free airport shuttle service, room service and an outdoor swimming pool.
The Driskill Hotel, Sixth and Brazos Streets, (800) 252-9367 or (512) 474-5911, fax (512) 474-2214, has 177 rooms that range from $125 to $205 for two people, with a 10 percent discount for A.A.A. members (however, in December I got a discounted rate of $69).

HEADLINE: Four Hands, One Bench, Still Married

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: SCARSDALE

 BODY:
MARRIED to each other for 47 years, Jean and Kenneth Wentworth have an unusually close relationship -- literally. They have shared the same piano bench since the beginning. As duo pianists, they also share a reverence for a special form of musical literature.
"Limited but distinguished" is how they refer to the repertory for two pianists at one piano. Mozart wrote two hours' worth of such music; Schubert, Debussy, Dvorak and the American Louis Moreau Gottschalk were other composers who favored the form. 
 "It's likely to be a connoisseur's art," Ms. Wentworth said recently in the couple's living room here, where a Steinway and a Yamaha nestle in a corner. The Wentworths practice separately on two pianos but meet on the Steinway bench as early as possible when preparing for a concert. Their next performances are tomorrow at 2 and 7 P.M. and Tuesday at 8 P.M. at the Good Shepherd Presbyterian Church, 152 West 66th Street, near Lincoln Center in Manhattan, where they will play the music of the 19th-century Austrian composer Carl Czerny with the Jupiter Symphony Orchestra. Anton Kuerti will be the guest conductor. The program includes an overture, a concerto and a symphony. Tickets range from $7 to $21.
Some composers have written deliberately for four hands, the couple said, while some works for four hands have been arranged from other forms of music. Publishers, for example, routinely arranged symphonies for four hands at the piano when music making was a popular family pastime. "The recording industry put that concept out of business," Ms. Wentworth said.
The couple talk about "traffic problems" at the piano, but this is better seen than described. Picture two bodies on a single bench and then imagine most virtuosic piano recitals. Cramped is not quite the word for two artists sharing a tight space. Accommodating, cooperating, collaborating might be better terms. By now, intuition and empathy mix in equal measure with handwritten notes on their sheet music. An asterisk reminds one to get his hands quickly out of the way; the word "squeeze" means, roughly, to make way for the other person.
"Four hands on a piano are less likely to be sailing all over the place," said Ms. Wentworth, who always plays on the upper keyboard. "In the Lisztian virtuoso sense, that is," said Mr. Wentworth, who plays on the bottom. Of course, they are not always confined to their own territory. His fingers may suddenly appear in the treble notes, and vice versa. During their recent practice of the Czerny concerto, three hands came tumbling down the keyboard, Ms. Wentworth's smaller one cupped beneath those of her husband.
"You have to get on in order to play four hands," said Ms. Wentworth, who exudes a quiet radiance. "Piano four hand presupposes friendship." Music for two pianists at two pianos, on the other hand, connotes a spirit of rivalry, she said.
The Wentworths met at the Juilliard School, when they studied with the same teacher. In the early 1960's, they went to live in India on Fulbright scholarships, and there began concentrating on the four-hand literature. "You were lucky to find one piano that worked," said Mr. Wentworth, who described taking a piano apart to fix it before one concert.
The couple also told of watching two grand pianos arrive in Calcutta, where they lived with their three children. "Six or seven men walked four miles with the piano on their heads," Mr. Wentworth said, recalling that the piano legs had been removed. "The men wound turbans on their heads and sat the pianos on them. It was the best way to move pianos -- for the pianos, that is."
Ms. Wentworth won the Walter W. Naumburg Award in 1954 and is known as a Debussy scholar. She is on sabbatical from Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers, where she has taught piano, music history and chamber music since 1972.
Mr. Wentworth taught music at Sarah Lawrence for nearly 40 years, retiring in 1993. He also ran a popular concert series called Summer Evenings at Sarah Lawrence. He now runs an artist-management business called Jonathan Wentworth Associates, which represents more than 40 conductors, pianists, jazz musicians and chamber groups. The company got started when Mr. Wentworth helped the Borodin Trio, an immigrant Russian group, obtain concert bookings in this country.
The Mount Vernon-based company is named for the couple's son Jonathan, who died of AIDS in 1994. Their daughter, Martha, works with her father at the management company, and their son David is an economist in Maryland. The Wentworths wear red-ribbon pins and raise money in their son's name for the Gay Men's Health Crisis.
Soon after his death, the couple were in a serious car accident in England, from which Ms. Wentworth is still recovering. Her whiplash injury did not keep her away from the piano for long, however. Besides this week's concerts, she will perform on March 3 in a free concert at Sarah Lawrence, to be presented at 4 P.M. in Reisinger Auditorium by members of the faculty. She will also give a solo recital of works by Debussy and Ravel on April 14 at 8 P.M., also in Reisinger Auditorium. Tickets for that concert are $10 and $8.
The Wentworths think of their playing as chamber music, perhaps of the most intimate kind. Their own working metaphor is the string quartet, which Mr. Wentworth calls "the high point of music making, the most pure."
Their four hands represent the four string parts -- Mr. Wentworth's hands acting as the cello and viola and his wife's as the two violins. "That's the closest we can come to that highest form of art," he said.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 9; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1527 words

HEADLINE: Revolutionary Thinking

BYLINE: By John Patrick Diggins 

 BODY:
John Patrick Diggins is a Distinguished Professor at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, where he teaches American history. He is the author of the forthcoming "Politics and the Spirit of Tragedy."

A STRUGGLE FOR POWER
The American Revolution.
By Theodore Draper.
544 pp. New York:
Times Books/Random House. $35.
FOR more than two centuries, partisans and historians have given differing interpretations of the American Revolution. We Americans, even those of us whose immigrant ancestors had no direct connection to the event, have every reason to take pride in it. The American Revolution courageously challenged the mightiest empire of the world and emerged victorious. It did so, moreover, without devouring its own children in a bloody reign of terror. And having won freedom, it successfully secured that freedom in a constitutional system that would ultimately prove liberating for all Americans. Thus, to understand the meaning of the Revolution is the first step in understanding the meaning of America itself. 
 "A Struggle for Power," by Theodore Draper, takes a giant step toward historical understanding. It should be read by every citizen. A work of prodigious research, lucid prose and penetrating analysis, it teaches us truths that have gone untaught in much of American historiography, where the struggle for liberty is generally depicted as taking place somewhere other than in our own will to power.
Not that others have entirely ignored the subject of power. The distinguished Harvard historian Bernard Bailyn dealt with it in his influential "Ideological Origins of the American Revolution." Wondering how grievances as slight as taxes of a few pennies (demanded in the Stamp Act of 1765) could have led the colonists to revolt, Mr. Bailyn focused on an opposition ideology, inspired by Whigs in Britain, that the colonists adopted to make their case, a perspective that rendered them almost paranoid in seeing power conspiring against liberty in every assertion of parliamentary sovereignty over the Colonies.
But for Mr. Draper the distinction between power and liberty that is made by Mr. Bailyn -- between domination on the one hand and self-determination on the other -- becomes obscured when the issue actually is who orders and who obeys. Moreover, power is not so much a matter of differing intellectual perspectives as an aspect of material factors like expanding geography and demography. Whereas Mr. Bailyn sought to show why America grew anxious about Britain, Mr. Draper shows why Britain became anxious about a young America growing by leaps and bounds. It was not the misimpressions of the alleged British misuse of power that led to the Revolution, he insists, but power itself -- power as appropriation, augmentation and exclusion, power as whatever it takes to prevail in political life.
Among the epigraphs to the text is one by Thucydides, to the effect that the Peloponnesian War broke out because of the growth of the power of Athens and the alarm it aroused. Another is cited by Horace Walpole: "To be a good historian, it is necessary to be without religion, without country, without profession and without party."
Both epigraphs make sense in view of Mr. Draper's background. The author of books on topics ranging from Communism and the cold war to black nationalism and the Iran-contra affair, Mr. Draper has always been concerned with the ways revolutionary ideals are betrayed and constitutional principles violated. After his own break with Communism in the 1930's, he resolved never to allow his thinking to be determined by ideological commitments or party affiliations. And in keeping with Thucydides, Mr. Draper is less interested in justifying the Revolution than in explaining it, examining ultimate causes and conditions that go deeper than immediate quarrels and grievances.
His narrative begins with the end of the French and Indian War in 1763, the moment at which the British, having eliminated the French menace in North America, asked the colonists to pay for their share of the war effort and for the upkeep of the imperial system in general. The colonists, now bold and recalcitrant, protested, and Britain withdrew the Stamp Act and other measures designed to raise revenue and regulate trade, including smuggling. Subsequent measures were enacted, and once again, in the face of colonial protests, Britain resorted to vacillation and revocation.
This infirmness of policy, Mr. Draper argues, revealed a deeper theoretical incoherence at the foundation of the empire. It has been said that the Colonies were founded in "a fit of absent-mindedness." But Mr. Draper makes clear that while the British mind was present at the creation of the empire, its premises defeated its purposes. The British policy, he astutely observes, asked that the colonists be self-supporting without realizing that such a policy made them less dependent on Britain.
And what of the shibboleth "No taxation without representation"? Colonial leaders themselves, Mr. Draper notes, were uninterested in representation, not only because it was geographically unfeasible but also because representation of the 13 Colonies in Parliament would still be insufficient to give them a significant voice. The real issue was where sovereignty resides, and Mr. Draper shows the colonists invoking John Locke to argue that the consent of the governed resided in the colonial assemblies. Yet even sovereignty, like representation and taxation, turned out to be more shadow than substance. "In the end, the argument over taxation was an argument over power," Mr. Draper writes. "The struggle to deprive Parliament of its power over taxation struck at the heart of British power in the Colonies and spilled over everything else."
Two prevailing interpretations of the Revolution current in American historiography scarcely make their appearance in Mr. Draper's text. Marxist-inclined social historians see a class struggle going on within a war for independence. Mr. Draper finds no evidence that the role of revolutionary leaders, many from the wealthy elites, was challenged from below. That is, the Revolution had little to do with poverty, the advent of democracy and the supposed radicalization of American society.
Nor did it involve republicanism, civic virtue and the cult of the small, ancient polis -- themes that have been pervasive in recent historiography and political philosophy. On the contrary, Mr. Draper says, the colonists remained loyal to the King until the eve of the Revolution, and colonial pamphlet literature hailed America's becoming a "rising empire." The Revolution was made not out of a desire to return to ancient virtue but, in Mr. Draper's words, "in behalf of the future."
To Mr. Draper it was not the Stamp Act but the Declaratory Act that "was the true casus belli of the American Revolution." The colonists agreed to the latter when the former was revoked. Under this act the colonists accepted, at least in theory, Parliament's right to make laws binding on them "in all cases whatsoever." Yet when Parliament then proceeded to pass such laws, the colonists had no choice but, as George III put it, to "submit or triumph." The colonists, in short, were content to remain British subjects as long as they were not subjected to British power.
Mr. Draper's thesis that the American Revolution represented a power struggle is refreshingly iconoclastic as well as original. But in concentrating on geographical and economic circumstances, and on political misperceptions and ironic outcomes, he seems unconcerned with the cultural sources that made America so vigilant and defiant. He does show us Adam Smith and Thomas Paine extolling a land of commercial enterprise; he notes as well that "the theoretical underpinning of colonial ideology" stemmed from Britain itself: "There was no Locke or 'Cato' in France or Spain to inspire its colonists and arm them with convenient arguments against its own rule." But contemporaries like Edmund Burke and John Adams, and later travelers to America like Alexis de Tocqueville and Max Weber, specifically cited religion, especially a "protesting" Protestant-Puritanism, as the key to America's spirit of insubordination -- and this religious dimension is missing in "A Struggle for Power."
Nevertheless, the book excels in its ambition to get to the bottom of a world-historical event that no party or country intended. The text ends with the outbreak of military skirmishes at Concord and Lexington in 1775, and thus it stops short of the Declaration of Independence, which was, after all, an afterthought, not to say a rationalization. America may continue to draw its ringing principles from the Declaration, but for the truths about the Revolution itself, especially the truths that reside in power, one must, as Mr. Draper understands, look earlier. It is for this reason that his brilliant analysis of ideas and events enables us to understand how America came to consciousness of itself and so took control of its own destiny, even if this drive to power came close to disobedience and usurpation.

HEADLINE: The Return of the Liberal

BYLINE: By Michael Lind; Michael Lind, a senior editor of The New Republic, is the author of "The Next American Nation: The New Nationalism and the Fourth American Revolution."

 BODY:

They Only Look Dead
Why Progressives Will Dominate the Next Political Era.
By E. J. Dionne Jr.
352 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $24.
The Republican capture of Congress has convinced many Democrats -- not least President Clinton -- that they can regain power only by adopting much of the conservative agenda. That this conventional wisdom is utterly mistaken is the thesis of E. J. Dionne Jr. in "They Only Look Dead: Why Progressives Will Dominate the Next Political Era." In Mr. Dionne's view, the present, like the late 19th and early 20th centuries, "combines social change with moral crisis, enormous economic opportunity with great economic dislocation and distress," and, now as then, the excesses of laissez-faire capitalism will generate a reaction in favor of progressive reform. His "central assertion is that the United States is on the verge of a second Progressive Era." 
 That his bold prediction cannot be dismissed as mere whistling past the graveyard of liberalism is a tribute to Mr. Dionne's thoroughness as a reporter and rigor as a scholar, qualities manifested in his 1991 book, "Why Americans Hate Politics." Mr. Dionne, a Washington Post columnist, makes a convincing case that the 1994 election was a repudiation of the Democratic Party, not an endorsement of Republican conservatism: the swing voters, in both 1992 and 1994, were "the Anxious Middle," made up largely of "white voters of moderate incomes" who defected from the Democrats without permanently joining the Republicans.
Why is the middle anxious? Mr. Dionne identifies four crises confronting the United States: "the economic crisis itself, a political crisis, a moral crisis and a crisis over how Americans view their country's role in the world." The first crisis is the cost of globalization and automation, enriching the few while endangering the living standards of the majority and increasing inequality. The second involves the abandonment, particularly by the left, of grandiose ideologies like socialism, creating a vacuum filled by particularist movements of "race, gender and culture" or "nationalism, religious fundamentalism and xenophobia." The third pits social conservatives against those who favor "new roles for women" and "a somewhat looser and more tolerant attitude toward sexuality." These economic, political and moral crises are joined by discord on foreign policy, with the division between nationalists and internationalists cutting across both parties.
The response of the political class to these four crises has been evasion and worse, Mr. Dionne writes; increasingly, politicians avoid substantive debate altogether in favor of vicious attack politics. Disgusted with gridlock, in 1992 the Anxious Middle ousted a Republican President and gave the Democrats complete control of the political branches of the Federal Government for the first time in 12 years, offering the Democrats, Mr. Dionne says, a chance to revitalize the progressive tradition -- and they blew it. He acknowledges the obstacles: the fiscal constraints imposed by the budget deficit and volatile capital markets, and Republican obstructionism in Congress. Nevertheless, he blames division and inertia among the Democrats for their failure to give the voters what they were demanding: radical but sensible reform in health care, welfare and campaign finance.
Part of the problem, Mr. Dionne argues, is the incoherence of the Democratic Party, now divided not simply into "New" and "Old" Democrats, but into five distinct groups: "Southern moderates and conservatives; suburban centrists; urban, labor-oriented white liberals; black and Hispanic members . . . (who are also mostly liberals); and a diverse group of Western and Midwestern Democrats from rural areas." On health care and welfare reform, Bill Clinton's attempt to implement his synthesis of neoliberalism and traditional liberalism required a unity that the Democrats lacked. And on the budget, Mr. Dionne reminds us, Mr. Clinton was only capable of "salvaging a one-vote victory." Nor did the Democrats pursue campaign finance reform -- "the precondition of all other serious reform" -- because too many Congressional Democrats were addicted to the corporate money that was to turn against them in 1994.
The Democrats' failure to reinvent the progressive tradition, Mr. Dionne says, provided the Republicans with an opportunity. "Moderate Republicans had hoped in the wake of the Reagan era to ease the party toward acceptance of a kind of Eisenhower conservatism, now exemplified by Colin Powell," he writes, but House Speaker Newt Gingrich and his allies rejected feel-good, pay-later economics, producing a more honest but far harsher and more radical conservatism, one that wants to roll back not just the Great Society but the New Deal too.
As Mr. Dionne sees it, "the new Republican philosophy looks backward to the late 19th century, seeking to revive the radical, unregulated capitalism of the Gilded Age." He quotes Mr. Gingrich asking a group of corporate executives to tell Congress what laws to write: "You tell us how to make this the best place on the planet to invest." But then, as Mr. Dionne notes, "Gingrich had never objected to the influence of money on politics as such," and so was "unembarrassed" when it was disclosed that lobbyists for interests that had been heavy campaign givers "were deeply involved in writing the party's deregulatory legislation."
Democrats should oppose, not emulate, the subordination of government to business, Mr. Dionne declares: "To the extent that Democrats have joined Republicans in delegitimizing government, they have prepared the way for their own crushing defeats." Nor does defending the need for sensible government mean political suicide, he says, because the current political upheaval should be seen "less as a revolt against big government than as a rebellion against bad government -- government that has proven ineffectual in grappling with the political, economic and moral crises that have shaken the country." What is more, Democrats have conservative divisions to exploit: "Many on the cultural right -- as well as many drawn to the far right -- are part of the Anxious Middle in fearing for their living standards and mistrusting the state and the market alike."
Mr. Dionne concludes with his own attempt to restate the progressive credo and the progressive project. "The Progressive's goal is not to strengthen government for government's sake, but to use government where possible to strengthen the institutions of civil society." Progressive welfare reform, he suggests, "would involve work requirements for welfare recipients, in exchange for a decent level of public support and the creation of work where private jobs were lacking." A progressive trade policy would recognize the need "to protect environmental and labor standards," to "level up," not "level down," wages.
"They Only Look Dead" is a luminously intelligent and quietly passionate polemic that deserves to alter the terms of American political debate. It is not without weaknesses. Mr. Dionne hardly discusses immigration and racial preferences, two areas where liberal policies have alienated the Anxious Middle. For that matter, his description of the Anxious Middle lacks nuance, blurring two groups of centrists, the communitarian radical center and the libertarian moderate middle.
Mr. Dionne is persuasive when he predicts that the new Social Darwinism of the Republican Party will produce a backlash by the Anxious Middle. But the Democrats may not be the beneficiaries; indeed, Mr. Dionne's account of their disunity suggests that more than a new party platform is needed. He does warn that if they falter and do not usher in "a new Progressive period . . . the calls for third and fourth parties will grow as the country seeks alternatives to Republican policies premised on the idea that government can almost never do good." But in developing his historical analogy, he neglects to mention that there were three rival forces at the turn of the century: conservatives, progressives and populists. We can only hope that today's Social Darwinists will be checked by the descendants of Theodore Roosevelt and not by the intellectual and political heirs of William Jennings Bryan.

HEADLINE: The Eastern Front

BYLINE: By Orlando Figes; Orlando Figes teaches history at Cambridge University. His new book, "A People's Tragedy: The Russian Revolution, 1891-1924," will be published later this year.

 BODY:

WHEN TITANS CLASHED
How the Red Army Stopped Hitler.
By David M. Glantz and Jonathan M. House.
Illustrated. 414 pp. Lawrence:
University Press of Kansas. $29.95.
On the 50th anniversary of the Normandy invasion of 1944, an American news magazine featured a cover photograph of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower labeled as the man who defeated Hitler. But the Allied victory in World War II was surely not the achievement of a single man -- this was a "people's war" par excellence -- and if any one country could claim to have won it, if only by its share of the fighting, it was the Soviet Union. Eighty percent of the 13 million German military casualties between 1939 and 1945 fell or were captured in the East. Russian Army casualties, now conservatively estimated at 29 million, represented more than three-quarters of all Allied casualties in the war. And that is not counting millions of Soviet civilians who perished as a result of the Nazi occupation of their countries (equivalent to an invasion of the United States from the Atlantic Coast to beyond the Mississippi) or as a result of the Stalinist assault on nationalities assumed to be disloyal to the regime. Lend-lease and D-Day notwithstanding, victory over Germany was bought with Soviet blood. 
 Just how the Russians defeated Hitler's armies defies any straightforward explanation. It is a story of remarkable endurance that, until the recent opening of Soviet archives, had been mainly told from the German point of view. Operation Barbarossa, as the Germans called their invasion of Russia, caught the Soviet forces unprepared. Stalin's terror had deprived the army of half its officers; most of the survivors were too inexperienced or too afraid to reach independent judgments on the battlefield, and they simply followed outdated textbook methods. The army was in the middle of a major restructuring program, hastily trying to learn new tactics and rearm itself with mechanized forces when the Germans attacked in June 1941. In Byelorussia and the Ukraine the mass of the peasants were so alienated from the Soviet regime that many welcomed the invaders. In a matter of weeks Hitler's seemingly invincible armies swept through the panic-ridden Soviet defenses to the gates of Moscow and Leningrad before turning south to attack the strategic industrial city of Stalingrad. But there the Russians made their final stand, fighting for the city street by street, before slowly driving back the Germans to Berlin -- and in the process building up an army that overshadowed Europe for the next 40 years.
What was the key to this extraordinary reverse? In "When Titans Clashed" David M. Glantz, a former director of the United States Army's Foreign Military Studies Office at Fort Leavenworth, Kan., and Jonathan M. House, an associate professor at Gordon College in Georgia, offer a purely military explanation: the gradual emergence from 1942 of a "competent and trusted" officer corps that learned through war and was allowed to develop its own increasingly sophisticated tactics of "mechanized warfare on a massive scale." But this is not enough.
As a military history, "When Titans Clashed" is rather disappointing. It provides a detailed account of all the major battles, often calling time out to analyze the tactics, yet it seldom looks up from the battlefield itself. It is written in a dense and turgid prose interspersed with military jargon and technical terms. Sentences often break down into long lists of armies, corps and brigades. Even the most dramatic moments of the story are lost in the morass. Thus the account of the battle for Berlin begins: "At 0730 hours on 14 April 1945, after a 15- to 20-minute fire raid, reinforced rifle battalions from 1st Byelorussian Front and 1st Ukrainian Front's first-echelon rifle divisions began reconnaissance-in-force actions on main attack axes." It might do to start a lecture at West Point like this but it surely will not do at the climax of a book intended for the general reader.
Unlike John Erickson's superior two-volume history of the Soviet war against Germany, "The Road to Stalingrad" (1979) and "The Road to Berlin" (1983), this book pays very little attention to broader aspects of the Soviet campaign. There is surprisingly little, for example, on Stalin's tortuous relationship with the generals, or on the effect of his personality cult on the country's morale, although both crucial subjects have been opened up by the new archival evidence. The only place where Stalin really figures is before the June 1941 invasion, when (as has been shown by many other recent studies) he dismissed the reports of his own intelligence about the German buildup on his borders as British disinformation meant to draw Moscow into the war, and tried to appease Hitler by selling him cheap oil.
Nor is there much discussion of the Russian wartime economy, although the authors say that victory would not have been achieved without the huge increase that occurred in the production of weaponry between 1942 and 1944. This rearmament was an extraordinary achievement after the industrial catastrophe of 1941 -- more than 1,500 factories were hastily dismantled and taken east in a few months -- and it says a great deal about the planned economy: it was only good for wartime emergency.
But the unforgivable omission of "When Titans Clashed" is its failure to account for the sheer endurance of the Russian people. Mr. Glantz and Mr. House say that the Soviet Union won because of its almost endless capacity to mobilize new armies, gradually eroding the better German forces by sheer numbers and securing victory at enormous human cost. Yet they never stop to ask what lay behind this capacity: whether the totalitarian power of the state enabled it to call up limitless cannon fodder; whether the people's own patriotism kept them flooding into the army (it is significant that Soviet propaganda stressed loyalty to the motherland rather than the state, and that after a decade of war against religion the regime enlisted the support of the church in its military campaign); or whether it was the people's growing hatred of the German troops and SS units, which enslaved and terrorized Slavs as well as Jews.
It is telling that Mr. Glantz and Mr. House give no more than a sentence to the siege of Leningrad; it was not a battle, so it does not get discussed. Yet this epic story tells us much more about the Russian people, about their capacity to suffer and endure, and about the reasons for their victory, than all the military histories of the war. Let's hope the next one remembers that.

HEADLINE: Seasons of the Patriarch

BYLINE: By Mary Hawthorne; Mary Hawthorne is on the editorial staff of The New Yorker.

 BODY:

CHILDREN OF THE ALLEY
By Naguib Mahfouz.
Translated by Peter Theroux.
448 pp. New York: Doubleday. $24.95.
Naguib Mahfouz completed his masterwork, the Cairo Trilogy, in 1952, the year of the military coup that brought Gamal Abdel Nasser to power and put an end to centuries of foreign domination of Egypt. Set in the years between the two world wars, the novels quietly bring to mesmerizing life the intimate, hidden world of a middle-class Islamic Cairene family presided over by an autocratic patriarch. The entire family is in collision with the changing political and social forces of the world outside. Seven years elapsed before Mr. Mahfouz published another novel, during which time Egypt saw, along with land reform and heavy taxation of the rich, the emergence of the Nasser dictatorship. Then, in 1959, an allegorical novel, "Children of the Alley," appeared serially in a Cairo newspaper. 
 The book marked an abrupt stylistic and thematic departure from the earlier novels; Al Azhar, the ancient Islamic mosque and university in Egypt, judged it to be heretical and promptly banned it. Thereafter, Mr. Mahfouz returned to his subject of contemporary Egyptian life and its relation to eternal existential questions, going on to publish some 30-odd additional books without incident. "Children of the Alley" was all but forgotten by the world until l988, when he received the Nobel Prize in Literature (though it was the Cairo Trilogy that had earned him the prize, Muslim fundamentalists saw the award as a conspiracy by the West to discredit Islam). Mr. Mahfouz began receiving death threats, which became more frequent the following year, as the world level of Islamic outrage rose after the publication of Salman Rushdie's novel "The Satanic Verses." A year ago last October, in a puzzlingly clumsy assassination attempt, he was stabbed in the neck with a kitchen knife -- several Islamic militants were put on trial for it -- while on his way to the weekly literary gathering he had attended every Friday for decades.
"Children of the Alley" actually marks the second publication in English of the novel. The first was brought out in 1981, to little notice, by the American University in Cairo Press, under the title "Children of Gebelaawi." Gebelaawi (here Gabalawi) is the vain, forbidding, mercurial and unknowable ancestral patriarch for whom Gabalawi Alley is named. The novel comprises five chapters, all of them named for Gabalawi's descendants, four of whom bear qualified resemblances to biblical or koranic antecedents: Adham suggests Adam; Gabal, Moses; Rifaa, Jesus; and Qassem, Mohammed. The fifth character, Arafa, is less ancient and more ambiguous. If one views the book as a chronology (the narrator tells us that he has set down the stories of the alley's descendants "in the right order"), Arafa suggests not so much a prophet as modern man: cynical, faithless, anxious and uncertain of his identity, he holds the secret to more power than he is capable of handling -- he has learned to concoct lethal chemical cocktails.
The book opens with Gabalawi and his children all peacefully residing at the mansion he has built in an oasis in the middle of a barren desert. Palm trees flanked by bowers of henna and jasmine peek out over the high walls that enclose the mansion and its verdant garden. One day Gabalawi announces that he has chosen Adham, one of his younger sons, to manage his estate. Idris, the eldest, rises up in indignation at this insult, and Gabalawi banishes him. Adham performs dutifully in the estate office, just outside the mansion's main gate, until Idris surreptitiously arrives and tempts him to steal into a locked chamber off Gabalawi's bedroom, where the estate documents are kept, and learn the secrets of their inheritance. Adham, abetted by his wife, succumbs to his longing to peer into the Pandora's box, not realizing his brother's duplicity until it's too late: Gabalawi catches him out, and he too is banished to the desert. The couple go on to raise two sons, one of whom accidentally slays the other in an argument, and they spend their remaining days in misery. On his deathbed, however, Adham receives a promise from Gabalawi that Adham's children will inherit the estate. Their surviving son, having left his parents' home years earlier, returns with his wife, the daughter of Idris, and their children. From them are descended all the people of the alley.
For a time, with the income from the estate, the alley flourishes. Eventually, however, the mansion closes its gates to all but Gabalawi and his closest servants, and the last of his offspring becomes the overseer of the estate. But even he soon succumbs to greed and begins helping himself to estate funds, and before long only some gangsters and the overseer, who pays them for his protection, live in comfort and luxury. The rest, hopeless and powerless, live in appalling squalor and terror, governed by the truncheons of the gangsters. Gabal is the first of Gabalawi's descendants to receive his message that the residents of the alley have equal right to the estate, and he leads the first successful uprising against corruption and mob rule. A period of universal prosperity returns, but, sadly, as the narrator tells us at the end of Gabal's chapter, "Good examples would not be wasted on our alley were it not afflicted with forgetfulness." It is not long before the cycle of abuse resumes, interrupted only by the occasional interventions of one of Gabalawi's descendants.
It is possible to see why "Children of the Alley," narrowly read, might be held blasphemous according to the tenets of Islam. But it's equally possible to believe that Mr. Mahfouz, as he claims, did not intend to write a heretical book. He holds religion and the perversity of Gabalawi up to harsh light, but religion is only one element of a larger critique of an entrenched patriarchial authoritarianism that extends from the familial to the political. The book also makes for astonishing (and alarming) prophecy: Egypt today has a population of nearly 60 million people, living on 5 percent of the land. It receives lavish amounts of foreign aid and yet its per capita G.N.P. is $800 a year; wealth is consolidated in the hands of a few. "Most of our social occasions call for storytelling," the narrator tells us at the outset of the novel. "Whenever someone is depressed, suffering or humiliated, he points to the mansion at the top of the alley at the end opening out to the desert, and says sadly, 'That is our ancestor's house, we are all his children, and we have a right to his property. Why are we starving? What have we done?' "

HEADLINE: BOOKEND;
Brave Little Books Conquer Italy

BYLINE: By Celestine Bohlen; Celestine Bohlen is the Rome bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: Rome

 BODY:
A mini-revolution has swept through Italy's book publishing industry in recent years, and it has even produced a small miracle: paperback sales are up and prices of all kinds of books are down, thanks to an explosion of little books costing, in many cases, less than a daily newspaper. Some say it began with Epicurus, the third-century B.C. Greek, a collection of whose aphorisms swept Italy in 1992, selling a million copies at a time when paperbacks on average sold 20,000 copies.
Known generically as mille lire books because most of them cost 1,000 lire (roughly 65 cents), the new arrivals -- some slim, some squat, but all small and cheap -- have made such a big noise on the Italian market that they now account for 25 percent of total paperback sales and are credited with an almost 30 percent drop in prices on all books, including textbooks, children's books and hardbacks. 
 Giuliano Vigini, editor of Editrice Bibliografica, the bible of Italian publishers, says that although the mille lire phenomenon has peaked, it has left its mark. "It was not just a revolution of prices, but of communication, a psychological revolution," he adds.
Small books at cheap prices -- typically reprints of literary classics whose copyrights expired long ago -- have popped up elsewhere: in Britain, Penguin celebrated its 60th year with 60 titles priced at 60 pence. The same publisher has an American line, at 95 cents. France and Spain have also seen small books cut a wide swath through their markets. But Italy is where the little book has had its biggest impact, and where it is still evolving, moving beyond predictable lists of classics toward a more daring world that offers new authors, wacky themes, useful dictionaries and academic treatises on subjects ranging from the history of Buddhism to Roman ruins.
Because books in Italian have few natural foreign markets, unlike books in English or French, the 1,000-lire book had a detonating effect. The drop in book prices -- which before were considerably higher than in the United States -- has forced major publishing houses to turn to new outlets and new promotion techniques, as well as to turn out cheaper books of their own.
But the main impact has been on readers, who, as it turns out, buy more books when they are cheaper. "People became accustomed to buying books and they continue to want more," says Mr. Vigini. "The more they consume, they more they want." A telling footnote has been the rush of sales in the south of Italy, which traditionally accounted for 13 percent of paperback sales nationwide, and now accounts for 37 percent of the 1,000-lire book sales.
Two small publishers can claim credit for the 1,000-lire book, which made its formal debut in 1992. The more revolutionary was Stampa Alternativa, a company with roots in the counterculture of the 1960's, which found in the 1990's that its recent line of elegant, expensive and eclectic art books -- adopted after books on marijuana growing and children's rights went out of vogue -- was also a losing proposition.
"We had decided to close shop," says Marcello Baraghini, publisher of Stampa Alternativa, who briefly worked as a shepherd while prosecutors took him to court for the marijuana book. "As a symbolic gesture, I thought I would put out a free book, as my swan song."
Instead, Stampa Alternativa came out with the little book of Epicurus' aphorisms, which, while not free, cost next to nothing -- 1,000 lire to be exact, 500 lire less than a newspaper. The book, which got a plug on a popular television program, became an overnight sensation. One man even wrote to Mr. Baraghini to say he had distributed a hundred copies at his wife's funeral.
From Epicurus, Stampa Alternativa went on to a book about a Samoan islander's trip to Europe (300,000 copies) and from there to a steady stream of offbeat mini-books -- pamphlets really -- on subjects ranging from graffiti found in Italian university bathrooms, to the messages left by Italian voters on invalidated ballots, to a book by children for children.
In that first year of the l,000-lire book craze, Stampa Alternativa -- which in 1992 saw its profits more than quadruple -- had only one rival, Newton Compton, a small publishing house founded in 1968 under a name that was meant to combine a fad for things English with an allusion to things scientific.
Newton Compton had been the first to experiment with super-economici -- supercheap -- books in 1988, when it reissued Freud's "Interpretation of Dreams" at a price equivalent to $3.50, and sold 350,000 copies. Within four years, Newton Compton had issued 200 titles at super-economici prices, selling a staggering 10 million copies.
"We too were surprised by the success," says Newton Compton's president, Vittorio Avanzini. The success was due not only to low prices but also to a distribution breakthrough. "We had to win over the indifference of the bookstores, which were concerned about their return on low-cost books, but we also rediscovered the newsstands and supermarkets," he says.
Newton Compton had an early fling with 900-lire books, none of which exceeded 100 pages. But in 1992, it too joined the mille lire stream, with, among other old favorites, Dante's "Divine Comedy," which for 1,000 lire could be had unabridged, printed in flea-sized print, jammed into 98 pages; it sold 750,000 copies. From there, Newton Compton moved through a list of classic titles, Italian and other, to a detective series, a science fiction series and an authoritative collection on Rome's historical sights.
With a series entitled "Il Sapere" ("Knowledge"), Newton Compton broke new ground, offering readers a tantalizing array of 200-page books, specially written for the 1,000-lire audience. These include a history of the Middle Ages, a dictionary of movie titles, a dictionary of difficult Italian words (for Italian speakers), a history of Futurism and one of Italian Fascism. Sales have been mixed, with a biography of Mussolini at the head of the list with 115,000 copies.
Sales aside, the "Il Sapere" series has had "an incredible resonance," according to Mr. Avanzini, who says several of his historical books are now required reading at universities. Academic authors, who forfeit copyright on the 1,000-lire books, feel compensated by seeing their works widely circulated. "They are thrilled because for the first time they get phone calls from all over Italy," he says.
Three years after it began, the boom in mille lire books is now subsiding, in large part because major Italian publishers, stung into action, have come up with their own cheap books. Mondadori, Italy's largest publishing house, now has its own 5,900-lire (about $3.70) series called Miti Mondadori, which has successfully intercepted the low-cost market, much to the dismay of Mr. Baraghini at Stampa Alternativa.
"Everybody has copied us, but nobody has picked up on the importance of content," he says, noting that he still publishes new works -- an average of two titles a month -- by young authors whose manuscripts arrive by the truckful. "Our books represent a defense of cultural freedom against a market tendency to consumerism. You could say we are the samizdat of the consumerist age."
Stampa Alternativa has already seen a turning of the tide, as its earnings drop back from their 1992 high. Ever on the lookout for fresh ideas, Mr. Baraghini has come up with a new product -- this time a book on hooking up to the Internet, which comes with a package of diskettes, sold in a box shaped like a one-liter milk container, now featured in museum displays as an example of Italian design.
One of the main legacies of the 1,000-lire book is the bolstering of Italy's paperback market, which was traditionally considered a corollary of the publishing industry. Total paperback sales, which came to about $120 million in 1991, reached $165 million in 1994. "This makes it the sector in the industry that has had the greatest percentage increase, bringing it to levels on a par with other countries," says Mr. Vigini, noting that paperback sales now account for 7.1 percent of book sales in Italy, compared with 9 percent in the United States.
In short, says Mr. Vigini, the 1,000-lire book has done its bit for history. "Nothing similar happened in the last 20 years," he says.

HEADLINE: The Ratings Game At the Cineplex

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL 

 BODY:
THE TIME: A RECENT SATURDAY afternoon. The place: the Cross County Multiplex, a 10-screen theater with all-weather carpeting and a video-game nook featuring Tekken 2. The theater happens to be in Yonkers but could just as easily be in Any Burb, U.S.A.
The scene: the time-honored quest of adolescents to buy tickets to an R-rated movie, unaccompanied by a parent or guardian. Sometimes you get in, sometimes you don't. 
 On this day, anxious youngsters were lined up for tickets to "12 Monkeys," an R-rated film in which Bruce Willis is glimpsed naked in a shower and later blows away a thug with a hand gun, and "Sudden Death," which features Jean-Claude Van Damme using a Super Soaker-type squirt gun filled with lighter fluid to torch an enemy. The fact that theaters and movie studios, in their wisdom, hav' decided that adolescents are not old enough to choose to see such scenes gave this crowd not a moment's pause.
"I don't think anybody our age wants to see anything rated under R," said Kevin, a tall, scrawny 16-year-old.
Rafael, a baby-faced boy of 11, added with a shrug, "They show the same things on TV." He and his 14-year-old sister, Jennifer, in braces, were part of a group of seven hoping to see "12 Monkeys." At the ticket window, the oldest members of the group, who were 14 and 15 and did not look a day older, requested the tickets. The clerk asked the ages of the younger children. Jennifer, pointing to heads, said truthfully, "12, 11 and 8." The c'erk sold them the tickets.
So it goes in multiplexes around the country: the ratings, issued with black-and-white clarity and Olympian authority by the Motion Picture Association of America, the trade organization of the major Hollywood studios, are enforced in real life with a great deal of wiggle room. Ratings, which do not have the force of law, are based on a voluntary industry agreement intended to avoid government regulation of film content.
Studios and directors regularly tangle with the Motion Picture Association in noisy controversies over ratings given to specific films. But in the malls of America, where real money is slid through ticket windows, or across the counters of video rental stores, what do the ratings mean in actual practice? Based on interviews with dozens of parents and teen-agers in the New York area and with leaders of national industry trade groups, it seems clear that despite the sanctimoniousness with which ratings are proferred, they do little to prevent young people from seeing inappropriate movies, for several reasons:
* To a teen-ager, an R is not so much a prohibition as a challenge; it rarely stops anyone with a desire to outwit the system.
* To many parents, the more cautionary ratings like R and PG-13 play little role in discouraging them from taking young children to adult-theme films, even those with graphic violence.
* In an era when adult entertainment is no longer confined to movie theaters but saturates the cultural landscape like the weather, young people turned away at the box office often need wait only a few months to rent the movie from a cooperative video store or catch it on cable.
 
How the System Works
Many Ratings, Much Indifference
Young people, of course, have always sneaked into the local Bijou, whether to catch a glimpse of Edward G. Robinson's blazing Tommy gun or the bikinied Bond girls of "Thunderball." But the issue of access to ultra-violent or ultra-salacious fare, from movies to pop music, has become far more important in recent years.
Implicit in discussions of ratings is the notion that society should shield children from images of deadly violence and casual sex because they are likely to breed antisocial behavior. It is an assumption endorsed by a majority of Americans in polls and a theme beloved by politicans from conservat've Republicans to President Clinton. It will undoubtedly be raised anew this campaign season, fueled by studies like one released this month by the cable television industry, which discovered, to the surprise of few, that violence saturates television. The broad telecommunications law just signed by the President requires television manufacturers to include a computer V-chip so parents can block objectionable programs.
MANY SOCIAL SCIENtists say there is a convincing body of evidence that repeated exposure of children to screen violence will encourage, if not cause, real-life violence. But Hollywood disputes this conclusion, no doubt because of the implied consequences. It has no desire to see government restrictions on film content.
"We're not talking about Newtonian laws here," said Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association. "It's very, very murky. None of the studies has been able to pinpoint a causal link between watching an action picture and becoming a murderer or a rapist the way you can track that your lungs will become blackened if you smoke cigarettes.
"People get frustrated because of what they think are violent streets and want a quick fix. You can darken every theater in America or cut the wires of every television set, and you'll do zero to restore the moral center."
There is no legal penalty incurred by teen-agers, parents or theater owners who ignore the ratings, which Mr. Valenti had a major hand in conceiving 27 years ago. Nonetheless, most theater owners say they support and enforce them.
In response to questions about the subject, National Amusements, the owner of the Yonkers multiplex, where unescorted minors seemed to have no trouble buying tickets to "12 Monkeys," the company said in a prepared statement, "Our employees are specifically instructed to comply with the rating system."
Mary Ann Grasso, executive director of the National Association of Theater Owners, a trade group that represents 65 percent of movie theaters in the United States, said, "I think you'll find in most cases theaters are very stringent in their enforcement of the restrictive ratings like R and NC-17."
That is not, however, what many teen-agers say. They report wide variations in the way the R rating is upheld: Theaters owned by image-conscious national chains, such as Cineplex Odeon and AMC Entertainment, are more restrictive, whereas smaller independent theaters are more lenient.
Lewis, a 14-year-old from Darien, Conn, who like many teen-agers refused to give his full name when talking about skirting the ratings, ticked off a list of his local theaters and their permeability: "State Cinema in Stamford almost always lets you in; the theater in the Stamford mall is pretty strict; Darien Playhouse lets you in."
(Managers for the State Cinema and Darien Playhouse insisted that they did their best to enforce the R rating and said that if unaccompanied minors got in, it was because they found adults in line to buy tickets for them.)
Teen-agers say that older ticket sellers tend to be tougher, but younger ones often look the oth'r way. Moreover, theaters seem to crack down selectively, depending on the content of individual R movies. For a "soft R" like "Four Weddings and a Funeral," which features a smattering of profanity, a theater might check identifications o'ly lightly. But it will turn tough for a "hard R" like Oliver Stone's "Natural Born Killers," one of the most violent movies of recent years.
Few teen-agers, of course, line up to see a movie like "Four Weddings." Instead, they swarm like bees to pictures with a high b'dy count and liberal nudity. "Broken Arrow," an R-rated picture that opened last weekend featuring decapitation by helicopter blade, fiery explosions and over-the-top slug-fests, is the latest must-see among teen-agers.
Because teen-agers are some of the most fanatic movie-goers, crucial to the success of many R-rated action films, one might assume that theaters have an economic stake in turning a blind eye.
"That's a popular notion," Ms. Grasso said, "but it isn't worth sacrificing the system for a couple of bucks."
Faced with a tough ticket clerk, teen-agers can often find adults to buy them tickets. And if all else fails, there is auditorium hopping. "You buy a ticket for 'Toy Story,' " explains Peter, 13, from Rowayton, Conn., "and walk back and pop into 'Showgirls.' "
Ms. Grasso did not dispute any of this. She even added one inconsistency of her own: Theater owners in the South tend to enforce the R rating more toughly than those in other regions. "I know, and I'm not going to lie, that kids get into R-rated films all the time," she said. "It's a rite of passage. When I was 14, that was my goal, and I think that's probably still the case."
When they so desire, theater owners are capable of rigidly controlling admission, as was demonstrated last year with the release of "Showgirls," a marathon of Las Vegas nudity, whose NC-17 rating meant that no one under 17 was allowed. Many multiplexes posted extra ushers at auditorium entrances to prevent movie-hopping. "We were very strict about checking ID's and told people before they got in line they would have to present ID's," said Marc Pascucci, a vice president of Sony Theaters, which manages about 850 screens nationwide.
 
How It Was
From the Code To NC-17
The National Association of Theater Owners tries to use educational campaigns to convince individual proprietors that it's in their interest to enforce ratings, reminding them of the troubled period before the current system began in 1968. Back then, a patchwork of local rating boards issued conflicting and often prudish restrictions, and owners were sometimes arrested for showing mopies considered indecent in Muncie, Ind., that played without incident in Minneapolis.
In the same era, the studios began to flout their own archaic Production Code, which decreed in straitjacketing detail how to portray sex and violence. Michelangelo Antonioni's "Blow-Up," the first studio film to feature nudity, was denied Production Code approval in 1966 although M.G.M. released it anyway.
Two years later, in part fearing a government crackdown, the M.P.A.A. and the theater owners organization developed the current system, which has evolved into one with five ratings: G (suitable for the youngest viewers), PG (may contain some material unfit for young children), PG-13, (some material may be unfit for pre-teen-agers), R (children under 17 must be escorted by an adult) and NC-17 (no one under 17 admitted). The NC-17 replaced the X rating in 1990 with the intent of removing the X's stigma of pornography, a goal that has been only partly successful.
The studios belonging to the M.P.A.A. may release only rated films, but independent companies may distribute films without ratings.
 
The Video Market
No Ushers For Home Viewing
With the rise of the videocassette industry in the 80's, video retailers also endorsed the ratings. "We take them very seriously," said Bob Finlayson, a spokesman for the Video Software Dealers Association, which represents more than 20,000 stores. His organization sends members a "Pledge to Parents" stating that the store will enforce R and NC-17 restrictions. Some stores ask parents to sign a permission form allowing their children to take out R movies.
But many teen-agers say video stores can be just as permissive as movie theaters. "If you look 10 they'll ask to see your parents, but if you're 13 or 14 they'll let you," said Brendan Mahoney, a 13-year-old from Darien who said he recently rented the R-rated "Johnny Mnemonic" on h's own.
The ratings debate has become immeasurably more complex in the age of video and cable television. Whereas movies shown in theaters were once the primary source of "mature" images, now children who have never been admitted to an R-rated movie have probably seen plenty on a VCR or on cable.
Margie Ryerson, a mother of two teen-age daughters in Orinda, Calif., recalled objecting when her oldest, then a sixth-grader, was invited to a slumber party where the entertainment was a video of "Pretty Woman."
"I thought no purpose was served in having my pre-adolescent daughter see a movie about a woman who's a hooker and her romantic involvement with someone," Ms. Ryerson said. Even more surprising, she said, was that out of ten 11- and 12-year-olds, her daughter was the only one who hadn't already seen "Pretty Woman."
 
The Parents
They Too Are Offenders
Sometimes parents t'emselves are the problem. A scene common to many movie houses unfolded recently at the Crown Sono Regent in South Norwalk, Conn.: as ticket sellers diligently turned away unescorted 15-year-olds from R movies, a stream of far younger children, many as young as 4 or 5, were led in by adults to the same movies.
According to a study done for the M.M.P.A., 75 percent of parents with children under 17 find the ratings useful. Yet a surprising number of parents say ratings play little ro'e in influencing what films they take children to.
In the popcorn line of the Crown Sono Regent, Angela Grant was waiting with her 6-year-old daughter, Morgan, to see the R-rated "Waiting to Exhale," in which four women discuss in frank detail the sexual ineptitude of men.
"I don't know what this movie's about," Ms. Grant said. "I'll cover her eyes, I guess, where she's not supposed to see."
Ms. Grant's boyfriend, Cleveland Keller, a self-described film buff, said that based on what he had gathered from television advertisements, he did not think the film was inappropriate for a 6-year-old. "I think the direction of the movie is done in great taste," he added.
Just about the only one who thought Angela was too young for "Waiting to Exhale" was her 15-year-old sister, Teka, who had already seen it. "But I'm not her mother," she said.
In the same multiplex, a couple escorting a girl of about 8 found their seats a few minutes into the wildly violent "From Dusk Till Dawn," just as George Clooney executed a lawman with a .44 and a liquor store burst into flames. Later, the rape and murder of a woman, glimpsed tied to a bed with blood spattering the walls, was played for sick humor.
Afterward, the couple with the young girl, Al and Stacey Johnson, did not seem disturbed that their daughter, Ashley, had seen such images. Ashley called the movie "stupid."
To Dr. Victor Strasburger, chief of adolescent medicine at the University of New Mexico Medical School in Albuquerque, exposing children to such films represents "a kind of electronic child abuse."
Dr. Strasburger, the author of the book "Getting Your Kids to Say No in the 90's When You Said Yes in the 60's," added: "I can't tell you how many time I've been tempted to walk up to a family in a movie theater and say: 'Here's 10 bucks. Get a babysitter.' "
