HEADLINE: Signs of an Invigorated Luxury Market in Chicago

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHAROFF 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
The most exclusive block of downtown Chicago's most exclusive street, Lake Shore Drive, is acquiring some new luxury apartments.
The apartments are in two historic buildings, one of which was formerly occupied by the Mayfair Regent Hotel; the other was a rental. The Mayfair, at 181 East Lake Shore Drive, will become a condominium. 
 The rental building, next door at 199 East Lake Shore Drive, is being transformed by John Buck, a developer known primarily for large-scale civic and commercial projects, into the city's first new luxury co-op in many years.
These new developments, the first additions to the drive's stock of luxury housing since the decade began, are viewed as a sign that the lull in the downtown luxury market is ending.
"We had a very good year selling multimillion-dollar properties," Patricia Study, vice president of Rubloff Residential Properties, said of 1995. "The best year since 1985."
Both new projects are almost sold out, even though prices, from $1.25 million to $5 million -- are among the city's highest. Of the 29 apartments at the Mayfair, 21 are under contract. At Mr. Buck's project, 13 of the 14 units, each with 4,500 square feet of space, have been spoken for.
"That's a very high absorption rate at that price level," said James Kinney, president of Rubloff, whose offices on Michigan Avenue overlook East Lake Shore Drive. "Part of it is due to the fact that the high-end market is rebounding and part is because this is a once-in-a-lifetime deal. It's the last chance to get in on something there. This finishes the block. Nothing else will be developed there."
The block, which has been declared a historic district, is in the heart of the city's Gold Coast, a stone's throw from the fashionable Michigan Avenue shopping district. Nancy Reagan, the former First Lady, grew up on East Lake Shore Drive, the stepdaughter of Loyal Davis, a prominent surgeon. Current residents include Jay Pritzker, the billionaire financier, and Eppie Lederer, the advice columnist better known as Ann Landers.
The western end of the block is dominated by the venerable Drake Hotel. The rest is occupied by seven buildings, most of which are co-ops and the newest of which dates from 1929.
The Mayfair project is being developed by Bruce Abrams, whose company, LR Development, has a reputation for innovative residential-renovation projects. Three years ago, the company acquired the former Playboy Mansion -- home to Hugh Hefner in the 60's and 70's -- on nearby State Parkway and converted it into seven condominium units.
The Mayfair was built as an apartment hotel in 1924 and contained more than 200 rooms. Mr. Abrams has gutted the building and is selling apartments ranging from 3,700 to 8,600 square feet. "It will essentially be a modern building in a vintage shell with high-tech, high-efficiency mechanicals," he said. The company offers several floor plans and finishing packages, including duplexes, and buyers can also bring in their own architects. The base package offered by the company costs about $150 a square foot.
Mr. Buck's building was designed in 1915 by Benjamin Marshall, a top residential architect of the period whose name is synonymous with prewar elegance in Chicago. Mr. Buck is selling the existing apartments for $1.25 million each.
New co-ops are a rarity in Chicago. Mr. Buck declined to comment, but people in the real estate community say he opted for a co-op rather than a condominium because he was unable to buy the land underneath the building. He does, however, have an option to buy it from the owner, the Cohen Perlman family trust, at a later date.
Both Mr. Buck and Mr. Abrams plan to live in their respective buildings. Mr. Abrams has hired Gregory DeStefano, an architect at DeStefano & Partners, to design his own apartment.
What do luxury buyers want in a new apartment today? "The layouts are as open as you can get them and there is far more emphasis on family spaces like kitchens and children's playrooms," Mr. DeStefano said. "It's also less formal and less glitzy than the 80's." Another lifestyle change is the absence of servants' quarters. "Housekeeping has been outsourced today," Mr. DeStefano said. "People have day help."
Mr. DeStefano is also the architect for the Regent, a condominium project Mr. Abrams is developing on property he owns in back of the Mayfair that fronts on Walton Street. The Regent will have 17 units that will be somewhat smaller than the Mayfair's and will sell for $400,000 to $1.075 million. The Regent will be ready for occupancy in June 1997, the Mayfair by next January.
The two projects have dominated the high-end market this year at a time when it has been reviving. According to the Chicago Association of Realtors, sales activity on the Near North Side -- which includes the Gold Coast and Lake Shore Drive -- jumped significantly in 1995, as did prices.
"Back in the 80's before the recession, there were very few sales over a million dollars," said Joan Armstrong, a broker at Koenig & Strey. "That's not true anymore."
When real estate agents talk about the drive, however, they are really talking about a handful of vintage luxury buildings, most of which are co-ops. "Many of these buildings used to have waiting lists and then there was no assurance you'd get past the co-op board," Ms. Study said.
There has been almost no development -- high or low -- on the drive in the last decade. In the 70's and 80's, nearby Michigan Avenue started to come into its own as a luxury residential address with the construction of half a dozen high-rises. The clear winners on Michigan Avenue are 950, 900, Water Tower Place and Olympia Center. All are part of larger mixed-use developments that include stores, offices and hotels.
Still, if given a choice, most people opt for the drive. "When people come in to buy," Ms. Armstrong said, "the first thing they ask for is a view. And in Chicago, a view means one thing: Lake Michigan."
Richard Phelan, a lawyer who moved into Mr. Buck's co-op recently, said: "I feel like I've died and gone to heaven. We're right in the heart of everything: movies, restaurants, shopping. Also, I've paced it off and my office is exactly 1.1 miles from my apartment."
Mr. Phelan, who is 57, exemplifies a growing trend in the Chicago area that is helping a resurgence in the downtown luxury real estate market. After spending 20 years in the suburbs -- first in Evanston, then in Winnetka -- he decided to move back into the city.
"My wife died and I remarried and my kids are all out of the house," he said. "I just decided it was time to move on."
He is not the only one. "The whole suburban-flight issue is being reversed with older couples," Mr. Kinney said. "We find a lot of people moving back because they like all the amenities."

HEADLINE: Habitats/East Side, West Side?;
A Newlywed Solution

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
SOME people are dog people. Some people are cat people. Some people are East Side people. Some are West Side people.
Kathryn McCormack, 26, is a West Side person. Her new husband, Christopher McCormack, also 26, used to be an East Side person. 
 "I tried to keep our horizons open," said Mrs. McCormack, an economist who works as a researcher in a securities firm. "But he lived on the East Side and I hated going there. I hated everything about it. I hated the restaurants, I hated the stores."
"She was a real trouper about it, though," interrupted Mr. McCormack, who specializes in mortgage-backed securities, worried, perhaps, that his wife of two months sounded too vehement. "We looked all over."
First, Mr. McCormack went on a treasure hunt; he called various banks -- Apple Bank, Citibank and Chemical were three -- asking for their lists of foreclosure sales. "Just open up the Yellow Pages and pick a bank," he explained.
"We didn't want to be the typical couple spending $1,500 a month for rent," he continued. They looked at apartments that other couples had paid $150,000 to $175,000 for in the height of the market, and now had a child and wanted to move but couldn't sell for anywhere near that amount. "Some of these people were up to lose $50,000," he said. "I didn't want that to be us."
They found a spacious one bedroom in a doorman building on Gramercy Park. The apartment was "dark, dark, dark," but it had potential, he said. The price was, incredibly, $40,000.
The couple bid $35,000; another couple bid less, but they offered all cash, and the other couple got it.
"It was our first big mistake," Mr. McCormack said. "We went right to Citibank and paid them $150 and were pre-approved for a mortgage." The pre-approval gave the couple a three-month window to find a place; after that, they said, they'd pay another $150 to extend it.
In the meantime, the couple widened their search to include, as they delicately put it, "places in need of repair." One was on York Avenue. "I don't know if you could call it a wreck," Mrs. McCormack said, dubiously. "I mean, there were people living in it." She paused. "Sort of."
One Sunday, they saw the advertisement they'd been waiting for: "West End Avenue; needs to be completely redone; partial river views. Asking $120,000."
The ad did not lie; you can glimpse the Hudson from the double window in the master bedroom -- and, judging from the photograph, the one-bedroom apartment, near the corner of 91st Street, certainly did need to be completely redone. Huge slabs of paint hung off the water-damaged ceilings in all the rooms.
The McCormacks bought the apartment from a 101-year-old woman. Young as they are, the couple were tough negotiators, and worked with Richard Grossman, vice president of Heron Ltd. They paid $93,500.
They put about $6,000 worth of work into it -- plastering and repainting and a new $2,500 kitchen with cabinets from one of the huge home improvement chains, and, to their surprise, the apartment was appraised for $167,000.
"We don't want to sell it or anything," said the effervescent Mr. McCormack, who pointed out that the apartment's monthly costs -- $715 for maintenance and $529 for mortgage payments are still less than the cost of the renting the same apartment in today's heated rental market. "But it's nice to know we made a good investment."
"And," she said, in her shy, but determined fashion, "we did get to live on the West Side after all."

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: February 18, 1996

SECTION: Section 6; Page 42; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3525 words

HEADLINE: CHINA: OPPORTUNITY ... OR TRAP?;
Tricks of the Peanut Butter Trade

BYLINE: By Seth Faison; Seth Faison is The Times's Shanghai bureau chief.

 BODY:
Less than 100 yards from the peanut butter factory he has traveled across China to see, Michael McCune is stuck. His car has come to a halt in a narrow, muddy alley lined with old wooden shacks that look as if they've been there for centuries. McCune, a hulking 25-year-old American with a John Travolta dimple on his chin, cranes his neck to look for the factory gate. But the passageway is barely 10 feet wide and his view is blocked by a cart that has stopped to unload its wares -- an extensive collection of broken machine parts -- one by one. Hard to tell how long this chore will take; time moves slowly in rural China.
McCune is cheerful on this chilly January morning, despite his inability to find any caffeine, and climbs out of the car to look around. As a consultant, McCune often ventures through China's hinterlands in search of information that will help American companies sell their products, and he has a favorite game for passing time: he tries to buy a can of Coke. 
 In this dusty brown town called Hong An, 500 miles inland from Shanghai in Hubei Province, his chances don't seem very promising. Glancing up and down the tiny lane, McCune sees one shack offering slabs of raw beef that hang on hooks in the open air. Another proffers unwashed cabbage and carrots on a dilapidated table. A third has a simple glass counter displaying an assortment of crackers, cheap-looking candy and two rows of bottled drinks.
McCune steps through the doorless entry of the candy shack and sets his gaze on the young woman behind the counter, who is wearing a filthy smock. He smiles a broad smile and raises his eyebrows expectantly.
"Do you have Coke?" he asks. The woman does not answer and stares back blankly. It's hard to tell whether she cannot understand McCune's accent or cannot believe that a foreigner -- "big nose" in local parlance -- can even speak Chinese.
"Do you have Coke?" McCune asks again. Silence still. A second woman, wearing a pea green Mao jacket and combing her waist-length hair, steps forward.
"No," she says firmly. "We have Pepsi."
Western goods seem to be seeping into even the most rural parts of China, as though floating on an inevitable tide of modernization. But the process is far from effortless. Even if Coke is outselling Pepsi in China, both have to fight hard to carve paths into the vast and forbidding territory of the Chinese market.
Western businessmen have been salivating at the notion of access to China's masses for more than 100 years. The phrase "If everybody bought one . . . " has been as infectious as it is far-fetched. Even if someone could magically create a product that all 1.2 billion Chinese consumers wanted to buy, how could every Chinese possibly afford it?
Poverty infests the tumbledown villages dotting the countryside, where most ordinary people still live. And between urban corners where commerce has begun to thrive, connecting roads and distribution networks are still so primitive that the overall market remains badly fragmented. Most consumer goods are made and sold locally -- there are about 400 brands of cigarettes, most of them sold only where they are manufactured -- and logistical obstacles make it difficult to market anything nationwide.
Yet, as Pepsi knows, it can be done. It just isn't easy. Pepsi had to set up an intricate, connect-the-dots route to get its soda from a bottling plant in Shanghai to that candy shack, alternating between inefficient state-owned truckers and unreliable local start-ups. As McCune will tell you, it is essential to figure out not only what will sell here but also how to get it somewhere it can be sold.
WHEN MCCUNE CAME TO CHINA IN early 1993, he worked in the commercial section of the United States Consulate in Shanghai and recognized an opportunity. He heard one American executive after another complain about the bureaucratic headaches and practical difficulties of getting their goods to market and saw the need for a business to address those problems head-on. Late the following year he and two like-minded young Americans set up a consulting company in Shanghai called China Link.
"Everybody's dying concern is distribution," says Ira Bloom, one of McCune's partners. "As soon as we say 'distribution,' everyone is willing to talk to us."
China Link, founded on a shoestring, is small: it has only eight steady clients and grossed a just-scraping-by $120,000 last year. But McCune and his partners have already had some success: one client has carved a huge portion of the Shanghai ice cream market away from Unilever, the British-Dutch consumer products giant. Another client, a major American food products company (which has requested anonymity), has hired them to research market conditions and investment possibilities. Coke is not a client; McCune does his recreational research on the company, he says, because it's his favorite drink.
Over the past five years the number of consultants on business in China has grown almost as fast as the economy. China Link is a rarity in that it is specifically geared to advise on how to bring consumer products to market, and that seems to be a business in which demand can only increase.
Markets are changing so fast, and are still so poorly coordinated, that the only way to get reliable market research is to constantly canvass stores, distributors and factories in person. Which is what McCune does, sometimes on a specific assignment from a client, sometimes just to keep abreast of market trends. China Link's brochure points out that it can also help clients obtain licenses and customs clearance, yet its primary focus is on figuring out how to deliver goods and get them prominently positioned on a store shelf. That's the idea, anyway. Reality can be a little more slapdash.
As Bloom, 27, sits in the China Link office, explaining the business to me, McCune busts in with a large tub of ice cream in each arm.
"What's going on?" Bloom asks.
"Gotta put these in our fridge for now," McCune says over his shoulder as he heads to the kitchen.
It turns out that the ice-cream-making client, the Taiwanese-owned Fuller Foodstuffs Company, shut down production in Shanghai for a few days to clean its machinery but forgot to warn regular customers, including a restaurant that depends on a daily supply. Bloom and McCune arranged to buy ice cream elsewhere and deliver it themselves, so the restaurant wouldn't be tempted to switch suppliers.
Common sense and flexibility are essential in any business, but a remarkable number of American executives lose their heads when they come to China, both seduced and daunted by the wonder of being in what the Chinese like to call the Middle Kingdom. The more banquets with senior officials, McCune calculates, the less cost-efficient you are.
"It's the market you have to keep your eyes on," McCune says. "Rather than send a team to Beijing and set up a fancy office, you'd usually be better off sending a couple of young guys to figure out how to sell."
"Young guys" often figure in McCune's recipe for what an American company needs in China. Part of it may be Generation X hubris, a belief that young men like himself can always do it better. But part of it is the recognition that working in China -- where the unexpected delay or unannounced tax man always lurks around a corner -- does not demand brainy analysis or finesse; it requires hustle and common sense.
Sometimes that means a "guerrilla visit" to a store, which entails McCune's ignoring the store manager, who would sit him down for tea and an hour of meaningless chitchat, and talking instead to clerks and customers about what is selling and why.
McCune looks as comfortable as a regular customer as he breezes into the Shanghai Number Two Foodstuffs Store, a poorly lighted supermarket in downtown Shanghai. As a 6-foot-5 white guy who towers over most shoppers, he can't fail to turn some heads.
Narrow aisles are packed with haphazardly arranged domestic and imported goods, many with the dull colors of cheap packaging, though a few have flashy, eye-catching blues and reds. Pringles chips are clearly visible on one shelf, Quaker Oats oatmeal can be seen on the next. McCune starts quizzing a clerk about jam sales. The clerk seems surprised that anyone would ask her opinion on anything and ignores a sizable crowd of customers to talk to McCune.
McCune scribbles notes as the clerk explains why a particular brand -- made by one of McCune's clients -- is getting so much less shelf space than a competitor. "The other brand has more flavors available," she says.
McCune is irritated that so few of his client's available flavors are making it from the factory to the store. "What the manufacturer is telling the distributor is obviously not getting to the retailer," he says.
Passing another counter, McCune sees bottles of Coke and Pepsi next to one another. He cannot resist asking about them.
"Coke is selling much better than Pepsi," the clerk volunteers. "Pepsi is a little bit sweeter, and Chinese don't like things too sweet. I think Pepsi must sell better than Coke in America, right?"
A FEW MONTHS AGO, MCCUNE FOUND Happy Word peanut butter on the shelf of a Shanghai supermarket; store clerks and distributors told him it is one of China's best-selling brands. McCune dialed the Hong An telephone number printed on the label and invited himself for a visit. His major American client wants to know about peanut butter.
Venturing far from Shanghai to research successful Chinese companies to see if they are prospective investments or competitors with secrets to reveal can often be a wild goose chase. A common way for American companies to invest in China is through a joint venture in which a local and foreign partner share ownership and management. Here lie the main obstacles of working in China: though stubborn bureaucrats and sleazy businessmen get in the way, what makes the day so long is old habits, poverty, a simple lack of information and sorting through disorganization.
But every such journey into rural China is full of the unexpected and is thus an education in itself. During the drive to the peanut butter factory in Hong An, McCune looks out past the rutted single-lane road that winds through vast patches of brown, untended land. Along the roadside are stacks of hay as enormous as sleeping elephants. A pack of about 50 poorly dressed young men stand in the early-morning darkness at the intersection of a dirt road, apparently hoping to be hired as day laborers by an unknown employer who has yet to make an appearance.
In Hong An, McCune finally gets past the stalled cart in the muddy lane and reaches the peanut butter factory. The first signs are not good. Passing a collection of unpainted old buildings so dark they almost look abandoned, McCune enters a meeting room with a bare concrete floor, a wooden table and, inexplicably, a rusting sink in the corner. All the lights are out.
"Blackout," says the factory director, Li Nengsheng, as if he loses electricity every other day. Yet as he realizes how bad that must sound to a potential investor, Li adds: "We don't have any electricity problems. This happens very rarely."
"And no heat?" McCune asks.
"We don't need heat," Li says, holding out his hands as if to enjoy the warmth in the air. It's about 45 degrees.
Li, 38, has more the air of a bureaucrat than a businessman. He wears a black leather jacket over his maroon sweater, white shirt and tie, and the tight collar on his blue long underwear peeks conspicuously above his shirt collar.
McCune has a long list of questions. Li answers some -- the factory has 307 employees, pays most of them less than $100 a month, grossed about $6 million last year -- and ignores others.
Before long it is clear that the Happy Word peanut butter factory is not a place McCune would recommend as a partner. It has a dilapidated plant, is not particularly sanitary and, like even the most successful state-owned companies, is burdened with the cost of housing and educating its employees and retirees and their families. But it is Li's success in distributing from his rural base to several Chinese cities that piques McCune's interest. Although Li is evasive about details, McCune learns that the factory has salesmen in every major Chinese city.
It is time for lunch and -- whether he is meeting with a potential partner or competitor -- simple politeness requires that McCune accept the invitation. He is asked to wait in the meeting room while the meal is prepared. One of Li's assistants, Zheng Taizong, whose navy blue pants have a Chicago Bulls logo printed on the seat, sidles up to ask a question that seems to have been nagging at him: "Do you think China should be capitalist or Communist?"
McCune thinks for a long while, hesitates, then finally says: "That's not the issue. China's problem is that it's still run on a system of men, not law. It's not a problem of socialism or capitalism. If you ask me, of course, I prefer capitalism, but that's not the most important thing for China now."
Zheng nods thoughtfully. Which system does he prefer?
"Socialism. I still think we should take care of the unemployed and the elderly."
After a momentary silence Zheng leaves the room. Whether McCune likes it or not, his presence represents an advocacy of market economics and capitalism. These days most Chinese managers do not want to talk ideology; those who do often sing about the benefits of capitalism to a visiting foreign businessman and about the wisdom of socialism to a visiting Communist Party chief. But Zheng's comment is a reminder that the once-dominant issue of ideology, while it seems to have disappeared among entrepreneurs in Shanghai, still lurks within the party structure that stretches from the top in Beijing down to the state-run peanut butter factory in Hong An. That doesn't make cooperation impossible, but does effectively limit it: Li and Zheng want foreign investment, but they are not going to be on the same wavelength as any foreign partner.
The wait for lunch in the unheated meeting room becomes a long one. McCune is relieved when Li finally shows him to a simple room with folding chairs and a small wooden table where some vegetable dishes are served.
"I hope we don't get crickets," McCune mumbles in English as he takes a seat.
Something equally unexpected, it turns out, is on its way. A short cook in a white smock carries out a steaming plate of stew, a meat dish with spinach and potatoes in it, and McCune looks at it carefully.
With a proud smile, Li asks, "Do you like dog?"
McCune freezes, his chopsticks in midair. It takes a moment before he regains his composure and politely tries the dish, which tastes a bit tough, not unlike scrawny beef.
When the cook re-enters, carrying another vegetable dish, McCune cannot resist asking how fresh the meat is.
"We just killed it 15 minutes ago," the cook says cheerfully. "Went out to market, brought the dog back and killed it."
Lunch was delayed, McCune now realizes, so that the cooks could obtain, slaughter and prepare the dog as a special treat for him. He is silent. As if on cue, a dog suddenly howls in the distance, too far away to tell if it, too, is being sold at market.
Li looks over between mouthfuls. "You're a little sensitive about eating dog, eh?"
"It makes me think about my own dog waiting at home in Shanghai," McCune says, slightly embarrassed.
MCCUNE AND BLOOM LIVE AND WORK on one floor of a three-story house in an old section of Shanghai where their dog, Foster, is better known among the neighbors than any human; their house is like one you'd find on a college campus. Late Sunday morning a dozen mostly American, mostly businessman friends gather for brunch, followed by a game of touch football.
Bloom cooks eggs and French toast while McCune and the others watch a videotape of "Seinfeld" sent from New York, where their other partner, Jason Foster, 25, handles the American side of the business.
For McCune and Bloom, China is not just another posting, as it is for many American executives who endure two or three years here before moving on to a more comfortable setting; it is a proving ground. China has become something of an obsession for them, a puzzle that never runs out of new pieces.
But first things first. McCune and Bloom are hoping to make their first million by the turn of the century. China Link appears to be ready to ride the wave of American consumer goods sales that is likely to grow steadily for years, but McCune recognizes that the environment is still deeply unpredictable.
"Maybe we'll do great, and after 10 years I'll go back home and start a new career," he says on the way to Hong An. "Maybe this will all flop."
Later, talking to Bloom in Shanghai, he seems more sanguine about China Link's prospects: "We're either going to get rich or we're going to get bought out." The three partners expect to plow all their profits back into the company for the next few years.
McCune grew up in Oakland, Calif., wanting to be a space-shuttle engineer. At the University of Michigan, however, he found classes in Chinese studies more intriguing than physics. After that the path was clear. He arrived in Shanghai -- looking for an adventure, ready for a career -- and landed his job at the consulate on his second day here. It was perfect training.
"I remember, some guy came in, laid out his plans and asked me what I thought," McCune says. "I said, 'Based on all the knowledge I have after exactly two days in China, it sounds great.' But after listening to 10 of those guys, I had an idea of what they needed. After listening to 100, I had a very good idea."
He says that he is fortunate to have found two American partners with a similar vision and that they work unusually well together, even if their day-to-day decision making amounts to a continuous argument.
Bloom was handling distribution for an American leather-goods company in Shanghai when he met McCune; Foster was the project manager for a medical provider in Beijing. "We balance each other out," Bloom says. "Mike is the most visionary and most marketable. Jason is the workhorse. I'm the nuts-and-bolts guy."
Most marketable, indeed. McCune is an unrepentant schmoozer. He sometimes seems unable to stop talking and has the confidence to start a conversation with a stranger about virtually anything. It helps that he speaks what the Chinese like to call "a mouthful of fluent Chinese," itself a cause for wonderment among most Chinese people he meets.
In Hong An, McCune notices a young woman with long, straight hair standing nearby.
Within a couple of minutes, McCune ascertains that her name is Shi Yaqiong and that she is 18, works for the local Agricultural Machine Bureau, spends a half-hour commuting each way, is bored with her job, does not drink alcohol, likes movies, lives with her parents and never goes to discos.
McCune can't resist asking his favorite question.
"Do they have Coke in this town?"
 
Michael McCune's Five Rules for Doing Business in China
 
1. Think small - focus on one region at a time.
China is more like Europe than like the United States - each of its many provinces has different tastes and ways of doing things. Would it make sense to start selling in England, Greece and Germany all at the same time? China's tastes are too varied, and the cost of doing business nationwide is too high.
 
2. Skip the manager, talk to the clerk.
Before meeting with senior officials or executives, know what their underlings are telling them. Store managers will give you the party line; clerks will tell you how the business works.
 
3. Study the side streets.
American executives often get a thrill from seeing upscale stores filled with Chinese consumers. But most Chinese still shop in small stores in back alleys. McCune urges visiting C.E.O.'s to get out of the motorcade and walk down a market street. Sometimes it's dirty, sometimes it smells. "People say, 'Take time to smell the roses,' "McCune jokes. "I say, 'Take time to smell the night soil.' "
 
4. Get the goods to market.
It's not hard to build a factory or to create market demand for a product. "But if you don't connect the two," McCune says, "it's all for naught." A well-known American company making consumer products in southern China planned a major expansion northward last year before it figured out how to transport the goods. When company officials suddenly realized that no one could deliver what they were manufacturing they had to abandon most the expansion, at a significant loss.
 
5. Above all, be flexible.
What works in Baltimore or Bombay may not work in Beijing. In fact, it almost certainly will not. "The people who succeed in China are the ones who create a system that fits the need, not the ones who like to install a system that operated well somewhere else," McCune says. "There are no rules for what works. And there's no guarantee that how it worked 10 years ago or 2 years ago is how it works today. It changes daily."

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: February 18, 1996

SECTION: Section 6; Page 36; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1814 words

HEADLINE: CHINA: APPEASE ... OR CONTAIN?;
Speak Softly, Carry a Veiled Threat

BYLINE: By Fareed Zakaria; Fareed Zakaria is the managing editor of Foreign Affairs. This is his first article for the Magazine.

 BODY:
In Somerset Maugham's novel about novelists, "Cakes and Ale," one of the characters belittles Henry James for having "turned his back on one of the great events of the world's history, the rise of the United States, in order to report tittle-tattle at tea parties in English country houses." Today, as we talk about peace plans in Bosnia, elections in Haiti and hostages in Chechnya, there is a danger of similarly neglecting the defining international political event of this era -- the rise of China to world power.
Great powers are not made every day. The list that most would agree on today -- the United States, Russia, Britain, France, Germany, Japan and China -- would have been nearly the same 100 years ago. (Austria-Hungary is the dropout exception.) China is the new giant on the block. Depending on how you count, China has either the ninth- or the second-largest economy in the world and is growing by about 10 percent annually. Its military budget is the world's fourth-largest and is growing robustly as well. It is home to one of the dominant civilizations of the world, with a diaspora spreading across East Asia and beyond. And in a world with post-modern powers like Germany and Japan -- which could act abroad but don't because of self-doubt -- China is a thoroughly traditional great power. 
 Nicholas Kristof has called China's compound of liberalizing economics and repressive politics "Market Leninism." The phrase captures the two sides of China, but also the two sides of the debate in America about China. Those enamored of the "market" see China's growing economy as a historic opportunity. In the eyes of many businessmen and some scholars, the prize is so rich that everything else should be subordinated to it. Those transfixed by China's "Leninism," in contrast, see a brutal dictatorship that systematically oppresses its people, bullies its neighbors and blithely sells weapons around the world. For these people, China's growing economy is not an opportunity but a danger.
From this starting point, it seems clear that Washington faces a choice between appeasing and containing China. It does not -- yet. If Beijing were basically friendly, we could accommodate its rising influence, as Britain did with America. If it were intrinsically hostile, we could take on the enormous costs of countering its worldwide influence and working to overthrow it, as we did with Hitler's Germany and the Soviet Union. But China lies somewhere between those extremes, and Washington will have to live with it there for a while. As China's future becomes clearer, so should American policy.
Appeasement has had a bad rap since Neville Chamberlain handed over a chunk of Czechoslovakia to Adolf Hitler in 1938. But much of everyday diplomacy is appeasement. It is the accommodation (a nicer word) to realities that you cannot fundamentally change. In the late 19th century the British foreign office even used the word "appeasement" to describe favorably its policy toward the rising power across the Atlantic Ocean.
Negotiations, even one-sided ones, are often an effective way to manage international problems. War is, after all, the most expensive solution. Making this kind of calculation, the Truman and Eisenhower Administrations reluctantly accepted the reality of Soviet domination in Eastern Europe, opting for containment rather than "rollback." The problem with appeasement, however, is that it is sometimes futile and counterproductive, feeding the aggressor's appetite while lulling its neighbors into a false sense of security. Chamberlain's mistake was to apply a policy that worked with the United States to Nazi Germany.
What about China today? Certainly the regime in Beijing has characteristics that make it a difficult partner. The best analogy, though, is not to the Third Reich but to the Second. Like Germany in the late 19th century, China is also growing rapidly but uncertainly into a global system in which it feels it deserves more attention and honor. China's military is a powerful political player, as was the Prussian officer corps. Like Wilhelmine Germany, the Chinese regime is trying to hold onto political power even as it unleashes forces in society that make its control increasingly shaky.
Regimes in transition often make policy erratically, use nationalism as a unifying device and look for support from groups like the military, which then acquire even greater influence. This combination of hubris and insecurity can be difficult to negotiate with. And once Deng Xiaoping dies, China will have no more Bismarck-like statesman with the skill and credibility to keep the balancing act going.
If appeasement won't work, why not containment? It would not work either. The containment of a great power is impossible without sustained support from several important countries. The prospect of such support against China is nonexistent today. The smaller states of East Asia have decided, at least for now, to live with China's hegemony and hope that it is benign. South Korea is too nervous about its worse half and about Japan to take on such a task. Japan is still too jittery about its regional role to try anything so ambitious. Vietnam would be our only taker. That would be like having tried to contain the Soviet Union with Belgium as our only ally.
More important, however, containment is premature. China is simply not Hitler's Germany or Stalin's Soviet Union. It is not a revolutionary, messianic state with an aggressive dictator firmly in power who is bent on spreading his power and ideology abroad. In its foreign relations, China has done little more than rattle its saber in some regional disputes, and -- more worrying -- sell arms and nuclear technology to rogue regimes. The country is clearly in a transitional phase, deciding how to orient itself in the world. Premature containment would help China make that decision.
In coming years, China's ambitions are bound to expand. Additionally, Beijing treats its people with a repressive callousness, which we rightly abhor. This is a recipe for ceaseless argument and conflict with the United States. To avoid sparking crisis after crisis, Washington should ask itself what Chinese actions would threaten its core interests and values. It should warn Beijing -- usually in private but sometimes publicly -- that if these lines are crossed, normal relations would become impossible. By crossing them, China would make strikingly clear to its neighbors that a policy of containment has become necessary and feasible.
Such a policy would aim to create defensive alliances and provide military aid to East Asian states to secure their sovereignty and independence. It would also halt the integration of China in various international institutions and seek to limit Beijing's economic and political influence worldwide. The goal should not be to "defeat" China, as it was with the Soviet Union, but to get Beijing to respect the borders, treaties and norms that make up the current international arrangements.
What Chinese actions would trigger containment? First and foremost, those that threaten the stability of East Asia. This is not simply for balance-of-power reasons. The "Asian miracle" is about politics as well as economics. Economic growth has been followed by political reform in most East Asian countries. If China were to upset the regional balance of power, this enormous economic, political and moral progress would be jeopardized.
We should oppose Chinese attempts to gain influence by destabilizing the status quo in the South China Sea, Korea, Vietnam and Taiwan. On Taiwan, the United States should try to perpetuate the uneasy balance, which has allowed both China and Taiwan to prosper. Washington should make plain to both sides that it would actively oppose attempts to change the status quo unilaterally, whether by invasion or declarations of independence. A Chinese invasion of Taiwan would be utterly self-defeating; much of the investment in mainland China comes from Taiwan. A regime that would do this could not be rationally negotiated with.
If regional aggression would trigger containment, we should also be clear that actions short of this, while earning our public displeasure, would not. Once we have drawn a line in the sand, we must observe both sides of the line. Human rights are important, but we cannot construct a post-cold-war grand strategy around the problems of neglected orphans, brave dissidents and cheap labor. The greatest danger is that the United States will adopt the rhetoric of containment and the reality of appeasement, drawing the line so tightly around China that we continually denounce Beijing without being willing to pay the price to oppose its policies.
Any policy toward China will be costly because it is a great power. We can choose to ignore brutalities in Liberia, but China is one of the most important countries in the world, and the most populous. Its abuse of human rights is qualitatively different, affecting the norms and standards that international society observes (or at least pays lip service to). Thus, the moral cost of doing little in the face of China's repression is high. But it pales beside the staggering economic and political costs of challenging a great power. It took 40 years, a worldwide alliance and trillions of dollars to contain and transform the Soviet regime.
Besides, it might not even be necessary; here again realism and idealism meet. Responding to individual human rights abuses is noble but futile. What causes these abuses is a system of government; when that system changes, only then do the abuses lessen irreversibly. And the regime in Beijing will change. It has no ideology that captivates the world, no legitimacy to secure its rule at home. Nowhere in history has a country grown as fast as China without political and social upheaval. This is the strongest reason to adopt a policy of watching and waiting. In 10 years -- perhaps fewer -- there will be a different regime in Beijing.
Great powers are like divas; they enter and exit the stage with great tumult. While the rise of great powers has usually led to terrible wars, there are other examples. The rises of Britain and the United States took place with less global conflict (though the Central Americans and South Asians may not have noticed the calm). And the rise of Germany and Japan after 1945, albeit inside an American security cocoon, suggest another hopeful trend. These happier stories are admittedly fewer in number. But American policy must try, with sticks and carrots, to help Beijing and its neighbors resist the terrible pull of history and make China a secure and responsible great power, deserving of the respect that it will command. That is a prize worthy of a realistic American foreign policy. All else will prove to be tittle-tattle.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
New Limit on Assessment Appeals Protested

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
AS demands for property tax-reform grow more heated on Long Island, an amendment to the real-property tax law that took effect Jan. 1 will make it even more difficult for overassessed property owners to get relief.
As a result of the new amendment to the tax law, homeowners and commercial property owners who win an assessment reduction in a small-claims court or State Supreme Court will be barred for three years from filing for an additional reduction unless a major change to value -- such as a fire -- occurs. The moratorium also applies to pretrial settlements. 
 On the flip side, assessors also are barred for three years from increasing assessments unless major improvements or other changes affecting value occur. The law applies to all taxing jurisdictions except New York City.
Bernard Hyman, a tax-appeals lawyer at the Certilman Balin Adler & Hyman law firm in East Meadow, said the measure would have a particularly devasting effect on Long Island.
"This effects Long Island particularly because the tax rates here are so high and because assessing procedures in upstate areas are more up-to-date," he said. "Anybody whose property is in a community where values are declining is going to get hurt immediately by the law because they would be entitled to a further reduction, but won't be allowed to protest."
Property owners who feel they are overassessed initially file a protest with their local board of assessment review. The grievance period in Nassau County was in January. In Suffolk County, it will be from May 1 to May 21.
If relief is denied at that level, owners of owner-occupied one-, two- and three-family houses can elect to file petitions in a Small Claims Assessment Review Court. The filing fee is $25 and owners can represent themselves, though they often turn to tax consultants who charge a percentage of the savings.
All other property owners must take their cases to State Supreme Court, which is a far more costly and time-consuming procedure.
But nowtaking an appeal to small-claims court has a major drawback: The rule still prevails in that court that homeowners can receive no more than a 25 percent reduction in any one year, even if they can show that a house is overassessed by much more.
In some areas of Nassau County, which has not revalued properties since 1938, houses are overassessed by 50 percent or more, according to a recent study by the Nassau Citizens Budget Committee. The same inequities occur in some parts of Suffolk County.
State Senator Joseph Holland, a Rockland County Republican who co-sponsored the new amendment with Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester County Democrat, said the law's intent was to stabilize the tax base.
"What we are hoping to do with the legislation is get a fair settlement and leave it there so we can get some kind of stabilization," said Patrick Kehoe, Senator Holland's counsel.
Under the new amendment, tax appeals brought in State Supreme Court must be settled or brought to trial within two years and eight months. The previous limit was four years, which meant that if a petitioner prevailed taxing jurisdictions immediately faced paying a four-year accumulation of refunds plus interest.
These large settlements "often caused horrendous problems for school districts," Senator Holland said. He added that the law was not intended to hurt homeowners. "I had not heard it would have much impact on homeowners," he said. "The 25 percent limit hadn't come to my attention."
I N the past, homeowners who did not get sufficient relief knew they could file again the following year and get another reduction said Paul M. Henry, president of Tax Reduction Services, a Greenport company that files tax protests on behalf of homeowners.
"Now that right has been taken away by the State Legislature, and that's unconscionable," he said. "And if a hearings officer makes a bad decision, this law means we are stuck with it for three years."
James Pardo, who with his wife, Karen, owns a three-bedroom ranch in Glen Cove, said he was lucky that the law was not in effect when he first protested his taxes. Represented by Mr. Henry's Tax Reduction Services in small claims court, the Pardos have had their assessment reduced twice since 1992. Another petition, filed last year, is still pending.
In 1992, the house was assessed for $385,000. The Pardos won a 20 percent reduction to $308,000. In 1994, they filed another petition and the assessment was further reduced to $250,000. The petition still pending asks for additional relief based on a $230,000 appraisal.
"If I hadn't been allowed to refile in 1994 I would have been paying taxes on a house which was assessed for much more than it is actually worth," Mr. Pardo said. "What they are doing now is taking your legal rights away."
Lawyers say the law also will hurt Long Island's economic recovery and will result in even more clogged court calendars because commercial property owners will no longer be as willing to settle cases.
Commercial values fall when income is reduced, and loss of a tenant is grounds for appealing an assessment. Lowered taxes allow the owner to reduce rents and attract new tenants.
"Commercial owners have to remain competitive, and they now will have to get 100 percent of the tax relief they are entitled to," said Laureen L. Harris, chairwoman of the Nassau County Bar Association committee on tax appeals. "Usually, you can compromise and settle out of court because you can go back, but that flexibility is now removed by this law."
Lawyers say that they will continue to file cases as before. "Right now, we are taking the position that this law is unconstitutional," said Mr. Hyman, the East Meadow lawyer. "If the county makes a motion to dismiss, we will appeal and get our day in court."
The Association of Assessment Consultants, an 18-member trade group of companies that, like Tax Reduction Services, represents homeowners in assessment cases, already is preparing a court challenge to the new law.
"This is a due-process issue," said David G.Gabor, a Garden City lawyer who represents the association. "If a municipality places a value on a property, the homeowner must have a right to address that, and the three-year moratorium breaches that right."
E QUAL protection is another constitutional issue, said Donald Leistman, a partner of the Koeppel Martone Leistman & Herman law firm in Mineola. "It gives some the right to review their assessments in a given year, and not others," he said. "This is a bad bill all around."
But Abe Seldin, the chairman of Nassau County's Board of Assessors, said that although he had some concern that out-of-court settlements on commercial properties would now be more difficult to negotiate, "the general thrust of this law is a good one because it eliminates the constant repetition of filing."
In Nassau, 53,439 protests to assessments were filed in 1993, 76,820 were filed in 1994 and about 66,000 were last year.
Mrs. Harris, the tax-appeals committee chairwoman, pointed to what she described as another problem. Under the new law, municipalities now have the option of refunding tax overpayments through credits against future tax payments.
In upstate communities, tax refunds come out of the school district's budget. On Long Island, the 10 Suffolk towns and Nassau County are responsible for paying refunds. The new law now allows them to shift that burden to the school districts. "It will pit municipalities against school districts," Mrs. Harris said.
Senator Holland said that an amendment already has been proposed that would exempt Long Island school districts from that provision of the new law.

HEADLINE: ON THE MAP;
Honoring a President, the Jersey City Way

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

 BODY:
At Lincoln Park in Jersey City, there is an astounding bronze statue of the 16th President, born on Feb. 12, 1809, and fatally shot on April 14, 1865, five days after the Civil War officially ended.
In contrast to the idealized Lincoln in Washington, chiseled by Daniel Chester French with an almost regal bearing and enshrined in grand portico, Jersey City's version is of a mere mortal, and a troubled one at that. This Abraham sits slouching, arms dangling between his knees, his gaze downcast. When it rains, the drops stream down his cheeks. 
 In some ways, the nature of the statue is a reflection of the city itself: troubled by rising taxes and falling property values, high unemployment, and neighborhoods scarred by drugs and violence. It is also a city divided: corporations and young artists and professionals to the east versus the more traditional neighborhoods, industrial sites and blighted areas to the west.
 Dennis Doran, 49, a real estate investor who grew up in this widely diverse city of a quarter-million people, is a member of the Lincoln Association, an institution that dates back six score and 11 years. He spoke before a ceremony at the statue last week.
Q.What's Lincoln's connection to Jersey City?
A.Nothing specific, really; it's just that he was revered by people here. A group of civic leaders and businessmen were appalled by his death, and they resolved to meet every year on his birthday. They began doing that in 1866, and apparently have never missed a year all the way along. So they claim to be the oldest association honoring Lincoln in that manner in the country.
Q.When was the statue erected?
A.The statue was sculpted in 1929 and put up there in 1930. It's called "Seated Lincoln," and it's by James Earle Fraser. He did a lot of public sculptures, but he is most renowned for designing the buffalo nickel.
Q.Can you compare this one to the one in Washington?
A.It's not a very dynamic depiction. The one in Washington is very magisterial. The interesting thing about Lincoln is that he embodies so many different qualities. I mean, he is a very dynamic leader, but he's also a very thoughtful and contemplative guy. It's certainly a more human depiction. I think he looks kind of sad, doesn't he?
Q.About what?
A.Oh, God knows. It was such a blood bath to go through the Civil War. It was a great burden on anybody to be the leader there. And I think it was largely his leadership that brought us through that in one piece, because it very easily could have gone awry.
Q.Why has the association persisted?
A.He's a very inspiring man, a very pivotal figure. Even though he has no direct connection with the people of Jersey City, I think he's inspired the people here.
Q.Is the association's goal simply to preserve his memory?
A.One of the things we've tried to do is stop this trend of reducing everything to the lowest common denominator. Lincoln's Birthday was a big deal, and Washington's Birthday, and then it was all blobbed into Presidents' Day. Well, there are a lot of Presidents, and they're not all equal. So that's been a policy here, to try to restore Lincoln's Birthday to the prominence it once held. And to try to stop the silly caricatures of Lincoln -- you know, you get the white sale in the department store and they have Lincoln wearing all these funny costumes. It's degrading to the guy. And we have written letters and we have been on record regarding the Legislature passing resolutions and things like that. And we bring that to people's attention to keep that stuff to a minimum and to keep him up there on a pedestal. STEVE STRUNSKY

GRAPHIC: Photo: Christopher McGovern reads the Gettysburg Address near Jersey City's contemplative Lincoln. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Coping With the Aftershocks of a Sponsor's Default

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
THAT Friday night five years ago when a van rolled to the curb and half a dozen process servers bearing stacks of 200-page legal papers climbed out still grips the minds of people at the Acropolis, a 16-building co-op near the towers of the Triborough Bridge in Astoria, Queens.
Making their way home from work that crisp March evening, residents of the five-story walkups ringing a slim courtyard on Ditmars Boulevard had no notion that for years those legal papers would hang over their heads, their bank accounts and their sense of security. 
 The Bank of Tokyo, holder of the underlying $25.6-million mortgage on their 617-unit complex, had filed to foreclose -- without warning.
Robert Bass, president of the co-op board, remembers the night the van came, and the nights that followed. "They rang your bell, constantly coming back," Mr. Bass said. "They wanted to make sure they served everybody. My phone was ringing off the wall. People panicked. They thought they would lose their life savings, and be dispossessed on top of it."
They were not alone.
There is no central registry for all the buildings -- and, more poignantly, all the people -- whose financial health was shaken when the bottom dropped out of parts of the co-op market after the boom of the 80's. It was a time when promises went unkept, renters balked at paying for neglected apartments and shareholders stopped paying maintenance; a time when sponsors defaulted and disappeared -- some after pocketing proceeds -- and when banks foreclosed and some buildings even deconverted, leaving residents owing loans and owning nothing.
Now, six years after cracks in the financial underpinnings of many co-op conversions first surfaced,"the vast majority of troubled co-ops have resolved their problems," said Gary Connor, chief of enforcement in the New York State Attorney General's real estate financing bureau. But the financial condition of many co-ops remains, at best, guarded, Mr. Connor said, and new cases regularly arise.
Great pains would be suffered before the Acropolis struggled back to its feet, and its workout would serve as a model for dozens of other troubled co-ops. But residents of 101 Lincoln Road, a 6-story building in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, would never recover: Their co-op has deconverted to a rental building, and savings have been lost.
"In the end, I still owe $60,000 for nothing," said Martin McMichael, former president of the co-op board. "I don't have anything."
The Attorney General's office does not maintain records on the financial difficulties of co-ops. But between 1980 and 1994 in New York State, 11,688 buildings containing 830,833 apartments were either built as, or converted into, co-ops or condominiums.
"We have historically stated that about 10 percent of offering plans that came through from 1980 to the present have shown some type of sponsor-related financial problem or default," Mr. Connor said. That percentage holds true for the 1,850 members of the Council of New York Cooperatives, which only tracks information on its own members.
One of the hardest hit communities during the co-op market collapse was Queens, where Borough President Claire Shulman created a task force to help co-ops work their way out of trouble. Buildings containing about 80,000 apartments were converted in Queens, Mrs. Shulman said, "of which about 20,000 got into some kind of difficulty."
Although there have been few conversions in recent years (31 across the state in 1994 compared with 1,361 in 1987, the peak year), there has been a strengthening in the market for individual apartments -- mostly larger, more expensive units but, in recent months, trickling down to studio and one-bedroom sales, said Alan J. Rogers, managing director of Douglas Elliman, a major brokerage company in Manhattan.
The slight upturn notwithstanding, thousands of co-op owners -- unable to sell or even refinance their individual mortgages -- are still hoping to dig out of the financial hole while not quite comprehending how they got knocked over the edge.
What hit them was a one-two punch to a market that was already out of shape at the opening bell -- a market bloated by overvalued properties purchased with mortgages granted to speculating sponsors by high-risk-taking lenders. The big blows were the Tax Reform Act of 1986, which stifled incentives for outside investors to buy apartments, and the confidence-chilling stock market crash of 1987.
"Looking back," said Michael Finder, a lawyer who has represented numerous co-ops as they struggle for recovery, "it's amazing that everybody had such a myopic view of the economics of New York City in believing that the bubble would expand throughout all the boroughs. There was heavy speculation in neighborhoods where the economy could not possibly support the expectation of expanding gentrification."
There have been earlier co-op waves this century, but they were "user-initiated, rather than by sponsors," said Herbert Marcuse, an urban history professor at Columbia University.
IN the 20's and 30's, "there was a strong ideologically driven move toward cooperative living," the professor said, "and it succeeded. There were a number of buildings converted and others that were built in New York City." But even the best intentions could not survive the Great Depression.
After World War II, another series of co-op conversions and construction, including efforts to build single-family homes in groups, took hold, primarily by people seeking to hold down operating and construction costs.
The most recent co-op wave, Professor Marcuse said, "is a far cry from the original spirit of the cooperative movement, motivated by the financial consequences for the participants rather than any wish to live convivially or communally."
For many owners of rental buildings during the co-op wave of the 80's, the conversions represented a chance to realize the market value of individual apartments in buildings whose earning capacity had long been restricted by the rent-regulation system.
Conversion sponsors obtained bank financing and bought at prices based on the expectation of gradual sales of vacant apartments. But when the market collapsed, the sales never occurred, and the buildings were burdened with excessive debt, sometimes leading to default.
"It was horrendous because the conversions had less to do with the true value of buildings, but rather what the sponsor thought was the maximum value all the apartments could achieve on selling all the apartments," said Stuart Saft, chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives.
Many sponsors, in their conversion plans, would add a wraparound mortgage to the underlying mortgage, creating additional capital for themselves and adding debt to the resident-shareholders who purchased the individual apartments. Tenants, sometimes, did not have the power to block the wraparound or, often, did not raise objections because they were more interested in buying apartments at low insider prices and then selling for a quick profit.
BEFORE 1986, a sponsor could expect to sell blocks of his unsold apartments to other investors -- a syndicate of doctors, for example -- who saw short-term tax benefits and long-term value in eventual sales to outsiders. But the 1986 Tax Reform Act eliminated most of those deductions, and, in time, a significant portion of the market.
The following a year, 1987, the stock market crashed, with the Dow Jones average dropping from 2,722 in August to 1,739 in October -- and by 508 points on Black Monday, Oct. 19, alone. "Wall Street, the banks, law firms began making a lot of layoffs," Mr. Finder said, "not just white-collar workers earning $200,000, but support staff, a lot of middle-class folks making $35,000. The ones who buy apartments in Queens."
Sponsors started applying for, and getting, end loans -- the mortgages for individual apartments -- against the value of their unsold apartments. Often, the sponsor got a loan based on an estimate of one-third of what the apartment's price would be when it was someday sold to an outsider, even though the apartment was still occupied by a rent-regulated tenant. The rent the sponsor received would be significantly less than the maintenance and debt service the sponsor had to pay.
"Each step the banks took was stranger than the last," Mr. Saft said. "They lent far more against the building than the building was worth and they lent far more against the apartment than the apartments were worth. All they saw was short-term dollars."
By 1989, because of the contraction in New York's economy, sales plummeted. Out of their pockets, sponsors had to pay the shortfall in maintenance on the apartments they held, and also the debt service on their end loans, and on the mortgages for the buildings themselves. They began to default.
It was on the evening of March 22, 1991, that the van from the Bank of Tokyo pulled up to the Acropolis in the heart of a thriving commercial district near the el in Astoria -- a complex built in 1927 on a foundation of bricks fashioned from the ballast of trading ships. "This place is what New York is all about," said Donald Novitt, the lawyer for the co-op corporation, "a regular United Nations, salt-of-the-earth working people."
A group headed by Marsar Realty was the sponsor at the time of conversion in August 1988. It looked like a good deal. "People lined up in the rain to purchase," Mr. Novitt said.
But "the co-op was doomed from the start," said Mr. Bass, the board president, "unless it could restructure the mortgage." The original loan was for $25.6 million. At the time of the final workout the property would be appraised at $12 million.
During the first year after conversion, Mr. Bass said, "many operating costs were absorbed by the sponsor" -- a tactic used to keep the initial maintenance low to attract buyers -- "and these hidden costs would come back to be billed to the shareholders."
Hidden costs often constituted one of several time bombs written into offering plans that potential buyers either failed to notice or chose to ignore because they were more interested in low apartment prices than riskier elements in the conversion, according to real-estate lawyers.
In some cases, sponsors sold the apartments but retained building amenities, like the garage or the commercial space, siphoning off revenues that would have subsidized the property. Some plans included "dancing interest," adjustable mortgages with low start-up rates followed by walloping increases.
"In 1989," Mr. Bass said, "we woke up one morning and found ourselves with a $100 maintenance increase and the possibility of another $100 in six months."
Marsar had retained 65 percent of the units and, therefore, controlled the board, a common situation that often left resident shareholders cut off from vital information. "Too late," Mr. Bass said, "we started finding out that we were millions of dollars in arrears to the bank and to many vendors. He had stopped paying."
AFTER months of negotiations, a deal was struck in which the sponsor agreed to auction his units and relinquish control of the board. Meanwhile, negotiations to restructure the mortgage were under way with the bank.
The auction, held in October 1990, "did not go the way we hoped," Mr. Novitt said. "Over 400 units were sold, but 350 went to one individual, Daniel Weinberger, for $1 each, and those had rent-regulated tenants." For his first two months, Mr. Weinberger didn't pay maintenance, Mr. Novitt said, "and we sued him." Mr. Weinberger filed a countersuit. The Bank of Tokyo wanted out, and the van arrived.
The Acropolis had one distinct advantage -- political clout. City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, who represents Astoria, had once been the lawyer for the tenants' association. And Borough President Shulman was not sitting idly by while, she said, "we were getting frantic calls from young couples who had invested their last nickel in their first real estate deal."
And so a workout process began that has served as a model for dozens of co-ops. Mrs. Shulman and Mr. Vallone called a meeting and "told all the parties that there will be no talk of bankruptcy, that an amicable resolution had to be reached," Mr. Novitt said.
Thirty meetings and 20 months later, the workout was in place: For $100,000, Mr. Weinberger transferred his 350 units to a holding company formed by the Bank of Tokyo. The bank reduced the mortgage from $25.6 million to $17.6 million, leading to a 17 percent maintenance decrease. The bank benefited because its shortfall between maintenance and rents on the individual apartments it owned narrowed.
But in October 1994, there was a glitch. The bank tried to sell the mortgage, at a discount, to a private investor. The co-op balked, and Mrs. Shulman called another meeting at which, Mr. Novitt said, "Peter Vallone went ballistic on the Bank of Tokyo."
The parties appealed to the Community Preservation Corporation, a consortium of 57 banks and insurance companies that finances housing. "What we did, and it worked beautifully in this instance," said Michel D. Lappin, the corporation president, "is purchase the underlying debt at a price that eliminated any operating deficits from the management of the building so that even if there was never another unit sold it could still pay for its normal operations. Then we organized some of our member banks to do the end loans on new sales."
Since the Acropolis, Mr. Lappin said, that formula has been applied to about 5,000 units in 25 projects, with 21 more projects currently in the pipeline.
Under the final workout, with the property reappraised at $12 million, the underlying loan was reduced from $17.6 million to $9.5 million, with a mortgage granted by the Community Preservation Corporation paying off the bank. The bank was able to write off $14 million in losses.
With political figures urging it on, the State of New York Mortgage Agency agreed, in a record three months, to insure the underlying loan. And when the deal closed last April, all of the apartments were transferred to the co-op. "Now we were in control of our destiny," Mr. Bass said.
EIGHT apartments have been sold since. "Units that went for $1 at the auction are now selling for $25,000 to $40,000," Mr. Bass said. "For the first time ever, the co-op is operating in the black. And people are breathing easier."
There would be no such help for the people at 101 Lincoln Road in Flatbush.
The sponsor for the 82-unit building was Aaron Ziegelman, a converter who, by 1989, had taken over 140 buildings, including two around the block from 101 Lincoln Road.
The residents of 101 Lincoln were "West Indian, African, hard-working middle-class people," said Mr. McMichael, who became president of the board after Mr. Ziegelman defaulted. The building later deconverted with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation taking title.
"A lot of these people left, simply went back home," said Mr. McMichael, "because they figured, 'I'm not going to let the American government take what little I have left.' "To the underlying $1.45-million mortgage, granted by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddy Mac, Mr. Ziegelman had added a $2 million wraparound. Twenty apartments were sold, three to insiders.
Mr. Ziegelman rehabilitated the sold apartments, but those occupied by rent-regulated tenants remained in dire disrepair. "We did everything to fight the plan," said Joan Ann Charles, the lawyer for the tenants, "but we were told by the Attorney General's office that the sponsor's only duty was to disclose the defects in his offering plan; they had no power to make him fix the defects."
Retaining 75 percent of the units, Mr. Ziegelman controlled the board. "He set up this dummy board," said Mr. McMichael. "Most of us were not clear on the laws, the rules on running a co-op. He was like a ghost. We tried to get him to call meetings. You could never reach him by phone."
Soon, rent-regulated tenants stopped paying. "Some people couldn't shower because their walls were falling down," Mr. McMichael said. "They had legitimate reasons not to pay."
Two months after conversion, Mr. Ziegelman stopped paying maintenance on his 62 apartments. But it would be a year before the shareholders found out. Robert Hartman, a lawyer hired to represent the shareholders after Mr. Ziegelman defaulted, said a company controlled by the sponsor was the building's managing agent. "If an independent agent had been there, perhaps some alarm bells would have gone off," Mr. Hartman said.
When Mr. Ziegelman sold someone an apartment "he would say, 'You can go to the bank or we will do the end loan for you,' " Mr. McMichael said. "Nothing wrong with that; it's American enterprise." Then Mr. Ziegelman would sell the loan to a bank.
"From those who got their own loan, he got the $60,000, $100,000, whatever the price of the apartment, right there," Mr. McMichael said. But when Mr. Ziegelman financed the end loan, he would receive a small down payment from the buyer and a promissory note for the balance of the loan. Then, when he sold those end loans to a bank, even at a discount, "he still made another $20,000, $30,000," Mr. McMichael said. "All he was interested in was getting the money and running."
Mr. Ziegelman sees it differently. "All I know is I lost all my money there," he said in a brief telephone interview. "When the trouble arose, the buyers defaulted because of the problems in the building. When the rents collected were less than the maintenance and the whole thing collapsed, that's the problem. No one accused me of doing anything that was improper. It was like a chain reaction."
In March 1992, with Freddy Mac about to foreclose and auction off the property, the co-op filed for bankruptcy. Mr. Ziegelman also defaulted on the two neighboring buildings.
Most of the following year was spent searching for a "white knight" -- someone willing to invest in the unsold apartments while negotiations continued with Freddy Mac to restructure the mortgage. A parallel plan, Mr. Hartman said, was to transfer the shareholders from 101 Lincoln Road and those from one or both of the neighboring co-ops into one building, creating at least one viable co-op and two rentals. Neither plan materialized.
And in early 1993, Freddy Mac had the bankruptcy stay on foreclosure lifted, with ownership reverting to the F.D.I.C., and the building eventually deconverting into a rental.
"It was so much stress," said Mr. McMichael. "I was a newlywed. We just didn't know whether we were going to have a home from one week to the next. I was 21 years old, looking at $60,000 of debt. In the end, I still owe $60,000 for nothing.
"I'm trying to build a new life and constantly looking over my shoulder."
The injustice is real and unnecessary, said Mr. Lappin of the Community Preservation Corporation. "It's inherently unfair for the individual," he said. "The community loses good and affordable home ownership. And it's incumbent on all of us -- government and the banking community -- to change all of that, because there are solid solutions to avert such a bad outcome."
