HEADLINE: Bill Linder And His City Of Hope

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
KENDELE BASKERVILLE, 20, in a navy-blue security-guard uniform, is a New Community man. He got his job through the New Community Corporation. He works in a supermarket run as a partnership between Pathmark and New Community in Newark's beleaguered Central Ward. He is getting a high school diploma with the help of New Community staff members. His uniform is made by New Community's fashion institute, its green NCC logo -- on fleets of vans, the front of the monthly newsletter, apartment buildings and restaurant menus -- symbolizing hope and new beginnings.
For Mr. Baskerville -- an eighth-grade dropout, a father at 13, a thief who has done jail time -- and tens of thousands of other poor or troubled people here, New Community has become an island in the bleak Central Ward landscape that was nearly flattened in five days of deadly rioting, arson and looting in 1967. 
 Today the Central Ward is still poor, with deteriorating housing and high rates of crime and disease. But out of the wreckage of the old city came the outline of another: the vision of a tough parish priest, Msgr. William J. Linder, who saw something palliative, something better: a new community.
And the corporation he established is just that: a new community that began with the big talk and far-fetched daydreams of poor people and a parish priest in a Catholic church basement in the mid-60's. Like farmers raising a neighbor's barn, people in impoverished areas throughout the country are uniting, applying for loans and grants, and supervising the building or renovation of their own development. In the 1960's, when New Community began, there were only a handful of these neighborhood-based developments. Now there are roughly 2,000, ranging from a few renovated houses to major complexes with thousands of apartments and stores.
"Typically they start with people meeting on a stoop," said Paul S. Grogan, president of the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, which supports such neighborhood redevelopment projects. Banks and foundations, not Federal agencies, lend most of the money.
New Community was one of the first, biggest, most successful -- and most urgently needed. In achieving its goals, Monsignor Linder sidestepped or ran over politicians who opposed his work or bureaucrats who tried to slow him down. When Federal housing officials were slow to issue a permit for a new homeless shelter, he broke ground anyway. When they complained, he called Jack Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, for support. When Newark refused to issue the shelter a certificate of occupancy, he put up a Christmas tree, called reporters and asked Mayor Sharpe James if he wanted to be Scrooge or Santa Claus.
High-handed? Perhaps. But few have criticized the scope or the quality of New Community's achievements. It has 3,000 apartments and town houses in 18 complexes. Its day-care centers care for 700 children, including the homeless, children of battered women and babies with AIDS. Its services have been sought for running a day-care program for the headquarters employees of Blue Cross-Blue Shield of New Jersey. It runs housing for the elderly and for homeless families. It has a full-care nursing home, a medical clinic, job-training and job-placement programs. It has 102 security guards, headed by a retired captain of the New Jersey State Police. In a neighborhood without banks, it established a credit union and installed automated teller machines. It has parks with sculptures and restaurants offering everything from doughnuts to Cajun dinners with wine and live jazz.
And after years of attending to Newark's needs, New Community is starting to expand its housing and social programs outside the Central Ward and Essex County.
As urban poverty worsens and an increasing number of children are supported on welfare, the self-help nature of New Community, replicated many times and unencumbered by the conflicts and bureaucracy that can strangle government programs, appears to be an answer.
In the years he has led the building of New Community, Monsignor Linder has acquired opposition, jealousy and praise, not to mention a $356,000 MacArthur Award for extraordinary accomplishment.
"He's had the tenacity and wisdom to stay with the people and attain their full support for good works," Senator Bill Bradley said in an interview. "He's very tough with any level of government or private sector. Everyone knows him as a man of great integrity. It's the old story -- a man of truth makes those who don't speak truth back down."
 
A CITY BOY
Learning the Ropes
Monsignor Linder -- who introduces himself as Bill -- is a short, pudgy-faced, unprepossessing-looking man of 59. He is short, his neck is encircled by a black clerical collar, his white hair wavy. "His hair used to be jet black," said Joseph Chaneyfield, one of New Community's founders. "That's not age. We did that to him."
Monsignor Linder has lived in the Central Ward for 33 years, since he was a young assistant priest at Queen of Angels, his first parish. He became a priest to help people, but it took him a while to learn how.
"In the 60's he wasn't the expert he was now," said former Gov. Thomas H. Kean. "He had immense good will but he didn't know much" about urban renewal.
"I thought he was a very naive suburbanite," said Mary Smith, founder of Babyland, whose child-care centers are an integral part of New Community. "He had preconceived ideas of what we were like."
Actually, he grew up in Jersey City, not the suburbs. His father was a gas company supervisor, a behind-the-scenes volunteer for state politicians. Dinner-table talk was of local and state politics -- who was efficient, who was corrupt. "I went to the Hudson County university of politics," he said.
Political savvy would come in handy. When New Community was only an architect's model and Babyland had its first 26 children, a Short Hills pediatrician volunteered to examine them. Monsignor Linder regularly gave messages and requests to the doctor to give to another patient's father, Assemblyman Tom Kean.
Before entering Immaculate Heart Seminary near Ramsey, Monsignor Linder studied engineering at Seton Hall University. "Engineering can be kind of remote," he said. "A parish priest can work with people on a different level."
He continued to read and take courses in urban studies, architecture and city planning. "I've always liked cities," he said, in a profound understatement.
Some of his first parishioners became his lifelong partners in New Community. Mrs. Smith and Joe Chaneyfield belonged to Queen of Angels, to which he was assigned in 1963. Mrs. Smith's husband had lost his job and with four young children, she could not get outside work. They fell behind on their rent and had to move into the sprawling Scudder public housing project.
From the day they moved in, the Smiths had to walk up to their 12th-floor apartment, because the broken elevator was never fixed. Nor was there hot water. Upset as she was raising children in such a place, it was at Scudder that Mrs. Smith learned to lead. She organized other tenants and was elected president of the tenants' association. She got to know her neighbors' problems -- no jobs, no day care, the ever-present danger of fire.
Most of all, she discovered what she already knew from her own experience -- mothers could not get jobs without access to day care and would not take jobs without being sure their children were safe and well cared for. At the time, day care centers were rare, especially for the poor. Eventually, with help from women organized in suburban churches, who also understood the demands of child rearing and who formed a group called Operation Housewife to support her, Mrs. Smith opened the first Babyland.
Joseph Chaneyfield was a burly factory worker who went on to become president of a union representing maintenance workers.
"Those laborers were tough, but Joe could rally people in a minute," Monsignor Linder said. Mr. Chaneyfield's power was to be crucial in establishing New Community. After the 1967 riots -- though Monsignor Linder took over when truck drivers refused to enter the Central Ward, delivering bread, milk and Spam to families huddled at home -- many black leaders opposed the white priest.
"They'd say, 'You do the work, he gets the credit,' " he continued. "Well, when you're talking about the monsignor, you're talking about Joe Chaneyfield. New Community is about all of us."
 
GETTING ATTENTION
'It's Faith'
After Sunday Mass, Father Linder, then the new assistant priest, mixed with people in the church basement, trying out ways of drawing attention to the needs of the Central Ward, ways that were usually blunt, loud and liable to upset church and political leaders.
"We won't sell our souls," he said. "You have to say what you think." As a young priest sparring with church hierarchy or a venerable monsignor criticizing the the mayor, he speaks out.
Mr. Chaneyfield, 68, sitting at his regular table in the New Community's World of Foods cafeteria near the Pathmark, recalls with glee one of the many times Monsignor Linder said what he thought, with vigor.
The story centered on the Archbishop of Newark, Thomas Boland, who in the mid-60's moved from Newark into a large gated-and-guarded house in the Llewellyn Park section of West Orange. Many people raised their eyebrows at a church leader deserting Newark for luxury. But Father Linder was the only one to get a hold of an aerial map and plot to invade his boss's home.
"It was a beautiful, nice, sunshiny day," Mr. Chaneyfield says. He and Father Linder and 40 others slipped past the security guards and raised pickets and voices out on the Archbishop's lawn. The protest made the front page of The Star-Ledger. Shortly after, the Archbishop moved back to Newark. But for a time, Father Linder was refused a parish assignment.
Years later the subsequent Archbishop, Peter Gerety, made a point of touring Newark with Father Linder and, after getting calls and letters from members of Queen of Angels and his later parish, St. Rose of Lima, elevating him to monsignor.
It was after the riots that Father Linder saw the limitation of protests, the necessity of creating concrete things: a safe, secure city with roomy, private houses, day care, and jobs with good pay and benefits. The necessity of creating the impossible, without money or power. He recruited neighborhood backers to commit themselves for 20 years -- the first New Community board of directors.
"People used to call us crazy," Mr. Chaneyfield said. "Some black ministers laughed at us: 'You think the state is going to give you, black boy, and a German priest not even head of a parish money?' Well, I've lived to see it."
"There's the religious element," Monsignor Linder said, explaining why he never doubted New Community would happen. "It's faith. Not belief, but faith meaning trust. If God's behind it it's going to happen."
 
MAKING IT HAPPEN
Seed Money and Moxie
"The genius of Bill Linder is 'start small.' Do something tangible, very modest, and build on that," said Mr. Grogan of LISC. "It's the paradox of small steps." Newark was devastated physically, economically but also psychologically. People don't ever see victories. With small concrete victories you build the morale of the city. You rebuild hope. Sources of support -- private companies -- say, 'Boy, this can really happen.' "
With $13,000 in seed money from the state, Monsignor Linder hired experts and arranged field trips to teach future residents to design their houses. He bought two acres of largely vacant land with $100,000 raised with the help of state Jaycees.
When a corporate president wanted to donate $40,000, Monsignor Linder asked for -- and received -- a $200,000 loan and the assistance of the company's top lawyer and engineer. Six years later, people moved into the 120 terraced low-rise apartments surrounding a central playground in 1975.
They had designed these apartments themselves. Since then, seven other housing complexes have been built or renovated. Much of the money comes from selling tax credits the organization earns by building low-income housing. The profitable new Pathmark, which opened in 1990 -- the first supermarket to open in the Central Ward in 20 years -- is jointly owned by the supermarket company and New Community. Before, residents had to take the bus three miles to buy groceries at a supermarket or pay much higher prices for lower quality and meager selection at local bodegas.
As New Community grows, Newark politicians become increasingly uneasy. The burned-out neighborhood is becoming a political force. A word from Monsignor Linder or other New Community leaders has packed City Council chambers and could swing votes. Many city politicians viewed Gayle Chaneyfield, a recently elected Councilwoman (and Mr. Chaneyfield's daughter), as the New Community's first candidate. Ms. Chaneyfield said New Community has long been "a Switzerland, not involved with city politics." When she decided to run -- a decision not influenced by anybody at New Community, she said -- she was roundly supported by members of the group. Other candidates used that support "as a weapon," she said, and went on: "I'm being supported by a nonprofit that's done so much. Only in Newark would that be an albatross around my neck."
Slamming New Community has become "a banner for local politicians," she said. The fear is that New Community is too big and independent, "a giant willing to crush the City of Newark," she said. "They're a thorn in the side of the city government because they remind the government this is the job they should be doing, the services they should be providing."
Nor does Monsignor Linder bother to placate skittish city leaders.
"The city's pretty ineffective," he said, in a typical comment. "I question their competency. The Mayor clashes with us. He calls us arrogant. Very well. Leave us alone. There's certain things we need from the city. We want them to cooperate with us."
Mr. James denies that there is tension. When the city recently threatened to shut off water to New Community until it received past-due payments of $2.6 million, it was simply treating residents like all others. "We're glad you have housing," he said. "Now you got to pay your water bills." Monsignor Linder denied owing that much and eventually New Community settled by paying a fraction.
"I'm proud of him," Mr. James said, of Monsignor Linder. "I hug and embrace them for the great good they've done the city. The James administration has been a partnership with them and we're proud of that. Sometimes they tend to forget that. Some people say we're scared of New Community. But government is here to stay -- elected by the people, keepers of the treasure."
Hearing of this, Monsignor Linder snorted. "I wish," he said.
Scholars of urban development who have been watching are impressed -- they only wonder if New Community could be duplicated in places that don't have a Monsignor Linder.
"Not a lot of places that are severely distressed blossom like that," said Nicholas Lehman, an urban development scholar and author of books on the subject. "It has a huge range of activities and a lot of stuff -- buildings, programs, schools, stores. It has risen to the level where you can say the essential character of the neighborhood has changed. But its success if not easily replicable. The real model is that Linder's a genius. And there aren't that many Monsignor Linders in the world."

HEADLINE: LOOKING AHEAD;
Three Plans Later, How a Region Has (and Hasn't) Changed

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
When the Regional Plan Association introduced its third long-range plan for the metropolitan area last week, it sparked a debate among officials and civic leaders in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut about just how many of the goals were realistic. As the debate continues, it is likely to center on how successful the states were in adopting recommendations that the research group put forth in two previous reports, published in 1929 and in 1968.
In both instances, government officials in New Jersey and elsewhere seized on the most straightforward recommendations. In particular, they paid close attention to suggestions for expanding transportation networks and preserving open space. But all three states were slower to take the association's advice on more complex, sensitive issues like social policy, taxation and urban revitalization. Addressing problems in these areas would require a well-coordinated joint effort on the part of government, business, civic groups and the housing, education and health care sectors. 
 Bill Shore, a senior fellow at the Regional Plan Association who has spent 35 years there, said the 1929 report had the greatest impact on transportation planning. Since city residents were starting their exodus to the suburbs when it was published, it provided a blueprint for the three states to build an interconnected network of highways, bridges and tunnels. It also recommended a tristate railway system that never came to fruition because of the Depression. (The idea has not gone away, though -- a similar goal is included in the new plan.)
For New Jersey, the 1929 plan recommended major highways in areas where the Garden State Parkway, Route 287 and a number of other roads were later built. But it is unclear whether their construction was a direct result of the plan.
"Certainly there was an enormous amount of highway construction during the Depression," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "But New Jersey had already built a skeletal framework in the 1920's, before the regional plan came out."
The first report also recommended local planning and zoning standards to prevent congestion and sprawl, many of which were adopted by New Jersey's municipalities between the 1920's and the 1960's. By the late 60's, most municipalities had also developed master plans similar to what was recommended in the 1929 report.
While the 1929 plan was the work of a small group of powerful business executives, including the uncle of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, the 1968 plan drew on discussions at hundreds of community meetings and input from civic leaders in the three states. Mr. Hughes of Rutgers said that plan focused more on social issues than economic and transportation concerns because it was produced in an era of social activism.
"There was a real revolt against physical plans because of the tenor of the times," he said. "In that era, there was much more of a concern that citizen groups be included in the planning process."
Acknowledging that New Jersey residents had moved far beyond the business hubs of Newark and Trenton, the 1968 plan suggested focusing on a number of smaller cities that could be developed as "metropolitan centers" where offices, shops, colleges, hospitals and theaters would be concentrated.
"Where offices, shopping, health facilities and colleges scatter, cultural institutions may not be established at all," the plan warned, "and all the activities will be lower quality than could have been supported if they were grouped."
The plan pointed to Bergen County as an example of such sprawl, and suggested that New Jersey focus its efforts on cities like New Brunswick, Hackensack and Morristown. Mr. Shore of the Regional Plan Association, who wrote the 1968 plan, said that New Brunswick benefited the most from its recommendations. Shortly after the plan was published, he said, Johnson & Johnson built its headquarters there.
"It's not all we conceived of, but it's certainly better than what would have happened in New Brunswick without our plan," Mr. Shore said.
On the other hand, he said, efforts to revitalize downtown Paterson failed. And there were disappointments in other cities.
"We won a lot of battles, but we lost the war," he said. "We couldn't carry out most of these plans on the local level without strong, ongoing local support."
While most urban renewal plans for New Jersey did not come to pass, Mr. Shore said the 1968 plan did inspire the state to preserve several areas as parklands. Based on specific recommendations, he said, New Jersey created Wawayanda State Park in Sussex County, Round Valley Recreation Area in Hunterdon County, Spruce Run Recreation Area in Hunterdon County and Island Beach State Park in Ocean County. It also made the public beach at Sandy Hook part of the Gateway National Recreation Area, the first national park in an urban area, he said.

LENGTH: 910 words

HEADLINE: NEWS AND TOPICS;
As Small Airports Struggle, Local Governments Start Investing

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: LAKEWOOD

 BODY:
Like many small private airports in New Jersey, Lakewood Airport has been scraping by for years, making do with a taxiway that's pockmarked and gravelly, a beacon that hasn't worked for eight years and runway lights that flicker at 25 watts.
But this month the airport got a new, inexperienced owner with big plans to make substantial improvements: Lakewood Township itself. 
 "The airport has been here a long time, it provides a service to residents and businesss, and it's a community resource that shouldn't go by the wayside," said Gregory C. Fehrenbach, the township manager.
Lakewood is not alone in its thinking. Around the state, a growing number of municipalities are interested in buying privately owned airports within their borders, or are in the process of buying them. In each case, the goals are similar: to lift the local economy, to prevent airport land from being gobbled up by developers and to help relieve air-traffic congestion in the region.
Some people are wary of the trend. They say the transfer of airports from private to public hands goes against the current push to privatize, and could be construed as a government bailout for struggling airport owners.
"When a municipality takes something like that over, they're very bad at running things and managing things that privatization should manage," said Samuel Perelli, chairman of the United Taxpayers of New Jersey, a private advocacy group. "Here we are with school systems that we're trying to privatize, services in these schools, and now we're going in the opposite direction with the airports."
But others say the involvement of municipalities is beneficial to all parties.
In the last five years, air traffic in the state has increased about 10 percent, even though there are fewer places to land. New Jersey has lost eight airports in the last decade, 58 since 1952. And 35 of the state's 51 airports open for public use are in private hands -- one of the highest ratios in the country -- and many are struggling to stay afloat, said John S. Penn, executive director of the New Jersey Division of Aeronautics.
There is nothing to stop airport owners from selling their properties to the highest bidder, like a real estate developer. But to preserve the number of "reliever" airports that could siphon smaller planes from major airports, the Federal Aviation Administration has offered to put up 90 percent of the money to help a public entity acquire a private airport, with the remaining 10 percent paid by the municipality, the state or even the current owner. The money, which would help pay for repairs, safety improvements and maintenance, would come not from additional taxes but from a reallocation of existing Federal transportation funds, Mr. Penn said.
In Lakewood's case, the owners, a group of private investors, were interested in selling because the 192-acre airport wasn't generating much profit. In stepped the township, which determined that it could easily afford to lose the $40,000 the private owners pay in property taxes. It plans to allow commercial development on 30 acres on airport property, and the State Department of Transportation and the the private owners will pay Lakewood's 10 percent of the $8.9 million purchase price.
Now the municipality is looking for a management company to operate the airport, a renovated version of which Mayor Jerome Greenberg hopes will include a restaurant as well as improved services for the flight school students and charter passengers who pass through the trailerlike terminal.
"The airport is definitely underutilized, so this is a major economic development tool and a terrific investment," said Mr. Fehrenbach, who manages a township that was once a winter resort but now counts on industrial parks to spur its revival. "It's sort of like buying a $8.9 million zero-coupon with no money down."
Other communities are in early stages of airport takeovers. On Tuesday, Lincoln Park introduced an ordinance to spend $5,000 on a study of a possible purchase. In West Milford, the economic development committee has recommended that the township spend $10,000 for a similar study for Greenwood Lake Airport, whose current owners, the Lembo family, want to sell.
And in Somerset County, Hillsborough Township is evaluating a study on buying Kupper Airport, whose owners are in bankruptcy. The 100-acre airport could serve as an anchor of the township's corporate zone.
There has not been much opposition to these plans, other than objections raised by people who didn't like the airports in the first place because of noise and traffic.
Still, airport owners are cautious. These are, after all, tough times in a business saddled with increasing equipment, insurance and fuel costs, and tighter regulatory requirements.
"As a path of last resort, it's great when the state says, 'We will guarantee the sale,' " said Bob Bogan, president of Aero New Jersey, which represents the state's airport owners. "But we are concerned that the state will direct all their attention to the acquisition of airports versus devoting a substantial amount of their money toward safety projects at existing airports."
But owners and aviation officials say the municipalities seem the best option to save the airports. "I can't see any more airports being built," said Mr. Penn. "If you don't preserve what you've got, you're going to end up with the same thing that happened with the railroads."

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
More Buses, not Trains, For Route 9 Corridor

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
After two years of intense debate, New Jersey Transit last week scuttled plans to extend commuter rail service to Freehold and Lakewood, choosing to provide more bus service and more road improvements along the Route 9 corridor. The reasons, officials said, were money and local opposition.
Increased bus service, like connections between Route 9 and the Garden State Parkway near Exit 123 in Sayreville, would cost $67 million. Rail service from Lakewood to Monmouth Junction would run $260 million, and $129 million from Lakewood to Red Bank. Meanwhile, the projected number of daily bus riders would hit 20,000 by 2010; the number of train riders would reach only 7,400. 
 Lakewood residents had hoped commuter rail would spur economic development in their township. But residents of South Brunswick, Monroe Township and Jamesburg were vociferously opposed, saying rail service would be too expensive and too close to homes.
Rail advocates said they were disappointed, especially in light of last week's study by the Regional Plan Association concluding that the New York metropolitan region faces major economic decline if mass transit links are not developed fully. DAVID W. CHEN

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Toyota RAV4;
A Cute Brute Rocks to an MTV Beat

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
A FRIEND'S daughter bounded into their kitchen and asked which family vehicle she could have for the day: the luxury sedan, the sport utility vehicle, or, heaven forbid, the mini-van.
"Yes!" she exclaimed, rejoicing, as her mother tossed over the keys to their hulking Ford Explorer. 
 Sport utilities like the Explorer are increasingly the vehicles of choice among young drivers. But until recently, young adults without a trust fund could afford few of these vehicles. Along with the basic Jeep Wrangler, the Geo Tracker, sold by Chevrolet, and its twin, the Suzuki Sidekick, had the market pretty much to themselves.
More auto makers have recognized that low-priced sport utilities -- by that, I mean those under $20,000 -- represent a golden opportunity to lure first-time buyers to their folds, so more offerings are on the way. These include a revised Kia Sportage, coming later this year; a new Wrangler for 1997; a Honda Civic-based model called the CR-V, which is being displayed at auto shows, and possible car-based offerings from Pontiac and Ford in the more distant future.
Setting the standard by which all will be measured is the Toyota RAV4, short for "recreational active vehicle with four-wheel drive," which began arriving in American showrooms last month. (And, logic be damned, the two-wheel-drive version is not called the RAV2.)
Since its introduction in Japan and in Europe in 1994, Toyota's small sport utility has enjoyed substantial sales success. In fact, a shortage of assembly capacity delayed the RAV4's American debut. Toyota is virtually guaranteed a similarly strong response in the United States, where the market seems ready for a vehicle like the RAV4.
 In the grocery store checkout line, a cherubic-faced baby bundled in a blue snowsuit smiled at me. I couldn't resist pinching his pudgy cheek. Outside, as I walked toward the pint-sized RAV4, I felt the same urge. It's so darn cute. Too cute, some guys who saw it said, derisively calling it a "chick mobile" -- a car only a young woman would drive. But once behind the wheel, even the macho men were generally won over.
Indeed, the RAV4 attracted considerable interest from women, especially young ones, during my test drive. (Geo Tracker owners are 59 percent female and mostly under 30, according to Chevrolet.)
At a trendy music and video superstore, three women in their early 20's stared so intently at the RAV4 that they nearly walked smack into their GMC Jimmy. Another woman, driving a Toyota Land Cruiser, stopped us in the supermarket parking lot to ask what we were driving.
Compared with the Jimmy and the Land Cruiser, the RAV4 is puny. I was especially struck by its diminutive size as I searched for the four-door test model hidden by much larger vehicles in the mall parking lot. And the two-door version is 16 inches shorter.
The four-door RAV4's wheelbase, at 94.9 inches, is shorter than that of the Geo Tracker/Suzuki Sidekick, and closer to that of the Jeep Wrangler. In overall length, the RAV4, at 162 inches, is a few inches longer than the Tracker/Sidekick and the Kia Sportage. But the RAV4 is shorter than the Jeep Cherokee, at 167 inches.
The RAV4's petite size and smooth lines, a stark contrast to its boxy competitors, give it a friendly look. Adding to its baby-cute appearance is body cladding of high-strength plastic that surrounds the RAV4's bottom like a diaper -- from the front bumper, around the sides and across its back end -- to guard against stone chips. The RAV4 carries its spare tire on its rear door, which is hinged and opens like a regular car door, making loading a snap.
The RAV4 comes in a variety of youthful colors with hip names like "purple storm," "confetti blue metallic" and "Sequoia green metallic." The tested model was "Prussian red pearl," a.k.a. maroon.
Because it is car-based -- many of its components came from the parts bins for defunct All-Trac versions of the Camry and Celica -- the RAV4 is a cinch to board. The low step-up makes it easy for children to climb in and out, which isn't the case for most sport utilities.
Once seated, the driver and passengers sit tall, an attribute that sport utility fans, particularly women, say they like, since they feel they have a greater command of the road. The front seats are adjustable buckets that fitted every size person who sat behind the wheel. I could comfortably adjust the seat close enough to the pedals for my short frame, while tall, lanky types with long torsos noted that they had ample headroom. The split rear seat is a bench for three passengers, or it can be reclined backward or folded forward for added cargo space.
The RAV4's cuteness doesn't extend to the functional interior. The materials are durable, from the patterned fabric seats to the matte-finished plastic, and one can imagine hosing down the inside after a day at the beach or on the trail.
The instrument panel and center dash are logically laid out, for the most part. My sole complaint was that the speedometer, often used in light of my recent history of speeding tickets, is far to the left of the instrument panel, and its numbers are small and hard to read. The less-used tachometer, with large numbers, is directly in the driver's line of vision through the steering wheel.
Storage is generous throughout. The front doors have small pockets suitable for compact disks. The door to the cargo bay has briefcase-size pouches. The area behind the back seat is big enough for a couple of large suitcases and some duffel bags.
Where the RAV4 excels in its class is in its ride and drive performance. Unlike most of its competitors, which are generally built on the chassis of rear-drive trucks, the RAV4 begins with the front-wheel drive and many components of a car. That results in nimble handling, responsive steering, good stability even at top highway speeds, and a ride as comfortable as most small sedans'. But the interior suffers from excessive road noise, which reverberates through the cabin.
The RAV4 would make a great beach buggy, and with four-wheel drive it could probably handle less challenging off-road trails. But it will clearly be used mainly around town, and it is ideally suited for that.
The RAV4's two-liter four-cylinder is a modified version of the Camry's base engine. With 120 horsepower, the RAV4 provides peppy performance with good fuel economy: 22 miles a gallon in town, 27 on the highway. The tested model came with the standard five-speed manual transmission; a four-speed automatic is optional, but only on the four-door, and I highly recommend the stick shift for maximum fun.
Four-wheel anti-lock brakes are optional. Other safety features include dual air bags.
Also optional is full-time four-wheel drive, which will raise the price by about $1,000 while providing light off-road capability, though the RAV4's front-wheel drive should be adequate for most drivers. Prices start at $15,345 for a two-door with two-wheel drive. The price of the test vehicle, a four-door with four-wheel drive, totaled $21,128 with destination charges, a hefty sum for first-time buyers.
Yes, the RAV4 makes a lot of noise. But what the heck -- we just cranked up the stereo, which is what young RAV4 owners are likely to do as well.
"It's noisy," my 7-year-old daughter said from the back seat. "But it's fun." I smiled in agreement.
After all, isn't that the point?
 
INSIDE TRACK: Awesome, totally.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: William J. Nasgovitz;
Heartland Value Fund

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY MIDDLETON 

 BODY:
WITH the stock market soaring to yet more record highs, perhaps no one has a tougher time than a money manager who likes to buy shares that are cheap.
Undaunted by the prospect is William J. Nasgovitz, who has guided the Heartland Value fund to an impressive record for more than 10 years. He says values can still be found in the stock market, though he is covering his bases by letting his cash position rise to nearly four times its normal level of less than 5 percent of assets. 
 The fund, which specializes in small companies, closed to new investors in July after assets ballooned to more than $1 billion. So if you want the benefit of Mr. Nasgovitz's expertise, you will have to try his other fund, Heartland Small Cap Contrarian, begun last April.
Discovering stocks before Wall Street finds them is Mr. Nasgovitz's goal. Employing the classic financial analysis of Benjamin Graham, he seeks companies with certain attributes. In particular, he looks for companies with a ratio of debt to capital of no more than 25 percent and with low share prices relative to their earnings, cash flow and book value.
Exactly who owns the stock also carries great weight. He prefers companies in which the top executives and directors have big holdings and in which other institutions have a small stake.
 The strategy has led Mr. Nasgovitz to very small companies. The stocks in Heartland Value have a median market capitalization of $63 million, and those in the new fund average $46 million, while the median is $574 million for small-company funds, Morningstar says.
Though the funds are similar, his small-cap fund can take short positions, or bets that stock prices will decline, with up to 25 percent of its assets. It now has a short position equivalent to 18 percent of its $106 million in assets.
"Small stocks have been known to go to ridiculous valuations on both extremes," Mr. Nasgovitz said, "so we're short about a dozen of Wall Street's most overvalued, overloved, overowned high-fliers." An example is Molten Metal Products, a pollution cleanup company with a market cap of nearly $800 million and no earnings.
 But Mr. Nasgovitz really likes to spot tomorrow's winners. Here are two favorites in Heartland Value, which has 19 percent in cash, and one in the new fund, with just 2 percent cash:
 
 
 
Caught on the Rebound
 "I like Gehl Company, based in West Bend, Wis., which is north of here about 30 miles," Mr. Nasgovitz said in a phone interview from his Milwaukee office. Gehl, a maker of agricultural and construction equipment, nearly went out of business a few years ago after its management took on debt and tried to expand too rapidly, Mr. Nasgovitz said. But more recently, with another member of the Gehl family at the helm, earnings have strengthened.
 "Somebody is going to discover this company," Mr. Nasgovitz said, "either in the public stock market or a strategic buyer."
Mr. Nasgovitz says he will keep buying the stock at less than $9, which is only about 7.5 times his profit expectation of $1.20 a share this year.
 
 
 
Victory from Defeat?
 Right Choice Managed Care Inc. of St. Louis has two strikes against it. Its market is limited to Missouri, and all of its voting stock is owned by Blue Cross/Blue Shield of Missouri.
The control by Blue Cross is seen as an impediment to a takeover, yet the company's market is too small for economies of scale in an era of nationwide managed care, causing the stock to sell at a discount, Mr. Nasgovitz said.
 The stock closed at $16.125 on Friday, for a market capitalization of about $300 million, or $200 for each 1.5 million members. The industry average is about $1,000 a member, Mr. Nasgovitz said.
 One-state companies are doomed, he said, and competitive pressures will force Blue Cross "either to become more active in the acquisition market, or to sell off Right Choice."
 
 
 
Careful Shopping
 Retailers are profoundly out of favor, and that makes them attractive to value investors. "You can generally find something that's in its own private bear market, so retailing is at the top of our list," Mr. Nasgovitz said, adding that Small-Cap Contrarian owns 10 retailing stocks.
 One of his top retailing picks is Fred's Inc. of Memphis, with 200 discount stores in the Southeast. The stock has tumbled to $7.125 a share from a high near $20 in the summer of 1993. A new management team led by a one-time Wal-Mart executive has adopted an "everyday low-price" strategy, said Mr. Nasgovitz, who says earnings could reach 50 cents a share -- well ahead of Wall Street expectations -- in this fiscal year.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2343 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Can Retirees' Safety Net Be Saved?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
SOCIAL SECURITY is going bankrupt -- again.
But don't sell off the family Wedgwood or apply for Swedish citizenship just yet. In 1983, the Social Security cupboard was nearly bare. This time around, the economic and political crisis is coming in slow motion: the system's income from payroll taxes is expected to exceed pension outlays until 2013. 
 Thereafter, however, the relentless growth of pensioners will eat into Social Security's accumulated claims against the Treasury, forcing Washington to raise taxes or slash spending on other programs. And, for the first time in the 60-year history of Social Security, some of its friends are asking for fundamental change before the system cracks under the weight of promises that would be inconceivably expensive to honor.
"We are damning our children to a very grim future if we continue to hide our heads in the sand," said Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska.
Impressed by the need to increase national savings to pay for the graying of the baby boomers, many pension specialists want to tie Federal benefits more closely to individual efforts to build nest eggs. Indeed, inspired by the vogue for market-based solutions to social problems -- particularly the experience of several Latin American countries, notably Chile, that have privatized their pension systems -- some are calling for the dismantling of Social Security.
"Business as usual is no longer sufficient to provide retirement security for future generations," said Michael Tanner, director of the Social Security privatization project at the libertarian Cato Institute.
Even defenders of the New Deal faith are entertaining changes that would have been denounced as heresy a few years ago. Robert M. Ball, a former Commissioner of Social Security and a main negotiator for Congressional Democrats in the 1983 fix, wants to invest a chunk of the system's revenues on Wall Street.
"Why should the trust fund earn just one-third as much as common stocks?" Mr. Ball asked.
Thirteen years ago, Democrats and Republicans gritted their teeth and put in place a series of modest benefits cuts and tax increases intended to finance the pension and disability portions of Social Security for another 75 years. But new estimates, based on revised labor force and demographic data, suggest that the current payroll tax rate of 12.4 percent (employer and employee combined) is two percentage points shy of the amount needed to meet the 75-year target.
To put it another way: if nothing is done before 2022, promised benefits for retirees will have to be cut by a third to keep a positive balance in the Social Security trust fund.
Lawrence White, an economist at the Stern School of Business at New York University, sees the issue in more alarming terms. The Government is implicitly relying on a huge cash surplus from Social Security to keep the overall budget deficit under $200 billion today and to balance it in 2002. But this projected surplus peaks in 2005, at $120 billion, and falls to zero in 2013. So just a decade from now, Mr. White notes, Washington will face fiscal pressures from the deteriorating net cash flow from Social Security. And after 2013, the ink turns red.
"It's a chain-letter scheme with socially redeeming features," Mr. White said. "But it's still a chain letter."
Barry Bosworth, an economist at the centrist Brookings Institution, elaborates: America has failed, he suggests, to accumulate the capital to make it possible for a relatively small work force to sustain a decent living standard while supporting parents and grandparents. But rather than saving more to create this capital, Americans -- young and old -- have been saving less. Between World War II and 1980, households and businesses set aside about 8 percent of income, while Government deficits drained off a bit less than 1 percent. Since 1980, private saving has slipped to about 6 percent, while budget deficits have cut net savings to just 3 percent.
There is nothing very new in the view that Social Security's woes follow from demographic imbalance and are aggravated by a spend-now, pay-later mind set. What is new, or at least suddenly respectable to assert, is that the system's failings follow from a failure to ask individuals to bear more responsibility for their own retirement.
As it is, Congress shuffles the Social Security pot in ways the public is only dimly aware of. Intergenerational transfers -- the chain-letter aspect -- are the most obvious. A single worker born in 1930, with average earnings, can expect to get back about 90 percent of the total payroll tax paid, plus interest, while the same kind of worker born in 1950 will end up with just 55 percent.
But that is only the beginning of the wide range of payouts, determined by Government policy, that often provide a bigger return to those who have paid in less. Under the current formula, a single low-income worker born in 1930 can expect to get back about 120 percent of his or her contribution, while a married couple with just one low-income worker born in that year can expect to reap 235 percent. Meanwhile, a single worker born in 1930 who has had maximum taxable earnings can expect just 70 percent.
Then there is the issue of the return on trust fund investments. Social Security's claims against future Government revenue -- I.O.U.'s the agency holds in the form of Treasury bonds, which now exceed $500 billion -- have historically earned just 2.3 percent after adjusting for inflation. Had this money been broadly invested in common stocks over the last half-century, the return would have been close to 7 percent.
While bills to revamp Social Security have been introduced, no one expects Washington to touch the issue before the election this year. Hence the clearest sense of the plausible range of options is coming from private sources, notably the Cato Institute and the specialists on the Social Security Administration's advisory council, whose chairman is Edward M. Gramlich, an economist at the University of Michigan.

Keep the Faith
An obvious approach is to buttress the finances of the existing system. Increasing the payroll tax anytime soon is probably a nonstarter. But Mr. Ball, along with 5 other members of the 13-member advisory council, argues that there is a way to eliminate the shortfall of two percentage points without asking for much public sacrifice.
He assumes that revisions in the way inflation is computed by the Department of Labor will trim the growth of indexed benefits by half a percentage point a year, clipping off roughly a third of the projected 75-year deficit. Another third would be closed by taxing Social Security benefits in sync with private pensions, and then directing that all the revenues -- including those that now go for medical benefits -- be used for pension and disability payments.
Most of the rest of the needed money would come from Mr. Ball's single concession to the new political order -- investing three-eighths of future payroll tax revenues in a Government-run stock mutual fund whose return would mirror that of the market as a whole. This, he reckons, would raise the expected return to the trust fund to 3.8 percent, from 2.3 percent.
Sylvester Schieber, vice president of the Watson Wyatt pension consulting firm and a member of the Social Security advisory council, calls this approach "a trim, a tuck and a prayer." More specifically, he points out that much of the revenue Mr. Ball would direct to pensions would come from money currently shoring up Medicare, a social program with awesome financial problems of its own. Mr. Schieber also notes that the stock market may not perform as well in the future as it has in the past.
A final catch, which Mr. Ball readily acknowledges, is that the plan would probably not keep Social Security solvent past mid-century. He anticipates a need to increase the payroll tax in the distant future.
 
Full Privatization
Those who rejoice in thinking the unthinkable ponder a radical break from the "defined benefit" Social Security system run by Washington to a private, but mandatory, "defined contribution" system that would operate like I.R.A.'s and 401(k) plans.
Investments, presumably made largely through mutual funds, would be regulated. "You couldn't buy derivatives on the Singapore market," Mr. Tanner of the Cato Institute explained. And you probably could not withdraw money as a lump sum upon retirement. But in contrast to the current system, which pays a fixed monthly amount, each worker's benefit would be determined by how much that person invested, and how well. Bare-bones subsistence for retirees who would otherwise be destitute would be financed through Government revenues.
The pluses are plain. Americans would be obliged to save for their own retirement, presumably benefiting from the higher returns historically available from private investment. What's more, the system could never be in deficit and could never become a vehicle for buying political support from the elderly with the taxes of the young.
But the minuses are clear, too. Serious poverty among the aged, almost eliminated by the progressive distribution of Social Security, might reappear. And middle-income Americans would be at greater risk. "Relatively few of the 122 million contributors would have any idea how to invest their money," Mr. Ball said. Moreover, there is no assurance that the private market would convert the savings into annuities indexed to keep up with inflation.
Surely the most difficult issue, though, is how to cope during a transition from the current pay-as-you-go public system. Going cold turkey -- writing off the unfinanced promises to older workers and current retirees -- is not an option. (Younger workers are actually paying in enough to finance their promised amounts.)
Mr. Tanner would require Uncle Sam to assume a substantial portion of the $3 trillion to $4 trillion (yes, trillion) in unfinanced benefits, with older people getting more than the young. And he would raise the money from unspecified Government savings or, as a last resort, from new taxes.
 
A Public-Private Hybrid
Mr. Schieber and four other members of the advisory council favor a compromise between radical privatization and Mr. Ball's plan for muddling through.
Workers under 55 at the program's inception would be given a rebate of half of the 10 percent payroll tax now earmarked for pensions. (Disability payments account for roughly 2 percent of the tax.) But they would be obliged to invest the money through "personal security accounts," which would function like I.R.A.'s. Most of it would presumably end up in mutual funds.
Workers and retirees over 55 would be "grandfathered," receiving currently promised benefits for the rest of their lives. But Mr. Schieber envisions a two-tier payment for everyone younger.
The first tier would be a basic benefit, roughly $360 a month in 1995 purchasing power. The retirement age with this benefit would rise to 68 by 2017, as now scheduled. Then the eligibility age would rise with average life expectancy. The second tier's size would depend on an individual's savings, investment decisions and retirement age. Computer models suggest that with modest wage growth and a 4 percent return on investment after inflation, personal security accounts would finance retirement benefits for today's young workers that exceed those promised under current law.
As with full privatization, raising money to finance the change from pay-as-you-go to a fully paid retirement system would be a problem. Indeed, "the transition could be ugly," Mr. Gramlich said.
Mr. Schieber would make the cost of the transition visible and amortize it over a very long period. He would sell Government bonds to replace payroll revenues lost by the Social Security trust fund in the switch to personal security accounts. And he would cover the interest and pay off the principal with a 1 percent national sales tax -- dubbed a "liberty tax" -- over 70 years.
The relatively high expected return on private investments would make it possible to deliver roughly the same benefit to low-income workers as the current system promises, with less money diverted from the payroll taxes of high-income people.
Still, some of the cautions that apply to full privatization apply here, too. Individuals might make bad investments with the substantial sums in their personal security accounts. But Mr. Schieber responds that the "risks are no greater than the political risks" to which benefits are now subjected.
Patching the current system with the relatively modest changes suggested by Mr. Ball may seem the path of least resistance. But the need to compromise to secure the agreement of a Republican-controlled Congress may lead to more radical measures.
In 1983, Congress had to act because the payroll tax was inadequate to cover pension outlays in the immediate future. This time around, Social Security is rolling in cash and nothing will force action for a decade if Washington chooses to sit on its hands. And that, suggests Mr. Tanner, means conservative Republicans will not be under pressure to accept reforms they dislike.
By the same token, time is not on the side of those who favor minimal change. The longer Washington waits to make a patch, the more it will have to raise taxes or cut benefits -- and the harder it will be to sell. Hence, those who defend Social Security may be forced to accept partial privatization as the price of sustaining benefits.
Besides, there is a small but influential group in Congress who have staked their careers on restoring fiscal prudence and intergenerational equity. They will not quietly accept changes that do not assure the higher savings rates needed to pay for the retirement of baby boomers.
"Perhaps Bill Clinton and Newt Gingrich can afford to wait for a real fix," said Senator Kerrey, who was co-chairman of the Bipartisan Commission on Entitlement and Tax Reform. "But most Americans can't."

HEADLINE: The Vaew From: Irvington;
New Orleans Gala With Egyptian Theme Helps Black Colleges

BYLINE: By LYNNE AMES 

DATELINE: IRVINGTON

 BODY:
IT was a glittering evening, and not just figuratively speaking. Many partygoers arrived in gold lame; those not draped in shimmering stuff had touches of gold encircling their throats, nestled in their hair, dangling from their ears. In the ballroom, light from gilded wall sconces shown on walls and ceilings adorned with intricate gold-leaf designs.
The event was a costume ball billed as "An Egyptian Masquerade: Mardi Gras Comes to Westchester," and it was held at Villa Lewaro, the 35-room Italianate mansion here that once belonged to Madame C. J. Walker, the first self-made famale millionaire in America. 
 Villa Lewaro, a vast white stucco edifice, is now the home of Harold E. Doley Jr., president of the Doley Securities investment firm, and his wife, Helena, a guidance counselor at the Cottage School in Pleasantville. The Doleys are from New Orleans, and, they s'id, they wanted to bring a taste of Mardi Gras up North.
They also wanted to help a cause in which they deeply believe. The gala, sponsored by the Tri-State Friends Committee of the United Negro College Fund, drew 225 guests who paid $125 to $2,000 each and raised $50,000 to benefit four historically black colleges: Bowie State University in Bowie, Md., Clark Atlanta University in Atlanta, Shaw University in Raleigh, N.C., and Xavier University of Louisianain New Orleans.
Also at the benefit, Michael R. Bloomberg, founder of Bloomberg Financial Markets, was honored for his donation of $2.6 million worth of computers to United Negro College Fund member schools. Mr. Doley, who has served as United States Ambassador to the African Development Bank in the Ivory Coast among other government positions, is an alumnus of Xavier; he said it is crucial to support such institutions.
"These colleges are very, very important," he said. "They provide tremendops educational opportunities for large numbers of African-Americans. Being a transplanted New Orleans native, I thought it would be wonderful to do a Mardi Gras-style party here in Westchester to benefit these institutions. Helena and I are very epcited that the house, with its incredible history and special meaning for African-Americans, is being used for fund-raising events."
One guest observed that the soiree was very much in the spirit of Madame Walker herself. Born in 1867 in De'ta, La., to two former slaves, she went on to found a line of beauty-care products that earned her more than $1 million. In 1916, already a fixture on the New York social and philanthropic scene, she commissioned the building of Villa Lewaro, which she used until her death to entertain notables from the arts, politics and business.
The Mardi Gras ball held last weekend also drew its share of high achievers. Toni Cox-Burns, a fund-raising consultant from White Plains, said with a laugh, "I'd say we have the black elite from the county and beyond, but that might sound elitist, so let's just say there are lots of movers and shakers here."
Guests began arriving at 7 o'clock, gingerly stepping out of cars to protect delicate costumes. Men appeared as pharaohs draped in white robes and wearing gold-tone headpieces and breastplates; more than one woman was Cleopatra. Mrs. Doley was wearing an iridescent gold skirt and top, which left her midriff exposed a la ancient Egypt, and on her head and arms were gold sequined snakes.
Ira Moss, the 6-foot-7 president of a chemical company in Washington, towered over the crowd in white-and-gold-embroidered pharaoh robes; his wife, Darlene, was resplendent in gold-pleated skirt, multicolored jeweled collar and a two-foot-high headdress. An almost identical Egyptian queen outfit was worn by Shirley Hinton, who works for International Business Machines. Ms. Hinton had rented hers from the Elephant's Trunk in Mount Kisco; Ms. Moss's was rented from a costume company in Washington. "Who would have thought that the two of us, coming from two different states, would end up in the same costume," Mrs. Hinton said. "Oh well, at least I was at the party first."
Lois T. Bronz, a Democratic County Legislator from Greenburgh, was wearing a costume she had made of dazzling blue-and-silver cloth and a huge headpiece she had constructed for the county's Caribbean Festival last fall. Mrs. Bronz, 68, grew up in New Orleans where she was one of 10 children and, she recalled, her mother "made Mardi Gras costumes out of flour sacks for us -- we always had a costume for Mardi Gras."
She spoke, too, of her years attending Xavier University. "I was the first member of my family to graduate from college. I always knew I'd go. The nuns at the Catholic high school I attended identified me as having college potential. I won a scholarship to pay for my education. I knew I was among pace setters, and I felt a sense of responsibility to do something with my education, a sense of commitment that I think has stayed with me all these years."
Logan Delany also talked about the significance of a college education. Mr. Delany, a 46-year-old financier who lives in Irvington, is the grand-nephew of Sarah Delany and her late sister Bessie, the centenarian sisters from Mount Vernon who gained worldwide fame in the last five years. A Harvard graduate, he said that historically black colleges play "a tremendously important" role in American education.
"These schools tend to be underfunded and underrecognized," he said. "Look at the historical role of these colleges: until a generation ago, blacks had virtually no choice of where to go. Just about all of the black leadership came out of these historically black colleges. When I went to Harvard, my freshman year 1966, only 2 percent of the class was black."
In a lighter vein, Mr. Delany said he loves parties and proclaimed this one a major success. Although he was not wearing a costume, his tuxedo lapel was adorned with a pin depicting Nefertiti, and he said he thought the Mardi Gras theme and New Orleans cuisine were "fabulous."
In this he was not alone. People oohed and ahhed as they sampled seafood gumbo flown from Dookey Chase Restaurant in New Orleans. They also had high praise for the lavish buffet catered by J. E.'s Restaurant in Newark, returning for second and third helpings of shrimp creole, crawfish etoufe, sausage jumbalaya, ham with raisin sauce, short ribs, turkey with cornbread stuffing, peach cobbler and coconut cake. And phey admired the tiger lilies and gold papier-mache Egyptian-style decorations provided by Felicia C. Sneed, a petite, silver-haired woman who for many years has run a bridal and party business in East Orange, N.J.
"Mr. and Mrs. Doley are among the nicest hosts and hostesses I've ever worked with," Mrs. Sneed said. "People in their position could allocate a lot of the decisions and the work about a party, but they didn't -- they got right into it and were involved every step of the way."
Judie Beville also had praise for the Doleys and the event. A 1976 graduate of Clark Atlanta University who is a special events coordinator in Valhalla, she said she thought the party struck just the right note. "It's fun; it's glamorous, and it's quite original for this part of the country," she said as Karen Lopes and the Katts, who had played rhythm and blues and rock and roll most of the night, began "When the Saints Go Marching In."
"It also helps an extremely meaningful cause," she added. "I went to a historically black college, and it was one of the best experiences of my life. It has kept me connected spiritually to the African-American culture and people. Yet it excluded no one. We had black professors, and we had white professors, and everyone was caring and friendly. The professors adhered to the highest academic standards, and they expected us as students to do the same. They expected a lot from us, and they got it."

HEADLINE: Where Students Teach Students

BYLINE: By BARBARA HALL 

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
THERE will be a need for about two million qualified teachers in the United States over the next decade, according to the National Commission on Teaching and America's Future, a nonprofit research group based at Teachers College of Columbia University.
At least one Westchester high school is showing active concern about the projections. The Lincoln High School of Economics and Finance, a magnet school here, has taken the unusual step of guiding high schoolers into the teaching profession. 
 Little about Lincoln is usual: passages from Ravel's "Bolero," for example, are often played at the school, which operates a school within a school called the Early Childhood Center, where young children are taught by high schoolers under the supervision of faculty members.
The center was established in September 1987. At first it offered instruction only to high school seniors. Today all high school grades can take advance courses, including ones on early-childhood development.
This year, there are 160 prekindergarten, kindergarten and first-grade children in the program. They are local youngsters chosen by lottery. (Coordinators confirm that there is a long waitilg list.)
About 220 Yonkers high school students are involved in classes in the Early Childhood Education wing at Lincoln High School. In addition to advanced prep courses with children in the lab school, the high schoolers can take education-related courses at the Pleasantville campus of Pace University.
Kathleen Ryan, by all accounts the prime mover of the program, said: "Pace has been very, very good to us. College is a whole new world for our students. It proves to them that, yes, they can succeed in the college environment. We give them a head start. We say, 'Let's open up a few doors here.' "
She added that 90 percent of her students are accepted by colleges.
The Lincoln effort received support with recruiting from New Teachers, a nationwide network based in Belmont, Mass. One goal is to encourage precollege teaching as practiced at the Yonkers magnet school.
Roseanne Bacon, a former teacher who for a year and a half has directed the precollege effort, praised Ms. Ryan. "She has always been terrific," Ms. Bacon said.
The program's overall mission, Ms. Bacon said, "is to improve the awareness of today's students to the possibilities, the joys, of teaching as a profession." "Although Yonkers is an urban area, it has a suburban flavor to it," she continued. "They are doing an excellent job of bringing diverse groups together. They're providing meaningful experiences. After all, teaching isn't fun all the time. We've identified 400 precollegiate programs in the country. Only 29 are teaching magnets within the school. Yonkers's teaching magnet is very unusual." James Wilson, a junior, is one of the minority of boys in the Early Childhood program. "I want to be a teacher for the little kids," he said. "I get satisfaction when they remember something I've taught them. At first I was scared to do it. It was difficult. Now, when they get active, I know what to do."
A dance class, perhaps, reveals the program at its liveliest. In a large room walled with mirrors and framed by ballet barres, 16 kindergarten and prekindergarten children were high-stepping to music, with help from high school students under the watchful eye of Judy Rubin.
In one exercise, the troupe mimicked elephants, giraffes, tigers, then monkeys, against a background of drumbeat and chant.
"I'm the rookie this year," Mrs. Rubin said. "It's so exciting to see my students with the little ones. They really get in there and work." Her group, she said, will give a recital in the spring.
One of her high school students, Paulina Vallejos, said she was having the time of her life. "It's a good feeling you get to see the expressions on their faces," she said. "I'm a lady to them. I'm some authority for them to look up to." For special occasions, she added, the children make their own costumes. "They come up with really interesting designs," she said. Asked what she remembers most, Ms. Vallejos said: "There was this one little boy who said to me: 'I remember you from last year. You taught me that dance.' He actually remembered. I thought, 'Wow, he must have liked it a lot.' "
Ms. Vallejos said she wants to major in elementary education at New Rochelle College next year.
Quanda Meakers also chose to teach the youngsters in dance.
"It's just that I like little kids," she said. "I love their innocence."
Another of her dance classmates, Yocaira Gonzalez, a senior, said that years of baby-sitting influenced her involvement in the program. "I'm leaning toward becoming a teacher more and more as I teach here," she said. "The children look pp to you. I think teaching is an instinctive thing."
Ms. Gonzalez is one of the Lincoln students taking courses at Pace. "The professors didn't know we were high school students until we told them ourselves," she said. "You get confidence from this." Wilfa Almonte, a junior and dance-class participant, added accolades of her own.
"Dance brings the children out," she said. "They get happy, emotional. As for me, Lincoln is fun, a family. The teacher is like my second mother. I treasure this school."

HEADLINE: Don't Give Me Fahrenheit; Tell Me How It Feels

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
I spent most of my childhood just north of Oshkosh, Wis., a city we saw as a center of cosmopolitan sophistication, in a town called Neenah, where winter was winter. Deep snows and sub-zero temperatures were a routine part of life. And when the weatherman reported that it was 20 or 30 degrees below zero, we suited up like astronauts and put on ski masks like bank robbers -- no skin exposed, period.
Yet today, when a winter worthy of the name arrives, the coldness numbers are way off my childhood charts. In the New York area, there are reports of 20 degrees or so below zero, while from the Midwest and Plains states come declarations of 50, 60, even 90 degrees below zero. Is this America or Antarctica? 
 The temperatures haven't dropped because of global cooling or global warming. The reason, of course, is the rise of the "wind-chill factor," an inflationary number that is used so often these days that the actual temperature is just an afterthought. How did the wind-chill factor come to upstage mercury itself?
The notion that the wind can make the cold feel colder is merely common sense.
But the idea for a wind-chill index was first proposed in 1939 by Paul Siple, an Antarctic explorer. In 1945, after watching water freeze in plastic containers, he and a colleague, P. F. Passel, published an empirical formula for calculating the heat loss due to wind chill, using measurements of air temperature and wind speed.
The formula states, for example, that at a temperature of 20 degrees Fahrenheit and a wind speed of 20 miles an hour, the wind-chill reading is 9 degrees below. At zero degrees and a wind speed of 25 miles an hour, the wind-chill becomes 45 below.
Even though the formula has been around since the end of World War II, the wind-chill factor did not enter the vernacular until 15 years ago. The explanation, it seems, is a combination of meteorology and the media.
The National Weather Service began reporting wind-chill numbers in the mid-1970's, after the agency received inquiries. But things really took off in the 1980's as weather announcers became fixtures on television screens across the country.
"Wind-chill caught the public's imagination, and the notion was spread by the rising popularity of television weather reports," said Michael Glantz, head of the environmental and societal impacts group at the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo. "And wind-chill is a very appealing concept to people. Temperature just exists, but the wind-chill tells you something that weather does. How it makes you feel."
So reporting the wind-chill factor was justified in the name of weather relevancy. In addition, as more television weather people were trained in meteorology, they felt more confident in not merely reporting the weather but interpreting it, amplifying it. They understood the wind-chill formula, and they began doing the calculations themselves.
Besides, as Todd Miner, a meteorologist at Penn State University, noted, the wind-chill version "is more dramatic."
Some meteorologists have questioned just how accurately the Siple wind-chill index captures the combined cooling impact of wind and cold on humans. "It's a leap to go from water in cylinders to how quickly your skin cools," said Thomas Schlatter, a meteorologist for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
Using only temperature and wind speed, the Siple index is simply understood, but it leaves out factors like sunlight, activity and clothing. Other formulas have been proposed. In 1971, R. J. Steadman devised a formula for heat loss for what he memorably described as "an average clothed mobile human."
The Steadman formula results in more moderate wind-chill ratings than the Siple index, according to a recent issue of Weatherwise magazine. At a temperature of 20 degrees and wind speed of 20 miles an hour, the Steadman wind-chill is 5 degrees, roughly 15 degrees higher than the Siple index.
Some meteorologists believe that the Steadman approach is more accurate. Still, the Siple index seems assured of remaining the wind-chill standard, at least until Mr. Steadman finds a cooler name to quantify how that "average clothed mobile human" feels.
Shrewd phrasing is required for any aspiring weather term. "Wind-chill" is so bluntly descriptive that one feels colder just hearing it. Meanwhile, its ungainly hot-weather counterpart -- "apparent temperature," the combined effect of heat and humidity -- has not caught on. Small wonder.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: America's Burden;
At Hour of Triumph, Democracy Recedes As the Global Ideal

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
THROUGHOUT the world's longest experiment with democratic government, America has always thought of itself as morally obliged to export its way of life. What the White Man's Burden was to Kipling's generation of Englishmen, the promotion of democracy has been to four generations of Americans -- the foreign policy equivalent of apple pie. Ever since Woodrow Wilson vowed to make the world safe for democracy, most Presidents have rhetorically endorsed this goal.
But now, less than a decade after democracy's greatest leap forward, the idea that America must promote it everywhere has lost some of its charm. Funds for encouraging elections overseas are drying up as the Clinton Administration struggles simply to secure peace in Bosnia, the Middle East and elsewhere. In part this reflects the reluctance of Americans to send their dollars abroad. But it also hints at a deeper change -- a new sense that Americans doubt that every country in the world would be better off if only it had more democracy. 
 Of course Washington's actions have often been inconsistent with its lofty words. Some American actions ignored democracy altogether and simply made a corner of the world safe for United Fruit. And when, during the cold war, Presidents from John F. Kennedy to Ronald Reagan proselytized for democracy, they did so selectively, and primarily to stop Communism.
Later, when the Soviet Union collapsed, the global triumph of democracy seemed for a while not only inevitable, but a laudable end in itself, a development that would, incidentally, enhance American national economic and security interests.
But is this true? A debate is now raging.
To some extent, recent Administrations have had little choice but to embrace efforts to advance democracy abroad. Surprised by the democratic wave from Chile to South Africa after the fall of the Berlin Wall, the Bush Administration went so far as to suggest that promoting democracy was a goal of its war to liberate Kuwait (which never was, and isn't now, democratic). Not to be outdone, President Clinton in 1993 created new posts in the State Department and National Security Council for the purpose of spreading democracy, and set up a committee to consolidate financing for such activities. He also proposed a 60 percent increase in funds for the National Endowment for Democracy, the foundation Congress created in the Reagan years to pay for fostering elections overseas, among other things.
Recently, however, supporters of such pro-democracy programs have found themselves lobbying to preserve the Endowment's $35 million budget and prevent Congress from cutting the more than $725 million that the Administration estimates that it has spent on democracy-related programs in fiscal 1995.
It seems unlikely that Congress will abandon direct promotion of democracy altogether. But many policy makers and private analysts now say they are less sanguine about democracy's prospects, more sober about the difficulty of promoting it and more skeptical about whether its triumph in several strategic countries would enhance American interests.
Mr. Clinton, too, has gradually de-emphasized the goal he once championed, says Thomas Carothers, a former State Department lawyer and senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. "With the single exception of Haiti," Mr. Carothers recently wrote in The Washington Quarterly, "Clinton has not, relative to Bush, substantially increased the U.S. emphasis on democracy promotion in any country or region." Mr. Carothers, incidentally, thinks this is a sensible step toward realism.
What explains this unease? First, the democratic trend that seemed inevitable after Communism's fall has slowed, and in several regions has been reversed. Consider Yugoslavia, where elections meant only the end of the pluralism and tolerance that Americans take for granted as essentials of democracy. Or Poland and the Czech Republic, where voters disenchanted with slipshod administrations have elected former Communists to run their countries better. Or Russia, where the rise of ethnic, religious, and nationalist passions has led Washington to back Boris Yeltsin, the best of a bad lot of would-be czars-through-election.
Fareed Zakaria, managing editor of the bi-monthly, Foreign Affairs, argues that while there are more signs of "democratization" -- especially elections -- there are fewer democracies. "Serbia held elections, reasonably fair elections," Mr. Zakaria writes in a forthcoming essay. "And the Serbs chose Milosevic, a xenophobic dictator." In this argument, elections are just one attribute of democracy; effective democracy implies a system in which elections help a society govern itself fairly and well. Mr. Zakaria argues that America might do better by promoting civic values like free speech, separation of church and state and property rights.
All too often, such elections have produced not "democracy" as Americans understand it, but what Ken Jowitt, a political scientist at the University of California at Berkeley, calls "Potemkin" or "mimic democracies" with few of the civic virtues found in the handful of "liberal-capitalist-democratic" states. Ironically, he says, efforts to promote democracy may have weakened the power of the state. And now, as a result, democracy is not nearly as important as stability.
 
 
 
Not for Everyone
 Most analysts agree that democracy building has traditionally been ignored in Arab states, , where the United States has vital national interests. Whatever praise the Administration has had for political liberalization in Jordan and Yemen, and for the recent Palestinian elections (which legitimized the autocratic rule of Yasir Arafat), officials remain wary of democratization as a general rule for the region. The worry is that anti-American, militantly Islamic regimes might replace the durably autocratic but pro-American governments of Egypt, Saudi Arabia and many gulf states.
So Washington did not protest when in 1992 the military cancelled an election in Algeria that would have brought the anti-Western Islamic Salvation Front to power. And the State Department was quiet last month when Britain began deporting a leading Saudi dissident, Mohammed al-Massari, whom the United States suspected of links to terrorist groups. "Saudi Arabia is the only place where U.S. officials have flatly told me that human rights and democracy are not an American concern," said Neil Hicks, Mideast coordinator of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, a private group based in New York.
Moreover, critics say, promoting democracy may not advance, or be consistent with, other American goals. Presidents Bush and Clinton both sacrificed concerns for human rights and democracy to protect America's profitable trade relations with China. In Latin America, the United States has found, alas, that autocratic regimes often suppress the drug trade more effectively than the region's elected leaders. Only in Africa, argues Mr. Carothers, has advancing democracy been a key element of American policy. But, he adds, only in Africa does the United States have no "significant economic or national security interests."
Penn Kemble, deputy director of the United States Information Agency, and Brian Atwood, director of the Agency for International Development, both say that the cost of promoting democracy is worth it. But, Mr. Kemble admits: "We're a little sadder, a little wiser now. We now know we need patience and perseverance to change a country's political culture. Changing Russia's will take at least a generation."
Even the suggestion that Russia might become democratic in a generation seems optimistic given its history and current behavior. But in American democracy, patience is not a virtue. The Administrations that will deal with Russia can last, by law, no more than eight years.
