HEADLINE: More People Grow Food In Cities, Report Says

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 16

 BODY:
From the garbage dumps of Calcutta to the rooftops of Mexico City and dirt strips along roads in Jakarta and Nairobi, millions of people are farming the world's cities, feeding their families and supplying markets with vegetables, fruit, fish and even meat, a study has found.
Urban agriculture is a rapidly growing industry, providing a significant amount of the world's food, according to the study, published this week by the United Nations Development Program. City farmers are also increasing their share of world horticulture and animal feed production. 
 "In China, the cities produce 90 percent and more of the vegetables consumed," said Jac Smit, president of the Urban Agriculture Network in Washington, which researched and wrote the report for the United Nations. "In Africa, we came to the conclusion that 20 percent of the nutritional requirement was produced in the towns and cities."
The ability to farm, however small the plot, can contribute significantly to family health, the study reports.
In Kampala, Uganda, the survey found, children in families who grew some food crops were as healthy as the children of wealthy city families and far healthier than children of urban families without agricultural plots.
On the Philippine island of Negros, malnutrition among urban as well as rural children dropped to 25 percent in 1991 from 40 percent in 1988, the study found, in large part because more food was available closer to home at a lower price.
The report, based on field studies in 18 countries in Asia, Africa and Latin America, also discovered that urban agriculture and aquaculture were playing a role in recycling uncollected waste, including sewage, in a number of cities.
But the use of urban waste and the lethal levels of air pollution in many cities in the developing world raised questions about the safety of the food grown there, Mr. Smit, an agricultural scientist and city planner, said in an interview today.
Cholera outbreaks have occurred in Lima, Peru, and in Santiago, Chile, because of contaminated vegetables, he said. However, he added that the outbreaks happened because food was not cooked and because the cities either lacked regulations for food production or the guidelines were simply not followed.
"The technology of producing safe food is well known and widely dispersed in the scientific community but not in the press, so the regular citizen does not know about it," Mr. Smit said.
The United States Department of Agriculture, the Governments of Japan and China, the European Union and the World Health Organization, among others, have all produced guidelines for growing food in urban centers, he said.
"The global upshot is that whether you go to Kinshasa, Zaire, or Moscow, or Shanghai, where urban agriculture is a major part of the diet, we don't hear of health outbreaks related to this," said Mr. Smit, who is now doing a survey on food safety for the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization. Three years of ad hoc farming in the Bosnian city of Sarajevo have not produced health problems, he added.
Urban agriculture has a long history, the United Nations report says. It is also not limited to cities in poor countries. Not all urban areas are defined the same way -- some, for example, might include large greenbelt or farming areas -- and cities in industrial nations are also food producers, the study found.
"Urban farmers also include wealthy producers of specialty crops for expensive restaurants," the report said, not just women growing vegetables on small plots in underdeveloped countries.
The new report, "Urban Agriculture: Food, Jobs and Sustainable Cities," was produced for Habitat II, an international conference on urban life scheduled to take place in Istanbul in June.

HEADLINE: AN ECONOMIC BASKET CASE;
In North Korea the Threat is Total Collapse

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
JUST two years ago, the Clinton Administration's biggest fear about North Korea was its determination to develop nuclear weapons -- a determination that could have led to war with the South. That worry was allayed after North Korea promised not to pursue atomic weaponry, in exchange for help with more benign nuclear power plants. But now, the United States has a different worry -- that North Korea is in so much trouble economically that it could fall apart. Rather than eliminate a threat, a sudden collapse could touch off internal chaos, a flood of refugees and -- if things got truly desperate -- war with the South.
South Korea, even more than the United States, is eager to avoid a sudden collapse of the North Korean regime. It is not just the threat of another war. South Korea's leaders are just as concerned that the North could fall the way East Germany did and, despite their stated commitment to reunification, they are extremely reluctant to make any real moves in that direction as long as the North remains an economic basket case. 
 In recent months, a wealth of anecdotal evidence -- severe food and energy shortages, an increase in defectors, a dramatic scaling back of annual military ground exercises -- suggests a country in economic crisis and a leadership struggling to cope with it.
One difficulty the United States faces in figuring out what to do in response is that North Korea is the black hole of Asia -- an isolated, rigid, Stalinist regime whose policies, capabilities and intentions are nearly impossible for the outside world to divine.
Another is that for years, American intelligence agencies have focused hard on North Korea's 1.2 million man army and its nuclear weapons program. The satellites and other secret intelligence gathering told America a lot about where the tanks were pointing and whether their engines were running, but little about whether peasants had enough to eat or whether the leadership was secure. So it is hard now to know just what to make of the anecdotal reports now emerging, and even harder to know how to react to them.
"For a long time there was little attention paid to such things," said Toby Gati, the State Department's most senior intelligence official. "If it was not an indication of war, there was no way to put it into the charts. The main focus of our analysis was and continues to be whether and under what conditions the North would invade the South. This is still crucial because of our troops. But a country is more than a tank, and now we have to have more than a one-dimensional look."
 
 
 
Floods and Oxcarts
 The task of analyzing the country's economy has become more crucial following floods last summer that wiped out entire villages and a large percentage of the country's food stocks and new harvest. This aggravated an economic crisis created after the Soviet Union collapsed and North Korea lost its patron and after China decided a year ago to stop selling the North grain on credit.
When the North Korean regime, whose guiding principle is self-reliance, turned to the outside world for help, the United States concluded that the economic problems were severe enough to warrant $2 million in food aid. Since North Korea remains subject to a 46-year-old economic embargo , the pledge of emergency aid was a diplomatic overture as much as it was a humanitarian response -- designed to show that the United States had no interest in seeing North Korea fall apart.
Last November, the secretive North even allowed the United Nations' World Food Program to open an office in the capital, Pyongyang; its presence has provided rare snapshots of everyday life.
Earlier this month, for example, Trevor Page, the program's director, visited Hwanghae, a prosperous town by North Korean standards and the fifth-largest in the country, where, according to his report, conditions were "appalling." Children from one to 16 years of age met in unheated classrooms where temperatures were about 5 degrees below zero. Most of the children were coughing and sneezing. School feeding rations had been cut in half.
There were no cars on the streets, only a steady stream of oxcarts and bicycles -- a sign of a fuel shortage. Groups of peasants were furtively selling firewood, clothing, cigarettes, matches and ballpoint pens on an illegal black market, which, according to an internal World Food Program report, "the Government is now tolerating because the public rationing system has broken down for lack of food."
In another report after a World Food Program visit to North Pyongan province last month, people interviewed said they were eating only two meals a day and stretching rice by turning it into porridge. The agency also has reported that the police are not arresting peasants who come into Pyongyang from the countryside with nothing to do but wander around in search of food. "Is there famine in the Biblical sense?" asked Mr. Page in a telephone interview from Pyongyang. "Clearly not. But the North Korean winter is hard and long and people are cold and the people are hungry and desperately short of food."
Another sign of discontent is that more North Koreans are fleeing overland into China and defecting to the South. Although American intelligence analysts look with skepticism on the stories told by defectors in staged press conferences in South Korea, the sheer number of the reports, particularly from soldiers who have defected, means they are now taken more seriously. Some defectors, for example, claim that hungry soldiers are deserting, robbing peasants, and being treated in hospitals for malnutrition.
Most interesting to the Pentagon is the fact that although North Korea's annual Air Force exercises are at about the same level as last year, its ground exercises are dramatically smaller. That, military analysts say, could mean that the Army does not have enough fuel to exercise.
Still, there is no agreement inside or outside the Administration about the extent to which shortages have affected morale or military readiness, whether the country is going to collapse or whether a collapse would prompt the North to invade the South.
"When you combine the failure of the economic system, the absence of political legitimacy and the lack of international backing, common sense tells you this is a country falling apart from within," said Stanley Roth, until recently the chief Asian analyst at the National Security Council. "But it's almost impossible to project when you have such little data."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Left, Right, Left: The Primaries Turn Politicians Around

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: GOFFSTOWN, N.H.

 BODY:
A NEW Bob Dole showed up in this state last week. Not the one who shuttles on corporate jets from his condominium in the Watergate to his condominium in Bal Harbour, Fla. This Bob Dole was heading for the eastern front in the class war, marching shoulder to shoulder with the working stiff.
Senator Dole's transformation, however momentary, can be traced to Monday night, when he just barely managed to win the Iowa caucuses. Frightened by Patrick J. Buchanan, who placed a close second and is a threat as Tuesday's primary here approaches, Mr. Dole echoed his rival's blue-collar lament. "Corporate profits are setting records -- and so are corporate layoffs," he asserted in his first speech after arriving in New Hampshire. 
 The shift is striking in the case of Mr. Dole, a highly experienced politician with a voluminous and generally consistent public record. But he is hardly alone. President Clinton is famous as a flip-flopper, as was his predecessor, George Bush.
 
 
 
In the System
 These changes of heart are easy to dismiss as mere political pandering. But they represent something more than disingenuousness. For the pressures that push politicians off their preferred places on the ideological spectrum are locked into the electoral system. Voters demand loyalty to an ever-shifting set of regional interests and popular notions even as they cry out for consistency.
Mr. Clinton, who has sent confusing signals on foreign policy, taxes, even his basic view of the role of the Federal Government ("The era of big government is over," he declared just two years after proposing a top-down reorganization of the entire national health-care system), leads in the early Presidential polls. These days, a consistent politician is often a losing politician.
Senator Phil Gramm of Texas is a classic case. No matter the occasion -- even at an anti-gay rally in Des Moines the other day -- he would dwell on the same economic message about spending cuts and budget-balancing that he has championed for all his years in Congress. Last week, his poor showing in Iowa forced him out of the race.
Mr. Dole himself learned the risks of consistency while being accused of inconsistency in the New Hampshire primary eight years ago. When he refused to sign a pledge not to raise taxes, he was labeled "Senator Straddle" in a particularly damaging campaign commercial by Mr. Bush. This time, Mr. Dole signed the pledge on the day he announced his candidacy.
The competing impulses to please and to stand firm are only ratcheted up in the glare of the primaries. Under the current system, candidates find themselves tailoring their messages to small, often narrow, constituencies. From Iowa, where religious conservatives are pivotal in the caucuses, candidates headed to this state, where anti-tax fervor and trade issues are center stage.
"This is the silly season and that's why you have to go back to people's records," said Grover Norquist, president of Americans for Tax Reform. "Things that are said in the heat of battle are terrible ways to judge people."
Indeed, hot issues emerge on which candidates are forced to take positions. Often, candidates believe that they have no choice but to respond to their competition -- and often to narrow issues that seem crucial in New Hampshire but fall flat when the race moves to Delaware the following week.
 
 
 
Scared by a Bear
 Stanley Greenberg, who was Mr. Clinton's pollster in the 1992 primaries, recalled that his candidate stopped pushing his middle-class tax cut after New Hampshire because a rival, former Senator Paul Tsongas of Massachusetts, relentlessly attacked him for it. "The candidates who get the high ground, who are able to set the agenda, will have an impact on what aspect of your perspective that you'll emphasize," Mr. Greenberg said. "Tsongas was successful in characterizing the middle class tax cut as pandering." Mr. Tsongas even had a "pander bear" that he toted to news conferences.
The Republican contenders spent much of last year's run-up to the 1996 campaign taking on big government. But the rise of Steve Forbes, the publishing magnate who built his candidacy around the flat tax, led the candidates in a debate several weeks ago to emphasize how their politics could spur economic growth. Now that Mr. Forbes has taken a dive in the polls here, his issues have also been sidelined. In their debate in Manchester last week, candidates took up the issue of trade.
"What you would like is for candidates to take consistent positions and demonstrate real leadership on them," said Richard G. Niemi, a political scientist at the University of Rochester. "But these days, I don't know if that's possible. Maybe the system is too demanding of these guys -- to be in front of the public every day and have your every word analyzed, you don't even have the time to think."
Hasty turns to the left or right can backfire when the nominees play to a broader electorate in November. "It does really contribute to the cynicism of the voters," said Senator John McCain of Arizona, who was chairman of Mr. Gramm's campaign.
 
 
 
Tilting Right
 Mr. Dole's decision to criticize corporations may be inevitable given the state of the Republican primary race. For most of last year, the majority leader considered Mr. Gramm his biggest threat. So he tried to tack to his right on social issues. And, worried that he was overshadowed by Speaker Newt Gingrich, he did his best to identify himself with House Republicans -- at least until voters began souring on them.
Mr. Dole is no more fickle than many of his rivals. Mr. Buchanan, who attacked Mr. Dole in the debate Thursday for "pirating my ideas and parroting my rhetoric," has shifted here and there, too. Four years ago, when he took on Mr. Bush in the primary here -- at a time when workers were suffering -- Mr. Buchanan abruptly abandoned his long-held support of free trade.
"It is a foreign policy of inertia and nostalgia," he said of his former free-trade advocacy. "Lord help me, I used to be one of them." In an interview, Mr. Buchanan explained his reversal by saying that "the political cause of my lifetime -- anti-Communism, the cold war -- it's over," and that it was time to "start looking out for No. 1."
And while Mr. Dole was borrowing from Mr. Buchanan last week, Mr. Buchanan was borrowing one of Mr. Forbes set lines when he declared: "We come here to New Hampshire now with our crusade to put America and Americans first really brimming with hope, growth and opportunity."
Nor should former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee get off the hook. Mr. Alexander, who served as Secretary of Education, has more recently called for abolishing the Education Department. In New Hampshire, he took up a new cause the other day, against "environmental extremists."
Gov. John M. Engler of Michigan, a popular Republican who has not endorsed a primary candidate, said that in his own races he tries not to become preoccupied with figuring out just what the voters want.
"Voters can be very demanding -- they can be very arbitrary as well," Mr. Engler said. "They can be very unrealistic in their expectations. Sometimes you get so wrapped up in trying to appeal to a subset of the electorate, that you can miss the winning message."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
In Contracts, Red Sox Choose Not to Follow The Indians' Example

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
If Mo Vaughn and John Valentin played for the Cleveland Indians, their employer would not have approached their salary arbitration hearings with economic trepidation. That's because if Vaughn and Valentin played for the Indians, they would have been signed for 1996 a couple of years ago and the team would not have faced any arbitration hearings.
But they play for the Boston Red Sox so they entered this arbitration season unsigned. 
 Vaughn finally reached agreement with the Red Sox Friday on a three-year, $18.6 million contract, 72 hours before his scheduled hearing. Valentin would like to join his teammate on the multiyear list, but the Red Sox haven't been real interested so they are scheduled to see an arbitrator Tuesday.
Unlike the Indians, who by now might have revolutionized baseball's salary scale if anybody had been watching, Boston does not believe in signing its good young players to multiyear contracts early in their careers.
"Dan prefers the shorter term, in a broad sense, for now," Mike Port, the Red Sox assistant general manager, said of General Manager Dan Duquette. "Flexibility is important for the Red Sox. That may change, but for now, that's it."
The absence of flexibility, if that's what multiyear contracts produce, has not hampered the Indians. Four years ago they began signing their promising young players to long-term deals, figuring they would save money through the players' arbitration years. Now, not only have they saved money, but they also have constructed an outstanding team with a nucleus of players who could wear the same uniform for years, if not their entire careers.
The Indians have not waited for a player to be four years into his major league career and two years away from free agency, as Vaughn is, to enroll him in their program. Kenny Lofton, Jim Thome and Charles Nagy each had played basically one season in the major leagues when the Indians signed them to contracts covering three to five years. Just this off season they wrapped up Manny Ramirez and Julian Tavarez for five years after they had spent less than two years in the majors. When Albert Belle signed for four years, he had played two and two-thirds seasons; Carlos Baerga played for three years, then signed for seven.
"The Indians signed them on a long-term basis to stabilize their costs," Duquette said. "But they also were going into a new stadium and they knew they were going to have an increase in revenue. Other clubs who aren't going into new stadiums don't have the dependability of their revenue base."
Others point out, however, that signing good players early saves larger expenditures in subsequent seasons.
"You have to give credit to John Hart," one agent said of the Indians' general manager. "He is a master at premature long-term contracts." Then, using Ramirez as an example, he added: "He might lose money in the long run, but he couldn't resist the guarantee of that contract. It's a great deal for the Indians. They're going to save $7, 8, 9 million over the life of the contract."
But Port, former general manager of the California Angels, talked about players falling short of expectation or suffering injury. "You don't mind paying for performance," he said. "It's paying for nonperformance that you don't like."
Certainly, the practice involves some risk, and not even the Indians have batted 1.000. But in creating the new economics, they have established a model for others to follow.
Other teams cautiously have begun to follow the leader. Before the 1994 season, California signed Tim Salmon (with 1 year and 45 days of major league service) to a four-year contract and Gary DiSarcina (2 years, 94 days) to a three-year deal, and the Dodgers signed Eric Karros (2 years, 36 days) and Mike Piazza (1 year, 34 days) to three-year contracts. Last April, Toronto signed Pat Hentgen (2 years, 24 days) to a three-year deal with an option for a fourth year.
On Friday, Chipper Jones, after his first year in the majors, agreed to a four-year deal with Atlanta.
The Red Sox could have acted similarly with Vaughn and Valentin after the 1993 or 94 season. It's not as if the players had not displayed their talents. In 1993, Vaughn hit .297, slugged 29 home runs and drove in 101 runs while Valentin batted .278 and drove in 66 runs. The next season Vaughn batted .310 and, with the strike-shortened schedule, hit 26 home runs and knocked in 82 runs while Valentin hit .301 with 49 r.b.i.
If the Red Sox had signed them after either of those seasons -- Duquette said he considered but rejected a two-year deal for Valentin in 1994 -- Vaughn and Valentin would not have been able to capitalize on their monster performances last season: .300, 39 home runs, 126 r.b.i. for the overpowering first baseman, .298, 27 home runs, 102 r.b.i. for the blossoming shortstop.
The Red Sox, like the Indians, would have saved millions of dollars, an achievement akin to winning a division championship in these times of supposedly scarce money.
 
 
 
Leiter Ready to Earn His Pay
 After an injury-plagued career in which shoulder and elbow ailments limited him to 13 major league games in a four-season span, Al Leiter had reason to look forward to the winter after a healthy and effective season.
"I thought I would have enjoyed this free agency thing, but it was hands down the hardest decision I made in my life," Leiter said. "Considering the past relationships in the Toronto organization -- the fans, the city -- it was extremely difficult to leave that. The day of the signing I felt elated and joy and yet saddened and upset."
Slightly less than six weeks after his 30th birthday, the left-handed pitcher became one of baseball's off-season celebrities by signing a three-year, $8.6 million contract with Florida. The contract grabbed everyone's attention because the Marlins committed nearly $3 million a year to a pitcher who seemingly had spent more time on the disabled list than on the mound and whose career record was one game over .500 -- 33-32.
Yet Pat Gillick, the Baltimore Orioles' general manager, who traded for Leiter when he operated the Blue Jays, validated the signing by acknowledging that he, too, offered Leiter that kind of deal. Forget the past, Gillick and others pronounced; Leiter had a future.
"As an arbitration player, clubs look at your past three years," Leiter said. "My past three years were the accumulation of disabled list time and didn't amount to a whole lot. When you become a free agent, that's all thrown out the window. Scouts see that this guy's on the verge. He helped the club win a championship, and each year he's gotten stronger and healthier. I look at my situation almost like a high school or college draft pick. You give this kid a big bonus because you think he's going be a star in the big leagues."
Pitching for a team in rapid decline, Leiter had only an 11-11 record last season, but his performance exceeded those numbers. He had the eighth lowest earned run average in the American League, 3.64, and he was sixth best in opponents' batting average (.238), batting average with runners in scoring position (.220) and hits per nine innings (7.97). He led the league in walks with 108, but the Blue Jays undermined him by averaging only 3.84 runs a game when he pitched, the most meager run support for any A.L. starter.
"The scouts have been saying how nasty my stuff was," Leiter said. "To say Al Leiter is one of the top left-handers in the American League for stuff is nice to hear."
Leiter, once the most promising young pitcher in the Yankees' organization, obviously chose the right season to display his talents. In its aftermath, he emerged with such a lucrative contract that it was used as a prime example of the owners' returning to their wild-spending ways.
But, countering that characterization, Leiter said, "If these people are right, and I certainly plan to prove them right, it will turn out to be a good deal. I don't see any reason why I can't be among the top pitchers in the league if I go out and do what I'm capable of doing. I don't see it falling off; I see it getting better."
 
 
 
Who's Tuning In?
 The National Basketball Association is such the rage that the owners awarded Commissioner David Stern almost as much money as Michael Jordan makes. But people in baseball raise an intriguing and legitimate question:
If the N.B.A. is so far ahead of baseball in popularity among fans, why did its recent All-Star Game, with Jordan present for the first time in three years, draw an 11.7 television rating and baseball's All-Star Game, at the nadir of that sport's popularity last July with season attendance down by more than 20 percent, get a 13.9 rating?
 
 
 
Knoblauch Wins in Arbitration
 Arbitrators continued to be the players' favorite friends yesterday. Minnesota Twins second baseman Chuck Knoblauch became the latest player to win his salary arbitration case when Anthony Sinicropi, who heard the case Friday, awarded him his request for $4.67 million. The Twins argued for a $3.75 million salary for Knoblauch, who batted .333 and made $2,987,500 last year.
The outcome left the players with a 7-2 advantage in arbitration hearings with two cases scheduled for this week: Arthur Rhodes of Baltimore tomorrow and John Valentin of Boston on Tuesday. The last year the players prevailed in the majority of cases was 1990, when they had a 14-10 margin. In the first 20 years of salary arbitration, the players had a winning record only four other times.

HEADLINE: An Endowment Turns a Big Land Gift to Texas Into a Bonanza

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
Forty-thousand acres of rugged West Texas ranch land have been donated to the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department in what officials say is by far the largest land gift to the state.
But the property, 62 square miles of canyons, bluffs and woodland plateaus, has another feature that caught the attention of state and local officials: a private endowment to maintain the property and offset the loss of local taxes. 
 Known as the Mesquite Ranch, the tract was donated last month by the Richard King Mellon Foundation, which operates a land conservation program and has made similar bequests of Civil War battlefields, wildlife habitats, and community open spaces in 25 states since 1988.
The ranch, located in Presidio County just north of the United States-Mexico border in the Chinati Mountains, is almost 50 times the size of Central Park and will become the second-largest component in the state's park system.
But it was the endowment, established by the previous owners, Heiner and Philippa Friedrich of Houston, that made the gift even more attractive.
The money will be used to maintain the property and to offset the loss of approximately $7,600 in property tax revenue to the county and local school districts.
For a major acquisition like the Mesquite Ranch to come with an endowment is "a new phenomenon nationwide," said Barry Tindall, director of public policy at the National Recreation and Park Association in Arlington, Va.
Usually only established parks receive financing from non-government sources, Mr. Tindall said, citing Central Park as an example. The Central Park Conservancy has raised more than $100 million since 1980 and is credited with doubling the number of park employees, supporting several education programs, and financing numerous restorations and improvements.
Some land gifts have been turned down because governments do not want to be saddled with the operating costs.
In Peoria, Ill., a conservationist's proposed gift of a 2,000-acre wildlife preserve was rejected by state officials who said they could not afford to make up an annual operating deficit of $300,000.
Andrew Sansom, the executive director of Texas Parks and Wildlife, said that the endowment accompanying the tract "signals a threshold change in how we go about land acquisition."
"At a time when states are giving local governments more and more responsibilities, we shouldn't be damaging their ability to pay for services," Mr. Sansom said.
"Our department has become increasingly business-like in terms of its operations," Mr. Sansom said. "Even though a gift like the Mellon Foundation's is one of the most spectacular things we can do for the state and for the future, it's a liability. To consider its operating impact prior to the time it's acquired is fundamental."
"Though this might be a new concept for us right now, in the future a pre-existing endowment could be a condition of acquisition," Mr. Sansom said.
Judge Jake Brisbin of Presidio County said that those involved in the gift "took the time to understand the tax implications on Presidio County."
"Border counties are the state's poorest," he said. "Add issues like high unemployment and illegal immigration, and our ability to provide even basic services is jeopardized." Though a higher tourism profile for Presidio County will be welcome, he added, "the last thing we need is a smaller tax base."

HEADLINE: February 11-17;
Gas-Loving, Go-Go Americans

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
"Small Is Beautiful," the classic little book on the economics of the 1970's by E. F. Schumacher, offered a central warning: energy was the most vulnerable resource. "If energy fails, everything fails," he warned. Yet Americans have already forgotten that era of fuel rationing, long gas lines and compact, fuel-efficient cars.
Today Americans are consuming gas at ever higher levels as they embrace sport utility vehicles that give them the air of desert warriors at the shopping mall. They zip past recently raised speed limits in glorified trucks hardly known for fuel economy. 
 But half the oil consumed in America is imported, up sharply from the 1970's, and a large amount comes from Saudi Arabia and other less stable nations. Few political leaders or experts, however, are worried: revolutions in oil-producing countries have led to much higher oil prices but have not disrupted the supply. A few experts do believe that a reckoning is inevitable and that Amreicans are woefully unprepared. AGIS SALPUKAS

HEADLINE: The Top Colleges Are Reporting Record Numbers of Applications

 BODY:
The nation's prestigious colleges are being flooded with record numbers of applications as high school seniors increasingly worry about getting into the top tier, admissions officers say.
Admissions officers from the Ivy League schools, Georgetown, Tufts, Stanford and other colleges are reporting that the number of applications has risen by at least 50 percent in the last decade, while the number of high school graduates has risen only in the last year as the children of the baby boom generation reach college age. 
 "The toughness this year is in the sheer number -- we can't take everybody," said Fred Hargadon, the dean of admissions at Princeton.
Top high school students appear to be sending out more applications than ever -- more than 10, instead of the 4 or 5 common a decade ago. Admissions officers said the increase was mostly likely driven by the same fears that have generated record numbers of students seeking early acceptance.
"There are definitely students who, if they would have applied 10 years ago or 5 years ago or even 3 years ago, would have had a better chance of getting in to the top tier," said Stephen Singer, director of college counseling at the Horace Mann School in the Bronx.
David Cuttino, dean of admissions at Tufts, said its increase of 8,500 applications from last year to 11,500 this year was unprecedented.
Admissions officers and high school guidance counselors suggested a variety of reasons for the increase: stepped-up recruitment by colleges seeking diversity; S.A.T. scores that were revised upward last April, giving students false hope; electronic applications forms on computer disks; and an increase in the number of 18-year-olds in the population. But the most common explanation is that students are worried about their prospects after graduation from college.
"The state of the economy and job market is probably scaring some people into focusing on recognized institutions," said Wayne Becraft, the executive director of the 8,400-member American Association of Collegiate Registrars and Admissions Officers.
Charles Deacon, the dean of admissions at Georgetown, also agreed that students today are more concerned about their economic well-being after graduation.
"Whereas 15 years ago a college degree kind of insured your success, right now it doesn't guarantee anything," said Mr. Deacon, who has seen the number of applications grow from 6,500 in 1991 to more than 10,000 this year at Georgetown.
Students are focusing on the application process earlier and becoming more competitive, counselors said.
"There's more anxiety, more concern," said Daphne Rhodes, who runs a college-counseling service in New Jersey, "with students worrying, 'Have I done the best to prepare myself? Am I going to present myself well? What kind of classes do I need to take? What should I be doing outside class?' "
At Harvard, which received a record 18,000 applications this year, more students are including props with their written applications to get attention. The dean of admissions, William Fitzsimmons, cited everything from videotapes to all the papers a student ever wrote to Harvard logos made of chocolate.
Jon S. Katzman, president of the Princeton Review, the nation's largest S.A.T. preparation program and the publisher of a guide to colleges, said students now think in terms of getting into any good school, rather than getting into their first choice.
"Ten years ago, students were stressed because they wanted to be the winner," Mr. Katzman said. "Now, they're stressed because they don't want to be the loser."

HEADLINE: Edmund G. Brown Is Dead at 90; He Led California in Boom Years

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD 

DATELINE: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Feb. 17

 BODY:
Edmund G. (Pat) Brown, the former Governor of California who fathered the state's modern economic boom with expansive government programs to build freeways, vast water systems and public universities open to all at low cost, died on Friday at his home here. He was 90.
Mr. Brown died of a heart attack, but had been ill for some time, said a granddaughter, Kathleen Kelly. 
 The burly and ebullient Mr. Brown, a Democrat, served two terms as Governor, from 1959 until 1967, turning back a challenge from former Vice President Richard M. Nixon in 1962. But a growing conservative mood and divisiveness within his own party over student unrest and the Vietnam War led to his defeat by a conservative Republican, Ronald Reagan, in 1966. The election effectively ended nearly a quarter of a century of public service for Mr. Brown and inaugurated a national political career for the former actor.
Mr. Brown's death comes as California is struggling to recover from a post-cold-war recession that has resulted in the paring back of many social programs he helped create.
As Governor, Mr. Brown symbolized better times in California, times that the historian Kevin Starr described as "an exhilarating period in which California assembled itself as the cutting edge of the American experiment."
Prof. Bruce E. Cain, associate director of the Institute of Governmental Studies at the University of California at Berkeley, said of Mr. Brown: "He was part of an era when growth was considered a good thing, when we could afford public services that would encourage people to come to California, to add to the tax base. Everything then had a golden aura to it."
In addition, Mr. Brown left a considerable personal political legacy. His only son, Edmund G. (Jerry) Brown Jr., also served two terms as Governor of California and ran for President in 1976, 1980 and 1992. But the younger Mr. Brown's philosophy of diminished expectations seemed directly at odds with his father's.
Mr. Brown's youngest child, Kathleen Brown, was the Treasurer of California and ran unsuccessfully for Governor in 1994 against the Republican incumbent, Pete Wilson.
As Governor, Mr. Brown epitomized an era when the American public seemed to have had a greater trust in its leaders to do the right thing, and in the capacity of government to shape the future. He came into office when the California economy was slumping after the Korean War, but the state's population was growing relentlessly.
He called for more, not less, government spending -- for transportation, parks, schools and reclamation projects. Two decades of unparalleled growth and prosperity followed.
Mr. Brown, a Roman Catholic, was a gregarious, plain-spoken man known for his advocacy of progressive and populist causes in general and for his strong opposition to the death penalty in particular. In the late 1950's, some Democrats thought he might make a good Presidential candidate, but his political career ended with his loss to Mr. Reagan in 1966.
Despite that defeat, Mr. Brown remained active, both as a lawyer and an author, producing two books that were sharply critical of Mr. Reagan's performance as Governor. In another book, he condemned the death penalty as barbaric.
Mr. Brown agonized and equivocated over the death penalty when he was Governor. He ruled on 59 last-ditch appeals from condemned convicts, commuting the sentences of 23 but allowing 36 to go to the gas chamber.
One who was executed was Caryl Chessman, the "red light bandit" who had robbed and sexually assaulted women on lonely mountain roads. With self-taught legal skills, Mr. Chessman staved off execution for more than a dozen years. Governor Brown at first stayed the execution several times, but finally let it proceed in 1960.
Mr. Brown, however, ultimately grew to loathe capital punishment. "The naked, simple fact is that the death penalty has been a gross failure," he wrote. "Beyond its horror and incivility, it has neither protected the innocent nor deterred the wicked." He said he felt it was punishment primarily inflicted on "the weak, the poor, the ignorant."
As Governor, Mr. Brown oversaw the creation of a state commission on fair employment practices and the passage of two fair-housing laws, pushed the development of expanded water supplies for Southern California and worked for the creation of jobs outside the military industry.
Under his administration the state produced its Master Plan for Higher Education, a landmark document that plotted the expansion of California's college system. During his eight years as Governor, the University of California added three new campuses and the state college system added six.
He also increased benefits for the unemployed, the blind and the elderly. And in this quintessential automobile state he was instrumental in the construction of 1,000 miles of freeways.
Edmund Gerald Brown was born in San Francisco on April 21, 1905, the son of Edmund Joseph and Ida Schuckman Brown. He was one of four children born to a businessman father who had moved to California in the wake of the gold rush -- not to mine gold, but to mine Californians' yearning for cigars, photo arcades, nickelodeons and shooting galleries. The elder Mr. Brown was Catholic, his wife Protestant, and their son's early years were filled with their spirited discussions about religion.
Eddie Brown went to a Catholic school, and it was there, as a 12-year-old orator at a World War I Liberty Bond rally, that he ended his speech with Patrick Henry's "Give me liberty or give me death." Classmates began calling him Patrick Henry Brown. The shortened name Pat stuck through the rest of his academic and political careers.
At Lowell High School, Pat Brown gave ample evidence of what was to come, running for 11 student offices and winning each time. But he lacked the money to attend college, so he went to work in his father's cigar store after high school and studied law at night. In 1927 he received a law degree from the San Francisco College of Law.
Although he was identified with the progressive wing of the Democratic Party for most of his life, Mr. Brown started his political career as a Republican, losing a campaign for a seat in the State Assembly in 1928. Four years later he changed to the Democratic Party, but his political fortunes did not immediately improve; in 1939 he ran unsuccessfully for District Attorney of San Francisco.
In 1940 he worked hard for the re-election of President Franklin D. Roosevelt. Mr. Brown served as a delegate to the Democratic National Convention that year; it was a role he continued to fill until the 1960's.
In 1943, Mr. Brown was elected District Attorney in San Francisco. He held that post until 1950, when he became Attorney General of California. He made his reputation in that post by investigating the scandal-ridden State Liquor Administration.
In 1958 he ran for governor against William F. Knowland, a right-wing Republican who had resigned from the United States Senate to make the race. Mr. Brown won by more than a million votes out of nearly five million cast.
Governor Brown once described his politics as "liberal and responsible" and as "reasonable, rational and realistic." He was very much a part of the bipartisan era of California politics, and shared the philosophy of one of his progressive Republican predecessors, Earl Warren, later Chief Justice of the United States.
"One had a suspicion Earl Warren was happy to see Pat Brown as Governor," said Mr. Starr, the historian, who is now the state librarian of California.
The high point of Mr. Brown's first term was probably the enactment in 1960 of the Master Plan for Higher Education, the cornerstone for the three-tiered system of more than 100 public colleges in California.
He also oversaw the beginning of the State Water Project, a huge system of dams and aqueducts that to this day provides irrigation for Southern California and makes the state's agricultural production the largest in the nation.
In 1962, after a bitter election campaign, Mr. Brown defeated Mr. Nixon by nearly 300,000 votes out of the more than 5.6 million cast. The defeat led Mr. Nixon to blurt his famous remark to reporters, "You won't have Dick Nixon to kick around anymore."
In 1966 Mr. Brown was upset in his bid for a third term by Mr. Reagan, then a political novice, who won by more than 900,000 votes out of six million cast.
Mr. Brown's loss came at a time of tumultuous civil unrest. The Watts section of Los Angeles still simmered after the racial riots there in 1965, and opposition to the Vietnam War was growing, particularly among young people. Some political analysts ascribed the defeat to a white backlash vote coupled with mounting voter concern over antiwar demonstrations at Berkeley and other campuses.
Many voters thought that the Governor had been too slow to move against the students and that Mr. Reagan, a hard-line conservative, would be better able to deal with them. Mr. Starr said Mr. Brown once told him that his political demise was rooted in his handling of the Chessman execution. In one of his last acts as Governor, he spared the lives of four condemned murderers.
Although he often seemed bumbling in public appearances, Mr. Brown was regarded by many Californians, Republicans as well as Democrats, as both a builder and a decent man.
"He was a builder, one of the governors responsible for laying the foundation that allowed California to take off the way it did," said Steven A. Merksamer, who was chief of staff to former Gov. George Deukmejian, a Republican.
Mr. Brown was honored by a special session of the State Legislature in 1992. But because of his failing health, he rarely appeared in public after that.
Mr. Brown is survived by his wife, the former Bernice Layne, whom he married in 1930. Besides his son, Edmund Jr., and daughter Kathleen, he is survived by two other daughters, Barbara Brown Casey and Cynthia Brown Kelly.

HEADLINE: THE POLITICAL TERRAIN;
Where the Government Is Kept at Arm's Length

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 17

 BODY:
When Congress approved the Goals 2000 education program two years ago, most state governments were delighted.
The program, setting national standards to improve the public schools, had been developed by the Bush Administration in conjunction with the nation's governors and embraced by President Clinton. It meant millions of new Federal dollars for strapped local school boards. 
 But New Hampshire so far has declined to apply for the $9 million in Federal grants to which it is entitled. Communities here, Gov. Stephen Merrill explains, simply do not need more money with Federal strings attached. That despite the fact that one-fifth of New Hampshire's schools do not meet the state's own minimum standards, and the state has no public kindergartens.
Outsiders who pay attention to New Hampshire only every four years, for the Presidential primaries, tend to think that such quirky principles are as outmoded as the giant textile mills that dominated the state's economy in the 19th century.
But Jere Daniell, a historian at Dartmouth College who specializes in the history and the mores of New England, argues that New Hampshire is now actually in the vanguard of American politics.
"The most powerful political force in America today is decentralization," Professor Daniell said, "and this is by far the most decentralized state."
In this respect, he added, "New Hampshire is the most radical state in the Union."
Indeed, New Hampshire residents prefer an arm's length relationship not just with Washington but also with Concord, their state capital. This is the only state besides Alaska without a general income or sales tax.
Money for schools, welfare and other services is raised mostly through local property taxes. In most instances, the authority to make final governmental decisions lies not with the State Legislature or even municipal councils but with town meetings.
The antipathy to Federal and state taxes is nothing new. Before the Revolutionary War, according to the Almanac of American Politics, New Hampshirites made fortunes poaching in the king's forests and smuggling to avoid taxes.
For the last 20 years or so, the opposition to taxes has been a decisive factor in Republican Presidential primaries here. Ronald Reagan, who won in 1980, favored an across-the-board tax cut, and his main opponent, George Bush, did not. Mr. Bush learned his lesson. Eight years later, he defeated Senator Bob Dole after signing a pledge not to raise taxes while Mr. Dole refused to do so.
So it should have been no surprise when taxes became the hot issue in this year's race. Last month, Steve Forbes caught fire with his proposal for a low, flat Federal income tax. Other Republican candidates have responded with tax-cut proposals of their own.
Since the 1960's, liberal Massachusetts to the south has attracted a larger share of high-technology businesses. Liberal Vermont to the west has become more of a center for tourism. But New Hampshire, with its low taxes and fewer state services, has prospered in a way that has outstripped its neighbors.
Since 1960, the population of New Hampshire, now about 1.2 million, has doubled, the fastest growth of any state in the Northeast. The poverty rate, 7.7 percent in 1994, is about half the national rate. The crime rate is the third-lowest in the nation, behind those of West Virginia and North Dakota. S.A.T. scores are high. The infant mortality rate is low. Per capita income is well above the national average. The unemployment rate, 3.2 percent at the end of last year, is well below the nationwide rate of 5.6 percent.
But New Hampshirites do not see these as particularly good times. Perhaps the reason is that, prosperous though the state is, its economy has not fully rebounded to where it was in the late 1980's.
It is unclear what the implications of this will be in the primary election on Tuesday -- whether, say, the voters will respond more to Mr. Forbes's flat tax or to Senator Dole's concentration on balancing the budget or to Patrick J. Buchanan's advocacy of trade restrictions.
But New Hampshire being New Hampshire, the economy will almost certainly be the decisive issue. In Iowa, conservative Christians controlled many of the caucuses, and issues like abortion and family values were central. In New Hampshire, according to Linda Fowler, a professor of government at Dartmouth who conducts public opinion polls, conservative Christians make up only about 10 percent of likely voters in the Republican primary.
One New Hampshirite, former Senator Warren B. Rudman, said Washington political analysts often incorrectly associated the state's voters with Meldrim Thomson Jr., the outspoken Governor of the 1970's who made news when he wanted to arm the National Guard with nuclear weapons, and with the archconservative Manchester Union Leader, the state's largest newspaper, which once described Martin Luther King Jr. as a tool of Communists.
Actually, Mr. Rudman said, the typical Republican voter in New Hampshire, though very conservative on economic issues, is quite moderate on social matters.
But there may not really be a typical Republican voter in New Hampshire, beyond the fact that almost all voters here are white, given a statewide black population that is only about 0.5 percent of the total.
Most of the state's people live within 50 miles of the Massachusetts line. Nashua, the second-largest city, with a population of 80,000, is basically an exurb of Boston, filled with young families attracted by the lower taxes and the less expensive real estate in New Hampshire. The largest city, Manchester, about 20 minutes north of Nashua on the turnpike, is a commercial center. The voters in this area tend to be less conservative on social issues than the rural voters who live north of Concord.
In the end, the outcome on Tuesday may turn on independent voters, who are allowed to vote in party primaries. They make up about 30 percent of the general electorate, compared with the 38 percent who are registered Republicans and the 31 percent who are registered Democrats.
The problem is that no one knows how many independents will vote in the Republican primary. If the proportion is only 15 percent or so of all the primary's voters, look for Mr. Dole and Mr. Buchanan to come out ahead. But if the proportion is up to 25 or 30 percent, then Mr. Forbes and Lamar Alexander can be expected to do well.

HEADLINE: Spacecraft Is Off on 3-Year Voyage to Asteroid

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 17

 BODY:
The space agency launched a spacecraft today on a three-year voyage to an asteroid that may contain clues to the birth of the solar system.
An unmanned Delta rocket blasted off at 3:43 P.M. with the craft, bound for the asteroid Eros, one of the largest asteroids orbiting the sun relatively close to Earth. The probe is expected to reach Eros in February 1999, after a journey of 1.3 billion miles, and become the first spacecraft to orbit an asteroid. 
 "We'll get the first really good close-up look at an asteroid," said a project scientist, Andrew Cheng of the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory.
The spacecraft, called Near, for the project's name, Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous, is to circle Eros for nearly a year, flying as close as 10 miles to its rocky surface. Eros, a potato-shaped asteroid, is estimated to be 25 miles long, 9 miles wide and 9 miles deep, and may contain materials dating to the origin of the solar system 4.6 billion years ago.
The next two months will be critical as the spacecraft hurtles farther from Earth and as its five science instruments are activated in stages. After that, it will be a matter of "keeping our noses to the grindstone and making sure we bring back the goods," Dr. Cheng said.
Early signals from the spacecraft indicate that it is on course and working well. The spacecraft is also expected to fly within 750 miles of another asteroid, Mathilde, in 1997, and then head back toward Earth to use its gravity to help put it on the same orbital plane as Eros.
Once at Eros, Near will measure the mass, density and composition of that asteroid and, the space agency hopes, provide a better understanding of how Earth and the other planets were formed. Scientists say they are not certain whether Eros is a fragment of a ruptured former planet or a primitive celestial body that never evolved.
The findings should also contribute to the study of how to keep asteroids from crashing into Earth and help determine whether it is feasible to send astronauts to an asteroid, a goal some scientists have espoused.
At $122 million, the spacecraft is one of the least expensive deep-space probes ever flown and is the first in a series of low-cost efforts in NASA's push for faster, cheaper and better designs in financially tight times.
"This is really an exciting and defining event for space science," said the agency's space science chief, Wesley Huntress Jr.
NASA's economizing effort limits the cost for spacecraft to $150 million and development time to three years. Johns Hopkins came in under on both counts. The total mission cost for Near is $223 million, including the cost of launching and four years of operations.
The program is to continue with the launching of a spacecraft every year or so, Mr. Huntress said, with the next one being the Mars Pathfinder, which is scheduled for takeoff to Mars in December.
The craft launch today was supposed to have been launched on Friday, but it was delayed by problems with the rocket-tracking system at Cape the Canaveral Air Station.

HEADLINE: Clinton Backing Vast Effort To Restore Florida Swamps

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
President Clinton has decided to endorse a huge project to protect the Everglades by spending hundreds of millions of dollars to take farmland out of production and restore a more natural flow of fresh water across Florida's swampy southern half, according to senior Administration officials.
Environmentalists have been urging such a project for years over intense opposition from the region's sugar cane growers. It would be one of the biggest ecological restoration efforts ever undertaken, the Administration officials said. 
 Over the next 10 to 20 years, its effects would be felt across a region bursting with some of the nation's fastest growing metropolitan areas, where tourism and agriculture vie in an economy that has grown at the expense of an aquatic ecosystem unlike any other on the planet.
The plan is expected to be announced by Vice President Al Gore on Monday at Everglades National Park, which contains the most pristine remnants of the vast marsh of saw grass that was largely drained earlier in the century, either to be turned into farmland or to supply cities with water and protect them from floods.
The Everglades restoration project has been in planning for three years, during continuous debate over its effects on agriculture, urban water supplies and the environment. This is the first time that the White House has given the enormous project its blessing or declared that the sugar industry must help pay for it, as environmentalists have been demanding for years.
The proposed expansion of existing efforts to reverse the Everglades' decline would be financed in part by fees imposed on the region's sugar industry, Administration officials said. For years, environmentalists, who blame sugar growers for much of the harm to the Everglades, have been campaigning to impose a two-cent tax on every pound of sugar produced in the Everglades region. The Administration is expected to endorse a one-cent tax, although other options have also been discussed.
Many elements of the Administration's plan, including any new fees on the sugar industry, would have to be approved by Congress, where the prospects for action this year are uncertain. But Administration officials noted that restoring the Everglades is a popular cause in the Florida Congressional delegation, and said they had high hopes of winning approval.
Administration officials called the new plan one of the most significant environmental efforts of the Clinton Presidency, surpassing in scope even the famous plan for managing the spotted owl habitat of the Pacific Northwest forests.
It calls for the Federal Government to spend an additional $500 million or more during the next several years, on top of the $100 million or so that Federal agencies already spend each year to protect the Everglades. The additional spending is a much bigger expansion than the Senate recently approved in passing a new farm bill, and it represents something of a bidding war, just before the Florida Presidential primaries, between the Administration and top Republicans, including Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas.
The White House decision to push ahead attests to the political potency that the Administration attributes to environmental issues, and to the importance of Florida in the Presidential campaign.
Environmental groups are welcoming the Clinton Administration's approach.
"We are talking about a lot of money, we are talking about a lot of land, and we are talking about ecosystem restoration on a scale we have never seen before anywhere in the world," said Ron Tipton, who is in charge of the Everglades project at the World Wildlife Fund.
In effect, the plan would try to erase much of the human signature that has been etched with levees, canals and pumping stations on the central and southern Florida landscape in the past half century.
"This is the replumbing of South Florida," said one senior Administration official.
At the core of the plan is what scientists call an urgent need to restore the natural hydrologic patterns before the Everglades disappear entirely.
In the past, water flowed south from the headwaters of the Kissimmee River to Lake Okeechobee, where it overflowed seasonally, spilling over the lake's southern shores and drifting in a broad, grassy sheet down the ever-so-subtle slope to Florida Bay.
Now, that terrain is crisscrossed by a thousand miles of canals and levees, some of which divert the system's water directly out to the Atlantic tides.
While it is impossible to bring about a complete return to the natural water cycles of a hundred years ago, with their extensive floods, studies have shown how to imitate some of the natural rhythms of the water flow, without which the vestiges of the Everglades would likely continue to dwindle.
According to specialists involved in the planning, it requires two things: an engineering project on the scale of the one that took decades to drain the land at mid-century, and the purchase of a huge swath of land, on the order of 100,000 acres, mostly at the southern end of the Everglades Agricultural Area below Lake Okeechobee.
"That land would be the heart being restored to the Everglades," said one senior Administration official.
The plan was worked out in the last month by a task force under Vice President Gore along with such high-level Administration officials as Carol M. Browner, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency; Alice M. Rivlin, Director of the Office of Management and Budget; Kathleen A. McGinty, Director of the White House Council on Environmental Quality; and Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, as well as Florida State officials.
It would go well beyond the provisions of a landmark settlement on water quality reached between sugar companies and the state and Federal governments in 1993 and ratified by the Florida Legislature in the Everglades Forever Act of 1994. That called for a program of land acquisition and water treatment costing an estimated $700 million, including as much as $312 million contributed by the sugar companies, which over the years have been accused of polluting Everglades waters with fertilizer-laden runoff.
The companies have said that is all they are willing to spend. But the Administration is now seeking hundreds of millions of dollars more.
Administration officials called the new fees an attempt to recapture from the sugar industry "a fair share" of the perennial subsidies that have enabled it to take root in Florida.
Like other elements of the Administration's proposal, any new Federal fees on sugar would have to be approved by Congress, either in the farm bill now being debated or in separate legislation. The cost of the project is likely to be shared by Florida as well.
Despite opposition from farmers -- whose activities in the drained areas also include growing vegetables and raising cattle -- restoring the Everglades enjoys broad support in Florida, partly because the demise of the ecosystem has harmed offshore waters like Florida Bay, where fishing and tourism are major industries.
The White House's plan calls for a great deal of further scientific research into how the complex and delicate Everglades functions as an ecosystem. Questions of water flow, biological diversity, invasions by foreign species, and water monitoring need to be better understood before all the decisions can be made about how much land to buy, and where.
But some engineering work that is already under way on on the drawing boards will be accelerated under the plan, Administration officials said.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: PARTY ISSUES;
MANY REPUBLICANS FEAR PARTY RIFTS MAY COST ELECTION

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 17

 BODY:
Many prominent Republicans say they fear that the rancor in the Presidential contest has so magnified tensions among social and economic conservatives that the party risks unraveling much like the Democrats did in their failed efforts to win the Presidency in most of the 1970's and 1980's.
Buoyed by their takeover of Congress in 1994, Republicans had expected the party to rally on the Presidential level and win back the White House. Instead, many said they were worried that the emergence of Patrick J. Buchanan as an energetic competitor for the nomination, and the relative weakness of the front-runner, Senator Bob Dole, have brought to the forefront divisions that for years the party tried to play down. 
 Indeed, many leading Republicans -- conservatives and moderates alike -- who had criticized Democrats and the media for making too much of the party's rifts are now acknowledging publicly that they are very real. They complain that Mr. Buchanan's rise has given a louder voice to issues that have been anathema to the party, like protectionism, and to groups of voters like religious conservatives.
Despite such concerns, some Republicans say they are hopeful that the party's troubles are not permanent and may be driven by the heat of the campaign -- particularly in the early part of the race in Iowa and New Hampshire where the candidates feel obliged to attack early and often to prove their conservative credentials. They held out the possibility that a candidate would be nominated who can patch up the differences.
"We seem to be tearing ourselves apart," said Steven Merksamer, a lawyer and Republican consultant in Sacramento who is an adviser to the Dole campaign. "At some point, the leadership of our party has to step in and say, enough is enough, or we're going to be relegated to a very bad fate on Election Day."
Referring to President Reagan's rule that Republican candidates should never attack one another, Frank J. Fahrenkopf, the party's national chairman from 1983 to 1989, said: "They all seem to have forgotten Ronald Reagan's 11th Commandment. With the incessant negative attacks, they're down a slippery slope right now."
Even Gov. John M. Engler of Michigan, one of the party's most popular figures, said he was concerned that long-shot candidates like Morry Taylor, a tire manufacturer, had not allowed the major contenders to get their messages across at debates and other events. "They are not serious candidates," said Mr. Engler, who is staying neutral in the Republican primaries. "They are just taking up space."
Lamenting the "just staggering" volatility in the Republican field only three days before the nation's first primary in this state, Mr. Engler predicted that for the first time in years, whoever wins the primary here might not win the nomination. "We still have the history that you have to win New Hampshire," he said. "But this may well be the year that that goes by the boards."
Unlike the Democrats, who are known for divisive primary battles, Republicans usually have far less infighting and nominate a candidate who is favored by the political establishment. But now, Republicans seem to be behaving more like Democrats, with the intramural jabbing of the insurgent Mr. Buchanan reminiscent of Jesse Jackson's effort to take on Democratic leaders when he ran in 1984 and 1988.
"Now the Republicans have many of the same troubles the Democrats have had for years," William Kristol, a leading conservative who is publisher of The Weekly Standard, said. "There is a splintered field with candidates who represent mobilized blocks of the party who have no incentive to unite or compromise." He added, "Every Republican I've talked to is pretty morose."
Another telling sign of the unease appeared on Friday on the editorial page of The Wall Street Journal, an influential voice of economic conservatism. A lead editorial under the headline "McGovern Republicans" opened with this lament: "Standing at the edge of a potential 40-year reign in American politics, the Republican Party now finds itself pondering a detour into the political wilderness." Warning that the party could transform itself "into the mirror image of the Democrats," a party where "the only people who can be nominated are people who can't win."
The editorial was written before the candidates' forum here on Thursday night, which was marked by personal attacks and gave Republicans even more grist for their disenchantment.
His seven opponents were so combative that Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana scolded them over the unusually negative tenor of the campaign.
"This campaign has already so demeaned the political process in this country," Mr. Lugar said, "that Americans wonder what kind of a party we have and what kind of people aspire to the Presidency."
In an optimistic note, Mr. Fahrenkopf said, "We're a party that's been able to heal." He added: "If we have a nominee by the end of March, it does give us five or six months prior to the convention to mend the fences."
But others say the strains would not be so easily repaired. They complain that the public face of the Republican Party as the party that vowed to remake Congress and return power to the people has been replaced by the picture of Presidential candidates slashing one another. In fact, any mention of the Congress, and the House Republicans' vaunted Contract with America, is nowhere to be found in the dialogue among the candidates. Mr. Dole, for one, said recently that the Republican Congress needs to get moving and pass new laws.
Mr. Buchanan, a former commentator who finished second in the Iowa caucuses and is rising in the polls here, is viewed as contributing most to the unease, not only for his political beliefs but because of his history of inflammatory remarks that are anathema to many Republicans. Polls show that Mr. Buchanan has particularly high negative ratings even in his own party.
After Mr. Buchanan's controversial address at the Republican Convention in 1992, many Republicans tried to distance themselves from him. But his showing in Iowa raised Mr. Buchanan's profile in the party, and in American politics, and it is now the highest it has ever been.
Even some of the most conservative groups are in an uproar over Mr. Buchanan's ascension. "It's one thing to be very conservative, which I am, and another thing to be a little kooky," said the Rev. Louis P. Sheldon, chairman of the Traditional Values Coalition. He expressed concern about Mr. Buchanan's "relationship with blacks and Asians and with Israel."
Mr. Sheldon said he had favored Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, who withdrew last week, and now will probably back Alan Keyes, a former State Department official.
The division between economic and social conservatives has become increasingly stark -- and more complex -- in recent months and is at the root of the problems the party now faces. Economic conservatives are most concerned about pushing proposals to spur the economy like cutting taxes and spending. But even differences have broken out among that wing of the party over the importance of balancing versus encouraging growth through proposals like a flat tax. Social conservatives contend that the central themes of the party should be issues like opposition to abortion.
Many well-known Republicans said that they viewed Mr. Dole as a leader who could help pull the party together. But they expressed surprise about his political weakness -- and questioned whether other contenders, like former Gov. Lamar Alexander, the third-place finisher in Iowa, would have the stature or the ability to pull the party together.
Some of these Republicans blame the candidacy of Steve Forbes, the publishing magnate, for dumping millions of dollars into negative television commercials. They also say his moderate views on social issues like abortion and gays in the military are at odds with many Republicans.
Richard Brookhiser, a senior editor at the National Review, a conservative magazine, said he was troubled about the state of the party given the Republican successes in 1994. "You have to be concerned if people are taking a winning formula and junking it," he said of the Republican candidates. The magazine had backed Mr. Gramm but cannot support Mr. Buchanan, he said, because of his "protectionist kick" or Mr. Alexander because "we are not really sure what he stands for."
"At the end of the day," Mr. Brookhiser added, "Dole may seem to be the best of the lot, but it isn't anything that makes you enthusiastic."
Several Republicans said the discordant state of the Republican field reminds them of the Democrats in 1984. They argue that Mr. Buchanan is not popular enough in the party to win the nomination, but, as Mr. Jackson did to Walter F. Mondale in 1984, he could stay in the race and try to pull the party to his positions -- and leave the nominee damaged in the general election.
Some Republicans said the only option for the party was to let the primaries play out and see what happens. "What can be done about it?" Mr. Kristol asked. "It's too late in the day to draft Colin Powell."

HEADLINE: Clinton Urged To Cite Mexico For Drug Flow

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Armed with a flood of intelligence showing that Mexico has become a huge conduit for cocaine, methamphetamines, marijuana and heroin sold in the United States, Federal narcotics officials are urging the Clinton Administration to drop Mexico from a list of countries making progress against drug trafficking.
If the Administration takes such a drastic step against Mexico -- and the odds are still against it though a final decision has not been made -- it would almost certainly be accompanied by a waiver that would allow Mexico to continue receiving aid. 
 But the effect would be to brand Mexico as a narco-state like Colombia, Bolivia and Peru.
The Administration has been willing to use certification as a weapon against drug-producing countries. Some officials credit last year's decertification of Colombia, albeit with a waiver that allowed aid to continue, as a pivotal step that prodded the Government to arrest several top figures in the Cali cocaine cartel.
"We've used certification before in the case of Colombia where we knocked the legs from underneath the Cali cartel, and it is under review now in the case of Mexico," a White House official said today.
The dynamics of the discussion over Mexico, and an equally sharp debate about how to deal with Colombia this year, are shaped by a provision of the Foreign Assistance Act that requires the President to announce by March 1 each year which nations will be officially listed, or certified, as cooperating in fighting drugs. Those determined to be failing to make such efforts can be decertified, but can get a "vital national interest" waiver.
Colombia continues to be part of the certification battle. If the Administration determines that Colombia is no longer cooperating and decertifies it, some officials say the move could be a final blow to President Ernesto Samper, who this week was formally charged with financing his presidential campaign with more than $3 million in Cali cartel funds.
Moreover, decertification would open the possibility of trade sanctions against legitimate Colombian industries like flowers, coffee and sugar.
In the case of Mexico, denying certification would anger the Mexican Government. Mexican officials in Washington said they refused to recognize the legitimacy of the certification process and viewed it as an unjustified intrusion into Mexico's internal affairs.
But certifying Mexico as making progress on drug enforcement seems likely to create political repercussions for the Clinton Administration at the start of the Presidential election campaign.
Lawmakers in both parties have criticized Mexico's efforts as inadequate. Some, like Senators Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican, and Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, have sponsored legislation urging the Administration to decertify Mexico.
At the same time, a growing number of Federal narcotics officials express frustration over what they view as a preoccupation by American policymakers with economic stabilization and trade issues, while they play down the enormous surge of Mexican drug trafficking and its toll in crime, misery and corruption on both sides of the border.
Narcotics officials have issued a stream of reports detailing the growth of the Mexican drug cartels.
At first, the reports say, the Colombian organizations hired Mexican smuggling gangs to ferry drugs across the border for delivery to Colombian distributors in the United States. But in recent years, the trade has undergone a transformation.
Increasingly, Colombians pay the Mexican rings not with cash but with drugs, usually a pound of cocaine for each pound brought across the border. As a result, the Mexicans have turned into large-scale dealers, acquiring their own distribution territories in the United States. A few Mexican traffickers have grown into multibillon-dollar dealers with extensive contacts in the Government and the police, law officials say.
Some Federal drug enforcement experts fear that Mexico may be only a few years away from a point of no return when drug cartels have so deeply penetrated the country's criminal justice and political systems that anti-drug and anti-corruption efforts have little chance of success.
These officials are pressing for a tougher approach now, arguing that a conditional decertification would send a necessary rebuke southward, in effect demanding more aggressive steps against drug trafficking.
But using the annual certification as a weapon against Mexico is colliding with longstanding American foreign policy goals. Some State Department officials oppose stripping Mexico of its certification on grounds that it would undercut the relationship between the Administration and the Government of President Ernesto Zedillo, who longtime drug enforcement officials say is seriously committed to battling his country's traffickers.
Moreover, traditional architects of American policy in the State Department contend that the central objective of American policy in Mexico rests on strengthening the Mexican economy. This was also the rationale behind the emphasis on the North American Free Trade Agreement and the Administration's decision last year to sidestep Congress in arranging a $20 billion rescue package to help keep Mexico from defaulting on its obligations.
Denying certification, these officials have argued, could only weaken the Government of Mr. Zedillo when he has demonstrated progress against the drug trafficking elite. Administration officials said President Clinton, in meetings with Mr. Zedillo in Washington in October, expressed the Administration's desire for tangible steps against narcotics trafficking.
Those discussions, in which the Mexican President is said by officials to have voiced his own concerns over drug trafficking as a national security issue, have been followed by closer cooperation between American and Mexican drug enforcement units on the Southwest border and by concrete actions, like last month's arrest of Juan Garcia Abrego, the Mexican drug lord on the F.B.I.'s most wanted list.
