HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS 

 BODY:

FILTERS (I)
Offensive Yes, Indecent No
Reviewing the telecommunications law signed recently by President Clinton, a Federal district judge in Philadelphia upheld the ban on "patently offensive" material that might be transmitted over computer networks in a manner accessible to minors. But Judge Ronald L. Buckwalter temporarily blocked enforcement of the ban on transmission of "indecent" material, agreeing with civil liberties groups, which had sued, that the provision was unconstitutionally vague. A swift judicial review is planned.
Earlier in the week, the on-line service Compuserve said it would restore access to 200 sex-related computer data bases that it had recently blocked and would provide subscribers with software that could be used to filter material. The company said it had decided that censorship should begin at home and not with the government. The change puts Compuserve, which is owned by H & R Block, on the same footing as its rivals America Online and Prodigy. 

FILTERS (II)
Weighed and Found Wanting
Trying to head off Government-imposed ratings and at the same time respond to growing complaints about the sexual and violent content of some programming, the four major television networks want to develop a self-imposed rating system similar to what the film industry employs. Fox said it was close to adopting the ratings regardless of whether the other networks went along. The industry ratings might then become the basis on which viewers could block certain types of programming, using the V-chip that the new telecommunications law requires all new television sets to carry. Network officials hope to have the ratings system in place before they meet with President Clinton later in the month.
(Table gives the current ratings for motion pictures)
 
POLITICS AND THE ECONOMY
Republicans Just Say No
The White House wanted the New York investment banker Felix G. Rohatyn to become vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, and Mr. Rohatyn wanted it even more, campaigning vigorously for the post. But Republicans on the Senate Banking Committee made clear they would not approve the nomination, and the Administration backed off. The Clinton team complained that the Republicans were playing political games; the Republicans responded that Mr. Rohatyn, a managing director at Lazard Freres, was too far outside the economic mainstream and too unconcerned about inflation. The name-calling came amid a spate of fresh data that showed the economy was slowing somewhat sharply and that inflationary pressure was virtually nonexistent.

BREAKUPS
Dial to Split in 2
After 17 acquisitions since 1981, John W. Teets, head of the Dial Corporation, announced that the company would divide in two, with one company providing travel services and the other offering consumer products. The travel services include Travelers Express money orders, a cruise line and a majority stake in Greyhound Lines of Canada. The consumer products include Dial soap, Breck shampoo, Armour Star canned meats, Purex detergents and Brillo scouring pads. The plan fell short with investors, as Dial's stock dropped xx, to xxx, on Friday.

LIABILITIES
Dow Corning Wins a Round
In a victory that could help Dow Corning emerge from bankruptcy protection and may also provide more money to plaintiffs in breast-implant cases, a Michigan jury ruled that 30 insurance companies must provide the company with about $400 million in liability coverage. Dow Corning, a joint venture of Dow Chemical and Corning Inc., sought protection from creditors in May, saying it was overwhelmed with health claims related to implants. The company previously settled with other insurers to receive about $1 billion of coverage.
 
THE NEW YORK ECONOMY
A Call for Billions
A major planning group said billions of dollars of improvements were needed in transportation, education and other areas to avoid long-term decline in the New York metropolitan area. The Regional Plan Association said the problem had shifted from managing growth to "finding growth" and warned that if the commitment was not made to make improvements, "We're going to be left behind."

AIDS
Seeking Industry Cooperation
Federal health officials released a blueprint for encouraging development of an AIDS vaccine, hoping to revive corporate interest in the project. The number of companies involved in trying to develop a vaccine has declined in recent years. The blueprint will spell out in advance the specific scientific guideposts that must be met to propel a vaccine along the licensing path.
 
COMPUTERS
Sour Taste at Apple
For the first time, Apple Computer suspended payment of a quarterly dividend and said it did not foresee one in the near future. The announcement was widely viewed as the first step by the new chairman and chief executive, Gilbert F. Amelio, in turning around the ailing computer maker. Apple also disclosed details of Mr. Amelio's compensation: he will receive a minimum salary and bonus of $2.5 million annually and could get as much as $10 million a year.
(Graph tracks Apple's quarterly dividend per share since 1987)
 
HOLLYWOOD
Come Play in My Yard
Frank J. Biondi Jr., ousted last month from Viacom by its chairman, Sumner M. Redstone, has been invited by Edgar Bronfman Jr. to lead the team running MCA, people involved in the discussions said. All the principals in the talks have declined to comment, but those in the know say Mr. Biondi was offered the post of chief executive at MCA. The president of MCA, Ron Meyer, who was recruited by Mr. Bronfman from Creative Artists, is generally viewed as long on Hollywood skills but on less familiar ground in corporate finance.

HEADLINE: The Training's for a Real Job (Cooking)

BYLINE: By KAREN BERMAN 

 BODY:
THINGS had gotten bad for Alston Duncan. A single parent with a young son, he was laid off from his job as a cook in a nursing home and after searching in vain for another job that would enable him to have child care, he wound up on welfare, a client of the Aid to Families With Dependent Children program.
"I had to take care of my son," the New Haven resident said simply. 
 Then he heard a radio announcement, an advertisement for Connecticut Hospitality Careers training. "I went down there," he said, completed a 12-week course and got a job at Splash, a Westport restaurant. This time, when the waterfront restaurant laid off most of its kitchen staff (the summer rush was over), Mr. Duncan was one of two cooks chosen to stay on.
"It helped me a lot," Mr. Duncan said of his training. "A lot of things I do at Splash I learned at school."
Connecticut Hospitality Careers has been training students like Mr. Duncan for the past five years, and with the state's new 21-month limit on A.F.D.C., the program is likely to become increasingly popular.
According to Tad Graham-Handley, vice president and chief operating officer of the Connecticut Culinary Institute, which runs the program, an average of 87 percent of enrollees graduate and get jobs. And, he said, the demand for food service workers, both cooks and bakers, is expected to increase well into the next century.
"With welfare reform, people are looking for programs they can complete in a relatively short period of time," said Julie Watson, assistant director of the Meriden-Middlesex Regional Workforce Development Board, one of nine public/private agencies in the state that administer funds for training programs.
"A lot of the fields that people might go into with the amount of training we offer are flat," said Ms. Watson, whose agency uses Federal Job Training Partnership Act moneys to underwrite training programs. "We're funding this program because the data show growth in the food service field."
The regional boards contract with vocational schools and training services, like the Farmington-based Connecticut Culinary Institute, to run their programs. So far, seven of the boards have made contracts with the culinary institute at a cost of $35,000 per 12-week class of 10 students. Some 500 students have completed the program since its inception.
"This program works," said Mr. Graham-Handley. "The payback period on this program is very short for the taxpayer." Students often have jobs lined up even before they graduate.
"They really get a lot of support in a lot of different ways," said Julie Barrett, manager of contract training for the program.
"We're taught all the basics," said Tony Pina. "Theory and practice go hand in hand." As he spoke, displayed trays of muffins and apple tarts, the result of an early-morning baking session.
Classes are conducted in various locations -- Hamden, Hartford, New London, Torrington, Middletown, Norwalk and Waterbury. Mr. Graham-Handley and his staff have found that church kitchens make good teaching areas. The congregations, which represent a spectrum of faiths, are happy to do their part to help, he said, and they usually offer their kitchens free of charge. Connecticut Hospitality Careers reimburses its hosts for utilities. All the enrollees are poor and at least 65 percent suffer from other "barriers to employment," the Federal training bureaucracy's term for those who did not complete high school, are deficient in basic skills, have received welfare, are disabled or have a history of substance abuse or incarceration. About half of the students are on some form of welfare.
Enrollees vary in background and skill level. Some are simply victims of the sluggish economy while others are beset by a variety of problems. Some have experience in food service while others have only cooked at home.
Diane Lambert, for example, had worked in a meat business for 24 years when she was laid off in 1991. After an unsuccessful search for a comparable job, she decided to change directions because, as she put it, with a family to care for, "most of the time I was in the kitchen anyway." "I figured I might as well make a career of it." Weeks before graduation Ms. Lambert landed a job at the Hometown Buffet in Hamden and soon was promoted to head its pantry department.
"Every day you have to learn something new," she said. "You have to keep your mind open."
The students start by learning basic knife techniques and sanitation procedures and move on to sauces, stocks, spices, roasting, braising, breads, pastry, presentation and other kitchen basics. Field trips to restaurants and food purveyors supplement their classwork.
Within a few weeks they are helping to manage inventory and taking turns cooking entire meals, which are eaten and critiqued by the group. One day the menu might consist of sauteed halibut with citrus beurre blanc served with new potatoes, asparagus and baby carrots. The next day it might be cream of broccoli soup, New York strip steak, broiled potatoes and cheesecake with raspberry sauce.
Basic math skills and knowledge of measures and equivalents are polished. By the end of the course, all the students are sprouting French culinary terms. The curriculum, however, covers more than recipes.
"The cooking is extremely important here but at least as important is professionalism," said Mr. Graham-Handley. Students review job-seeking skills, going through mock interviews, preparing resumes and cover letters, and contacting prospective employers.
On-the-job skills emphasize punctuality and team work.
"We have all these key words: control, discipline and respect," explained Ms. Barrett, a former head chef.
At the center of these lessons is the chef-instructor. "The chef-instructors are part Mother Teresa, part George Patton and part Escoffier," said Mr. Graham-Handley, a former executive chef.
At a recent session conducted in Hamden, Gary Roberts was in charge as eight students carried out eight assignments. The chef fielded questions about everything from kiwi Bavarian to the next day's assignments.
"I wouldn't trade this job for anything in the world," said Mr. Roberts.
"Chef Roberts helps out and he makes sure you remember," said Michael Cohens of New Haven, in the midst of biscuit making. "When the test comes you can't say, 'I don't remember.' " Mr. Cohens explained that although he had never been very good at taking exams, in this course he has scored high on every test.
The hospitality program is required to follow its students' progress for 90 days, after which, said Mr. Graham-Handley, most graduates "are on their way and don't require follow-up."
Ms. Barrett, however, sometimes keeps in touch with her graduates long after the required time period. "If there's an individual who has special needs, we continue to follow up," she said.
Graduates find jobs in various places from restaurants to hospitals to nursing homes. Some 30 graduates now work at the Foxwoods High Stakes Bingo and Casino in Ledyard.
The program does not claim to turn out seasoned chefs in 12 weeks. "It will take years for the students to perfect their skills," said Ms. Barrett. The class exposes them to the techniques they will use and to the protocols of the workplace, she explained.
Tony McFadden had started as a dishwasher and worked his way up to salad and grill cook at several New Haven restaurants. He credited his new job at Sports Haven in New Haven to the comprehensive training he received from Connecticut Hospitality Careers. "I never made soups in my life. I learned soups, sauces and baking. Now I've got the hands-on experience."

(Photographs by Janet Durrans for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Robert J. Sternberg;
Intelligence in All Its Interactive Aspects

BYLINE: By MELINDA TUHUS 

 BODY:
ROBERT J. STERNBERG, 46, who is IBM Professor of Psychology and Education Psychology at Yale University, got his undergraduate degree at Yale, his Ph.D. at Stanford, then returned to Yale, where he has been ever since.
In 1988 he published "The Triarch ic Mind," which discusses three kinds of intelligence: analytical, practical and creative. (His latest book, "Successful Intelligence," is due out this year.) 
 Recently, he has challenged the conclusions in "The Bell Curve," Richard Herrnstein and Charles Murray's 1994 book about race and intelligence. Nor is he an admirer of standard methods of intelligence testing -- the Scholastic Aptitude Test developed by the Educational Testing Service, for example.
Dr. Sternberg discussed his views in a recent interview in his office at Yale. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. What is intelligence?
A. I call it mental self-management, the manner in which we order and make sense of the events around us or within us.
Q. How did you get interested in this field?
A. I had a negative experience as an undergraduate; I wanted to major in psychology, but I got a C in the intro course. I wasn't good at memorizing, and that's what the course required. So I switched to math. And fortunately, I did even worse. So I switched back to psychology, and, in the upper level courses and in my whole career since, I've never had to memorize anything.
It got me thinking: the system means that you miss a lot of good kids, conversely we get people who are not necessarily the right ones.
Q. What is the triarchic theory?
A. According to the theory, there are three principal aspects of intelligence: analytical -- the ability to analyze, judge, evaluate, compare and contrast; creative -- the ability to create, design, invent, originate, imagine, and practical -- the ability to use, apply, implement, put into practice. Although each can be looked at individually, they are best understood in interaction, since most tasks require a combination of skills.
Q. Does your theory complement or contradict Howard Gardner's theory of seven intelligences?
A. His theory specifies domains of talent: linguistic, logical/mathematical, spatial, musical, bodily/kinesthetic, interpersonal and intrapersonal. It suggests fields of human endeavor. In contrast, the triarchic theory specifies uses of human knowledge for analytical, creative or practical purposes. The two theories are compatible, and in fact, we collaborated to create a program called Practical Intelligence for Schools.
Q. What did you learn?
A. That analytical, creative and practical intelligences can all be developed. People who are successful are those who figure out their strengths and then find ways of capitalizing on them. In the areas they are not good at, they learn enough to get by. The critical thing is to figure out what you have to offer and then make the most of it. But that's not how schools teach at all.
Q. You are said to advocate "intelligent use of intelligence tests." What do you mean by that?
A. We need to expand the kinds of abilities we measure. The kind of test I use measures analytical ability but also creative and practical abilities.
We have both multiple choice and essay and we find that people who do well on one often are not the same people who do well on the other. We also have verbal, quantitative and figural -- geometric with no words or numbers -- to measure each of the kinds of intelligence.
Q. What did your tests reveal?
A. People who are high creative and high practical were a much more diverse group. The high analytical were mostly white and high income or middle class. The former group had not been seen by their schools as particularly smart. The system is set up to benefit one kind of person, but when you get out in the world it's the creative and practical skills that matter a whole lot more.
Q. Have you put this finding into practice in your research work?
A. We ran a summer program at Yale and recruited high school students nominated by their schools in each of the three areas of intelligence, as well as "high balanced" and "low balanced," meaning they were high or low in all three areas. They all took an advanced placement course in psychology at Yale. But there were different classes based on the different kinds of intelligence. What we found, not surprisingly, is that if you're put in a course that matches your ability, you do better. The only group that preferred the memory course was the "low balanced" group.
Q. For a country that has a history of valuing practical skills, how did we get to this point of focusing on and rewarding just one kind of intelligence, which is not very practical?
A. The system perpetuates itself. For example, people who work at E.T.S. are high-S.A.T. types. People who do well in the system stay, and those who don't do well leave or are kicked out.
Q. You worked at E.T.S. in the summer of 1970. How have tests changed since then?
A. The testing industry is a dinosaur. The first Wechsler adult intelligence scale test came out in 1939, before the Univac computer. In the computer industry if you don't innovate quickly you are dead. But if you don't have competition you don't have to innovate, and that's what's happened with the testing industry.
Q. Another of your areas of research is gifted individuals. What is the problem there?
A. Gifted education is always the first thing to be cut, because people say these kids can get by without special programs. Why we blow off our gifted kids I don't understand.
The biggest problem we have as a society is that today we have to be super-competitive. In global educational competition we don't do well. Our economy is a mess, our political system's a mess. If we don't get with the program we are not going to be competitive.
Q. Do you see a connection between your work and the recently popular notion of "emotional I.Q."?
A. The regulation of emotions is part of translating intelligence into success. Practical and creative intelligence are very important in both interpersonal and international relations.
Q. You're a prolific author. Do you attribute that mainly to analytical intelligence, or do the creative and practical play a significant role?
A. It's an interplay. First you need to have ideas -- that's the creative part. Then you have to know which are good ideas -- that's analytical. The practical is knowing how to reach a given audience and to write something people will want to read.
Q. About Herrnstein and Murray's "Bell Curve," how would you summarize your critique of their book?
A. There is nothing new in their book. Their book is intellectually dishonest. One thing they do is equate correlation with causation, even though they say they don't do that.
One example of that is when they point out that African Americans consistently score 15 points lower on S.A.T.'s than whites, and conclude from that that race is a causal variable. They discuss in detail only one of seven studies on the genetic versus environmental origins of the differences. The other six do not support a genetic interpretation, and the one they do discuss is equivocal.
Their own data do not show that the difference in I.Q. scores is genetic: when they controlled for I.Q. differences, they found telling environmental differences in which blacks were much more likely to be in poverty, to have low birth-weight babies.
Q. Your books don't get the kind of media play as "The Bell Curve." Though often negative, the publicity itself gave their theory more credibility. How do you respond to that?
A. There is pressure to be outrageous. My work is not outrageous enough.
Q. So how do you get the word out?
A. Well, I wrote an introductory psychology textbook that came out last January, called "In Search of the Human Mind." It sold over 40,000 copies in its first edition, which I'm told is very good for a book of that type.
And of course I hope this new book, "Successful Intelligence," will get more publicity. It's about what works in real life, not about what you write on tests.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert J. Sternberg, an author and Yale professor, has little use for established testing systems. (Helen Neafsey for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Interview

HEADLINE: Plan for Lilco Encounters A New Obstaclte

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
DAYS after gaining conditional support from Suffolk Republican leaders for Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to cut electric rates 12 percent, the Long Island Power Authority has lost support in Nassau County.
The setback, which involves a tax problem, illustrated the one-step-forward-one-step-back aspects of a complex plan that continues to receive mixed receptions. 
 Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, one of the plan's earliest supporters, said he was withdrawing his backing in protest over the authority's proposed solution for a $500 million tax liability that Suffolk faces for overassessing the Shoreham nuclear power plant.
Leaders of the authority and the Suffolk Republicans tentatively agreed this month on a so-called split rate, in which Suffolk would receive 1 percent less in rate reductions than Nassau over 30 years, to make up for the overassessments.
The agreement was the basis for Suffolk's tentative support of the plan for a partial public takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company.
Mr. Gulotta insisted that any refund be made in one payment and be used to lower electric rates immediately. He said the 30-year term was too long and unfair to Nassau residents, who received none of the benefits but paid higher electric rates because of the excess taxes on the defunct plant. The assessment on the $5.5 billion plant, the subject of a suit by Lilco, produced hundreds of millions of dollars in property taxes for Suffolk, the Town of Brookhaven and the Shoreham-Wading River School District from the mid-70's to 1992.
In 1992 the utility sold the completed but unopened plant to the authority for $1 under a plan to shut it forever because of safety concerns. The Brookhaven assessors set the property-tax rates.
Since 1992 the authority has made payments in lieu of taxes equal to what Lilco would have paid, and it, too, is eligible for refunds.
The question of how much, if anything, Suffolk should pay has been a troubling obstacle for the plan, and that problem led to the rift with Nassau. Last year Suffolk embraced an earlier plan from the authority for a complete takeover, largely because it would have forgiven the tax liability.
Under the new authority plan, which Mr. Pataki endorsed in December, Lilco would sell its generators and gas business to separate companies. The authority would sell up to $4.5 billion in tax-exempt bonds to buy the transmission and distribution system and refinance Lilco debt, much of it related to Shoreham.
On Feb. 28 leaders of the authority are to ask their 15-member board to authorize talks with Lilco. Even opponents of the plan said they expected that the trustees would approve the move. Mr. Pataki appointed the chairman, James F. Gill, and eight trustees.
Mr. Gill seemed to have achieved a breakthrough when Suffolk County Executive Robert J. Gaffney and other top Suffolk Republicans endorsed the authority's efforts. Mr. Gaffney had been noncommittal.
Some politicians said they believed that the plan was doomed without Suffolk's support. But Nassau support, which officials had assumed, is equally critical.
The qualified endorsement in Suffolk followed a meeting on Feb. 9 among Mr. Gill; other leaders of the authority; Mr. Gaffney; the Presiding Officer of the County Legislator, Donald R. Blydenburgh, Republican of Smithtown, and the county's Republican leader, John Powell of Brookhaven.
Mr. Gaffney said after the meeting that he supported the concept and process in the authority plan. He said the plan was best understood as a concept, because it was being formulated and did not have final costs.
A leading critic and a member of the power authority, Richard M. Kessel, said lowering the status of the plan to concept or idea showed that the initiative was in disarray. Mr. Kessel said the plan was dead, because there is no public support to break up Lilco, among other reasons.
Officials from the authority have had other private meetings to promote the plan. Mr. Gill addressed the board of the Long Island Association last week in an effort to reverse or soften the business group's earlier rejection of the plan.
Mr. Gaffney and Mr. Gill said after their meeting on Feb. 9 that they had made progress toward resolving the tax case, in which Lilco is seeking $500 million for overassessments from 1984 to 1992. Such an award would compel major borrowing to avoid immediate sharp property-tax increases in Suffolk and Brookhaven. The blow would fall hardest on Brookhaven, a Republican stronghold where Mr. Gaffney and Mr. Powell live.
Mr. Gaffney said the county had agreed to allow the authority to seek a negotiated settlement as part of its negotiations with Lilco. "Suffolk County is embracing efforts of Lipa to affect a plan leading to a settlement of the tax case," he said.
Mr. Gaffney and Mr. Blydenburgh said they would support a settlement that would reduce electric rates less in Suffolk than in Nassau. Mr. Gaffney said he would give final support only if the size and term of the split rate were set to the county's satisfaction.
Suffolk Democrats denounced the proposal for a split rate. "We're one region," the minority leader of the County Legislature, Maxine S. Postal, Democrat of Amityville, said. "What happens to some of us affects all of us. Suffolk spent a lot of money to stop Shoreham from opening. Nassau never spent a penny."
Democrats said the law that created the authority specified that the tax claim would be forgiven in the event of a takeover. Mr. Gill said forgiveness was possible only for the years before 1987, the year that the law that created the authority took effect.
Mr. Gill said that a split-rate solution would be "rough justice," but that it was "the most painless, gentle way."
"It's a question of how do you settle a lawsuit," he said.
The case is before Justice Thomas M. Stark of State Supreme Court in Riverhead, who presided over a case involving taxes on Shoreham covering from 1976 to 1983. Justice Stark set the award for Lilco in that case at $81 million, including interest. The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court later upheld that decision.
Potentially more difficult issues lie ahead as the authority nears the opening of formal talks with Lilco on the plan. Lilco has said that it is ready to cooperate in any plan that would lower electric rates, but that it has to agree with the authority on a long list of financial questions that would lead to its dismantling as a Long Island utility.
In an action notable for its timing, the State Public Service Commission ordered Lilco last week to show why the utility should not take steps to refund more than $100 million to its customers. The steps would include a prompt refund, through lower rates, of the $81 million that Suffolk paid Lilco last month for overassessing Shoreham from 1976 to 1983.
The P.S.C. action, which appeared to place Lilco in a pincer between the state regulators and the power authority, was the first by the commission to address Long Island electric rates since a new chairman who was named by Mr. Pataki, John F. O'Mara, took office.
Noting that Lilco rates were "a persistent source of customer displeasure and an obstacle to the economic well-being of Long Island," the commission ordered a thorough review "to examine the rates, charges, rules and regulations of the Long Island Lighting Company for electric service."
It gave Lilco 25 days to answer a series of questions.
The interest in immediate rate relief appears to modify a policy aimed at paying off Shoreham-related debt to keep future rates stable. "Lipa's pending proposal to acquire Lilco and sell off portions of its operations," the P.S.C. said, "is designed to address long-term rate and structural issues."
The statement recognizes that if the plan succeeded all Lilco debts would be settled and the issue of how the customers would pay off the costs related to Shoreham would be moot. In addition, the P.S.C. would no longer set rates.
In its initial response Lilco said it "shared the commission's concern about lowering electric rates" and would cooperate to find "new ways to lower rates and to maintain the programs and plans already in place to provide long-term rate relief."
But by the time the utility makes a formal response it may be involved in separate talks with the power authority to set a price for its assets.
Authority leaders would then seek a final vote from the trustees on the plan. Approval would also be needed from Mr. Pataki; Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, Democrat of Manhattan, and the majority leader of the State Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, Republican of Rensselaer.

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 1; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Son Takes the Reins From His Father

BYLINE: By JANE JULIANELLI 

 BODY:
NOT many sons have overpowered their father in the family business. But not many men are dynamos like Michael Smith of J. Richard Smith Advertising in Melville.
At 34, Mr. Smith is running JRS singlehandedly, three years after he became president. Last May his father, Jerry Smith, formally retired. 
 The change of leadership from one generation to another is characteristic of many Long Island companies, as Long Island's population and businesses age. While the elevation of Michael Smith is indicative of this trend, the step is also different because, in this case, a son won total control.
"Michael and I sat down and we decided that I would retire," said Jerry Smith, 62, who built the business over 32 years into the largest independent advertising agency on the Island and second to Greenstone & Roberts, a public company. It was a decision Mr. Smith described as "torture."
"Financially, the deal was O.K.," he said. "Mentally and physically, it was not."
JRS, with over $40 million in gross billings last year, handles 40 accounts, including Seaman's Furniture, Dale Carnegie and Associates and the Chyron Corporation, with 60 percent of its account base on Long Island.
In their offices on Broad Hollow Road in Melville, JRS employs 35 people in production, copy and design, broadcast production, marketing, media and administration. Using the latest computer equipment, the company plans campaigns and writes, designs and executes ads for print and television.
"When you meet Michael you understand more clearly that Michael has to work within his own framework and his own thought process," Mr. Smith said of his son. "And I felt that, the last couple of years."
Jerry Smith now goes to the 6,500-square-foot office complex of JRS on Broad Hollow Road to consult with Michael when Michael needs him.
"I used to come in in the morning just to sit in an office," said Mr. Smith, "because after 30 years doing something, not to do it, is very, very difficult.
Mr. Smith said he had made his decision to retire for the good of the business, and not because he had reached a certain age. It is a philosophy that strikes a concordant note throughout the Smith family.
Rhonda Gastman, Jerry Smith's daughter, has a similar philosophy. "My father felt that Michael can take the business a lot further than he could take it," said Mrs. Gastman, 38. "Michael is more opinionated, bolder, maybe more argumentative."
Mrs. Gastman started in the business at 14. She worked at JRS until last year, starting as a paste-up artist and working up to assistant art director and production manager.
She met her husband, Wayne Gastman, when both were working at JRS and Michael was in high school.
In 1983 Michael, fresh out of Bentley College in Waltham, Mass., joined his father, sister and brother-in-law in the firm.
"Eventually the business was going to go over to the two of them," Jerry Smith said. "This was my dream. I wanted my son and my son-in-law working together and living happily ever after."
While both worked as vice presidents, it became obvious that it was not going to work, Mr. Smith said. "I didn't know how to handle it. It took several years but the culmination was that Wayne left the company. It's still a sore spot. It still hurts."
"Wayne has a more mellow style than Michael," said Mrs. Gastman about her husband, who is now a vice president at Packaging Trends Corporation in Hauppauge, "and I think he and Michael had different business philosophies. When you have a mixture of family members with different styles, you don't want it to escalate to where it damages the family. The family core is everything. My husband said, 'This is your dad's business. I never want to hurt it.' "
Jerry Smith said it had taught him that everything you plan doesn't always work out. "I have always considered my daughter and my son as equals," said Mr. Smith, "and yet I am not portraying or delivering them as equals. She does not have the business, my son has the business. It is a very difficult thing for me."
The way things are with Michael at the helm, are the way things should be, the family says. Michael's mother, Sandy Smith, who works at JRS three days a week on accounts payable, payroll and taxes, feels her son is good for the business.
"Michael would like to do everything in-house," said Mrs. Smith, 60. "He would like to have every machine possible. He still asks his father for advice but Michael is very into computers which my husband is not. Neither am I. I do computer work, but very little. I'm always afraid I'm going to press a button and everything will disappear."
Jerry Smith believes that the next generation, which includes Michael, is stronger in technology and more intuitively geared toward computerization, accounting and marketing, whereas his generation dealt with people and put the emphasis on management and personal relations.
"This advertising business is an entirely different business now than when I started," Mr. Smith said. "The retail companies that we were doing everything for now have their own in-house advertising department. So if we did not change with the times we'd be out of business. With the advent of the Macintosh, they can basically do newspaper ads, mailers and so on. And most of them are.
"A lot of them are going back and fragmenting some of the business back to the advertising agencies. And there's a good blend now. And that's where Michael has put the agency, to be able to blend with other companies."
One of the companies is Seaman's Furniture, which has an in-house advertising agency. But JRS does the creative work for Seaman's television and radio advertising.
"There's a great tie-in and it works very well for their company and our company," said Mr. Smith. "And that's where business is at today."
Dr. Harold Lazarus, former dean of the Frank Zarb School of Business at Hofstra University and currently professor of business there, cautioned about generalizing about a son's taking over a business from his father.
"The impact on the business depends upon the relative managerial effectiveness of the son," he said. "The business might improve significantly were the son to be more, rather than less, effective than the father.
"Some fathers retain their position as C.E.O. and president not because it was in the best interest of the others but because one hates to give up one's baby. And that's the father's baby. He feels a loss of mission, power, prestige."
A son, he added, can be "highly aggressive and push out the father and still be a superb manager."
The Smiths, father and son, do not always agree on issues affecting the company or Long Island. "Everything is very saturated right now," said Jerry Smith. "There's too much of everything. I think the economy has leveled and I don't think it is going to get much better. I think a lot of people want to leave Long Island."
Michael Smith disagreed. "I see the 90's as a resurrection of the late 50's and 60's on Long Island," he said. "I see more opportunity here today on Long Island specifically than any other time. I think the quality of people, the highly motivated, highly educated work force, the environment of Long Island, offers everybody a unique opportunity."
Michael Smith, a burly man with a boyish face and curly brown hair, worked in shirtsleeves and seemed most comfortable talking from behind his desk, surrounded by computers and other tools of his trade. On a tray where his business cards were kept was a stack of fortune-cookie fortunes.
" 'Get your mind set in the path and it should follow,' " Mr. Smith read a fortune, "and, I certainly believe if you develop the end result in your mind it's very easy to achieve."
When asked the difference between his and his father's business philosophy, Michael Smith had a lot to say about the benefit of the old way, although it is not his way.
"The company was built around a retail environment which by the way is culturally a great strength for us," Mr. Smith said. "That experience of looking at yesterday's numbers and what it achieved has become so prominent in advertising throughout all the industries today. That culture, created over the years, is an intrinsic strength in this organization.
"We are developing the strategy for our clients today,integrating them with their sales, distribution, own marketing and administrative efforts. We used to be geared around an all-or-nothing deal. No longer."
When he first joined the company, he was an account executive, handling the Newmark & Lewis account. JRS contends that its implementation of the "Dick Lewis is watching" campaign helped the retailer grow. In two years JRS sales increased by 35 percent to 40 percent, he said.
"We took that account from a $2 million a year account doing $60 million in business, when I first came on board, to $300 million in business, spending $18 million a year in advertising by the time the relationship ended."
Mr. Smith said that one of the most important changes he feels he made was to selectively choose the clients JRS does business with. He will not handle a cigarette company, for example, although, in contrast to his father, he would take a fur account.
For her 50th birthday Jerry Smith gave his wife a mink coat. "About a year later Jerry became a vegetarian," Mrs. Smith said. "Now I have this beautiful coat. What am I going to do with it? So we gave it away to charity because it got him very upset. Now I agree with him. I don't like fur anymore."
Mr. Smith was born in Brooklyn, where he grew up with his parents in the home of his Russian-Jewish grandparents. His father, George, installed awnings and chauffeured limousines. His mother, Estelle, died of cancer when he was 21.
From his father, Mr. Smith said, he got his work ethic. "My father used to say to me, the only way you can make money easily is rob a bank, and you're not going to do that so you might as well work hard."
Mr. Smith met his wife, Sandy, 44 years ago, on New Year's Eve as the ball dropped in Times Square. "We dated a few times and then I went into the Navy for 47 months.We fell in love through letters."
Mr. Smith was working as an appliance and furniture salesman when he decided to leave Brooklyn because he loved the open spaces and beauty of Long Island. He said that when he first started the business around 1964, he and his wife worked all the time.
"Sandy did everything at the beginning and took care of the two kids too," Mr. Smith said. "We started the business in the basement of our home in Islip Terrace," said Mrs. Smith.
In 1969 they moved to Northport, where they live today. "At that time the business was called Jerome Erwin Advertising," Mr. Smith said. "I started out with my brother-in-law, working with programs for local chambers of commerce. "There was a lot of traveling. We would go to different parts of the country and stay there all week. It was very good money. But when my 7-year-old daughter Rhonda came to me and said, 'Daddy, I don't really know you,' I said it was time to make a change. 'Why are the other daddies home and you're not home?' she asked. It's tough to explain to a kid."
When they split up the business, Mr. Smith saw a vacuum on Long Island for a full service advertising agency and said that that was when he really started JRS rolling, around 1968. He opened offices in a 1200 square foot space on Walt Whitman Road with a secretary, an art director and some artists. He specialized in retail accounts. His first large account was Harrow's.
"We grew with Harrow's," Mr. Smith said. "The smaller companies were growing too. They were growing with Long Island. In the late 60's Long Island really boomed. I've always said I was pretty lucky.
"People said, how did you start a business? I said, well, I really could have put a map of Long Island under my feet, blindfolded myself and dropped a dart and wherever it landed I could have started a business.
"It was only like a year and a half of really lean times when I bought the house," Mr. Smith said. "I probably never really should have bought the house the way business was. But I had confidence in myself, and in Long Island, and it was a good move.
"Probably the leanest, toughest time was when the creative director who was working for the company took the three major accounts we had," said Mr. Smith. "I always said to myself, trust everybody until they prove you wrong. He lost all those accounts after a year. And something very interesting, we got them all back, Newmark & Lewis, Playworld and Harrow's.
When Jerry Smith took an early retirement last year, as he put it, he felt he still had a lot of gas in his tank and he wanted to do something with his time. So he asked himself why did he really stay on Long Island.
"What do I like about Long Island? I like the parks and beaches a lot," he said. So he took a volunteer position as director of development for the Long Island Region of the New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation.
Mr. Smith is also a board member of the Long Island chapter of the American Arbitration Association, of the Long Island Association, the American Cancer Society and the Breast Cancer Coalition of Long Island.
Michael Smith grew up in the business. At 12, he was making stats in the stat room. He came into the business for good at 21 after he chose a conservative New England business school education at Bentley because it contrasted with his freewheeling life during his high school years.
"I kind of went through teenage years being a rebel," Mr. Smith said of growing up in Northport and attending Northport High School where he met his wife, Randee. "After that I felt I needed to be brought back into a conservative realm, and that's why I chose Bentley College."
Mr. Smith lives with his wife and three children in Smithtown. Although he went right into the family business after college, he said he probably shouldn't have. "It took me until I was 30 years old to realize that I probably didn't know much."
He is co-founder of the 22-member Advertising Agency Council after being on the board of the Long Island Advertising Club for three years, and is a member of Young Presidents Organization.
Jerry Smith said he stays in Long Island now primarily because of the family. "I spend a lot of time enjoying my grandchildren: Rhonda and Wayne's children, Brian Matthew, 13, Evan Blake, 9, and Michael and his wife Randee's children, they have twin girls, Jessica and Danielle, 9 1/ 2, and Zackary, 5 1/2," Mr. Smith said.
When asked did he think his son Michael was priming any of them to be the next generation running JRS, Mr. Smith said he'd love to see it, but he did not think so. "I think it's a little premature for that," said Mr. Smith. "What I see is that most businesses fail in the second generation, forget the third. Because you just can't take a child and say, here's the business. Go run it and do it successfully. Some can and some can't."
In other words, he went on, "if Michael was not Michael, I don't think I would have worked something out where he would take the business over if I didn't think he could run it successfully. And that's the main thing, to keep the business going."
However, Mr. Smith said that his son-in-law's leaving the business was one of the lowest points of his life because his dream was for both son and son-in-law to work hand-in-hand.
When asked what do most parents who have a family business do in that situation to make things fair for both the children, Mr. Smith answered, "I don't know. I know that the most important thing is to keep the business going the best way you can. The best thing for the business was Michael, to have Michael run it. Michael wants to be top man. The best thing for me was to have Wayne and Michael in the business, but it wasnot to be."

HEADLINE: How Trinity Aims to Stay Competitive

BYLINE: By GITTA MORRIS 

 BODY:
FOR Edwin Robles, a 37-year-old Hartford police officer, the boarded-up, decaying Victorian brick house in the Frog Hollow neighborhood is a dream come true. "It's appealing to me because I like antique structures," he said. "It's part of Hartford's old past. And I want to be part of something good in the area."
What's good is Mr. Robles' opportunity to buy the house, completely renovated, as a small part of a $175 million program sparked by Trinity College, Hartford Hospital, the new Connecticut Children's Medical Center and the Institute of Living. With additional support from city, state and Federal government as well as private sources, the impoverished neighborhoods that ring the college are already assuming an attitude of hope and renewal. 
 While the need to revitalize neighborhoods like Frog Hollow, Behind the Rocks and Charter Oaks has been discussed for years, it took a new man in town to set a plan in motion. He is Evan S. Dobelle, president of Trinity College since April, who recalls, "I took one look at the campus and the city that looms in the distance, and saw the opportunity. That's one of the reasons I chose Trinity, and they chose me."
Now, plans and the money to implement them focus on the construction of three public schools, early childhood and family resource centers, a boys' and girls' club, and low-cost mortgage money for people to buy the rehabilitated houses. Also, the neighborhood is being rewired and each house will be connected to the Internet by the Southern New England Telephone Company, with Connecticut Public Television, which is on the Trinity campus, the primary information resource.
When people ask him how a project of this scope was kept secret until a few weeks ago, Mr. Dobelle laughs. "It was easy," he said. "Nobody believed it."
He is adamant that the endeavor will not condescend to the neighborhood by simply training residents for minimum wage jobs, or force them out by gentrifying the area. "This is not a situation where I lure my faculty to live in a neighborhood," he stressed. "I hope my faculty will want to be here, but not at the expense of people who have tried to survive for years and have a right to live next to museums, technology centers and schools."
The Southside Institutions Neighborhood Alliance is the umbrella organization under which the plan is being developed. Its members -- Trinity and the three hospitals -- and Connecticut Public Television have among them some 7,500 jobs. "Our interest is to make a difference in people's lives," Mr. Dobelle said, "for them to be able perhaps to become a radiologist or a stenographer, to become qualified for an entry level job at Trinity or the other institutions in the neighborhood."
There is only one caveat. In order to get subsidized housing, as well as health care, after-school care and ultimately jobs, occupants must make a commitment to keeping their children in school.
Mr. Dobelle has a reputation of championing change wherever he goes. As mayor of Pittsfield, Mass., as chief of protocol for the Carter White House and Assistant Secretary of State with the rank of ambassador, as president of Middlesex Community College in Lowell, Mass., and as president and chancellor of the City College of San Francisco, he has lowered taxes and built schools, libraries and campuses.
Upon coming to Trinity, his first step was to approach his future partners with his proposal. They all agreed it would be a good thing. If there were skeptics who said they'd heard it all before, Mr. Dobelle remained undaunted. "What I've learned in life is, if you have an idea that has a degree of workability and a degree of self-interest, and you're relentless about it, it usually can have results," he said.
He is candid about Trinity's self-interest in the project. "I was recruited basically because the board understood that for Trinity to remain a viable institution, it had to be more competitive," he explained. "A significant number of students who do not apply to Trinity, or who are accepted but decide to go to schools like Williams, Bowdoin or Hamilton," give the college's neighborhodd as their reason.
"We're taking a neighborhood which is a debit and making it an asset," Mr. Dobelle said.
About the $175 million, Mr. Dobelle said: "It's a lot of money to spend in a city that too many people have walked away from. I can't imagine there has been more money spent in a concentrated area in Connecticut in a decade except for Foxwoods Casino."
In round figures, about $60 million for the new schools' construction will come from city and state bonds. Another $25 million is earmarked for the technology center. In addition, $75 million in new mortgage and home renovation subsidies will be available through the Federal National Mortgage Association, and the Department of Housing and Urban Development is loaning $15 million. The four institutions are contributing another $10 million.
Mr. Dobelle hopes that eventually the private sector will take over and says banks, private corporations and manufacturers of health related products and technology have been calling with interest in the project.
"It's a true neighborhood partnership," said the executive director of SINA, Jose Perez, a former Assistant Secretary of Economic Affairs for Massachusetts and a community developer. "We're working with local contractors through the neighborhood organization, Hartford Areas Rally Together, which will also hire workers from the neighborhood when possible. We've also met with the security chiefs of the four institutions and we're trying to work out a partnership of community policing."
Crime, particularly gang-related violence, had grown to epidemic proportions in the area. Two years ago, however, United States Attorney Christopher Droney put together a task force of Hartford police, state police and Federal agents and, applying the anti-racketeering laws known by their acronym RICO, went after the gangs.
"Since then we've indicted about 50 members of the Los Solidos gang and convicted about 35 of them," he said. "The gangs are not dominating the neighborhood now."
Mr. Droney noted that the second part of the job is to address some of the root causes of the problem. "The Trinity proposal goes a long way toward doing that," he said, "to really make the neighborhood a better place to live and work. And, I think, going hand in hand with the crime prevention and enforcement that we're doing, it will make a significant long-term benefit."
David Martinez, a postal employee who lives in Frog Hollow, agrees. "At one time there was a gun fatality a day," he said. "There was rampant drug selling. Now I hear gang members say, 'It doesn't pay to get arrested. You're talking about prison.' Before, I would never let my kids go out on the street and play. Now they can walk the streets on their own."
With the poor neighborhood schools, and because the Martinezes believe in the value of education, two of their three children are in private school. Long active in block watches and other neighborhood improvement groups, he and his wife, Meri, a teacher's aide, look forward to seeing the Trinity initiative, and new schools, become reality.
"You know the old adage, it takes a village to raise a child," Mr. Martinez said. "The key point I would make, if I were selling this neighborhood, is that this is becoming a village again."
Work is beginning on rehabilitating and financing eight vacant houses in the neighborhood. Some buildings to be torn down will not be replaced, thereby leaving space for little parks and community gardens. More than $2.2 million is slated for street and building facade improvements, lighting and fencing.
The next stage is the design of the schools, to be built in an abandoned bus yard. They include a kindergarten through grade six Montessori school that will replace one in a different part of town. Because it will be an interdistrict magnet school, with children coming from both Hartford and surrounding towns, it will receive state funding.
A middle school and a Science and Math Resource High School also will be built on the site.
The high school will be unusual in that students will not enroll there, but instead be sent from other schools to work on special projects for as few as two days a week, or as much as several months a year. Trinity faculty and students will be involved and in the summer, the college will open its campus to students attending science and math camps at the school.
The Health and Technology Center, to be staffed by the hospitals, will include a science museum in which children can participate, as well as research labs.
Mr. Dobelle also talks of developing an artery of cafes and art galleries along the west side of the campus, where a high iron fence separates the college from its neighbors. The fine arts department already runs the student-operated storefront Zion Gallery there. A few doors down the street, Timothy's, a small restaurant, was about to close its doors after 22 years, but Trinity has guaranteed its mortgage to assure its survival. "In the last year and a half the city has made big strides cleaning up," said Timothy Otte, the restaurant's owner. "The neighborhood is getting better. The people have a lot of hope."
Mr. Dobelle is optimistic that everything can be in place by the fall of 1998. "I am not naive enough to think there won't be a glitch somewhere along the way," he said, "but we'll overcome it. We're doing something that will help us survive, that's very unique and might be replicated in other parts of the country. What we have fixed on is safety and schools and home ownership. Without them, America is kidding itself that it's going to turn the cities around."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE;
Community Groups Protect the Arts From Extinction in Schools

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
When he was in junior high school on the Lower East Side, Jose Garcia's days were studded with classes in voice, band, art and music appreciation, a creative cornucopia that eventually led him to a stage career. Today, at age 32, he spends one morning a week at a Brooklyn elementary school where there are no such classes.
For the last 18 months, Mr. Garcia, a performer affiliated with the Gowanus Arts Exchange, has brought the Brooklyn New School a series of eight-week workshops that combine theater, dance and music. Professionals like Mr. Garcia, and arts groups like the Gowanus Arts Exchange, are rays of light in city schools where fiscal belt-tightening has all but eclipsed arts instruction. 
 Some groups are solely dedicated to teaching arts in the schools: Arts Connection dispatches professional artists to teach in 100 schools citywide, mostly paid by private dollars. Museums and orchestras have increasingly reached out into the classroom. So have several small groups like the Gowanus Arts Exchange, even as public funds for the arts are drying up.
The arts groups have stepped up their work because the choir teachers and band directors that were once a staple of public education in New York are now a rarity. The trend began with the fiscal crunch of the mid-70's and has snowballed in the last several years. The number of arts teachers has dropped sharply. In 1985, there were 1,851 full-time licensed arts teachers serving a student population of 937,000 in kindergarten through high school, according to the Board of Education. In 1995, the number of teachers had declined to 1,414 while the number of students had risen to 1,054,000.
At the Brooklyn New School one recent morning, as the sun streamed through the windows, Mr. Garcia and another Gowanus performer, Jennifer Fleming, led a small cadre of fifth and sixth graders in exercises designed to build discipline. "Focus," Mr. Garcia commanded, striking a pair of claves. "You don't focus, you miss the universe."
At each strike of the wood blocks, the six boys and six girls were instructed to strike a pose and freeze. On the first beat, they held their arms akimbo, then curled up their bodies on the second beat, like a tulip that has closed.
Later, the students were asked to write about photos clipped from a magazine. One made up a ditty about Spam, another wrote a moving tribute to labor unions. To Mr. Garcia and Ms. Fleming, the exercises unleash creativity, but they also teach things like confidence and thinking ahead.
"I want to go back to the beginning when the arts were for everybody," Mr. Garcia said. "It's a privilege now and it shouldn't be a privilege."
Anna Allanbrook, a third-grade teacher at the school, said that for most of the students, these sessions are their only exposure to the arts. So she regrets that economic reality forces schools to choose between math supplies and theater classes.
The Gowanus Arts Exchange raises its own funds -- a mix of private and state and city dollars -- to dispatch artists into the Brooklyn New School and two other Brooklyn schools. Some of the students start taking after-school classes at the arts exchange, but to the executive director, Marya Warshaw, what counts most is the cultivation of their interest in the arts.
"When you get families involved through their children, that is a really powerful force," Ms. Warshaw said. "They are going to advocate for our survival as well, in a way that they wouldn't if their kids were not involved." SOMINI SENGUPTA

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jose Garcia unleashing creativity at the Brooklyn New School. (Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FOREST HILLS;
Home Depot Plan Stirs Fears

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
For years, the industrial area along Woodhaven Boulevard south of Metropolitan Avenue was desolate with abandoned warehouses and a vacant lot owned by the city. But a recent effort by the city's Economic Development Corporation and the borough president's office to develop it into a commercial shopping strip has met with opposition from the community.
Under the plan, a Home Depot and a shopping center with a supermarket and small neighborhood stores would fill these vacant spaces. But so far, the opposition to the project is so strong that the Borough President, Claire Shulman, has put together a task force to study the situation. 
 Residents in the area say that although they would be happy to see the empty warehouses put to use, they were not prepared to have their routines disturbed by the increased traffic the combination of these developments would bring.
But there appears little they can do to stop Home Depot, which plans construction of a 130,000-square-foot store in the spring. The store's site is zoned for light manufacturing, which allows Home Depot to build without undergoing the Uniform Land Use Review Procedure, Jesse Masyr, a lawyer for Home Depot, said. And because the store is classified as a hardware store, it does not require approval of a special zoning variance by the City Council.
The shopping center, however, may be a different story. Part of the proposed site, a narrow strip of Long Island Rail Road right of way, is owned by the city and is subject to the Uniform Land Use Review Procedure. If purchased from the city, that strip would be restricted to parking only.
To address the parking issue, both Home Depot and Forest City Ratner, a Brooklyn-based company that is a contender to develop the shopping center, are planning to build their own parking lots that will accommodate 700 cars each.
Dan Andrews, the spokesman for Ms. Shulman, said no decision will be made until the task force meets later this month.
During a recent meeting of the Forest Hills Civic Association that was also attended by local politicians and representatives of Forest City Ratner, most of the objections arose from the combined environmental impact of Home Depot and the shopping center.
One after another, residents voiced concerns that the two projects would worsen the existing traffic problem during rush hours. They say it would lower not only their quality of life but also their property values.
"I chose to live in this community because of the lack of commercialization," said Jan Swiatocha, who lives near the proposed shopping center.
The City Council Minority Leader, Thomas V. Ognibene, whose district runs through central Queens, has threatened to use his power in the City Council to block the shopping center over the parking issue. "This project doesn't stand a chance at the City Council," he said. JANE H. LII

HEADLINE: Plan for Luxury Mall In Syosset Advances

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW 

 BODY:
DESPITE some concerns, plans for a one-million-square-foot shopping mall in Syosset, aimed largely at affluent shoppers, are moving forward.
The builder and owner, the Taubman Company of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., has said it plans to apply for a permit to build the center, to be called the Mall at Oyster Bay, on 40 acres zoned for light industry. 
 The land, formerly the site of the Cerro Wire and Cable Company factory, is bordered by the Long Island Expressway, the Long Island Rail Road, Robbins Lane and land owned by the Town of Oyster Bay.
The Chicago Tribune Company owns the parcel. Last year it formed a partnership with Taubman to develop the site, which has been unused for years and has a large industrial building, several smaller structures and a water tower on the property.
Plans for the mall, scheduled to open in the fall of the year 2000, call for a three-level enclosed mall with three anchors and 130 to 150 smaller stores. The center would have 5,000 parking spaces.
The senior vice president for development at Taubman, Tony Ness, said no anchors had made commitments but his company has been meeting with Bloomingdale's, Lord & Taylor, Neiman-Marcus, Nordstrom and Saks Fifth Avenue.
The center would be fashion oriented, Mr. Ness said, aimed at an affluent part of the population, but it would also try to attract a broader customer base. The tenants, he added, would include Madison Avenue and other designer names like those at the Americana Shopping Center in Manhasset.
"Market studies have shown that there is a demand for upper-end merchandise that is not available on the Island," Mr. Ness said. "Many affluent North Shore customers are now shopping in Manhattan or from catalogues."
The average household income in the area around the site is $92,000, compared to the national average of $44,000, according to a study that Taubman commissioned.
"This area," Mr. Ness said, "has a local affluent base to support such a center with regional access, being near the parkways to draw people from throughout Long Island. Research tells us that 88 percent of the money generated by the center would be new business, and only 12 percent would come from existing local malls.
"There is now nothing on the Island that presents the upscale fashion format we have proposed. Roosevelt Field, while a very successful shopping center, is aimed at the middle market. With its major anchor stores being J. C. Penney, Stern's and Macy's, it has had to complement them with specialty stores that are budget oriented or moderately priced, so customers find a cohesive group of stores. It doesn't offer choices to the more affluent customers like we wish to offer."
Some retail analysts agreed that a luxury mall would be a welcome addition. Steven B. Greenberg, president of the Greenberg Group in Hewlett, real-estate advisers to retailers, said there was a market and demand for such retailing. The only true luxury shopping on Long Island, he said, is at the Americana, which has been extremely successful in leasing and re-leasing stores.
A study by his concern, Mr. Greenberg said, found that the first place affluent shoppers went to was Manhasset, because it has the stores they are looking for and is convenient. The second most frequent destination was Manhattan.
"Long Island is fairly saturated with off-price retail at this moment," Mr. Greenberg said, "and is about to go through another wave of bankruptcies. Be that as it may, the one sector of retail that is still glowing is upscale retail. Gucci sales have been tremendous, Saks Fifth Avenue had a good year, and most stores in the Americana shopping center are doing very well. The affluent North Shore customer is somewhat insulated from today's economy."
A recent survey by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics confirms that residents of the New York metropolitan region, including Long Island, spend more than shoppers elsewhere. The average annual spending in the region per household was put at $36,111, compared to $31,750 nationally. New Yorkers spent $5,378 on food, compared to $4,410; $13,388 on housing, compared to $10,106; $2,367 on clothing and services, compared to $1,644, and $484 on personal care, compared to $396.
Opponents of the mall proposal contend that the area is saturated with shopping centers and that the proposed mall would hurt local businesses and neighboring shopping centers.
Supervisor Lewis J. Yevoli of the Town of Oyster Bay said marketing studies had found that there was nothing new that any new mall could offer that could not be found in other malls on Long Island.
"That sums up the entire point," Mr. Yevoli said. "This proposal reflects a terrible story throughout Long Island, where no thought is given to planning, and entire downtown areas dry up."
The problem has two facets, said Ira Rubin, president of the Syosset Homeowners Against Pollution of the Environment, a group of more than 1,000 residents from Syosset, Jericho, Woodbury and Plainview. The first concern, Mr. Rubin said, is that the mall would destroy local businesses. He cited a recently renovated Gap clothing store in the nearby Plainview Shopping Center, saying: "If a Gap goes into the new mall, the Gap in Plainview won't be able to survive, and we'll be left with a lot of empty stores."
The second aspect, he said, is that nearby malls would lose customers. The Broadway Mall in Hicksville is two and a half miles southwest of the proposed site, and the Walt Whitman Mall in Huntington is six miles east.
"Roosevelt Field just opened a Bloomingdale's and is building a Nordstrom," Mr. Rubin said. "Walt Whitman wants to add two major department stores and a number of specialty stores. Nassau and Suffolk Counties have both declining populations and aging populations. Where is the logic to this plan?"
The proposed mall is not the proper use of that land, added Judy Jacobs, a Nassau County Legislator and president of the South Woodbury Taxpayers Association. "We have a responsibility to the community," Ms. Jacobs said. "We've already seen development along Jericho Turnpike create a ghost land in the local community. What this mall will do to local stores and neighboring malls will be devastating. You cannot inundate an area and expect everyone to survive."
Mr. Ness said that although such concerns were often voiced when new shopping centers arrive, the effects are usually the opposite of what is feared.
"What has happened in other communities where we've built similar centers," he said, "is that by bringing a critical mass of retail into the area and bringing in new customers it becomes a benefit to the entire retail community, not only within the shopping center."
Last month representatives from Taubman met civic groups and community leaders to discuss their proposal. The next meeting is to be at the end of this month.
Traffic and other safety concerns overshadow economics for a large group of residents. "More than half the traffic into the mall will go through the intersection of the Long Island Expressway and South Oyster Bay Road, which is very close to the public library," Gene Herman of Woodbury said. "This will add thousands of cars every hour and will therefore greatly impact on safety. We are also concerned about the effect these noxious fumes from the cars will have on the air quality in this area."
The enormous amount of traffic generated by a mall of this kind would spill over onto local roads that were not meant to handle such traffic, said Mrs. Jacobs.
"The best use of the property," she said, "would be a user-friendly company like an Olympus or a Canon, that would occupy the land for office use, come in the morning and leave at night, leaving the weekends quiet."
Several residential areas are at the intersection of Robbins Lane and the north service road of the Long Island Expressway.
"From East Birchwood," Mr. Yevoli said, "there are times during commuter rush hours that it's now almost impossible to get in and out of the development. And that's without any additional traffic. There are other areas like 500 acres of Grumman property that are just crying out for development."
The 11 Parent-Teacher Associations in the Syosset School District have voted to oppose a regional mall at Cerro Wire. The president of the Syosset Council of P.T.A.'s, Susan Sariego, said: "We have grave concerns over the dramatic effect this would have on the health and welfare of the children in this community. Because of its close proximity to two elementary schools and the public library, it would be a very detrimental project."
Mr. Ness said that many studies had examined traffic and that Taubman was continuing to look at the subject. Taubman, he added, plans to make road improvements that would make intersections safer. One advantage of the location, Mr. Ness said, is that 90 percent of the traffic would never use the local streets.
But some residents have not been convinced. "Unless it's in your immediate backyard," Mr. Rubin said, "most people don't pay attention to these proposed projects. They don't worry about it, until usually it's too late."

HEADLINE: China: Jerry-built ... or built to last?;
Boom-at-a-Glance

BYLINE: By Jane H. Lii

 BODY:
All the World's a Market
Since China began its economic reform, its gross domestic product (G.D.P.), measured yuan, has grown nearly tenfold, from 447 billion yuan in 1980 to 4.4 trillion yuan in 1994. In U.S. dollars, the G.D.P. rose from $298 billion in 1980 to $508 billion in 1994. It is an economy that has far outstripped the competition. Here, a few significant G.D.P. growth rates (in percentages):
 
In 1994, China's trade surplus was $5.2 billion. One of its best customers is the United States, whose trade deficit with China is fast becoming a rival of its better-known deficit with Japan.
 
In 1994, foreign investors poured $81.4 billion into China, up from $2.9 billion in 1984; American investors spent $6 billion up from $165 million. The United States was the second-largest foreign investor in 1994, behind Hong Kong/Macao ($48.7 billion) and ahead of Taiwan ($5.4 billion) and Japan ($4.4 billion). The five American companies whose joint ventures yielded the highest gross sales (in millions of dollars, and with rank among all joint ventures):
 
Chrysler $497 (4th)
Motorola $310 (6th)
Procter & Gamble $234 (14th)
United Technologies $184 (33rd)
Coca-Cola $119 (59th)
 
In 1993, only 0.1 percent of Chinese owned automobiles, a total of 1.2 million; about 70 percent were imports. (Bicycles, meanwhile, number upward of 450 million.) "China is such a potentially huge market that if 1 percent of Chinese people could afford cars, that would be 12 million," says Michael G. Meyerand, a spokesman for General Motors. "That's roughly our market size in Europe."
 
Big Economy, Tiny Budgets
 
The national average household income was $685 in 1994. Per-capita income has risen about 20 percent over the past two years, and average income should reach $4,000 by 2020, compared with $35,000 in the United States (both measured in 1995 dollars).
 
The average income of:
 A businessperson is $581 a year.
 A factory worker: $420.
 An agricultural worker: $213
 
A worker for a company that is partly foreign-owned earns at least 200 percent the salary of a comparable worker at a Government-run company, but Government jobs also provide insurance and subsidized housing.
 
Before 1979, 100 percent of agricultural workers had medical insurance: now only 20 percent do.
 
How does a Chinese household spend its money?
 
AVERAGE MONTHLY EXPENSES FOR A CHINESE FAMILY
 Food $22
 Savings $11
 Clothing $6
 Children's Education $5
 Rent and Utilities $4
 Nonfood Goods $4
 Medical care $2
 Entertainment $1
 
Below, the percentages of families who own certain consumer goods, from a survey of 3,500 households.
 Color television 40%
 Refrigerator 25%
 VCR 12%
 Telephone 9%
 Computer 2%
 
(A 29-inch foreign-made color television costs about $1,200. The paucity of telephone lines, not the cost of the phone itself, accounts for the sacarcity of ownership.)

HEADLINE: Inside 'City Hall'

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick

 BODY:
"City Hall," the new film starring Al Pacino as a popular, populist Mayor, is a wholly realistic portrait of gritty city politics. But it is friction. Here are a few examples of who's really who and what's really what.
 HIZZONER
 
FILM: Mayor John Pappas (played by Al Pacino) is a dramatic, compassionate, overwrought politician who wants to be effective and talks about New York City's greatness: "It was a palace! It can be a palace again!"
 
FACT: The closest to the emotive Pappas is Mario M. Cuomo, the silver-tongued former Governor. Not that it's hard to imagine Edward I. Koch or Fiorello H. La Guardia being as headstrong as Pappas. Or Rudolph W. Guiliani, who has also been known to be willful on occasion.
 But a mayor's embracing the coffin of a murdered black child, mesmerizing the congregation, as in the film? Racial tentions are such in New York City that at the 1989 funeral of Yusuf K. Hawkins, a black teen-ager killed by a white gang in Bensonhurst, Mr. Koch and Mr. Cuomo were heckled. Two years later, the death of a 7-year-old black child, struck in Crown Heights by a car driven by a Hasidic Jew, touched off searing racial unrest. Mayor David N. Dinkins did speak at the boy's funeral, but that did not stop rioting.
 THE BOSSES
 
FILM: Frank Anselmo (Danny Aiello) is a Brooklyn political boss who is close to both the Mayor and the local Mafia don. He's a powerful figure who wants goodies for Brooklyn in exchange for supporting BankExchange, a mayoral development project. Everything moves along until Anselmo gets his political allies to pressure a judge into freeing a drug dealer, a nephew of the don. Back on the streets, the dealer kills an innocent child.
 
FACT: Anselmo is an obvious mix of Meade H. Esposito, the late gruff Brooklyn Democratic leader, and Donald R. Manes, the late Democratic leader and Borough President of Queens. Esposito, last of the old-time "bosses," died in 1993 at age 86, five years after his conviction on influence-peddling and bribery charges. Manes committed suicide in 1986 as his role in a bribery and extortion scheme began to surface. In their day, both Esposito and Manes could, like Anselmo, twist political arms and had the ear of the Mayor.
 The film's BankExchange is in reality the Citicorp building in Long Island City, Queens.
 THE DEPUTY MAYOR
 
FILM: The protagonist of "City Hall" is not the Mayor but his Deputy Mayor, Kevin Calhoun (John Cusack). He is a young Louisianan who gets to the bottom of a mystery.
 
 FACT: Never has City Hall seen a Deputy Mayor like Kevin Calhoun. Deputy Mayors tend not to come from parts south - other than southern Brooklyn. Nor do they play detective (unless they are investigating the reason for overtime in the Sanitation Department). Mainly, they run the $32 billion city government.
 Nor is hero a word that comes to mind to describe deputy mayors. Workaholic is more like it. But Ken Lipper, Mr. Koch's Deputy Mayor for economic development, has always though very highly of his tenure. He wrote the first screenplay for the film and was a co-producer.
 THE SETTING
 
FILM: Many scenes show City Hall and Gracie Mansion.
 
FACT: The exteriors of Gracie Mansion are the real thing, but interiors were filmed in a private home in New Jersey. The Mayor's offices are not really the Mayor's. They are the offices of the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, decorated to look like the Mayor's. For security reasons, Mr. Guiliani would not allow filming in his offices.
 For the nitpickers: The metal detector in the City Hall rotunda is not seen in the film. Reporters do not wear suits and ties to mayoral news conferences. Deputy mayors do not often run off to Buffalo (in a train!) to pursue mystery clues, or drive their own cars (they have chauffeurs).
 And not in recent memory has a Mayor of New York been blessed with the dark, thick locks that sit atop Al Pacino's ever-furrowed brow.
