HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Astoria, Queens;
Where the Piano Meets the Bouzouki

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
UMBRELLAS were the only concession to wind and rain on a recent Saturday afternoon along Astoria's Steinway Street, where a seemingly unending expanse of small shops and eating places of every description fairly bristled with shoppers undeterred by the weather.
With its brightly colored canopies and double-parked cars, Steinway Street is only one of several main thoroughfares in Astoria, a Greek-American stronghold in northwestern Queens known for its shopping, about 200 restaurants, night life, affordability and good subway connection to Manhattan. 
 The Steinway Piano Company, an economic bulwark since the company moved here from Manhattan in the 1880's, still provides jobs for craftsmen at its factory on 19th Avenue in Astoria's main industrial area.
But the humble bouzouki, not the Steinway grand, is the instrument that best sets to music a neighborhood where Greek is heard as often as English along Ditmars Boulevard, another commercial hub.
For Greeks, Greek-Americans and lovers of Greek cuisine and culture from throughout the metropolitan area, Astoria is a siren song and the place to be. "They all come to Astoria for the food and the entertainment," said George Delis, the district manager of Community Board 1.
Among the restaurants are Elias Corner, serving Greek seafood; Minore, a Greek nightclub with live bouzouki music and serving traditional Greek cuisine; Bank Restaurant, serving Italian and Croation food, and the Taj Mahal, with Indian cusine.
Yet in a working-class setting that has been home to many immigrants in its history, new waves of ethnicity are pouring forth. Around Broadway, near Astoria's ever-open-to-interpretation border with Long Island City, recent immigrants from Bangladesh, the Philippines, Ireland, Colombia, India and China lead the transformation.
Americans of Italian, German, Irish and Polish extraction have been at home in Astoria for decades, and a Hispanic and African-American presence has been growing.
Above 31st Street, the N line subway lumbers along elevated tracks through the middle of town to the last stop on Ditmars Boulevard. The ride back to midtown Manhattan takes less than half an hour. Rows of two- and three-story, red-brick, attached and semidetached houses stretching off on both sides are typical of the two-family housing that predominates.
A DECADE ago, some developers thought that the subway, coupled with Astoria's work-ethic stability and the allure lent by the Greek presence, made this plain-hewn community ripe for gentrification. Except for the huge Shore Towers condominium, it never happened, and Astoria churned on with a vitality and momentum of its own.
"Astoria keeps moving," said Gregory Fiasconaro, a broker at G.M. Dynasty Realty at 35-04 30th Avenue. "It's so close to the city it's like the step-brother."
Even some who left are coming back.
"A few years ago a lot of Greeks started moving out to Flushing and Bayside," said Angelo Langdakis, a broker at Owners Club Realty at 31st Street and Ditmars Boulevard, recounting an exodus others said reached out to towns like Port Washington and Glen Cove on Long Island. "But they still hung around this area because of all the big stores and restaurants and night life. Driving back and forth was difficult, so many of them moved back."
A shrewd buyer can cover annual taxes, averaging about $2,000, and most of the mortgage by renting the upstairs and basement of a two-family house, according to Mr. Langdakis.
"With today's interest rates, someone putting down a 10 percent payment can almost live for free by renting the second floor and the basement," he said.
Basement rentals are illegal but extremely common, brokers and others said. "Ninety-nine percent of the houses have finished, rentable basements," Mr. Langdakis said.
But the upstairs apartments, often rented out by owners living on the ground floor, are at the core of Astoria's active rental market.
A new development, Estates at Hallett's Cove, is offering 107 two-family units for $229,000. David G. Hughes, the marketing director for the Seavey Organization, a partner in the development, said the houses were tailored for buyers in the $40,000 to $68,000 annual income range. The development is on 21st Street between 33d and 34th Avenues.
Shore Towers, a five-year-old, 23-story, 405-unit condominium on Shore Boulevard overlooking the East River, advertises "affordable luxury on the Queens coast" with views of Manhattan and East River bridges. A two-bedroom apartment sells for $125,000. The monthly common charge is $242.
STREET crime, people in Astoria say, is less a problem than in many parts of the city. "A lot of people want to live here right now" said Charles Sciberras, an associate salesman at Crest Haven Realty at 28-17 Astoria Boulevard. "The market is very tight. There's a pent-up demand for houses and we sell them as quick as we get them if the price is right."
Astoria Park, near the Triborough Bridge crossing over Hell Gate, has 62 acres of playing fields, tennis courts, green spaces and the largest outdoor pool in the city.
A major city-owned housing project on Shore Boulevard, Astoria Houses, has about 8,000 residents. The Ravenswood Houses, another city project with about 10,000 residents, is just beyond Astoria on 35th Avenue near 21st Street.
The American Museum of the Moving Image, which opened in 1988, celebrates Astoria's long association with films and video. Its enlarged exhibit, "Behind the Screens," opens on April 20.
The museum, at 35th Avenue and 36th Street, is next to Kaufman Astoria Studios, a major East Coast film and video production center. The studio is the historic successor to the Famous Players-Lasky Corporation, which opened a studio here in 1920 to produce silent movies for Paramount Pictures. Stars from Rudolph Valentino and Gloria Swanson to Robert DiNiro and Meryl Streep have worked there.
The Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum at 32-37 Vernon Boulevard is named for the internationally known sculptor, whose studio was at the museum site. He died in 1988. Galleries and the outdoor garden display over 250 of his works. The museum reopens to visitors on April 3 after its annual winter closing.
GERMANS settled in Astoria during the latter half of the 19th century, followed by the Irish. Italians came after World War I. Greeks followed after World War II. The Greek populations surged after a change in immigration laws in 1962 opened the doors to southern Europeans. Greek Orthodox, Roman Catholic and Lutheran churches and four synagogues witness the tides of immigration.
St. Demetrios, a 69-year-old cathedral on 31st Street and 30th Drive, the largest Greek Orthodox church in the nation.
There are 20 elementary schools and five junior high and intermediary schools in Astoria, which is in school district 30.
At I.S. 126, a visual- and performing-arts magnet school at 31-51 21st Street, Spanish and Bengali are the most frequent native tongues of students who speak limited English. The school, built in 1925, has about 1,000 students in grades six through eight.
Many Astoria students attend the newly built Long Island City High School, where the principal, William C. Bassell, said an interdisciplinary program in technology, humanities and the arts would begin in September. About 80 percent of the school's 2,600 students are from Astoria.
The building opened in September, making it the newest public high school in the city. It has a 1,400-seat theater and a pool.
In June 1994, 68 percent of the class that started four years earlier graduated within four years. Of these, about 76 percent went on to two- or four-year colleges. About 25 percent of students in the class of 1994 took the Scholastic Assessment Test. Average scores of 302 in verbal skills and 389 in mathematics were below the citywide average.
The William Cullen Bryant High School, the other zoned high school for Astoria, has an enrollment of 3,500. In a recent survey, about 78 percent of graduates went on to higher education. There is one parochial high school in Astoria -- the Roman Catholic St. John's Preparatory School -- and one Lutheran and five Catholic elementary schools. There is also a pre-kindergarten to grade 12 St. Demetrios school.
Astoria bore the Indian name Sintsinck, meaning "a stony place," when the first settler, William Hallett, arrived in the 1650's. Hallets Cove on Hell Gate is named after the family. During the Revolutionary War, British artillery batteries set up where the Astoria Houses now stand aimed over Hell Gate at Colonials holding Manhattan.
The area owes its current name, but little else, to the fur merchant John Jacob Astor. Despite protests, village leaders adopted the name when the village was incorporated in 1839 to attract investment from Astor in what was then a well-to-do retreat for New York merchants. But flattery, in this case, got Astoria nowhere.
 

CORRECTION-DATE: March 10, 1996, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Feb. 18 about living in Astoria, Queens, misstated the number of public schools in the neighborhood. There are six elementary schools and three intermediate schools in Astoria. The article also misstated the street on the western border of the Astoria Houses. It is First Street, not Shore Boulevard.

ANCIENT GREECE REDUX: Athens Square at 30th Street and 30th Avenue, a small city park with an amphitheater that recalls those of ancient Greece, is soon to get some finishing touches. Three 23-foot-high, white-granite columns costing a total of $250,000, weighing 14 tons each and fashioned after the Doric columns of Delphi are expected to arrive soon from Rhode Island, where they were crafted from Georgia stone. Once erected, they will add to an unusual Hellenic park whose creation was given early support in 1983 by City Council President Peter F. Vallone. Mr. Vallone's $100 contribution initiated a local fund-raising drive that has since raised $300,000 from the Astoria community for the park, the columns, and what George Delis, the Athens Square Committee vice president, called the only full-bodied statute of Socrates in the country. The bronze statue was erected in 1993. "Athens Square is a beautiful place for the performing arts," said Mr. Delis He said a second season of free musical performances was planned for the summer following an unveiling of the new columns in the spring.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Survey Finds Travel Tax Rarely Goes to Tourism

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
EVERYONE knows that travel is taxing, but a good indication of how taxing can be gleaned from the recent report, "Travel Taxes in America's Top Destinations," a survey conducted for the Travel and Tourism Government Affairs Council in 50 cities from Anaheim, Calif., to West Palm Beach, Fla. The cities are those with the largest number of hotel rooms.
The survey made no attempt to extrapolate the figures beyond the 50 cities, and not every city responded to every portion of the survey. But those that did respond reported collecting billions of dollars in taxes, of which only a fraction was earmarked for travel and tourism. 
 The 43 cities that responded to the survey question about restaurant taxes collected $3.1 billion in 1995 -- of which only $47.9 million, or 1.6 percent, went to travel and tourism. The 43 cities that answered that part of the survey about hotel taxes (not all of them the same 43 that answered the restaurant question) collected $1.8 billion last year, of which $637.3 million, or 34 percent, went to travel and tourism.
The report was researched by William Evans with assistance from Arleyne Udo. Mr. Evans is director of economic studies for the Travel Industry Association of America, a Washington trade group. The yearlong project was paid for by the Travel and Tourism Government Affairs Council, an affiliate of the Travel Industry Association. The information was obtained by mail and by telephone interviews with convention and visitor bureaus, state travel offices and state and local tax bureaus.
But the report does not include taxes on air travel, including the $6 tax for international departures and the 10 percent tax on domestic air fares -- both of which lapsed last Dec. 31 and presumably will not be restored until Congress and the President agree on a budget bill for this year.
Nevertheless, the report describes Federal fees on air travel and excise taxes on gasoline as "the best example of truly 'dedicated' user fees where the traveler enjoys many benefits (e.g., efficient and safe road and air travel) for having paid those particular taxes and fees."
The report does not object to the fact that state and local taxes, which make up the greatest share of taxes paid by the traveler, usually wind up in the general fund. But it strongly protests the use for general purposes of additional taxes and fees charged to the traveler, including taxes on hotels, restaurant meals and car rentals, which are rarely earmarked for tourism promotion, visitor information centers and other programs that directly benefit the traveler.
"Too many states and cities have used this scheme," the report declares, "to raise new revenue from visitors who are not voters to pay for programs unrelated to travel."
Most of the report consists of a city-by-city breakdown of taxes, and many of its findings are surprising.
For example, Columbus, Ohio, had the highest room tax in 1995 of the cities surveyed, 15.75 percent. Seattle was runner-up with 15.2 percent, followed by Anaheim, Houston and San Antonio, each with 15 percent. Las Vegas had the lowest hotel tax, 8 percent, followed by Portland, Ore., at 9 percent.
But because Portland has no sales tax, and therefore no tax on restaurant meals, its total tax on food (none) and lodging (9 percent) was the lowest of any of the 50 cities. Boston was next lowest with a combined 14.7 percent.
By contrast, San Antonio's 24.7 percent combined hotel and restaurant tax edged out Chicago (24.65 percent) as the nation's highest, with Seattle (23.4 percent) and Washington (23 percent) runners-up. But when car rental taxes are added, Chicago (with an 18 percent tax, plus $2.75 surcharge per rental) was in a tax class by itself.
Tax data on rental cars were not specific enough to provide accurate information for the report, but the take from such taxes obviously runs into the millions. The Florida Division of Tourism's entire $15.1 million budget last year was financed by a portion of that state's $2.05-a-day surtax on rentals, and all 50 cities in the survey impose a base tax on car rentals averaging 8.24 percent. In addition, 31 cities tack on additional taxes for cars rented off airport property, while 18 impose additional surcharges -- often to pay for athletic stadiums.
 

CORRECTION-DATE: March 10, 1996, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
The Correspondent's Report column on the Travel Advisory page on Feb. 18 about taxes at tourist destinations referred incorrectly to a tax in San Antonio and misstated the combined total of two taxes there. The city has a sales tax, which applies to restaurants; it does not have a restaurant tax as such. The sales and lodging taxes total 22.75 percent, not 24.7.

SECTION: Section A; Page 15; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: In America;
An Exercise in Futility

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

DATELINE: PORTSMOUTH, N.H.

 BODY:
None of the campaigns are working. Millions are being spent on inane and annoying ads, and the candidates are dutifully tramping through the snow and the bitter cold, proffering one false promise after another (like compulsive salesmen who couldn't stop peddling their discredited wares, even if they wanted to), all for naught.
Tomorrow's G.O.P. primary vote will be an exercise in futility. It won't matter who wins. No one from this group of flim-flam artists and charm school dropouts can satisfy the growing hunger among American voters for a President who will honestly and aggressively address the economic difficulties that are steadily eroding the quality of life for working men and women. 
 Arielle Silver, a politically conservative young woman who works for a computer software company, discussed the Republican candidates as she folded clothing on a snowy afternoon at the Wash 'N Clean laundromat in the Plaza 800 shopping center.
"I can't stand it," she said. "They're like a bunch of little kids quibbling. They are not professional and they look awful. I think it's giving a big opening to Clinton."
Ms. Silver was laid off a year ago and spent eight months searching for another full-time job in the computer industry. In the interim, she said, she worked at temporary jobs "that were almost full time." Employers would limit her hours to 37 1/2 per week, thus escaping the obligation to pay health and other benefits.
In Ms. Silver's view, the workaday world has become increasingly cutthroat and "scary." The candidates, she said, should knock off the "negative" nonsense and deal squarely with the problems of underemployment and economic insecurity.
Her sentiments were echoed in interview after interview.
"I know so many people who have lost jobs, good jobs, since the mid-80's," said David Lavoie, a 31-year-old jeweler. "And yet the candidates have not addressed these economic issues the way they should. They have not been responsible. I could vote for a Republican, but right now I'm leaning toward Clinton."
Al Miller, who runs a hardware store in nearby Newbury, Mass., said, "Ask them what they're going to do with Social Security and Medicaid. I'm going to retire in five years. Tell them I'll shoot anybody that touches Social Security."
The problem for the Republican Party at the moment is as follows: There is a cosmic disconnect between what the voters want and what the party of the corporate interests can give them. The voters have experienced the reality of the so-called Republican revolution of 1994 and much of it frightened them.
The party's inherent problems are exacerbated by its miserable field of candidates. Bob Dole's cranky wit is not playing well. And it's difficult to imagine working-class voters going hog-wild over a zillionaire whose tax plan undermines the single biggest investment of most working men and women -- their home. And Americans are not about to rally en masse behind a Presidential candidate who has to spend most of his time hiding the hooded sheets in his campaign.
It's ironic that a year into the Republican revolution the concerns of working men and women have been most eloquently expressed by Senator Edward Kennedy, an unabashed liberal who has long been written off by the smart set.
"Americans are working more and earning less," said Mr. Kennedy earlier this month. "They worry -- about losing their jobs, losing their health insurance, affording their children's education, caring for their parents in old age, and somehow still saving for some semblance of security in their own retirement."
Since 1973, said Mr. Kennedy, real family income "has fallen for 60 percent of all Americans, even as the income of the wealthiest 5 percent increased by nearly a third, and income for the top 1 percent almost doubled."
He zeroed in on the central hypocrisy of the Republican Party's message. It makes no sense, he said, "to preach hope, growth and opportunity while touting policies that bring growth only to the richest, deny hope to the poorest and restrict opportunity for the vast majority."
Voters riddled with economic anxiety will find no solace in tomorrow's election. Each vote that they cast will be against their own interests, as they are in search of answers that conservative Republicans are philosophically unable to provide.

HEADLINE: Innovation, Hence Survival, at Apple

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18

 BODY:
If Apple Computer's new chairman and chief executive, Gilbert F. Amelio, has a grand vision for remaking the personal computer company as it approaches its third decade, he has not yet disclosed it.
Meeting with journalists on Friday for the first time as the company's chief, Mr. Amelio offered a clear and concise message: Apple's problems are not life-threatening and can be corrected without slashing the work force or merging with another company. 
 "We have ourselves in a little trouble right now," he acknowledged. "The troubles are fixable. I've been down this road before."
But he left unanswered deeper questions about the fate of the quixotic company, which once offered the revolutionary idea of a computer on every desktop and the nonbusiness slogan "the journey is the reward."
"Apple has to combine innovation with accountability, and it hasn't been innovating fast enough in recent years because its executives haven't been accountable," said Richard Shaffer, editor of The Technologic Partners Computerletter, an industry publication. "It's one thing to have vision; it's another thing to get the vision out the door."
Indeed, even Apple's most loyal customers are beginning to ask whether the company can set itself apart from the field that has been imitating it for almost two decades.
Mr. Amelio, who owns five Macintosh computers himself, has apparently been moving cautiously but directly in his first 10 days at Apple's helm. David Nagle, the executive who heads Apple's product development, said Mr. Amelio had been touring the company, visiting teams and scoring points with the staff with his understanding of the technical issues the company confronts.
In the spotlight on Friday, Mr. Amelio seemed most concerned with diffusing an atmosphere of panic and disorder at Apple. His answers to questions were not always extensive, but they were direct.
He rejected outright the suggestion that as an Apple board member for 15 months -- while he was chairman and chief executive of National Semiconductor -- he shared the blame for the recent turmoil, saying he was still learning about the company as it encountered its profound troubles.
He also deftly deflected a suggestion that his compensation package, which includes a salary and bonus totaling $2.5 million, was unseemly at a company facing a financial meltdown. His salary was dictated simply by what the market would bear, he replied.
The problems Apple faced, he suggested, involved a little "housecleaning" and might mean moving some people around within the company rather than the wholesale layoff of thousands.
Mr. Amelio's most immediate problem has to be to find a way to stop the brain drain. If Apple is to remain an innovator, it must be able to keep the people who have for so long been willing to "bleed in six colors," a reference to the company's colorful bitten-apple logo.
Innovation is clearly the company's life-or-death challenge today. Once an innovator in personal computing, Apple has found it increasingly difficult to differentiate itself.
The creator of the hand-held computing market, Apple has yet to renew its commitment to the Newton project. And despite being the first company to commercialize the original hypertext vision of electronic documents that could be linked together with pointers -- with the Hypercard program Apple developed in the mid-1980's -- the company was unable to discern the vast power of the obvious next step to the World Wide Web.
But it may be impossible to go back to the days of the quirky Apple Computer that thumbed its nose at its competitors with legendary cockiness.
Under John Sculley, a former Pepsico executive who took over from Apple's co-founder, Steven P. Jobs, in a bitter board room spat in 1985, Apple held to a course that set it apart from the rest of the computer companies. Mr. Sculley painted a future of a trillion-dollar information economy in the next century, but ultimately lost his job when he promised too much.
Under Michael H. Spindler, who took over from Mr. Sculley in 1993, Apple's sense of mission grew murky. The company seemed to turn inward, as if Mr. Spindler -- who had a reputation as the consummate operations man -- believed that it was enough to please customers and ship products.
Mr. Spindler rejected the idea that Apple needed a public vision to differentiate itself from other computer makers. He cut public contact to a minimum, and, when conditions turned down, the company started to slip into a bunker mentality.
Mr. Amelio may ultimately evince the vision and passion necessary to restore Apple's culture of innovation. But from his first public outing, it was difficult to see how he would evoke the heritage of Apple's co-founders, Mr. Jobs and Stephen Wozniak, who pioneered one of America's remarkable industries with their savvy -- and also with their passion.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gilbert F. Amelio answering a question on Friday at Apple's headquarters in Cupertino, Calif. 'The troubles are fixable,' the new chief said. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Cash and Carry On at Trader Knick

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
Economic downsizing continued yesterday at Madison Square Garden. Soon to follow is the head-hunting process, in which someone very good at what he does will be paid gobs of money to guide the company back to prominence.
Until then, Willie Anderson will try his best to serve as the interim impact player. 
 The Knicks may not catch the Chicago Bulls or the Orlando Magic this season, but in a span of 11 days they have put themselves in position to become one of the most aggressive bidders during the Great Free Agent Auction of 1996.
With the National Basketball Association trading deadline approaching on Thursday, they completed their second deal in less than two weeks yesterday by acquiring the 6-foot-8-inch, multitalented Anderson and the backup center Victor Alexander from the Toronto Raptors in exchange for guard Doug Christie, the backup center Herb Williams and an undisclosed amount of cash.
Nothing personal, the Knicks keep saying. Just business.
"Unless somebody calls and gives us a Michael Jordan, this is the team we'll stick with," General Manager Ernie Grunfeld said via a conference call. "Most likely, we'll have betwe'n $9.5 million and $10 million to work with under the cap. We explored all our options, the best situations for the present and the future.
"There have been a lot of rumors about certain deals that didn't come to fruition. We just looked at this as a case of where we could stay on a competitive level and also improve for the future."
With the nearly $10 million in spending money they will have this summer, the Knicks will be able to court almost anybody not named Shaquille O'Neal. They can realistically go after a power forward of the future such as Juwan Howard, or pay a shooting guard like Steve Smith enough to keep him happy but not enough to upset the salary framework of the other starters. They can even, though they will constantly deny it, test Patrick Ewing's value on the supreme-center market that will include Dikembe Mutombo.
For now, they finally have a backcourt player in Anderson who can consistently break down a defender off the dribble.
"Willie's been around a long time; he's been a good player and he satisfies a position which we really haven't had," Nelson said. "It gives us a different look."
Anderson, a slashing type swingman who has missed 115 games over the past four years with different leg injuries, has played in all of Toronto's games this season. Viewed as one of the league's pre-eminent players after his first two seasons, he has slipped many notches the past few years but still has enough Scottie Pippen-like and Clyde Drexler-like skills to be effective in the open floor.
In 49 games for Toronto this season, the eighth-year player averaged 12.4 points on 44 percent shooting, 3.8 rebounds and 31.9 minutes. His best season was his rookie year in 1988, when he averaged 18.6 points, 5.1 rebounds and 4.6 assists a game for the San Antonio Spurs.
Alexander, a 6-10, 26-year-old, has been on the injury list since Nov. 11 and is not ready to run up and down the court. His foot problem nullified a trade to Cleveland earlier this season. Alexander was the player in the Knicks-Raptors deal that everyone had concerns about.
All four players in yesterday's trade must pass their physicals for the trade to be cfficial.
Grunfeld said the Knicks would not put Alexander on the injured list immediately but that he would need time to get ready to play.
Alexander said the injury is not a problem, but admitted that he wou'd need at least two weeks to get into game shape.
As coach and general manager for Golden State, Nelson drafted Alexander out of Iowa State. He said Alexander has always had a weight problem.
Alexander is listed at 265 pounds and would not disclose his current weight. "Usually when he doesn't say, it's not such a good thing," Nelson said.
The difficult part of the trade for Grunfeld was parting with Williams. Grunfeld called him the classiest veteran he has been associated with. Grunfeld said Williams, who may be traded again by the expansion Raptors before Thursday, "will always have a spot in our organization, on the floor as a coach or in the front office."
The key factor in the deal, though, was that both Anderson and Alexa'der are in the last years of their contracts. Christie had two years left on his and Williams had one year left.
Anderson makes $2.5 million, but nearly $700,000 of that money is deferred. About $1.8 million of his salary counts against the cap. Alexander makes $1.7 million. Christie ($1.463 million) and Williams ($1.3 million) amount to less than $3 million in salary this season, meaning the Knicks probably parted with about $500,000 in cash.
So now, over the course of 11 days, the Knicks have changed one-third of their roster, parted with nearly $25 million in contracts and freed themselves of two players Nelson was never fond of, basketball-wise, in Christie and Charles Smith. Smith and Monty Williams were dealt to San Antonio on Feb. 8 in exchange for J. R. Reid, Brad Lohaus and a first-round draft choice.
Now, the Knicks will most likely go through an adjustment period as their four new players learn Nelson's system and Charles Oakley sits out for six weeks because of a broken right thumb. The Knicks lost to the Nets on Saturday night at the Meadowlands and have lost two of three since the All-Star Game break -- or since the first trade was made.
At any rate, the club has followed its midseason brainstorm -- dump the contracts of Smith and Christie, free salary-cap room and try to make a playoff run with what they already have -- to perfection. The only casualty may be whatever distant hope there was of winning a title this season.
"Oakley getting hurt was obviously not a part of our plan," Grunfeld said. "We are concerned about that, but injuries happen. Until he comes back, we just have to hold down the fort. It's probably going to be quite some adjustment period. I don't know how long that adjustment period is going to be.
"As of today, we still have the sixth-best record in the league."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Willie Anderson is a Knick after a four-player deal with Toronto. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Apartheid's Fall Opens Door to Scourge of Cocaine

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 18

 BODY:
On a weekday afternoon recently, the streets of this city's largely black Hillbrow neighborhood were alive with commerce -- vendors selling fruit from plates on the sidewalk, barbers working under makeshift tents, men sitting behind ancient pedal-powered sewing machines, willing to tailor at a moment's notice.
But everywhere, it seemed, there were also anxious young whites. A group of white teen-age girls, still in school uniforms, approached a doorway looking over their shoulders. Across the street, two white boys waited outside a gate nervously jiggling their pockets. At a service station, a young white woman darted from her car to speak to a man on the corner. The exchanges -- money for drugs -- were quick and not particularly subtle. 
 Nearby, in a more residential area called Yeoville, runners waited on the grassy corners of each block, approaching any car that slowed down. "What you looking for?" was the opening line.
While a crack epidemic raged through the United States and much of Europe in the 1980's, this country remained virtually free of cocaine. International sanctions, which isolated South Africa from the world and eventually helped to topple the apartheid government, had the unexpected benefit of also isolating South Africa from the hugely addictive drug.
But now, as South Africa returns to the world economy, it has become a target for drug traffickers seeking to enlarge their markets. In the last few years, the amount of cocaine confiscated here has soared, and even more telling, officials say, the price of the drug on the street has plummeted because so much is available. Heroin use is also on the increase, though not as fast as cocaine.
"A few years ago, if you'd get a few grams, that was a decent case," said Superintendent Ian Ralph of the Johannesburg narcotics squad. "Now it's much bigger. Cocaine is freely available, just about anytime day or night. It's all over the place, and it's still getting worse."
Police officials admit that they are hardly ready to combat the influx of drugs. The South African police force has only about 400 men assigned to the task nationwide. At Johannesburg airport, where international flights have more than doubled since 1990, no new narcotics agents have been hired, and the X-ray machine they used to inspect luggage from the planes broke down more than a year ago and has not been replaced.
Police officers at the airport are amassing an interesting collection of suitcases with false bottoms and storage containers made to look like everything from hair-spray cans to engine parts. But there is no doubt about how much gets through.
In one instance, the officers found an unaccompanied suitcase filled with cocaine. By checking shipping records and comparing handwriting, they figured out that it was only the latest shipment from a dealer who had passed more than two tons of cocaine through the airport.
The police confiscated only about 400 pounds of cocaine in 1995. But that was up from about 24 pounds in 1992. South Africa's new status in the drug world has drawn the attention of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration, which announced last month that it would soon open an office here. The British have promised to do the same.
South Africa not only has a sizable population rich enough to use drugs. It is also strategically placed between South America and the Far East and is therefore particularly attractive to drug dealers looking for a transit point for shipments to Europe. It also boasts the best airports, ports and roads in Africa.
"Many of the things that make this country so great are the things that give it such potential for major international drug dealing," Thomas A. Constantine, the head of the D.E.A., said after touring the country.
While South Africa is only now discovering cocaine and heroin, it has always had a drug-using population. Most popular was a powerful, locally grown marijuana called dagga that has played a role in tribal customs for centuries.
More recently, a synthetic drug called Mandrax, which is manufactured in South Africa and India, has been popular. Mandrax was a legally available sleeping pill until the 1970's. Since then, many South Africans have taken to crushing it, mixing it with marijuana and smoking it.
Officials estimate that 4.5 million tablets of Mandrax were sold in this country last year, for between $8 and $10 a tablet.
Those who run rehabilitation centers say they first began seeing cocaine addictions about four years ago. But in recent months there have been more and more users of crack, the smokable and most addictive form of cocaine.
"It's getting totally out of hand," said Dr. Sylvaine de Miranda, the director of Phoenix House, a rehabilitation center here. "Four years ago, we might have had one cocaine case a year. Now we are getting 6 to 12 inquiries a day."
For the time being, the smallest quantity of cocaine usually sold here is a "rock" of crack, which sells for about $14. Police officials say their greatest fear is that cocaine -- which is half the price it was a year ago -- will become as cheap as Mandrax.
"Crack is much, much worse than Mandrax," said C. J. D. Venter, the head of the country's organized crime task force. "If they can swing that market, then the potential for violence is enormous."
The cocaine originates in South America, and it is usually distributed here by Nigerians, who come in as tourists or refugees. They rarely use the drugs themselves.
Their customers are largely white, since whites are the most likely to be able to afford cocaine.
At a rehabilitation center here recently, a 16-year-old girl described her downward spiral of addiction to cocaine. In three months, she said, she wiped out her $3,000 savings account. Then, she said, she pawned her jewelry and even her shoes. Then she started stealing from her parents.
"I found I could buy cocaine anywhere I wanted," she said. "I went to four different high schools in the last year, and I could get whatever I wanted at all of them."

HEADLINE: Essay;
In a Smoke-Free Room

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Two weeks ago, newsmagazine covers were touting Steve Forbes; polls were reporting growing Forbes strength in Iowa and pulling away from the field in New Hampshire.
Eschewing all food during that feeding frenzy, I expressed a certitude that no rich newcomer would be the Republican nominee. Now, with Forbes's balloon punctured, there are none in fickle medialand so poor to do him reverence. 
 The frenzy relocates. Still afflicted with the urge to surge, the pollster-pundit-strategist complex has now chosen Pat Buchanan as its Hero-Villain of the Week.
We are being treated to the If parade: If it snows hard, and if the Forbes TV barrage has weakened Dole, and if the floaters split the support of electable candidates by alighting on Lamar Alexander -- won't Buchanan's True Believers propel him to victory?
Certitude time again: no Buchanan showing in any early primary will determine the nomination outcome. Today's Republican Party has a life wish and -- remembering how its Goldwater debacle ushered in L.B.J.'s Great Society -- will not be led down the path to certain defeat.
Therefore, Republicans interested in replacing Clinton can treat the Buchanan showing, whatever it is, with respect but not with a deference rooted in fear. Sideshows are over; the 1996 G.O.P. campaign is now between Dole and Alexander.
I recall a dinner with Lamar early last year. In a booth at the Palm restaurant in Washington, with the field of candidates widening and his recognition factor in single digits, he revealed a strategy of survival known best to long-distance runners: "The last one left standing wins."
After New Hampshire, he will be one of the two electables left standing. What will the Dole-Alexander race be about?
At the start, it will center on who has the best chance of beating Clinton.
The resolute Alexander, who learned speechwriting at the knee of the legendary Bryce Harlow, knows how to focus on a few issues and hone his message down to a few memorable lines; that's why he can present himself as a more articulate and media-savvy opponent to Clinton in toe-to-toe debate.
Beyond that, Lamar will find ways (other than walking across the United States) to contrast his relative youth and energy with Dole's age and the potential return of Dole's testiness. The younger man has not been doing this subtly enough; now that he has established himself as Dole's alternative, Alexander is likely to appeal to undecided Republicans with the vigor of his "outsider's" attack on Clinton.
The experienced Dole, tested in crisis and advantaged by his handicap, is the long-distance runner. He paces himself better now; knows the track's purpose is to collect delegates rather than media kudos; and may have enough kick left for a convention sprint.
Dole will leave most of the hard-shell Buchanan vote to Buchanan and compete with Alexander for the other three-fourths of Republicans. That means casting the race along the lines of 1980, with himself as ol'-shoe Reagan and Alexander as preppy Bush. (Lamar, financed and advised by Bushies, is aware of the danger; the key state may be Texas, with Senator Gramm and Governor Bush taking different sides.)
At March's end, if both Dole and Alexander are on their feet, the strategy of mutual undermining -- "too old" vs. "Bush II" -- will lose appeal and have to be subordinated to a more elevated campaign about ideas showing "vision" and "leadership."
Cornball? Hardly; conservatives like me would like to see a preconvention campaign that focuses not on flat taxes or border fences but on the means to budget balancing, power devolution, term limits and assertive foreign policy.
China and Russia may force foreign decisions, Dole's strong suit; as the economy turns down, Alexander has the more imaginative ideas. Both can play off the Buchanan minority's iso-protectionism.
If the party and nation are lucky, we will sail through to an open convention in San Diego. Credentials fights; platform debates; horse trading in smoke-free rooms; floor demonstrations; above all, suspense (Lugar on the 10th ballot?)
Can't wait. Pity the dull Democrats.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Balkan Leaders Pledge to Carry Out Dayton Accord

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Officials of the United States and its NATO allies concluded two days of sometimes tense meetings with Balkan leaders here today, producing a series of declarations that recommit the former warring parties to full compliance with the Bosnian peace accords.
In four formal documents, the Presidents of Serbia, Croatia and Bosnia pledged to resume contacts with commanders of the NATO-led force, to carry out on schedule the establishment of a unified administration in the Bosnian capital of Sarajevo, to insure the safety of war prisoners and refugees, and to commit themselves to the prosecution of war crimes and other human rights abuses. 
 The talks were called because of increasing frustration over the pace at which many provisions of the Dayton peace accord were being put into effect.
Serbian agreement to at least some of the terms of today's documents was eased by assurance from the United States and its allies that moves would begin this week to suspend economic sanctions against the Bosnian Serbs.
Much of the substance, if not always the detail, of this weekend's agreements was included in the Dayton accord, which was signed in Paris in December. It is unclear to what extent the renewed assurances, which were accepted by Presidents Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, Franjo Tudjman of Croatia and Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia, will restore momentum to the faltering peace effort.
Nevertheless, Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke, the chief American negotiator, said, "We have avoided a crisis."
Speaking at a news conference, Mr. Holbrooke, who is to retire from the State Department this week, said, "We have prevented a situation that could have jeopardized the Dayton agreements."
In the principal document, the three Presidents reaffirmed their commitment to fully carry out the Dayton accord. Thus, Serbia agreed that its military officers would resume contacts and talks with NATO military officials, which were suspended to protest the arrest of Bosnian Serb officers as suspected war criminals.
Agreement was reached on specific terms to reunify the Bosnian city of Mostar, which is divided between Muslims and Croats and has been a major stumbling block to progress.
Mr. Holbrooke insisted that the weekend's meetings, which were joined by officials of France, Britain, Germany and Russia -- the countries that with the United States make up the "contact group" that has tried to bring peace to the former Yugoslavia -- did not alter the Dayton accord.
"Let me stress: there was no change to Dayton here in Rome," Mr. Holbrooke said.
Officials sought to emphasize the progress made in resolving problems surrounding Sarajevo, where the transfer of several Serbian-held suburbs to the control of the Muslim-dominated Government has faced resistance. In what appeared to be a concession to the Serbian side, the United States and its allies agreed to begin the process of lifting sanctions imposed by the United Nations against the Bosnian Serbs, in exchange for fresh impetus on resolving the deadlock in Sarajevo.
In recent days, large numbers of Serbian families have deserted Sarajevo. In a statement that was signed by Presidents Milosevic of Serbia and Izetbegovic of Bosnia, as well as political leaders of the three factions in Bosnia -- Muslim, Serb and Croat -- the Sarajevo Serbs were called on not to desert their homes.
"We appeal to all to stay in the city," the statement read, adding that residents should "rest assured that their legitimate rights will be taken into account."
Deputy Foreign Minister Nikolai N. Afanasyevsky of Russia said the decision to consider lifting sanctions would "promote peace and positive attitudes toward the three parties."
American officials sought to play down the significance of this issue, recalling that an end to sanctions had been foreseen by the Dayton accord. They suggested that it represented merely a technical step, which hinged on NATO commanders' assessment of the Bosnian Serbs' willingness to abide by the Dayton agreement's terms on military disengagement.
"This is not a concession," Mr. Holbrooke said. "It must be earned by actions on the ground."
In Dayton last year, the rival factions agreed to a timetable for pulling their troops back behind a zone of separation, and the suspension of sanctions was made contingent on compliance.
Officials said substantive agreement had been reached early today, but hours of further debate had been required to resolve the final issue, the reunification of Mostar.

HEADLINE: Newspaper Owners Do the Shuffle;
Communities Worry as Dailies Pass From Chain to Chain

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

DATELINE: MIDDLETOWN, Conn.

 BODY:
For a generation, family owners of local newspapers in places across the country like this old city on the Connecticut River have been selling off to chains.
But a new phenomenon has arrived here in Middletown and from coast to coast: chains are now selling many of those same newspapers to other chains. The result is a widespread churning of hometown dailies that is reshaping the newspaper industry, leaving communities confused about who their corporate publishers are -- or what they stand for -- and raising old questions about whether corporate control of newspapers is good for the country. 
 Many people in communities with new corporate owners of their newspapers said their towns seemed diminished when their papers became a commodity traded among outsiders. Some people here in Middletown say the arrival of the Journal Register Company, the second chain owner in four and a half years, has meant a disappointing end to some of the local idiosyncrasies and autonomy that survived the first phase of chain ownership.
One example much noted by people here is the newspaper's new design, which made The Middletown Press look just like the newspapers that Journal Register bought not long ago in the nearby towns of New Britain and Bristol.
"You wonder whether The Middletown Press is just going to be one of those papers that changes hands every few years when the owner can make a profit," said Stephen T. Gionfriddo, a councilman and former mayor here, who echoed the sentiments of people in a dozen other places.
Some newspaper executives say groups of nearby papers are more efficient to manage and can benefit from economies of scale like shared printing plants. Local news, they say, can be re-used in neighboring papers, on computer on-line services and in printed "niche" products like tabloids on high school sports and other topics.
The Middletown Press and four other Connecticut dailies owned by the Journal Register Company now share articles, and all the papers can rely on a single reporter to cover Hartford sporting events or news from the statehouse, said Robert M. Jelenic, the company president.
But, "to me," Mr. Gionfriddo said, "The Middletown Press no longer feels like a hometown paper, and that, to me, has been a loss."
During the last three years, 256 of the nation's 1,550 daily papers have changed hands, more than the total during the previous six years. At the same time, the number of newspaper deals involving groups selling to other groups has increased steadily. Last year, 75 percent of all the newspapers sold passed from one group to another, up from just 16 percent 10 years ago, according to Dirks, Van Essen & Associates, a newspaper broker.
Newspaper analysts say the churning of local papers is a symptom of an industry reshaping itself to compete with new competitors like electronic information distributors. They say it also represents a new phase in the deepening trend toward consolidation that has been bringing newspapers across the country under the control of chains for decades.
With many newspapers struggling against higher newsprint prices and weakening circulation, some companies are shuffling their papers to "cluster" dailies so they can cut costs and share information gathered by their reporters.
Other companies are collecting small papers, which typically have much higher profit margins than big-city dailies. Still others are backing away from smaller papers to concentrate on larger dailies or electronic media as the newspaper industry grows more competitive.
Some industry analysts say such strategies reflect the reality that it has become harder to wring profits from newspapers of all sizes. "There is a realization that the newspaper business is still a good business, but it has to be made more efficient and the way you become more efficient is by reducing costs and through economies of scale," said Kenneth T. Berents, a newspaper securities analyst at Wheat First Butcher Singer in Richmond.
The shuffling of local papers has involved companies of all sizes, including giants like the Gannett Company, which bought 11 dailies last year, and The New York Times Company, which sold five dailies last year, and smaller companies like the Journal Register Company of Trenton, a fast-growing chain that bought the Middletown paper in September. Journal Register is owned by the New York investment firm E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Company.
In the newspaper equivalent of an odd-lot sale, Thomson Newspapers, based in Canada, sold 25 American newspapers last year, from the Barstow (Calif.) Desert Dispatch to the Herkimer (N.Y.) Evening Telegram. The biggest buyer was Hollinger Inc., controlled by the Canadian press entrepreneur Conrad Black, which now publishes 111 dailies in the United States, more than any other company.
Executives at Journal Register, echoing those at other companies that are buying newspapers, say efficient management will give their papers new life. But to some people changes in ownership have brought unwelcome changes to their hometown papers.
In places like Fayetteville, Ark., and Sedalia, Mo., people said editors installed by new owners did not seem sufficiently acquainted with the towns to know who was prominent enough to merit an obituary.
Jane Gray, the Mayor of Sedalia, said the sale of The Sedalia Democrat by Thomson Newspapers to Freedom Communications of Santa Ana, Calif., seemed to leave Sedalia out of the equation. "It seems to me," she said, "there needs to be some kind of peer input, which you can't have if you don't even know who they are, where they are."
What has happened to The Middletown Press in recent months and the local debate about it in this city of about 43,000 south of Hartford, provides a glimpse of similar stories in scores of other towns.
For The Press, the latest chapter began four years ago with the D'Oench brothers, who had run the paper for 32 years and knew most everyone in town. They realized, Russell G. D'Oench Jr. said recently, that no one in the family was interested in taking over the paper. "We were trying to put it into good hands," said Mr. D'Oench, who was editor while his brother, Woodbridge D'Oench, was publisher.
The natural choice, Mr. D'Oench said, was Eagle Publishing, a small chain owned by the Miller family, which published the respected Berkshire Eagle in Pittsfield, Mass. But soon after the sale to Eagle, residents and staff members of The Press said, the match provided a disturbing first taste of the risks of chain newspaper management.
Executives sent in by the Massachusetts managers quarreled bitterly with each other and then abruptly changed The Press from an afternoon to a morning paper, a decision that some people here said betrayed a lack of understanding of the rhythm of Middletown. Some blame that switch for a rapid drop in daily circulation to about 13,000 from about 20,000.
Not long after that, Eagle Publishing slipped into its own financial troubles because of an ill-timed real estate investment in Massachusetts. The Middletown Press, some people here say, seemed something of a stepchild after that.
By last summer, the Millers' financial troubles led them to sell their newspapers to Media News Group of Denver, controlled by W. Dean Singleton, one of the newspaper industry's most bottom-line-oriented executives. But by the time the dust had settled in September, Mr. Singleton had sold The Middletown Press once again, this time to Journal Register.
Journal Register, which owns The New Haven Register, The Trentonian and 15 other dailies, was from the start a different kind of corporate owner from Eagle. Known as intensely focused on profit, the company's reputation preceded it here. Journalists at The Press said they were concerned about whether the new owner would block efforts to put out a quality paper. Some said they were especially anxious about several incidents that had received extensive publicity in Connecticut.
When Journal Register started a new Sunday issue in 1994 at its paper in Torrington, Conn., for example, a reporter for the paper wrote an article about delivery problems for the new issue. The reporter was dismissed. Then the editorial page editor resigned, saying the paper had refused to print letters to the editor protesting the dismissal.
News accounts had portrayed the episode as a sign that Journal Register would compromise journalistic values in favor of its business interests.
And just as the company was buying The Middletown Press last fall, The Hartford Advocate, an alternative paper that circulates here, described Journal Register as "a top-down, bottom-line, feed-'em-to-the-wolves corporation."
Mr. Jelenic, president of Journal Register, said in a recent interview that some of the bad publicity came from worried competitors. He refused to discuss the Torrington incident, but he said Journal Register improved all its papers by, among other strategies, combining operations with nearby papers it owns.
"Because you have so much in the way of efficiencies," Mr. Jelenic said, "you can have a few fewer people but you can get a better product."
Within a few weeks of Journal Register's arrival, national and international news, which had long been featured prominently in The Press, was de-emphasized. Some of the paper's longtime journalists were not offered jobs. Soon, virtually the entire news staff was gone.
On Oct. 1, the familiar black-and-white layout was replaced with the new design, which emphasized bright colors, including a red banner on the front page and large pictures. There were new sections and many small local articles by reporters no one around here had heard of before.
James F. Normandin, the new publisher here, said the newly designed paper had received an enthusiastic response because of an emphasis on local news.
But on Main Street, where the changes in The Press have often been a topic of conversation, the reviews have not always been good. Vincent Amato, who has run Amatos toy store for 56 years, said the paper relied on young reporters "who don't know the background like the people who were here for a long time and lived here." He said the paper was filled with insignificant articles. "It takes me about a quarter of the time to read the paper that it used to," he said.
William Corvo, who is active in local Republican politics and whowrote a political column for the paper until the new management stopped it, said The Middletown Press had lost the flavor of Middletown. "The substance is missing," he said.
Russell D'Oench, the former editor and co-owner, said the story of The Middletown Press had not worked out as he had hoped. The new publishers, he said, seem to have designed their paper without a sense of place. "It is definitely a chain cookie-cutter solution," he said. "It wouldn't have been my preference."
Mr. Jelenic said he was used to criticism and he did not dwell on it. In fact, he said, he was off on a trip: He was in search of other towns where papers like The Middletown Press are for sale again.

HEADLINE: Hark! A Mainer Stirs Economic Populism!

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: NORTH PARSONSFIELD, Me.

 BODY:
Clanging on a trash-can lid to kick off a Maine corn chowder potluck meeting this month, the featured speaker and organizer plunged into a fast-paced condemnation of corporate downsizing and free trade.
"Corporations aren't there for the public good," she told the crowd of about 70 loggers, farmers, environmentalists and self-described anarchists at a schoolhouse in this town near the New Hampshire border. "They're there to produce more profits for the stockholders in the next quarter." 
 Patrick J. Buchanan is not the only one bringing a message of economic populism to working-class New Englanders worried about layoffs and weakening wages.
The potluck speaker, Carolyn Chute, Maine's native-daughter novelist, has been organizing a grass-roots political movement centered on making corporations and government more responsive to workers. Calling her group the 2d Maine Militia, Ms. Chute has attracted some of Maine's conservatives with her support for gun-ownership rights and by bashing the North American Free Trade Agreement.
But the group, which Ms. Chute began last year and which is more gun club than militia, is appealing to conservative and liberal Mainers alike by opposing proposals for a flat income tax and demanding an end to corporation campaign contributions and tax subsidies for big business.
Regarding such issues as abortion and gay rights, she and her followers consider them distractions from the more important issues of jobs and government accountability to the working class.
Growing up in a blue-collar family, and experiencing poverty as a single parent, Ms. Chute, who is in her 40's, has long complained about the lack of attention given to have-nots in this country.
"Many other militias and many individuals blame gays, blacks, Jews, Spanish-speaking folks, welfare mums, illegal drugs, seat belts, schools without prayers, women with shoes, abortions, environmentalists, unseen Communist forces and so-called liberals," Ms. Chute wrote in a Dec. 24, 1995, opinion article in The Maine Sunday Telegram, a Portland newspaper.
"The whole of America is squabbling over all these details while huge corporations smilingly take more than 50 percent off the top of the Federal budget for subsidies including outright handouts for researching new business opportunities in other countries where they can exploit foreign workers like they exploit us, all in the name of free enterprise and individual rights."
Ms. Chute has gained a fierce loyalty from many rural Maine readers with her 1985 best-selling first novel, "The Beans of Egypt, Maine," and other gritty books about working-class poverty and powerlessness.
But despite Ms. Chute's popularity, her group has an uncertain future. No definitive plans have been made on how to achieve the group's goals, and no donations have been solicited. She acknowledges her ignorance of the political process but pushes aside suggestions that the group will simply fade away for lack of money and sophistication.
"We realize that our goals may take many lifetimes," she said in an interview at the potluck lunch. "We have to be patient. We're trying to educate and we're also trying to educate how powerful we can be."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The novelist Carolyn Chute talking to a small group after a recent meeting of the 2d Maine Militia in North Parsonsfield, Me. The group's goal is to make corporations and government more responsive to workers. (Rick Cinclair for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: LOSING MOMENTUM;
The Surge Has Waned, but Forbes Remains Hopeful

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

DATELINE: NASHUA, N.H., Feb. 18

 BODY:
Barely two weeks ago in Iowa, Steve Forbes was a heavyweight. His Presidential candidacy spooked the front-runner, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas. Now, on the eve of New Hampshire's primary, Mr. Forbes finds himself a bantamweight candidate, hoping to do well enough to get an economy-class ticket to future primaries.
This, of course, is not a fate Mr. Forbes muses about, at least in public. He has settled into a survivalist mode. "This race is now wide open," he said in an interview on Saturday. "Dole has lost his aura of invincibility. Buchanan has become a serious player. Alexander has become a serious player. The question is, Can Buchanan and Alexander survive the examination that every candidate goes through? So it's going to be very fluid, very fluid for another three weeks before it shakes out." 
 By and large, the forces that converted a heavyweight into a bantamweight seem to have been matters within Mr. Forbes's control. They include his multimillion-dollar campaign of negative advertising, his decision not to speak in depth about any issue beyond his flat-tax plan, and an inability to win the trust of a critical mass of religious conservatives. Even minor breaches of political etiquette, like returning to his headquarters for a strategy session the day after the Iowa caucuses instead of coming straight to New Hampshire, annoyed some of the party faithful here.
Asked how he felt about the advertising strategy, which he has abandoned and now refers to as "a mistake," he said: "Certainly my negatives are going down. How much that translates into votes, I don't know. But I think we have turned the corner."
At some of the stops Mr. Forbes has made in the final run-up to Tuesday's primary, there are subtle signs of his flagging fortunes. At his speech in the Daniel Webster College gym on Saturday, the college students flanking the Forbes family on the bottom row of the bleachers and the ones in the second row held Forbes signs, but many were not supporters. The second row was made up of students from a political science class at Tufts University in Massachusetts; a few supported him, but others were just there at an instructor's advice.
And Mr. Forbes is finding it much easier to move about New Hampshire than was the case in Iowa -- because media interest in him is waning. Last Sunday a swarm of television crews surrounded him as he entered a Holiday Inn in Des Moines to give a speech, making movement through a section of the lobby dangerous. ABC reported later that there were close to 50 crews. On Friday night, after Mr. Forbes greeted Nashua City Republicans at a dinner, only six crews trailed the Forbes family to elevators in the Nashua Marriott.
In the eyes of some analysts, Mr. Forbes's negative-advertising war broke a cardinal rule. "You've got to lay a positive base before you go negative on everyone else," said William Kristol, editor of the Weekly Standard, a conservative magazine. "I'm a friend of his, and I hope he gets out of the race."
Once Mr. Forbes won the perceptual look-at-me primary in the minds of voters and the media, he seemed unable to broaden himself from Steve Flat Tax; he never gave major addresses devoted solely to other issues.
And although he is not the only candidate using attack advertising, his record in that regard in Iowa and New Hampshire is longer than any of his rivals. Only Mr. Forbes has had the means to wage a multimillion-dollar air war, because he dipped into his own fortune and chose not take public matching money, freeing him of Federal spending limits.
Mr. Forbes has also been unable to convince many Christian fundamentalists that his opposition to abortion is genuine. Today, mindful of that, he made a last-minute effort to open a dialogue by meeting informally with clergy members and others who oppose abortion.
The views of Lyn Nofziger, who was an aide to President Ronald Reagan and now is a Dole supporter, are typical of the analysis of Mr. Forbes's rise and near-collapse in an anti-tax state that appeared hospitable to his message.
"Once you got him out of talking about the flat tax, he was a little vague," Mr. Nofziger said. "Secondly, I think his negative ads against everybody seemed to have a bad reaction."
But there is also a Lazarus current in speculation about Mr. Forbes. "His message of growth and opportunity and freedom is one that still has powerful resonance," said a prominent conservative who asked for anonymity. "It's too early to write his obituary."
Mr. Kristol disagreed.
Reiterating a position taken in a recent editorial in his magazine, he said that Mr. Forbes remained "an improbable Presidential candidate," a person Americans would not be willing to take a gamble on.
Mr. Forbes sees his reduced circumstances here as the confluence of forces mostly beyond his control. In the interview, he cited Mr. Dole's negative television advertisements. Also, he said, both the leadership of the Christian Coalition and the press damaged his candidacy.
Mr. Kristol said that if Mr. Forbes withdraws soon, he can continue pushing the party to embrace Mr. Reagan's vision of growth, opportunity and curbing government. He said Mr. Forbes deserved credit for moving the party "away from an almost excessive focus on balancing the budget."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Before his less-than-impressive showing in the Iowa caucuses last Monday, Steve Forbes looked as if he could just possibly make it all the way to the White House. Now Mr. Forbes, arriving yesterday at the airport in Littleton, N.H., hopes he can make it to the next primary. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Incoming Leader of N.A.A.C.P. Vows That 'Change Is at Hand'

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Kweisi Mfume, who is to be formally sworn in tomorrow in Washington as the newly chosen chief officer of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, has already put his personal stamp on the troubled organization.
"Change is at hand -- we are in the process of reinventing ourselves," Mr. Mfume said Saturday night after his selection was ratified at the N.A.A.C.P.'s annual board meeting in New York. 
 Mr. Mfume, who served as chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus from 1992 to 1994, faces the challenges not only of reviving the N.A.A.C.P. but also of grappling with a national political climate that threatens to roll back civil rights advances.
In approving his contract by a unanimous vote, the board tried to put to rest the recent years of internecine power struggles and scandals that have hurt the N.A.A.C.P.'s recruitment drives and fund-raising campaigns and damaged its clout as the country's oldest and best known civil rights organization.
The top post had been vacant since 1994, when the board dismissed Benjamin F. Chavis Jr. as executive director after revelations that he had secretly spent N.A.A.C.P. money to fend off a sexual harassment and discrimination complaint.
Entrusting Mr. Mfume with broader power than his predecessors held, the board amended its constitution to create for him the new post of president and chief executive officer. It also agreed to have him report to a 17-member executive committee instead of to the full 64-member board.
Board members called Mr. Mfume's speech healing and upbeat. The chairwoman, Myrlie Evers-Williams, said, "It's a glorious day for this organization as well as for the country."
But the internal problems Mr. Mfume faces were still evident in the wrangling and disorganization at the three-day board gathering at the Hilton hotel in Manhattan, ending with a 12-hour meeting -- much of it in executive session. In a public relations blunder, a news conference scheduled to showcase the new president to the nation was delayed more than eight hours.
Even after staff cuts, the N.A.A.C.P.'s $6 million-a-year operation has a $3 million debt. Stressing its commitment to fiscal responsibility, the board authorized its lawyer to seek restitution of more than $100,000 it says was misspent by the former chairman, William F. Gibson, whom it ousted a year ago but who still has loyalists.
Mr. Mfume said he was eager to rebuild the organization's membership, which he estimated the paid total at 500,000, plus 500,000 volunteers. He promised to straighten out the records "so there won't even be a question."
President Clinton's expected attendance at the swearing-in underscores the symbolic importance of the N.A.A.C.P., with its long history of protests, litigation and legislation. But critics say the N.A.A.C.P. seems irrelevant, uncertain of its mission and upstaged by other black organizations, like the Nation of Islam with its Million Man March.
In Kweisi Mfume (pronounced kwah-EE-see oom-FOO-may), the N.A.A.C.P. has a self-made man who rose from dire beginnings in Baltimore. An orphan, he became a school dropout and homeless youth who fathered five children out of wedlock.
But he turned his life around through education and work, becoming a poised, popular radio broadcaster and then a City Councilman and five-term Democratic Congressman.
Identifying with the "despair and hopelessness" of disaffected black youths, Mr. Mfume said he would make them a priority for the N.A.A.C.P. Also high on his list is voter registration, economic development and support from foundations and corporations.
Mr. Mfume relinquished his Congressional seat to lead the N.A.A.C.P. The board declined to release the terms of his contract but did not dispute a reported salary of $200,000.
In a bitter episode in Mr. Mfume's career, he announced "a sacred covenant" with the black nationalist Louis Farrakhan in 1992. Jewish organizations and some black leaders assailed Mr. Mfume, who later disavowed his remarks.
At the board meeting, he said: "Racism, sexism and anti-Semitism are wrong. As long as there is an N.A.A.C.P., they will never enjoy a quiet and acceptable existence."
He called for wider coalitions with other minority groups, saying the organization is "big enough, bad enough and broad enough" to reach out to Hispanic, Asian-American, native American Indian, Jewish and other groups.
Noting that blacks have always reflected a broad spectrum of political views and styles, Mr. Mfume struck a mainstream note for the N.A.A.C.P.
"We want to create and cultivate a movement that represents the best of America," he said. "Racial and religious tolerance and effecting change in government became the banner of N.A.A.C.P." years ago and remain valid today, he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Slow Recovery, or a Shift In the Business Cycle?
The greater New York region has recovered only about a third of the 770,000 jobs it lost in the most recent recession, and it shows no sign of quickly regaining the rest. The phenomenon has shaken faith in the long-held belief in the area that the business cycle is eternal and that when an economic downturn is over, old-fashioned growth will resume. [Page A1.]
 
Procter to Cut Marketing Budget
Procter & Gamble plans to cut its spending on marketing as it shifts to a strategy of reducing prices for its products. [D2.]
 
Canada's Chinese Publications
Two leading Canadian magazines are bringing out Chinese-language editions, responding to an influx of immigrants. [D5.]
 
Back in the Cyber Stone Age
Fifty years ago, scientists at the University of Pennsylvania first demonstrated the Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer, a 30-ton behemoth that was considered the first general-purpose electronic computer. The Eniac, as it is called, was anything but personal, and no laptop version was built. [D3.]
 
One Size Fits One
Because about half of all Americans buy clothing that does not fit them, an apparel industry group is developing a system that would let retailers scan a customer's body to create relatively cheap custom-fit garments. No, the process could not be used in reverse, to make a customer's body fit the clothes. [D3.]
 
Unclear Route for Apple's Journey
Does Apple Computer's new chief executive, Gilbert F. Amelio, have a grand vision for remaking the company? If so, he has not disclosed it as he has moved cautiously to apply his engineering skills to running the computer maker. News analysis. [D2.]
 
Little Interest in Milwaukee Bid
The employee-owners of The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel's parent company have shown little interest in accepting a bid to buy their company, even though the offer is equal to twice the price of the stock they hold. [D6.]
 
New Imprint for Young Editor
William Morrow, the publishing house, lured a 30-year-old editor from Bantam with an accolade usually reserved for much older editors: his own imprint. [D5.]
 
Tonight's Lineup: Sex. More at 11.
You know it is a Nielsen ratings sweep month when every television magazine program is doing a weeklong report on a fashion show featuring lingerie from Victoria's Secret. Some network and advertising executives complain that stunts like these are skewing the ratings. Bill Carter: Television. [D5.]
 
Using a Deck, Not a D.E.C.
A new game is set in the "dark technofuture" in which "ruthless corporations scheme to accomplish secret agendas as they build elaborate fortresses of data." The players' tools for navigating this web: a deck of cards. Edward Rothstein: Technology. [D3.]
 
Job Hunting on the Web
Many employers, from government agencies to private companies, sponsor recruiting sites on the World Wide Web. [D6.]
