HEADLINE: Kennedy-Castro Encounter Touched by History

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Feb. 18

 BODY:
At the height of the cold war, Fidel Castro and John F. Kennedy were the bitterest of adversaries. So when the Cuban leader strode into a reception room at the Palace of the Revolution here early today to meet Robert and Michael Kennedy, two nephews of the American President, history hung heavily over the encounter.
The Bay of Pigs, the Cuban missile crisis -- Mr. Castro reflected on the major conflicts between the United States and Cuba that marked his first years in power, and on the Kennedy assassination. But pressed by his American visitors during a colloquy that lasted nearly three hours, he also responded to issues that still cloud relations with the United States, like human rights and Cuba's nuclear power program. 
 "My family and my own life have been intertwined with Cuba," Robert F. Kennedy Jr. told Mr. Castro at one point, recalling how as a child he was allowed by his father, the Attorney General and chief adviser to his brother the President, to come into meetings on the Cuban missile crisis. "Although there was much antagonism in the political relationship," he added, there was also respect for Mr. Castro's skills as a soldier and leader.
"It's unfortunate things happened as they did, and he could not do what he wanted to do," Mr. Castro said, referring to John F. Kennedy's assassination. "It is my impression that it was his intention after the missile crisis to change the framework" of relations between the United States and Cuba, which remains hostile even today.
The Kennedy brothers have been in Cuba since Wednesday as part of private visit by a delegation of 10 American energy experts and environmental safety advocates organized by the Natural Resources Defense Council and the Citizens Energy Corporation.
The United States Government granted the groups the licenses that allowed them to travel legally to Cuba for the visit, which is to end on Monday.
Robert F. Kennedy Jr., 42, is senior staff attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council, which is based in Washington, and lobbies in the United States and abroad on environmental and energy issues.
Michael L. Kennedy, 37, is chairman of Citizens Energy Corporation, a Boston-based nonprofit company that promotes the development of alternative energy resources and has been active in the third world.
Their meeting with the Cuban President began at 12:30 this morning because, Mr. Castro said, he had been watching a Cuban baseball playoff game on television late Saturday night and wanted to see how it ended. The team he was rooting for, Villa Clara, won 12-4, as it turned out, beating the Havana Industriales, and Mr. Castro entered in a chipper mood, wearing his customary green fatigues.
As is his custom in such discussions, the Cuban leader roamed over a wide variety of topics, offering assessments of luminaries ranging from Jacques Chirac and Mikhail S. Gorbachev to Babe Ruth and Louis Farrakhan. But he turned several times to his memories of the three years in which he squared off against John and Robert Kennedy during the cold war.
Mr. Castro did not refer to the American-sponsored assassination attempts against him that took place during the Kennedy Administration, nor did he offer his theory of who killed the President. But he talked at some length about the failed Bay of Pigs invasion in April 1961, which, he argued, was primarily a product of the Eisenhower Administration. The invasion attempt, carried out by Cuban exiles who were armed and trained by the United States, was a disaster, with most of the invaders killed or captured.
"I don't think they were left with many options in regard to Cuba," he said, referring to John and Robert Kennedy. "When they took office, all the plans were on. It would have been too difficult for them to change things. I think they inherited a legacy from the previous Administration."
Clearly in a ruminative state of mind, the Cuban leader reflected on how the fortunes of the Kennedy Administration were linked with his own. "President Kennedy enjoyed great prestige after the missile crisis," he said of the October 1962 showdown over Soviet missiles in Cuba in which both Mr. Castro and Nikita S. Khrushchev were forced to back down. "It was different than after the Bay of Pigs."
The day President Kennedy was killed, Mr. Castro recalled, he was meeting with a French journalist who had agreed to serve as an unofficial messenger between the men. "We were talking in Varadero at noontime," he said, referring to a beach resort on Cuba's northern coast. "What a coincidence that was. Just as we had started talking, the radio broadcast news of the President's assassination. That was very dramatic news, especially for me."
Michael Kennedy informed Mr. Castro that recently declassified United States Government documents now in the possession of the Kennedy Library in Boston indicate that President Kennedy was considering steps to improve relations with Cuba at the time he was killed.
"Have they all been declassified?" asked a clearly curious Mr. Castro, who was given copies of the documents at the end of the meeting.
Mr. Castro was also reminded that before he seized power in 1959, Robert and Michael Kennedy's maternal grandfather, George Skakel, owned a home in Varadero, where a neighbor was Fulgencio Batista, the dictator Mr. Castro would overthrow.
"Did we nationalize it, by any chance?" Mr. Castro asked, laughing at the thought. He then mocked legislation currently before Congress, sponsored by Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican, and Representative Dan Burton, a Republican of Indiana, that would impose sanctions on foreign investors who acquire properties in Cuba originally owned by Americans.
"You don't need Helms-Burton to be able to go there," to the family's winter home, he told the Kennedys and their cousin Michael C. Skakel. "We can make an arrangement."
Appealing to their host's sense of history, and his place in it, the Kennedys urged Mr. Castro to free several political prisoners. The Cuban leader did not seem surprised by the request, but neither did he offer much encouragement when he was handed two lists of names.
"You too?" he said, referring to previous meetings with members of the Kennedy family and foreign delegations that have also asked him to release political prisoners. "You can show me the list so that you will be forgiven in the United States."
After examining the lists and asserting that "these were surely given to you by the State Department," Mr. Castro suggested that if the United States lifted its 34-year economic embargo against Cuba he might be inclined to be more yielding.
"When the blockade is lifted and there are no longer hostilities, this category of prisoner will not exist anymore," he said. "It's in your hands. It's up to you."
Mr. Castro's remarks followed a roundup in recent days of Cuban dissidents. At least 10 people, all of them members of a coalition of opposition, human rights and professional groups called Concilio Cubano, have been arrested in the crackdown, and another is still being sought, according to colleagues of those detained.
The coalition has been trying to organize a conference here next weekend and has asked for Government authorization to meet, citing provisions of the Cuban Constitution.
The bulk of the meeting was devoted to discussion of Cuba's energy needs and its recently renewed nuclear power program. The Kennedys and the others in the delegation strongly urged Mr. Castro to abandon the nuclear program, arguing that alternative energy sources would be far safer, cleaner, cheaper and more efficient.
The future of the nuclear power plant is "a very complex question," Mr. Castro responded. But he indicated some flexibility on the issue and poked fun at his former Soviet allies and their technology, saying he looked forward to the day nuclear reactors would become "20th-century pyramids, like those in Egypt," and describing the Soviet Union's nuclear power program after the Chernobyl disaster as "just an excuse to ask for more money."
As Mr. Castro was speaking, a Russian delegation led by Minister of Nuclear Energy Viktor Mikhailov was arriving here to discuss plans to finish a nuclear reactor on Cuba's southern coast. If anyone else has a better idea, the Cuban leader indicated in what was clearly a reference to the United States and other Western nations, he would be happy to hear it.
"That chapter is not closed yet," he said. "We are open to options."

Kennedy, far left, and President John F. Kennedy, leaning over table at right, at a White House meeting during the Cuban Missile Crisis. (United Press International, 1962) (pg. A6)

HEADLINE: Toronto Journal;
Down These Frigid Streets: Homeless in Canada

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Warily, he walked into the Moss Park Armory of the Canadian Armed Forces in downtown Toronto, spotted a large cardboard box filled with pile and down jackets and tried one on for size. Other homeless men and women were doing the same.
His eyes sunk in dark pools on a furrowed face, his hands slightly shaking, he gave his name only as Matt and said he was 53, a former construction worker, living on the street for the last three years. 
 "Construction went down the tubes," he said, his voice cracking. "There was nothing else out there for me."
His wife found another man, he said, and took their five children.
Matt kept the jacket, as he was meant to, then helped himself to coffee, soup and doughnuts and spent the night on a cot -- benefits of an unusual military mission. For the first time, the Canadian Army has swung into action to try to stop deaths of the homeless from the numbing cold on Toronto streets.
Winters are always cold here, with temperatures plunging sometimes well below zero Fahrenheit and the wind off Lake Ontario something else again. But this year's harsher than usual Arctic blasts, on top of a 22 percent cut in provincial welfare allowances and the failure of employment to pick up after the longest recession since the 1930's, has created emergency conditions that are straining the resources of Canada's biggest metropolis.
"I can safely say I'm shocked at the condition of some of the people coming in here," said Lieut. Col. Tony Welsh, commander of the armory regiment, the Queen's Own Rifles of Canada, which this month responded to an emergency appeal from the Toronto City Council to host the homeless. "A lot of the skills we're using aren't regular soldiering skills."
"Or if they are," he added with a smile, "they are being used in different ways."
Three homeless men have frozen to death so far this winter, more than in any other winter in recent memory. One, in a plywood lean-to under an expressway, could not be identified for days because his hands had frozen solid over his face. A second was huddled by the door of a beauty college in a Chinese district, the third curled inside an unheated bus shelter.
Intensely proud of their Scandinavian-like social safety net, Canadians usually identify homelessness with the United States, or the third world. Yet here in Toronto, often held out as one of the best-functioning cities of North America, a surge of homelessness is not only testing compassion but setting off a political storm.
"It's a shock to see three people die here like this," said David Hutcheon, a city councilor who worked with Mayor Barbara Hall to persuade the army to open the armory to the homeless. "It's like watching somebody die in your living room."
Until the army came on the scene, hostels and churches were struggling to meet the demand. Some 4,500 hostel beds are available on any one night, up 700 over last year, and 26 churches have opened their doors.
The best estimate of the total number of homeless comes from Anishnawbe Health Toronto, an Ojibway Indian organization that looks after street people, about a fifth of whom are Indian.
Anishnawbe, which operates a health center downtown and sends out street patrols with sandwiches, coffee and soup for all the homeless, not just Indians, has gathered statistics that show the number of homeless in this city of three million rose from 11,500 in 1992 to 19,500 in 1995.
The executive director, Barbra Nahwegahbow, noted a 43 percent increase in just the last nine months of 1995. "The social conscience that Canadians seem to think they have is not really there," she lamented. "The concept still exists, but resources needed to make it fully work are harder to come by."
Spurred by the deaths of the homeless, Toronto's City Council has just approved a crisis fund amounting to $450,000 in United States currency to provide a 24-hour telephone line with information on available hostel beds, to help with psychiatric problems, to pay salaries at day drop-in centers and to increase sources of food.
"No more funerals," a demonstrator shouted as the council voted for the package this month. A sign held by another activist read, "Westinghouse and Frigidaire do a better job housing the homeless than the province of Ontario and Metro" -- a reference to shelters made by street people out of the cardboard containers that wrap refrigerators.
Easing the plight of the homeless is not high on the political screen of the new Progressive Conservative government of Ontario's Premier, Mike Harris. It was elected last June on a platform of eliminating the province's swollen budget deficit and cutting high tax rates that it says impede economic growth. Mr. Harris says the way to solve the basic problem of homelessness is through faster economic growth.
Jack Layton, chairman of the Toronto City Council's newly created Homelessness Task Force, said what frightens him the most are large numbers of people arriving at homeless shelters as part of families led either by a mother or two parents.
"Out of a total of 4,500 in the hostels, we now have more than 1,000 children and an increasing number of single mothers," he said. "We've just never seen anything like this before."
A recent report by the Toronto city government's hostel division notes that there are more women among the homeless. "Life on the streets is dangerous for women and not an option that many would choose. It naturally follows that those women who do become homeless are exceptionally vulnerable and needy."
Mr. Layton and the municipal report both cite as an important factor the shrinking stock of cheap rental apartments in the wake of a provincial government decision to halt housing projects for the poor.
The sharp cuts in welfare allowances are also taking their toll. "The poor are getting poorer," said Maj. Ronald Bowles of the Salvation Army, which runs three Toronto shelters. "We like to think this kind of thing doesn't happen on our doorstep, but it does."
Roger Hunter, chaplain at the 75-year-old Scott Mission, which also serves the homeless, lauds public donations of sleeping bags, blankets and boots. "The deaths," he said, "have raised the awareness of the community and challenged people's comfort levels."
Comfort levels are most directly challenged during a ride with an Anishnawbe street patrol. Every night, two vans loaded with hot food and drink, sleeping bags and blankets make the rounds of downtown sites frequented by the homeless.
Despite the low temperatures and availability of the armory and other refuges, many of the homeless prefer to remain outdoors, citing unsafe conditions and restrictive regulations in the shelters. It is considered a violation of their basic rights to move them indoors forcibly, as is done is some American cities.
One homeless man encountered by the patrol was Marty, 30, who sat in front of a bookstore wearing a sweatshirt, sweater, winter coat, knitted hat and scarf. He was inside a goose-feather sleeping bag and covered with blankets.
A street person for the last three years, he said: "I have no job and no education. So this is the only way I know how to stay out of trouble and survive without money." Why wouldn't he go into a shelter? "They're too far away and they make you do things."
Katt, 42, who is part Indian, lives on a grate across the street from the United States Consulate. She used to work in an auto body shop. Cataracts have impaired her sight and she has not been able to work for the past six years. How does she survive? "I've been out in Regina where it's minus 70. This is paradise."
An element of pride creeps in as people talk. Frank, 42, sleeps in front of a restaurant in Chinatown. "Last night that wind was cutting through like crazy, but I lasted it," he said. "If it goes below minus zero, it doesn't matter. I'm still there."

GRAPHIC: Photo: With the homeless suffering in Toronto's pitiless winter, the Canadian Army is helping out. At Moss Park Armory, a man looked over donated coats, helped by Capt. Tim Lourie, center, and Rifleman Robert Bundy. (Arne Glassbourg for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: CANADA (96%); UNITED STATES (79%); ARCTIC (79%); NORTH AMERICA (79%); 

STATE: ONTARIO, CANADA (94%); LAKE ONTARIO (79%);

HEADLINE: POLITICS: LABOR;
With New Militancy, Nation's Unions Hope to Drive Republicans From Congress

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 18

 BODY:
The nation's labor unions, now under more militant leadership, are gathering here today to open a drive to oust Republicans in Congress, promising their most organized and expensive political campaign ever.
With the wealthy getting richer as workers have struggled to get by, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has scrapped its prior regime's scruples about pitting the two groups against each other and will attack Republican candidates they say have helped drive down standards of living. 
 "Class war?" asked Denise Mitchell, head of public affairs for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., whose leaders begin their annual, four-day policy-making convention here on Monday. "I think they're waging class war on us." The wage gap, she said, "has become the driving issue."
Acknowledging public indifference to narrow union issues, like laws on organizing new members and the right to strike, the labor leaders intend to emphasize issues of pay that affect all working people, union and nonunion.
Often at odds in the past over issues like abortion, trade and health care, leaders of most of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s 78 affiliated unions, representing 13 million members, are proclaiming the theme of raising wages and closing the income gap with rare unanimity.
In the campaign last fall that led to his defeating Lane Kirkland, the federation president who presided over 16 years of decline by organized labor, John J. Sweeney warned that unions were veering toward irrelevance. Unions have watched their influence dwindle as their membership fell to a sixth of the workforce, from a third in the 1950's.
Mr. Sweeney promised to commit much more money and personnel to organize new members and to elect lawmakers who agree with labor's agenda.
The federation says it will pour far more resources into this election campaign than it had ever done before. It says it will spend $35 million getting working people to the polls, at least twice as much as it spent in 1992, and that member unions will also raise their spending.
Mr. Sweeney's political director, Steve Rosenthal said unions will assign hundreds of members to work full time on campaigns by March and 2,500 to work full time getting out the vote in the weeks before the November election.
The federation's political strategy is shifting, too. While it will endorse a Presidential candidate and many unions will endorse other candidates, the leadership is discouraging attacks on their opponents. Rather, the unions will inform voters about the issues, and then let them decide which candidates respond best to workers' interests.
"We believe workers are smart," Mr. Rosenthal said. "Given the right information about what's going on in this country, they'll vote for our candidate."
So far, the strategy has passed one test -- the Senate race in Oregon last month. Representative Ron Wyden, a Democrat, defeated a Republican businessman, Gordon Smith, by 17,000 votes, with the help of organized labor.
The federation fielded 12 full-time staff members from its Washington headquarters, and unions provided 25 more. Mr. Rosenthal said they had helped get 78 percent of union members in key districts to the polls.
"The Oregon race," said Mr. Sweeney after the election, "provides a vital first chapter in a new textbook on politics we're going to write this year."
Still, the labor movement's threats and breast-thumping pronouncements have often proved naively quixotic. In November 1993 they promised to rally their members to vote out the 37 Democrats in Congress who supported the North American Free Trade Agreement with Mexico and Canada, which unions saw as a threat to American jobs.
While union leaders could not stomach supporting the Democrats' opponents, many of those pro-Nafta, but otherwise pro-union, lawmakers were swept out of office when the Republicans took control of Congress after the 1994 elections. Forty of the new Republicans lawmakers have since earned zeros in the federation's ratings of their votes on labor issues, Mr. Rosenthal said.
The trade agreement and the shift in Washington provided turning points for the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s political strategy.
"Since Nafta, the world has changed," said Jay Mazur, president of the 252,000-member Union of Needle Trades, Industrial and Textile Employees. "With words like downsizing, people are being fired wholesale while corporate leaders keep raising their own salaries."
Union leaders cite a cascade of economic data showing a growing gap between the lowest and highest paid workers. The nonpartisan Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris reported last year that among its 25 member nations, the gap was widest in the United States.
Many other studies show the salaries of American corporate chief executives steadily growing to levels equivalent to 150 to 225 times the wages of their lowest paid employees. Census Bureau studies show that the lower four-fifths of American households have experienced declining incomes over 20 years through 1994. The top 1 percent of American households collect 17 percent of all income and own 42 percent of the wealth.
"The ground has never been more fertile for clean, class-based appeals than it is today," Greg Tarpinian, executive director of the union-funded Labor Research Association in New York, wrote in his monthly newsletter.
The union leaders are both flattered and fretful that the theme of wages, jobs and the income gap is reverberating in the Republican Presidential campaigns of Patrick J. Buchanan and Bob Dole.
They note that Senator Dole, who recently spoke about the disparity between workers' difficulties and Wall Street's success, has in recent years led Congress's rejection of every hot-button issue on the labor agenda, including raising the $4.25-an-hour Federal minimum wage, tightening enforcement of workplace health and safety regulations and barring employers from permanently replacing workers who strike. Mr. Buchanan has urged trade policies to thwart the loss of American jobs abroad. "But nothing could be more divisive," Ms. Mitchell said, "than his positions on women's rights and immigration."

REGION
 
Local Economy Struggles On
The metropolitan region has recovered only about a third of the 770,000 jobs it lost during the recession years of the late 1980's and early 1990's, and shows no signs of quickly regaining the rest. While old-fashioned economic growth seems to have returned to most of the country, the growth of the region's economy since 1992 has been weaker, spottier and downright stranger than anything before it, because so many of the region's industries have been fundamentally rearranged and in some cases seriously eroded. [A1.]
 
A Model for Outpatient Care
 The future of health care in the New York region, industry analysts say, is an airy, gleaming building on Union Square that looks like a medical mall: pediatrics on 2, orthopedics and internal medicine on 3, coffee shop on 1, and glass-walled waiting rooms looking out on an atrium with a waterfall. Health care experts are calling it a model for the city and the region, where outpatient, or ambulatory, care is booming. [B1.]
 
Newspapers Do the Shuffle
 For a generation, family owners of local newspapers across the country have been selling off to chains. But a new phenomenon has arrived in Middletown, Conn., and elsewhere: chains are now selling many of those newspapers to other chains. The result is a widespread churning of hometown dailies that is reshaping the newspaper industry, leaving communities confused about who the corporate publishers are -- or what they stand for. Business Day. [D1.]

HEADLINE: POLITICS: LOOKING TO ECONOMICS;
Dole, Stung in 1988, Charts Cautious Economic Course

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: HUDSON, N.H., Feb. 18

 BODY:
When he was running for President eight years ago, Bob Dole offered bitter medicine to reduce the deficit: an across-the-board freeze for one year on all Federal spending. And he lost the New Hampshire primary.
Now, with just two days to go until New Hampshire votes again, and with talk in the air of a possible upset of Mr. Dole by Patrick J. Buchanan, Mr. Dole is offering a somewhat more palatable pill. 
 In a speech here on Saturday night, he outlined an unspecified package of what he called the "four freedoms of economic security": support for a balanced budget, no "unreasonable" taxes, less regulation and a free international market.
The speech was billed as a major economic address. But in pulling together various notions that Mr. Dole, the 72-year-old, five-term Kansas Senator, has mentioned in snatches on the campaign trail and in the well of the Senate over the years, it broke no new ground. The speech was delivered at a nonpartisan Chamber of Commerce dinner on Saturday night after the 6 o'clock news, guaranteeing minimal exposure.
Mr. Dole's advisers concede that as he attempts to appear more upbeat this year, in his final pursuit of the Republican Presidential nomination, he is being vague about his economic plan, searching for a way to address the economic anxieties of the New Hampshire voters who are responding to Mr. Buchanan's clarion call of economic populism. Mr. Buchanan rails against trade deals that he says have benefited corporate America at the expense of workers, and he wants to halt immigration.
"There's a period of evolution going on as to what the Dole economic plan would be," one aide said. "Within the campaign, there is some debate over how to respond to the issue of wage stagnation, which the Clinton White House will be making a big deal of.
"Some in our campaign want to stress it," the aide added. "Others are more concerned that those solutions don't involve more governmental intervention, that it be a very market-oriented approach."
Mr. Dole's overall goal, aides said, is to show support for a growth-oriented economic program that shows sympathy for workers who are nervous about the future -- without alienating the corporate giants who might be downsizing. Those corporations make up the traditional Republican base and have contributed heavily to Mr. Dole's campaign.
Mr. Dole reflected this ambivalence in his speech. "Yes, these are the best of times for many who work on Wall Street," he said. "But the facts leave no doubt that they are also the worst of times for many who live and work on Main Street, Main Street America."
He cited the loss of 258,000 high-paying manufacturing jobs in the last year nationally -- but suggested that the blame lay with President Clinton, not with corporate America. "The average hourly real wages are now 5 percent lower than they were a decade ago," Mr. Dole said, "and they haven't increased one cent, not one cent, since President Clinton took office."
Noting that Americans are "working more and earning less," he then borrowed some of the words that Mr. Clinton himself pounded repeatedly in his 1992 campaign. "These are the Americans," Mr. Dole said, "who for years have paid their taxes, played by the rules and have made sure that America's future was always better than the past."
The audience, about 150 people, applauded only twice during the speech, for generic antitax sentiments aimed at the heart of the typical tax-loathing New Hampshirite: He said he would sign unspecified legislation to "end the I.R.S. as we know it" and would support a constitutional amendment requiring a three-fifths' majority before Congress could raise income taxes.
"Everything he had to say was positive," said Kathy Cardin, 40, a nurse who listened to Mr. Dole. "But we've been told this -- lower taxes and more jobs -- before, and he didn't say any ways that he would do it. Wages aren't going up, people are being laid off and there are no guarantees on retirement. I'm sorry he wasn't more specific."
Russell Thibeault, president of Applied Economic Research, an economic and real estate consulting company based in Laconia, said, "Buchanan really spotted the anxiety about job security, and it sounds to me like Dole has fashioned a response that is shooting toward economic growth, but it is pretty late to be fashioning responses."
One problem for Mr. Dole, Mr. Thibeault said, is that his campaign "has been selling leadership and experience in the face of an electorate that is looking for some fresh ideas." He added: "He has not been very specific about an economic program, although I don't think there's a big payoff in being too specific because then you become a lightning rod."
Acknowledging Mr. Dole's lack of specifics, an aide said: "He's a very consensus-oriented, input-oriented politician. He wants to get a better feel for where the majority of America wants to see this thing move forward, where there is support instead of ethereal theory -- that's where the process is now."
Mr. Dole, who has a lengthy history of supporting both tax increases and tax cuts, might have learned in 1988 that too much stiff medicine can sour a candidacy. He refused to sign a no-new-taxes pledge back then, but he signed one this year. And on the trail, he comes close to offering a tax cut without actually doing so. Defending a balanced budget, he says that it would save the Federal Government $60 billion in interest payments every year, "and those savings could translate into a $500-a-year tax cut for every household."
Because of his hardscrabble background in dust bowl Kansas, Mr. Dole's top priority has always been balancing the budget and eliminating the deficit, not cutting taxes. But in this tax-allergic state, Mr. Dole walks a fine line when he criticizes the flat tax proposed by Steve Forbes, the publishing heir.
Some Dole advisers wish that Mr. Dole had proposed a flat tax some time ago, while others say such a proposal appears to favor the wealthy and would be a disaster for Mr. Dole to advocate.
Mr. Dole could not hide his true colors on this topic on Saturday night, as he veered from his prepared text -- the first time this year that he has read from one -- and made this warning about the flat tax: "We're either going to add to the deficit or not everybody's going to get a tax cut. You can't have it both ways."
Everything in Mr. Dole's history suggests that given the choice, he would not add to the deficit -- that is, he would not cut taxes. But that could be a perilous statement to make directly here. So Mr. Dole has been sticking with bromides.
"If we keep our eye on doing the right thing," he said at a Chamber of Commerce breakfast in Portsmouth, without specifying what the right thing might be, "we'll have a great future.
"We're going to enter the next generation stronger than ever," he went on, "with more jobs and more opportunities, better education, better environment -- all the things that we're concerned about are going to be there because of you and your confidence in the future of America."
He seemed so carried away with being upbeat that he went on to say that New Hampshire voters did the right thing in 1988 when they elected George Bush instead of him.
Mr. Dole said at first that New Hampshire "made a little slip in '88" when it elected Mr. Bush. Then he added: "But as it turned out, you probably did the right thing. President Bush did an outstanding job, and I was very proud to work with President Bush as the Republican leader in the Senate."

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 211 words

HEADLINE: Why Women Decide to Skip Marriage

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Single Motherhood: Stereotypes vs. Statistics" (Week in Review, Feb. 11): This is a global phenomenon and not unique to the United States. The most dramatic rise in out-of-wedlock births has occurred in advanced industrialized countries. The United States rate is about the same as that in Canada and Britain, slightly lower than in France, and far lower than in Denmark and Sweden. 
 Recent research has found that increased female labor force participation accounts for a far greater portion of the decline in the American marriage rate than the drop in male employment and wages (and far more than availability of welfare benefits, which declined in value as rates of single motherhood rose).
It is not clear to what extent the slow pace of men's adaptation to their changing roles may have left women more disenchanted with marriage.
United States marriage rates remain among the highest in the industrialized world. But as women become more independent economically, men's willingness to be full partners in the family may emerge as an increasingly important factor in determining how women value marriage.
 
SHEILA B. KAMERMAN
Co-director, Cross-National Studies
Columbia U. School of Social Work
New York, Feb. 12, 1996

HEADLINE: China Searches for Respect

BYLINE: By Lucian W. Pye; Lucian W. Pye, professor of political science emeritus at M.I.T., is the author of numerous studies of Chinese political culture.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
This is a tough time in relations between the United States and China. Washington is torn over what to do about Beijing's saber rattling in the Taiwan Strait, its covert nuclear aid to Pakistan and Iran, its failure to clamp down on the pirating of intellectual property and its continued flagrant disregard of human rights.
China, for its part, is apparently convinced that the United States is a superpower in decline and determined to contain China, a superpower on the rise. Both the reformers and hard-liners are united in the conviction that they must appear firm and bold if they are to make a smooth transition after Deng Xiaoping's death. 
 In contrast, Washington seems ambivalent. Its actions do not match its words, and its words do not appear toreflect careful thought or strong conviction.
The fact that relations with China are troubled should not be surprising, for the relationship has rarely been close, except for the brief period of near alliance against Soviet expansionism. There are just too many fundamental obstacles in political cultures, history and ideologies for the political relationship to be a warm one.
The economic successes of Deng Xiaoping's reforms should have warmed up relations, making the Chinese more self-confident and at ease with the outside world, less touchy about slights to their sovereignty or perceived meddling in their internal affairs.
However, this success has only generated greater tensions and frustrations. The Chinese take seriously the forecast that they will soon have the world's largest economy. They therefore feel that they deserve recognition and respect as a superpower-in-waiting. It is not enough that they are already a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council and one of the five nuclear powers. Somehow all of their accomplishments of the last two decades have not produced as dramatic a change in their international status as they had expected or believe is their due.
Most of the reasons for the hypersensitivity of the Chinese leadership can be traced back to the regime's eroding legitimacy. With the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, and the need to erase the memory of the Cultural Revolution and the Mao Zedong era's ideological fanaticism, the leadership is confronted with a crisis of faith in Marxism and Leninism. Therefore it has had to look for a new basis of legitimacy, and has sought to find it in nationalism.
However, Beijing suddenly finds that the only version of nationalism, available is a bankrupt one, barely better than angry xenophobia, a crude "we" against "them" view of the world. Possessing what is the world's oldest civilization, China should have a trove of ideals and principles, myths and symbols, and stories of heroes that could be woven together to produce an uplifting, positive nationalism.
Yet a half-century of the Communist Party's unrelenting attack on Confucius and all the values associated with his legacy have left a population emotionally dead and unresponsive to the glories of China's high culture.
China also has one of the world's richest folk cultures. Yet puzzlingly, no politician in modern times has sought to tap into that storehouse in order to articulate a vision of what makes China a unique and worthy nation. Mao may have praised the Chinese peasantry, but only as an abstraction, a symbol of the downtrodden. He did not bring to the country's political discourse the excitement of the peasants' calendar of celebrations or their didactic myths.
With neither the high culture nor the popular culture providing a coherent sense of Chinese nationalism, the country is left without a shared and inspiring vision of what the nation should stand for in the world of nation-states.
China is a congeries of contradictions that should not be united by only base atavistic sentiments of race. It needs a loftier vision of national identity. Indeed, to call for the return of Taiwan to the "motherland" on the basis of blood ties alone, without any overarching ideals, common values or shared visions, does violence to China's historic grandeur. Such an approach to reunification has no more legitimacy than bluffs of war.
Without the security of a proud and constructive nationalism, China's leaders are bound to be thin-skinned, suspicious and arrogant in claiming their self-defined rights.
Moreover, the lack of a principled nationalism means that there are no standards of honorable and legitimate leadership, no constraints on Beijing as to what is unthinkable, or "un-Chinese." Therefore the threat of conquest only advertises to the people of Taiwan that submitting to reunification would be to suffer rule by whim.
It is questionable whether the current leadership can articulate a version of nationalism worthy of the Chinese people. Also, the task of formulating for China an appropriate set of collective ideals and sentiments cannot be left to an intellectual elite, for they have already floundered in their attempts at it over the last century.
The current pattern of economic growth and political stagnation has led not just to violations of human rights but to a shutting down of debate over the values that would give content to a higher sense of nationalism.
By contrast, Taiwan, in renouncing dictatorship, opened the way to a public dialogue that is giving shape to a sense of collective identity -- something that will elude China until it opens itself to a similar process.
In the face of all this is there anything the United States can do to ease relations with a China so bedeviled? Given the hypersensitivity of the Chinese leadership, it is understandable that Washington feels it must walk on eggs and seek "constructive engagement" through quiet diplomacy.
Yet there may be a problem with such an approach. American politicians, in spite of operating in a democratic political culture, tend to believe that honest communication is best realized in face-to-face meetings behind closed doors and that public statements are unreliable because they usually only serve public relations purposes, rarely expressing real convictions.
The exact opposite is the rule in Chinese political culture. There, private settings are where hypocrisy usually prevails because everything said is designed either to preserve harmony or for dramatic effect. One knows where the other really stands only from public statements, which are made without the constraints of courtesy.
Therefore, Washington's attempts at "constructive engagement" will not go far unless backed by a clear and unequivocal authoritative statement as to what it expects of the relationship, and what it foresees as China's place in the world.
The statement should probably declare that America expects China to become a more open and freer country, and to this goal encourage greater trade and contacts between our two peoples. The Chinese authorities may not like what is said, but their rejoinders would start a debate as to alternative visions, which, in going beyond "to get rich is glorious" would advance the quest for a new national identity.
What troubles United States-China relations is not going to be solved by tinkering with policy. The need is for more of the "vision thing," on the part of both parties.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ROUNDUP;
Pledges, Accusations and Appeals As First Primary Vote Draws Near

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 18

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole won a high-profile endorsement. Patrick J. Buchanan turned his attacks on the "knights and barons" of the Republican Party. Steve Forbes appealed for votes from anti-abortion forces. And Lamar Alexander reiterated his opposition to the ban on assault weapons.
With a series of television appearances, campaign stops and commercials, the Republican Presidential candidates moved into the final hours of the primary today, mixing the personal attacks that have characterized the campaign until now with endorsements and some discussion of issues. A look at where the three candidates highest in the polls were and what they were saying: 

Bob Dole
A Longtime Rival Steps Into Line
MANCHESTER, N.H. Feb. 18 -- One month after warning that Republicans could never unseat President Clinton with Senator Dole's "empty rhetoric," Senator Phil Gramm flew here today to make the exact opposite argument as he endorsed his former rival in the Republican Presidential primary this week in New Hampshire.
"Bob Dole is the one Republican candidate in this race today who can bring together economic conservatives and who can bring together social conservatives and who can make the Republican Party again one united party that is committed to beating Bill Clinton," Mr. Gramm said at a press conference at Mr. Dole's campaign office here.
Mr. Gramm's endorsement of Mr. Dole had been expected since he dropped out of the Presidential race last week, after his fifth-place showing in Iowa. Both Mr. Gramm and Patrick J. Buchanan had laid claim to the support of the Republican Party's right wing, and Mr. Buchanan's position here improved markedly after Mr. Gramm's withdrawal, to the distress of Mr. Dole.
The Dole campaign had pressed for Mr. Gramm's endorsement this weekend.
Advisers to Mr. Dole said today that they did not expect any particular tactical advantage from Mr. Gramm's decision, given that Mr. Gramm had so little support here in pre-primary polls. And while Mr. Gramm had assembled an impressive organization here, Mr. Dole already has the support of most of the state Republican leaders.
Mr. Gramm asserted that his decision to support Mr. Dole had nothing to do with reports that Mr. Buchanan's supporters had distributed photographs of him and his wife, Wendy, who is Korean-American, with a caption that read, "Many conservatives will not vote for him due to his interracial marriage. He divorced a white wife to marry an Asiatic!" Mr. Dole's aides have been making certain that reporters are aware of those allegations.
But Mr. Gramm went on to note that Mr. Buchanan had received help from supporters of David Duke, the white supremacist from Louisiana.
"In the party of Bob Dole and Phil Gramm, there's no room for racism," Mr. Gramm said. "I've never in my political life made any kind of compromise with racism." ADAM NAGOURNEY

HEADLINE: Japan Merchandise Trade Surplus Cut 83%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Japan's merchandise trade surplus fell 83 percent last month from a year earlier, its biggest drop in six years, the Finance Ministry said today.
Weak exports and strong imports of automobiles, personal computers, semiconductors and clothing helped narrow Japan's trade gap in January to $467 million. 
 The dollar initially fell against the yen on the news because currency traders had speculated that the trade gap could have been lower. The dollar slipped as low as 104.88 yen from 105.24 yen late on Friday in New York. But it recovered as the session wore on; in late afternoon trading today, the dollar was quoted at 105.10 yen.
"Some traders had even expected a trade deficit," said Masahiro Yamaguchi, manager of foreign exchange at Tokai Bank.
With the United States, Japan's trade gap in January fell 51.2 percent to $1.55 billion, its biggest monthly decline in 16 years, the ministry said.
Japan's trade surplus with Asia and the European Union also shrank. With Asia, the gap narrowed 1.1 percent to $1.61 billion, its first decline in 12 months. With the Union, it fell 24.7 percent to $676 million, the first decline in three months.
Economists warned about reading too much into the sharp decline because January's surplus tend to fluctuate significantly. Still, they said, the figures show that Japan's trade gap is shrinking, having fallen for seven consecutive months, and should continue to shrink for at least the rest of the year.

HEADLINE: A Mean Chess-Playing Computer Tears at the Meaning of Thought

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
 But for many cognitive scientists, computer experts and philosophers, the question is not: Which entity is more intelligent? Rather, it is: What is intelligence, anyway? The smart answer is, It depends on whom you ask.
Both Mr. Kasparov and his adviser on computers, Frederick Friedel, said this week that they felt Deep Blue, with its vast computational excavations of each chess position, had begun to emanate signs of artificial intelligence, the first they had ever sensed from a machine.
"As it goes deeper and deeper, it displays elements of strategic understanding," Mr. Friedel said of Deep Blue. "Somewhere out there, mere tactics are translating into strategy. This is the closest thing I've seen to computer intelligence. It's a weird form of intelligence, the beginning of intelligence. But you can feel it. You can smell it."
Herbert Simon, a professor of computer science, psychology and philosophy at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, concurred. Any computer thinks to some degree, he said, when it brings to bear the element of problem solving he calls selectivity -- that is, a sense of knowing where to look in its warehouse of information for its answer to a question.
Human thought, he said, consists of "first, a great capacity for recognition, and second, a capability for selective research."
Deep Blue has to be considered a thinker, he said, because along with its colossal ability "to spin its wheels", the brute force calculation which is the traditional strength of computers, it also has a sophisticated evaluation system. In other words, Deep Blue, like a human being, does not have to search out each and every possible chess move to discover the best option; it has the ability, programmed in its software, to recognize useless possibilities and discard them along the way, a function that increases its efficiency.
This, of course, is what a human chess player does; Mr. Kasparov cannot match the computer's searching speed, but with his intuition and experience, he does not have to. He recognizes fruitlessness instinctively.
It was in 1957 that Professor Simon, whose lifelong research has focused on the human thought process and who won a Nobel Prize in economics in 1978, predicted that a computer would be the world chess champion within a decade; in that service, he helped design a computer program that tried to emulate the thought processes of a grandmaster.
He proved to be wrong, and today he says he did not understand it would be brute force as opposed to selectivity that would bring a chess computer to an equal footing with men and women. But that does not diminish the accomplishment of Deep Blue, he said, which with its powerful amalgam of brute force and selectivity, is not unlike what humans do, if different in the ratio of its elements.
There are different types of thinking, he added, "but I would call what Deep Blue does thinking."
Baloney, said John R. Searle, a philosophy professor at the University of California at Berkeley and the author of "The Rediscovery of the Mind," (M.I.T. Press, 1992), which argues against the possibility of mechanical thought.
"From a purely mathematical point of view," Professor Searle said, "chess is a trivial game because there's perfect information about it. For any given position there's an optimal move; it's solvable. It's not like football or war. It's a great game for us because our minds can't see the solution, but the fact that we will build machines that can do it better than we can is no more important than the fact that we can build pocket calculators that can add and subtract better than we can."
Professor Searle scoffed at Mr. Friedel's sense that the calculating power of Deep Blue had begun to evince the feel of an intelligent being.
"I could say the same thing about my pocket calculator," he said. "In the early days I could outwit it. Divide 10 by 3, then multiply that by 3 again. You wouldn't get 10 again; you'd get 9.999999. Now, they have tricks to solve that. But in order to get human intelligence, you've got to be conscious. Does the computer worry about its next move? Does it worry about whether its wife is bored by the length of the games?"
Virtually everyone seems to agree on two things. One is that it is inevitable that a computer will eventually be the world chess champion. The other is that whatever the accomplishment of Deep Blue, the accomplishment of its creators is sublime.
"In building a path-breaking, successful program, the I.B.M. team has definitely demonstrated artistry that is impressive and moving," said David Gelernter, the Yale art historian and computer scientist. "But the artistry is on display in the code, the program they wrote, more than in the chess game played by the computer, which is hard to associate with their own creativity and artistry."
A. Joseph Hoane, one of Deep Blue's programmers, said after the match that there was no question they could go on and improve the machine, but he wondered aloud whether he wanted to be part of it. The research was undertaken as part of a more general effort to bring powerful parallel processing technology to bear on complex computational problems, a field of study with proven applications in such diverse arenas as pharmacology, data mining, finance and air traffic control.
"I want my work to be fundamentally useful, and after this I have to be shown that it is," Mr. Hoane said. "At this point I have to wonder whether I'd be spending my time doing computer science or whether I'd be spending it improving the way a computer plays chess."
Several cognitive scientists said Deep Blue's victory in the opening game of the recent match told more about chess than about intelligence.
"It was a watershed event, but it doesn't have to do with computers becoming intelligent," said Douglas Hofstadter, a professor of computer science at Indiana University and author of several books about human intelligence, including "Godel, Escher, Bach," which won a Pulitzer Prize in 1980, with its witty argument about the connecting threads of intellect in various fields of expression. "They're just overtaking humans in certain intellectual activities that we thought required intelligence. My God, I used to think chess required thought. Now, I realize it doesn't. It doesn't mean Kasparov isn't a deep thinker, just that you can bypass deep thinking in playing chess, the way you can fly without flapping your wings."
Those who ascribe to the theory that machines are just machines that will always be apprenticed to human masters tend to view the hoopla over the chess match and the worry over the ascension of the machine as, well, "crazy," to use the word of Berkeley's Professor Searle.
"It's just a hunk of junk that somebody's designed," he said of Deep Blue.
Paul Saffo, a technology expert at the Institute for the Future, a think tank in Menlo Park, Calif., more or less agreed. "People who fear machines don't need to lose any sleep just yet," he said. "To me, the match was interesting as a cultural event. Chess, whereas it's a difficult problem to solve for computer scientists, is just a constrained formal problem. O.K., a computer beat a grandmaster, but computers aren't any smarter than they were the day before. The question I'd ask, now that this Rubicon has been passed, is What's the new arbitrary measure? Maybe it's a computer that plays go," -- the ancient Japanese board game that has yet to be conquered by a machine -- "or a computer that can fill in an I.R.S. form without getting an audit."
Professor Hofstadter has another idea. He says it is not impossible that a machine might one day learn from experiences and feel things as humans do. But in the meantime, that is still what separates us and them.
In "Godel, Escher, Bach" he held chess-playing to be a creative endeavor with the unrestrained threshold of excellence that pertains to arts like musical composition or literature. Now, he says, the computer gains of the last decade have persuaded him that chess is not as lofty an intellectual endeavor as music and writing; they require a soul.
"I think chess is cerebral and intellectual," he said, "but it doesn't have deep emotional qualities to it, mortality, resignation, joy, all the things that music deals with. I'd put poetry and literature up there, too. If music or literature were created at an artistic level by a computer, I would feel this is a terrible thing."

HEADLINE: A Public Station Sheds Some Glitter And Digs for Its Intellectual Roots

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN 

 BODY:
At the Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Awards presentations for excellence in broadcasting a few weeks ago, public television's "The American Experience" was honored for a trio of documentaries: "The Battle of the Bulge," produced by Tom Lennon; "F.D.R.," produced by David Grubin, and "The Way West," produced by Ric Burns.
Those three esteemed documentary film makers all live and work between West 73d and West 93d Streets in Manhattan. Yet the place they turn for production partnership is not the New York public television station, WNET, but Boston's PBS station, WGBH. 
 They are not exceptions. Despite the abundance of film makers, writers and historians in New York City, few groundbreaking or provocative documentaries get produced at WNET/Channel 13 anymore.
Two decades ago, WNET was the intellectually principled and driven eldest sibling in the poor but striving family of public stations. Until 1983, it was home to the Independent Documentary Fund, which financed Fred Wiseman's pioneering unnarrated films, among others; it ran the WNET Television Lab, which nurtured experimental video work by Nam June Paik and Twyla Tharp and documentaries on subjects ranging from the effects of low-level radiation to Harvey Milk, the slain San Francisco Supervisor and gay rights champion.
Today, WNET still produces more hours of programming for the PBS system than any other station. But it is best known for opulent productions of ballet, opera and classical music like "Great Performances," and for the "Nature" series.
Channel 13's image as glossy purveyor of low-risk, high-entertainment programs is not entirely fair. But it exists, and William F. Baker, the station's president, says he wants to change it. After persuading Ward B. Chamberlin Jr., a longtime public-television programming executive who had been at WETA in Washington, to return to WNET in 1994 as his deputy, Mr. Baker said he told him, "I want to hire the best programmer there is in public television, bar none."
That person, the two men decided, was Tamara E. Robinson, also of WETA, where she directed cultural and arts programs. So last March she became WNET's vice president for national programming.
"One reason we brought Tammy in was we felt our relationship with the independent community was not as strong as it should be," Mr. Baker said. "And she had a reputation as being the best there is."
Ms. Robinson said that upon arriving at Channel 13, she found the volume of programs in the works to be a little thin, especially in public affairs and news. She said she was trying to rebuild bridges to independent film makers.
"There were some bad feelings, a sense that the station was not friendly to their ideas," she said. "Some felt that 13 was arrogant, didn't return their phone calls, didn't treat their projects carefully."
"Treating projects carefully" means serious fund-raising, and there WNET faces the frustrations the whole public television system faces. It is generally easier to raise money for programs underwriters know will be popular -- like the performance arts -- or at least noncontroversial, like science, nature and educational programs. And it is easier to raise money for a series than for a onetime documentary: quality documentaries take years to research and produce and can cost from $400,000 to $1 million per hour of final film.
That's why a station's commitment is needed. At WGBH in Boston, a number of independent documentary makers say, the executive producers of two series, "Frontline" and "The American Experience," have been relentless in their pursuit of two goals: first, the money to produce documentaries, and second, excellence in the final product, so that the underwriters, public and private will give again.
"WNET was the cutting-edge station for a while, but it didn't have the staying power this place has," said a WGBH executive who insisted on anonymity. "Constancy is important. The challenge is to keep the show going, keep the money flowing and the personnel in place."
Several independent producers complained that before Ms. Robinson arrived, WNET programming decisions were made by committee and project proposals were endlessly passed around.
Steven Fischler and Joel Sucher, partners in Pacific Street Films in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., said that they had been getting the runaround since 1989 on a one-hour documentary they have just completed on the photojournalist Jacob Riis.
"One would say, 'We have to talk to marketing,' and marketing would say they had 'too much on their plate' right now," Mr. Sucher said. "Someone else would say, 'Let's keep trying.' They gave us lip service. Finally the Ford Foundation put up the money, and we finished it on our own."
They still don't know whether WNET will be the presenting station for the PBS system, or even whether the film will be presented on public television at all.
But Mr. Grubin, the producer of "F.D.R.," "L.B.J." and other historical documentaries, said that PBS stations cannot be all things to all producers. He noted that he and Bill Moyers raised the money themselves for the poetry series they produced for WNET last fall.
"I'd like to have a poet on every week, the way we have Louis Rukeyser every week," Mr. Grubin said in a reference to the economist on PBS's "Wall Street Week," produced by Maryland Public Television. "But they can find sponsors for Rukeyser and not for poets.
"It would be different if Channel 13 were sitting on a pot of money and said, 'We don't like poetry,' " he said. "There's always a problem of money."
Ms. Robinson said that she was more interested in series than in specials or single-installment documentaries because "you spend as much time raising money for a onetime special as for a series."
Her job of rebuilding bridges to independent film makers has been complicated by WNET's backing of two projects that compete with films already well under way at WGBH in Boston.
WNET is planning to co-produce a 10-hour series by the Hollywood producer David L. Wolper on New York culture in the 20th century as well as a film on Harry S. Truman by the documentary film maker Charles Guggenheim. WGBH has a 10-hour series on the history of New York City by Mr. Burns and a Truman film by Mr. Grubin in the works.
Mr. Grubin, who has done all his presidential films for WGBH, said, "Nobody says all history films have to go through Boston; anyone can do Truman, if they can find the resources."
But Mr. Burns, after two years of being "graciously courted," as he put it, by executives at WNET, said he had hoped the two stations would present his New York series jointly -- "WGBH because of my longstanding relationship with them, and WNET because it's the flagship New York station."
"I have enormous respect and affection for the people who run WNET and still hope we may sort things out," he said. "But I just don't understand their priorities."
Ms. Robinson emphasized that the Wolper and Burns projects were different and that Channel 13 viewers would eventually see both. She also noted that Warner Brothers, to whom Mr. Wolper is under contract, was putting up "a lot of money" to help produce the film on New York culture for WNET.
"If they can bring money to the table, and we can raise money, and we can produce an interesting, compelling, entertaining, educational documentary, there's nothing to lose," she said. "And they can help with promotional possibilities, too.
Officials of the station point out that more of WNET's budget goes to program production now -- about 80 percent of its gross revenue -- than in any previous year. Its December pledge drive was one of its most successful fund-raising efforts, drawing 15,754 pledges totaling $1.3 million. And the station has attracted $53 million in a capital campaign intended to raise a $65 million permanent endowment, Mr. Baker said.
"At least people know the place is economically sound and stable," he said. "That has been my first priority."
It also means that he and Ms. Robinson can focus on the next priority, diversifying the programs WNET produces. Ms. Robinson pointed to a number of programs in the works for this year and the next, among them a history of America's love affair with the automobile, a one-hour documentary on the legacy of the G.I. Bill, a biography of Norman Rockwell and a five-part series on the Arab lands of the Middle East and North Africa.
WNET has also made a deal with the fledgling Independent Film Channel, a small cable network whose programming is not available in the New York City area, to broadcast some of its films.
"We also focus on programs that can extend into the schools, like the Norman Rockwell or Truman biographies," she said. "People forget that's a major part of our mission. God knows teachers appreciate it, though, especially the extra teaching materials we provide."
Although changing a big institution takes time, Ms. Robinson sees progress in sharpening WNET's programming. "There is more focus, more teamwork," she said. "With funding always precarious, we have to be careful we focus on where the best ideas are, not just on which ideas will attract funding."
 The article also misstated the availability of the Independent Film Channel, a pay-cable service, in the New York area. It is indeed available, to subscribers of Liberty Cable, a satellite-delivered cable service reaching parts of Manhattan, the Bronx and New Jersey.
