HEADLINE: Nesting Beyond the Snowbirds;
Foreigners Flock to Miami's Luxury Condominiums

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER 

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
Ugo Colombo is a smallish man with a big taste for finely tailored Italian suits and tall buildings. Very tall buildings.
Today, he sits atop Miami's latest luxury-condominium boom -- the first in 15 years and the most extravagant by far -- watching his new project, a 51-floor tower called the Santa Maria, rise on the shores of Biscayne Bay. When completed next year, the $120 million tower will be the tallest residential building south of New York and east of Chicago. 
 Mr. Colombo, the 34-year-old scion of a Milanese family that made a fortune in plastics, is the leader of a pack. Other developers, most of them foreign-born like Mr. Colombo, are propelling dozens of orchid-colored buildings skyward along waterfront property extending from the northern reaches of Miami Beach to south of the spiky office towers of downtown Miami and Key Biscayne.
Apartments in many of these buildings are not the kennel-sized units of past condomania booms. By comparison, the new wave of development is palatial in size and price, aimed not at the typical winter-weary Northerner seeking an escape or a modest place to retire but at affluent Europeans, Latin Americans and local residents who already own a house in fashionable neighborhoods of Dade County.
The reshuffling of the real estate market here -- yet another measure of the widening gulf between the wealthy and just about everybody else -- reflects Miami's growing success in attracting international travelers, investment and trade. More specifically, deep-pocket developers like Mr. Colombo and his CMC Group are tapping affluent buyers in a market deemed dead and buried in the 1980's.
When outsiders think about Latin Americans in Dade County -- population, two million -- one image is that of Cuban and Nicaraguan exiles mixed with Colombian drug cowboys. South Florida remains a major point of entry for illegal narcotics and a way station for drug money.
But that image only scratches the surface. Today, some 650,000 Cuban-Americans, 75,000 Nicaraguans and 65,000 Colombians reside full time in the area, most of them hard working and prospering. And children and grandchildren of the exiles are now prominent in professional ranks, giving the business world a vibrancy Miami had previously known only in its nightlife and sports teams.
As the American hub for expanding hemispheric trade and banking, Miami is also home to tens of thousands of well-heeled Brazilians, Venezuelans, Peruvians, Argentines, Ecuadoreans and other Central Americans. It has long been a magnet for flight capital chased by political unrest or currency instability, particularly in the 1970's and 1980's when rich Latin Americans sought refuge from economic tumult.
Buyers of the new luxury condos also include business executives from Germany, Italy and France with offices plugged into Miami's prosperous international trade community, or their compatriots who crave a piece of the subtropical life for extended winter or summer vacations. Even Russians tasting the first fruits of capitalism are snapping up second homes at a surprising rate.
"Los Angeles is too far to travel for Europeans," said Mr. Colombo, who escaped the bleak overcast winters of Italy in 1983 to study at the University of Miami and learn English. "New York is too expensive. Miami is a perfect place for a second home in the sun, a city on the beach."
It helps to be high above it all, though. Glass-wrapped apartments on the top floors of the Santa Maria -- just beneath the $4.6 million penthouse -- come with sticker prices approaching $2 million, occupy 5,733 square feet of floor space and 1,742 square feet of terrace. That's enough room to fit a large suburban house and garden. Lower-floor condos spiral up from a $386,000 base price, with the average three-bedroom at somewhere more than $600,000.
Mr. Colombo throws himself into nearly every aspect of his project, whether negotiating with his financial backers, which include union pension funds; selecting Gagineau ovens for the Italian Snaidero kitchens, or working on details of the tower's smoothly cantilevered design with his Miami architect, Louis Revuelta.
Other new projects emphasize high style, including a 15-story condominium proposed for Miami Beach's Ocean Drive that was designed by Michael Graves, the noted Princeton, N.J., architect.
"All our research shows the three most important things buyers want are life-style issues," said Richard Lamondine, a developer putting up the first of five towers in the new planned community of Aventura, north of Miami Beach. The three: "Privacy, exclusivity and security."
To lure customers, developers have sales representatives in a wide number of overseas offices. "I have brokers in Caracas, Rio and Paris," said Gerald Kaufman, who directs marketing for several projects. "I myself have made two trips to Moscow in the past year or two."
Miami's appeal to visitors -- foreign and domestic -- is centered around South Beach, a 30-square-block neighborhood lined with sidewalk restaurants and restored Art Deco hotels in the lower third of Miami Beach. That's where Hollywood celebrities have joined the fashion-model set and European tourists.
But there is much more to this condo boom than European glitz and fashion. The pace of high-end condo development in the Miami area has more than doubled in three years, jumping from 23 individual projects in 1992, to 46 in the first three quarters of 1995. More than 3,500 high-end units, priced at more than $325,000 each, are coming on the market in the next three years, according to Lewis M. Goodkin, a real estate expert here who is a consultant for Price Waterhouse.
Meanwhile, older hotels and apartment houses on Miami Beach are rapidly being converted into condos at lower price ranges. And other projects that could add thousands of units are seeking financing.
In 1985, when a huge backlog of unsold smaller condos from the 1978-80 building binge glutted the market, the average sales price was less than $70,000. By last November, lifted by the revival of the high-end market that began in 1993, the average price of all new condos had jumped to nearly triple that level.
Real estate busts following booms are as expected here as summer heat and humidity after a glorious winter, but many analysts of the local market argue that this time should be different. Mr. Goodkin cited several factors.
"There is such diversity among the buyers, from so many offshore economies," he said, "that it's not likely that localized problems like the collapse of housing prices in the Northeast or currency controls in Venezuela can damage this market as they did in the 1980's."
The last cycle of condominium sales, he added, was exaggerated by speculative fever, with buyers snapping up blocks of units in a building, putting less than 10 percent down.
"When the market turned down they simply walked away from the problem, leaving the banks holding the mortgages," he said. "The savings-and-loan crisis ended that kind of lending. Now buyers are putting down 15 to 20 percent or more and that should bring stability."
New banking regulations and more conservative lending practices are also forcing developers to provide more of a project's start-up costs. As a rule today, banks will not provide construction loans until the developer has already signed tenants for 50 percent of the apartments.
But other local analysts are more skeptical about how sustainable this boom really is. "It's in the nature of builders to envision more demand than actually exists," said Paul Black, vice president of Appraisal and Real Estate Economics Associates of Miami.
With the Santa Maria, Ugo Colombo is betting that the demand will arise in response to the supply. He had the same hunch several years ago and hit the jackpot.
At the time, he was managing a dozen or more apartments owned by his father and other European investors on Brickell Avenue, a high-rise corridor of banks and apartment buildings on Biscayne Bay just south of downtown. He started snapping up unsold condos auctioned by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, forming a partnership with Trammel Crow, the Texas-based real estate firm.
"Everyone said condos on Brickell were dead, but by 1990 I saw the demand was there for the right properties," Mr. Colombo said.
His plans for the construction of a 40-story luxury condominium on the Brickell waterfront called Bristol Towers were met with derision. The real estate market at the time had taken a dive and condo sales were flat. Survivors of the savings-and-loan collapse were loathe to lend money at all. Mr. Colombo, along with new partners, went instead to European, Canadian and Japanese banks for the $50 million project.
"I felt I had a handle on what people wanted," Mr. Colombo recalled. "There was a pent-up demand for quality and security. People who already owned expensive homes in Miami and were fearful of crime wanted to shift to a secure, vertical location without giving up the comfort of a house."
What he also recognized was that Miami, hemmed in by the ocean to the east and the Everglades to the west, was running out of prime real estate, especially on the water. As the project began, other developers were busy replacing or repairing single-family homes damaged in 1992 by Hurricane Andrew. The only condos being built, with few exceptions, were inexpensive low-rises far from downtown.
By the time Bristol Towers was completed in 1993 nearly all of its 147 apartments had been sold for a total of about $80 million, netting Mr. Colombo a windfall and setting off a stampede by other developers. Counting on success, he had already acquired land for the Santa Maria, the last waterfront lot available on Brickell.
Skeptics, noting that the Santa Maria faces a lot more competition than Bristol Towers did, are not convinced Mr. Colombo can work his magic at a second Brickell property, especially one with selling costs of $250 a square foot, 20 percent more than his first project. There is also caution expressed about whether Japanese, Brazilian and Italian banks -- prime investors in the Miami real estate market -- will continue to pour money in if sales slow.
But that kind of rainy-day talk generally falls on deaf ears in Miami, where the subtropical sun inculcates optimism and the building cranes are flying once again.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
A Flare-Up of Passions On Trade And Jobs

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
Usually arguments over America's trade policies are considered a snooze on the campaign trail, and for four decades how Washington should deal with its economic rivals has rarely been an issue for Republicans, the party of big business and traditionally an unflinching defender of free trade.
But the way the issue has suddenly flared in New Hampshire illustrates how divided Republicans have become in the past two years on the question of how to manage the nation's economy. And it is a testament to the power of Patrick J. Buchanan's oratory -- the underpinnings of a campaign that many Republicans agree has identified the anxieties of voters even if they dislike his solutions. 
 The most explicitly protectionist of the candidates, Mr. Buchanan has gathered steam and passionate crowds with his thundering calls for economic nationalism, and his declarations that his thinking is "the future of the Republican party." His rivals, meanwhile, perhaps a bit shocked at how well the message is playing, have simultaneously denounced Mr. Buchanan as an isolationist and a protectionist, while delicately edging in his direction.
Not one of the main rivals for the nomination has embraced Mr. Buchanan's most headline-grabbing economic remedies: for Japanese imports, 10 percent tariffs, and for Chinese-made goods, 20 percent, an extra margin that in Mr. Buchanan's view China deserves for both its obstreperous economic behavior and its repeated threats to Taiwan. Nor have any other candidates joined Mr. Buchanan's pledge to pull the United States out of the North American Free Trade Agreement and the newly created World Trade Organization, the Geneva-based arbiter of trade rules around the globe.
But to listen to the candidates in the last few days of the first primary battle is to discover that almost everyone in the race, from the tire magnate Morry Taylor to the front-runner, Senator Bob Dole, believes Mr. Buchanan has struck a chord among swing voters whom they ignore at their peril.
So far, however, only Mr. Buchanan has managed to sew the country's economic anxieties and its sense of diminished influence in the world into a single tapestry, with an interpretation of economic history that leads to his protectonist message. "It's a remarkable transition for the Republican Party," said I. M. Destler, a professor of the University of Maryland and one of the country's leading experts on the use of trade as a political tool in American politics. "Before Eisenhower, the protectionist wing of the party wanted to protect its friends in big business. But now there is a very different kind ofpopulist protectionism rising up."
The new strategy is explicitly aimed against Wall Street and the big contributors that have historically been the backbone of the Republican establishment. At the same time it is tailored to appeal to disaffected workers, once a core Democratic constituency.
Mr. Buchanan trumpeted that point today. "Who do you think can bring the Perot voters home for the Republican Party?" he asked at one campaign stop. "Do you think Bob Dole can bring them home? He was for Nafta and GATT and all those sell-out deals. I can bring the Perot voters home."
 The appeal of Mr. Buchanan's message has clearly caught Mr. Dole off balance, as he acknowledged half-heartedly today when he told workers at a New Hampshire electronics firm, "I didn't realize that jobs and trade and what makes America work would become a big issue in the last few days of this campaign." And the result is that so far, at least, Mr. Dole has been unable to respond to Mr. Buchanan's fire-breathing with anything more specific than a promise to "use the powers Congress has given the President" to open markets abroad and stop unfair competition at home.
Anything more specific is something of a minefield for Mr. Dole because his entire legislative life has been a testament to pressing the frontiers of free trade.
Mr. Dole, for example, joined President Clinton in pushing through the Nafta, though in recent weeks Mr. Dole joined other Republican leaders in torpedoing the Administration's effort to speed along negotiations that would have expanded the treaty to include Chile.
But Mr. Dole may rue the day in late 1994 that he showed up in the Rose Garden of the White House, next to Mr. Clinton, to announce his support for the global trade treaty that created the trade tribunal, which has become something of the economic equivalent of the United Nations.
Few voters in New Hampshire have heard much about the World Trade Organization, but that has not stopped Mr. Buchanan from using it to make his case that America has handed away its national sovereignty to "these institutions of the new world order." He was greeted with big cheers in Portsmouth, one of the state's more liberal cities, when he noted that the United States gets only one vote in the World Trade Organization, "which makes the world's greatest superpower the equal of Cuba, Bangladesh and Burundi."
Such imagery seems to have thrown Mr. Buchanan's opponents so off base that, so far at least, they have not challenged any of his claims, even the most dubious ones. The world trade panel, for example, does not have the power to overrule American laws. At worst, it can authorize trading partners to impose modest economic sanctions.
Nor has anyone challenged another of Mr. Buchanan's assertions: that the North American agreement has cost Americans 300,000 jobs. That is not based on unemployment figures; Mr. Buchanan said several months ago that he calculated the figure himself, by reversing the Clinton Administration's logic that every $1 billion in American exports creates 20,000 jobs.
But that is economics, not politics. And for the next few months, the party's future course may well depend on whether Mr. Buchanan's message has enough staying power to bring other candidates around to his views, even if they hate the whole idea.

HEADLINE: Willie Brown's Performance Is a Hit

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19

 BODY:
It is more than a run-of-the-mill political honeymoon that this beauty of a city is having with its flamboyant new Mayor.
"It's a loooooove affair," Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. said in a deep-throated croon. 
 Since he took office last month, coming home after years in Sacramento as Democratic deal-master and Speaker of the State Assembly, he has found that gourmets here lay down their shellfish forks to applaud when he enters restaurants. Moviegoers have shouted "Hurray! Here's the Mayor!" as he searched for a seat, he said. And a poll taken after his first month found that 61.6 percent of voters thought Mr. Brown, the city's first black mayor, was doing a good job.
"It's easy to adjust to adulation," he said with a chortle.
But it has not been as easy for Mr. Brown, 61, to adjust from manipulating the back rooms of the Assembly to governing a city, where the Mayor's every word is dissected by press and public.
He caused considerable alarm with a proposal that "gang kids" police city buses. He also provoked some outrage when, in defending an appointee who was accused of inflating his credentials, Mr. Brown said that everybody lies on their resumes.
Indeed, his reputation in Sacramento as an operator slippery as an oil slick -- a California Journal poll released this month ranked him the smartest member of the Assembly but 76th out of 79 members on integrity -- still causes low-burning concern among his new constituents.
Nevertheless, most San Franciscans still appear enchanted with their Mayor, citing an indisputable reason: Mr. Brown is making city politics interesting again. In an era when most big-city mayors have become conservative in manner and politics, Mr. Brown has brought panache and extra pull on the national stage, holding meetings with friends like Bill Clinton.
"A lot of people were scared originally that he was just a crook, he was going to come in and steal everything worthwhile in the city, that he'd be using the mayorship as a springboard to a bigger job," said Harry Swets, an advocate for the homeless known as Hooks for his two prosthetic arms. For now, though, Mr. Swets said, after asking Mr. Brown to ease up on arrests of the homeless and getting good signals: "It's exhilarating. It's a rush. We were looking for something optimistic."
Part of the rush Mr. Brown brings with him is the wicked fun he provides a town that revels in local gossip. Some say he reminds them of Jimmy Walker, who presided over New York in similarly high style (until he was driven out of the Mayor's office by scandal in 1932).
The city can now follow Mr. Brown up close to see which exquisite suit or hat he will wear next; which glamorous young date he has been seen dining with or which outrageous bon mot he has tossed out.
Then, there is a less benign new pursuit: reacting as one unpredictable idea after another floats off the top of his head and into public debate, prompting editorial huffs and popular concern only, as often as not, to see the proposal withdrawn.
San Franciscans are also watching as the new Mayor tries to take control of a somewhat ossified City Hall and give its policies more of the left-leaning slant that the city has historically taken, even while maintaining his status as arguably the most important Democrat in California.
Over all, judging by Mr. Brown's first weeks' performance, "I would predict he'll be more powerful than ever," said James Richardson, Mr. Brown's biographer and a reporter at The Sacramento Bee. "Because he's in a more visible position than ever and makes it even more visible by being Willie. People don't really know what an Assembly speaker is but they know what a mayor is."
Especially this Mayor.
Mr. Brown began generating unusual noise and heat from the moment he won office in a runoff election on Dec. 12, beating the incumbent, Frank Jordan, a former police chief, with 57 percent of the vote. He sported a cap reading "Da Mayor," celebrated his ascension with a public bash for more than 50,000 on the city's waterfront and bantered with President Clinton on the phone.
Within days, he had appointed the city's first Asian-American police chief and its first black fire chief. Along with them came a diverse array of officials reflecting this urban kaleidescope of about 750,000 people, with its sexual mix of heterosexuals, homosexuals and bisexuals, and its ethnic and racial mix that is roughly 11 percent black, 29 percent Asian-American, 13 percent Hispanic and 47 percent white.
He also began igniting verbal firecrackers. Some were minor, like his declaration that in his City Hall, employees would not wear jeans -- and if they did, he would send them home to change and dock their pay. ("What's next?" demanded The San Francisco Chronicle. "The creation of a new city Department of Couture?") He ran into graver criticism for his proposal that "gang kids" maintain order on the city buses. The foxes would be guarding the henhouse, bus riders complained. Mr. Brown later said that he had meant that the youth patrols could include reformed gang members. But that uproar and others were enough to prompt The San Francisco Examiner to complain about his premature verbalizations in an editorial titled "The Mayor's Mouth."
The looseness of Mr. Brown's remarks has not translated into a loose grip on his administration, however. In contrast to Mr. Jordan, who was seen as submitting to the mind-control of his consultants and dubbed by one official the "nebbish mayor," Mr. Brown runs an autocratic regime, wielding his power as nakedly as he did in Sacramento.
Mr. Brown is milking his dukedom to the last drop, with such vainglorious moves as plans to give visiting dignitaries leather-framed snapshots of them with Mr. Brown, CD-ROMs of San Francisco's best music and art with Mr. Brown on the cover and bottles of Napa Valley wine with guess-whose signature on the label.
Mr. Brown faces a typical compendium of urban ills, from a homeless population even more painfully visible than New York's to a heavy caseload of AIDS patients and a troubled transportation system.
He has offered few specific programs so far but asserts that "San Francisco will be the city to watch" to see how those problems can be tackled. He is planning a meeting of business and government leaders on the city's economic future this spring and has begun a program that circulates police officers onto buses at least twice per beat.
The new mayor's greatest possible pitfall, said Merv Field, an analyst who has been measuring California politics for 50 years, is that "San Francisco's endemic problems are just intractable."
Others believe the ultimate test for Mr. Brown will be whether he can tame the city employees when contract time comes; whether he can pull together a deal to build a waterfront baseball park meant to keep the Giants in San Francisco and whether he can win generous state funds for the city from his once and future nemesis, Gov. Pete Wilson, and an Assembly now under Republican control.
But even if the Mayor is stymied right and left, Mr. Field said, he has a proven ability to come out of any situation smelling sweet, a Teflon quality that can only be compared to Ronald Reagan's. Whether Mr. Brown will indeed try to parlay the local power he is expected to gain here into a bid for the governorship or Congress remains to be seen.
"Willie never plans anything," Mr. Richardson said. "He's a daylight runner: he sees the opening and goes for it."
Mr. Brown is widely expected to help run President Clinton's re-election effort in California, but he maintains that while he plans to be very helpful to Mr. Clinton, he will seek no title in the campaign organization.
"I have a city to run," Mr. Brown said. He is also, he freely admitted, busy having the time of his life.
"I am now beginning to wonder why I didn't look into local government sooner," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

 
Apple Agrees to License
Mac System to Motorola
Apple Computer, in one of the first announcements under its new chief executive, said it was licensing its Macintosh operating system to Motorola. Analysts said the arrangement pointed to a new strategy by Apple of confronting Microsoft's and Intel's rival PC standard in parts of the world where the personal computer market is not yet well developed. [Page D2.]
 
NatWest Bids $713 Million
For a British Asset Manager
National Westminster took a step toward becoming a comprehensive financial-services company by offering $713 million for Gartmore, one of the fastest-growing asset management companies in Britain. [D9.]
 
Two Faces of the G.O.P.
Republicans, generally champions of American globalism and big business, find themselves in an unusual situation on the day of the New Hampshire primary: in disagreement on the issue of trade and how the United States should deal with its economic rivals. As the issues in the campaign have shifted, the latest focus has become the American worker. [A1.]
 
No Deal for Iraq and the U.N.
Two weeks of talks between Iraqi diplomats and the United Nations on a plan to allow limited Iraqi oil sales to buy food and medicine ended without agreement. Both sides said the next step was up to political leaders. [A5.]
 
China's Pirates Go Unpunished
A year after China promised the United States that it would aggressively fight violations of intellectual-property rights, pirates still flout enforcement efforts. They are evidentlyprotected by powerful forces -- the military, secret police and organized crime -- that Beijing has failed or declined to rein in. [A1.]
 
Small Travel Agencies Dwindle
Since most airlines limited the size of commissions paid to travel agents a year ago, an increasing number of agents, particularly mom-and-pop operations, have gone out of business. [D2.]
 
A State Lifts Ban on Merrill
Massachusetts has lifted a two-year ban against Merrill Lynch that had prevented the securities firm from managing the refinancing of the state's bonds. [D4.]
 
Sara Lee Ends Talks on a Merger
JP Foodservice said it and Sara Lee had ended talks on merging JP with Sara Lee's food- distribution business. Sara Lee had made a $946 million offer. [D6.]
 
On Your Mark,
Get Set to License
Winners and losers are emerging in the race among companies to cash in on the licensing of products for the 1996 Olympic Games in Atlanta. Olympics officials say sales of licensed goods have been strong. But not every company is ready to give Izzy, the mascot for the Games, a gold medal. [D3.]
 
Labor Plans Organizing Push
The A.F.L.-C.I.O., trying to halt a slide in the percentage of workers who are union members, plans to intensify efforts to attractAmerican workers to unions, particularly in the South. [A13.]
 
What's the 300-Year Return?
At the Dutch stock exchange in 1688, the "concealment of facts, quarrels, provocations, mockery, idle talk, violent desires, collusion, artful deceptions, betrayals, cheatings and even the tragic end" were to be found, a trader at the time wrote. Three centuries later, market similarities persisted. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D8.]
 
Let's Play 20 Questions
Now that the the equipment company being spun off from AT&T has been named Lucent Technologies, how soon will it be before some agency proposes a campaign carrying the theme "I love Lucent"? And a few other questions. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;
CANDIDATES CLASH OVER TRADE ISSUES HEADING INTO VOTE

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 19

 BODY:
In the final hours before the nation's first primary, the unusually vituperative competition here for the Republican Presidential nomination swerved today into a confrontation over international trade.
Senator Bob Dole, who led for months in polls and now finds himself in a tight, unpredictable competition, offered a revealing acknowledgment of how Patrick J. Buchanan and his protectionist positions have come to dominate the race. 
 "We didn't plan it this way," Mr. Dole told more than 300 workers crammed into the cafeteria of Cabletron Systems, an electronics firm in Rochester, on the Maine border. "I didn't realize that jobs and trade and what makes America work would become a big issue in the last few days of this campaign."
In a biting retort, Mr. Buchanan said in an interview in his hotel room here: "Where has he been? Where has he been? That is a pristine example of an attitude or outlook in Washington -- of a Washington, D.C., that is totally out of touch with America." The former commentator, himself a native and lifelong resident of Washington, added, "How they could go through an entire campaign of a year and not be aware of this, I do really not know."
Mr. Dole's unprompted remarks were the biggest surprise on the final full day of stumping, which stretched from a pancake-flipping contest that attracted several candidates (wearing aprons) here this morning to a well-orchestrated torchlight parade this evening led by Mr. Dole in Milford, in the southern end of the state.
His comments underscored how issues in the race have shifted on a week-by-week, if not a day-by-day, basis -- from curbing big Government to abortion, then to the flat tax and now to the American worker. They also demonstrated how Mr. Dole, who enjoyed a commanding lead for most of last year, was caught off-guard by an issue that is critical to voters here.
As the candidates made last-ditch efforts to elbow one another out of the way in the drive up to what is traditionally the most crucial primary, Lamar Alexander, the former Governor of Tennessee, also ridiculed Mr. Buchanan on trade. But on the coast in Portsmouth, where Mr. Alexander completed the last mile of his 100-mile, yearlong walk across the state, he devoted himself to a stepped-up assault on Mr. Dole.
"Bob Dole is ducking interviews," Mr. Alexander said. "He's running negative ads. He doesn't have one single idea about how to lead us into the next century."
But Steve Forbes, the publishing magnate, could not resist entering the fray over trade, declaring to workers at a fiber-optic cable factory in the town of Newington near the coast: "There's another vision that says America can't compete in the world any more -- that America can't move ahead. That we have to bunker down, hunker down and isolate ourselves from the world, sort of a fortress mentality."
The jousting over trade was the latest turn in one of the most fluid primary battles here in years. A half-dozen of the latest tracking polls by independent organizations and campaigns showed that Mr. Dole and Mr. Buchanan -- the first- and second-place finishers in last week's Iowa caucuses -- were locked in a too-close-to-call duel for first place here.
The surveys also showed that Mr. Alexander and Mr. Forbes were in a competitive fight, with both trying to break out and even make a long-shot try for first place. Mr. Alexander appeared to be in a stronger position than Mr. Forbes -- and could benefit from a high turnout -- because he has the highest favorable ratings among the contenders. But all that anyone could seem to agree on was that the outcome was too close to venture a prediction and that it could well hinge on variables like the weather. The forecast for Tuesday in many parts of New Hampshire is for light snow and freezing rain, which could dampen turnout.
The other candidates -- Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana; Alan Keyes, a former State Department official; Morry Taylor, a tire manufacturer, and Representative Robert K. Dornan of California -- were barely registering in the polls.
"As I sit here today," said John P. Stabile, the state Republican Party chairman, "I would not want to bet a nickel on who might win -- and, usually, I have a good sense. Buchanan's people are maniacal. Dole's people are large and well-organized. And Lamar's people, though they were slow getting together, they seem to have been reinvigorated."
The most pronounced substantive shift in the final hours of the race has come from Mr. Dole. After months of campaigning on his leadership skills and three-decade record in Congress, Mr. Dole is now reacting to Mr. Buchanan, who has been rising in the polls by making populist appeals to the economic anxieties of workers and by bashing international trade agreements.
Without citing Mr. Buchanan by name, Mr. Dole pressed his free-trade position, telling the workers in Rochester: "Building a wall around America is totally wrong. No one would share that view who's concerned about the future of this country." He warned the Cabletron workers that "your company is going to shrink" if protectionist trade policies are enacted.
Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, a moderate on social issues who withdrew from the Presidential race last year, endorsed Mr. Dole today and immediately took on Mr. Buchanan's trade proposals. He also accused Mr. Alexander of playing both sides on abortion.
The attacks seemed only to enliven Mr. Buchanan, who clearly relished the newfound attention as he was surrounded by a shoving, swirling mass of hundreds of reporters.
"I will look out for and defend the interests of Americans in all these trade negotiations," Mr. Buchanan said at a lumber yard in Barnstead, northeast of here. "I cannot understand why my Republican opponents go into their little mantra of protectionist isolationism every time we say we want to defend the interests of American workers and American businesses."
The frenzied debate today reflected a race that is more volatile and intense than Republicans say they have seen here in years. Some analysts said that with the close competition, a front-runner might not emerge on Tuesday.
"If the polls have any accuracy," said Robert Craig, a professor of political science at the University of New Hampshire, "it looks like we're going to have a first in that we're going to have three tightly grouped front-runners."
If that happens, the race could drag on far longer than many Republicans had imagined. Mr. Dole has the most at stake because he has long been viewed as the candidate to beat. And he raised expectations last week when he said he had to prevail in his New Hampshire campaign, his third try.
But even as their supporters fretted over the fluctuations in the polls, Mr. Dole, Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Alexander behaved like confident front-runners.
"If we break through in New Hampshire," Mr. Buchanan said, "they're not going to be able to stop us."
Mr. Alexander said: "My own sixth sense of politics tells me it's a very tight race and, however it comes out, I'm going to be doing very well because people are going to be looking at a weakened Dole with no ideas at all."
And Mr. Dole, winding up at the torchlight march, tried to set his sights beyond Tuesday. "One candidate," he said, "and only one candidate, can bring our party together and beat Bill Clinton."
 "And Mr. Dole, winding up at the torchlight march, tried to set his sights beyond Tuesday. 'One candidate,' he said, 'and only one candidate, can bring our party together and beat Bill Clinton.' "

HEADLINE: Small Travel Agencies Face Hard Times Under Fee Cap

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Mary Hogan, the owner of a tiny three-person travel agency in Cambridge, Mass., thought she was ready for anything in the notoriously fickle travel business. "I survived the gulf war," she said, "when not a soul was traveling anywhere."
But she did not survive the decision made a year ago by the airline industry to limit the normal 10 percent commissions on domestic travel to no more than $50 a ticket. She closed up shop last April, shortly after the cap went into effect. 
 "When my income went down and my overhead didn't, I had the business sense to know to get out," Ms. Hogan said. "As we speak today I know five other people who are closing their agencies. The small, independent agency is an endangered species."
That may be an exaggeration, but clearly something is amiss. Last year, even though overall travel revenues were up and the number of agents grew, 1,550 full-service travel agencies went out of business. That is 53 percent more than in 1994, according to figures compiled by the Airlines Reporting Corporation, the clearinghouse for funds between airlines and travel agencies. Many of those were replaced by new agencies springing up elsewhere, for a total of 33,600. But single-office locations -- most of them the traditional mom-and-pop shops that have long been the mainstay of the industry -- fell by 1.3 percent.
Moreover, the longer the cap has been in effect, the more agencies are going out of business. Travel Weekly magazine reported 484 full-service agency closings in the fourth quarter of last year, compared with 407 such closings in the third quarter of 1995 and 340 in the second quarter. There were only 290 closings during the fourth quarter of 1994.
"Many small agencies struggled all year to hang on," said Lauraday Kelley, president of the Association of Retail Travel Agents. "When you'll really see closings and mergers is later this year, when leases and contracts with customers expire."
Others echoed that view. "Lots of people in the industry think we'll see a drastic number of people calling it quits in the next few months," said Paul Rudin, senior vice president of industry affairs for the American Society of Travel Agents.
The majority of agencies do less than $2 million in business annually. Most of them see themselves as under siege from almost every side: from the imminent opening of a prototype Wal-Mart Travel agency in Roanoke, Va., to the spread of travel and reservation services onto the Internet. And with the savings airlines already achieved last year by capping domestic flights -- commissions fell 3 percent to $3.69 billion -- carriers are now talking about whether they can get away with capping commissions on international flights as well.
No wonder, travel agents say, that so many smaller agencies have decided to call it quits.
Stephen and Ruthie Dukkony of Annapolis, Md., were travel agents for 17 years before recently concluding there was little future as an independent agency for their Annapolis Travel. Three months ago, they sold it to Travelogue, a small chain based in Washington, although they continue to run the agency.
"In the past we used the 10 percent commission we made on fares over $500 to offset the money we lost writing low-priced fares," Mr. Dukkony said. The caps "pushed us over the edge."
Although about one-third of agencies charge service fees or say they plan to do so, small agencies fear that fees will drive away customers. Even giant American Express withdrew its $20 fee on airline tickets priced less than $300.
When Delta Air Lines began the stampede by airlines to cap agency commissions last February, the driving force was clearly economics. Delta, in its bid to cut a total of $2 billion in operating costs in little more than two years, argued it had little choice but to seek savings from commissions, its third-biggest expense after salaries and fuel. Delta's commissions to travel agents fell $157 million last year, or 12.5 percent, to $1.1 billion. During the fourth quarter of last year, Delta's commission payments plummeted 17 percent compared with the comparable period a year earlier.
The only hope for the agencies of lifting the cap is to win a class-action lawsuit against AMR's American Airlines, Continental Airlines, Delta, Northwest Airlines, UAL's United Airlines and USAir. The suit contends that the carriers conspired to impose the caps. The jury trial -- from which Trans World Airlines was dropped as a defendant last spring when it restored the full 10 percent commission -- is tentatively scheduled for the fall in the United States District Court in Minneapolis.
"Because it's in litigation, we don't have any comment on the cap," said Jackie Pate, a Delta spokeswoman.
To blunt the impact of commission caps, many agents have diversified into specialty markets and into booking more tours, hotels, rental cars and cruises. Results appear mixed.
Hotel commissions more than doubled last year, to $74 million. But only about 300 agencies out of an estimated 10,000 responded to an offer by Carnival Cruises to increase commissions for bookings from those who had not done business with the cruise line before. That was "far fewer than we expected," said Tim Gallagher, a Carnival spokesman.
Still, many surviving travel agencies are optimistic. Northwestern Travel Service, a large Minneapolis agency, spent a good part of last year renegotiating contracts with its commercial accounts, at a cost to its bottom line. "But our clients are now paying more attention to what services we offer them, and finding them worth the price," said Arthur I. Dahl, Northwestern's president.
While acknowledging that the commission caps hurt, Mark Mancini, an industry consultant in Los Angeles, also sees vast opportunities for travel agents as opinion brokers.
"You can access the best fare from New York to Paris, but try finding how far it is to Monet's gardens at Giverny," he said. "What travel agents can do best is tell you what planes have more legroom and what airline has better food."
Meanwhile, newcomers are still coming into the business, although at a slower pace than before.
Faye DiGirolamo opened Paradise Travel Ltd. in Kansas City, Mo., after having worked as an independent agent for a dozen years. "Even with all the drawbacks, I love the business," he said, "I never intend to be in another one the rest of my life."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 22, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption in Business Day on Tuesday, with an article about the difficulties faced by small travel agencies since the airlines put a cap on commissions, misidentified the Massachusetts travel agency once owned by Mary Hogan. She ran Hogan Travel Inc., which has gone out of business; she now works for Uni globe/the Travel Connection.

HEADLINE: ATLANTA 1996;
Wrong Turn: Swords Into Plowshares

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BUDAPEST

 BODY:
For decades, Hungary was the powerhouse of Olympic fencing, bringing home more gold in that sport than any other. Their male duelers were virtually invincible.
Then politics, of the Soviet kind, intervened. The Hungarians had to share with the Russians their secrets of balance, distance, footwork and blade work, as well as the ability to coordinate them all into a rhythmic movement. With the help of exiled Hungarian coaches, the Germans started to improve and the Italians, always talented, got better. 
 Now, it's hard for the Hungarians to remain dominant the fencing team's senior coach, Tamas Kovacs, conceded above the din of clashing steel blades during a team practice.
"More and more nations are joining fencing and more and more are developing on the world stage," said Kovacs, whose father was one of Hungary's repeat gold medalists in the saber class.
Like most sports in Central Europe in the post-Communist era, fencing, even though it is Hungary's glory, is strapped for money. Fencers are no longer handed a job with a decent salary where they don't have to work, Kovacs said. His national team members now receive a monthly stipend from the Government that is only enough for two tanks of gasoline for their cars. There is no prize money from the Government for victories abroad.
These days, Hungary's best hopes are not with their male swordsmen but with the women, who are world champions in the epee class.
Internationally, fencing was considered an arcane sport, usually practiced by an elite group with access to the money needed for expensive and hard-to-get equipment. But the sport, based on the dueling of centuries ago and romanticized by sword play in Errol Flynn movies, has begun to catch on in the United States. About 150,000 Americans belong to 800 fencing clubs, according to the United States Fencing Association.
For first-time spectators, one of the most striking attributes of fencing is the age of its champions. Compared with many other sports, fencers are golden oldies -- in their late 20's -- by the time they reach their peak. This is in part because fencing relies as much, if not more, on mental shrewdness as it does on physical prowess. Like boxing, tactics are crucial.
Take the 25-year-old Gyorgyi Szalay, who is training in the epee for Atlanta. Even she is a little young, by Kovacs's standards at least. "The best age is 28 to 30," he said. "By that time you have the maturity in the head and the body."
Szalay, relatively tall (5 feet 10 3/4 inches) and not slim (143 pounds), describes competition this way. "It's 60 percent brain work and 40 percent physical work," she said. "If you take two equal competitors, what will decide who is champion is who is stronger psychologically."
At the world championships at The Hague last July, Szalay said, she and her partner, Timea Nagy, defeated the Japanese team through sheer mental stamina. "They were ahead, 40-35, and then we won by 45-40," Szalay said. "At the point we broke even I was coming on stronger psychologically."
Indeed, Kovacs refers to Szalay as the brains of the team. It doesn't matter that she is slightly slower on her feet than some of her teammates.
Nagy, also 25, is lighter (123 pounds) and shorter (5-10), and as a result, she is the speedster.
"They represent different styles," Kovacs said. "This is good for a team because if they are all the same, it is easier for an opponent to figure out the vulnerabilities. There are national teams where the competitors are the same, but the results are not good."
In Hungary, fencers generally start at age 10. By then they are old enough to wield the weapons but young enough not to be absorbed completely by other sports, Kovacs said. Young fencers are encouraged to dabble in some other sports so that their legs and shoulders don't become overdeveloped as they develop physically.
Szalay recalls first fencing at age 8 when she wandered into the local club that happened to be close to her home. Now, as the Olympics loom, she trains 12 hours a week -- much less than swimmers, for example -- and is serious about her university studies in economics. "You can't do fencing for such a long time," Szalay said during a break between matches. "It's not a monotonous type of sport which only involves physical work."
She held her helmet, a kind of wired cage in one hand, and her weapon, attached to an electronic wire, in the other. She was dressed in a white sweatshirt of heavy protective material, white breeches and white leather gloves, a uniform reminiscent of the days when tennis was whites-only. Szalay said she had just heard that competitors at Atlanta can, for the first time in the Olympics, wear uniforms with colors. "I think I will stick with white and hope my opponents won't be wearing something designed by Vaserily," she said, referring to the Italian artist whose work features patterns with pointillist dots.
Fencing's three classes are the saber, the foil and the epee. In epee, all of the body can be touched by the opponent's weapon; in foil only the torso, and in saber the upper body. (Saber is a male-only sport.)
Since the 1956 Olympic Games, the foil and epee classes of fencing are judged electronically -- every time a fencer touches an opponent with the tip of the weapon in the correct target area, a circuit is completed, a buzzer sounds and a light goes on on the scoreboard.
Hungary's drooping financial support for fencing keeps the sport struggling to keep abreast of Western countries where the fencing tradition is not so deep but the equipment is now more plentiful. In Italy and France there are now weapons specially designed for children, an innovation that the Hungarians cannot afford.
The insignia of a prominent Hungarian bank, OTP, adorns the walls of the training hall here, but the bank's financial support is spent on organization and travel, not on incentives for players, Kovacs said. But even the bank's support is not sufficient.
Italy and Germany, Kovacs said, have made great progress in part because of lucrative prize money.
When he requests more financial support from the Government, he is politely told how proud the nation is of the fencing results and then brushed off.
Under those circumstances, Kovacs said he was hoping for slightly better than the medal cache at the world championships when he was "pleased but not very pleased." There, the Hungarians won one gold (women's epee team), one silver (women's epee individual) and two bronze (men's saber team and men's epee team).
"We can only stay in the front line of world fencing if we create a professional system," Kovacs said. "For the sport to survive it is essential to have prizes so it attracts the best people."

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
ORLEY ASHENFELTER, the Princeton University economist who regularly upsets the wine establishment with his unorthodox approach to judging vintages, has completed a new classification of California cabernet sauvignons.
His method is similar to the most famous of all wine rankings, the 1855 classification of the wines of Bordeaux: it is based not on tasting and sniffing, the traditional tools of wine experts, but on the prices of mature wines at auction. 
 For the California wines, his ranking is based on prices that the wines attained at auctions during 1995 in San Francisco, Chicago and New York. The youngest wines were from the 1985 vintage, the oldest from 1968. Some 2,000 transactions were involved.
To make his comparisons, Mr. Ashenfelter chose one wine as a benchmark: Beaulieu Vineyards Private Reserve. It is, he said, "the most commonly sold mature premium California wine."
The prices of the other wines in his ranking are expressed as a percentage of the price of the Beaulieu Vineyards wine from the same vintage.
The top wine in his new classification was Caymus Vineyards Special Selection. With the Beaulieu Private Reserve rated at 100, the Caymus wine's rating was 366. Second was Opus I, the wine produced in the Napa Valley by the combined efforts of the Robert Mondavi Winery and Chateau Mouton-Rothschild in Bordeaux. Its price as a percentage of the Beaulieu Private Reserve was 242. Third was Stag's Leap Wine Cellars Cask 23, with a rating of 239.
Rounding out the top five were Dunn Vineyards Howell Mountain, with 215, and Heitz Cellars Martha's Vineyard, with 206.
The next five, in order, were Spottswoode Vineyard Napa, with 172; Ridge Vineyards Monte Bello, with 155; Silver Oak Cellars Napa, with 150; Dunn Vineyards Napa, with 142 and Beringer Vineyards Reserve Napa with 141.
All wines in the top 10 were grown and produced in the Napa Valley except the Ridge Monte Bello, which comes from a mountain vineyard in Santa Clara County.
Five years ago, in a ranking of cabernets from 1958 through 1982, Heitz Cellars Martha's Vineyard was first, Cask 23 was second and the Monte Bello third. Fourth and fifth were Joseph Phelps Vineyards Insignia and the Jordan Vineyard and Winery's Alexander Valley. Five years later, the Phelps Insignia had slipped to 14th place and the Jordan to 24th.
In the 1991 rating, Caymus, which is now far ahead of any competitor, was in 13th place with its regular Napa Valley issue. The Special Selection, which normally sells for $100 or more a bottle, apparently was not yet a presence in auction sales. Nor, similarly, were Opus I and Dunn Howell Mountain.
In the 1991 rating, nine wines sold for more than Beaulieu Vineyards Private Reserve. In the current ranking, 17 wines demand higher prices than the benchmark.
"It would be tempting," Mr. Ashenfelter said, "to suggest that the B.V. Private Reserve had slipped, but a look at our price listings shows that this is not the case. The benchmark simply has more competition at the top end of the market."
Mr. Ashenfelter ranks 19 wines below the Beaulieu Private Reserve, beginning with Duckhorn Vineyards Napa, with a comparative rating of 99 and dropping down to Charles Krug Winery's Vintage Select, with a rating of 33. It is in this group of wines, Mr. Ashenfelter said, that the best bargains are likely to be found at wine auctions. He mentions, among others, Sterling Vineyard Reserve wines from the 1970's, Freemark Abbey Bosche, Clos du Val and other bottlings from Heitz Cellars, Ridge Vineyards, Joseph Phelps and Robert Mondavi.
Auction prices for well-known mature wines are invariably higher than younger versions of the same wines at retail. But almost without exception, the top wines at auctions are also very expensive when new. The top 10 on the Ashenfelter list retail for $45 to $100 a bottle. As Mr. Ashenfelter notes in his commentary on the rankings, it is almost impossible to find a bottle of California cabernet for under $25 that can be matured for a decade or more.
Mr. Ashenfelter notes that while more than half of all mature California wine sold at auction in this country is sold by Butterfield & Butterfield in San Francisco, prices of the same wines sold at auctions in Chicago and New York are much cheaper. His advice to collectors: "Sell your California wines in San Francisco. If your are looking for bargains, bid on the relatively small number of California wines offered in the catalogues of the Chicago and New York auction houses."
He is somewhat elitist when it comes to what to buy. "Stick to wines from the Napa and Alexander Valley," he advises. "Although a few wines from the Sonoma appellation have entered our list of top wines, just as many have departed."
He forgets that Ridge Monte Bello figures prominently in all his lists. And of course, the Alexander Valley is in Sonoma.
Mr. Ashenfelter asserts that while prices vary somewhat from vintage to vintage, "it is important to recognize that while it may exist, the role of vintage variability is far smaller in California than it is in Europe." More than a few California growers might disagree.
Based purely on the prices they bring, 1968 and 1970 are the most desirable California vintages in the last three decades. The 1974's and 1978's follow close behind. Of more recent releases, 1985 stands out, with 1984 highly regarded, too.
Mr. Ashenfelter tracks the auction prices of all these wines, as well as the wines of Bordeaux and Burgundy, in his newsletter, Liquid Assets, which is published at 169 Nassau Street, Department Q12, Princeton, N.J. 08542. A subscription costs $30 a year for two issues.
 
TASTINGS
Niebaum-Coppola Estate Rubicon 1990.
Napa Valley. About $35.
In 1975, when Francis Ford Coppola bought Inglenook, the Napa Valley home of Capt. Gustave Niebaum, he wanted to make the kind of wine that had been made there in Captain Niebaum's time -- great cabernet. By almost all accounts, he has done just that. Officially, Rubicon is just a red table wine blend, one that isn't necessarily 75 percent cabernet sauvignon, which by law it would have to be to use the name. But in practice, in some years it contains as much as 95 percent cabernet. Rubicon is often a tough, tannic wine when it's young. It's always packed with flavor; it just needs time to come around. Recognizing this, Mr. Coppola and his wine maker, Scott McLeod, have held back some vintages for up to seven years before releasing them. This 1990 is a big, assertive wine. It's good now; in 10 more years, it will be great.

HEADLINE: West Side Project Has Many Opponents

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "On Riverside South, It's Time to Break Ground" (letter, Feb. 17): Edward J. Malloy is wrong that "Representative Jerrold L. Nadler stands virtually alone" in opposing the project. Every West Side Democratic Party district leader, city and state legislator stands with Mr. Nadler in questioning the wisdom of the developer Donald Trump's proposal. 
 There are good reasons. The proposed mammoth buildings would dwarf the already overdeveloped neighborhood, exacerbating pedestrian and vehicular congestion and worsening our dirty air and diminished light. Moreover, the 5,700 apartments would further strain the inadequate sewage system that barely services the West Side now.
Good urban planning requires that environmental and economic concerns be addressed. That is why we stand with Mr. Nadler in stressing environmentally sound development -- to meet our needs as a growing community without compromising our health, safety or quality of life.
 
JERRY H. GOLDFEDER

The writer is a Democratic Party district leader on Manhattan's West Side.

HEADLINE: Journal;
The New Cynics

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH; Thomas L. Friedman is on vacation.

 BODY:
Since my household is not yet protected by the V-chip, I could not prevent Simon, who is 11, from stealing glimpses of the G.O.P. bloodbath in New Hampshire. But when I caught him red-handed over the weekend watching a Steve Forbes rally on C-Span, he had an airtight excuse: He was reporting a story.
For two years Simon has been a reporter for Children's Express, the national organization that trains kids to gather news and disseminate it through syndicated columns and broadcast media. For a Presidents' Day appearance on National Public Radio's "Talk of the Nation," Simon and other C.E. reporters (as they call themselves) had been assigned to find out their peers' view of Presidential politics. 
 Simon had asked some 30 contemporaries if they wanted to grow up to be President -- and found only two who said yes. He agreed with the disenchanted majority and saw little on TV to dissuade him from his negative view of politicians. "In their speeches I can't tell their opinion of stuff," he said. "They just say how good they are and that they're going to do good for America." The next day on the radio only one child -- Izetta Mobley, 14, of Washington -- wanted to grow up to be President, but even she was turned off by the mudslinging of New Hampshire. "It makes us very cynical," she said. "It makes us not want to find out anything about politics."
When I was 14 and growing up in Washington, I'd never heard of cynicism. The Presidents of my youth, Ike and J.F.K., were role models, even if one of those Presidents was something less than a patron saint in a family of Adlai Stevenson partisans. Role model is hardly the part that Bill Clinton was born to play. And the Republicans who yearn to replace him can't even fake it. The conventional adult wisdom about last week's televised debate was that the candidates all behaved like 11-year-olds, but if you met Simon and his friends, you'd see what an insult that is -- to children, not politicians.
The tragedy of the G.O.P. campaign is that it actually boasted a potential hero -- Mr. Dole. But for all his rhetoric about undertaking one final mission for his country, he slept through the alarm once the battle had to be fought -- when his country, not to mention his party, needed him to stand up to Pat Buchanan.
Unlike any candidate of either party, Mr. Buchanan is addressing the economic fears of middle-class Americans in the era of downsizing -- albeit with the false panacea of xenophobic protectionism. Rather than acknowledge such fears as genuine and offer positive proposals of his own, Mr. Dole at first wanly mimicked his opponent's populist rhetoric, then retreated entirely with out-of-it expressions of surprise that jobs had become a campaign issue.
On the cultural front, Mr. Dole lacks the courage to take on Mr. Buchanan's courtship of the bigot vote. Imagine if the Senator had forcefully challenged him during the debate on his views about women, blacks, immigrants, the Jewish "amen corner" and homosexuals -- playing Joseph Welch, if you will, to Mr. Buchanan's Joe McCarthy. Instead Mr. Dole made a Nixonesque joke about a photo of his dog.
As the Senator disappeared on primary eve to hide from TV interviewers, he might have done well to consult a powerful new memoir, now circulating in galleys and due out this spring, by a Republican who has loomed large in New Hampshire, former Senator Warren Rudman. In the book, titled "Combat," Mr. Rudman enthusiastically supports Mr. Dole for the Presidency. Like Mr. Dole, he is "classically conservative" and a war hero (of Korea). Unlike Mr. Dole, Mr. Rudman is willing to engage in eloquent peacetime combat to advance patriotic causes that include deficit reduction, campaign reform and the defeat of what he calls the "repugnant" social agenda of "self-commissioned Christian soldiers" taking over his party.
But Mr. Rudman is in private life now, soon to be joined by former colleagues he admires, like Bill Cohen, Bill Bradley, Sam Nunn and Nancy Kassebaum. The surrogate hero he backs for President was missing in action in New Hampshire. Given this spectacle, what American of any age wouldn't be turned off? If we are to rescue our children from permanent cynicism, we must insist that they forsake the campaign at once for more wholesome TV fare. "Beavis and Butt-head," maybe, or "Jenny Jones."

HEADLINE: Jobs and Environment Aren't in Conflict

 BODY:
To the Editor
Your Feb. 15 front-page article on layoffs in the Eastern coal fields provides an instructive lesson on the extent of the "jobs versus environment" trade-off. 
 Around 600 coal miners a year, across a multistate region, have lost their jobs over a five-year period as electric utilities switched to low-sulfur Western coal to meet clean air standards.
At the national level, however, there is no trade-off between jobs and the environment. Jobs created from environmental spending offset those lost in industries bearing higher regulatory costs.
Job losses in manufacturing as a direct result of environmental regulation have been small compared with other sources of job loss; around 1,000 to 2,000 jobs a year in the late 1980's.
This pales in comparison to layoffs from, for example, AT&T-style corporate downsizing.
Few manufacturing companies are relocating overseas because of strict environmental regulations in the United States. More than a dozen studies have tried to find evidence for the so-called pollution haven hypothesis, but none have succeeded.
The jobs-versus-environment trade-off is most severe in rural, extractive industries, like logging and coal mining, because relatively large numbers of good jobs are at stake, and because of the resource-dependent nature of the communities affected. This kind of trade-off is atypical. At the national level, jobs and the environment are not in conflict.
 
EBAN GOODSTEIN
Portland, Ore., Feb. 16, 1996
 
The writer, assistant professor of economics at Lewis and Clark College, is a research associate at the Economic Policy Institute.

HEADLINE: Citing Crackdown on Dissidents, Cuban Group Cancels Conference

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Feb. 20

 BODY:
A coalition of Cuban dissident and human rights groups has canceled plans to hold a conference here this weekend, citing what they called "a wave of repression" by the state security apparatus against the organizers of the event, which would have been the first of its kind.
In a statement made available to reporters here, six of the main leaders of Concilio Cubano, as the recently formed group is known, said they canceled the conference because of "the imprisonment of numerous dissidents and acts of harassment against others." 
 They also said that state security officers had searched the homes of some members of the organization, which advocates free and democratic elections and respect for human rights.
The organization's leaders and diplomats here said that at least 28 of the group's members have been arrested as part of a crackdown on dissidents over the last week, including a group of 10 today and 4 of the 5 members of Concilio Cubano's steering committee. The fifth person is said to be in hiding, and at least one of those already in custody is reported to have begun a hunger strike.
The United States has condemned the arrests, saying they "exposed the truth about claims by the Cuban Government that any semblance of freedom of speech and association exists in Cuba today." A State Department declaration called on the Cuban Government to "release these defenders of human rights, to cease its campaign of harassment" against them and "to accede to this organization's reasonable requests."
Concilio Cubano was formed last year by some 130 human rights, dissident and unofficial professional groups. Its members include several of Cuba's best-known human rights campaigners, as well as organizations that have developed ties with democratic political parties abroad and independent associations that represent economists and lawyers.
The group's steering committee wrote a letter in late December to the Council of State, the Cuban Government's supreme body, formally requesting permission to hold the conference. Though the Government acknowledged receiving the request, the group's leaders said, it still has not issued a formal written reply.
In its request, a copy of which was made available to reporters, Concilio Cubano said it was seeking to hold "a plural, democratic and constructive encounter."
In the absence of a response, the group had gone ahead with plans to hold its first national congress, and had organized 14 study commissions to examine various aspects of Cuban life. But on Friday, a lieutenant colonel from the Ministry of the Interior contacted Gustavo Arcos Bergnes, Secretary General of the Cuban Committee for Human Rights, and told him that the meeting would not be permitted, according to the statement issued by the group.
Last month, an official delegation from the European Union, led by Manuel Marin of Spain, visited Cuba and urged Cuban officials to permit the conference to be held, according to diplomats here. The Latin American Association of Christian Democratic parties made a similar appeal, and had asked for visas to attend the conference as observers.
While here, the European delegation also met with leaders of Concilio Cubano at the home of the Italian Ambassador, diplomats said. The European Union began talks about an economic agreement with Cuba last November, and has been hoping to use the prospect of more favorable trading and investment ties to encourage a more open political atmosphere here.
"This shows that internal security considerations predominate over all international considerations," a diplomat here said. "It's very discouraging for anyone who has hopes of a peaceful transition or of increasing political space."

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Justices Reconsider Law Requiring Cable TV to Carry Local Stations' Signals

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
In a case with important First Amendment implications for Government regulation of communications, the Supreme Court agreed today to review a 1992 Federal law that requires cable television systems to retransmit the signals of local broadcast television stations.
The cable industry has fought the requirement as an unconstitutional interference with editorial discretion, a form of compelled speech that under Supreme Court precedent would clearly violate the First Amendment if applied to require a newspaper to carry material that its editors did not want to print. 
 Broadcasters sought and have defended the "must carry" rule, as the requirement is known, as necessary for the survival of at least some stations that would otherwise be dropped by cable systems and thus be cut off from the nearly two-thirds of American households that now do their television-watching by means of a cable connection.
The case is before the Supreme Court for the second time. In June 1994, a bare majority endorsed the general economic theory behind the law, the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act: that the role of cable as a "bottleneck or gatekeeper," as Justice Anthony M. Kennedy described it in his opinion for the Court, creates a potential for abuse that could result in fewer choices being available to television viewers.
But rather than uphold the law at that time, the 5-to-4 majority voted instead to send the case back for further review before a special panel of three Federal judges. The special court, authorized by Congress to provide a speedy constitutional review of a law with evident constitutional vulnerabilities, had initially upheld the must-carry provision in 1993 and upheld it again two months ago. The cable industry then brought the new Supreme Court appeal.
The case, which will not be argued until next fall, reaches the Court at a time of change and ferment in communications law, with First Amendment issues at the forefront. On Wednesday, the Justices will hear arguments in a constitutional challenge to a separate Federal law, intended to curb access to sexually explicit programming on certain cable channels. And the new Telecommunications Act of 1996, an overhaul of current law that President Clinton signed earlier this month, is already under attack in Federal court for provisions regulating indecency.
While these cases raise distinct issues, they have in common the need for the Court to settle on an appropriate standard of review for the constitutional issues presented. In its earlier ruling on the must-carry provision, the Court selected an intermediate standard of review for regulation of cable television: more searching scrutiny than would be applied to broadcast television, but well short of the strict scrutiny that bars most Government regulation of the print media.
Now the Court must give some content to the general prescriptions of the 1994 ruling by deciding whether the economic evidence the lower court considered about the effect of cable on the health of broadcast television was weighty enough to meet the standard of review.
The lower court concluded that in the absence of the must-carry provision, substantial numbers of broadcast stations would lose the cable audience and would decline or fail as a result. In its appeal, Turner Broadcasting v. Federal Communications Commission, No. 95-992, the cable industry is arguing that this concern amounts to protectionism and reflects an impermissible judicial endorsement of the proposition that "more broadcast stations is always a good thing."
The makeup of the Court has changed in a potentially significant way since its initial consideration of the must-carry provision. Justice Harry A. Blackmun, a member of the 5-to-4 majority in 1994, has retired, and his successor, Justice Stephen G. Breyer, who tends to analyze Government regulation from an economic perspective, may well take a more skeptical view of the desirability and efficacy of the regulation in this case.
The very fact that the Court decided on a second, full-dress review of the case suggests that the Justices were not satisfied with their 1994 ruling as the last word. Under the special appellate review provisions Congress attached to the law, the Court could have decided the case summarily, upholding the lower court in a brief order without a full opinion. The Clinton Administration, joined by the broadcast industry, urged the Justices to take that course.
There were also these other developments at the Court today:
 
 Sentencing Appeal
There were numerous allusions to the history of a case that was argued before the Court today on appellate review of sentencing, but essentially no discussion of the actual facts of the case: an appeal by the two Los Angeles police officers convicted after a Federal trial of violating Rodney G. King's civil rights by beating him in a violent arrest in 1991. Their lawyers were arguing that a Federal appeals court erred by setting aside the lenient sentences they received.
While the Federal sentencing guidelines called for the two men, Stacey C. Koon and Laurence M. Powell, to receive 70 to 87 months in prison, Judge John G. Davies of Federal District Court in Los Angeles imposed a sentence of only 30 months. Judge Davies cited several factors to justify what is known under the guidelines as a "downward departure," including the "specter of unfairness" from the Federal prosecution that followed a state criminal prosecution in which the men were acquitted.
In a 1994 ruling, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, found the factors Judge Davies relied on to be impermissible, and ordered the sentences recalculated. Mr. Koon and Mr. Powell, who have been released from prison, were both in the courtroom today, but face renewed imprisonment if the Court upholds the Ninth Circuit and if they eventually receive increased sentences.
The question for the Court in the case, Koon v. U.S., No. 94-1664, is the degree of deference an appellate court should give to a trial judge's selection of factors warranting a lower sentence than the guidelines provide. Perhaps reflecting a widespread dislike of the sentencing guidelines among Federal judges, the Justices did not appear particularly receptive to the Administration's view, presented by a Deputy Solicitor General, Michael R. Dreeben, that trial judges should receive little if any deference on appeal if they vary from the guidelines.
 
 Right to Die
Without comment, the Justices turned down an appeal in a case from Michigan that could have given the Court an opportunity to elaborate on a question it has addressed only tentatively: whether states are obliged as a matter of constitutional due process to defer to a person's wishes, as understood by a legal guardian or other surrogate decision maker, not to be kept alive by artificial means.
The case was an appeal by the wife of a man whose catastrophic neurological injuries in a 1987 car accident left him paralyzed, unable to communicate, and fed through a tube. Her request to allow him to die, based on his often-stated desire before the accident never to be kept alive to live "like a vegetable," was supported by the hospital's bioethics committee, a probate judge, and a state appellate court. But the Michigan Supreme Court ruled last year that because the man was not technically in a vegetative state, his earlier statements were inapplicable. The case is Martin v. Major, No. 95-821.
 
 Ten Commandments
Also without comment, the Court refused to hear an appeal challenging Colorado's display of the Ten Commandments, carved in stone on a four-foot-high monument in a park adjacent to the state Capitol in Denver. Local members of the Freedom From Religion Foundation, a group based in Wisconsin, had sued the state on the ground that the monument violated the constitutional separation of church and state.
A lower state court agreed, but the Colorado Supreme Court overturned that decision in a 4-to-3 ruling last June, finding that the monument was part of a permissible display of various historical monuments and artifacts that celebrated "the cultural tapestry that is Colorado." The case is Freedom From Religion v. Colorado, No. 95-527.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Hong Kong and Singapore Vow To Join Japan in Monetary Steps

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 20

 BODY:
Monetary authorities in Hong Kong and Singapore have agreed to intervene in their currency markets on behalf of Japan, an arrangement that will give Tokyo a new weapon in resisting the rise of the yen, Japanese officials said today.
While the long-term effectiveness of the new arrangement remains to be seen, the announcement -- as well as reports that Japan's central bank was buying dollars for yen in the foreign-exchange markets -- bolstered the value of the dollar, sending it up by more than 2 yen in Asian trading. The dollar's advance faded in European trading. 
 [In New York late Tuesday, the dollar pared its gains to end the day at 105.75 yen, up from 105.20 on Friday. The dollar slipped to 1.4473 marks, from 1.4535. The British pound fell to $1.5450 from $1.5520 on Friday. Financial markets in the United States were closed Monday.]
Under today's agreement, the authorities in Hong Kong and Singapore will buy or sell currencies in their markets at Japan's request, using Japanese central bank funds.
A senior Japanese Finance Ministry official said Japan wanted to increase cooperation with other Asian nations because these countries were becoming increasingly important in world trade and currency markets. "They cannot be excluded anymore," the official said.
Today's announcement, currency-market analysts said, raised the possibility of powerful coordinated Asian actions.
C. H. Kwan, an economist at the Nomura Research Institute, said the agreements were part of a broader trend toward cooperation among monetary authorities in East Asia.
The Hong Kong and Singapore currency markets are substantial. Their combined turnover equals that of the New York market, Finance Ministry officials said. The foreign-exchange reserves of Asia, Australia and New Zealand accounted for 42 percent of the world's total in 1994.
Japan has been trying to lower the exchange value of the yen as part of an effort to revive its economy by making exports more competitive. Toward this end, the central bank has cooperated with the American Federal Reserve in buying dollars.
