HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Atlanta's Real Summer Games

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20

 BODY:
For the first time since the night they won the World Series, Bobby Cox gathered all of his players in the Atlanta Braves' clubhouse today. With suntan lotion substituting for Champagne, the manager issued a warning.
"All this nonsense you read about conceding the division to us, and everybody else is playing for a wild card, is a bunch of beans," Cox said, substituting a couple of clubhouse-type words in spots. "We don't throw our names up on the wall and win." 
 But with names like Greg Maddux, Tom Glavine, John Smoltz, Mark Wohlers, Fred McGriff, David Justice, Marquis Grissom, Chipper Jones and Ryan Klesko, the Braves do pose a problem for the other teams in the National League East. Some members of those teams have already remarked that, realistically, they have to set their sights on the wild-card spot this year because how on earth could they possibly expect to knock the Braves from the division's No. 1 spot?
It is those comments that Cox addressed on the day of the Braves' first full-squad spring workout, and it is that perception that he will try to dispel throughout the spring and the summer. Once his players start believing in the perception, Cox knows, they will be ripe for removal as King of the N.L. East Mountain.
"You're going to have great memories from '95, but we have to get our game faces on and crank it up again," he told the players. "We have an owner who wants to see us do it again. And how are we going to do it again? We're going to do it with hard work and pulling for each other and picking each other up. Certainly the talent's here to get the job done."
Five members of the Braves' championship team are gone, though no key members, meaning five new players will be on the roster opening day. One fellow Cox doesn't want lurking in the clubhouse is the one named Complacency.
"I used that word a lot," Cox said after his meeting with the players, offering excerpts from his address: " 'It's just a word that will not exist here. We won't let it happen because I know each one of you well enough to know that you do want another championship. That's why we're in this uniform. And our owner, I've never seen him so happy. He's really, really pleased.' "
Ted Turner was not on hand to see his troops run around the field and take their first swings of the spring. Until they get to the post-season, he generally follows them -- closely, Cox said -- from a distance because he has so many other business matters to occupy his time. But with Turner's economic blessing, General Manager John Schuerholz and Cox have assembled the best team in baseball.
Even so, Cox and his players rejected the idea that the Mets, Marlins, Phillies and Expos have already conceded -- or should concede -- the Braves their fifth straight division championship.
"I wouldn't concede nothing," the manager said. "I'd never say that."
Nor would Glavine, who allowed only one hit in eight innings in the Braves' 1-0 victory over the Cleveland Indians in the sixth and clinching game of the World Series.
"People can say all they want -- we're the team to beat, we're the best team," Glavine said. "But that's all just talk. You still have to go out and play the games."
But what hope could Glavine and his teammates give those other teams, teams they outdistanced by 21 games last season? If they really believe their division rivals have a chance to unseat them, at least give them a clue about how it might happen.
"Maybe there are some teams out there that are surprising," Glavine said, "like we were in '91."
There it is -- 1991, a season cited by other players besides Glavine.
"We had no chance to do anything and we went to the World Series," Smoltz said. "Baseball is a great sport in that you can be the best team on paper, but if you don't get the job done on the field, it doesn't matter."
On July 7, 1991, the Los Angeles Dodgers, with a 49-31 record, led the Braves (39-40) by nine and a half games. When the season ended, the Braves were the champions of what was then the N.L. West. They edged the Dodgers by one game, running out the rest of the season with a 55-28 record, compared with the Dodgers' 44-38.
"Everything fell into place," Smoltz said. "We got the breaks. Guys filling in had career years. When you look at championship teams, you'll see guys having career years."
So if the Mets, say, are to topple the Braves, Lance Johnson, Bernard Gilkey and Todd Hundley, for example, would have to have career years. It wouldn't be difficult for Bill Pulsipher, Jason Isringhausen and Paul Wilson to have career years because they have had little or no major league careers.
A veteran leader or leaders could also help, the Braves said.
"We got some leaders -- Sid Bream and Terry Pendleton -- and we started believing," Smoltz said of a team that had become used to languishing in last place in the 1980's. "If I had experienced nothing but those losing teams, I'd say forget winning the division; let's play for something else. Now you look at those teams in our division, each team has enough leadership to get them to where they want to go. That's why when Terry Pendleton went over to the Marlins, we all said, hmmm, he might help them out more than we'd like."
Those leader type of players also have a function with the Braves. Second baseman Mark Lemke said they are the players who will keep the Braves from becoming overconfident, helping Cox in his quest to keep everyone's feet planted firmly on the ground and their minds focused sharply on the need to win the proverbial one game at a time.
"The leadership of the veterans, guys that have been here before, like Bream and Pendleton, rubs off," Lemke said. "Guys like Maddux come to work hard every day. They've won Cy Youngs, but you wouldn't know it the way they come in here and do their work."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Crude Oil Prices Rise Sharply On Lack of Agreement With Iraq

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices posted their sharpest one-day gain since the Persian Gulf war yesterday, while gold prices tumbled.
The surge in oil prices came after Iraqi and United Nations negotiators ended two weeks of talks on Monday without an agreement on a plan to allow Iraq limited oil sales to pay for food and medicine. The plan would have allowed Iraq to sell as much as $2 billion worth of oil over six months. 
 "Without the Iraqi thing hanging over our head, people are looking at how good demand is, and demand all over is up," said Jerry Samuels, managing director at ARB Oil Inc. in New York.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for March delivery jumped $1.89, to $21.05 a barrel, the highest price since March 4, 1993. It was the biggest one-day gain in an active contract since Jan. 26, 1991. The market was closed Monday in observance of Washington's birthday.
The March contract expired yesterday; the active April contract surged 87 cents, to $19.27 a barrel.
While traders still eventually expect an oil-sale agreement between Iraq and the United Nations, the apparent failure of the recent talks indicates that no Iraqi oil will come to market for months.
In the meantime, demand for crude oil from refineries is strong and oil stockpiles in the Midwest, where the futures contract specifies delivery, are at their lowest since the American Petroleum Institute began measuring them in 1987. Stockpiles in the nation's refining center on the Gulf of Mexico are also close to their lowest on record.
Gold prices plunged. Gold had been bolstered in part by hopes that economic weakness would prompt the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates. But testimony by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, dashed those hopes yesterday. Mr. Greenspan told Congress that weakness in the economy was "likely to be temporary."
Mr. Greenspan's speech "was very bearish for gold," said Jim Steel, a vice president for commodities research at Refco Inc. in New York. "We have high interest rates in a low inflationary environment, and now, no prospects for further rate cuts."
The April gold contract fell as much as $8.30 on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange before recovering to end $6.40 lower at $401.10 an ounce, the lowest since Jan. 19.
On other commodities markets, wheat prices plunged following forecasts that rains would soak the winter wheat crop during the coming weeks, helping ease months of dry weather. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities fell 0.51 point yesterday, to 249.64.

HEADLINE: Wife Recalls Subway Bomber's Obsessions

BYLINE: By DON VAN NATTA Jr. 

 BODY:
The wife of Edward J. Leary took the witness stand yesterday in her husband's defense, telling jurors how his behavior became increasingly bizarre and obsessive in the months and weeks leading up to two subway firebombings that he carried out 14 months ago.
The wife, Marge Schaller, a pediatric nurse, testified for the defense as Mr. Leary's lawyer began presenting their case in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. Mr. Leary, 50, is charged with attempted murder and assault in the two firebombings that injured 50 people in December 1994. 
 Although prosecutors say the explosions were part of a plot to extort money from the Transit Authority, Mr. Leary's lawyers, who do not dispute that he carried out the attacks, say his behavior stemmed from his use of a mix of drugs, including Prozac, prescribed to treat his growing depression.
In answering the questions of his defense lawyer, Robert Fogelnest, Ms. Schaller recalled how she watched in frustration as her unemployed husband failed to find another job as a computer technician after Merrill Lynch dismissed him in January 1994. At times, she said, it appeared as if he was not even trying to find work.
This lack of ambition was not the only change Ms. Schaller said she noticed in her husband. Instead of looking for work, she said, Mr. Leary devoted much of his time to strange, inexplicable activities.
For example, she said her husband spent many days, and some nights, rummaging through garbage cans and Dumpsters near their home in Scotch Plains, N.J. She said he brought home a variety of items: a dozen old suitcases, 12 car batteries, 5 rusty weight-lifting benches, shards of broken glass and discarded clothes and food. She said he spent many hours assembling a wooden model car, sanding and painting it over and over again.
Ms. Schaller also testified that Mr. Leary became obsessed with his physical appearance, often staring at himself in a mirror, trimming his hair three or four times a day and picking at blemishes on his face with a nail clipper.
When she pointed out his odd behavior to him, she said he replied: "It's O.K. I'm going to someone really good." The reference was to a psychiatrist named John Steven Weihs, who advertised his services in The Village Voice. Dr. Weihs had prescribed Prozac and a wide range of psychotropic drugs to Mr. Leary, she said, adding that her husband had complete confidence in him.
Mr. Fogelnest asked Ms. Schaller a series of questions seeking to show that the Leary family had not suffered from financial troubles in 1994, which prosecutors say was the motive for Mr. Leary's extortion plan.
She testified that they owned three apartments in Park Slope, Brooklyn, and two houses in New Jersey. "We weren't concerned about our finances," Ms. Schaller said. Mr. Leary, she said, even turned down a job offer during the summer months of 1994.
Throughout the day yesterday, Mr. Leary sat at the defense table, twiddling a pen between his fingers and looking impassively at his wife. Several times, their eyes met. Each time, Ms. Schaller smiled at Mr. Leary, but he quickly looked away.
During cross-examination, the prosecutor, Peter Casolaro, focused on statements that Ms. Schaller made about her husband's behavior several days after the Dec. 21, 1994, explosion. He tried to show jurors that she said her husband had not acted despondent or angry when she left for work that morning.
But Ms. Schaller said she could not recall what she had told reporters about her husband. "I was under extreme stress when I was having that press conference and I don't remember what I said or did not say," she said.
Mr. Casolaro also asked Ms. Schaller whether she had sought help for Mr. Leary or whether she felt her family was in danger. "I never thought we were in danger," she said. "In hindsight," she said, she wished that she had sought more help for her husband.
"Your husband is depressed, exhibiting bizarre behavior, and you did not find that was sufficient to take action?" Mr. Casolaro asked.
"No, I did not," she said.
In addition, Ms. Schaller said she had originally told reporters that her husband was not responsible for the subway explosions.
But in later questioning by defense lawyers, Ms. Schaller said that she believed that he had no role in the bombings because that is what Mr. Leary had told her from his hospital bed. Mr. Leary's legs were severely burned in the Dec. 21 explosion.
"He said he dropped his resume to the subway floor," she recalled. "He said he pulled the resume up off the floor and the bag blew up." She added that she now knows that he carried the explosive on the train.

HEADLINE: Squeezing the Textile Workers;
Trade and Technology Force a New Wave of Job Cuts

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

DATELINE: PISGAH, Ala.

 BODY:
Martha Smith cried as she left the Dover Mills plant of Andover Togs Inc. on a Wednesday afternoon late in January. Along with approximately 100 other people, she had lost her job sewing children's clothing.
Now she is enrolled in a state-sponsored program to learn clerical skills. "There's no more textile jobs around here," she said. "They are all going to Mexico and overseas." 
 Ms. Smith, who has lost three jobs due to plant closings, seems to have the evidence on her side. Two other sewing mills in this region of northern Alabama closed at about the same time, sending 550 people, most of them women, into the local labor market.
The layoffs are not just a regional phenomenon. After four years of stability, employment in the apparel industry took a sudden plunge last year, falling by more than 10 percent, to 846,000, from 945,000 at the end of 1994. An additional 42,000 jobs vanished in the fabrics industry, which produces the raw material to make clothing, for a total shrinkage of 141,000 jobs -- 40 percent of all manufacturing jobs lost in the United States last year.
Job losses like these provide grist to politicians with protectionist messages, especially in an election year. So while dismantling trade barriers benefits most consumers by lowering prices, it also deepens blue-collar anxieties in industries that are vulnerable to foreign competition.
The new wave of job losses in the apparel industry, coming as they did soon after the passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement and the latest global trade accord, benefits candidates who say they want to save jobs and protect workers. Four years ago it was Ross Perot railing against free trade accords, and this year, the Republican populist, Patrick J. Buchanan, has enjoyed a surge in the polls with his attacks on free trade as a sellout of American labor.
And while textile-plant closings have been a fixture of the economic scene in the small towns of the South and Northeast for nearly a quarter-century, the recent hemorrhage of jobs, though predicted by many economists, is devastating some areas. It is driven by two forces -- government policy, which encourages free trade with low-cost apparel exporters like Mexico and Malaysia, and high technology, which helps big, profitable textile companies produce more cloth with fewer workers.
"We have lost on the order of 500,000 jobs in apparel in the past 23 years and we will probably lose another 40,000 to 50,000 this year," said Carl Priestland, an economist with the American Apparel Manufacturers Association.
Most of the pain will be felt in small towns like Pisgah, named after the mountain that Moses climbed to get his first glimpse of the Promised Land. Locals fear that Andover Togs, Pisgah's biggest employer, will shut down its remaining operations, including lithography and engineering, in addition to the sewing plant it just closed. If that happens, 400 more jobs will disappear -- and with them, the town's hopes for an economic recovery.
"I do a good business with people at the mill, so this is going to slow down the economy big time," said R.D. Mitchell, a former mayor who runs a Chevron service station that is one of the town's unofficial gathering spots. "There are a lot of people being pushed out of jobs within a 20-mile radius of here," he added. "People can't spend money they don't have."
For all the financial turmoil in textile workers' lives these days, the industry itself remains a huge and profitable sector of the American economy. Output has grown steadily, from $32.8 billion in 1974, to $56.3 billion in 1984 and to $74.2 billion in 1994, the last year for which figures are available. Even after adjusting for inflation, the increase over the last two decades has been more than 33 percent. Profits in 1994 totaled $1.74 billion, or 2.7 percent of sales, half the 5.4 profit margin for all manufacturing.
Broadly speaking, the textile trade consists of three sectors. Fiber manufacturers, the smallest of the three, spin cotton and other raw materials into threads for the fabric makers, which weave the threads into cloth for apparel producers to make into clothing.
While it is profitable, the continued prosperity of the industry hinges in large part on its ability to squeeze out as many American jobs as possible from the production process. The two main sectors -- raw fabrics and finished clothing -- achieve that goal in two very different ways, cutting labor costs and automation. And industry experts say that outside attempts to stanch the bleeding may do more harm than good.
Clothing manufacturers, swamped by a flood of cheap imports from Asia and elsewhere that have grabbed 50 percent of the American market, up from 20 percent two decades ago, stay profitable by exporting jobs to low-wage Latin American countries like Mexico and the Dominican Republic.
These companies have been unable to exploit America's vaunted technological superiority to offset their foreign rivals' wage advantage because no one has been able to develop an economical alternative to the old-fashioned sewing machine. Automated machines have a hard time handling soft, floppy cloth, and the vision-recognition systems needed to match patterns at seams, collars and cuffs are far too expensive for the low-margin apparel business.
In an integrated apparel factory, one that converts raw fabric to finished clothes, 50 percent of the jobs are sewing machine operators, 86 percent of whom are women. "You can automate design, you can automate pattern setting and cutting, but sooner or later you have to push fabric through a sewing machine," Mr. Priestland said. "That's still the bottleneck."
And that is where government policy comes in. Congressional approval of the North American and world trade accords in 1994 and 1995 made it much easier for American corporations to bring in goods from factories in third world countries, notably Mexico, by moving to eliminate quotas on imported apparel.
The search for cheap labor is nothing new. Many of the mills that are closing now migrated to impoverished regions of the rural South decades ago from the relatively prosperous Northeast. Even today, says David Thornell, director of the economic development authority of Jackson County, an economically depressed region that includes Pisgah, many of the factory workers here till the fields part time to make ends meet.
But with the factory idle, farming alone will not pay all the bills, and residents are bitter. "They pay those people down there a dollar and a nickel an hour," said Jim Mabry, another Pisgah resident. "Then they ship the clothes back here for finishing so they can call them American-made."
Andover Togs, which is based in New York, says it had little choice but to open its factory in the Dominican Republic. "I don't think we have ever seen a retail environment this sour," said Alan Kanis, the company's chief financial officer. He added that the company's major customers, discount chains like Wal-Mart and Kmart, were major importers, forcing the company to keep a tight rein on its costs.
David Buchanan, associate dean of the college of textiles at North Carolina State University, predicted more mills would shut down. The trend could turn out-of-the-way places like Pisgah into ghost towns, just as many farm villages in the upper Midwest faded into history when farming became mechanized.
"Historically, the role of the textile and apparel industry has been to provide employment for the otherwise unemployable," Mr. Buchanan said. "But that has been changing. If there is no work, the sons and daughters will move away, the way they did in farming. If there is no reason for a town to exist, it will go away."
If American apparel makers are surviving by hiring cheap labor overseas, the other big component of the textile industry, the companies that weave the cloth and fabric, is thriving by applying the latest technology at home.
A visit to the Cone Mills Corporation plant in Greensboro, N.C., shows the strides in productivity that American fabric makers have made in recent years. In the weaving room, a total of 416 looms pump out 12,000 square yards of denim every hour, nearly 50 percent more than the 1,000 older machines that they replaced. Yet they are so much easier to operate that only about 20 workers are needed to tend them, about one for every 21 looms and a tiny fraction of the 400 or so workers that handled the previous generation.
Not only that, but weaving technology is about to take a major step forward. The projectile looms in use now can insert 258 threads a minute; new air-jet machines just now coming onto factory floors can process 745 a minute, nearly three times as many.
Cone plans to replace its older machines with the more advanced models but will not increase its production capacity, since little growth is seen in the American market. "We'll just have fewer looms and fewer people," said Patrick Danahy, Cone's president.
The combination of faster machines and fewer people explains the decline in employment in the fabric industry from more than 700,000 in the late 1980's to 625,700 in January, even as fabric output increased.
Although the people in Pisgah are unhappy when their jobs depart for Caribbean nations like the Dominican Republic, the location is good news for the American fabric industry because the new factories there are more likely to buy cloth from them rather than their Asian competitors.
"Eighty percent of clothing imports from Mexico and the Caribbean are made of American fabric," Carlos Moore, executive vice president of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute, said. "That explains why we have been able to supply a lot of fabric in the face of slow growth and imports."
And though the recent liberalization of world trade seems to be accelerating the exodus of apparel jobs from the United States, Mr. Moore said it might also provide an opportunity to increase American raw-textile exports. "Most countries have traditionally protected their textile industries, but now they may be forced to open up," he said.
Moreover, some people question whether the North American Free Trade Agreement and other trade pacts should be blamed for the flight of jobs abroad. Without the trade agreement, Mr. Danahy of Cone Mills said, "Both the apparel and textile jobs would have gone to Bangladesh and elsewhere in the Far East.
"With Nafta in place," he added, "the textile complex on this continent is more competitive."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rate Doubts Still Undercut Bond Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Investors in Treasury bonds extended their losing streak to four sessions yesterday as disappointment with the Federal Reserve and technical factors led prices down.
The Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, testified before a Congressional subcommittee yesterday on the state of the economy and monetary policy, but did not give any definitive signs of the Fed's intentions concerning interest rates. Those anticipating assurances of further rate cuts, perhaps as soon as March, got none. In fact, Mr. Greenspan said nothing to prevent further selling in the current climate of rising rates. 
 The 30-year bond tumbled 2 points yesterday, to 94 22/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, rose to 6.40 percent, from 6.24 percent on Friday. The yield jump, and the corresponding slump in the long bond's price, was the largest one-day move since May 1994.
Eric Hamilton, senior fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said that the market "is clearly on the defensive and needs to see continued signs of an economic slowdown before its regains its lost ground." With a weakening economy, interest rates can fall, and bond prices rise.
Without fresh economic data to give direction, traders said, the market leaned toward technical trading, like volume and price movement.
Tony Crescenzi, head of government bond trading at Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company, a New York brokerage firm, said, "There are times when selling begets selling because there are technical support levels that have been violated." While the technical activity had increased, he said, there has been no apparent change in market fundamentals.
James Hale, a fixed-income analyst at MMS International in San Francisco, said that selling started in Europe on fading hopes of lower interest rates there, and that caused a selloff in New York.
Meanwhile, large hedge funds put pressure on the market by selling Treasury securities they had financed in Japanese yen. Weakness in the dollar alarmed some investors as the yen grew stronger, forcing the funds to unwind the yen trades because of the potential for currency losses.
As for Mr. Greenspan's testimony, Mr. Hale said that the market was nervous before he even began to speak. Prices fell before Mr. Greenspan spoke, and then fell further after he left traders doubtful that the Fed would lower rates further.
"I think it's fair to say, considering the backdrop of only moderate economic growth and slow inflation, that the market has oversold," Mr. Hale said. "In the short run, the market behavior has turned psychologically so bearish that the oversold condition may continue."
Gerald A. Guild, senior vice president of the taxable fixed-income department at Advest Inc., said that while the day's decline did begin for technical reasons, it expanded beyond that. "The psychology has changed so that people are now concerned about an acceleration in economic growth, accompanied by increased fears of inflation.
"Economic growth is still at 2 to 2.25 percent, which is tame," he continued. "Consumer prices are up 2.75 to 3 percent, and unemployment will fall minimally to between 5.5 to 5.75 percent, from the current 5.8 percent. There are no wage pressures, so it's important to remember that wage growth only grew 2.9 percent in 1995 -- the lowest rate in 15 years. The market is overselling itself."
The three- and six-month bill auction yesterday drew decent demand as rates were mixed, with the rate for a three-month down 2 basis points, to 4.78 percent, and the six-month issue up 4 basis points, to 4.75 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: Testimony by Greenspan Rattles Stock and Bond Markets;
Blue Chips Fall 44.79; 30-Year Bond Plunges In Fourth Day of Selloff

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Stock and bond markets declined sharply yesterday, continuing a four-day selloff that is leading some investors to question whether a fundamental shift in sentiment might be under way.
For months, investors have been wagering that slower economic growth would lead to further declines in interest rates. And that belief, traders and analysts said, helped send the stock market to highs and pushed short- and long-term interest rates down sharply. 
 But in the last week that faith has been fading. And yesterday, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, raised doubts about additional cuts in short-term interest rates, knocking one of the main supports from beneath this year's stock market boom.
In a volatile session that saw two rounds of sharp price declines and only one solid rebound, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 44.79 points, or more that eight-tenths of a percent, to 5,458.53. At one point, the index was down nearly 70 points. With yesterday's decline, the Dow has lost 142 points, or 2.5 percent, in the last four sessions. (The stock and bond markets were closed on Monday in observance of Washington's Birthday.)
Other market indexes also fell yesterday. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 7.33 points, or 1.13 percent, to 640.65, while the Nasdaq composite index slipped 7.47, to 1,083.24.
Bonds also tumbled, with the price of the 30-year Treasury bond falling more than 2 points, the largest loss since May 1994. The yield on the long bond, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, rose to 6.40 percent, up from 6.24 percent on Friday. As recently as Jan. 19, the yield on the long-term bond was less than 6 percent, and the selloff has wiped out all the gains made at the end of last year. [Page D17.]
Analysts are not yet ready to declare this year's market rallies over, especially in stocks, where the Dow is still up 6.7 percent despite the current selloff. But the recent declines are making them wonder if investors have given up hope for further cuts in interest rates and are beginning to worry more about inflation, despite the fact that inflation has remained at 3 percent for four years.
"Based on what Alan Greenspan said, there are valid questions about the timing and degree of further cuts in interest rates," said A. Marshall Acuff, portfolio strategist at Smith Barney.
Byron R. Wien, director of United States portfolio strategy at Morgan Stanley, added: "The Administration wants growth even if it includes higher inflation. The focus has shifted from fiscal responsibility to economic growth, and that's bad for interest rates."
Election-year talk about getting the economy to grow faster, especially the new emphasis among leading Republican Presidential candidates like the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, is what is making some investors worry about inflation. To the bond market, growth raises the possibility of inflation, giving bond traders yet another reason to be cautious. And rising interest rates can worry the stock market.
The Republican candidates have all but dropped their previously fervent calls for balancing the Federal budget, focusing instead on reasons why the United States economy needs to continue to grow.
President Clinton yesterday sounded his own call for continued economic expansion, saying he wanted to appoint someone to the Fed's board of governors who holds pro-growth views on the economy and does not just represent the "conventional wisdom."
Mr. Wein of Morgan Stanley asked: "How long has it been since you've heard somebody get up and scream about a balanced budget? That kind of talk smacks of cutbacks and sacrifice, and that doesn't attract voters."
Already, bond markets around the globe have started to suffer higher interest rates, said E. Wayne Nordberg, a partner at Lord, Abbett & Company, a New York money management firm. In recent weeks, traders who borrowed money at very low rates in Japan to invest in bonds paying higher rates in Germany, for example, have begun to unwind those positions, he said.
In addition, the inclination of central bankers across Europe to act together "is beginning to weaken," Mr. Nordberg said. "Therefore, European central banks might pursue more inflationary monetary policies." In such an environment, "for more speculative traders to turn around and take profits is not unusual," he said.
That is starting to spell trouble for foreign stock markets. Among other active markets yesterday, the Mexican Bolsa index fell 71.03 points, or 2.4 percent, to 2,904.41, and the Toronto Stock Exchange 300 index declined 62.57, or 1.2 percent, to 4,963.80. In Britain, the FT-SE 100 index lost 29.70, to 3,714.60, and in Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 index dipped 65.58, to 20,655.67.
Mr. Nordberg added that he expected to continue to see greater volatility in the American stock market leading up to the fall election.
Reflecting the sharp decline in the big American stock indexes yesterday, stocks recording losses on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered those with gains nearly 4 to 1. Volume was 395.9 million shares, down from 445.6 million on Friday.
Volume was relatively light throughout the day, giving at least one trader pause about whether the decline in prices represented the beginning of a larger decline in stock prices. "I would expect more volume if institutions really were selling heavily," said Jack Baker, head of institutional equity trading at Furman Selz.
After stock prices declined sharply at the opening bell, falling more than 50 points in the first half hour, they quickly rebounded and stayed relatively steady, at about 5,470, until 2:30 P.M., when Mr. Greenspan began his testimony before Congress.
What Mr. Greenspan said was not as important as the way in which many investors and traders chose to interpret his remarks. The Fed chairman said that the seeds are in place for moderate, sustainable growth. While a positive remark for those worried that economy may be slowing too much, stock and bond traders decided that Mr. Greenspan's comments cast considerable doubt on whether the Fed would make further cuts in short-term interest rates in the near future.
Not all large stocks were losers yesterday. I.B.M., for example, traded as high as 120 7/8 before closing 1 1/8 higher, at 119 1/8, its highest price since March 1991. The company yesterday introduced new products and services that will allow its existing mainframe computers to serve as Internet servers, perhaps breathing new life into the large boxes that many computer experts consider to be dinosaurs.
Among other active stocks, Sierra On-Line gained 7 3/8, to 34 1/2, after agreeing to be acquired by CUC International, which fell 6 1/4, to 31 1/4.
In addition to I.B.M., several other technology stocks also posted gains. Cisco Systems rose 1 1/8, to 45 5/8; Micron Technology moved up 3/4, to 36 7/8; Motorola jumped 7/8, to 56 1/8, and Apple Computer, whose new chairman outlined his priorities to the media on Friday, rose 1 1/2, to 29..
Bank stocks fell sharply on the outlook for higher interest rates. J. P. Morgan fell 1 7/8, to 79 3/8; Bankers Trust New York dipped 2 1/8, to 63; Citicorp fell 1 1/2, to 73 7/8, and Chase Manhattan, finished down 1 1/2, at 68 1/2.
Utility stocks, which also typically feel the effects of sharp moves in interest rates, declined. The Dow Jones utilities average, a closely watched industry barometer, fell 3.99 points, or 1.7 percent, to 225.75.

HEADLINE: U.S. Set to Impose Limited Trade Sanctions on China

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration intends to punish China for supplying nuclear materials to Pakistan by applying selective sanctions intended to hurt China without disrupting American companies that do business there, senior officials say.
The sanctions, which could be tariffs on Chinese imports or restrictions on the export of American goods that the Chinese want, are an alternative to broader penalties prescribed by law for countries that violate international arms trading rules. 
 Officials said President Clinton would formally impose the broad sanctions, but waive them on grounds of national interest and immediately order the narrower measures "to make the punishment fit the crime," as one senior Administration official put it.
Without a waiver, the law would cut off $10 billion in loan guarantees to American companies, hurting American workers along with the Chinese.
Officials have been examining possible penalties since last week to try to head off a growing furor about China in Congress. Action is expected soon.
Possible penalties could aim to cut off high-tech American products that China cannot get elsewhere, or could be devised to punish the specific military-run factories blamed for the arms exports to Pakistan.
To punish Pakistan, the officials say, an agreement to deliver $368 million in American aircraft -- missiles and howitzers that already have been paid for -- is likely to be blocked, as it was once before.
The Administration is also threatening separate economic sanctions against China for failing to stop its factories from wholesale piracy of copyrighted music compact disks and computer software.
With conflicts bubbling over intellectual property rights, human rights, trade and military threats to Taiwan, Administration officials say they cannot ignore the violation of China's vows on cooperating to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons and retain credibility with Beijing or Congress, especially in an election year.
"Good relationships have to run both ways," a senior American official said, echoing the new, harder line in American policy toward Beijing stated most vividly last week by Secretary of Defense William J. Perry in a speech at the National Defense University.
"It takes two to tango," Mr. Perry said. "It takes two to engage. While we are committed to engagement, we are not committed to engagement at any price."
While emphasizing that engagement with China is a vital part of America's security interests and its policy of "preventive defense in the Asia-Pacific region," he said, "It is time for China to start sending the right messages."
But at the same time, American officials want to be sure they are sending the right messages, especially to an insecure leadership waiting for the death of Deng Xiaoping and using nationalist credos, whether over Taiwan or trade, to buttress a faltering Communist ideology.
Whether the issue is the export of nuclear materials, a peaceful resolution on Taiwan or a satisfactory end to the struggle over intellectual property rights, a senior official said, "We feel a deal is a deal, and telling China you have to play by your commitments sends a positive message on other issues."
Officially, the United States has not yet stated that China is in violation of nuclear nonproliferation law, only that officials are evaluating intelligence reports indicating that China supplied Pakistan with 5,000 ring magnets late last year to enrich uranium for weapons use.
Although China and Pakistan deny all wrongdoing, senior American officials say there is little doubt that a violation occurred and that the United States must respond.
The officials say that talks are going on with the Chinese to be "absolutely sure we know the facts" and to try to negotiate China's "future behavior, which will be one factor in how we proceed."
But the officials feel constrained by a 1994 American law that requires the cutoff of United States Export-Import Bank loan guarantees to American companies doing business in China if China sells nuclear-weapons information and technology.
The amount at stake is now $10 billion, and if the American companies lose their contracts, China can buy the same products in other countries, the officials say.
"The main victim is U.S. business, and China doesn't suffer," said Stanley O. Roth, who was in charge of Asia policy at the National Security Council until Jan. 1 and now is the head of research at the U.S. Institute for Peace.
James R. Lilley, a former American Ambassador to Beijing and director of the American legation in Taiwan, who is now at the American Enterprise Institute, said, "China violates nonproliferation norms and the United States shoots itself in the foot, and no one else in the world follows us on this."
That is why, in several interagency meetings at the White House, officials are searching for sanctions and penalties that do not cut both ways.
Mr. Roth suggested that waiving the Export-Import Bank penalties would be easier if China would acknowledge its actions and negotiate a stricter regime "to stop in the future." Failing that, he suggested, "sanctions could be targeted in a way that gets China's attention" on issues of high-technology trade with the United States that Beijing cannot replicate.
"Anything will inevitably lead to howls of protest from Beijing, but at least you don't undermine nonproliferation," Mr. Roth said.
Of course, American officials acknowledge, China may respond by canceling the American projects guaranteed by the Export-Import Bank, including a $23-million sale of generator parts by Westinghouse Electric Corporation.
As an indication of the mood in Beijing, China's Foreign Trade Minister, Wu Yi, vowed last week to retaliate against American exports to China if Washington imposed more than $1 billion in sanctions against Chinese imports in the dispute over intellectual property rights.
The American trade representative, Mickey Kantor, has vowed to impose the sanctions if China does not live up to a bilateral agreement reached last year to shut down more than 30 factories producing millions of dollars worth of pirated American software, compact disks and videos.
As they debate these issues, American officials say, they are concerned that hitting China with multiple penalties in such rapid order may encourage Beijing to act more aggressively or irresponsibly toward Taiwan, which holds its first democratic presidential elections on March 23. President Lee Teng-hui, who has been pushing to get Taiwan a seat in the United Nations, is expected to win handily, and the Chinese have been organizing military exercises and threatening missile strikes to put psychological pressure on the Taiwanese to back off any moves toward independence.
American officials have repeatedly said that China could not successfully invade Taiwan, but they have also warned Beijing about stability in the waters around Taiwan and sent an American aircraft carrier through the Taiwan Strait, ostensibly because of bad weather.
Given the most serious danger, which is military conflict, and China's generally good relations with Mr. Perry, it was no surprise that he became the front man for the Administration's tougher tone, Mr. Lilley said.
Mr. Lilley said he believed that Beijing was using threats against Taiwan as a tactic to obtain softer American responses on other issues, from nonproliferation to trade.

HEADLINE: Poll Indicates Support for Tax to Rebuild Schools

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
Rather than allow a $1.50-a-week tax to expire, an overwhelming majority of New Yorkers would be willing to redirect the money to help rebuild the city's crumbling schools, according to the results of a poll released yesterday by Quinnipiac College.
Eighty-two percent of the poll respondents said they approved of the idea behind a plan that the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, proposed last month to raise $1.4 billion for school reconstruction. 
 Mr. Vallone hailed the poll results as proof that his proposal has popular support. But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani held firm in his opposition. He said once again that he did not believe that the Board of Education could be trusted to spend the money wisely. And he called the poll question "a loaded question that produced the result it wanted."
Poll participants were asked: "Currently, the average taxpayer pays an extra $1.50 per week in New York City income taxes, which is dedicated to hiring more police. This tax is due to expire at the end of the year. Do you think the tax should be continued and spent on rebuilding the city's public schools or do you think the tax should be allowed to expire in December?"
The poll was conducted from Feb. 9 to 13 and found that New Yorkers believe education is one of the most important problems facing the city -- second only to crime. It also found that black and Hispanic residents favored the school construction tax plan more strongly than the overall group; 90 percent of them answered yes.
"These numbers say that people think this is what should happen," said Maurice Carroll, director of the college's Polling Institute in Hamden, Conn. "It says that $1.50 a week doesn't seem like a lot of money to people if the money goes for school repairs. And this is everybody -- across the board."
Mr. Carroll also defended the phrasing of the question, and said: "It's a fair statement of what happens."
The city is not expected to need money for hiring police officers because the Mayor has said he plans to cut the police force by about 1,500 officers from its peak of 38,310 by the end of this year.
The poll surveyed 880 city residents and had a margin of sampling error of 3.3 percentage points.
Mr. Vallone, who has spent the last few weeks lobbying the Mayor, Gov. George E. Pataki and leaders of the State Legislature on behalf of his plan, said he hoped the results would help advance the political debate.
"It should be the spark plug to get everybody on the same page," Mr. Vallone said. "And it should zero in on the fact that New Yorkers may be tolerant of debate, but they want action."
The Mayor, however, repeated his concern that the money from the surcharge would not actually be spent on schools.
"The fact is, we should straighten out the school system first before we put more money into it or before we give it a dedicated source of funds," he said. "That would be the worst possible thing to do."
Mr. Vallone insisted, however, that the money would go directly to the School Construction Authority, which is overseen by a board made up of the Schools Chancellor and representatives appointed by the Mayor and the Governor. He said he hoped to conclude negotiations with the Mayor by May, in time to send the plan to the State Legislature for final approval.
Dave Begel, a spokesman for Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, said he was heartened by the poll results. "But I don't think it's surprising that people are willing to dig a little deeper when they think the money will go to schools," he said. "The conditions have been pretty well documented, and people recognize that it's hard to learn under these circumstances."

HEADLINE: Changing City, Changing Carnival

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 20

 BODY:
The parade was staged by one of the lesser of the private, secretive clubs that put on the world-famous party of Mardi Gras. What it lacked in history and old money, it filled in with racket and tableau as it lurched along St. Charles Avenue last week, the drums booming like thunderclaps, the colored beads dropping like Kool-Aid rain.
It was almost a full week before Fat Tuesday and the roaring climax of Carnival in New Orleans, but the avenue's median -- what people here call "neutral ground" -- was awash with jumping, cheering, hollering spectators who begged for the trinkets tossed from the passing floats. Most of the spectators on that block were black, as are most of the people in New Orleans, but the men looking down from the floats were white. 
 Then, as the parade moved past the stately old Pontchartrain Hotel, one club member pushed back his mask, revealing a black face underneath. The sight of him made several people shout a greeting, and made one teen-age girl smile.
"People just like to see a black person on a float," said 16-year-old Cornelia Williams, who has been coming to parades since she was a baby. It is not that she dreams of riding in one herself. But in a city where a migration of whites to the suburbs has left a racial mix that is more than 65 percent black, she does not want a white man telling her she cannot be a part of something because of her color.
Four years have passed since the city adopted a landmark ordinance barring racial discrimination against prospective members by clubs that parade at Mardi Gras. Rather than comply, a few of the oldest clubs, or krewes -- among them Comus, which had paraded here since 1857 -- shut down their parades, leaving what many older white families see as a gap in Carnival's soul.
But the truth, many here say, is that the ordinance did to Carnival and New Orleans only what the passing of time was sure to do anyway; it just erased a little early the insult of the exclusion that blacks felt when a parade of no one but white men passed in the streets. While it is true that the ordinance took from some people a gilded part of the city's past, that part could not have survived much longer in a city of high crime and high unemployment, where many whites had given up and were moving out.
In a way, the changes in Mardi Gras reflect the deeper changes taking place in the older Southern cities as families that controlled commerce and social lives for 100 years lose political power to blacks and others moving in from other parts of the country. The old Mardi Gras was the last symbol of the power these families held here in New Orleans.
"There is a sense in which Carnival is New Orleans, and it reflects the sociology of the city damn near to perfection," said Munro Edmonson, a retired professor of anthropology at Tulane University, who for some 40 years, as both social scientist and casual observer, has studied the complexities of Mardi Gras.
Comus, Momus and other private men's clubs remain part of the city's mosaic, still hold their grand balls and still congregate with their own kind. But the time when their ideal could be paraded in public has passed. "At a symbolic level, it was very dramatic," Dr. Edmonson said of the 1992 ordinance. "But it was a change that was already going on."
To outsiders, and to many residents as well, the gaps left by the departure of the stately parades of Comus (pronounced KOH-muss) and others is barely felt. New krewes fill the street with grand parades, and the revelers fill the air with "throws" -- fake gold coins, cheap plastic beads and even ladies' underwear -- just as they always have. The flambeau carriers still light the way with their smoking torches, jazz still sounds on St. Charles Avenue and on Canal Street, and the big floats still glide. What some said would be Carnival's death knell has turned out to be more like a speed bump on the way to something different and inevitable, white and black revelers alike said this week.
Carnival is always in flux. Over the years there have been not only black krewes with histories dating from early in the century -- the first king of one such krewe, Zulu, spoofed Rex, the King of Carnival, in 1916 by donning a lard-can crown -- but also gay krewes that have boomed and died, their members lost to AIDS, and even a parade for people who just want to parade, a procession of big trucks filled with them.
Mardi Gras traditionalists say Comus, Momus and Proteus, the three top-drawer krewes that dropped their parades rather than endure the city's intrusion, were true Carnival and cannot be replaced. On the other hand, another traditional krewe, Rex, established in 1872, retained its parade by opening membership to blacks after enactment of the ordinance, which had been proposed by Dorothy Mae Taylor, then a Councilwoman.
"I know for a fact that three years before Dorothy Mae Taylor" pushed through the legislation, "Rex was trying to integrate," said Arthur Hardy, editor and publisher of the Mardi Gras Guide, who is a lifelong follower of Carnival history. "She didn't accomplish anything except destroying a part of our heritage. We kicked our great-grandfathers in the shin. Certainly the black community hasn't won anything."
Asked about changes in his secretive club, a Rex spokesman, demanding anonymity, would say only that "our organization abides by the ordinance" and that "it has caused no problems of any kind." Rex still has "all the functions it had before," he said, "continues to parade and continues to be the pre-eminent Carnival organization."
He would not comment at all on whether he was proud that the color line had been broken. It is against the krewe's guidelines to discuss its members, even, apparently, in the abstract.
The history and the topography of New Orleans are the key to understanding why the drunken prelude to the penitential season of Lent has come to spur such a world of feeling here, Dr. Edmonson said.
"New Orleans has never been as segregated as other cities," he said. "It doesn't have enough dry land for that. Everyone lives cheek by jowl. That has changed with white flight, but there never was a kind of spacial segregation possible elsewhere. With the Creoles," the lighter-skinned blacks, traditional leaders in black New Orleans, "we did not have two races, but three. The mansions and slums are within shouting distance."
Over its history, he continued, the people of New Orleans "fell into a pattern of social interaction in which they knew everything about their neighbor's business but put on elaborate pretenses of not knowing. You're polite to your neighbor here; politeness is a shield against contact. In that sense, the snobbery of the krewes was a way of separating rather than uniting people.
"The whole thing came to be a system largely composed of fantasy, and largely retrospective. Carnival glamorizes the past, and looks back to a day that never was: an elite that never had any legitimate claim to the aristocracy ride their floats like sneering marquises before the French Revolution, tossing baubles."
But in the last decade, New Orleans has been in the throes of change that, "anywhere else, would have been social revolution," Dr. Edmonson said. "We went through the major upheaval of white flight, the beginning of burgeoning suburbanization."
Still, white residents belonged by the thousands to private Mardi Gras clubs that excluded blacks. And although the clubs financed their own floats and costumes, it was public money, for police services and so forth, that allowed them to parade. "It became unreasonable not to raise some kind of fuss," Dr. Edmonson said. "The city spends a lot of tax money coping with Mardi Gras."
The change did not come easily, though. Whites opposed it overwhelmingly, and, a poll in The Times-Picayune showed, so did 51 percent of blacks. "People naturally select, like with business partners," said Mr. Hardy, the Mardi Gras Guide publisher.
But on the parade routes this week and last, black revelers, and some whites as well, said they did not miss the parades of the old krewes and did not believe that Mardi Gras had been badly wounded. Indeed, the desire by some black people here to continue with the old system had been based not on respect or approval of the white krewes but instead on years of resentment: they simply wanted nothing to do with them.
Ultimately, integration moved both ways across the color line. "We had a graduate student from Norway," Dr. Edmonson said, "who fell in love with the Mardi Gras Indians," the black men who stage their own elaborate festivals of feathered costumes, song and verbal assaults. "Eventually, they made him a member of a tribe."

NEW YORK CITY
 
2 More Victims of Child Abuse
In unrelated incidents, two Bronx children -- both of whom were taken from city custody and returned to a parent -- became the latest additions to New York City's list of child abuse victims. One 2-year-old boy was found dead and a 2-year-old girl was raped. [Page B1.]
 
Failure to Monitor a Suspect
Doctors at Kings County Hospital Center never checked on the outpatient treatment of a mentally ill teen-ager accused in the death of a woman in a subway robbery, even though officials say hospitals are required to monitor such patients. [B3.]
 
Judge Won't Be Reassigned
New York State's top administrative judge refused to reassign a Criminal Court judge whose removal has been demanded by Governor Pataki and Mayor Giuliani. The judge, Lorin Duckman, has been criticized for freeing defendants in two domestic violence proceedings who were subsequently arrested for other crimes . [B1.]
 
A Latin Takes Manhattan
In Washington Heights, a grinning conqueror dwarfs the city skyline with his black beret and Afro comb. He is Orodoto Balbuena, a romantic rube played by Luisito Marti, the star of "Nueba Yol," a movie comedy made by Angel Muniz. It is every immigrant's story of scheming and dreaming to get a visa. About New York by David Gonzalez. [B1.]
 
Wife Testifies in Bomb Trial
The wife of Edward J. Leary took the witness stand in her husband's defense, testifying how his behavior became increasingly bizarre and obsessive in the months leading up to two subway firebombings. [B4.]
 
Sentences in Officer's Killing
Two teen-age brothers were sentenced to long prison terms for their roles in a Brooklyn robbery in which their uncle killed the officer. [B4.]
 
The One Giuliani Won't Endorse
Mayor Giuliani still may not be ready to say whom he will endorse among the Republican candidates for President, but he said that he would never support Patrick J. Buchanan for any elected office. [B4.]
 
Poll Finds School-Tax Support
Rather than allow a $1.50-a-week tax to expire, an overwhelming majority of New Yorkers would be willing to redirect the money to help rebuild the city's crumbling schools, according to a new poll. [B4.]
 
REGION
 
Tax Proposed on Nonprofits
The Mayor of Syracuse has proposed charging nonprofit tax-exempt institutions like churches, universities and hospitals a "core service fee," a tax-like payment for such basic services as road maintenance and police protection. [A1.]
 
Questioning Aid to Cornell
Cornell University is best known as a private Ivy League school, but it is also part of the State University system, receiving about $170 million a year to teach industrial arts and farming. Officials of the State University system are beginning to question whether Cornell should get so much state money. [B1.]
 
Houses Painted With Graffiti
Twice recently, a person spray-painted anti-Semitic graffiti and swastikas on the sides of houses in a heavily Jewish neighborhood in Mamaroneck, N.Y. [B5.]
 
Indian Sales Taxes Sought
The Pataki administration proposed that New York begin collecting taxes on some gasoline and cigarettes sales on Indian reservations starting July 5. [B5.]
 
Jail Investigated After Rape
Prosecutors and the county police are investigating operations at the Union County Jail in New Jersey after two inmates were charged with raping a woman who had been held in the jail overnight. [B6.]
 
D.O.T. Issues Train Rules
After 14 deaths in commuter train wrecks in the last 14 days, the Transportation Department issued emergency procedures intended to reduce the speed of the trains after they leave stations where there are no signals. National Report. [A11.]

HEADLINE: House Democrats Assail Welfare Plan Backed by Governors

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
House Democrats today sharply criticized a package of welfare proposals endorsed unanimously this month by members of the National Governors' Association, including 18 Democrats.
At a hearing of the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources, Republicans praised the governors' proposals. Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., the Florida Republican who heads the subcommittee, said the governors "rode into town in the darkest days of winter and breathed life back into a welfare reform debate that was on life support." 
 But all four Democrats at today's hearing criticized the proposals, saying they did not adequately protect poor children. Catholic Charities USA, a national network of local charities run by the Roman Catholic Church, echoed that concern.
The comments underlined the differences between liberal House Democrats and President Clinton, who has applauded the governors for their bipartisan effort. In a speech to the governors on Feb. 6, Mr. Clinton said, "I believe we're going to pass welfare reform legislation." But he and his appointees later objected to specific elements of the governors' package, including cuts in the growth of spending on food stamps and a provision that would allow states to reduce their own welfare spending.
An Administration official said tonight: "The President wants a welfare bill. He absolutely, positively does. The question is, Can you get a decent one? Some House Democrats would clearly prefer that nothing pass this year, while we would prefer that something pass."
Sharon M. Daly, deputy director of Catholic Charities, said the governors' proposals "would repeal the Federal guarantee of protection for poor children, allow states to turn their backs on their obligations to poor families and repeal the right of individual children to receive protection against abuse and neglect" by parents.
"For more than a year," Mrs. Daly said, "the welfare debate has focused almost exclusively on personal responsibility." But, she said, the Roman Catholic Church, from the Pope on down through the bishops, teaches that Government and society also have responsibilities: to help guarantee that people have "suitable employment," adequate wages and welfare benefits when jobs are unavailable.
The chairman of the governors' association, Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, a Republican, told the members of Congress today: "Governors are just as concerned about children as you are. We will not allow children to go without protection, without food, without sustenance."
Under questioning by Democrats, Mr. Thompson said flatly, "The Catholic Church is wrong."
The governors said Congress should give each state a lump sum of Federal money, known as a block grant, for assistance to poor people. State officials would have vast new discretion to design their own welfare programs.
While poor people would no longer be entitled to cash assistance, the Federal Government would establish a $2 billion contingency fund to help states with high rates of unemployment or child poverty.
Representative Sander M. Levin, Democrat of Michigan, said the contingency fund "is likely to be wholly inadequate" in a recession. Moreover, he said that the governors' proposals would shift costs from the states to the Federal Government and "threaten to undermine the food stamp program as a safety net for children."
Mr. Levin asserted that "a substantial number of welfare recipients could lose their Medicaid coverage" under the governors' proposals.
Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California, said he was not surprised at the bipartisan agreement among governors. "Governors can get together whenever greed is involved," Mr. Stark said. "They all support this because it will save them a lot of money."
Another California Democrat, Representative Robert T. Matsui, said in an interview: "This would be a great deal for the governors. We raise taxes. They spend the money and are not accountable."
The split among Democrats is reflected in the Clinton Administration. Officials at the Departments of Labor and Health and Human Services are more critical of the governors' proposals than are White House officials. Mr. Shaw said, "The Administration has chosen not to send a witness to today's hearing."
The Secretary of Health and Human Services, Donna E. Shalala, plans to testify next week at a Senate hearing on the governors' proposals.
New estimates by the Congressional Budget Office show that the governors' proposals, by adding money for child care and other services, would significantly reduce the savings achieved by the welfare bill. The measure passed by Congress last year would have saved $60.2 billion over seven years. The version favored by the governors would save $42.3 billion, or 30 percent less, the budget office said.
In the 1992 campaign, Mr. Clinton promised to "end welfare as we know it," but last month he vetoed a welfare bill passed by Congress, saying it was too harsh. Haley Barbour, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said Mr. Clinton could embrace the governors' proposals or "kowtow again to his liberal base and destroy any chance of genuine welfare reform."

HEADLINE: Testimony by Greenspan Rattles Stock and Bond Markets;
Hopes of Rate Cut Dim As Economy Is Termed 'Basically on Track'

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20

 BODY:
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, described the economy today as soft but dismissed fears of a downturn, giving the impression that he was not eager to bolster growth with another round of cuts right away in short-term interest rates.
"A number of fundamentals point to an economy basically on track for sustained growth, so any weakness is likely to be temporary," Mr. Greenspan told a House panel in his required semiannual report to Congress on the outlook for the economy and the central bank's monetary strategy. 
 Traders in the securities markets, who have been counting on further rate cuts from the Fed in response to a string of weak economic reports for early 1996, registered sharp disappointment. Even though Mr. Greenspan did not entirely close the door to lower rates in his afternoon appearance, his generally positive spin on the economy contributed to a surge in interest rates in the bond market. Losses in the stock market mounted after his testimony.
Also today, an index intended to predict the economy's course posted its first advance after three months of declines. With 8 of its 10 available components moving higher, the index of leading economic indicators climbed two-tenths of 1 percent for December.
Mr. Greenspan's appearance came at a particularly delicate time, scheduled coincidentally on the day of the primary election in New Hampshire, where questions about economic growth figured significantly in the political debate. In a speech in New York last week, President Clinton, after studiously avoiding criticizing Mr. Greenspan for three years, suggested that the Fed should be more concerned about encouraging growth and not so worried about the threat of inflation.
Mr. Greenspan's term as chairman expires at the end of next week. White House officials have made clear that Mr. Clinton sees no alternative to reappointing Mr. Greenspan to another four-year term. Indeed, the Fed chairman suggested today in ducking a question about various tax proposals that he thought he would have ample future opportunity to expound.
The White House is also hoping to announce nominees this week for two vacancies on the seven-member Federal Reserve Board, according to the White House spokesman, Mike McCurry. One slot is the vice chairmanship, which the President had sought for Felix Rohatyn, the New York investment banker. Mr. Clinton had said that Mr. Rohatyn's presence on the Fed would encourage a debate over whether the economy is capable of sustaining faster growth than the generally sluggish rate of recent years. But Mr Rohatyn withdrew his name after strenuous opposition emerged from Congressional Republicans.
The current list of candidates for the Fed posts is believed to include Laurence H. Meyer, a St. Louis economic consultant; Peter Kenen, an economics professor at Princeton University; Eugene Ludwig, the Comptroller of the Currency, and Robert Shapiro of the Progressive Policy Institute, a Democratic research group that President Clinton helped found.
"The President is interested in the strongest possible nominees for the Federal Reserve Board," Mr. McCurry said today, "and he's made it clear he thinks there should be a representation of views on the board that reflects the debate among economists and specialists on how best to stimulate economic growth."
While Mr. Greenspan is a virtual shoo-in to win approval from the Republican-controlled Senate, the nominees for the other Fed positions are expected to face intense grilling from the Senate Banking Committee. Still, any of them appear more likely to win support than Mr. Rohatyn would have. His role in the financial rescue of New York City in the 1970's and his frequent calls for greater public investment have been cited by conservative critics as evidence of a fondness for government intervention.
Mr. Greenspan, a paragon of caution and a master of disguised intentions, said nothing explicit about the probable direction of interest rates in his testimony today. But the tenor of his prepared statement and his answers to questions suggested that he saw no urgency to extend the quarter-point cuts in rates that were made in mid-December and late January.
"There is no question this is a soft economy," the chairman said in response to Representative Jim Leach, an Iowa Republican, who had inquired whether the economy might contract for a few months. But Mr. Greenspan said he doubted that the situation would deteriorate into "negative growth," observing that January's "dismal" numbers, which were hurt by the Northeast blizzard, may be giving way to a modest rebound.
"It seems February is doing a shade better," Mr. Greenspan said, noting, however, that little data are available yet for this month. .
The views expressed in the monetary report that Mr. Greenspan delivered were close to the consensus among economists. It projected that the growth of gross domestic product, adjusted for inflation, would be 2 to 2.25 percent in the period from the fourth quarter of 1995 to the fourth quarter of 1996, quite similar to the Clinton Administration's projection of 2.2 percent.
The Consumer Price Index was projected to rise by 2.75 to 3 percent, just below the Administration's 3.1 percent, while the Fed's projected unemployment rate, 5.5 to 5.75 percent, was in line with the Administration's 5.7 percent. The outlook is more important as a guide to the thinking of Fed officials, who tend to respond with policy changes when the economy appears to be veering outside the projected path, than as a particularly reliable forecast of the economy.
"The economy has started off slowly early this year, but fundamental conditions appear to be more encouraging than recent data might seem to suggest," the report said, predicting that the economy will "grow moderately" in 1996 with no significant pickup in inflation.
Members of the House banking subcommittee elicited these other observations from Mr. Greenspan today:
*A failure by Congress and the White House to reach agreement this year on a credible deficit-reduction plan would mean that some of last year's two-percentage-point decline in long-term interest rates "will have to be refunded." Passage of a program, by contrast, would bring rates down "quite a bit further," Mr. Greenspan predicted.
*The Fed would have been "irresponsible" not to have raised interest rates in 1994 because classic signs of accelerating inflation were starting to appear, including longer lead times on supplier deliveries and a surge in overtime hours worked by employees.
*Stressing the need for a better-educated work force, Mr. Greenspan, a conservative, said he agreed with Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, a liberal who often sounds this same theme, "on quite a lot of things." Their accord on this issue, he said, has proved "quite a surprise to both of us."
As for today's statistic, the rise in the index of leading indicators, the compilation of which has been taken over by the private Conference Board from the Commerce Department, was a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in December. Yet it did break a string of three consecutive declines that averaged a similar amount and it was broadly based.
The biggest positive influences were a decline in average first-time claims for unemployment insurance, higher stock prices and a rise in consumer expectations. The two negatives were a decline in the price of materials especially sensitive to the business cycle and a shrinking factory workweek.
But analysts said the index for January, to be reported March 7, was likely to turn negative again.

HEADLINE: Abused Boy Found Dead In the Bronx

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
In unrelated incidents, two Bronx children -- both of whom were taken from city custody and returned to a parent -- became the latest additions to New York City's list of child abuse victims yesterday. One 2-year-old boy was found dead and his father was charged with murder; a 2-year-old girl was raped and her mother and uncle were arrested.
Both victims recently had been under the care of the city's child protection agency, but both had been returned to a natural parent within the last year, according to city officials with knowledge of the cases. It was unclear last night whether the agency had supported returning the children. 
 Nicholas Scoppetta, the Commissioner of the Administration for Children's Services, said investigations of how the city handled both the cases were under way. Mr. Scoppetta said he was uncertain whether the details of either case would be publicly released under the terms of recently enacted legislation relaxing confidentiality restrictions.
The two cases were the latest in a numbing series of abuse incidents that have come to light since the death last November of Elisa Izquierdo, a 6-year-old child whose mother was charged with her slaying. Since the girl's death, the city's child protection agency has been reorganized and put in the hands of Mr. Scoppetta. And in some of the recent cases, the moves in Albany to ease the confidentiality rules have allowed officials to release more details about abuse incidents than they had in the past.
In the death of the 2-year-old yesterday, Anthony Mikell, 43, was arrested and charged with second-degree murder after the police responded to a report of an unconscious child in an apartment in a Mott Haven housing project. The police said Kevin Mikell was found with a dislocated arm, bruises and cigarette burns on his body. The medical examiner's office is to conduct an autopsy today.
James Taylor, a neighbor, said one of the three children living with Mr. Mikell had come to his door around 8 A.M. The child said her baby brother was not moving. Mr. Taylor said he entered the apartment and discovered the child lying under a thin blanket on a day bed in a darkened living room. Mr. Mikell was present and crying, the neighbor said, adding that the father claimed the child had vomited and choked.
But the portrait offered by the police of Kevin Mikell's final 24 hours was a brutally grim one: Bronx detectives said the father had forced the boy to sit for more than 12 hours on the toilet as part of a grotesque training exercise, alternately smacking and feeding the 26-month-old child. At roughly 11 P.M. on Monday night, the detectives said, the father beat the child until he collapsed on the living-room floor. The detectives said the child, with bruises on both sides of his face and his forehead, had been dead for four hours when they arrived shortly after 8 A.M.
The detectives said Mr. Mikell had one prior arrest, a 1987 charge of disorderly conduct and resisting arrest, and they said that in 1994 police officers and child protection agency workers had responded to an incident at the apartment, though they did not offer any details. Detectives added that Mr. Mikell had a hearing impairment and was living on government disability payments.
According to the officials with knowledge of Kevin Mikell's brief life, the child was born on Dec. 18, 1993, and was officially placed in the city's care 10 days later, apparently because of a positive drug test. The officials said the child's mother had a history of drug abuse. Standard procedure in such cases would be to place the child with a foster family.
It was unclear last night who initiated the action to return the child to the father. Officials last night could not rule out the possibility that Mr. Mikell had filed a petition with the courts to retake custody. Any return, however, would have required the input of the city's child protection agency, as well as the approval of a Family Court judge.
Yesterday, Mr. Taylor, as well as another neighbor who often baby-sat for the three children living with Mr. Mikell, said the father was unemployed and living alone. They said Kevin Mikell's mother, Gwendolyn, lived in a shelter and would "come and go" to the apartment. They said that while the apartment was kept in less than ideal shape, they had not seen obvious signs of abuse. The two other children were placed under the city's care yesterday.
"The funny thing is that his little girls were not crying -- they were just so solemn-faced," Mr. Taylor said. "The only one crying was the father. He was crying so loud he was scaring me."
In the other case, in University Heights in the Bronx, the police arrested Melissa Julius and Joseph Julius and charged them in the rape and molestation of Ms. Julius's 2-year-old daughter. The police said yesterday that they initially responded to a 911 call from a woman saying she was being choked by her boyfriend.
After arriving and interviewing the apartment occupants, the police arrested Ms. Julius, 34, and the child's uncle, Mr. Julius, 26. The police said that Mr. Julius had raped and abused the child and that Ms. Julius had known of the assaults and not taken action. She was charged with endangering the welfare of a child.
Ms. Julius, according to the officials familiar with the city's child protection agency's records, is the mother of seven children, all of whom have been placed in foster care at one time or another. The listed reasons for the placements, the officials said, are neglect or abuse, and it appeared that the mother's drug problem was the underlying reason.
Beginning in 1991, the records are said to show, some of the children began to be returned to Ms. Julius. In 1991, two children were returned to her custody. A year later, another child was returned. Early in 1995, one child was adopted by a family, and last March, two children, including the child who the police have charged was abused, were discharged back to Ms. Julius's care. One child remains in foster care.
It could not be determined yesterday what the city's child protection agency's position was on returning the children to a home that agency officials knew to be seriously troubled.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who said earlier this year that the protection of individual children should take precedence over all other concerns, including the reunification of families, said he was aware of both of yesterday's developments.
"I have been informed in both," Mr. Giuliani said. "The agency is going through the facts under the new law to see what they can appropriately disclose."
The city's Public Advocate, Mark Green, whose office conducted a yearlong examination of the city's child protection system, said the rash of recent cases indicated the problem of child abuse appeared to remain out of control.
"Case after case shows that the Child Welfare Administration is dropping the ball when it comes to abused children," Mr. Green said. "While we applaud the appointment of Mr. Scoppetta, it is essential that he submit a timetable for reform. Nothing but a complete overhaul of the agency will help protect our city's children."
