HEADLINE: The Vision Thing, Again

 BODY:
The New Hampshire primary results may teach the Republican Party what the Democrats learned in the era of Walter Mondale -- the Presidency is not a reward for faithful party service. Senator Bob Dole has yet to find a message that means anything to Americans worried about a brand-new set of economic problems. Like Ted Kennedy's disastrous foray in 1980, Mr. Dole's wounded run for President has been defined by his inability even to articulate why he wants the job.
America is bedeviled by growing economic inequality in the midst of plenty. The efficient, post-industrial economy is brutal in the way it separates winners from losers. The bulk of the population, which has less than a college education, is falling further and further behind. This growing income gap is the critical political issue for turn-of-the-century Americans. The Reagan-era policies of low taxes and restrained spending spurred growth, but they supply no comfort. When people are worried about being laid off from their jobs, losing their health care or not being able to give their children a better future, every statistic that shows the economy doing well makes them feel worse. 
 Pat Buchanan's campaign offered a simplistic solution -- higher trade barriers -- that cannily played into voter insecurity. Mr. Buchanan's "conservatism with a heart" combined protectionism with his longtime appeal to the religious right and anti-U.N. paranoia. It served him well in New Hampshire, but it frightened Republican regulars with the prospect of turning the party over to fringe elements. Mr. Buchanan also never took his economic plan beyond hot-button oratory. He has never admitted that high trade barriers would mean higher prices for working-class families, and threaten the livelihood of American workers who produce goods for export. Still, the trade issue hit home, cruelly exposing Senator Dole's lack of any organizing vision for his campaign or the nation.
Mr. Dole originally hoped to slip past the economic issue, confining himself to a stump speech that was a paean to banality. "Like everyone else in this room, I was born," he confided to an election-eve rally. The Senate majority leader contended that his selling point was leadership. But he expressed it with ideas lifted from Newt Gingrich's Contract With America, usually couched in terms that suggested he was trying to submerge himself in the safety of G.O.P.-speak. ("We also believe it's real important to send more power back to the states. . . .")
Lamar Alexander's strong third-place showing may be a reward for the fact that the former Tennessee Governor tries to speak to concern about a rich but inequitable economy. He stresses education, promising to retrain laid-off workers for more sophisticated jobs, and give poor children $1,000 school vouchers. But after months of campaigning in New Hampshire, Mr. Alexander was still best defined by the fact that he was a mainstream Republican who was not Bob Dole. The most innovative sections of his platform were half-baked at best. His welfare plan and scheme to reduce illegal immigrants appeared to have barely gone anywhere near an oven. He will now be tempted to package himself solely as the un-Buchanan.
That would be a mistake. The last Republican nominee, George Bush, was ridiculed for his discomfort with "the vision thing." The New Hampshire campaign revealed that this year's Republican contenders have their own vision problems when it comes to offering real solutions to the next generation of economic issues. Senator Dole last night demonstrated the limits of a platform that fails to go beyond the concept of his Congressional seniority. The voters, meanwhile, are waiting for a candidate with a plan for the economy that lifts all boats, not just the yachts.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE VOTERS;
Down to the Wire, a Clutch Of Candidates and Choices

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: EXETER, N.H., Feb. 20

 BODY:
"I just now made up my mind right there," said Ruth Nottage, gesturing down at the entry threshold of the Town Hall voting precinct here this morning to underline the impetuosity forced upon her by what she decided was a befuddling slate of Republican Presidential contenders.
"I had questions about Dole from the very beginning," the 84-year-old voter said, explaining her last-minute decision, "and I thought, maybe Buchanan, but then I heard last night someone, Newt Gingrich, saying Buchanan would mean the Republicans lose Congress." . 
 "So I guess it'll be good old Dole, " she concluded with considerable resignation. "He had no message that came through, and I thought that was wrong. But, good old Dole it is."
With a sense of duty more pronounced than any motive of overwhelming enthusiasm, New Hampshire voters offered variations on Mrs. Nottage's theme as they trooped to the polls to pick a Presidential choice.
The one candidate who did stir them noticeably, Patrick J. Buchanan, was praised by his supporters for the very certainty of his positions as much as for the issues he pressed.
"He is extreme; that's what the White House needs," said Chuck Marich, a 34-year-old sales representative who voted for Mr. Buchanan. "We need someone drastic to go in there and make some drastic changes."
Supporters of other candidates sounded less certain in explaining their choices.
"We may just be changing the sax for the piano, but I voted for Alexander," said Carol Lynch, an Exeter civic leader, referring to former Gov. Lamar Alexander's resolutely upbeat piano playing on the hustings. "I like him, and his wife, Honey, was terrific on TV the other night.
"I've run in school board politics, so I know how rough campaigning can be, but this campaign did turn me off to Bob Dole. He has gotten mean and dirty with time."
A sense of the candidates being jammed together all the way down the homestretch was clearly reflected in the voting day's muddle of vox pop at election booths across the state. Buchanan voters stood out in emphasizing their candidate's feisty consistency in his views.
"I don't think it's true that he's a racist," said Laura Gustafson, a 26-year-old mental health worker. "He just says what he thinks. He's very honest. He's not like a politician."
Buchanan supporters exulted at their candidate's refusal to split the difference on issues. "It's not a time for moderation," said James Carbonaro, a 38-year-old transplanted New Yorker. "Everyone says he's a right-wing nut, and I'm hoping they're right."
Some of the cited motives were rooted in narrow deduction, like that of a guarded woman who gave her name only as Janet in explaining her vote for the millionaire Steve Forbes: "Only because he certainly isn't in it for the money."
Other motives were downright arcane. "I'm scared to death of Elizabeth Dole," said Bill Drinkwine, a 46-year-old electronics technician from Nashua who voted for Mr. Forbes as an anti-Doles measure.
"I hate what she did at the Red Cross," Mr. Drinkwine said, complaining about a bad blood transfusion and warning that a First Lady Dole would be "in charge of everything."
Some voters searched for resonance with their personal code. "Buchanan's against abortion and against the openness of gays," said Diana Dupont, a housewife from Nashua. "It's time people started putting their morals first."
Others voted by the process of elimination. "I voted for Bob Dole because I thought he was the lesser of two evils, or three or four," Sandra O'Rourke said.
But Mr. Dole was counted out by Eric Robinson because of a lack of a clear message. "If he can't tell us in a primary what he's going to do as President, that's scary," said Mr. Robinson, a 28-year-old unemployed voter. "What's he going to do in the White House?"
Some New Hampshire Democrats, idle this year with President Clinton facing no primary challenge, took advantage of the primary cross-over process and tried to influence the Republican line. "At least this would be someone I could stomach," explained Eric Wilson, a 32-year-old Nashua lawyer after voting for Mr. Alexander in looking forward to a November vote for Mr. Clinton.
Slowly climbing the steps to Exter Town Hall with the aid of a walker, 92-year-old Don Wark would not explicitly announce his vote. "Bob Dole's too old, that's for sure," Mr. Wark did say of the candidate 20 years younger than he. Then Mr. Wark, who has voted in all the state primaries for half a century, alluded to the sheer relativity of the ballot as he smiled and trudged onward: "But maybe Dole's my man. Maybe he's all there is this year."
Right behind came Helen Drazyk who said she had considered Mr. Dole but voted for Mr. Alexander. "It was a mean campaign," Ms. Drazyk said, "and the candidates didn't talk enough about what the people were interested in. Dole showed this time he hasn't got any oomph left. He used to be more peppy."
Ms. Drazyk was not overheard by Elizabeth Dole, who coincidentally showed up at Town Hall to cheer the process on. Mrs. Dole did break into a smile when another voter, Marilyn Purswell, approached and announced, "I just had the privilege of voting for your husband."
"Why, you've warmed my heart," Mrs. Dole replied, and Ms. Purswell explained: "It kind of jelled in the last week for me. Senator Dole can step in on day one into the office of the President and be up to speed. He can work with the Senate and with the Congress and that means a lot."
Dwight Sharp voted here for Mr. Buchanan because of the resolve he communicated in his statements about social and economic resentments. But Mr. Sharp admitted that his candidate might not have the stuff to go all the way onto the November ballot.
As for Mr. Dole, Mr. Sharp said: "I just don't think Dole has the excitement or drive, myself. But if he squeaks through to November, I suppose I'll have to go for him."
Similar reasoning was cited outside a voting booth in Petersborough. "I stood behind Buchanan because I feel he stands for what I believe in," said Donna Migneault, a housewife with three children. "But I think Dole has a better chance to beat Clinton."
Joe Cummings said he was originally for Mr. Dole, but switched to Mr. Alexander as the campaign ended. "Dole is a great bureaucrat," he said, "but he doesn't have the vision you need."
Minnie Crane, a retiree, was straight and to the point. "Bob Dole got my vote," Mrs. Crane said. "I followed him right along and stuck with him, and my A.A.R.P. newsletter showed me he's on the right side of the issues."
Doubt about Mr. Dole was expressed by Bob Kunkel, a World War II veteran who voted for Mr. Buchanan: "Buchanan talks of veterans in terms of what services we need. Dole always talks about the war and himself. He seems egotistical."
As a newcomer to the mix, Mr. Alexander often was talked of by voters for his genial style, rather than his less-known positions on specific issues. But Daniel Gleneck, a computer programmer, said he studied the candidate's plan to end welfare and replace it with local charity and found it "too radical."
Mr. Gleneck, who voted for Mr. Buchanan, said, "Alexander proposed giving everything to the states, and I think this is going too far."
Buchanan voters looked beyond the primary with hope that their candidate not flare out with a bang at the August nominating convention, as he did in 1992. Robert Taylor, a 59-year-old dealer in antiques, said he sensed that this time Mr. Buchanan had he power to go all the way and defeat President Clinton.
"I got to try with my vote," Mr. Taylor said, ultimately as uncertain as any other voter outside the ballot booth.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
BUCHANAN A NARROW VICTOR OVER DOLE IN NEW HAMPSHIRE

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 20

 BODY:
With the whole nation listening intently, New Hampshire roared once more tonight and delivered a stentorian message that promises confusion for the Republican Party for months to come.
This small, remote state, so difficult to please, so prone to surprise, converted Patrick J. Buchanan from a candidate of protest into a front-runner of sorts. After months of grueling work, Mr. Buchanan, Senator Bob Dole and Lamar Alexander established themselves definitively as the prime contenders, finishing very closely bunched. But most politicians were hard pressed to predict how the contest would unfold in the weeks ahead or to guess the outcome. 
 Gov. John Engler of Michigan, a Republican, said pointedly tonight: "There is a long way to go until nomination. This is an intense three-way fight, and it is going to stay that way for a while."
It was, of course, a big night for Mr. Buchanan and a grim one for Mr. Dole. For the first time, it raised the bare possibility that Mr. Buchanan might win the nomination despite the opposition of most of the party's leaders.
At the very least, he seems likely to carry his candidacy right to the convention in August, with disruptive results. If he is rebuffed and his message of economic nationalism rejected, he could run as a populist third-party candidate.
No Republican has won the Presidency since 1952 without first winning the New Hampshire primary. But Republicans like Henry Cabot Lodge in 1964 have won here and failed to win the nomination.
Mr. Buchanan fired up conservatives, which was the main reason for his victory, but none of the three stirred mainstream Republicans and independents. Because of that and the large field, Mr. Buchanan's winning percentage was one of the smallest in the modern era.
Searching, perhaps, for a hero to worship, a third of those interviewed in an exit poll by the television networks and The Associated Press said they would have voted for Gen. Colin L. Powell had his name been on the ballot.
For the Republican Party, the results afforded little cheer. They suggested that the nominating campaign may last considerably longer than expected, with ideological disputes, mudslinging and endless bickering among the candidates on display week after week. The longer a party takes to agree upon a nominee and unite behind him, the more difficulty it tends to face in November.
Above all, the Republicans want to avoid another 1964, when Barry Goldwater snatched the nomination from under the noses of the party leaders but proved far too right-wing for the country and suffered a disastrous defeat.
Mr. Dole has now been tarred by his rivals as a tainted insider, well past his prime. Mr. Buchanan said on television today that the Senator was "in his declining years." The party's traditional backers on Wall Street and in big business have been alarmed by the rasping populism of Mr. Buchanan. The Republican sweep of November 1994 and the Contract With America have all but faded from public view.
Although Mr. Dole suggested that only he and Mr. Buchanan remained viable contenders, it may be that Mr. Alexander, the former Secretary of Education and Governor of Tennessee, gained the most from today's voting. He fought Mr. Dole and Mr. Buchanan on equal terms, easily eclipsed Steve Forbes for third place, ran significantly better than in Iowa and positioned himself well for primaries to come in his home region.
According to the exit poll, he did well among those who said they were looking for a vision of the future, among moderates and among young people. Four in 10 of Mr. Alexander's backers said they had planned at some point to vote for Mr. Dole.
South Carolina, which votes on March 2, just 11 days from now, could prove crucial for Mr. Alexander, as it did for George Bush in 1988, setting him up for the other Southern primaries later.
But Mr. Alexander needs a victory or a strong second-place finish soon. It is difficult to raise money on the strength of third places, and he is starting to run short of cash.
Senator Dole, a political thoroughbred who for the last week has looked more like a spavined old dray horse, failed in this state for the third time. As in Iowa, he took only a bit more than a quarter of the vote here -- far from impressive for a man with an elaborate organization headed by the popular Republican Governor, Stephen Merrill.
The Kansan, a figure of national prominence for a quarter century, failed utterly to generate excitement on the stump. His constituency remains tilted toward the old and the rich, and the exit poll indicated that about a third of the primary participants believed his age would interfere with his ability to serve as President.
He will be 73 years old in November and would be the oldest man ever elected President if he won. But he has more money on hand than anyone, with the exception of Mr. Forbes, and could still prevail in a war of attrition.
Mr. Buchanan was the only full-throated conservative among the major candidates here, owing to the withdrawal of Senator Phil Gramm of Texas. His economic nationalism, including his advocacy of American withdrawal from Nafta and other trade agreements, transformed the agenda in the final days of the New Hampshire campaign. But it appeared to have solidified rather than greatly expanding his base.
Mr. Buchanan, however, remains locked in a tight ideological box.
The conundrum facing him was evident in the exit poll. By taking unyielding positions, he rallied those who described themselves as very conservative, those who identify with the religious right and those who above all were seeking a candidate with backbone. But several of those groups are minorities that are widely resented.
For example, the religious right gave Mr. Buchanan his most stalwart support, but the exit poll showed that more than half of today's primary voters disliked the group.
Mr. Forbes, a political supernova who looked for a time early this month as if he might emerge as Mr. Dole's main challenger, ran fourth for the second consecutive week, and this time he did not challenge Mr. Alexander for third.
"He's gone," said former Gov. Hugh Gregg of New Hampshire, a Dole supporter.
In normal circumstances, Mr. Forbes would be out of the race. But he has enough money and apparently enough ego to keep going, and he has invested heavily in the Delaware primary, which is Saturday, and the Arizona primary next Tuesday. Mr. Dole is a heavy favorite in the voting in North and South Dakota, close to Kansas, which takes place on the same day as Arizona's primary.
Mr. Forbes was unable to capitalize on his advocacy of a flat tax in a state with a phobia about taxes that is unmatched in the United States, perhaps partly because of Mr. Merrill's advertisements condemning the idea. The millionaire publisher took only 4 votes in 10 among those concerned about taxes, and the votes of those who liked the flat tax better than the present system were split four ways.
The other four Republican candidates, including Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, are considered unlikely to press their campaigns beyond New Hampshire.
Most voters, the exit poll showed, kept an open mind until the waning days of the campaign, despite the onslaught of television advertisements, and did not decide how to vote until after the Iowa caucuses on Feb. 12. Four in 10 said they had decided in the last week, but no candidate benefited disproportionately from that.
Eight years ago, George Bush snatched victory from Mr. Dole in the last 72 hours of the campaign. To the mortification of the Kansan, Mr. Buchanan did the same thing to him this year. Mr. Dole had hoped to banish the ghosts of 1988 and all but insure his nomination with a sweeping triumph that never came. Ever laconic, the Senator said tonight that he knew now "why they call this the Granite State -- it's so hard to crack."
Ralph Waldo Emerson, a Massachusetts man, once wrote sourly: "The God who made New Hampshire taunted the lofty land with little men."
New Hampshire has a way of disappointing the famous and powerful.
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The primary day poll was based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left voting stations throughout New Hampshire on Tuesday.
The poll was conducted by Voter News Service, an organization created by ABC News, CBS News, CNN, NBC News and The Associated Press.
The results are based on 2,529 Republican primary voters, in 60 randomly selected precincts across the state.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results from such polls should differ by no more than plus or minus three percentage points from what would have been obtained by seeking to interview all Republican primary voters who turned out in New Hampshire yesterday.
Results based on smaller subgroups have a larger potential sampling error. In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of voter opinion on Election Day may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Giggles Intact, Political Satire Is Back on TV

BYLINE: By CARYN JAMES 

 BODY:
"A lot of Republicans do not see Pat Buchanan as a joke, not any longer," Dan Rather said with high anchorman's seriousness on Tuesday night, not long before CBS projected that Mr. Buchanan would win the Republican primary in New Hampshire. Meanwhile, at the Comedy Central channel, which is covering the Presidential campaign under the banner "Indecision '96," the attitude was pretty much "Speak for yourself, Dan." Everyone from President Clinton to Mr. Buchanan becomes material at Comedy Central, and in an era of numbing press overload its coverage sometimes makes more sense than that of humorless reporters. The channel's standard-bearing talk show, "Politically Incorrect," is almost single-handedly reviving political satire on television.
With the comedian Bill Maher as host, "Politically Incorrect" deftly mixes guests from the world of politics and show biz, and keeps them on track as they discuss everything from gun control to the nature of celebrity. The show has become so successful that it has been snatched up by ABC, where it is to follow "Nightline" next year. It will stay on Comedy Central with new shows through the Presidential election. (It is shown every weeknight at 11, though Monday shows are repeats.) 
 Whether such a show can thrive at ABC is a wide-open question. One reason there is so little sharp political satire on television is that the form requires the freedom to take risks. It's no coincidence that satire on broadcast networks has become tame and unfunny, like the "Weekend Update" segment of "Saturday Night Live." The only truly risky satire is on cable, with "Politically Incorrect" and HBO's even edgier "Dennis Miller Live" (Fridays at 11:30). The economic stakes are lower and the language is looser. Bill Maher and Dennis Miller rely on a bluntness (the words "Buchanan" and "white supremacist" are a popular combination on "Politically Incorrect") that is hard to find anywhere else.
But "Politically Incorrect" has pulled off the rare trick of being irreverent without becoming irrelevant. It does this by using a healthy dose of common sense. The show is at its best when Mr. Maher and his guests don't strain to say outrageous things, but merely express what average viewers might have been thinking.
That approach was hilariously evident on Tuesday, when "Politically Incorrect" broke with its format and featured live reports from Chris Rock (once of "Saturday Night Live") in Manchester. It was after 11, Senator Bob Dole had come in second in the primary and Mr. Maher asked the traditional anchorman's question. "Chris, what's the mood there at Dole headquarters?"
"It's total denial," Mr. Rock answered. "It's like a community college pep rally. You'd think they won." That's exactly what some of us have been waiting years to hear a reporter say about a losing candidate's crowd.
On Tuesday, Mr. Maher had two guests instead of four, "one from the left and one from the right," as he put it, which is usually a bad "Crossfire" idea. Heather Richardson Higgins, from the conservative Progress and Freedom Foundation, was backpedaling hard about Mr. Buchanan's victory, insisting "the Republican party will never let him be the candidate." She was sparring with Al Franken, a master television satirist and author, whose new book, "Rush Limbaugh Is a Big Fat Idiot and Other Observations," is a best seller.
Combining entertainment and political observations, the book shares a satiric sensibility with "Politically Incorrect." The title of Mr. Franken's book lets him have it both ways: he gets a cheap laugh, and also parodies the typically low level of political commentary and humor. (What is the title, after all, except a satiric equivalent of those endless Clinton-at-McDonalds jokes?)
"Politically Incorrect" is more impartial; the Republicans just happen to be slugging it out right now. But it relies on Mr. Maher's savvy sense of when to get serious, when to joke and how to combine the two. The show lives or dies on his quick-witted response to guests.
When "Politically Incorrect" moved from New York to Hollywood last month, there was no significant change; it had always relied too much on celebrity guests. Some of them are smart and funny, some wearyingly sincere and some are just airheads. It is Mr. Maher's job to save them from themselves. When the film director Arthur Hiller turned up in the wearyingly sincere category, slowly intoning against Mr. Dole's attacks on Hollywood, Mr. Maher broke in with a lively, "You go, girl!" But on another show, when the actress Maria Conchita Alonso insisted that scientific tests should be done on convicted rapists instead of innocent bunnies, Mr. Maher found it impossible to regain control.
Sometimes an unlikely mix works. Star Jones, from "Inside Edition," and the actor Michael Gross recently took up the issue of a candidate for the Los Angeles Police Department who was turned down because he admitted to telling a racial joke. The question became: "What's worse? Being racist or dishonest about it?" This kind of lucid discussion would be hard to find on any other show.
It's not a good sign that Al Franken, Chris Rock and Dennis Miller are all refugees from the floundering "Saturday Night Live." When "Politically Incorrect" tries to bring its satire back to the networks, it will find out how far irreverence and common sense can go.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Pepsi Courts Myanmar, Preferring Sales to Politics

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

 BODY:
There are not many countries left where you can't buy a bottle of Pepsi-Cola, so when a suitable business partner turned up in the isolated Southeast Asian nation of Myanmar five years ago, Pepsico was eager to set up a bottling plant.
The timing was awkward, though. Almost three years before, in September 1988, an authoritarian Government with military backing choked off democratic protests that had evolved into an uprising, and the country formerly known as Burma was under tight army control. 
 Myanmar became a target of human rights campaigners, who continue to press for the kind of boycott they say helped bring change in South Africa.
Several American companies have pulled out in recent years. Levi Strauss dropped its contract suppliers in Myanmar three years ago. A spokesman, Michael Woo, said the step grew out of "a very serious review of the social and economic and political environment there as well as health and safety issues, the human rights environment and the possible impact on our brand image."
But Pepsico plunged ahead, thereby casting its vote in a long-running debate between boycott and constructive engagement in countries whose human rights policies fall short of American standards.
It is a debate with continuing implications, as American companies search the world for new places to grow -- and new sources of cheap labor. As they do, they face issues of human rights, exploitative working conditions and child labor.
Myanmar is a vexing case. Seven years after the repression of 1988, the military Government has begun to invitingly open the economy even as it clamps down on political opponents. Manufacturers say that the quality of work is consistently high.
American businesses, often out of self-interest, have argued that economic engagement is the quickest route to democracy, and Pepsico takes that view. "International trade over the long term builds understanding and communication," said Elaine Franklin, Pepsico's spokeswoman, citing the company's presence in the Soviet Union before the collapse of Communism. She said Pepsi had started small in Myanmar, with about $8 million in sales in 1994. But Pepsi was there, as elsewhere, she said, for the long haul.
In its global competition with the Coca-Cola Company, Pepsi has the edge in Myanmar, a nation of perhaps 45 million, though Coke has made a little headway in the north, where a thriving border trade has brought cheap goods from China.
A spokeswoman for Coca-Cola, Kathryn Norton, said that for "strictly business" reasons, the company had no plans to enter Myanmar. "Our policy," she said, "is not to involve ourselves in political matters."
Responding to the argument that companies should not dirty their hands with unsavory governments, Ms. Franklin of Pepsico said, "It is pretty arrogant of any company to decide to make its own foreign policy."
United States policy is neither to encourage nor discourage investment. But political sentiment is increasingly running against Myanmar's Government as it continues to stifle opposition led by the Nobel Peace Prize winner Daw Aung San Suu Kyi -- who has said that foreign companies should "jolly well wait" before doing business in her country.
And indeed, measures that would impose economic boycotts are gaining backers in both houses of Congress, with one in the Senate sponsored by Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky.
The Unocal Corporation, with a 28 percent interest in a $1 billion natural-gas pipeline project in Myanmar, is also moving ahead, despite lobbying by rights groups.
Barry Lane, a Unocal spokesman, said that if his company pulled out, another contractor would almost certainly step in. "What good is it going to do for the people of Myanmar by our not being there?" he asked. "We were in Indonesia when Sukarno was there; he put down some uprisings. But incredible improvements have been made there over the years. In the Philippines, we began under the Marcos regime."
But other companies, primarily clothing makers that can more easily transfer operations from country to country, have pulled out -- some citing moral objections, others for business reasons. In addition to Levi Strauss, these include Eddie Bauer, a unit of Spiegel Inc., and Liz Claiborne.
Levi Strauss has been a pioneer in "socially responsible business practices," issuing a set of guidelines in 1992 for its worldwide operations to insure, in the words of its spokesman, Mr. Woo, that its products "are manufactured in a way that is fair and humane and compassionate."
Typically, standards like these are applied to individual factories or local working conditions. Myanmar is a relatively rare case, in which companies have been forced by public lobbying to consider the human rights record of a government.
With most other companies that have withdrawn, human rights did not appear to concern them as much as the risk of bad publicity.
Eddie Bauer, for example, with 411 stores in North America and contract factories worldwide, pulled out of Myanmar last year to "better guarantee deliveries," a spokeswoman, Cheryl Engstrom, said.
In the past, the company has broken its ties with some foreign suppliers because of poor working conditions. But in Myanmar, Ms. Engstrom said, "it is difficult for us, as customers of a factory, to go outside the walls of that factory and begin making determinations about the status of the country."
Instead, she said, the company is concerned that because of growing opposition by the United States Government and human rights groups, "it would become impossible for us to work in Burma in the future."
Myanmar is flanked by nations eager to trade with it, sharply reducing the impact of withdrawals by Americans. It has not become a case on the scale of apartheid-era South Africa, where an international boycott helped end white-minority rule.
As of the last fiscal year, the United States accounted for just 8 percent of the $2.65 billion in investment commitments to Myanmar, with France, Britain, Thailand and Singapore providing most of the rest. China's vigorous cross-border trade is helping to spur the involvement of Southeast Asian nations, which do not want to cede influence to Beijing, the region's giant.
Still, backers of a boycott emphasize human rights concerns. "A lot of people have the attitude that business is business," said Matthew Donohue, a lobbyist with the Burma Action Committee, based in Portland, Ore. "But this is business that by being transacted is directly contributing to arrests and repression."
That is the sort of thing people will "have to start confronting as we move into the global economy," Mr. Donohue added. "We are going to have to assume some responsibility for the effects of the dollars we spend if we are going to consider ourselves to have the kind of moral fiber that traditionally the United States has held."

HEADLINE: The G.O.P.'s Extremism Debate

 BODY:
The famed Eleventh Commandment popularized by Ronald Reagan ("Thou shalt not speak ill of fellow Republicans") takes a beating in most primary campaigns. But not since the Goldwater-Rockefeller contest of 1964 has it been so quickly broken as in this primary season. Following Pat Buchanan's victory in New Hampshire, Bob Dole, Lamar Alexander and the Congressional leadership immediately resorted to the G.O.P.'s rhetorical equivalent of a tactical nuclear weapon against Mr. Buchanan by labeling him an extremist.
The word has been anathema among Republicans because so many of the party's candidates, starting with Barry Goldwater and including Richard Nixon, Ronald Reagan and George Bush, flirted with extremism in their courtship of such factions as the Red-baiters, Southern segregationists, anti-abortionists and religious fundamentalists. Mr. Buchanan is not flirting with extremism so much as dancing with it. He has elevated the taking of far-out positions stated in inflammatory language from an occasional tactic to a constant strategy. 
 Senator Dole led the attack, declaring yesterday that "this is now a race between the mainstream and the extreme" and that Republicans must now decide whether theirs is a "party that keeps people out or brings people in." By implication, he denounced Mr. Buchanan as a "protectionist," an "isolationist," a "fringe candidate" and a "polarizer." Mr. Alexander and his enforcer, Bill Bennett, are using similar language. Last night, Colin Powell said he could not support Mr. Buchanan as the nominee. Mr. Buchanan has dismissed his opponents' comments as the "cuss words of a dying Establishment," while he wowed his ragtag audiences with an image of "peasants with pitchforks" marching on the castle.
Right now the Republican leaders are less worried about pitchforks and protectionism than about a Goldwater-sized defeat in November. If they truly wish to head that off, they should continue to confront Mr. Buchanan over the spirit and shape of their party.
The fine line between being a spokesman for the oppressed and a front man for the dark heart of American bigotry can be a narrow one. In a country as heterogeneous as America, where the economic system dictates that some people will be deemed winners and others losers, there will always be a lot of anger bubbling around the bottom of the melting pot. Hot-button orators like Mr. Buchanan have a particular obligation to make it clear what kinds of behavior and allies they will not tolerate. With his refusal to disown extremist aides and fringe organizations, Mr. Buchanan has shown a tendency to confuse building a "big tent" with sheltering a mob.
For all that, he is the most exciting stump campaigner since the 1980 Reagan race. He is witty, and in the somnolent Mr. Dole and the strait-laced Mr. Alexander, fate has provided him the perfect foils. But Mr. Buchanan is also dangerous, both to the Republican chances of winning the White House and holding the Congress, and to the future of his party.
He is a creature of the storm who is gaining strength because yesterday's consensus front-runner looks more and more like an extinct volcano. Mr. Dole spoke almost wistfully of wanting the G.O.P. to be "the best party in this country, not the narrowest party in this country." By definition that would be a party that attends to the issues of economic justice highlighted by Mr. Buchanan, but does not indulge in his demagogic appeals to those who flirt with repression, bigotry and violence.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls vs. Yen as Rumors Of Intervention Do Not Pan Out

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar slumped against the yen yesterday on signs that the Japanese central bank had not forcefully intervened on the American currency's behalf.
While there were reports that the Japanese were in the market buying dollars, some traders said that effort had no discernible effect, and the bank does not comment on its market activities. 
 On Tuesday, the dollar surged against the yen in Asian trading on reports that the Japanese were buying dollars and on an announcement that Singapore and Hong Kong monetary authorities had agreed to cooperate with Japan in foreign-exchange markets. The dollar retreated late Monday, and yesterday the retreat turned into a loss when no further intervention materialized.
"People bought dollars anticipating the Bank of Japan didn't want it falling and would intervene," said John McCarthy, foreign-exchange manager at ING Capital Markets. "When the B.O.J. didn't come in, it got dicey for the dollar."
Japan wants a weaker yen to make its exports more competitive, bolstering the sluggish economy.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar fell to 104.98 yen from 105.75 yen on Tuesday. But the dollar rose to 1.4499 marks from 1.4473 marks. The British pound fell to $1.5430 from $1.5450.
The dollar received some support from United States stock markets, which rallied yesterday after recent losses. And the Treasury bond market, particularly hard hit on Tuesday, reversed course, making modest gains.
"The dollar is strongly correlated to U.S. stocks and bonds," said Karl Halligan, a currency trader at CIC Bank in New York. "At the moment, bonds are O.K. so the dollar is, too."
The possibility of further Bank of Japan buying is still buttressing the dollar, traders said. "The market perceives that the B.O.J. has an interest below 105 yen, so that's dollar-supportive," said Dan O'Connell, a currency salesman with the First National Bank of Chicago.
The dollar may also be benefiting from the Japanese bank's determination to keep interest rates low to help the economy pull out of its doldrums, said Wayne Grigull, managing director of foreign exchange at Merrill Lynch. "The B.O.J. has gone to great lengths to assure the market that rates will stay low, and that should continue to support the dollar against the yen," he said.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Heating Oil Prices Rise Sharply On Concerns Over Low Supply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Heating oil prices surged yesterday, while gold staged a modest recovery.
On other markets, lumber prices tumbled for the third consecutive session. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities rose 0.29 point, to 249.93. 
 Heating oil prices rose on expectations that heating oil stocks would drop another 5 million barrels, to two-year lows, with almost a month of winter remaining, said Tim Evans, an analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group.
Heating oil for March delivery rose 2.45 cents, to 58.84 cents a gallon, the highest since it settled at 59.59 cents on Jan. 10. The April crude oil contract, trading as the active contract for the first time, rose to $20 a barrel, but settled with a 44-cent gain at $19.71 a barrel. On Tuesday, the expiring March contract had its sharpest price jump since the Persian Gulf war.
Investors expected the American Petroleum Institute to report after the market closed that stocks of American heating oil and other distillate fuels fell 3 million to 5 million barrels after cold weather last week in the Northeast and Midwest, the nation's largest heating regions. The institute later reported that stockpiles fell last week by 3.9 million barrels, to 103.3 million barrels, the lowest level since April 3, 1994.
The smaller supplies have forced industries and others to pay premium prices for distillates on the cash markets.
Gold prices rose amid renewed expectations the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates soon. Lower interest rates would make gold more competitive with other investments. The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, in remarks to the Senate Banking Committee yesterday, left open the possibility of further rate reductions. A day earlier, he appeared to rule out rate cuts in the short term.
"The single most important thing for gold right now is interest rates," said Dinsa Mehta, senior chief bullion trader at Chase Manhattan. Prices were underpinned by continued declining production in South Africa. The nation's gold production is expected to fall to 416 tons in 1997, its lowest output since 1955, South African officials said.
April gold rose $2.90, to $404 an ounce, at the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A California initiative would put lawyers to the free-market test.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
SO, who are the good guys in California's battle over limiting legal fees in civil suits? "Consumer attorneys," according to the ads now saturating local television in the Golden State -- the ones "who get unsafe automobiles off the road, protect people's retirement savings from investment frauds and force polluters to pay for cleaning up their poisonous waste."
Who, then, are the bad guys? Check the web site of the Consumer Attorneys of California (http:// www.seamless.com/consumer) for a list of the Silicon Valley movers and shakers underwriting Proposition 202, the initiative on the March 26 ballot that would cap lawyers' fees at 15 percent of the settlement in uncontested cases. Those with remaining doubts need only click on the web site's photo of the locked front gate of Tom Proulx's mansion -- presumably ill-gotten gains that Mr. Proulx, the founder of the Intuit software company and a leading promoter of Proposition 202, hopes to shelter from the wrath of the masses. 
 But you may not wish to rush to judgment. For Proposition 202 is modeled after a contingency fee reform proposal that has drawn support from liberal legal luminaries ranging from Erwin Griswold, the late dean of the Harvard Law School, to Robert Pitofsky, the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission. And a close look suggests that apart from the vested interests at stake, the core question issue here is whether a free market can deliver legal services at competitive prices.
Proposition 202, one of three ballot initiatives that would radically change the rules for civil suits in California, regulates contingency fees. Typically, individuals suing for damages hire lawyers for a share of the court award or settlement, ranging from one-third to one-half. The advantage of this arrangement is that it doesn't take a deep pocket to go to court, providing the plaintiff can find a lawyer who thinks the case is worth the gamble.
If the market worked according to Adam Smith, however, one would expect the percentage fee to vary with the size and likelihood of the payout. In fact, contingency fees are almost never below one-third, even in cases that produce six- or seven-figure settlements after a brief negotiation. And Lester Brickman, a specialist in contingency fees at the Cardozo Law School at Yeshiva University in New York, thinks he knows why. "Lawyers hardly ever compete over price," he says. "Have you ever seen an ad for a lawyer that even mentioned the size of the fee?"
Proposition 202 would require a plaintiff's lawyer to solicit a settlement offer from the defendant. If the defendant made an offer within 60 days that was acceptable to the plaintiff, the lawyer's fee would be capped at 15 percent. If the defendant ignored the solicitation, there would be no restriction on the fee a lawyer could demand to pursue the case. But if an offer were made and the plaintiff rejected it, his lawyer could only reap bigger contingency payments on awards that exceeded the original offer.
Say a defendant's insurance company offers to settle for $100,000 and the plaintiff nonetheless decides to go to court, where he wins a judgment of $150,000. The plaintiff lawyer's fee would be capped at 15 percent of the first $100,000, plus whatever split he had negotiated with his client on the next $50,000.
Cases would be settled earlier, predicts Professor Brickman, and less of the proceeds would go to lawyers. More important, risks and fees would be linked in a logical way. "The premium for contingency," wrote Supreme Court Justice Harry Blackmun in 1987, "compensates for the risk of nonpayment if the suit does not succeed."
The fee cap would, no doubt, change the relationship between client and lawyer. Louis Storrow, a plaintiff lawyer in Carlsbad, Calif., who opposes the initiative, argues that it would create a "wedge between the client's interest and the attorney's interest." It would give lawyers an incentive, he contends, to press for quick settlements so they could collect an easy 15 percent and go onto the next case.
But Professor Brickman notes there is an inherent division of interest between lawyers and their clients, no matter how the fee is structured: hourly fees, the norm for lawyers in most other circumstances, create incentives to sell more services than necessary. And very few people in the market for legal help have the information needed to keep their lawyers on short leashes. Better, then, he suggests, to push the bias toward less protracted skirmishes using fewer legal resources.
For those who suspect that Proposition 202 amounts to a conspiracy against consumers, it may be reassuring that the lawyers who represent corporations -- California's Association of Defense Counsel -- oppose the ballot measure, too. "The initiative process is an unwieldy mechanism, at best, to enact complex laws," explains Julia Molander, a San Francisco defense lawyer.
The one thing everyone agrees on, it seems, is that Proposition 202 means less business for lawyers. And what's so bad about that?

HEADLINE: My Spy Story

BYLINE: By Frank Smyth; Frank Smyth has written for Foreign Affairs and other journals.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
After several days in a prison near Baghdad in 1991, I was told "they" wanted to see me. Blindfolded, I was led into a room where, judging from the voices, there were at least half a dozen men. For days, I had heard and sometimes watched as guards beat and tortured Iraqi prisoners.
The translator asked what my "real job" was. "I'm a reporter" for The Village Voice and CBS News Radio, I said. He translated my response in Arabic. I heard the reply from a man whose voice sounded older and less sympathetic. "You're lying," the translator echoed in English. "Tell us about your relationship with the C.I.A." I had none. 
 The interrogation lasted two hours. I was not abused. The Iraqis found me guilty of entering their country without a visa: I had admitted sneaking in from Syria after the Persian Gulf war with Kurdish guerrillas who wanted to overthrow President Saddam Hussein. As for the charge of being a C.I.A. agent, I remained "under suspicion," I was told. A week later, Iraq let me leave.
Last week, a blue-ribbon panel, sponsored by the Council on Foreign Relations, proposed repealing a 19-year policy that prevents C.I.A. agents from posing as representatives of the working press.
Part of the panel's rationale is that the C.I.A.'s use of American embassies as a cover won't wash any longer. Skeptical foreign officials are asking why an embassy that issues relatively few visas has so many consular officials, why the political section has doubled in size or whether that new department is really doing economic research.
The panel director, Richard N. Haass, a former member of the National Security Council, asks whether precluding the use of journalism as a cover "is a luxury the United States can still afford." (Leslie H. Gelb, a former New York Times columnist who is president of the Council on Foreign Relations, disagrees with the proposal.)
 The C.I.A. supposedly terminated the practice in 1977, but last month the agency admitted that the practice has continued -- on extraordinarily rare occasions, it says.
If the Iraqis had been aware of this during the war, any of the 47 or so journalists picked up and held by authorities might not have come back. (One didn't: Gad Gross, a freelance photographer, was executed minutes after soldiers captured him.)
If agents began regularly passing themselves off as reporters again, governments around the globe could easily accuse almost any American reporter of being a C.I.A. plant. The burden of proof would fall on the journalist to demonstrate that he or she is not a spy.
The council's proposal, if adopted, would make it easy for any hostile official who fears inquiries by the foreign press to accuse reporters of being spies. The most probing reporters may well be denied entry or expelled.
The council's panel concluded that if spooks could get press credentials, the C.I.A. would be more effective. But many academics and policy makers seem to agree that the information available in the media is often as good as, if not better than, that found in classified C.I.A. documents. Aren't many offices in the Pentagon and elsewhere always tuned to CNN?
Allowing C.I.A. agents to pose as journalists not only needlessly puts reporters at risk but also undermines their ability to report foreign news properly or at all, limiting the information available to policy makers and the public. Instead of rehabilitating this passe cold war practice, the C.I.A. should be ordered to end it for real.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
The cruise industry is moving toward more campaigns in the face of declining business.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
INDIVIDUAL cruise lines are advertising more than ever. And if the industry as a group can reconcile the conceptual and financial differences, another $10 million in ads will come onto the airwaves in each of the next three years.
The proposed industry campaign is motivated largely by something the industry never planned on -- the sudden end to years of unbroken growth, which from 1970 through 1993 averaged 10 percent a year compounded. But in 1994 the number of passengers fell a little, by one-half 1 percent, and preliminary figures indicate a falloff of as much as 3 percent last year. 
 To stem the erosion this year, when seven new ships will add 13,000 berths, the 26-member Cruise Lines International Association invited bids on a campaign to spend a minimum of $30 million over the next three years. It is meant to tout the value of cruise vacations and to attract first-time passengers. That latter goal is especially important, because association research shows that only 8 percent of Americans have ever been on a cruise.
After selecting 10 agencies early last December, the association narrowed the list to two by the end of the year: Harris Drury Cohen of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners of New York. A final selection was expected this month, after both agencies made presentations before the cruise line association's managing committee in late January.
But the decision was postponed, at least until the next committee meeting in June, when the expected harmony foundered over how much each cruise line would contribute to the ad campaign and over whether to seek financing from a cooperative partner, such as a credit card company. There was even apparent disagreement over the direction the proposed campaign should take.
"The management committee liked the presentations," said James G. Godsman, president of the association, "but they suggested a number of refinements to make them acceptable to all the members." He added that he expected adoption of an ad campaign in June, but acknowledged that it would miss the prime summer cruise season and possibly next fall as well. However, some cruise officials doubt that the campaign -- the largest in cruise line history -- will ever be put into effect.
Whether it is or is not, individual lines are spending millions of dollars promoting their new ships, because some of them are now big enough to benefit from economies of scale.
Overseas Shipholding Group's Celebrity Cruises, for example, which launched the Century (1,750 passengers) last December and will launch an equally big liner in both December 1996 and December 1997, is advertising on television for the first time.
"We are increasing the advertising budget by 50 percent over last year," said Al Wallack, senior vice president of marketing and passenger services, "with the incremental monies being put into broadcast -- specifically, national cable and targeted broadcast." That campaign, began Jan. 6, will continue throughout the year.
Royal Caribbean introduced the Legend of the Seas last April and will add two new ships this year, two in 1997 and one in 1998 -- all six of them big enough to carry 1,800 to 2,000 passengers. Accordingly, the cruise line increased its advertising budget by 6 to 7 percent this year, to about $40 million -- half in network television, 25 percent in newspapers and the remainder in consumer and travel trade magazines.
"We've also invested about $1 million in creating and staffing our new web site," said Rod McLeod, the head of sales, marketing and passenger services.
Carnival's Holland America, which has doubled its fleet to eight ships in the last four years, is running two campaigns. The first, directed at travel agents, features ads in trade publications from last September through this April. The campaign is partly intended to welcome the M.S. Veendam, scheduled for delivery on April 30.
The other campaign, the biggest television advertising campaign in Holland America's history, is on network and cable channels and will continue all year. Developed by Omnicom Group's Elgin Syferd/DDB Needham of Seattle, the commercials were shot aboard the M.S. Statendam using an 85-foot telescopic crane with a 35-millimeter motion picture camera attached -- a feature that allowed for close-ups and panoramic shots of the ship in one sweeping motion.
Carnival Cruise Lines, the industry giant, is running a multimillion-dollar campaign in People magazine, from Jan. 29 through Nov. 25. Carnival's first magazine ad purchase since 1990, and the biggest media buy placed exclusively in People, which is owned by Time Warner, the campaign was created by HMV/ McFarland & Drier of Miami. It will consist of 38 full-page spreads and 19 different ads, each of which asks (and presumes to answer), "What's your idea of fun?"

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Rise in Price, Ending Slide

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
What a difference a day makes.
Treasury prices rose slightly yesterday, halting a four-day slide. Market participants were encouraged by comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, whose remarks on Tuesday had disappointed those betting on a cut in short-term interest rates. 
 While the comments of Mr. Greenspan yesterday did not differ significantly from his testimony on Tuesday, market participants reconsidered the Fed chairman's words in a more positive light.
"The Fed chairman must have had trouble sleeping last night, because he sounded a little more conciliatory today," said Jack Ablin, director of fixed-income and senior fund manager at the Private Bank at Bank of Boston.
Appearing before the Senate Banking Committee yesterday, Mr. Greenspan said that since the economy rarely faced more than a 50 percent chance of recession he was generally inclined to think it would forge ahead.
His comments suggested to market participants that a rate cut could still come soon if inflation remained subdued.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 11/32 yesterday, to 95 3/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.37 percent, from 6.40 percent on Tuesday.
On Tuesday, the price of the long bond tumbled 2 points. While the Treasury market had been soft in previous sessions because of concerns over supply and because of selling by large hedge funds unwinding yen-financed trades, Mr. Greenspan's testimony that day accelerated the market's decline.
Still, Mr. Ablin of the Private Bank noted the Fed chairman's comments on Tuesday were "still consistent with his overall strategy and that is to have more flexibility going forward by characterizing the economy as better than the market perceives."
The reaction by the market to Mr. Greenspan, Mr. Ablin said, reflected in part its anxiety over delays in data caused by the Government's recent partial shutdown.
"Part of the problem is that market was relying on his intake, since conventional wisdom tells us that the chairman has sources of information that are perhaps unavailable to the market in general," Mr. Ablin said.
In other market activity, the Treasury announced that it would sell $18.25 billion of new two- and five-year notes at auction next Tuesday and Wednesday. In when-issued trading yesterday, the new two-year notes were being offered at a price to yield 5.15 percent and the five-year notes at a price to yield 5.54 percent.
Today, the Treasury is selling $29 billion of 55-day cash management bills. The Government often sells the cash management bills to meet cash flow shortages when it has interest and principal payments.
In the corporate sector of the market, J. P. Morgan was the lead underwriter in GE Global Insurance's first bond offering. It is the largest long-bond offering for an insurance company. The $600 million sale of 7 percent fixed-rate notes due in 2026 was priced at 99.05, to yield 7.077 percent, or about 64 basis points more than a Treasury security with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In the futures market, which often has an impact on the cash Treasury market, the March 30-year bond contract closed at a price of 116 5/32, after hitting a high of 116 29/32.
Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst with Thomson Research of Boston, said that "the long-term uptrend had reached a critical juncture at a price of 115 20/32 on the March contract."
"The initial reaction off this level yesterday showed there was an extreme interest in buying at this price point, as the market opened a full point higher in early trading," she said.

HEADLINE: What Buchanan Owes Clinton

BYLINE: By Jagdish Bhagwati; Jagdish Bhagwati, a professor of economics at Columbia, is the author of "Protectionism."

 BODY:
Patrick J. Buchanan's stump speeches calling for trade protectionism have taken on a life of their own even though they have been denounced by most mainstream policy wonks and politicians. He has used the issue to win the New Hampshire primary and has found that even Senator Bob Dole has borrowed part of his platform.
Yet Mr. Buchanan's specific prescriptions owe much to those very wonks and politicians -- many in the Clinton Administration -- who find his agenda appalling. He found the ammunition for his campaign without difficulty in his opponents' backyards. 
 Mr. Buchanan thinks that Japan is an unfair trader. His prescription: Bash it with 10 percent tariffs on every Japanese import.
I have a sense not of outrage but of deja vu. James Fallows once wrote a pair of influential articles in The Atlantic Monthly urging the "containment" of Japan. Among his remedies: precisely the retaliatory tariff that Mr. Buchanan espouses!
And Mr. Fallows's idea was not new. It had been suggested by Rudiger Dornbusch, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist.
Their conviction that Japan was an exclusionary importer and a predatory exporter has since been shared by other left-of-center journalists, including Robert Kuttner of The American Prospect and Michael Lind and John Judis of The New Republic.
As a Presidential candidate, Bill Clinton sought votes by catering to this prejudice. His platform, "Putting People First," promised legislation that would permit us to name Japan an "unfair trader" and to unleash retaliatory tariffs against it.
As President-elect, he appointed economists such as Laura Tyson, head of the National Economic Council, who shared these views. Unsurprisingly, Washington's think tanks suddenly had surprising converts to the cause of punitive tariffs against Japan.
But the get-tough policy with Japan failed miserably. The February 1994 summit meeting between Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa and President Clinton in Washington collapsed over our demands that Japan meet numerical import targets in specific sectors.
So did the May 1995 automobile trade talks. President Clinton threatened punitive tariffs on 13 models of Japanese luxury cars. In the end, he capitulated, with only a few paltry face-saving "concessions" from the Japanese.
Thanks to a passive press, somehow these failures turned into public relations successes. And the politics seemed to work to President Clinton's advantage. The thought that Japan-bashing pays politically could not have escaped Mr. Buchanan. He simply is much more forthright about it.
Such bashing is not the only element of his protectionism that derives from mainstream ideas. He also opposes the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and the World Trade Organization, multilateral trade agreements first opposed by environmental and labor groups.
These groups first vilified the GATT as Gatt-zilla. They may shudder at Mr. Buchanan's prominence now, but he has taken their issues and turned them into a Presidential campaign.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE UNIONS;
Labor Leader Calls Buchanan Workers' Enemy

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 21

 BODY:
A day after Patrick J. Buchanan won the New Hampshire primary by campaigning as a champion of workers' concerns, the leader of the American labor movement denounced the Republican candidate as racist, anti-Semitic and opposed to the interests of American workers.
John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., asserted that Mr. Buchanan only pretended to be a friend of workers, saying the candidate not only wanted to weaken occupational safety rules but also opposed an increase to the minimum wage and laws that would make it easier for workers to join unions. 
 "Saying Patrick Buchanan speaks for workers is like saying the Ayatollah Khomeini speaks for priests and rabbis," Mr. Sweeney said today at a meeting of the A.F.L.-C.I.O executive council here. "I don't think working Americans are going to be fooled by a Presidential candidate who talks the talk, but won't walk the walk."
Mr. Sweeney spearheaded a coordinated attack on Mr. Buchanan by union leaders here, with many of them voicing frustration and anger that the candidate had stolen labor's oratory to appear as the advocate of millions of workers who are anxious about falling wages and layoffs.
Steven Rosenthal, the A.F.L.-C.I.O political director, said: "It's like a wolf in sheep's clothing. He wants American workers to think he has the answers. But he has not put forward one proposal that's good for American workers."
Mr. Sweeney faulted Mr. Buchanan for embracing the same economic theories advocated by President Ronald Reagan, which the labor leader said "have transferred billions of dollars from the tattered pocketbooks of middle-income Americans to the silk-lined purses of the rich over the past 15 years."
"Patrick Buchanan is a racist, he's anti-Semitic, he bashes women right along with labor and immigration, and he's a believer in supply-side economics," Mr. Sweeney asserted. "We are none of those things."
At a breakfast with reporters on Monday, Mr. Sweeney said he broadly agreed with Mr. Buchanan's calls for scrapping the North American Free Trade Agreement and the World Trade Organization. But today, he distanced himself from Mr. Buchanan on trade, saying that unlike the Republican the federation favored open markets and that it opposed Nafta for reasons different from Mr. Buchanan's.
"Expanding our exports means good jobs, and we're for it," he said. "But we have to demand that we are not discriminated against in foreign markets."
At their meeting today, the executive council's 54 members approved the federation's most ambitious campaign plans ever, vowing to raise $35 million to educate Americans on pro-union issues and help Democratic House candidates.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Says Further Cut in Rates Is Possible

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Helping to calm jittery financial markets, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told the Senate Banking Committee today that further rate cuts are possible as long as inflation stays low.
While Mr. Greenspan's overall testimony was little different from his statements that spooked the markets on Tuesday, investors nonetheless seized on the Fed chairman's comments today to bid up both bond and stock prices. 
 "The most probable outcome is coming out of this soft patch into moderate growth with low inflation," Mr. Greenspan said. But if the economy fails to improve as expected, Mr. Greenspan indicated that the Fed stood ready to respond with further stimulus.
"If we envisage that inflationary pressures are significantly subdued, it would not be inconsistent to move rates lower, as we did on Jan. 31," he said.
Analysts suggested that Mr. Greenspan, aware of how closely his comments are followed, may have been playing to the markets after the negative assessment of his remarks to a House subcommittee the day before in which he described the economy as "on track for sustained growth." Many investors took that to mean that the easing of monetary policy they had been counting on was less likely to happen soon.
Paul L. Kasriel, chief domestic economist for the Northern Trust Company, said that Mr. Greenspan said similar things both days but that on Tuesday he neglected to say the more or less obvious -- that the economy's condition might still allow for another round of rate cuts.
Indeed, Mr. Greenspan's statement today that the economy is "going through a significant soft patch," was remarkably similar to Tuesday's characterization of "soft" conditions that would likely prove temporary.
"Luckily he got another chance today," Mr. Kasriel said.
John R. Williams, a senior economist at Bankers Trust, echoed those comments, saying that it would be a mistake to regard Mr. Greenspan's confidence about the economy's underlying health as ruling out rate cuts should conditions dictate.
Mr. Greenspan also took the opportunity to comment in an unusually direct way on the market swing, attributing the slump in the bond market in the last week to a growing fear that Congress and the Clinton Administration would fail to reach a budget agreement, rather than as a signal that inflation was picking up.
Ebbing of budgetary resolve, Mr. Greenspan told the committee, was "to a large extent" the reason for the bond market deterioration.
Without identifying any other specific factors, he also referred to the possibility that both bonds and gold prices might be reacting to what many investment professionals believe to be the political ascendancy of Patrick J. Buchanan.
Much of Wall Street worries not only about Mr. Buchanan's protectionist attitude toward trade but the prospect that his strong showing increases the re-election prospects of President Clinton.
Enlarging on comments he made Tuesday, Mr. Greenspan expressed skepticism about President Clinton's suggestion that the rapid spread of information and other technology has markedly raised the economy's ability to grow faster without re-igniting inflation.
Mr. Greenspan said one problem was that it took some time for new technology to show up in increased national productivity -- the only source of growth other than an expanding work force -- because much of it does not mesh with the infrastructure to which it is applied. He cited as an example the invention of the electric motor, which was well developed in the late 19th century but that did not produce dramatic productivity gains until companies fully harnessed it in the 1920's.
Another reason to be cautious, Mr. Greenspan said, is a lack of enough people trained in the use of the new technology, which is refined so quickly that even skilled workers become anxious about their jobs.
Until the fruits of technology became statistically evident, Mr. Greenspan said, it would be too risky to base policy on its supposed contribution to a rising standard of living.
Without mentioning Mr. Buchanan or anyone else in the Republican Presidential field by name, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, who left the race after the Iowa caucuses, lobbed Mr. Greenspan a question about protectionism and the chairman said it was "the last thing" one would do if the goal was to raise productivity. This is because putting tariffs or quotas on foreign goods reduces competition at home, he said.
"When I was in the private sector I hated competition," said the one-time New York economic consultant. But, he said, "I recognized that it made me work better."
Senator Paul Sarbanes, a liberal Democrat from Maryland, pressed Mr. Greenspan to take out some additional "insurance" against an economic downturn, reminding the Fed chairman that he saw no recession in August or October of 1990 even though it was subsequently determined that a mild recession had already begun in July of that year.
Mr. Greenspan responded by saying he defined "recession" somewhat more rigorously to refer to a period in which there is a "tearing" of the fabric of economic relations that induces "implosion" or a decline that feeds on itself, a condition he said was not apparent in the summer of 1990.

HEADLINE: Sears Moves To Shed Stake In Prodigy

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
And now it is Prodigy's turn.
In the latest sign of upheaval in the computer on-line industry, Prodigy Services, the nation's third-largest consumer on-line information service, was put up for sale yesterday -- at least the half owned by Sears, Roebuck & Company. I.B.M., Sears's longtime partner in Prodigy, declined to comment on its own plans for the service, which has 1.7 million subscribers. 
 Sears's move came just a day after H & R Block Inc. announced it planned to spin off its Compuserve division, the second-largest service.
It might seem odd that these market leaders would want to leave the field, in light of phenomenal growth that saw total on-line subscribers in the United States nearly double last year, to 11.3 million. But with the market booming, analysts say, now may be the best time to sell out for companies not fully committed to the increasingly competitive and volatile business of putting consumers in cyberspace.
Sears, which analysts say had pumped about $600 million into Prodigy, indicated yesterday that it remained a retailer first and foremost, and H & R Block said on Tuesday that it wanted to focus on its tax-return business.
America Online Inc., the country's largest on-line service, with more than five million subscribers, has no other lines of business. But even it has been forced to scramble full time to keep up with the needs of increasingly sophisticated, ever- more-demanding consumers. Among other changes, America Online recently set up a separate company to provide direct connections to the global Internet for subscribers who choose to bypass America Online's own, proprietary lineup of information and entertainment services, discussion groups and other offerings.
As hardly a week goes by without a new alliance, acquisition or rumor of yet another change in the on-line industry, analysts acknowledge that the millions of Americans with computers and modems could become confused. But the upheaval, driven by competition, will ultimately be good for consumers, many analysts say.
"There's an ever-increasing number of options for consumers, in both the on-line services and the Internet," said Adam Schoenfeld, vice president of Jupiter Communications Inc., a research company specializing in Internet and on-line businesses. "The breakneck pace of innovation will lead to lower prices and more variety."
And what happens if your on-line company should change owners or disappear altogether? "I don't think users should concern themselves with the business tribulations of these companies," Mr. Schoenfeld said. "If your company goes out of the business, there are plenty of others waiting to take you."
But certainly, the on-line lineup is in flux. Since the beginning of this year, Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation has effectively shelved what was left of the former Delphi on-line service; AT&T has pulled the plug on its Interchange Network; the General Electric Company has unloaded its Genie service; Apple Computer Inc. said it was re-evaluating its support for eWorld, and the Microsoft Corporation told developers of information services for its Microsoft Network to redirect their efforts and create offerings for the World Wide Web.
Analysts cite a variety of reasons for the tumult, including intense competition, the high cost of development, competition from Internet access providers who bypass consumer services like Prodigy and America Online, and recent passage of the Telecommunications Act of 1996.
"It's not a coincidence that these announcements happened right after the passage of the telecom bill," said Rod Kuckro, editor of the Information & Interactive Services Report.
The Telecommunications Act, recently signed by President Clinton, allows the big telephone and communications companies to expand beyond their traditional businesses and begin developing their own on-line information services.
"It's cheaper to buy a system with established customers than it is to build one from scratch, and the only companies that can afford to buy a stake in these on-line services and develop their infrastructure are the big telecom companies," Mr. Kuckro said. AT&T has been rumored to be a possible buyer of Sears's share of Prodigy.
Mr. Kuckro also noted the attractive demographic profiles of on-line service subscribers, who tend to be affluent and well educated -- people who are likely to buy advanced telecommunications services.
"Prodigy does not fit into Sears's long-term strategy for growth," Arthur C. Martinez, chairman and chief executive of the world's second-largest retailer, told financial analysts in New York yesterday.
Executives from both Sears and I.B.M. praised the evolution of Prodigy under its chief executive, Edward Bennett, a former cable TV executive at Viacom Inc. who was hired last year by Prodigy. Mr. Bennett made Prodigy the first of the big on-line services to offer its subscribers access to the Internet and the World Wide Web, an Internet service that reduces formerly complex computer commands to a point-and-click navigational system.
Since 1993, when the Internet's World Wide Web service suddenly became popular, analysts have been suggesting that the wide-open, global Web would overtake and overwhelm the smaller, proprietary services like Compuserve and Prodigy. The consumer services differ from the Internet in that they require special software, unique to each service, to tap into that service's private data bases of news, features, discussion groups and other on-line offerings.
Even with the Web, though, many analysts say the Internet is still too difficult to use. Services like Prodigy, Compuserve and America Online hide the Internet's complexity behind their own, easy-to-use software and back it with customer support systems that the Internet lacks.
"We remain convinced that the most compelling choice for the mass-market consumer is still on-line services," Brian C. Oakes, an analyst with J. P. Morgan Securities Inc., wrote to investors last month.
Sears's decision to sell Prodigy may be partly to capitalize on the potentially high value that an on-line system might command in the marketplace today. It is also, however, the culmination of a three-year program to return to its retailing roots. Sears has already spun off Allstate and Dean Witter, Discover & Company, its former insurance and financial services subsidiaries, and even sold the Sears Tower building in Chicago.
In yesterday's meeting with analysts, Mr. Martinez made no reference to electronic commerce.
But speaking to reporters afterward, Mr. Martinez said that if Sears were to become involved in selling over the Internet, it would be better for the company not to be tied to a single service like Prodigy.
Sears, like H & R Block, may also be eager to unload its on-line venture in what has become an increasingly hostile legal environment. Prodigy was sued for $200 million last year by a Long Island investment bank that accused it of libel, based on comments posted on the service by a subscriber. The suit was dropped, but a judge left open the question of whether Prodigy was liable.
 Compuserve, meanwhile, is under fire in Germany for providing children access to the Internet, which carries some pornography and hate literature. And all on-line services are challenging the Communications Decency Act, part of the new telecom law, which sets heavy fines and prison terms for the transmission of "patently offensive" material.
