HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE PRESIDENT;
Quiet Glee Over G.O.P. Demolition Derby

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
President Clinton steered determinedly away from an assessment of the Republican Presidential field today, saying, "This country doesn't need another pundit." But his aides and advisers were as jubilant as if Mr. Clinton himself was the only victor in New Hampshire.
The President, after all, has campaign money in the bank. He is free from the Democratic Party's tradition of debilitating Presidential primary challenges. 
 And now the White House is watching the Republicans tear themselves apart in a bitter battle that Democrats believe will weaken the eventual Republican nominee and give Patrick J. Buchanan at the very least a strong role at the G.O.P. convention that will play into Democratic attempts to paint the Republicans as "extremists."
"If you liked what you saw in Houston in '92, you're going to love what you'll see in San Diego in '96," said Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the general chairman of the Democratic National Committee. He referred to Mr. Buchanan's 1992 convention speech in which he declared that a religious and cultural war was under way in the nation.
For now, of all the Republican candidates, only former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee concerns the White House. "To have a moderate Southern governor with a huge wave of excitement behind him could be a problem," cautioned one of the President's advisers.
Publicly Mr. Clinton and the White House staff refused even to discuss the Republican field today, part of a strategy of keeping Mr. Clinton above the fray and Presidential.
"I'm going to be President and go out there and tell the people what I'm trying to do and what I will do if given a greater opportunity to do it," Mr. Clinton said, ducking questions about the Republican showing in New Hampshire. "I'm not going to get involved in their business."
In fact, the President's strategists see a two-phase campaign ahead and believe that Mr. Clinton may be waging the most important phase right now: an effort to pull his favorable ratings up so high that he will seem like the inevitable winner. That will, they hope, inoculate him for the second phase of the campaign that will come once the Republicans settle on a nominee.
"Seeing how venomously the Republicans attack each other, he's certainly prepared to face that kind of attack himself," the White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said this week.
To raise his standing before the campaign is engaged directly, Mr. Clinton plans to run what his aides describe as a modified Rose Garden strategy through mid-April. It calls for him to rise above the negative tone of the Republican race by using the trappings and majesty of incumbency and restricting his campaigning to jaunts like his sweep through New Hampshire last Saturday.
"Americans don't like politics these days," said Don Fowler, the national chairman of the Democratic Party. "The longer he can be Presidential and not political, the more they will like him. It's that simple."
Already, the Democratic National Committee has helped Mr. Clinton raise his ratings through an aggressive use of early television advertising tied to the budget debate and featuring Mr. Clinton on topics ranging from Medicare to the environment to education.
Since the fall in swing electoral states, the party has been running a series of 30-second commercials that have added up to a $17 million television campaign. And because the ads do not call for Mr. Clinton's re-election, they do not count against campaign spending limits.
Now, moving forward from the budget debate, Mr. Clinton will try to use his bully pulpit to emphasize a Democratic "values agenda" to Lcompete on the field of social issues that Republicans have long made their own. His agenda is largely family based and children oriented, to appeal to people who feel that politics do not affect their own lives.
Advisers expect this Rose Garden phase of the campaign to culminate in state visits to Japan and Russia in April, majestic occasions high on ceremony and news coverage. By then, because of this year's unusually early primary schedule, the Republican nominee could be chosen.
Once his opponent is clear, Mr. Clinton will formally begin his campaign, officially announcing his re-election bid and putting in place a senior staff at Clinton-Gore campaign headquarters.
But that staff will be subordinate to the White House, where the deputy chief of staff, Harold M. Ickes, will be running the day-to-day campaign. Dick Morris, the Democrat-turned Republican consultant who worked for Mr. Clinton in his early campaigns in Arkansas, will run the media campaign and help Mr. Clinton shape his overarching message.
Most incumbent Presidents try to trade on the glory of the office, and Mr. Clinton's current tactics could seem to resemble those of George Bush, who made the mistake of lingering too long in the Rose Garden.
Mr. Clinton began fund-raising last April, far earlier than recent incumbents, in part to scare off any Democratic primary challenger. As a result, the President all but wrapped up his primary season money raising by the New Year's -- months before Mr. Bush did four years ago.
The President has brought in $27 million in contributions and is receiving about $11 million in federal matching money, said his finance director, Terence R. McAuHliffe. A couple more mail appeals are planned to bring in the remaining few million dollars allowed before the campaign reaches the ceiling set by public finance laws. So far the campaign reports spending little more than $6 million.
By contrast, the President's aides calculate, the Republican nominee will be hard pressed for resources to get through the long period until the August conventions, after which the two political parties start pumping money into the Presidential race.
Though much could still go wrong for the President -- the steady drone of Whitewater hearings, the economy, Bosnia -- his aides say they believe that they will be tactically well positioned.
"Let's say it's Dole," said one Clinton adviser, who predicted that Senator Bob Dole would bounce back from his second place finish in New Hampshire. "He will probably have very little money left to spend. So April through the convention he has a tough time buying any TV, staffing, or paying for a campaign plane. We will be flush with cash to do what we need to do."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;
SOME REPUBLICANS HOPING FOR A WAY TO STOP BUCHANAN

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 21

 BODY:
Jolted by Patrick J. Buchanan's triumph in the New Hampshire primary, Republicans around the country, including Gen. Colin L. Powell, today plunged into a furious debate over how Mr. Buchanan emerged and how he could be stopped.
Before racing from this state to campaign in next Tuesday's primary in South Dakota, where he tried to put his defeat behind him, Senator Bob Dole declared at a news conference here, "This now is a race between the mainstream and the extreme, that's what it's all about." 
 Indeed, the struggle broke out in earnest as a parade of moderate and conservative Republicans -- from members of Congress to state party leaders, and from mayors to grass-roots political workers -- said they could not support Mr. Buchanan and ridiculed his positions as anathema to the party's mainstream.
Breaking his silence about the Presidential contest since he announced last November not to run himself, General Powell, the retired chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today: "Pat sometimes gives out messages that are of intolerance, which I think is very unfortunate. This is not the time for intolerance. This is the time for inclusion."
In an Iinterviewed on the ABC News program "Prime Time Live," he added, "We can't pull up our drawbridges and withdraw back into our own continent."
In a series of interviews, many Republicans who only a few weeks ago believed that Mr. Dole had the nomination cinched said today that they now consider it up for grabs. Mr. Buchanan's dizzying rise, they said, has had as much to do with the appeal of his message and his own political skills as the weaknesses in the entire Republican field.
But they said they were worried that Mr. Buchanan could fracture the party -- and cripple its prospects to win back the White House -- because of his support for a protectionist trade policy and an isolationist foreign policy, and for what many of his detractors decribe as his trail of racist remarks.
"I believe we have to make sure that Bob Dole's message of inclusion prevails," said Senator Olympia Snowe of Maine, who is supporting Mr. Dole. "It's absolutely essential for the future of the Republican Party."
Senator John McCain of Arizona, who was national chairman of Senator Phil Gramm's aborted Presidential campaign and who now backs Mr. Dole, said: "I don't know if he's unacceptable. There are positions he's taken which I have strong disagreements with. But I can't say we'd not respect the primary process."
Mayor Rudolph W. Guiliani of New York, who has stayed neutral in the race, put it bluntly: "We're going to do everything we can to stop Buchanan."
Former Vice President Dan Quayle complained: "There are a lot of nervous Nellies; there's a lot of hand-wringing going on. This is a wake-up call, folks. We're going to have to live with it, adjust and go on."
Mr. Quayle, who last year had considered making his own run for the 1996 nomination, lectured the Republicans who are in the race, saying they should have stuck with attacking President Clinton, not one another, and had become victims of their own negative campaigns.
"Clinton is the ultimate opponent and he has been missing from the debate," he said. Without irony, Mr. Quayle reprised a phrase of President George Bush's: "It's called 'the vision thing' -- they have to clearly spell out and articulate what they'll do for America."
Out on the hustings today, the candidates -- campaigning from South Carolina to South Dakota -- hardly heeded Mr. Quayle's warning. They went right back on the attack, with Mr. Dole and former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee calling on each other to quit the race.
Mr. Buchanan, meanwhile, relished the attention, predicting that his victory here would become "a legend in political history."
But even a Republican who sounded somewhat sympathetic to Mr. Buchanan, Representative Ernest Jim Istook Jr. of Oklahoma, said he was worried that the party would rip itself apart over Mr. Buchanan.
"I'm concerned over the different competitors that seem to want to join in bashing Buchanan, label him an extremist or any other such term," Mr. Istook said. "I think that's a major mistake. If you do that, you're also passing on that same label to the substantial number of people who are supporting him. Are you going to say that Republican voters are extremist just because he's touched a responsive chord with them?"
Nor were many Republicans particularly confident that Mr. Dole or Mr. Alexander, who finished third in the New Hampshire primary, could stop attacking each other long enough to slow Mr. Buchanan.
One important dynamic in the coming days will be whether Republicans who oppose Mr. Buchanan rally to Mr. Dole or view him as so damaged that they turn to Mr. Alexander.
Campaigning in Vermont, Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, who trailed in fifth place behind Steve Forbes, said he was not feeling any pressure to withdraw and try to help his fellow Senator. "Less than one-tenth of 1 percent of the Republican voters in this country have had a chance to cast a ballot," he said.
In any case, several prominent Republicans, including former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, who backs Mr. Alexander, said that given Mr. Buchanan's success, the nomination fight might drag on to the national convention in August -- and result in the brokered convention. "We're tearing each other apart," he said.
Republicans are not accustomed to such intramural turmoil because the party has a tradition of rewarding its best known establishment candidates, like Mr. Dole, with the nomination. Many Republicans said they feared a scenario in which Mr. Buchanan wins the nomination but is such a lightning rod that he leads the party to defeat in November, much like Barry Goldwater in 1964.
Another scenario is that Mr. Buchanan does not win the nomination but stays competitive long enough to inflict such damage on the nominee that that he loses in November. That would be an echo of what happened to the Democrats in 1984, when the Rev. Jesse Jackson was a constant irritant to the campaign of Walter F. Mondale.
Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, sought to play down the divisions in the party and asserted that the record turnout in the primary here reflected dissatsfaction among many independents over Mr. Clinton. But Mr. Barbour acknowledged that the nomination could go any way.
"I have no idea who's going to win," he said. "Any party chairman in the history of mankind would prefer to have the nomination fight start late and end early. I have no idea how long it will go on."
Asked if he could support Mr. Buchanan if he won the nomination, Mr. Barbour twice refused to answer the question. Instead, his response was, "I have confidence in the Republican voters in the United States."
Speaker Newt Gingrich, emerging this evening from a House leadership meeting in Washington, fended off any direct questions about the primary results and seemed to suggest that Mr. Dole's political plight might not be so dire.
"There's a ton of time," Mr. Gingrich said. "Clinton began to recover in July of 1992, when he was running third behind Perot and Bush. And he seemed to have a lot of time to recover."
Patrick M. McSweeney, the chairman of the Virgina Republican Party, said he might back Mr. Buchanan but was critical of others in the party whom he said were ganging up on the former columnist and commentator. "Where is the Big Tent when it's Pat Buchanan?" he asked. Speaking of the Buchanan candidacy, he said: "Handled right, it could energize us. Handled wrong, you create fissures that are very hard to repair."
Many other state Republican leaders were not as upbeat about Mr. Buchanan. "I don't think we're to the point of death, yet," said Barb McTurk, executive director of the Colorado Republican Party. "But if this continues on it becomes difficult."
Republicans in several states said it might be difficult for Mr. Buchanan to endure the rapid-fire schedule of primaries in the next four weeks, given that he cannot come close to matching Mr. Dole's money and organization. Even so, they also said that Mr. Buchanan's victory here could give him an edge in many states.
"I had some of the Buchanan people mad at me because I was quoted as saying Dole would probably take Texas," said Tom Pauken, the Texas Republican chairman. "That's all changed. I think it's going to be very competitive here between Bob Dole and Pat Buchanan."
Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, a leading moderate who withdrew from the Presidential race last year, called on his wing of the party to rise up. "Pat Buchanan may accomplish for the Republican Party what I couldn't: getting the centrist Republicans off the sidelines and onto the playing field so Pat Buchanan can be stopped," he said.
Like Mr. Specter, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey is backing Mr. Dole, but she sounded less nervous about Mr. Buchanan. "I am not worried by the kind of discussion and the issues that Pat Buchanan is bringing up," she said, "because as the American people look at them over time, they're going to reject them and I believe Bob Dole will be the nominee."
William W. Pascoe, political director of the American Conservative Union, said he was concerned that Mr. Buchanan, if successful, could greatly damage the conservative moement. And he said the only way to stop him would be for Mr. Alexander to make a deal with Mr. Dole and become his running mate.
"If they want to head off a Buchanan nomination, one of them has to get out of the race and fast," Mr. Pascoe said. "Many conservatives are concerned about Pat. They're worried less about the Republican Party than the future of the conservative movement. They don't want him to redefine the conservative movement in his image."
In the interview that was broadcast tonight, General Powell derided Mr. Buchanan's foreign policy. "We won the cold war," he said. "Our former enemies are now our competitors, and they're also going to be our markets in the future. And so I think fair and free trade is the road to go and not to pretend to the American worker, the American people, that there is some promise in the other direction."
General Powell went on to assess why Mr. Buchanan's message has appeal. "There are angry people," he said. "We are going through a transition period, where our economy is changing, where our whole world trading and economic structure is changing and there are dislocations, and people are anxious.
"We've got to work our way through this. But to think we can work our way through this by shutting ourselves off from the rest of the world is the incorrect answer."
Sam Donaldson asked General Powell, "Could you vote for Pat Buchanan for President?"
The simple reply, "No."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: ON THE MOVE;
Exultant Buchanan Pushes Economic Insecurity Theme

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: MOUNT RUSHMORE MEMORIAL PARK, S.D., Feb. 21

 BODY:
With perhaps more audacity, but inarguably with more delegates than his opponents for the Republican Presidential nomination, Patrick J. Buchanan came here today and took the measure of this mountain for his own face.
"Yesterday, I won the first election of my whole life!" Mr. Buchanan exulted before about 200 supporters, as the sun dipped behind the Black Hills. 
 "After my great New Hampshire victory," he continued, "we thought we'd come out here and see if there was any more space up there on that mountain. We're that confident."
Pausing only for three hours' sleep after his victory, Mr. Buchanan traveled through three states today, hammering at the themes of gnawing economic insecurity and creeping one-world government that have catapulted him to the front of the pack and rattled the Republican party.
Even as Senator Bob Dole and Lamar Alexander, his two chief rivals for the nomination, lit out across country too, arguing that Mr. Buchanan was too extreme to be the Republican nominee for President, the former commentator stood at Mount Rushmore and said the men memorialized here endorsed his ideas.
"All four of these gentlemen up here on Mount Rushmore agreed with Pat Buchanan," he declared. "Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln and Theodore Roosevelt all believed that the American economy was designed for the American workers and the American families."
He said those Presidents, who likenesses stared into the distance above him, would have rallied to his cry that the United States is sacrificing its independence through international trade agreements.
"What would these men up there have said?" he asked, before supplying the answer, which is becoming a slogan for his campaign, " 'Lock and load!' "
Mr. Buchanan said: "People tell me, 'Pat you're way out of the mainstream of the G.O.P. I'm in the mainstream of America!"
Pat Buchanan is having a blast. He has hardly slowed down since learning the results of the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday night, when he dashed down a hotel hallway, whooping and clapping his hands.
"In three weeks time, we've gone from nothing, from single digits, from questions like, 'Pat, when are you going to get out of this thing?' questions like that, to the point where the establishment in Washington is just terrified," Mr. Buchanan shouted today in Sioux Falls, S.D. "The phone calls and fax machines are going all over saying, 'What are we going to do to stop him?' I don't think they can stop us."
Mr. Buchanan, who barely two weeks ago was trailed by at best one mini-van's worth of reporters, found himself jetting from South Carolina to South Dakota to Colorado today, accompanied by three dozen journalists and several members of the Secret Service.
Police cars with flashing lights stopped traffic for him. Mr. Buchanan sought Secret Service protection in the last few days to help manage the crush of reporters.
"I'm very exhausted now," Mr. Buchanan said as he finished waving to the cameras. Then, turning to enter the door of his chartered airplane this morning in Columbia, S.C., the candidate added, "But we're having a lot of fun."
Whether he was inveighing against President Clinton, Speaker Newt Gingrich, "corporate butchers" or "Boo-Boo Ghali," as he likes to refer to Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the Secretary General of the United Nations, Mr. Buchanan continued honing his attack on what he calls the establishment.
"The whole establishment out there, they don't know what's going on in America," Mr. Buchanan declared at the stop at the Sioux Falls, where he addressed several hundred supporters at the airport this afternoon.
"You know they've got to get the State Department to start giving orientation courses for when they send them out in America from Washington D.C.," Mr. Buchanan said. "You know, give 'em shots and everything, have 'em learn the language of America."
For all his enthusiasm, Mr. Buchanan was quick to demur when asked if he was now the front-runner for the nomination.
"No, I don't think so," the Republican candidate said. "I think Senator Dole has the resources, and he probably has the, you know, in the national polls, he probably leads."
But he added, "I am the only authentic conservative left in the race, and I am the principal challenger to Bob Dole for the Republican nomination."
Mr. Buchanan continued to add today to his list of establishment figures who have opposed him. In attacking trade agreements as a "sellout of American jobs, a sellout of American farmers, and a sellout of our sovereignty," Mr. Buchanan thundered in Sioux Falls, "all the establishment there -- Dole, Gingrich, Gramm, and Clinton and Rubin and Greenspan and the Heritage Foundation and the Brookings Foundation and The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal -- all of them came together" to support the agreements.
Mr. Buchanan went on to mock the idea of putting United States troops under United Nations command. "We don't take orders from Boo-Boo Ghali," he said.
Mr. Buchanan also pressed his opposition to abortion today.
In Columbia, S.C., this morning, he was endorsed at a news conference by Phyllis Schlafly, president of Eagle Forum, a conservative foundation, and national chairman of the Republican National Coalition for Life.
"There is no stronger pro-life candidate who is left running," Mr. Buchanan said at the news conference, pledging to maintain the Republican Party's plank opposing all abortion, to nominate an anti-abortion running mate, and to appoint Supreme Court justices committed to overturning Roe v. Wade.
"Neither Bob Dole nor Lamar Alexander has made such commitments," he warned.

HEADLINE: Pataki and Giuliani: Bound by Pragmatism

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Not long ago, the scene would have seemed implausible. But there they were, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki, sharing a Manhattan dais last week, offering glowing appraisals of each other.
"I think he is a hell of a Governor," said Mr. Giuliani, who in 1994 predicted that "ethics will be trashed" in a Pataki-run government. 
 The Governor replied in kind. The Mayor's policies "are right for this city and this country," he said, even though in 1994 he accused Mr. Giuliani of crassly selling his endorsement to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in exchange for state aid to the city.
But now, defying expectations, Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Pataki have forged an unusually effective alliance. They have surmounted the institutional conflicts that have long estranged mayors from governors, even those of the same party. And they have sidestepped a bitter personal feud born when Mr. Giuliani bolted the Republican fold in 1994 to support Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat.
After he was elected just over a year ago, Mr. Pataki was so angry with Mr. Giuliani that he refused to return the Mayor's phone calls for almost three weeks, prompting Mr. Giuliani to accuse him of pettiness. But the two men have clearly come to realize that their political lives are closely intertwined. No Governor can seem hostile to New York City, even if he dislikes the Mayor. And every Mayor needs help from Albany.
So time and again, Mr. Pataki has vetoed popular legislation opposed by Mr. Giuliani, most recently a police arbitration bill strongly advocated by the powerful police lobby. And time and again, Mr. Giuliani has effusively praised Mr. Pataki as courageous, defending him against Democratic charges that his policies have hurt the city. But all is not perfect. Beneath the detente, the two camps remain wary of each other. And for all its outward chumminess, the two men's relationship is built largely on political calculations, overlapping fiscal problems and shared enemies. Pragmatism, not personal affection, is the glue that binds them.
Their appearance together on "Saturday Night Live" in January provided an apt, if unintended, illustration of their alliance. In the opening skit, the two men piled praise on each other for their handling of the blizzard -- mirroring recent real-life public appearances.
Yet behind the scenes, they spent almost no time together, even though they were on the set for nearly five hours. When they were not rehearsing, they closeted themselves in private dressing rooms or sat in separate sections of the audience. After the show, Mr. Giuliani left the building while Mr. Pataki took his daughter, Emily, to the cast party.
But if they are not close friends, their mutual needs have made them political partners. Mr. Giuliani depends on Mr. Pataki because he has almost no other allies in Albany, which wields enormous power over his budget.
The city's natural ally, the Assembly's Democratic leadership, regards him with open antipathy. Perhaps more important, Mr. Giuliani's natural allies, his fellow Republicans, are almost as antagonistic. And the men who control the state Republican Party -- William D. Powers, its chairman, and United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato -- are still furious with him for endorsing Mr. Cuomo.
Mr. Pataki, on the other hand, needs Mr. Giuliani because he has almost no other allies in the city, where he won a scant 18 percent of the vote in 1994. By helping the Mayor, Mr. Pataki hopes to stabilize the city's shaky finances before they damage the state's economy. But he also hopes to inoculate himself against charges that his deep-cutting budget will devestate the city, his aides say.
"The Governor doesn't want to give Rudy a chance to say, 'George Pataki bankrupted the city,' " a senior Pataki adviser said, speaking on condition of anonymity.
In separate interviews, Mr. Pataki and Mr. Giuliani both predicted thatpragmatism would keep them working cooperatively for years to come. But other politicians say that the bitter memories of 1994, combined with Mr. Pataki's close friendship with Mr. D'Amato, one of the Mayor's oldest rivals, make a blowup inevitable.
"Knowing people in politics, and knowing that the Governor felt betrayed, I doubt he will ever forgive Giuliani for what he did," former Mayor Edward I. Koch said. "When the time arrives where Pataki can do him in without hurting New York City, I believe he will."
Beneath the smooth veneer of their public alliance, the two men have a businesslike personal relationship -- cordial but not quite warm, people close to both men say.
In general, they rarely socialize together outside of the political dinner circuit. Mr. Pataki frequently holds parties at the Governor's mansion in Albany and at his home in Garrison, and he has on a few occasions invited the Mayor to official receptions. But when, for instance, he held a birthday party for himself last year, he did not invite Mr. Giuliani, though several of the state's leading Republican officials were invited.
Yet even if they are not close, the two men have developed an amiable working relationship, their aides say. Their phone conversations have become more personal and include chitchat about their families and jokes about the weather. And though they have never had a heart-to-heart talk about the 1994 campaign endorsement, they have at least progressed to the point where they can joke about it in public.
"As far as I'm concerned, I can only think of one wrong decision he's made in the last couple of years," Mr. Pataki said of Mr. Giuliani at a Republican fund-raiser in Manhattan last week, breaking up the room. "And nobody gets 'em all right."
In an interview, Mr. Pataki acknowledged that the Mayor's acidic remarks in 1994 hurt him deeply. But he said he was not interested in revenge against the Mayor or the city.
"I'm human, and obviously it was something that was very difficult," he said. "But I have seen too many people in politics destroy themselves by keeping records. That's just not my nature. My nature is to look at the next fight, the next goal, and try to figure out how we can work together to achieve them."
Mr. Giuliani has yet to apologize for endorsing Mr. Cuomo, angering many Pataki advisers. But the Mayor has expressed regrets for saying in 1994 that a Pataki administration would be "a government of D'Amato, for D'Amato, by D'Amato."
"If I had known George Pataki better, I would not have said those things," Mr. Giuliani said in an interview. "He is a very honest and independent person who is able to make his own decisions. He's handled his administration in a very honorable way."
Still, many Pataki loyalists in the Legislature and the Republican Party have not forgiven the Mayor. Even now, they say Mr. Giuliani's refusal to endorse the state party's favored Presidential candidate, Bob Dole, has only fueled the tensions. Some people in both parties even believe that Mr. D'Amato will work behind the scenes for a Democrat in the 1997 mayoral campaign if Mr. Giuliani does not join the Dole camp. Mr. D'Amato denies that.
Perhaps sensing these subterranean machinations, Mr. Giuliani says he believes that keeping on good terms with the Governor and the state's other Republicans is not enough. "It's a terrible mistake for the mayor of New York City to get owned too much by one party or another," he said. "At different times, you need both of them."
Many politicians predicted that Mr. Pataki would try to undermine Mr. Giuliani as soon as he was elected. Indeed, when Mr. Pataki refused to talk to Mr. Giuliani after the election, it was a planned effort to rebuff and humiliate the Mayor.
But then a rapprochement began. In one of the new Governor's first major acts, he vetoed legislation that would have increased the city's annual pension payments by hundreds of millions of dollars. Then last summer, Mr. Pataki and his counsel, Michael C. Finnegan, helped negotiate an agreement that is expected to protect the city's water supply without requiring New York to build a $7 billion filtration system.
And in the last six months, Mr. Pataki has vetoed five bills strongly supported by police unions -- an extremely influential Republican constituency -- at Mr. Giuliani's behest. The last veto, of the arbitration bill, which the Mayor said would cost the city $200 million a year, was overridden by the Legislature a week ago.
Mr. Giuliani has responded to the Pataki vetoes with enthusiastic applause. When Mr. Pataki proposed a budget last year that reduced spending on city schools, mass transit and hospitals, Mr. Giuliani commended him for trimming government bloat. When Mr. Pataki called for transferring 1,000 state jobs from New York to Binghampton, Mr. Giuliani said he was "very fair to the city."
And even after it became apparent that the Governor had not done all he could to prevent the Legislature from overriding his veto of the police arbitration bill, Mr. Giuliani called him courageous. "He's demonstrated right from the beginning that in making his decisions, he assesses the good of the entire state," Mr. Giuliani said.
Such cooperation is more the exception than the rule in New York State politics, historians say. Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and Mayor John V. Lindsay were bitter rivals for control of the liberal wing of the Republican Party. Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Koch, competitors in both mayoral and gubernatorial races, sniped endlessly at each other. And Mayor David N. Dinkins almost refused to endorse Mr. Cuomo in 1994 because he felt the Governor had repeatedly shortchanged him and the city.
"There is a natural tension that exists in all mayor-governor relationships because the city is a major claimant on the state," said Gerald Benjamin, a professor of political science at the State University at New Paltz. "I think Giuliani and Pataki are getting along famously, given the political context and institutional pressures."

HEADLINE: Farrakhan's Angry World Tour Brings Harsh Criticism at Home

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Four months after his Million Man March edged him toward the political mainstream, Louis Farrakhan has touched off wide criticism with an extended world tour, which included countries the United States considers pariahs, and his bitterly anti-American remarks along the way.
Mr. Farrakhan, the head of the American group the Nation of Islam, said his 20-nation "world friendship tour" to Iran, Libya, the Sudan, Nigeria, Syria and other nations was intended to spread the message of self-help and personal responsibility that was voiced in October at the Million Man March in Washington. 
 But critics suggest that Mr. Farrakhan's purpose was to raise money at a time when some commercial ventures linked to the Nation of Islam are in financial trouble.
Whatever his motives, Mr. Farrakhan has generated condemnation not only from the State Department, which accused him of "cavorting" with terrorist states, but from other black leaders, who said his meetings in outlaw states undercut their efforts to promote human rights.
It has also prompted calls for a Congressional investigation into his denunciations of the United States, like the one he reportedly uttered last month in Iran on the 17th anniversary of the overthrow of the Shah.
"God will destroy America by the hands of Muslims," the Iranian press quoted him as saying. "God will not give Japan or Europe the honor of bringing down the United States; this is an honor God will bestow upon Muslims."
Mr. Farrakhan's trip began Jan. 17 and is to end this week after a visit to Malaysia, where he arrived late today, and where the official religion is Islam.
There is evident discomfort over the tour among traditional civil rights organizations struggling to determine their relationship with the fiery leader.
Ronald Walters, chairman of the department of political science at Howard University, said: "The interesting thing is how it plays among people who, after the Million Man March, thought they could welcome him into the pantheon of black leadership. Now they're finding out that consorting with him is not going to be as easy as they thought."
In Iraq, Mr. Farrakhan, who is 62, compared the deprivations of Iraqis living under United Nations economic sanctions with the fate of Jews in Nazi death camps. And in Iran, he denounced the United States as the "Great Satan" and predicted his preachings would land him in prison back home, saying that perhaps he would be jailed next to Sheik Omar Adbel-Rahman, the Egyptian cleric convicted in a plot to bomb landmarks in New York.
"Maybe there's a cell next to Abdel-Rahman for me," Mr. Farrakhan said, "and maybe he and I will be together reading the Koran and encouraging each other."
In Nigeria, Mr. Farrakhan voiced support for the military Government, which has refused to honor an election last June to restore democratic rule. He also chastised Western nations for their criticism of the execution of Ken Saro-Wiwa, a writer and environmental advocate who had demanded a greater share of oil revenues for his people.
"They said that you hanged one man," he was quoted as saying, referring to countries that condemned the execution. "So what? Ask them, too, 'How many did you hang?' "
Many of Mr. Farrakhan's statements were reported by official press agencies and their accuracy could not be confirmed.
Mr. Farrakhan also sometimes puzzled his hosts. For instance, he and his 30-person entourage rode around South Africa in white stretch limosines with gold detailing, an ostentatious display unusual there. He also said he was scouring Africa to establish a "homeland" for black American prison inmates.
But what was merely puzzling to his hosts was offensive to many in the United States.
Randall Robinson, president of TransAfrica Forum, which lobbies on issues related to Africa and the Caribbean, was particularly upset at Mr. Farrakhan's support of Nigeria's military junta.
"I am extremely disappointed with the statements made on this trip in countries like Nigeria and Sudan," said Mr. Robinson. "His statements and the things that were said appear to make Minister Farrakhan an apologist for an authoritarian, corrupt and repressive regime."
Kweisi Mfume, the new president and chief executive of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (and a speaker at the Million Man March), said Mr. Farrakhan's visits to countries that flout international standards did "not help" efforts to establish "conformity with international law."
A State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, chastised the Muslim leader for his stops in Iran and Libya and accused him of "cavorting with dictators."
Representative Peter T. King, a New York Republican and a long-time critic, called for a Congressional investigation into whether Mr. Farrakhan had violated passport restrictions by going to Libya, where travel by American citizens is generally banned by Washington.
Calls this week to the official spokesman of Nation of Islam in Chicago seeking comment were not returned.
But Mr. Farrakhan has his defenders, among them Benjamin F. Chavis Jr., the former executive director of the N.A.A.C.P., who helped organize the Million Man March. "I think that the purpose of the trip was a good-will tour to take the spirit of the Million Man March -- which is a spirit of atonement and reconciliation -- to nations that need atonement and reconciliation,' Mr. Chavis said.
For some who took part in the rally, however, the trip seemed an irrelevancy.
"While some folks are international and beyond, we who function down here on the ground have to be about the business we talked about in Washington," said Jacques deGraff, president of a New York construction company, who attended the Million Man March.
Mr. Farrakhan's tour comes as several commercial enterprises affiliated with the Nation of Islam are experiencing financial difficulties.
A Chicago restaurant, Salaam, opened with fanfare last year, has accumulated tax bills, court judgments and liens sought by contractors totaling $300,000. And a security concern, the New Life Self Development Company, recently lost a $2 million contract at a public housing project in Chicago and is being sued by the city to recover more than $52,000 in back taxes.
Given these financial setbacks for the Nation of Islam, some critics suggest Mr. Farrakhan's tour was an effort to raise money from countries seeking to exert influence in American foreign policy.
"I believe he's trying to push as far as he can to, one, get money, and also to establish himelf as a spokesman for American blacks throughout the world," Representative King said.
A report by JANA, the Libyan press agency, that the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, had promised $1 billion to Mr. Farrakhan to finance political activities in the United States has prompted Congressional critics and the Justice Department to question whether the American Muslim leader should register as a foreign agent. Libya later denied any promise of financial support.
For his part, Mr. Farrakhan denies being motivated by money and is unapologetic about his comments, saying he is an American citizen who is guaranteed the right of free speech.
"I can go where I please and speak to anyone I please," he said in Ankara, Turkey. "I only have to answer to God."

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
Excerpts From Buchanan Campaign Speech

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech by Patrick J. Buchanan at a campaign rally in Nashua, N.H., on Saturday, as transcribed by The New York Times. The speech provides an example of the message Mr. Buchanan delivers in his standard campaign speech. 
 We're going all the way! . . .
Listen my friends, this is one of the final rallies in the great New Hampshire campaign, and let me tell you something. History is about to be made in the state of New Hampshire. I'll tell you -- I'll tell you why history is about to be made, because the establishment in Washington is quaking in its boots at what's going on across the country. . . .
The lights are burning late in Washington, D.C., tonight, friends. Because of this campaign. We came out of Alaska. We won a great victory in Alaska, down to Louisiana. We had a tremendous upset win in Louisiana. We went to Iowa, and after Bob Dole outspent us 5 to 1, he began with a 50-point lead. He ended up with a 3-point lead in Iowa. I don't think he's going to have a 3-point lead in New Hampshire. . . .
We will open the door of the Buchanan campaign to anyone who just doesn't close the door to us, friends. They're all welcome, because our objective is to send Bill and Hillary back to wherever they sent poor Joycelyn Elders. . . .
We'll get to the elections, my friends, but let me talk about something else. We'll get to there, but let me say something.
As I said in Louisiana, I said, now it's not a victory for a man, it's a victory for a cause. It's a victory for a cause that's larger than lotteries. It's a victory for a new conservatism of the heart. A conservatism that will look out and provide voices for the voiceless. It will look out for the right to life for the innocent unborn. . . .
It will look out for those working men and women who are seeing their jobs sent overseas. We're seeing those jobs sent overseas for the benefit of trans-national corporations. It's a new conservatism which is going to go to Washington. . . .
I know there's a lot of candidates running around, waffling around and ducking and hiding, and bucking and weaving and all the rest of it. With Pat Buchanan, even his critics will tell you in Washington, this is a man who means what he says. Let me tell you what I mean. I am pro-life. I will keep this party pro-life. . . .
(Inaudible)
I care about the working women and the working men of America. . . .
We're going to have a Republican Party that looks out for working men and women in middle-class families. . . .
Look what's happened in New Hampshire in the last five years. Wages of the working people are down 5 percent. Medium income of the New Hampshire family is down 15 percent. Twenty-thousand manufacturing jobs gone from New Hampshire. Lost a significant slice of your manufacturing base, just as America is losing a slice of the manufacturing base. . . .
They're all -- They're all sitting there talking nonsense, and they're throwing these questions up at me, and they don't realize I'm "Crossfire" trained and I can handle all that nonsense. . . .
All right, let me tell you something. Look at what's going on. They say, "Well, Pat, why didn't you oppose that wonderful free trade agreement in GATT?" I said, "Free trade agreement?" They said, "Yeah, free." I said, "Let me tell you about freedom." You find freedom on that stack of papers called the Constitution of the United States. You put GATT -- 23,000 pages, they're that high, they're that high -- and the first 20 pages, what do they do? They say that the control over world trade is transferred from the Congress of the United States, where our own founding fathers placed responsibility, to a global institution in Geneva called a World Trade Organization, where we get one vote out of 120. Our American vote can be canceled out by Fidel Castro.
People say, What does sovereignty mean, Pat? I say go down to the village green in Lexington. Go down and stand there, where 17-year-old boys stopped the greatest army in the world. Stand there for an hour, and you'll understand what it's all about. . . .
You've read the story of those 16 young Americans, shot down in that friendly fire incident in Iraq. . . .
The Vice President issues a formal statement to the parents of these young Americans to be proud; they died in the service of the United Nations.
Let me tell you, they didn't take any oath -- they took an oath to the United States. They took an oath to our Constitution, and when I'm President of the United States, never again will young Americans be sent into battle, except under American officers and to fight under the American flag.
You know about Michael New? Well, I'm going to tell those of you who don't know about Michael New. Michael New was a devout Christian, home-schooled, went into the Army of the United States, decorated in Germany, and Bill Clinton, his commander-in-chief, ordered him into Macedonia, and told him to put on that insignia, put on a U.N. helmet and take orders.
He said, I'm not going to do that, because I took an oath not to the charter of the United Nations, but to the Constitution of the United States. (inaudible) court-martialed Michael New, convicted him, and dishonorably discharged Michael New from the services of his country. Michael New is not the one who ought to be discharged from the service of this country. . . .
People ask me, what is our campaign all about, and could you sum it up in a couple of words? And, I said, my campaign is about restoring the Constitutional Republic. . . .
In this Constitution, certain responsibilities and duties are given to the Federal Government and the rest belong to the states respectively, and to the people, and one of those responsibilities, quite frankly, is the education of America's younger children.
That responsibliity -- that responsibility does not belong to the Federal bureaucrats. Now let me tell you something, there's a big secret in American politics about Federal bureaucrats, I want to tell about it. But to do so, I got to tell you the truth. I was born and raised inside the Beltway before it was a Beltway, Washington, D.C. I grew up in Washington, D.C. I even, at one time, 10 years old, I delivered The Washington Post. They robbed me blind, and I'll never forget it. . . .
I used to hitch-hike into an inner city high school every day for four years, and every day, one of those bureaucrats gave me a ride, and they're real nice fellows, but they're not all that bright. I'm telling you. Really, they gave us a ride down there, and now they're trying to dictate primary and secondary school education.
Well, I'm going to tell them, "Listen fellows, it's going to be short, we're going to put you on leave here. What we're going to do is we're going to end Goals 2000 and we are going to shut down the U.S. Department of Education."
(Inaudible)
Here's what's going on up there, what's going on, they're all watching you New Hampshire. They are watching New Hampshire. You've got the national press, and you've got the world press, they're all coming in.
(Inaudible)
You know, they said, What is he doing here? I've told the story many times. Let me tell it again.
It all began a year ago. . . .
This reporter comes up and says, "Pat you're not serious about getting into this are you?" I said, "Let me tell you what I'm doing. I'm giving up my job, opposite the great Michael Kinsley. I've given up my radio show opposite Rush. I've given up my sindicated column, and I've even given up my book contract." He said, "That isn't as big or as impressive as Newt's." A little bit of change, so I'm giving it up. So, I said, what does that tell you? He just shook his head and said, "Pat, I'm afraid that gives me my lead: Unemployed, angry white male, may seek Presidency." . . .
Look how we've changed the dynamic af American politics.
Bob Dole. . . . Now that fellow is extreme. He's an extremist. Who's Bob Dole most sound like he's acting like? I sound like an echo chamber at times. . . .
All the while, Bob's idea of a populist rally is to have dinner with Bob Strauss and Dwayne Andreas of ADM at Katharine Graham's place over in Georgetown.
(Inaudible)
I said look, you can't fool folks in New Hampshire. I said for 20 years in the realm of Pat Buchanan, William Lowe and (inaudible) and no one else was here to stand up against those tax increases, and my friend Lamar sipping coffee in the Cabinet room along with the tax raisers and the big spenders. . . . Lamar, you can't -- can't smoke 20 years of that by putting on that plaid shirt and walking across the state. It just won't do up here.
But they're all sounding like us. Even Bill Clinton. That fellow, Imus -- Imus -- Lamar, is that his name? Imus in the Morning said after Clinton's State of the Union, that's the best State of the Union Bill Clinton ever gave. He said, I think Pat Buchanan wrote that one.
. . .
Clinton in '96 is running against the guy who was President in '93.
(Inaudible)
He also says, "Listen, I think we got to get prayer back in the public schools." This guy is shameless, and you'll see him at the National Rifle Association, I'll tell you. At the next convention, he'll be up there and he'll have that camouflage outfit on. . . .
He'll hold up an AK-47 over his head and say, 'Don't try and take my firearms away from me, bud.' . . .
I came up here in 1992 . . . and challenged the President of the United States, 10 weeks before the New Hampshire primary. The reaction was mockery, laughter, and ridicule. . . . We almost get it and they beat us down. They beat us down in Georgia, and they beat us down in Tennessee. He said, well we finished that guy off. . . .
Then we slipped back in a year ago. (Inaudible) We shot through to Alaska and stunned them in Louisiana and stunned them again in Iowa and they are in a terminal pattern.
Better they shout their message from over the hill. You watch the establishment of all the knights and barons, and they're riding into the castle, pulling up the draw bridge real fast. All the peasants are coming with pitchforks, too.
We're going to take this over the top. This has been a great and good campaign. It's been about -- I'll tell you why it's been a good campaign. Look, we aren't going after these guys. (Inaudible) I don't know -- Look at all these guys -- Bob Dole is running and hiring these guys for $400,000, and the best they can do, you know, is college dirty tricks.
They got no vision. They got no objective. They got no convictions, beliefs -- all of them. Head piece filled with straw. That's what they're all about.
We got heart. We got soul.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ASSESSMENT;
How 'Front Runner' in G.O.P. Race Had a Flat Tire in New Hampshire

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 21

 BODY:
How did it happen? How did Bob Dole, one of the most effective politicians of the post-war era, elected five times to the Senate, elected Republican leader more often than anyone in history, backed by the potent organization of a Governor who won re-election two years ago with a record 70 percent of the vote, contrive to lose the New Hampshire primary to a television commentator who had never before won an election anywhere?
Part of the explanation of Tuesday's victory by Patrick J. Buchanan lies, of course, in the ardent articulation by Mr. Buchanan of the economic fears and the social ideals of people who feel forgotten or disdained by politicians. 
 Voters surveyed by the television networks and The Associated Press as they left the polls said the question that mattered most to them was a candidate's willingness to stand up for what he believed in. Mr. Buchanan, who spells out his ideas in neon letters that no one could possibly miss, won the support of more than half of those who were searching for someone with backbone.
Obviously, Mr. Dole was hurt by the simple fact that Mr. Buchanan stood alone on the party's right wing, freed by the withdrawal of Senator Phil Gramm of Texas from the necessity of competing for conservative voters, while Mr. Dole and former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee competed for the backing of moderates, along with Steve Forbes, the publisher, and Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana.
"You have four people drawing from the same well," said former Senator Warren B. Rudman, a Dole man. "That's tough. If Forbes or Lugar had pulled out, and Gramm had stayed in, the whole election would have been different."
In a bid to change things, Mr. Dole said on Tuesday night that voters had to choose now between him and Mr. Buchanan, implying that Mr. Alexander was a distraction. But Mr. Alexander remains a viable if underfinanced candidate, as does Mr. Forbes, who has enough money to keep running as long as he wants.
Yet in truth, most of the blame for Mr. Dole's troubles lies not in his opponents, not in his stars but in himself. Mr. Buchanan's bold prescriptions would have seemed less so if Mr. Dole had put forward a program of his own. Like George Bush as President, Mr. Dole is thought to lack "the vision thing."
Intensely conscious of their special role in choosing Presidents, New Hampshire voters like to hear detailed ideas from candidates, adding up to a plan for the nation. They punish candidates who offer mainly a resume -- Edmund S. Muskie in 1972 and Walter F. Mondale in 1984 among Democrats, Mr. Bush in 1980 and 1988, when he won unimpressively, and Mr. Dole in 1988 and this year.
"Bob Dole is the quintessential in-basket candidate," said Tom Rath, a Concord lawyer who backed the Kansan eight years ago and switched to Mr. Alexander this year. "He tells the electorate, 'Throw me a problem and I'll figure out how to solve it.' This time, he was worse than usual. By Election Day, he had morphed into Fritz Mondale."
Mr. Dole's strategists kept telling him he had to talk about the future if he wanted to win. He tried, but often he produced banalities like this one, which emerged as he was cutting a ribbon at the former Pease Air Force Base near Portsmouth, which has been converted into an international trade center: "This is about the future. That's where this country is headed."
Seldom during his travels around the state did he speak with real passion. After it was clear that he had lost, he finally caught fire, telling his supporters that "we are engaged in a fight for the heart and soul of the Republican Party" between the forces of hope and the forces of fear, between the excluders and the includers. Too late, but much the most effective speech he made here.
Clearly, the flatness of his campaign contributed to a pervasive impression in New Hampshire that at 72 years of age Mr. Dole was too old for the Presidency. More than one voter said he should have been content to stay in the Senate instead of making a third run at the Presidency. Some even said they felt sorry for him as he made his umpteenth visit to Derry or Milford, and there is nothing more corrosive to a candidate's chances than to have people pity him.
Kathy Snyder, a mother of three from Nashua who voted for Mr. Buchanan, gave a typical explanation.
"I like Dole," she said. "I think Dole's a good man. I think he's been there a really long time and I think he's getting old. I think he's been comfortable there too long."
In the exit poll, a third of the voters said Mr. Dole's age would hinder him in carrying out the duties of the Presidency. A similar proportion said the same thing in Iowa last week. Here, only 7 percent of those expressing worries about the Senator's age voted for him, which means that about three voters in ten were unprepared to support him, no matter what he did in the campaign.
The younger the voter was, the less likely he or she was to vote for Senator Dole, the poll indicated. Among those 60 years old and older, he took 39 percent, a healthy plurality. But the numbers fell off quickly; among those 45 to 59, he took only 27 percent; among those 30 to 44, 21 percent, and among those 18 to 29, 18 percent.
There is anecdotal evidence as well of a fearsome generation gap. Younger voters in a group assembled by The New York Times to watch last Thursday's debate reacted with boredom or disdain to the Senator's references to his military service in World War II. To many Baby Boomers and Generation-X'ers, the fighting in Europe and the Pacific seems as wrapped in the mists of time as the War of 1812.
In conversations with friends last night Mr. Dole denied that there was anything wrong with his message. The problem, he said, was Mr. Forbes's negative television commercials, which he blamed for "knocking 7 points off my total and giving them to Alexander." Gov. Stephen Merrill of New Hampshire said the same thing this morning -- the morning when, he had said, he would have not egg but a whole breakfast on his face if Senator Dole did not win the primary.
Only 15 percent of the participants in the exit poll said that Mr. Merrill's endorsement made something of a difference or a lot of difference in their choice of a candidate, which is not good news for Mr. Dole. He is counting heavily on endorsements to carry him through the 28 contests in the next month.
"We're not going to change our views," the Senator maintained at a news conference in Manchester this morning, "but I think there are some things we need to listen to coming from people who are disenchanted and frustrated."
Sunnier than on Tuesday night, Mr. Dole called his defeat "a little bump in the road, but not a very big bump." New Hampshire, he said, was "just one stop on the way" to November. Conceding that he had not been in his best form, he promised, "You're going to see the real Bob Dole out there from now on."
For a little while, he sounded as if he meant it, inveighing against isolationism and protectionism and by extension, Patrick J. Buchanan, their new champion. He framed the contest to come as one between "the mainstream and the extreme." But then he lapsed back into platitudes: "Finally, it's about the future. I believe in America. I love America. And I know what made America great."
Perhaps Mr. Dole's biggest asset before this week was the widespread belief, based on his achievements over the last three decades, that no one could deny him the nomination. Now that mantle of inevitability lies in shreds.

GRAPHIC: Table: "AT THE POLLS: G.O.P. Voters in New Hampshire" shows results of a poll based on questionnaires filed out by 2,556 voters leaving polling places in 60 precincts throughout New Hampshire on Tuesday. The exit poll was conducted by Voter News Service, an organization of ABC News, CNN, NBC News and the Associated Press.

HEADLINE: French Government Will Sell Thomson This Year

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

 BODY:
The French Government announced yesterday that it planned to sell Thomson S.A., the huge defense and consumer-electronics company, to private investors by the end of 1996.
It also said it would work to merge two other military giants, Dassault Aviation, manufacturer of fighter jets, and Aerospatiale, producer of aircraft, missiles and satellites, within two years. 
 The consolidation would serve to limit government spending. The moves are also intended to help carry out President Jacques Chirac's plans to reorganize the French military as well as to privatize state industries.
The statement on the intended sale was issued a day before Mr. Chirac is to announce a shake-up of the French Army and the military industries, including a plan to do away with compulsory service, possibly cutting the armed forces in half.
"Almost everyone else has downsized their militaries since the end of the cold war, but France hasn't," said Chris Avery, technology analyst at Banque Paribas in London. "The taxpayers have essentially been carrying the burden. So cuts and consolidations are long overdue, and it looks like they will come in a rush."
The driving force now is budgetary. An economic slowdown has reduced tax revenue and pushed the French deficit above the level required for participation in the first stage of a common European currency in 1999. With little hope that growth will surge in 1996, money saved from military cuts and the sale of state companies are key to France's hopes of qualifying for a role in European economic union.
The office of Prime Minister Alain Juppe said that the head of Thomson S.A., Alain Gomez, would step down and be replaced by Marcel Roulet, former head of France Telecom, the state telecommunications monopoly.
Financial analysts saw that move in a positive light, since Mr. Gomez, 57, who had been at the helm of Thomson for 14 years, was appointed by the late Francois Mitterrand, and is associated in their minds with big government, excess employment and the accumulation of huge debts at Thomson.
Mr. Roulet, 63, on the other hand, was dismissed from France Telecom last year, after four years as its chief executive, when he advocated an aggressive privatization of the telephone business, a process that labor groups opposed. At Thomson he is expected to push to make the company more profitable in the global weapons business.
Thomson S.A., which is a holding company, owns 58 percent of Thomson-CSF, which is traded on the Paris stock exchange and is active in aviation electronics, missile guidance and flight-control systems.
Though the company is profitable, the mergers that have taken place among military contractors in the United States, creating giants like Lockheed Martin, insure bitter competition and a questionable future, analysts said.
Thomson also owns Thomson Multimedia, which makes television sets under the RCA and General Electric names. That unit has hemorrhaged money, losing $120 million in 1994. Still, prospects for consumer electronics are considered brighter than the military business.
The holding company has accumulated losses of almost $2 billion over five years, and is thought to have accumulated debts of $4 billion, and to have less than $500 million in shareholder equity. It had sales in 1994 of $7.1 billion. "It's essentially a basket case," an analyst in London said, speaking on condition of anonymity.
The French Government owns 76 percent of Thomson, and France Telecom, 20 percent.
Analysts were annoyed that the announcement yesterday carried no details of how the privatization would take place, except to say that Mr. Roulet would head the effort. The statement said merely, "In close consultation with the relevant Government ministries, Marcel Roulet is charged by the Government to undertake the necessary work for the privatization."
Two basic approaches to privatizing Thomson have been studied. One would involve combining Thomson Multimedia and Thomson-CSF into one group, and the other calls for selling them separately.
A combined sale could bring in as much as $2 billion, analysts said, effectively canceling a large part of the Government's debt at Thomson.
While last year's idea of privatizing France Telecom was politically treacherous for President Chirac, involving many workers and assuring huge layoffs, defense-industry privatization is less so.
In December, Mr. Chirac's officials announced names of the companies it intended to privatize in 1996, hoping to raise $8 billion in asset sales. Among those on the list for partial or complete privatization were the auto maker Renault and the insurance company, Assurances Generales de France. Now, Thomson joins that list.

HEADLINE: Students Paid the Price When Private Firm Took Over Schools;
Privatizers Made Gains

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re: "School Privatizers, In Retreat" (editorial, Feb. 12): 
 You reach erroneous conclusions on the performance and future of the school privatization industry.
Contrary to your editorial, test scores at the elementary school in Dade County, Florida, run by Education Alternatives Inc. were higher than those for children not involved in our effort.
In Baltimore, the 80 or so non-college-educated paraprofessionals did not lose their jobs, as you imply, but were transferred to schools not managed by E.A.I. More important, they were replaced with about 180 college-educated "interns," thus costing us more but giving the students greater benefit.
In addition, the financial statement from the district proves that we were not spending more per child than comparable schools in the city.
In Baltimore and Hartford, economics and not performance were at the heart of the difficulties. Dr. Walter Amprey, the Baltimore Superintendent of Public Education, has stated that our efforts were a success and that "significant gains" in student achievement were made.
In Hartford, we were on target delivering results as promised in our contract.
 
JOHN T. GOLLE
Chairman and Chief Executive
Education Alternatives Inc.

HEADLINE: Short of Money, the French Face Cuts in Their Cherished Military

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: BOURGES, France, Feb. 19

 BODY:
For decades, this town of tank-makers and army bases has thrived on France's determination to be a military giant.
While similar cities in America -- Long Beach, Calif., home of Lockheed, and Groton, Conn., headquarters of General Dynamics -- have suffered from sharp cuts in defense spending, Bourges and its 75,000 people have been cushioned so far by France's strong Gaullist tradition of maintaining an independent national defense, whatever the cost. 
 But that is about to change.
On Thursday, President Jacques Chirac will bow to intense budget pressure and announce a five-year plan to reorganize and reduce by more than a third the 400,000-strong French military and the industrial establishment that feeds it. He is also expected to say the new armed forces should be all-volunteer, like their British and American counterparts.
In a country where military service, an independent nuclear deterrent and a flourishing arms trade are matters of deep national pride, Mr. Chirac's plan for a slimmed-down professional force is a political gamble.
And nowhere more than in cities like Bourges (pronounced boorzh), where the Gaullist ideal of national service is also the means of livelihood for thousands in a time of economic anxiety.
"Here, people wonder where we are headed, and whether Bourges is going to come out all right," said the worried Mayor, Serge Lepeltier, a conservative member of Mr. Chirac's neo-Gaullist party who was elected last June after more than a decade of Communist-dominated government here.
French defense plants and military bases now ring his city like a stockade. But, said Mayor Lepeltier, "The world has changed, and we face much more competition from the defense industry in the United States on the international arms market than we ever did during the cold war."
Tough price competition is blamed for part of a $2.4 billion loss last year at Giat Industries, whose plant employs 1,400 people here. The company, which was entirely Government-owned until 1990 and has 11,500 employees in 12 locations in France, sold 436 Leclerc tanks to the United Arab Emirates for $4 billion in 1994 but had to make so many expensive concessions to wrest the deal from American competitors that currency fluctuations later turned the sale into a loss-maker.
"We live off the Leclerc tank in Bourges," said Mr. Lepeltier. He said Defense Minister Charles Millon had reassured local officials during a visit to the region that the French Army would continue to buy the tank and that the Government would help improve the efficiency of production lines so that it could be sold abroad profitably in the future.
France, unlike Britain, Germany and the United States, has long delayed responding to the industrial consequences of the end of the superpowers' arms race and has continued to support a huge weapons industry that provided 230,000 jobs last year, down from 310,000 in 1982.
But with France trying to reduce its deficit to qualify for a common European currency with Germany by the end of the decade, some people here fear that Mr. Chirac's plans will force them to bite the bullet.
["France must achieve a profound reform of its military and defense establishment, with the transformation of the army and of national service and the reconfiguration of the industrial complex," Mr. Chirac told the Cabinet in Paris on Wednesday, according to the Government spokesman, Alain Lamassoure.
[Mr. Chirac will appear on national television on Thursday night after presiding over a meeting of the national defense council and will suggest a debate on possible alternatives to outright abolition of the draft, which now also supplies civilian agencies like fire departments, ambulance services and parts of the national police, officials said.]
"There's been no attempt yet to prepare public opinion for what's coming," complained Michel Hosmalin, a secretary of the French Democratic Labor Confederation at the Giat plant on the eastern outskirts of Bourges. "The discussions have been held to a small elite around the President so far."
"Unfortunately, in France we don't seem to be able to solve social problems unless we have a confrontation and an explosion first," Mr. Hosmalin joked, recalling the national transportation strike that paralyzed the country at the end of last year until the Government withdrew plans to change the rules for calculating state railroad workers' pensions.
Jean-Claude Sandrier, the previous Mayor of Bourges and a Communist, says the French and European authorities should help defense industries convert to production of civilian goods to save jobs.
"The Government says it wants to build a European defense," he said, "but this should not come at the cost of dismantling the entire French national system unless a referendum shows that a majority of the French people want it that way."
Some other people here find that a bit rich.
"I remember the Communists demonstrating in 1982 and demanding that France stop selling arms abroad," said Jacques-Louis Tabare, who owns a small variety store on the Rue Moyenne, the main shopping street of Bourges. "Now they're changing their tune because arms are jobs in Bourges."
Last Thursday, he and most other storeowners shuttered their shops to show sympathy for about a thousand unionized arms industry employees, including many members of the Communist union, who marched on city hall to warn that Bourges would be a dead city if defense cuts were too precipitous.
"I greeted them at the door to show my solidarity," Mayor Lepeltier said.
But he also told them that Aerospatiale, the company that makes the Exocet air-to-surface missile, was planning to move 500 to 700 workers and their families from Paris to Bourges to centralize production of the missiles here, bringing the company's total employment in Bourges to 2,000 jobs.
But the company employed 2,800 people 15 years ago, when there were 12,000 defense industry jobs in Bourges. Now there are only 5,000, city officials say.
Just up a narrow cobblestone street from Mr. Tabare's shop, the dominant feature of the Bourges skyline -- the magnificent 13th-century Gothic cathedral -- is propped up with French and European Government funds to keep its stone buttresses from crumbling.
Mr. Sandrier suggested that something similar could be done for the defense industry. "What we need now is an urgent French and European conversion fund with money specifically targeted at helping defense industries find new products and different markets," he said.
But with the defense budget frozen at $37.9 billion this year, about the same as last year, the choices ahead look difficult. "When people don't know what's coming, they don't spend," said Mr. Tabare, looking out his shop window at a scattering of teenagers. They looked unlikely to do much for his bottom line even if Mr. Chirac does do away with the draft.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 23, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about France's proposal to reduce its armaments industry, and the plan's effect on the town of Bourges, referred incorrectly to American cities in comparable situations. Long Beach, Calif., is a manufacturing center for McDonnell Douglas, not Lockheed; Groton, Conn., has a plant owned by General Dynamics but is not the company's headquarters.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Inge's Bus Passengers, Stranded Overnight

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY 

 BODY:
DURING the height of his career in the 1950's, the playwright William Inge was sometimes placed in the pantheon of post-World War II giants with Tennessee Williams and Arthur Miller. They were of the same generation, but Inge was not of the stature of the other two, being neither a great poet of the theater nor a grandly dramatic moralist. He was a deceptively prosy sort of writer.
Yet by his attention to the language and behavior of inarticulate, rural Americans, he created a small body of highly theatrical stage literature, works that are rivaled only by those of the far more rigorous Horton Foote. Inge dramatized the melancholy, the humor and the unconscious gallantry of commonplace characters. He saw them mostly in economically depressed but sexually charged circumstances, which proved extremely popular with both the critics and the public. In seven years he turned out the four plays that are his legacy: "Come Back, Little Sheba," 1950; "Picnic," 1953; "Bus Stop," 1955, and "The Dark at the Top of the Stairs," 1957. 
 He continued to work until his suicide in 1973, though nothing he wrote had the impact of those plays. His biggest hit: "Bus Stop," first seen as the memorable Broadway production, directed by Harold Clurman and starring Kim Stanley, then as the considerably rewritten film vehicle for Marilyn Monroe, directed by Josh Logan. It was also the basis of a 1960's television drama series for which Inge himself was a script consultant.
"Bus Stop" is still a good play, but you wouldn't know it from the superficial staging it's being given at the Circle in the Square, where it opened last night. This production and the 1994 Roundabout Theater production of "Picnic" would seem to demonstrate that Inge's work is as resistant to revival today as "Gammer Gurtons Nedle," which is nonsense.
"Bus Stop" is especially rich with possibilities. It can be very funny. It discovers the fresh and the particular within characters who can too easily be seen as archetypes of humdrum Americana. It's also constructed with an innate sense of a form that works well in popular theater:
A blizzard strands four bus passengers overnight in a small-town diner 40 miles west of Kansas City. They are Cherie, a pretty, not too bright, Ozarks-born B-girl and self-styled chanteuse; Bo, a strapping, lovesick young rodeo rider who's taking Cherie home to Montana to marry her, oblivious to the fact that she doesn't want to marry him; Virgil, Bo's brains and older pal, and Dr. Lyman, an alcoholic, Harvard-educated Ph.D. with a fondness for girls under the age of consent.
In the course of this fraught, turbulent night, Bo courts Cherie like a bull going after a blond mouse, Dr. Lyman romances Elma, the literature-loving, teen-age waitress, while Grace, the owner of the diner, finds time to accommodate Carl, the macho bus driver for whom she has long had an itch. Will, the local sheriff, and Virgil are the unsurprised spectators to the mayhem.
"Bus Stop" can be accurately described as a fugue whose themes are the various aspects of love. That, however, is to freight the text with meanings that should creep out in their own good time. It's primarily a comedy whose genuine sweetness never long disguises the bleak nature of the lives it's recording. Inge was too clear-eyed to be an outright sentimentalist. He longed for happy endings, but the ones he provided (and which soothed audiences) always left the door open for disaster.
He definitely was not a regional humorist. Yet this is the dominant impression you get from Josephine R. Abady's new production of "Bus Stop." In part this is because the principal performances appear to have been shaped in desperation. Though the actors are thorough professionals, they give the impression of being less concerned with the sense of their roles than with accommodating their uncomfortable rural accents while speaking their lines.
There's no doubt that Mary-Louise Parker and Billy Crudup, who play Cherie and Bo, are excellent actors. You should remember her in "Prelude to a Kiss" and him as one of the bright spots in "Arcadia." Yet both are allowed to sound like relatives visiting "The Beverly Hillbillies." It's not a question of the accuracy of their accents, but of the balance, of the way the accents take precedence in the performances, in this way clouding the characterizations instead of revealing them.
Wearing skintight toreador pants and a scrawny jacket of fake leopard, Ms. Parker looks exquisite and fragile as the besieged Cherie, but as soon as she opens her mouth we seem to be in a vaudeville sketch. In addition to his accent, the slightly built Mr. Crudup has another problem. He's physically miscast as the swaggering, rough-and-tumble bronco rider who has no idea of his own dangerous heft. As a result, Cherie and Bo don't seem to be involved in any deliriously crazy courtship, but in a contest to see who can outact the other. Everything seems too forced.
Patricia Dunnock is charming as the Shakespeare-quoting teen-age waitress, who's quite pleased when she learns that the elderly Dr. Lyman did have lascivious designs on her. Ron Perlman plays this fellow with fey elegance, and with less of any recognizable accent than with an insinuating W. C. Fields kind of slur. Kelly Bishop as the diner owner, the role originated by Elaine Stritch; Larry Pine as Virgil; Scott Sowers as Will, and Michael Cullen as Carl are all as good as they can be in a production that appears to condescend to the play.
Ms. Abady uses the stage space well. There's seldom the awareness that the actors are arbitrarily turning this way and that to allow the members of the audience, who are seated around the four sides of the stage, equal access to front views and profiles.
It should be noted that the performance seems to improve somewhat as it goes on. But it's anybody's guess whether this is because the performance really does get better, because one becomes adjusted to its failings, or because Inge's voice will not be stilled, no matter what the obstacles. Possibly it's a bit of all three.
 
BUS STOP
 
By William Inge; directed by Josephine R. Abady; sets by Hugh Landwehr; costumes by Linda Fisher; lighting by Dennis Parichy; sound by Tom Gould. Presented by Circle in the Square, Theodore Mann and Ms. Abady, co-artistic directors. At 1633 Broadway, at 50th Street, Manhattan.

WITH: Mary-Louise Parker (Cherie), Ron Perlman (Dr. Gerald Lyman), Billy Crudup (Bo Decker), Michael Cullen (Carl), Patricia Dunnock (Elma Duckworth), Larry Pine (Virgil Blessing), Scott Sowers (Will Masters) and Kelly Bishop (Grace Hoylard).
