HEADLINE: Wanted: Jobs of Last Resort

BYLINE: By Sheldon Danziger and Peter Gottschalk; Sheldon Danziger is professor of social work and public policy at the University of Michigan. Peter Gottschalk is professor of economics at Boston College.

 BODY:
Members of the National Governors' Association were on Capitol Hill yesterday, once again pressing their case for welfare reform. The group has captured glowing reviews from both President Clinton and Congressional Republicans for a package of proposals that would favor block grants to the states over a guarantee of Federal aid.
Liberal Democrats in the House have criticized the plan, saying its cuts in Federal spending are simply too hard on the poor. But they have not given enough attention to what is perhaps the plan's most problematic feature: It would end welfare recipients' entitlement to cash assistance -- after as little as 21 months in Connecticut -- even for those who, though diligently searching for work, cannot find anyone to hire them. 
 These provisions assume that anyone who really wants to work can find a job. And no one would dispute that any welfare reform proposal should require recipients to make a serious effort to find employment. But the proposal must be more realistic about the current demand for low-skilled workers, which has dropped steadily over the last two decades.
To take just one small but alarming example, the number of high school dropouts who are employed has steadily dropped since 1970 -- while the number of employed college graduates has risen by more than 40 percent.
Economists of all political persuasions have documented the increased extent of insecurity among American workers. Moderate economic growth since the early 1980's has on average raised our living standards, but low-skilled workers have seen the least benefit. The lack of jobs that pay adequately obviously bodes even worse for people trying desperately to get off welfare. Today, 45 percent of women who leave welfare find themselves back on it within a year.
The decline in demand for less-skilled workers is not so much the fault of Republicans or Democrats as it is of the changing economy. Real wages for low-skilled workers steadily diminished under Presidents Jimmy Carter, Ronald Reagan and George Bush, just as they continue to erode today. But these Administrations do share responsibility for the extent of the hardship. Government simply has not adapted its policies to deal with an economy in which the number of industrial jobs is shrinking.
The consensus among most Democrats and Republicans that welfare should be transformed from a cash-based to a work-based safety net is a promising development. But it will not be fulfilled by the governors' compromise unless their plan provides emergency help for people who have tried to find work and can't. Low-wage public service jobs of last resort would be the best way to provide such help.
The governors can improve their plan, which they hope will form the basis of Federal legislation, by requiring that states offer unsuccessful job seekers the kind of work-based safety net that Gov. John Engler has proposed for Michigan.
His proposal allows recipients who cannot find employment to perform community service in return for continued cash assistance. This provision is important in an economy in which the trend toward downsizing shows no sign of slowing, and it will be critical during any future recession. The National Governors' Association would be wise to include Mr. Engler's work-for-your welfare community service idea in its proposals.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Pat Calls the Tune

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Give him credit. Pat Buchanan has forced attention to the most important political fact in the country today: the belief of ordinary people that they are losing out in economic status and security.
Many Americans have seen their earnings stagnate or decline over the last 20 years. Thousands of middle-class people have lost their jobs in downsizings by blue-chip companies and merged banks. So voters respond when Mr. Buchanan says: "When AT&T lops off 40,000 jobs, the executioner that does it, he's a big hero on the cover of one of these magazines, and AT&T stock soars." 
Another service Mr. Buchanan has performed is to show that Gingrich ism is dead. Voters do not share the obsession of House Republicans with balancing the budget and gutting environmental protection. They care about their economic pain, not the Contract With America.
The trouble is that Mr. Buchanan offers quack remedies. Put a 40 percent tariff on all Chinese goods coming to this country: a nice round number. But what would China do about the American entrepreneurs trying to enter its huge market? And what would happen to political and military stresses in Asia?
The Buchanan program is essentially Stop the world, I want to get off. And that is a fantasy. The world market is here to stay. If America tried to wall itself off, we would simply fall behind other countries in economic creativity and growth.
Mr. Buchanan's success with his message is really a challenge to other political leaders, Republicans and Democrats, to offer serious remedies. For one, education is the key to individual and societal advancement in today's sophisticated economies. Yet American schools are crying out for reform and enrichment.
The need for better-trained Americans to compete in the world is a favorite theme of the Secretary of Labor, Robert Reich. This week it was taken up by the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, who said we were falling behind and called for "renewed commitment to effective education and training, especially on-the-job training."
So voices on both left and right point to the need for better-educated Americans. (Mr. Buchanan's main comment on the subject has been a demand to "shut down the Department of Education and return authority to the states and to the people.")
It is extremely important for Bob Dole and Lamar Alexander -- and President Clinton -- to address the public's economic fears. For unless they are convincingly addressed, they are the classic invitation to demagogy.
American history has been marked again and again by populist movements that worked off economic grievances by attacks on foreigners, bankers and "the elite." There were the anti-Catholic Know-Nothings in the middle of the last century, the Populists at the end of it (turning racist in the South), Huey Long in Depression Louisiana, the anti-Semitic radio priest Father Coughlin, the racist George Wallace.
The American economy is not, in fact, in the dreadful state the doomsayers claim. Unemployment is half the rate in major European countries. But people do feel menaced, and that is a critical reality.
The danger is increased by the growing disparities of wealth and income in this country. I recently saw an investment policy letter from PaineWebber, the financial house, that foresaw a widening gulf and advised its clients to invest accordingly. In five years, it said, the number of people with a net worth over $1 million excluding residences had "increased a whopping 91 percent."
That way -- toward the rich getting an ever-larger slice of the pie -- lies a resentful society. The other day a woman in California telephoned to say that I did not understand why people were for Pat Buchanan. She said:
"Big business and Government have wed. They don't care about this country. They pledge allegiance to the dollar of any country where they can get the most. None of the other Republicans can see that a few people control the United States of America when it was designed by the people, for the people."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Buying by British and Japanese Doesn't Lift Dollar Significantly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed yesterday despite a coordinated effort by the Bank of Japan and the Bank of England to buy dollars, currency traders said .
The Japanese central bank was in the Asian foreign-exchange market earlier this week, traders said, buying billions of dollars. Market participants believe the Japanese want the dollar at no less than 105 yen. 
 Traders said they saw signs yesterday that the Japanese effort was receiving help abroad. The Bank of England was buying dollars between 104.85 and 104.90 yen on behalf of the Bank of Japan, traders said.
But speculators tested those levels, restricting the dollar's gains. Still, without the intervention, the dollar would probably be lower since private sector demand for the dollar was low, said John Rothfield, an international economist at Nationsbank-CRT in Chicago.
Mr. Rothfield said it made sense for the Bank of Japan to leave "orders with central banks in other time zones since their intervention didn't work."
The Japanese and British central banks do not comment on their market activities.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar was trading at 1.4497 German marks, down from 1.4499 marks on Wednesday. It rose to 105.05 yen from 104.98 yen. The British pound rose to $1.5446 from $1.5430.
Coordination between two central banks would not be unusual. The Group of Seven industrial nations have been working since last spring to help the dollar recoup from postwar lows.
Part of the Bank of Japan's effort to strengthen the dollar involves a strategy that allowed investors to borrow yen at competitively low Japanese interest rates and invest in United States and South African securities with higher yields.
But the South African rand's dismal performance last week drove the dollar down world wide. Now traders are reluctant to make the same play, and market participants say this has led to the dollar's slide.
In other currency trading in New York yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.1800 Swiss francs, down from 1.1833 on Wednesday; 4.9838 French francs, down from 4.9968, and 1,570 Italian lire, down from 1,574.

HEADLINE: Counties Reaching for Lilco Tax Accord

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Summoned to Gov. George E. Pataki's office at the World Trade Center in Manhattan, top officials of Nassau and Suffolk counties said yesterday that they were moving toward resolving a tax refund issue that is the major stumbling block in a complex plan to dismantle the Long Island Lighting Company.
Their joint announcement, after a two-hour meeting, appeared to clear the way for the Long Island Power Authority, the state agency that drafted the takeover plan, to vote next week to open negotiations with the utility's management. 
 Both Thomas S. Gulotta, the Nassau County Executive, and Robert J. Gaffney, the Suffolk County Executive, endorsed the authority's moving ahead -- even as they vowed to continue talks on the tax issue.
"We anticipate we will reach an agreement," Mr. Gulotta said at an impromptu news conference after the private meeting. Mr. Gaffney said that "we want the plan to go forward" to replace Lilco. The plan is expected to cut electricity rates on Long Island by at least 12 percent.
Although the Governor was not present, his deputy secretary, Louis Tomson, helped oversee the meeting. The session was an example of Mr. Pataki's efforts to bring opposing sides together on thorny issues, as he did recently in brokering an agreement between New York City and upstate communities on a plan to protect the city's watershed.
Also taking part in the Lilco meeting was James F. Gill, the Power Authority's chairman. He said the two County Executives "made wonderful progress and I am confident they will work out this problem."
In past weeks, the County Executives have wavered and shifted on the Lilco plan. Mr. Gaffney was silent for weeks before offering qualified support. Mr. Gulotta at first endorsed it but then turned cold.
At issue is an enormous tax-refund liability caused by years of overassessment on the Shoreham nuclear power plant, which never went into service. Those excess tax revenues benefited Suffolk County, Brookhaven Town and the Shoreham-Wading River School District.
Lilco paid the taxes, which were included in electric rates charged all its customers, in Nassau, Suffolk and the Rockaways. Lilco began challenging the assessments in court and so far has been winning.
Suffolk officials have been trying to win an exemption as part of the overall plan to replace Lilco. But Nassau officials, who argue that their residents and businesses paid artificially high electric rates to subsidize low taxes in Suffolk, say that is unfair.
Speaking after the meeting, Mr. Gaffney at first did not mention the tax issue. He spoke of the need to eliminate Lilco, introduce competition and lower the Island's electric rates, now the highest in the continental United States.
Mr. Gulotta stressed those same points, but he did not forget the tax issue. "That one component remains a subject of discussion with Bob and me," he said. "It's a significant issue to Nassau County."
Although Mr. Gill has agreed with Nassau in principle, he is trying to avoid losing the broader objective of the Lilco takeover because of the tax issue. "I don't want people to be distracted by that," Mr. Gill said.
Mr. Gill has entertained one proposal that would charge Suffolk residents one percent more in their electric rates for 30 years, a solution Mr. Gaffney favors.
But Nassau officials say that would provide its residents too little relief and take too long. Suffolk officials say that if they pay too high a penalty, the disparity in electric rates will cause economic dislocation, inducing businesses to move to Nassau.
"I think it is doable," said one of the aides at the meeting, speaking on the condition that he not be identified. Referring to the two County Executives, the aide said: "Bob understands that the 30-year payout is not acceptable to Tom, and Tom understands that Bob can't afford a big rate discrepancy. They're looking for a number that everybody is comfortable with."
The Power Authority's vote next week is only the next in a series of steps. If Lilco agrees on a takeover plan, it would require approval by the authority's board, the stockholders and a panel composed of the Governor; the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, and the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bonds Gain on Hope Of Rate Cut

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended moderately higher yesterday, buoyed by a resilient optimism that the Federal Reserve would soon cut interest rates again.
The market's optimism was fed by a sharper-than-expected rise in weekly unemployment claims. The data pointed to mounting weakness in the economy, which market participants expect will compel the Fed to cut short-term rates. 
 While bond prices received a boost from the claims data, some investors took their gains and sold. As a result, the market continued to have trouble sustaining upticks in price.
A certain pessimism also limited gains tied to speculation that the Federal Reserve was in the market yesterday buying short-term securities. While such talk bolstered the short end of the market, analysts said it suggested that central banks might have been responsible for much of the recent buying, not bargain-hunting investors.
Still, there are signs that market participants are optimistic following a four-session selloff that ended Wednesday. James Hale, a fixed-income analyst with MMS International in San Francisco, said that while there was a cautious tone in the market, the worst selling was over. He noted that Smith Barney had recently raised the bond allocation in its model portfolio to 35 percent from 30 percent and cut its cash position by 5 percent.
The price of the 30-year bond ended up17/32of a percentage point yesterday, to 95 20/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.33 percent, from 6.37 percent on Wednesday.
Yesterday's weekly report on unemployment claims from the Labor Department showed an increase of 5,000 initial filings to a total of 391,000 for the week ended Feb. 17, up from 386,000 the week before.
Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, said the four-week moving average was down by 5,250 claimants, to 383,000, from 388,250 the week before. "With this most recently reported data," she said, "initial unemployment claims have continued to approach the 400,000 level -- to some, a mark of recessionary conditions in the labor market."
She said the market regarded the weekly claims report with greater interest yesterday because Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, cited the data in his testimony before Congress on Tuesday and Wednesday.
The market will soon turn its attention again to supply as the Treasury prepares to auction new two-year and five-year notes next week. Many traders say they expect dealers will make more concessions on the notes to attract buyers.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.10 percent, and the five-year, 5.45 percent.
The Treasury sold $29 billion of 55-day cash management bills yesterday at an average rate of 5.02 percent, and traders said demand was strong. The Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, said the sale of the 55-day bills -- to meet the Treasury's short-term borrowing needs beyond the money raised through the Government's regularly scheduled auctions -- was intended to cover Social Security payments and keep the Government running through the middle of March.
Earlier in the month, President Clinton signed legislation allowing the the Treasury to sell the bills even though Congress has yet to raise the debt limit. The legislation allows the Government to pay its obligations through mid-March while the Administration and Congress try to work out an agreement on a budget plan.
Rates at yesterday's auction were higher than those at this week's regular weekly bill auction of new three-month and six-month maturities, suggesting that traders and investors are demanding more compensation while the budget debate continues.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of 55-day cash management bills:

HEADLINE: Law Knows No City Limits;
As New York's Firms Thin Out, Outsiders Rush In

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Reed Smith Shaw & McClay, a 118-year-old Pittsburgh law firm, had consciously avoided the costs and competition in New York. Last year it hired an international lawyer, Alan A. D'Ambrosio, away from the New York firm of Schnader Harrison Segal & Lewis and put him in charge of a new Reed Smith office in Manhattan. "We realized that we could never get a reputation in the international arena without a New York office," said David W. Christopher, Reed Smith's chief administrative officer.
Pitney, Hardin, Kipp & Szuch, a 150-lawyer firm in Morristown, N.J., opened a tiny New York office two years ago to serve one domestic client. Now it is expanding that office, in hopes of wooing foreign business. "Offshore clients won't even consider you unless you are in New York," said Clyde A. Szuch, a partner. 
 Linklaters & Paines, the mammoth London firm, used to send lawyers to New York regularly to advise American investors about London-based capital markets. Linklaters now has 25 full-time New York lawyers. "Our business is servicing the capital flow, and now that flow is both ways," said David M. Barnard, a New York-based partner.
At a time when New York law firms large and small are struggling -- and some even collapsing -- under the burdens of huge overheads, defecting partners and squeezed fees, out-of-town firms are gleefully expanding in New York. "It seems every large law firm wants to be here," said Klaus Eppler, president of the New York County Lawyers Association.
Apparently so. According to The New York Law Journal, between 1990 and 1995 the number of lawyers at the 25 largest New York branch offices of out-of-town firms grew by 27 percent, to 1,821; the numbers at the 25 largest homegrown firms shrank 4 percent, to 7,409.
Meanwhile, small branch offices keep opening. The influx is so great that the Association of the Bar of the City of New York is, for the first time, compiling a list of those offices so it can notify them of association services and prod them to do pro bono work. "Now there are just too many for us to keep up," an association spokeswoman said. For their part, old-time New York lawyers profess not to be worried about the competition. "The firms that did not survive had serious management problems and cultural problems," said Jerome C. Katz, a partner in Chadbourne & Parke, a 94-year-old New York firm. "You can't infer from the breakup of a few law firms that the demand for exceptionally good lawyers isn't still very high."
But why are the out-of-towners all coming now? Mr. Katz has an answer for that, too. "Their markets have matured, and lawyers are always searching for new demand," he said. "For us that meant opening four offices overseas in five years; for out-of-town firms, it means opening offices in New York." Perhaps most important, New York -- historically a hub for finance and corporate law -- is finally a nut that can be cracked.
New industries are opening here -- interactive technology is the most visible one -- that have no entrenched connections with local law firms. And international business traffic in and out of New York is increasing exponentially. More foreign banks are lending money to New York landlords, more foreign retailers are opening stores, more foreign investors are buying property and even companies.
All of them need New York lawyers to ease their way, but few have longstanding legal relationships in the city. And when they do, it is generally with a lawyer, not a firm. As recently as a decade ago that was a specious distinction: lawyers and law firms bonded for life. Today, lawyers readily take clients from firm to firm.
Indeed, entire ready-made practices are becoming available, as many New York law firms succumb to an array of strains that collectively apply relentless economic pressure on once-stable practices. Many have invested heavily in new computer systems that among other things can fit an entire law library on a few disks but that ironically enable them to do a client's work more quickly and thus reduce their billable hours. Many are still paying huge rents and salaries they agreed to in the high-flying 1980's. Yet many are being pressed by corporations to do more for less, or lose the business.
The toll has been high. Shea & Gould, once the epitome of legal prestige and opulence, dissolved amid partner bitterness two years ago. Lord Day & Lord, Barrett Smith and Bower & Gardner are gone, victims of high costs and too-rapid expansion. Townley & Updike just went down. Mudge Rose Guthrie Alexander & Ferdon is disbanding.
The out-of-town firms are happily picking the carcasses. Morgan, Lewis & Bockius, once firmly ensconced in Philadelphia, picked up nearly 60 partners from Lord, Day & Lord, and now has about 200 lawyers in New York, almost as many as it has at home. Mudge Rose lawyers are at the New York offices of the Los Angeles firms of Latham & Watkins and O'Melveny & Myers, and of San Francisco-based Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe. Orrick, in fact, has built almost its entire 125-member New York office by lifting practices from other firms.
"It is great when you take entire practices because the lawyers are used to working together; they feel stable," said Ralph H. Baxter Jr., Orrick's chairman.
The availability of a juicy law practice can actually tip the scales for an out-of-town firm weighing a New York move or expansion. A few years ago, Orrick found out that the 12-member labor law department of Baer, Marks & Upham was ready to move, and voila, Orrick started a New York labor practice. "If they had been in Washington, we would have done it there," Mr. Baxter said.
Similarly, until recently Reed Smith's growth strategy involved spattering the Middle Atlantic region with satellite offices, the most recent in Princeton, N.J., in 1994. New York was not part of the equation until Mr. D'Ambrosio, whose client roster includes Gucci and other high-profile European companies, said he would join.
"Until then, the idea of New York was a skeleton we'd periodically dust off, talk about fleshing out, then just put back into the closet," said Daniel I. Booker, the firm's managing partner.
Firms like Reed, Smith have discovered that a New York beachhead not only gives them access to new clients but also lets them wrench more business from existing ones.
Dimeling, Schreiber & Park, a Philadelphia management buyout firm -- and a Reed, Smith client -- has often been forced by New York lenders to get opinions from New York lawyers. Now it will steer that business to Reed, Smith. "We save the cost of educating two law firms on one transaction, and we avoid the higher New York law firm fees," said William R. Dimeling, a partner.
The cost differential can be considerable. Mr. Szuch, for example, suggests that a top New Jersey lawyer would charge maybe $350 or $375 an hour, while an associate's time would be billed at $150 to $175. Their New York equivalents, Mr. Szuch says, would be charging at least $100 an hour more.
It is not surprising that many out-of-town firms ship the necessary legal scut work back to the home office, where associates' salaries and office rents are lower than in New York. "That's why we can offer New York law at New Jersey prices," Mr. Szuch said.
And they can measure their growth, hiring lawyers as they need them, and cherry-picking practice areas to avoid those where local legal stars seem to have a lock on the biggest clients.
"We'll stick with our mainstay real estate, international and corporate law practice," Mr. D'Ambrosio of Reed, Smith said. "We won't compete in product liability, intellectual property, mergers and acquisitions, or other areas where we can do it cheaper, but not necessarily better."
The new firms also often have more manageable real estate costs. Rents are nowhere near as high as they were in the 1980's, when many New York firms were locked into long-term leases. And today's clients often view fancy offices not as symbols of success, but as signs of ostentation and fee bloating.
Many new firms try to compromise between shabby and chic, and choose either a fancy building or a fancy address. Linklaters is in the "Lipstick building," a smart building on mundane Third Avenue at 53d Street, because "being on Park or Fifth was never important to us," Mr. Barnard said. Orrick last year moved into 666 Fifth Avenue, a nice address for a fairly old, albeit recently renovated, building at 52d Street.
"Our offices look professional, but not opulent," Mr. Baxter said. "Our clients won't think we're spending too much money on overhead, but they won't think they are at a discount center, either."
Of course, not all out-of-town firms are immune to the practices that felled some of their New York predecessors.
Linklaters, for one, plans to recruit a half-dozen or so graduates from top law schools. Mr. Barnard is ready to pay top dollar for them -- and charge top dollar for their services. "The guys who say, 'Hey, we're from Pittsburgh and don't pay our lawyers as much,' are making a statement about how they value expertise," he said.
Reed, Smith's new office is in the Seagram Building, the elegant 52d Street tower on Park Avenue that has some of New York's highest rents. Mr. Christopher insists that while American clients may be glitz-averse, offshore clients are not.
"We know we are paying a premium, but if you want to establish an international boutique, you do want the Park Avenue image," he said. Mr. Booker added, "We see New York as important for marketing purposes in a way that the Princeton office, say, is not."
That attitude, even among firms in less spectacular digs, may give the out-of-town firms their most formidable competitive weapon. Many feel less pressure to meet high costs with high fees because they see their New York offices as marketing tools for the rest of the firm.
"We'd never say, 'All right, New York, your expenses were this but your revenues were that, buck up,' " Mr. Baxter of Orrick said. "New York may send great clients to California."
Still, even with lower expectations, the New York newcomers may still hit obstacles. New York firms, angry at the competition, may stop making lucrative referrals to them in their hometowns. They may grow to the point where their costs simply cannot be absorbed by marketing budgets, and where their partners indulge in the same kind of infighting that killed Shea & Gould.
"When you start merging people who come from different firms, the sense of a cohesive culture frays," warned Barbara Paul Robinson, the New York bar association's president. "The result is not always a marriage that sticks."

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Rise by 5,000

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
The number of first-time claims for jobless benefits unexpectedly rose by 5,000 last week, which analysts said reflected a soft labor market.
The Labor Department said today that claims totaled a seasonally adjusted 391,000, up from 386,000 a week earlier. Many analysts had expected a slight decline. 
 It was the second straight advance and raised the number of new claims to the highest level since 412,000 applications in the week ended Jan. 20. Analysts had attributed the 96,000 jump that week to filings that were delayed when the January blizzard closed many unemployment offices.
The four-week moving average of new weekly jobless claims fell by 5,250, to 383,000; the latest average did not include the week ended Jan. 20.
Analysts usually prefer to track the less volatile four-week average because it smooths out spikes in the weekly reports.

HEADLINE: 16 Child-Abuse Programs Are Facing Shutdowns

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
Sixteen child-abuse-prevention programs in the city's Beacon School network of after-school educational programs could be forced to close next week unless the Giuliani administration spends $1.2 million to keep them open, city officials and social service providers said yesterday. The programs provide counseling, supervision and instruction to more than 2,500 children considered at risk of neglect or abuse.
The Beacon School network is run in conjunction with the city's child-protection agency. Many of the children and families involved in the programs are ordered into them by city caseworkers and the courts. 
 "We have not been ordered to close our doors," said Jim Marley, an official with the Pius XII Community Services, which runs one of the preventive programs at Middle School 45 in the Bronx. "But we will run out of money on Feb. 29. We will be gone after that."
The money for the programs dried up when the state slashed its appropriations for preventive services last year. The people who run the programs said that City Council officials assured them last June that the programs would be kept alive when the Mayor's budget was modified in November. But Council officials conceded yesterday that they had neglected to insure that the money was appropriated during negotiations.
Deciding whether to provide the $1.2 million necessary to keep the programs open could pose an awkward challenge for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. He has said for weeks that protection of the city's children is his top priority. And after a week's worth of disturbing child-abuse cases, Nicholas Scoppetta, the Commissioner of the Administration for Children's Services, has repeatedly said that his agency's budget of $1.2 billion will not be cut.
But the administration, reeling from budget shortfalls, has also indicated that there are limits to its ability to solve a crisis it says has been created by state budget cuts.
First Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers said yesterday that it was far from certain that the city would provide funds to keep the programs afloat through the end of the school year. He said the city had come up with $3.5 million eight months ago for the programs when the state slashed its budget for what are known as preventive services.
"We are in tight economic times," said Mr. Powers. "We are ready to take a look at which of these programs are working." Mr. Powers said that some of the programs might be closed and others asked to accept reduced funds.
The heads of the programs said a decision by the city not to allocate the $1.2 million could have serious consequences for the child welfare agency, which is responsible for 43,000 foster-care children. Indeed, Mr. Scoppetta, appearing at a news conference announcing the indictment of a Brooklyn husband and wife for the brutal beating of their son, conceded yesterday that "the system is in crisis," with caseworkers overburdened and often ill trained.
"The city has been aware of this problem with funding the programs since last October," said Jean Thomases, associate executive director of Good Shepherd Services, which runs a Beacon child-abuse program at P.S. 15 in Red Hook, Brooklyn. "We thought they would take care of it because it seemed to be right in there with their core goals."
Officials with the programs said that since 1992, when the effort began, city officials had regarded the Beacon School programs as models of cost-effective abuse prevention.
At Intermediate School 302 in the Cypress Hills section of Brooklyn, Larry Shweky said that his staff of three social workers was working with 45 families with children who might have been added to the city's foster-care population.
"Teachers who suspect abuse or neglect direct children to us," said Mr. Shweky. "Parents come in and say they fear for their children's safety. And they come because they know us."
Thomas L. McMahon, the City Council's director of finance, said that even a brief gap in financing could close the programs. He said that the City Council, which is to vote on the Mayor's most recent budget modifications on March 7, would seek to persuade the administration to provide the emergency money.
"What the resolution will be, I'm not sure," he said.

HEADLINE: Blunt Talker On Budgets And Deficits

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Perhaps no one in the Clinton Administration gets as fired up as Alice M. Rivlin about eliminating the Federal budget deficit. As director of the Office of Management and Budget since October 1994 and deputy director for 20 months before, she has been a powerful voice for balancing the budget -- and in this her views are strongly akin to those of Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman.
But Administration colleagues took pains to make clear that Ms. Rivlin, nominated yesterday to be the Fed's vice chairman, would not favor policies that took income away from Americans unnecessarily. And, they said, Ms. Rivlin, 64, would bring to the Fed a backbone that is likely to make her as sturdy a point person for the Administration as her predecessor, Alan S. Blinder, although less public about it. 
 Still, Ms. Rivlin holds views on economic growth that sometimes seem closer to those of Mr. Greenspan than to those of Mr. Clinton, who has suggested that the economy might benefit from more economic growth than Mr. Greenspan seems to favor.
Once, for example, Ms. Rivlin criticized the President for wanting to spend billions on public investments -- in part to stimulate economic growth -- rather than using the funds to cut the deficit.
Ms. Rivlin, who earned her Ph.D. in economics at Radcliffe College in 1958, was the founding director of the Congressional Budget Office. She has served as president of the American Economic Association, worked in the Johnson Administration, and was director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution.
Her marriage to Lewis A. Rivlin ended in divorce and she has since remarried to Sidney Winter. She has three grown children.

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT CUTS MAY CAUSE LOSSES IN LOAN PROGRAMS

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
When President Clinton delivered his State of the Union Message last month, no part was more warmly applauded than his declaration that the "era of big government is over."
To the audience and the President, "big government" meant the huge Federal bureaucracy, with its thousands of programs and workers. But even as the number of Federal workers has begun to shrink significantly for the first time in decades, there has been enormous growth in a largely unnoticed side of the ledger: Federal liabilities. 
 Each time a student or small business takes out a Federal loan, or a home buyer seeks a Federally guaranteed mortgage, or a farmer seeks Federal insurance against crop damage, the Government's liabilities grow. And the list of Federal liabilities, including loans, loan guarantees and insurance, is expanding so fast that by 1998 Federal loan guarantees alone are expected to exceed $1 trillion, up from $600 billion in 1992, according to the Office of Management and Budget. And in 1995 the Government set aside between $180 billion and $300 billion to cover costs and estimated losses on these programs.
"People want the Government to go away, to be less intrusive, less bureaucratic and more efficient," said John A. Koskinen, O.M.B.'s deputy director for management. "But they also want all the guarantees, the insurance, the promises. It's built into the fabric of their assumptions about what their lifestyle is like."
But with this unheralded growth of the Government's liabilities has come major cuts, beginning with Ronald Reagan, in the numbers of inspectors, auditors and regulators to oversee Federal loans, promises and projects. And with less oversight, experts warn, the financial health of the Federal Government's loan and insurance programs is at increased risk.
The Comptroller General, Charles A. Bowsher, said the General Accounting Office's recent audits have found that the Government now has insufficient financial accounting systems and managers to insure that those liabilities are properly monitored. Consequently, he believes the Government cannot afford to further weaken this system of controls as it continues to take on more responsibilities for loans and financial promises.
"When you don't have the management systems in place," Mr. Bowsher said, "you're taking a really big risk in downsizing, especially when there are a lot of things on the liability side of the balance sheet that are going up. You have to extend oversight."
During the 1980's, Government commitments grew, but, in the name of deregulation, Federal oversight was all too often lax, numerous reports show. Eventually, little-noticed Government insurance and credit programs lost hundreds of billions of dollars as the savings and loan industry collapsed, and farm, student and housing loan programs experienced large defaults.
This led to the Federal Credit Reform Act of 1990, a widely praised law that requires that agencies annually set aside anticipated losses in credit programs.
Mr. Koskinen of the O.M.B. pointed to that law in saying that he did not share Mr. Bowsher's worries. He said he believed that the Government has a better understanding of the cost of credit programs, and that the Administration has appropriate systems in place to do better with less.
He added that overseeing rising liabilities with dwindling resources presents "a risk if agencies don't have enough resources, if they cut willy-nilly."
Indeed, the Clinton plan to reinvent Government has won wide praise for making the Government more in tune to consumers; Mr. Bowsher is one of those who applaud the improved customer relations. Moreover, many of the new loans are aimed at people most in need.
For example, guaranteed loans to small businesses have gone to $25 billion in 1994, from $12 billion in 1990. Loan guarantees for companies doing business abroad have almost tripled over the same time frame.
 
Less Supervision, Mounting Liabilities
Since Mr. Clinton took office, more than 200,000 Federal positions have been cut from the Government payrolls, a point the President repeats time and time again. His Republican opponents on the campaign trail are also championing the cause of a smaller Federal Government. But neither the Republicans nor Mr. Clinton are talking about the potential dangers that can come from shrinking the Government.
There is no Government-wide survey showing exactly which Federal positions have been eliminated under Mr. Clinton. But his plan to reinvent Government specifically targeted supervisory personnel, budget analysts, accountants and auditors.
Meanwhile, the Government's insurance and credit backing programs stood at $7.3 trillion in 1994, up from $4.4 trillion in 1985.
"The United States Government is like a big holding company, a big insurance company that's underwriting all the catastrophes. These entities are like underground rivers, only when it rains do you see them," said Edward J. Kane, a professor of finance at Boston College who in the mid-eighties made the most accurate prediction of the impending savings and loan debacle, which bankrupted a federal deposit insurance fund.
Some of this recent growth in guaranteeing loans stems from the Clinton Administration's emphasis on making Federal credit more accessible to women and minorities. At the Small Business Administration last year, for example, loans to women-owned businesses went up 84 percent, and loans to minority-owned businesses went up 53 percent.
Moreover, traditional business interests, like real estate developers and lenders, continue to benefit from Federal credit programs. The Labor Department is helping Federally insured pension funds invest in urban mortgages; the student loan program is being expanded, and agencies like the Export Import Bank and the Overseas Private Investment Corporation are doing more to help American businesses operating abroad.
 
Cutting the Staffs That Monitor Programs
The G.A.O. is charged with auditing the Federal Government for Congress and is another tier in the internal controls system. On average, the G.A.O. says it saves the Government $15 billion a year through its audits.
Even though a new law increases the G.A.O.'s responsibilities for oversight, Congress has cut the G.A.O.'s staff by about 30 percent in four years. Mr. Bowsher, the head of the accounting office, said that he was worried that his agency has lost scores of accountants and other technical specialists, but that according to the agency's latest annual report, the G.A.O. has been able to fulfill its supervisory responsibilities by investing in new management systems.
But studies by the G.A.O. show that other parts of the Government generally have been unable to figure out how to build modern computerized systems to manage their risks.
Mr. Bowsher said one bright spot is the improved oversight of student loans by the Education Department.
Another level of Federal oversight consists of inspectors general, who perform somewhat like independent auditors.
The inspector general of the Small Business Administration, James F. Hoobler, has had his budget and number of positions reduced. While Mr. Hoobler said in an interview that the S.B.A. was making significant progress in deterring people from misstating their income on loan applications, he also said the combination of dwindling resources and expanded programs was a risky combination.
"You cannot increase the Government's loan guarantees and cut the personnel for managing them and reduce or hold steady the oversight without increasing the risk," he said, adding, "it is a formula for disaster over time."
 
An Agency Tries Doing More With Less
Philip Lader, the S.B.A. administrator, said his agency was a model for how the Administration has reinvented Government by slimming the agency in partnership with the private sector, producing results by expanding Federal credit opportunities yet protecting the Government's assets. Earlier this month, President Clinton talked about the S.B.A. in an appearance in New Hampshire.
"One of the things I'm proudest of about our Administration and all the work we've done to try and give the American people a Government that costs less and does more is that we have reduced the budget of S.B.A. by about 40 percent and we've doubled the loan volume," Mr. Clinton told the gathering.
The President praised an 18-month-old S.B.A. pilot program, called Lowdoc, in which applicants for loans of up to $100,000 can obtain approval in a few days with only minimal S.B.A. paperwork. The Lowdoc program accounted for 56 percent of the agency's 55,600 loans last year.
Mr. Lader said that "doing more with less increases somewhat the taxpayer's exposure" for the S.B.A., which backs $32 billion in loans, but that one solution has been to rely more on private lenders, whose loans the agency guarantees.
Already those lenders are sounding an alarm.
"Clearly in Lowdoc they pushed it out the door too soon," said Tony Wilkinson, the president of the National Association of Government Guaranteed Lenders. His biggest concern was that the program was begun without guidelines. "They had no program guide detailing what the standards are," he said. "You should have the standards first, then implement the program second." He and others say it is too soon to tell what the loss experience will be on the Lowdoc program.
An S.B.A. spokeswoman said a draft program guide was recently completed.
Acting on lender concerns that default rates might rise as a result of Lowdoc, Mr. Hoobler, the inspector general, recommended reducing Government risk on Lowdoc loans by lowering the S.B.A.'s guarantee from 90 percent to 75 percent Mr. Lader opposed that proposal, but Congress reduced the rate to 80 percent with S.B.A. support.
Under Mr. Clinton, each S.B.A. district office has a list of goals of how many loans it should make each year to various groups. Lenders have been pushed to meet the goals, and some have relaxed their review standards, prompting some S.B.A. officials to complain to Congress, according to agency documents, officials and Congressional aides.
One senior S.B.A. manager, who asked not to be identified, said many of the agency's district offices were finding that Lowdoc's promise of reduced Government red tape had mistakenly led many small banks to think they could reduce their own review of borrowers. This in turn increases the risk of the S.B.A., which guarantees these loans but relies on the banks to evaluate the worthiness of the borrower.
The loan goals are consistent with the Administration's ideas about evaluating Government performance. The President's budget last year listed as a performance measure and indicator of "Well-Being," the "numbers of loans extended for Federal credit programs."
Mr. Bowsher said using quantity, not quality as an indicator of success, was something that worried him.
In fact, the S.B.A. once used numerical goals for its direct lending program in the 1970's, but ended the practice in the early 1980's when officials discovered that their use had lessened standards, causing higher default and loss rates.

HEADLINE: Unemployment-Fund Battle Begins

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Business and labor leaders in New Jersey began a joint lobbying effort today against a legislative proposal that would use $1.1 billion from the state's unemployment insurance fund over the next four years to help pay for hospital care for the poor.
The state's authority to divert revenues from the Unemployment Compensation Fund expired on Dec. 31. State legislative leaders, who rejected Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposal last fall to raise cigarette taxes, proposed last week to continue drawing on the unemployment fund, but to reduce reliance over the next four years until total spending for charity care is included in the state's operating budget by the year 2000. 
 The business and labor leaders, however, argue that the proposal does not end dependence on the unemployment fund quickly enough. They say that many employers have had to pay unemployment taxes at higher rates over the last three years because the state has already diverted $1.6 billion from the fund from 1993 through last December. They also worry that a sharp rise in unemployment in the state could threaten the fund's ability to pay unemployment benefits. In December, the unemployment rate was 7.3 percent, the latest figure available, although new figures are expected to be released Friday.
"When the Legislature imposed this burden on business and labor three years ago, it pledged this would be a stopgap measure that would end in 1995," said Philip Kirschner, senior vice president with the New Jersey Business and Industry Association. "This pledge has been broken."
Mr. Kirschner is working to defeat the measure with labor leaders from around the state. Several busloads of union members arrived at the State House today to meet with their legislators to urge them to oppose the plan. The Assembly's Health Committee approved the measure today, and it is expected to be considered in the Senate next week.
Peter J. Lillo, vice president of government relations for the New Jersey Hospital Association, said that hospital officials were pleased that the Legislature was moving toward a solution. "We feel that this legislation provides proper reimbursement to our hospitals, which have been continuing to provide quality health care without charity care dollars," Mr. Lillo said.
The Senate majority leader, John O. Bennett, a Republican of Monmouth County, said that the groups opposing the legislative solution were jeopardizing health care for the working poor.
"If they are successful in garnering support for their opposition, there will be no charity care solution," Mr. Bennett said. "Hospitals have already missed one check and if we do not act soon, hospital bills for the uninsured will continue to go unpaid, putting their health care at risk."
Under the proposed legislation, the state would distribute $300 million to 84 hospitals, a $100 million cut from last year. Another $100 million would be used to help finance a state-subsidized health insurance program.
This year, the plan would use $387 million from the unemployment fund and $13 million from the state budget's general fund. In 1997, the state would increase spending for charity care from the general budget to $68 million. In 1998, the state would use $168 million from the general fund, then $268 million in 1999, and $400 million in the year 2000.
Governor Whitman would not say whether she would support the bill, but she did say that the legislation was closest "conceptually" to what she had proposed late last year.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Talent Lost to a Failure Called Politics

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
WHAT, other than unrealized Presidential ambitions, could Jesse Jackson and Ross Perot possibly have in common? Sympathetic phone calls to Felix G. Rohatyn, it seems. Independently of each other, those two political mavericks from opposite poles commiserated with Mr. Rohatyn, the New York investment banker and public watchdog, after he was forced to pull out of the running for the No. 2 seat on the Federal Reserve Board.
"They both said, 'We're terribly sorry that you're not going to be there because you could have made a difference, but we understand why you withdrew,' " Mr. Rohatyn recalled in the Rockefeller Center offices of Lazard Freres, where he is the managing director. "Now, these are clearly not men with the same philosophical point of view. It is, I think, a terrible indictment of the system." 
 Many agree, and they include conservative business executives and editorial writers who most days have as much use for his ideas on government activism as they do for tax increases.
Their annoyance goes well beyond personalities or Mr. Rohatyn's ruffled feelings after Senate Republicans made clear that they would block Administration plans to make him the Fed vice chairman. Far more important, and not only to conservatives, is a question that has become all too familiar -- and depressing:
How can we expect talented people to trade velvety positions in business for sojourns in government if they are going to be treated shabbily by politicians even before reaching the front door?
"My friends in the business community, without exception, thought from the beginning that I had been out of my mind to try to do this," Mr. Rohatyn said.
LED by Connie Mack of Florida, the only United States Senator who shares the name of a demolished ball park, the Republicans did not challenge the New Yorker's credentials in high finance or Government fiscal policy. How could they? Besides having guided countless corporate mergers, he was a central figure in pulling New York City back from the fiscal abyss in the mid-1970's.
No, the knock against Mr. Rohatyn was that he didn't share the government-as-devil doctrine of so many Republicans. In his view, that put him in the ranks of Robert Bork and Lani Guinier, other prospects for high office who washed out not for incompetence but for failing "some philosophical litmus test."
At one point, he said, he had sought guidance from a Republican friend, former Sen. Howard H. Baker Jr. Mr. Baker's grim advice: "Before you start, you should have no illusions; this is the ugliest climate that I have ever seen in Washington." Similar words came from another friend, the columnist George Will, hardly a flaming liberal.
"In all the years in which I've watched the political process," Mr. Rohatyn said, "I've never seen so much ideological certainty about things that nobody can really be certain about and so little willingness to engage in dialogue or any kind of a bipartisan effort." Had that climate prevailed in New York two decades ago, with Democrats and Republicans refusing to set aside their differences for the greater common good, the city, he said, would not have been saved from fiscal disaster.
IF he carries any label, Mr. Rohatyn said, it is that of fiscal conservative. But he added: "In this day and age, especially if you're a fiscal conservative, you have to maintain an active role for government because too many people have no other place to turn to, because it is a very rough game, this modern capitalism that we're playing."
What are the issues that weigh heavily on Americans, he asked, answering his own question with a lineup of worries like crime, failing schools, illegal immigration and unfair overseas competition. Who is going to deal with those problems if not government leaders? Bill Gates? Warren E. Buffet?
And obviously, New York has its own share of troubles. It may not be staring bankruptcy in the face, as in the 1970's, but the absence of an immediate crisis doesn't mean the city can ignore what Mr. Rohatyn calls the "very deep-seated, slow hemmorhage" in public services.
"The need for public investment in this country is staggering," he said. Once again, that is where government comes in. "I've never argued for big government," he said. "What I've argued for is effective government."
It is the kind of issue that he had hoped to discuss from the national soapbox the Fed would have provided. But it was not meant to be. Oh well, said Mr. Rohatyn, who in a few hours would take off to Paris on business. Not a bad consolation prize -- Paris for a few days. "There is," he observed, "very much of a life without Washington."

HEADLINE: Rich Nations Urge Action to Cut Dangers of Lead

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Industrialized nations have reached the first international agreement on measures to reduce the dangers posed by lead in the environment.
After a two-day meeting in Paris this week, the environment ministers of 26 nations committed their governments to fight the noxious effects of lead through cutting back use, tightening regulations and working with industries. The group met at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, whose 26 member nations consume 65 percent of the world's lead. 
 The agreements signed here include a political statement and a plan for action, but they are not legally binding and depend on the voluntary cooperation of industry.
They call for phasing out lead in widely used products like gasoline and paint, more recycling, developing substitutes and removing lead altogether from objects used by children or in food packaging.
The agreement sets the stage for binding action at the United Nations, said Carol M. Browner, Administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency. The United States and several European countries had fought for a legally binding document now. But Australia and Canada, the world's leading lead producers, blocked such a move. Although they already have strict domestic rules for lead, the two nations said they did not want to impose restrictions on export industries.
Lead has adverse effects as it accumulates in the body, especially for children and pregnant women. It can lead to anemia, mental retardation and permanent nerve damage.
Although many rich countries have phased out lead as a gasoline additive, global lead use is still increasing, especially in Asia.

HEADLINE: An Adviser to Presidents, Regardless of Party Stripe

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Laurence H. Meyer, a Democrat nominated yesterday to the Federal Reserve board of governors, has been dispensing advice on the economy to Presidents for more than a decade. He gave President Clinton advice on tax proposals during the 1992 campaign, and has worked with the Administration ever since.
Mr. Meyer's consulting firm, Laurence H. Meyer & Associates in St. Louis, operates one of the more sophisticated computer simulations of the nation's economy, and Mr. Meyer in recent years has twice won national awards. 
 "He brings to the board very strong forecasting skills," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, director of the President's National Economic Council, "and these are essential in the judgments the Federal Reserve must make."
Mr. Meyer, 51, holds fairly traditional economic views. Like Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, he argues that the economy may not be able to expand at an annual rate of much more than 2.2 percent over a long period without risking higher inflation. But he says that he might be more willing than the chairman to experiment with higher growth, to test whether there might be capacity not evident in the statistics.
"I am sensitive to the fact that the Federal Reserve historically has kept interest rates up for too long when the economy shows signs of weakening," he said. "And that exacerbates the weakening."
Mr. Meyer, who founded his firm with two partners in 1982, is also an economics professor at Washington University, near his home. Mr. Meyer was born in the Bronx and raised in Queens. He and his wife, Florence, a real estate agent, have two children in their 20's.

HEADLINE: Labor Sees Fiscal Hope in Credit Card Deal

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
To help finance its political activities and its plans to expand, the labor movement is harnessing an unexpected tool: capitalism.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. announced yesterday that Household International, a finance company based in Illinois, had offered to pay the labor federation an estimated $375 million over five years in exchange for being able to issue and service a special credit card to union members. 
 Officials of the labor federation, which has an annual budget of $69 million, hailed Household's offer, saying it could help finance labor's stepped-up efforts to organize workers and support pro-union candidates for political office this fall.
The federation asked finance companies to bid for its credit card business, known as Union Privilege. Labor officials said Household made the best offer, although the federation is giving its current credit card company, the Bank of New York, until next Wednesday to match Household's offer.
Federation officials said the A.F.L.-C.I.O. receives far less money in its current arrangement with the Bank of New York. They said that 2.2 million of the federation's 13 million members held the union credit card offered by the Bank of New York, and that their outstanding balance was about $3.6 billion.
Federation officials said the interest rate that Household would charge for unpaid balances -- expected to be 13.5 percent -- was lower than the more than 17 percent average for other credit cards. Household has agreed to charge the prime rate plus five percentage points.
Denise Mitchell, communications director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said its 54-member executive council had not decided how to spend the money from Household. One option, she said, is to divide the estimated $75 million a year equally between the federation and its 79 affiliate unions.
Financial advisers to the federation said Household was willing to share much of its credit card revenue with the federation because union members are loyal customers with a delinquency rate that is less than half the national average.
As part of his strategy to build a more militant labor movement, John J. Sweeney, president of the federation, introduced some ambitious and expensive plans at the executive council's winter meeting in Bal Harbour, Fla. They include spending $35 million this year to help elect pro-labor candidates, and spending $20 million over 18 months to help persuade workers to join unions. To finance its political plans, the federation is to vote next month on whether to assess an extra 15 cents a month in dues over the next year.
Before ending the Bal Harbour meeting yesterday, the executive council urged subscribers, advertisers and distributors to boycott the flagship publications of the Gannett Company and Knight-Ridder Inc., which own newspapers in Detroit that have faced a strike since July.
To step up pressure on the owners of The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press, the federation urged a boycott of USA Today, a Gannett publication, and The Miami Herald, owned by Knight-Ridder.
Gannett and Knight Ridder are publishing the papers with permanent replacement workers. Tim Kelleher, senior vice president for labor relations with Detroit Newspapers, which publishes the two Detroit papers, said the union should spend more energy at the bargaining table and less on organizing boycotts.

HEADLINE: Cold War Over, France Plans a Slim, Volunteer Military

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Announcing the most sweeping military changes since development of a nuclear deterrent almost 40 years ago, President Jacques Chirac said tonight that France's armed forces would shrink by about a third and become an all-volunteer force within six years.
To replace the military draft for young men, a hallowed institution since Napoleon, Mr. Chirac called for a national debate about how both men and women could serve France in civilian jobs instead. 
 Mr. Chirac told a national television audience that cutting the 500,000-strong uniformed forces was long overdue five years after the end of the cold war. "We are in a time when expenditures have to be reduced," he said. "We are no longer threatened by an external invader."
Last year the President also said the French military would partly reintegrate into NATO, 30 years after Charles de Gaulle pulled out to protest American domination.
The French military of 2002, Mr. Chirac said, will need only 350,000 people, all volunteers. "At the end of this reform, we will have the ability to deploy 50,000 to 60,000 soldiers abroad, with everything they need," he said. Britain and the United States, where the armed forces are all volunteer, already have that capability. France has only 8,500 troops in its most easily deployable unit, the Foreign Legion.
Speaking in an informal interview after a Government conclave on the military, Mr. Chirac said he was aware that Germany, as the last major continental power with a draft, was concerned about the implications of his decisions.
Perhaps as a sop to German concerns, he announced that 15 short-range Hades missile launchers, which can fire tactical nuclear weapons but are only capable of reaching targets in Germany, would be dismantled.
And he also pledged that the 15,000-strong French contribution to the French-German Eurocorps would remain untouched, though other units now stationed in Germany may be withdrawn as the army slims down from 124 regiments, to as few as 83 by 2002.
Even France's vaunted nuclear deterrent is coming under the budget knife.
Mr. Chirac, denounced around the world for conducting underground nuclear tests in the Pacific right up to last month, said one reason for the tests was to make sure that a new French strategic nuclear deterrent, entirely concentrated in a new class of missile submarines, would work.
The submarine deterrent now consists of five boats that can launch missiles with up to 96 warheads of 150 kilotons apiece. But this year the navy is to get a new class of four submarines with more powerful missiles with a 3,500-mile range.
Mr. Chirac said tonight that the new missiles would replace all of the 18 obsolescent S3-D medium-range land-based rockets now stationed on the Albion Plateau, in the southeast.
He also said France would close its only factory that makes plutonium and weapons-grade uranium, at Pierrelatte, south of Lyon, because the country has enough.
The sprawling French military industry is to be reorganized to meet intense competition from the United States on world markets.
Mr. Chirac said the military draft, in effect since 1905, had become unfair. Only half the young men called ever serve, and women are not drafted at all. Even at its current size, the army cannot absorb all the young men theoretically eligible for service.
"There are two possible courses," he said. "One is to to say that national service is a part of our national heritage and that we should retain it in some way. The other is to create a civilian service that would be open to both boys and girls, volunteers only, with incentives to take part."
He suggested a broad national debate between now and 2002, when the military draft would be abolished -- and the debate has already begun.
A former Prime Minister, Edouard Balladur, a fellow conservative, said a national referendum on the changes would be desirable.
Francois Leotard, a former defense minister who recalled that proposals for an all-volunteer army had stirred national passions five years ago, said, "Conscription has long been the soul of our defense and the expression of a vision of society."
The United States, Britain and Germany have all cut military spending by about a third since the collapse of the Soviet Union, but France has hardly cut back at all.
But now, with Mr. Chirac's Government faced with a need to cut a $59.3 billion budget deficit by next year to qualify to join a common European currency by the end of the century, cutting spending on the military and the vast industrial complex that feeds it may be easier than trying to cut back on social security or health insurance.
The Defense Ministry now employs 600,000 people, including 100,000 civilians. Of the 236,600 uniformed troops in the army, well over half, 132,320, are draftees; 50,000 more conscripts serve in the navy and the air force, and 18,000 in the national gendarmerie.
With unemployment at about 12 percent, Mr. Chirac promised that the cuts would not bring layoffs or uncompensated economic hardship to regions that depend on the military for their livelihood.
French officials said the army could be reduced to about 140,000 over the next five to six years, with smaller reductions for the other forces; parliamentary experts estimated that eventually this could save about $1.2 billion a year.
While Great Britain and the United States have made their forces more flexible for deployments like the NATO mission in Bosnia, France has left its armed forces more or less the way they were during the cold war -- allocated and trained to defend national territory in the event of an invasion, a threat that no longer exists.
"We had to beg, borrow and steal from 47 separate regiments to put together a 15,000-man intervention force during the war in the Persian Gulf," said Pierre Lellouche, a conservative member of Parliament close to Mr. Chirac on military issues, in an article in the daily newspaper Le Figaro.
"At the same time, the British Army, which is less than half the size of the French Army now, managed to deploy more than 30,000 soldiers to the same theater of operations."
By law, French draftees cannot be sent on overseas missions against their will; according to Francois Heisbourg, another expert, who is close to the opposition Socialist party, only one in six draftees accepts such duty, which requires them to sign up for longer tours.
"That and other things mean that the army we now have, with nearly 240,000 people, is less usable for the kind of short overseas deployments that are likely in the post-cold-war context than an all-professional army of 100,000 would be," Mr. Heisbourg said. "The draft provides more people than the army can use or provide with modern equipment, anyway."
Mr. Lellouche said, "The truth is that we do not have an all-volunteer intervention force that is up to our diplomatic ambitions."

HEADLINE: Two New Faces Join Greenspan As Fed Choices

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
President Clinton today renominated Alan Greenspan as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and filled two other vacancies with appointees considered unlikely to strongly dispute the chairman's slow growth strategy to control inflation.
The decision gives a third four-year term to Mr. Greenspan, 69, who was originally named by President Ronald Reagan in 1987 and whose priority has been to fight inflation by keeping the economy from becoming overstimulated. Mr. Clinton named his budget director, Alice M. Rivlin, as vice chairman, and appointed Laurence H. Meyer, 51, an economic consultant in St. Louis, to a second vacancy on the seven-member Federal Reserve Board. 
 While both Democrats, Ms. Rivlin, 64, and Mr. Meyer, 51, are considered less likely to rock the boat at the Fed than Felix G. Rohatyn, the New York investment banker whom Mr. Clinton originally hoped to name as vice chairman. Analysts said the appointments indicated that Mr. Clinton had backed away from using his appointees to press for a robust public debate on the pace of economic growth.
Mr. Greenspan "has inspired confidence, and for good reason," President Clinton said in an announcement from the Oval Office in the White House. "His decisions have helped us to work toward a period of sustained economic growth."
All three posts require Senate confirmation, and two key Congressional Republicans indicated today that the two nominees would not face the kind of strenuous opposition that caused Mr. Rohatyn to withdraw his candidacy last week.
"Clearly, I would look on these two more favorably than Mr. Rohatyn," Senator Connie Mack, the Florida Republican who is chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, said. "I would want to review some questions with them at the time of the hearing, but I am favorably inclined."
The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, pledged to schedule confirmation hearings "as quickly as possible" and said he was not aware of "any impediment" to their winning Senate approval.
Mr. Greenspan was also said to favor the appointments of Ms. Rivlin and Mr. Meyer, according to Administration officials and Wall Street traders.
As the nation's central bank, the Federal Reserve probably has more to say about the health of the economy than any other institution. It regulates the supply of money and exerts direct control over levers that determine short-term interest rates. The Fed can use its powers to slow down a rapidly expanding economy that in its view threatens to produce higher inflation, or stimulate a lagging economy that might be in or tilting toward recession.
The Administration has long signaled its intention to renominate Mr. Greenspan, a Republican, despite the fact that his cautious policy-making is somewhat at odds with Mr. Clinton's goals of encouraging higher growth and rising wages, issues that have become prominent in the Presidential election campaign.
To do otherwise would have risked roiling the financial markets, where Wall Street traders and major investors have come to see Mr. Greenspan as practically indispensable.
The markets appeared to signal their approval of Mr. Clinton's move. Analysts said the major source of the surge in the stock market today was renewed optimism that the economy will grow moderately without inflation. But some suggested that reports of the impending nominations contributed to the good mood on Wall Street.
Mr. Clinton had hoped to name Mr. Rohatyn as vice chairman of the Fed, replacing Alan S. Blinder, who had spoken out at times in favor of cutting interest rates somewhat more aggressively than Mr. Greenspan.
White House officials had expected that Mr. Rohatyn would have been a more forceful advocate of economic growth and job creation, thereby serving as a stronger counterpoint to Mr. Greenspan's caution. Republicans who now control Congress made it clear they would not support such a candidate.
"There is now a debate, a serious debate in the country, about whether there is a maximum growth rate we can have over any period of years without inflation," Mr. Clinton said last week.
For the last week, the Administration had considered an array of alternatives, including, officials said, allowing Mr. Greenspan to remain as chairman, but without formal appointment until after the November election.
Asked at a news briefing today whether Mr. Clinton had considered not naming Mr. Greenspan immediately to a third term, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of the President's National Economic Council, ducked the question. She said only that Mr. Clinton had been forwarded an array of options to choose from.
Ms. Rivlin, director of the Office of Management and Budget, clearly had to be persuaded by the President to become the first woman to hold the Fed's No. 2 position. The post can be seen as a step down from her Cabinet-level job. Earlier this month she vigorously stated her lack of interest in the job, saying she preferred to stay at the budget office to see the year's marathon budget deliberations to their end. "I have a big job here," she said at the time, adding that "no way, no how," would she be joining the Fed.
But as he announced the appointments late this afternoon, Mr. Clinton joked: "I haven't lost all my powers of persuasion. Battered and bloodied as I may be, I can still, once in a while, make a good argument."
Mr. Clinton said he thought his appointments would foster the kind of economic debate he would like to see. "Our objective should be to achieve the maximum sustainable economic growth in our country, consistent with not letting inflation get out of hand," he said.
Administration officials argued today that with Ms. Rivlin and Mr. Meyer joining Mr. Clinton's other Fed appointee -- Janet L. Yellin, a former economist at the University of California at Berkeley -- the President's viewpoint would be well represented on the central bank.
"We now have three like-minded people on the board," an Administration official said, "and they are all independent thinkers. They won't act as a herd, but there will be a significant voice articulating the high cost associated when economic growth slows too much, as well as the perils associated with inflation, when the economy gets too strong."
But Mr. Mack said he expected Ms. Rivlin and Mr. Meyer to be "supportive of a Fed that would be committed to price stability -- low inflation."
Bond market traders, too, shared Mr. Mack's view and suggested that Ms. Rivlin would in the end line up with Mr. Greenspan and be less outspoken than Mr. Blinder, who resigned the vice chairman's post to return to Princeton University.
"She is obviously in the main channel on policy," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston, a Wall Street bond trading house. "She might be a little more doveish than Greenspan but less outspoken than Mr. Blinder. The key thing is that the Fed governors disliked Mr. Blinder because he was more visible and more argumentative, and that made the bond market nervous."
Although the relationship between Mr. Greenspan and the White House began as a rocky one, his management of the economy has been widely praised and his relationship with Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin has been particularly good.
Mr. Greenspan's tenure has been marked by a reduction in inflation that has kept the annual rise in the Consumer Price Index below 3 percent for each of the past four years. Under Mr. Greenspan, the economy went through one recession, lasting from July 1990 to March 1991, and has grown, by past standards, relatively slowly since then.
By raising short-term interest rates to 6 percent from 3 percent between February 1994 and February 1995, Mr. Greenspan sought to achieve a "soft landing" from a period of faster growth at the end of 1993. There have been recent signs that the Fed may have overdone its tightening, however, raising the prospect of weak economic growth in an election year.
