HEADLINE: Metro Digest

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
More Power to Prosecutors?
 Seeking a far-reaching change in New York State's criminal justice system, Governor Pataki announced that he would propose legislation that would allow prosecutors to appeal sentences and bail amounts after judges set them. Under current state law, only defendants can appeal their sentences or bail amounts. [Page A1.]
 
More Students, Fewer Dollars
 As enrollment grows and government budgets shrink, New York City schools like P.S. 175 in Rego Park, Queens, are running out of space, cramming more children into each classroom and asking parents to do more to support their children's public school education. [A1.]
 
Rail Braking Plan Reassessed
 New Jersey Transit planned to install an emergency braking system on its Hoboken commuter lines for 13 years, but other pressing needs and a lack of money kept it from completing the job before the crash on Feb. 9 that killed three people, agency officials said. [B1.]
 
Firebomb Trial Focus Is Drugs
 Edward J. Leary was consumed by a dangerous mix of mind-altering drugs and incapable of realizing the damage that could result from the firebomb he carried onto a Manhattan subway train in 1994, a psychiatrist testified. [B1.]
 Because of the mix of drugs, the issue is more than just the effects of one, Prozac. [B2.]
 
Talent Lost to Politics
 Senate Republicans' successful threat to block Felix G. Rohatyn, the New York investment banker, as vice chairman of the Federal Reserve again raises the depressing question: How can we expect talented people to enter government if they are going to be treated shabbily even before reaching the front door? NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B1.]
 
Marching With Toy Soldiers
 A couple of times a week, people from a range of backgrounds come together in a loft in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to play with tens of thousands of toy soldiers and refight long-ago battles. [B1.]
 
2 Views on Alarm Experiment
The Giuliani administration reported that its experiment in disconnecting fire alarm boxes in certain areas showed that dismantling the whole system would reduce false alarms, but opponents were skeptical. [B3.]
 
Child Abuse Program May Close
 Sixteen child-abuse-prevention programs in the city's network of after-school educational programs could be forced to close next week unless the Giuliani administration spends $1.2 million to keep them open, city officials said. [B3.]
 
Charges in Store Shooting
 Michael Vernon, the suspect in the fatal shootings of five people in a Bronx shoe store last December, formally was arraigned on murder charges in Bronx Supreme Court. He pleaded not guilty. [B3.]
 
Aide Returns Consulting Fee
 The chief spokesman for Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has returned a $1,500 consulting fee that he collected from a private educational organization during his first month at the Board of Education last fall. [B4.]
 
REGION
 
Reaching for a Lilco Accord
 Top officials of Nassau and Suffolk Counties said they were moving toward resolving a tax refund issue that is the major hurdle in a complex plan to dismantle the Long Island Lighting Company. [B5.]
 
An Unemployment Fund Fight
 Business and labor leaders in New Jersey began a joint lobbying effort against a legislative proposal that would use $1.1 billion from the state's unemployment insurance fund over the next four years to help pay for hospital care for the poor. [B5.]

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Clinton Renames Greenspan And Fills 2 Fed Vacancies
President Clinton renominated Alan Greenspan to a third term as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and filled two other vacancies with appointees considered unlikely to strongly dispute the chairman's strategy of slow growth to control inflation. One is the budget director, Alice M. Rivlin, nominated to be Fed vice chairman, and the other is Laurence H. Meyer, an economic forecaster.
Mr. Clinton apparently backed away from using his appointees to press for more robust economic growth. [Page A1.]
 
Pepsico's Chief Is Stepping Down
Pepsico's chief executive, Wayne Calloway, at left, plans to resign after 10 years in the job, and will be succeeded by Roger Enrico, the company's No. 2 executive. Mr. Calloway is 60 and under treatment for prostate cancer. Mr. Enrico, 51, headed Pepsico's restaurant operations. [D3.]
 
A Giant Loan for Russia
The I.M.F. agreed to give Russia a $10.2 billion loan to carry out free-market reforms. But the agency said it would cut off funding if a new Government abandons the reforms. [A1.]
 
Last Hughes Assets Are Sold
The heirs of Howard R. Hughes Jr. sold the last remnants of his great business empire, vast tracts of land and buildings in Las Vegas, Nev., and Los Angeles, to the Rouse Company. Among the most valuable parts of the transaction are rights to half of any future profits on the resale of undeveloped land. [D4.]
 
Sprint Names New President
Sprint named Ronald T. LeMay, 50, its president and chief operating officer. He has been chief executive of Sprint's wireless telecommunications venture with several cable television partners. [D7.]
 
Penney Earnings Tumble 24%
J. C. Penney earnings fell 24 percent in the latest quarter, as stiff competition and winter storms hurt sales. The results were below expectations and marked the fifth consecutive quarter that profits fell. Sales also fell. [D6.]
 
Goodby Joins Front Ranks
Goodby, Silberstein, regarded as perhaps the strongest creative force in American advertising, is achieving a new prominence that it can use to attract larger accounts. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D2.]
 
Dell Profits Rise 17%
Dell Computer's earnings rose in the latest quarter but just missed matching analyst expectations. Earnings were up 17 percent, to $70 million, and sales jumped 50 percent. [D4.]
 
Federal Liabilities Balloon
By 1998, Federal loan guarantees are expected to exceed $1 trillion, up from $600 billion in 1992. But the number of inspectors and auditors of the guaranteed programs has fallen, increasing the Government's risk. [A1.]
 
Infinity Enters Outdoor Advertising
Infinity Broadcasting, which owns 34 radio stations, agreed to buy TDI Worldwide, which runs big-city transit ads, for $300 million. Radio and outdoor ads are enjoying robust growth, and both appeal to local advertisers, as an alternative to television and newspaper advertising. [D2.]
 
California Test for Securities Law
California Micro Devices is offering a public test of how securities class-action lawsuits may change under the rules enacted by Congress last year. Market Place. [D6.]
 
Dollar Steady Despite Intervention
The dollar was steady despite an apparently coordinated effort by the Bank of Japan and the Bank of England to buy dollars. [D5.]

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
What Dole Owes Us

BYLINE: By A.M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
"We didn't plan it this way. I didn't realize that jobs and trade and what makes America work would become a big issue in the last few days of this campaign."
Bob Dole blurted that out in the final hours of the New Hampshire campaign, a dreadfully self-destructive but sadly honest confession. It showed that he had handed the primary to Patrick Buchanan -- and how he might possibly find himself again before he is too long gone. 
Mr. Dole did not realize what was happening in the last days because he had not grasped it in the first days -- the anxieties eating at Americans across the whole blessed country.
"Where has he been?" asked Patrick Buchanan. So should we all, particularly those who see Mr. Buchanan, his bigotry, his nut-wing pals and his mean cockamamie nationalism as dangers to America.
Hunkered down, head in shell, in a dreary political hole of his own digging -- these are answers to where Mr. Dole was. Democrat or Republican, planning to vote for him or not, he hurt us all by giving Mr. Buchanan the primary. Pray Mr. Buchanan does not get the nomination, but Mr. Dole has increased his chances. The Senator owes us now.
Mr. Buchanan is an intellectual mediocrity and stands for nothing new. His proposals are numbskull ism. They would push America into a depression of economy and mind, leave us at once without allies and soon without customers. They would do more damage to America than all the left-wing multicultural movements laid end to divisive end.
New? We have seen his kind since the first demagogue picked up the scent of public fear and used it to attain power. I do not know if he studied Fascist and Communist propaganda techniques or just has a natural talent for them.
Any experienced opponent with the wit God gave him could have ripped Mr. Buchanan to shreds. As the leading Republican, Mr. Dole had that responsibility.
He failed because neither he nor his G.O.P. colleagues had the courage to face the issues -- including Mr. Buchanan's bigotry. The Democrats are not showing much stomach for it either. Mr. Buchanan gets a free ride as a symbol of American values, can you believe it.
Like Mr. Dole, other Americans also did not grasp the anxiety issues. For instance: Those businessmen, economists and writers who believe that workers and mid-level executives laid off during prosperity will be downright grateful once they see their invaluable role: today's manure to nourish tomorrow's flowers.
"What makes America work," said Mr. Dole. A lot more is involved than "It's the economy, stupid."
Do the rich, middle class and workers of America have a common interest, or is that sentimental garbage? Will the income of workers and middle class rise along with that of the wealthy? Or will more American pie be stuffed into fewer faces?
If downsizing insecurity makes so many Americans susceptible to a demagogue at a time of 5.5 percent unemployment, how much will his power increase if it becomes 10?
If we accept, as we must, that Americans will be displaced by increasing high-tech productivity, will we simply tell them that some day more jobs will be created and until then, tough on you? Or will we put profits and taxes into raising the entire American economy so it produces more good jobs quickly, not in the distant by-and-by?
Is it conservative or liberal to say that government, business and labor have joint responsibility in making America work? And who cares?
When does bottom-line obsession endanger something more important than profits: trust in a society democratic and intelligent enough not to treat too many people as dispensable lest they think so is the society?
I do not know yet how I will vote. But America deserves a choice between two good candidates. Lamar Alexander has not yet shown the country exactly why he should be President. Steve Forbes could use a few years for public achievements that might qualify him for office, say Mayor or Governor to start.
Praise Senator Lugar for staying in the race; maybe he will come up stronger. But it is Senator Dole who has the clearest duty to face American realities -- including showing Mr. Buchanan, consistently and plainly, as a danger to true American values and ideals. Now or never; that's the decision, Senator.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE NEXT STEP;
Delaware Vote to Test Forbes's Viability

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 22

 BODY:
Even his keenest admirers admit it: Steve Forbes must do a lot better soon or his Presidential campaign will slide quickly into terminal irrelevance.
The Delaware primary on Saturday would make a nice start, thank you. 
 "He has to win somewhere," said Representative Michael N. Castle, the state's leading Republican, who has refrained from endorsing a candidate. "He ought to be able to win here. It's close to his own New Jersey, small and the competition isn't much."
Fourth in Iowa, fourth in New Hampshire, the wealthy publisher is the only big-time candidate campaigning here. His sole active rival is Alan Keyes, the talk-show host and former diplomat. Other hopefuls have avoided this tidy little state as if it were a leper colony, fearful of offending people in New Hampshire who dislike upstarts trying to usurp a bit of the quadrennial political limelight.
But all the candidates' names are on the Delaware ballot, whether they like it or not, and much of the state's political and economic establishment, alarmed by the pitchfork-populist oratory of Patrick J. Buchanan, has rallied around Senator Bob Dole. Flanked by denizens of Chateau Country, as the locals irreverently call the colonies of DuPont heirs and executives north of here, Senator William V. Roth Jr. endorsed Mr. Dole at a news conference on Wednesday.
The Kansas Senator was not there, but his voice was, by way of an amplified telephone call from his plane, flying from New Hampshire to South Dakota. Mr. Buchanan "wants to build a wall around this country," Mr. Dole told people whose well-being is dependent on exports, but "I know where the soul of the party is."
You might call it virtual campaigning.
Lamar Alexander, the former Tennessee Governor, appears to have little going for him here. But Mr. Buchanan is highly popular with the religious right and other social conservatives in downstate Delaware, a land of enormous chicken farms where the accents and the politics have more in common with the rural South than cosmopolitan Wilmington. Some experts put the anti-abortion, anti-gun-control base at about 20 percent.
In addition, the arrival of thousands of Central Americans in the region in recent years to work in the chicken-processing plants has generated the kind of tensions, with local people feeling their jobs threatened, that Mr. Buchanan has exploited in the campaign so far. Housing is now short in some areas, language controversies have flared and social-service agencies are overstretched.
"We have a tradition of moderate Republicanism, fiscally conservative, socially slightly more liberal," said Basil Battaglia, the state Republican chairman. "But this is our first Republican primary, and it's hard to say what will happen. If the Wilmington suburbs don't vote and the southern counties do, Buchanan could surprise us."
Independent polls taken in the last two days show Mr. Dole about 10 percentage points ahead, followed by Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Forbes, with Mr. Alexander farther back.
So Delaware presents Mr. Forbes with an opportunity but also confronts him with a menace. Should he lose here, as the only active contender, running in effect against ghosts, it would open his flagging candidacy to ridicule.
He is giving it his all, campaigning in the Wilmington area on Wednesday night and today, then flying to Arizona for tonight's debate there and flying back -- completing a 5,000-mile round trip -- to campaign downstate on Friday. In a state with only 12 convention delegates and an almost invisible primary, he has spent hundreds of thousands of dollars on radio and television advertisements and a half-dozen mailings to Delaware's 137,000 registered Republicans, of whom perhaps 20,000 are expected to vote on Saturday.
Mr. Forbes has spent "the equivalent of Rwanda's national debt," wrote Ron Williams in a burst of hyperbole in The Wilmington News Journal, for commercials "on radio, television, cable, walkie-talkie, shortwave, single sideband, ship-to-shore and Morse code."
But Mr. Forbes has several things going for him besides big bucks. For one, this state is quite accustomed to the sight of a very rich, rather shy Princeton graduate with glasses talking endlessly about tax cuts. It had one as governor for many years, Pete DuPont (now a reluctant Dole supporter).
In addition, people here, like those in other small places slightly off the beaten track, like to be noticed. Voters may therefore reward Mr. Forbes for taking the time and trouble to come to Delaware to campaign and punish those who decided to give it a pass. Reflecting the resentment that many at being snubbed, Representative Castle said in a speech on Wednesday night: "When I signed the Presidential primary bill into law as Governor of Delaware, I never thought it would come down to people not showing up."
People here are seeing and hearing a much more polished candidate than the Steve Forbes who toured Iowa two weeks ago. At a Rotary Club luncheon today in an ornate ballroom of the Hotel DuPont, he gave 400 business and professional men and women the same pitch, almost word for word, that he has been giving for months, pushing for a flat tax, greater parental control of schools and a new retirement plan for young people.
He used the same four jokes he has used from Ames, Iowa, to Manchester, N.H., to New York to Phoenix. Sample: "The Washington diet is where you gain 10 pounds but tell yourself you would have gained 15 if you weren't dieting."
But his timing is better, his delivery more fluent and his feel for an audience improved. His smile seems less pasted-on. And he has added words of derision for Mr. Buchanan, who "would wall us off from the world."
Today at a news conference at New Castle County Airport, south of here, Mr. Forbes named former Senator Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming as his campaign chairman "with executive responsibilities" and promised to stay in the race until the convention in August, something he has plenty of money to do. He left vague the future roles of Carter Wrenn and William Dal Col, top aides who have been criticized for strategy and execution of the campaign to date.
"This race may not be decided in the early primaries," he said hopefully. "We're entering a new phase. It's going to go on longer than most."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: ON THE AIR;
Radio Talk Show Host Fears For True Conservatism's Fate

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Patrick J. Buchanan's candidacy for the Republican nomination has not simply stirred concern at the highest levels of the Republican Party. It has also alarmed Rush Limbaugh, the talk radio host who functioned as a kind of national precinct captain for the Republican electoral revolution of 1994.
Over the last few days, as Republicans and conservatives struggled over the meaning of Mr. Buchanan's victory in the New Hampshire primary, many of them hashed it out by calling Mr. Limbaugh's show. And Mr. Limbaugh was trying to walk a careful line: warning Republican leaders not to antagonize Mr. Buchanan's supporters (which has some overlap with the Limbaugh audience) but criticizing Mr. Buchanan himself as not a true conservative. 
 "I'll tell you something, you are being manipulated in a way that I find very bothersome," Mr. Limbaugh told Buchanan supporters on Wednesday. "Pat Buchanan is not a conservative. He's a populist."
Because of his protectionist stance on trade, "Pat Buchanan wants to engage in policies that expand the role of government in people's lives," Mr. Limbaugh said. The radio commentator argued that the level of government intervention necessary to guarantee individual jobs simply did not comport with the tenets of conservatism.
Mr. Limbaugh said in an interview that he was speaking "as a commentator and not part of the Republican establishment." He also said his primary concern was the fate of conservatism, not the Republican Party establishment. But he said he worried that party leaders were under-estimating "how large, how passionate and how upset with the establishment this group of people is."
Alluding to the criticism of the Buchanan campaign coming from party luminaries in recent days, Mr. Limbaugh added, "It's too risky for the Republican establishment to start insulting voters."
Still, the conservative commentator was experiencing for himself the tensions and strains that have afflicted the Republican Party in recent days. After his comments about Mr. Buchanan, Mr. Limbaugh said he came "under assault" from critics who asserted he had lost touch with regular people and the economic anxiety swirling at the grass roots.
He was also getting angry E-mail and calls, he said, from Buchanan supporters who asserted that all he cared about was tax cuts and other economic issues.

HEADLINE: After New Hampshire, People vs. the Party?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Pundits tell us that the results of the New Hampshire primary equal a vote for President Clinton because Patrick J. Buchanan cannot possibly win the Republican nomination. In other words, the Republican Party -- not the American people -- will have the last word on who will be the Republican nominee.
They would do well to recall that in the fall of 1994, as President Clinton forced a lame-duck Congress to stay in session to vote on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, Senator Bob Dole's office reportedly received more than 2,000 calls in a day, almost all urging him to vote no or to delay the vote until after newly elected members of Congress had beenseated. 
 In response, Mr. Dole was quoted as saying, "Bill Clinton needs to do a much better job of explaining these trade agreements to the American people."
The next day the Republican leader voted in favor of the GATT. Since then, of the 700,000 Americans employed in the garment industry, 100,000 have lost their jobs.
Democrats were free to state that they voted as they did because Mr. Clinton is their leader and they must present a united front.
But Bob Dole had no such excuse. Now he states (front page, Feb. 20), "I didn't realize that jobs and trade and what makes America work would become a big issue in the last few days of this campaign."
Wasn't it such ignorance that doomed the candidacy of George Bush?
Patrick J. Buchanan, on the other hand, has been extolling his brand of economic populism for years.
A magnificent drama is about to unfold before our eyes. Act I has just ended in New Hampshire.
The episodes to follow will answer these questions: Does government of the people, by the people and for the people still exist? Or is America's election process just a facade, all smoke and mirrors? The world is anxiously awaiting the denouement.
 
GEORGE R. TYNDALL
Los Angeles, Feb. 22, 1996

HEADLINE: Agency Is Both Fiscal Watchdog and Lame Duck

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Douglas A. Criscitello sits in a dingy, barren, borrowed office in the New York City Municipal Building. He has, for the moment, little more than a telephone, a desk and a stack of resumes, but he is presiding over the birth of a municipal agency that two mayors and most of the city's other elected officials have been trying for six years to kill.
Mr. Criscitello is the first director of the Independent Budget Office -- an agency voters approved in 1989 as part of the city's new Charter. It is intended to serve as an objective, nonpartisan monitor of the city's dauntingly complex, often deliberately obscured budgets. 
 Not only is he the first director, he may also be the last.
Even before Mr. Criscitello can hire a single assistant, three of the city's four top elected officials -- Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi and the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone -- are pledging to abolish the agency once and for all. Only the Public Advocate, Mark J. Green, has supported the agency, now only five days old. He, in fact, loaned the office space.
The rest of the government, having failed in court to delay the agency out of existence, now plans to ask the State Legislature to erase the Charter provision that called for it. Failing that, they may ask the voters to drive a stake through it in a ballot referendum possibly as soon as November.
Meanwhile, the officials are appealing the latest in a string of court rulings against them. The last one ordered the city to stop stalling and let the agency come to life. All of this for an agency whose budget -- $2.6 million for a full year -- is less than 0.00008 percent of the city's overall $32.6 billion budget.
The Mayor's senior aide, First Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers, said even that small sum would be "better spent on children or the elderly." Besides, he added, the city already suffers from a plethora of fiscal monitors, from the city's Comptroller to the state's Financial Control Board. (Those monitors, it is worth noting, often criticize the Mayor's fiscal policies.)
"We believe it's unbelievably redundant and wasteful of taxpayer dollars," Mr. Powers said, expressing a fervent wish for the agency's quick demise.
So much for a warm welcome.
In fact, with all the forces aligned against it, the agency's fate is now no more certain than it was before -- despite the earnest presence of Mr. Criscitello, a 34-year-old public policy type who knew when he accepted the post that it would be an uphill battle just to keep his agency alive.
"I can't worry about that," Mr. Criscitello said, sounding as if he worried just a little bit nevertheless. "My mission is to do a good job. If we can prove the I.B.O. adds some value to the city's budget process, then there will be no debate about its future."
For the agency's defenders, Mr. Criscitello's mere presence is nothing short of a municipal miracle.
After the city's new Charter created the agency in 1989, Mayor David N. Dinkins, joined by the Council's leaders, said he absolutely would not pay for it. It took a lawsuit in 1991 and a series of decisions and appeals that went all the way to the state's highest court in 1994 to make the new Mayor, Mr. Giuliani, relent -- for now anyway.
"The office arrives at just the right moment," said Gene Russianoff, one of the office's few defenders. He is a senior attorney for the New York Public Interest Group, an advocacy organization that, with three others, filed the lawsuit against the city. "There are all these sweeping and controversial changes being proposed in the city's budget, and many of us are having a tough time participating in the process. The whole point of the I.B.O. is to even the playing field."
For the moment, however, Mr. Criscitello is the Independent Budget Office.
He has no staff, not even a secretary. He cannot hire one either, because the agency will not have a budget until at least next month, when the City Council votes on an appropriation that the Mayor grudgingly submitted under the orders of the State Supreme Court.
It may also take some time to get a permanent office, although the Department of General Services has promised him another temporary suite on Chambers Street. The current office, such as it is, is on the 10th floor of the Municipal Building, down a warren-like hallway in a pre-renovation state of disorder and decay.
All of this has put Mr. Criscitello's first paycheck in almost as great a state of uncertainty as the first of the agency's mandated analyses on Mr. Giuliani's $31 billion budget proposal. And it does not seem very likely to get any easier.
"I'm not able to move as boldly as I'd like," said Mr. Criscitello, who served most recently as the acting chief financial officer for the Small Business Administration in Washington.
He was chosen after a highly politicized search led by Mr. Hevesi, Mr. Vallone, Mr. Green and Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx. He emerged as the choice, officials said, largely because he was an outsider -- unbeholden to the political powers that be.
To the agency's supporters, that makes him independent; to its opponents, that makes his office easier to kill, since fewer powers would likely rush to its defense.
Despite all that, Mr. Criscitello envisions a grand role for the new agency, like that of the Congressional Budget Office or the Office of Legislative Analysts in California's Capitol.
He hopes to build a respected office -- with a staff of 30 or so -- that provides line-by-line analyses of where taxpayer dollars go, offers alternatives and, perhaps most of all, educates the public on the intricacies of municipal budgeting.
"I want to provide objective, even-handed analysis," he said. "It's analysis that may benefit the Mayor. It may benefit the Council. It may benefit neither. Hopefully, it will benefit the public."
But it is not going to be easy. The agency's first report, as mandated by the Charter, is due on May 15. It is supposed to be a full-blown review of the Mayor's executive budget to be released in April.
Mr. Criscitello acknowledged that he might not make the deadline.
 
The Birth of a Fiscal Monitor
 
Approved as part of a new City Charter, the Independent Budget Office is opposed by city officials and was allowed to open only under orders of the State Supreme Court. But it still has no budget.
 
1989 As part of the Charter revision, voters approve the Independent Budget Office as a nonpartisan alternative to the Mayor's Office of Management and Budget.
 
1990 An advisory committee selects candidates for director, but no one is appointed.
 
1991 Mayor David N. Dinkins and the City Council appropriate $3 million for the agency but later erase its funds, citing a budget crunch. A coalition of civic groups files suit to force the city to comply with the Charter.
 
1992 A State Supreme Court judge rules that the city violated the law by not creating the agency. Mr. Dinkins and the Council appeal. At the same time, the Council Speaker unsuccessfully approaches the State Legislature about revising the Charter to eliminate the agency.
 
1993 The Mayor and Council lose the appeal, but appeal again to the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals.
 
1994 The Court of Appeals rejects the city's arguments and orders the city to obey the Charter. Having lost in court, the City Council adopts and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani signs legislation delaying financing for the agency. That sparks a new lawsuit.
 
1995 The Mayor and Council, now joined by Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, lose again in court. The Mayor's office grudgingly agrees, under court order, to finance the agency by February 1996.
 
1996 A new advisory committee selects Douglas A. Criscitello as the agency's first director. He starts on Feb. 20, even though the Council has not yet appropriated a budget. The Mayor, Comptroller and Council Speaker pledge to abolish the agency once and for all through state legislation or a referendum.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar's Early Gains Evaporate After U.S. Bond Prices Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar finished lower against most leading currencies yesterday, erasing earlier gains in Asia and Europe, after news of unexpected strength in American home construction pulled down the price of Treasury bonds.
Some of the dollar's fall was a result of foreign investors pulling out of Treasury securities and taking their money home. But market analysts also said currency traders had been expecting the dollar to weaken. 
 "There's a lot of profit taking," said Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer at the Bank Leumi Trust Company. "There's been a shift in sentiment."
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 104.77 Japanese yen, down from 105.05 yen late Thursday. The dollar also fell to 1.4470 German marks from 1.4497 marks.
The British pound slipped to $1.5410 from $1.5446.
The dollar rose sharply in early trading after the Bank of Japan again tried to support the dollar and Germany issued money-supply figures that encouraged speculation about a cut in interest rates there.
But shortly after American trading began, the Commerce Department said housing starts rose 4.4 percent in January, a stronger performance than had been expected for a month when there were severe winter storms in much of the country.
That led to a selloff in the bond market and gave currency traders an excuse to take profits before the weekend.
The data on housing starts came 90 minutes after a Commerce Department report that the American economy expanded 2.1 percent last year, the weakest performance since the last recession. The report had little effect on the dollar.
Traders said that during Asian trading there were signs that the Japanese central bank was trying to pull the dollar to 105 yen for the fourth time this week.
With the Bank of Japan apparently determined to keep the dollar from sliding, traders have been gambling that they can make money by pushing the dollar lower, then wait for the Japanese central bank to offer to buy at a higher rate.
The Bank of Japan is afraid that a lower dollar would translate into weaker profits for those Japanese companies that make much of their money in dollars, analysts said. They added that such concerns are particularly urgent now, as Japanese companies approach the end of their fiscal year on March 31.
"The question is: Will they throw in the towel before the 31st?" Mr. Waxman said.

HEADLINE: New Weakness Seen In New Jersey Jobs

 BODY:
New Jersey lost a significant number of jobs last month as the state's unemployment rate remained above the national average, suggesting continued sluggishness in the economy, according to new data. 
 Using a new method to estimate unemployment, New Jersey's joblessness rate was 6.5 percent in January. Officials revised the December rate downward, easing concern that a spike in unemployment had signaled a sudden downturn.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: BOB DOLE;
Dole Says Buchanan Is Extreme In Outlook

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: MEDFORD, Ore., Feb. 23

 BODY:
Bob Dole asserted his independence from religious right leaders today as he continued to criticize Patrick J. Buchanan's views.
At a speech this morning at a high-tech electronics plant in Wilsonville, Ore., the Kansas Senator branded Mr. Buchanan's views "extreme," despite pressure from Ralph Reed, executive director of the Christian Coalition, and other movement conservatives sympathetic to Mr. Buchanan's candidacy, to soft-pedal his comments. 
 "I don't work for anybody in Washington," Mr. Dole told reporters after the speech. "I'm the candidate; they're not."
A conference in Washington this morning of the Conservative Political Action Committee -- always suspicious of Mr. Dole's commitment to their cause -- seemed to lay bare the escalating rift within Republican ranks over the Presidential contest.
Mr. Reed said in a speech at the conference that name-calling and negativism "are not the traits of leadership, they are the trappings of demagoguery."
David Keene, chairman of the American Conservative Union, told reporters at the same conference that Mr. Dole was insulting Mr. Buchanan's followers and ran the risk of "enraging" them. "Pat Buchanan is not Bob Dole's problem," he said. "Bob Dole's problem is that he has not to this date given voters a reason why they ought to want him as their President."
And Gary Bauer, president of the Family Research Council, said in a telephone interview, "When you throw around that rhetoric, it makes it very hard to patch it all together after San Diego."
Asked in Oregon if he was worried about alienating Buchanan supporters, Mr. Dole said: "I'm not going to alienate anybody -- unless they feel women are somehow inferior or that we ought to expand rather than contract the availability of nuclear weapons." He was referring to previous statements by Mr. Buchanan.
Later, as he toured a Salvation Army warehouse here, where food was being distributed for flood victims, Mr. Dole suggested that his staff was looking for further documentation of Mr. Buchanan's positions, apart from those on women and nuclear weapons, that would show what Mr. Dole considers his extremism. "We're checking," Mr. Dole said. "There'll probably be some others before the day is out."
In the closing days of the campaign for Tuesday's New Hampshire primary, Mr. Dole stepped up his criticism of Mr. Buchanan and described his "extreme" positions in television commercials. As he was losing the primary on Tuesday night to Mr. Buchanan, Mr. Dole signaled the rhetorical direction of his campaign, declaring that the race was now a "struggle for the heart and soul of the Republican Party." He has repeated it several times since, saying at one point, "The party belongs to us."
When word first reached the Dole campaign plane late Thursday night en route to Oregon from Colorado that the conservative right wanted the Senator to ease up his criticism of Mr. Buchanan, Dole aides suggested he would.
Later when his plane landed in Portland, Mr. Dole appeared to be calculating his course and responded to questions by drawing a semantic distinction. He said that he had never used the word "extremist" to describe the commentator himself but had used only the adjectival form of the word to describe Mr. Buchanan's views. "I'll probably use it tomorrow," he said.
Mr. Dole and his aides have realized that since they lost New Hampshire, Mr. Buchanan's views have proved a useful foil and helped Mr. Dole focus his own message as someone who could hold the party together. Moreover, the campaign has been criticized in the past for capitulating to the right, and some inside the campaign believed it was important for Mr. Dole to stand firm this time.
At the same time, Mr. Dole has shaded his message to reflect the economic anxiety of middle-class Americans that Mr. Buchanan has successfully tapped. And while he fiercely rejects Mr. Buchanan's calls for protectionism, he also suggests that retaliatory trade practices would be okay.
"We don't have to be run over by Japan or anybody else to protect our markets and get access to their markets," Mr. Dole said in Wilsonville this morning. "My view is, if we don't have access to their markets, they shouldn't have access to our markets."
And again at a fruit-packing plant here, he said, "I don't think the jury is in yet on Nafta," referring to the trade agreement that Mr. Buchanan is criticizing but that Mr. Dole, as the Senate majority leader, worked to pass.
"He's touched a nerve," Mr. Dole told reporters, "and we need to address it."

HEADLINE: REACTOR ACCIDENT IN JAPAN IMPERILS ENERGY PROGRAM

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 23

 BODY:
Two months after an accident at its prototype reactor, Japan's program to use plutonium to provide a virtually inexhaustible supply of energy is at a crossroads, and could be in danger of collapse.
Even the most optimistic officials think it will take three years to restart the fast-breeder reactor, where the leak of dangerous sodium coolant occurred in December. Some other analysts think that the reactor, which is in the city of Tsuruga on the coast of the Sea of Japan, will never be activated again. 
 Japan has spent three decades developing fast-breeder reactors, which produce more nuclear fuel than they consume, in an effort to rescue itself from its near-total dependence on imported oil and uranium.
So intent has this resource-poor country been on achieving energy independence that it has stuck with the breeder, which uses deadly plutonium as fuel, even as the United States and most other industrialized countries have abandoned such reactors, judging that they contribute to the spread of nuclear weapons, are too technologically daunting and no longer make economic sense.
But the December accident, as well as a ham-handed attempt to cover it up, has undermined public confidence in the Government's assurances of safety and brought into the open serious opposition in Japan itself to the vast and expensive project. Nuclear proponents and opponents agree that this political damage will take longer to repair than the damage to the reactor itself, named Monju after the Buddhist divinity of wisdom.
"It's not an engineering but a social problem now," said Dr. Yoichi Fujiie, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, which sets nuclear policy.
For project engineers, who have thought they were working in the national interest, the doubts of their countrymen have come as a severe shock. "The social problem is so big, which we never thought of 20 to 30 years ago when we started designing Monju," Tadao Aoki, a mechanical engineer who has spent 23 years on the project, said as he led a visitor through the reactor recently as crews worked to clean up the mess from the leak.
Japan is not likely to pull the plug on the plutonium energy program outright. There is too much pride and investment for that. The Government has not changed its long-term goal of developing breeders, arguing that the rapid growth of other countries in Asia will eventually exhaust the world's supply of oil and uranium, even if it takes longer than they once thought. And officials point out that virtually no radiation was released during the accident.
But the program could die from attrition, or be changed into a research project to preserve the accumulated technology.
"The usual way is to postpone and postpone and postpone until there is nothing left," said Dr. Jinzaburo Takagi, executive director of the Citizen's Nuclear Information Center, an antinuclear group. Indeed, in the two months since the Monju accident, delays have been announced in two other key pieces of the plutonium program.
Still, some officials say that once the furor from the accident dies down, the project could resume, since the Japanese public in general tends to go along with government plans. And since the target date for developing commercial breeders had already been postponed until 2030, a delay of a few years now will not be that serious.
Breeder reactors offer a self-sustaining source of energy. Even as they generate electricity, they produce more plutonium than they consume by converting some uranium in the fuel to plutonium.
By contrast, a conventional light-water nuclear reactor burns uranium and uses it up, producing some plutonium as waste product. Japan intends to obtain plutonium for its breeder reactors by reprocessing the waste from its conventional reactors. This reprocessing is now being done for Japan in France and Britain, although Japan is building its own reprocessing plant.
The setbacks to Monju are not entirely welcomed by nuclear opponents. With Monju now unable to burn the plutonium that is being prepared for it, Japan's stockpiles of the deadly material will grow -- from about 11 metric tons to 25 tons by the end of the century, Dr. Takagi estimated. That would increase the risk that some of the material could be diverted to make nuclear weapons and violate Japan's pledge not to hold more plutonium than it needs.
The Monju accident has undermined public confidence not only in the breeder reactor but in conventional nuclear power as well. And with the market for their products dying at home, Japan's manufacturers of nuclear power plants are now seeking business elsewhere in Asia.
In recent years, Japan's plans have aroused uneasiness abroad. Some Asian nations worry that Japan might one day use its plutonium to make weapons, which Japan vociferously denies. The breeder program would also require many shipments of plutonium from France and Britain, and the first such shipment three years ago aroused world ire.
The project has also faced growing economic problems. When the breeder program was conceived in the late 1960's, it was thought that uranium for conventional nuclear plants would soon run out. But uranium is now cheap and abundant, and plutonium is becoming available from weapons being dismantled after the cold war.
"All the claimed advantages -- security, political and economic -- that appeared initially to favor plutonium use have changed," said a recent report by three scholars at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "Yet the rationales and main elements of the Japanese plutonium program have not changed."
Officials announced last month that the projected cost of Japan's own nuclear waste reprocessing plant had doubled to 1.6 trillion yen, or about $16 billion. The project will be redesigned and scaled back, and its operation will be delayed by three years, until 2003.
Perhaps that is just as well because with Monju down, Japan cannot easily use the plutonium. Indeed, to keep its plutonium stockpiles from getting out of hand, Japan had been planning, starting this year or next, to burn plutonium in conventional light-water reactors. But governors of three prefectures that are home to 60 percent of Japan's nuclear plants are now opposing that plan, so it will be delayed.
Monju had just begun producing electricity in August. It was still operating at only 43 percent of its 280-megawatt capacity when the liquid sodium used as a coolant began leaking from the secondary cooling system on the evening of Dec. 8.
Japanese investigators say the accident was caused by a broken temperature sensor. The sensors are long rods covered with a stainless steel casing that protrude into the flowing sodium. Vibrations caused by the sodium flow wore out the casing, and it broke off.
Officials say that only about one metric ton, about 2,204 pounds or one cubic meter, out of the 270 tons of sodium in the pipe leaked. But even that small amount of sodium caused more damage than expected.
The extremely hot sodium, which can explode if it comes in contact with water, warped a carbon steel floor and reacted with the moisture in air to form a corrosive mist and powder. Some of the mist spread outside the plant and to other rooms through an air duct that was directly below the leaking pipe.
But even more attention has focused on what happened after the leak. The Power Reactor and Nuclear Fuel Development Corporation, the Government-owned company that runs Monju, took more than 90 minutes to shut down the reactor, failed to promptly notify some local officials and concealed videotapes of the accident.
One 14-minute videotape showed men in silver space suits exploring the room in which sodium compounds hung from the air ducts like icicles. The floor was covered with powder like fine snow, so that the men left black footprints. Part of a covering on a pipe was burned away.
But the tape released to the public was reduced to one minute, showing only a small pile of powder on the floor in an otherwise pristine-looking room.
On Jan. 12, the company that runs the reactor conceded at a news conference that top officials had taken part in the cover-up. One of the men conducting the news conference was Shigeo Nishimura, a company official taking part in the internal investigation of the cover-up.
Late that night, Mr. Nishimura jumped to his death from an eight-story Tokyo hotel, leaving notes saying he was tormented by the discomfort his investigation was causing his colleagues.
The company is now due for an overhaul, with several officials already having been replaced. Today anti-nuclear activists petitioned prosecutors to file criminal charges against four company executives for falsifying reports on the accident.
This was not the first time the company had engaged in clumsy public relations. It was criticized by Energy Secretary Hazel O'Leary for making an animated video in which a character claimed that it is safe to drink plutonium.
In Japan, the nuclear industry has never had to explain much to the public. One serious accident at a plant in Tsuruga in 1973 was not made public for three years.
Localities accepted nuclear plants because they brought taxes, employment and special payments from the central Government and utilities. In Tsuruga, a city of 65,000 about 220 miles west of Tokyo, property taxes from Monju and several other nuclear plants will amount to about $100 million next year, or one-fourth of the city's budget.
Still, even before the Monju leak, plans for two new conventional reactors in normally pro-nuclear Tsuruga have been frozen because of concerns about earthquake safety, and most localities in the area have passed resolutions urging a freeze or scrapping of Monju.
"If a referendum were held, I'm sure 80 percent of the people would oppose Monju," said Hiroyuki Uchiike, owner of a seed shop in Tsuruga.
The same is true throughout Japan. The country has 49 nuclear plants, which provide 30 percent of its electricity. But there are only a handful more under construction because localities will no longer accept the plants.
Still, the future of the breeder program might be decided not by the public but by the electric utilities, which are becoming edgy about the potential high costs of plutonium power.
Last year the electric companies rebelled against the Government and killed a plan to build another type of plutonium-burning reactor, saying it was too expensive and unnecessary.
Yuichi Hayase, general manager of the nuclear power department of the Federation of Electric Power Companies, said the utilities are still backing the breeder program. Mr. Hayase said the breeder would cost no more than a conventional nuclear reactor, a figure nuclear opponents scoff at.
The utility industry will soon have to put its money where its mouth is. It is supposed to pay for the next breeder after Monju, a $4 billion, 600-megawatt "demonstration reactor" that is scheduled to be completed in about 2005. But the industry has not yet found a site for it, so this plant, too, is likely to be delayed.

HEADLINE: Rate Jitters Drive Down Bond Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond investors seemed to catch another case of interest rate jitters yesterday, sparking a selloff that sent prices lower and yields sharply higher.
By the close of the New York market the 30-year bond had fallen a full point to a price of 9420//32 and a yield, which moves in the opposite direction, of 6.40 percent, up from 6.33 percent yesterday. It was the second time this week that long-term interest rates had touched 6.40 percent, the highest they have been since last October. 
 Yesterday's bond slump capped a week in which the outlook for short-term interest rates and, therefore, economic growth, changed several times, leading to volatile trading that also spread to the stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average swung wildly yesterday from a 51-point surge in the first half-hour of trading to a 48-point fall in the afternoon, only to finish with a 70-point rally that propelled the Dow to a new high. For the day, the Dow was up 22.03, to 5,630.49. [Page 37.]
"Historically increasing volatility after long moves in the market suggest that the market is close to a turnaround," said Ricky Harrington, a senior vice president and technical analyst with Interstate /Johnson Lane in Charlotte, N.C. "This market -- the equity market -- in terms of the Dow has been without a correction of more than 3.5 percent since November 1994."
The selloff in the bond market yesterday was touched off, analysts said, by a unexpectedly strong jump in housing starts in January, which rose 4.4 percent. That surge could indicate that the economy, after nearly standing still in the last three months of 1995, is beginning to pick up again. If that is the case, then there would be less chance of the Federal Reserve's trimming its short-term interest rate target again soon. And that view -- combined with concerns about growth pushing inflation higher -- worried investors enough to prompt the day's selling of both short- and long-term Treasury securities.
But given the shifting views recently, investors and analysts could change their minds quickly, especially because there does not appear to be any near-term threat of a sharp rise in inflation. But the uncertainty over the outlook is likely to continue until there is a clearer picture of the strength of the economy now and that data will not be out until March and April.
Ken McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a market research firm, said, "The remarkable rebound in housing starts for January appears to be a bit of a fluke, but the general strength in housing does suggest that consumer spending will increase more solidly in the first half of 1996 than it did in the fourth quarter."
Housing starts tend to generate growth in consumer spending in the future as the houses started by developers are eventually sold and consumers than fill them with new goods. Thus appliance sales, furniture sales tend to follow housing activity and that is what appeared to bother the market.
Traders also said that bond prices sank after reports of selling activity yesterday by some large funds. Fidelity and and Morgan Stanley, traders said, were the names most often mentioned. The long bond also appeared especially sensitive to any bad news as traders and investors awaited next week's inflation reports. The producer and consumer price indexes will be released on Tuesday and Wednesday, respectively.
Fidelity said it generally does not comment on short-term trading. But Morgan Stanley's government trading desk in an advisory sent to its clients indicated it was time to sell. "We believe that investors should challenge the positive assumptions embedded in the U.S. fixed-income markets, the advisory said, "and now feel there is significant upside risk to U.S. economic growth and inflation over the next few months."
"The real issue today, which may need further explanation, is the talk of adjustments in the asset allocations of some large firms," said Thomas E. Donne, vice president and a senior portfolio manager at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio. "The stock market has accelerated quickly, and putting some people to wonder whether the bull market in equities is coming to a head and should they take profits and shift elsewhere. There has been a tremendous flow of cash into stocks."
Mr. Donne says there are a lot of asset allocators trying to decide which market they want to be with, and a lot of money that still has not been committed is at stake.
Whether next week will be as volatile as this week is hard to tell, but if the inflation reports are very positive the market could rally.
Last Tuesday morning investors seemed to be worried that the Federal Reserve would not cut short-term rates again soon. This helped send prices down and yields higher even before the afternoon testimony on the state of the economy by the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan. And when he did speak, investors and analysts became more alarmed -- and sold more -- as they interpreted his remarks to mean no rate cut soon.
But on Wednesday the market took the opposite view, as it collectively decided that the Fed chairman, in his second day of testimony in Washington, was signaling that the central bank would move again as long as inflation remained in check.
Yesterday that view switched one more time.
The report that the economy grew only nine-tenths of a percent in the fourth quarter last year helped lift the bond market before the housing report.
"Even though G.D.P. was good from the bond market's perspective," Mr. Donne said, "lower inflation and slow growth is still a look back at numbers that have already largely been discounted into the market."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Germans Are Gripped by the Return of Fugitives

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Feb. 23

 BODY:
Germany's most famous fugitive came home today from a Miami jail, looking more like a scared tourist than the wheeler-dealer who fled the country 22 months ago, leaving behind the ruins of a real estate empire and $3.5 billion in bad debt.
Jurgen Schneider and his wife, Claudia, walked off a Lufthansa Boeing 747 at 8:35 A.M., accompanied by German border police, after flying from Miami to Chicago and then to this city, Germany's financial capital. The German Government picked up the $5,842 tab for their two first-class tickets. 
 After waiting for hours in below-freezing temperatures, scores of camera crews taped Mr. Schneider's 15-second descent of the airplane steps. Paunchy, balding and wearing a light blue shirt, khaki pants and navy-blue jacket, he ducked into a green police van without saying a word to the waiting press.
Looking pale and drawn, the 61-year-old Mr. Schneider turned around and glanced at his wife in the van behind him. Husband and wife were then driven off to appear before a federal judge and were remanded to prison to await a formal indictment and trial on charges of falsifying documents, embezzling funds and causing the collapse of his real estate empire.
For a nation that had been transfixed by the couple's flight from German justice 22 months ago and their capture last May in Miami, and that had indulged in endless theorizing about their connections to people in high places, the Schneiders' arrival at the Frankfurt/Main International Airport amounted to a disappointing anticlimax.
The German press had thrown enormous resources into covering the return of the once thin and debonair entrepreneur who, only two years earlier, had made the rounds of Frankfurt high society in a tuxedo and toupee, hobnobbing with the rich and powerful.
RTL, Germany's largest private television station, paid a Lufthansa pilot to tip it off to the flight that the Schneiders would take, then bought all remaining tickets to prevent its archrival, SAT.1, from sending its reporters on the plane. Unfortunately for RTL, it bought tickets for the wrong flight, then had to scramble to get its journalists on the right one.
The mass-circulation newspapers made the Schneiders' flight to Germany the big story of the day. "Hello, Mr. Schneider, Your New Home," declared the banner headline of Bild Zeitung, showing a picture of a jail cell.
The reason for all the interest goes beyond just the sheer magnitude of the scandal, although that alone was worth plenty of attention. After all, the $3.5 billion in unpaid debt that Mr. Schneider left was more than triple the losses of about $1 billion incurred by the British trader Nicholas Leeson in the celebrated case of Barings P.L.C. early last year. And while Mr. Leeson's activities drove under a venerable British merchant bank, the demise of Mr. Schneider's real estate empire ruined hundreds of ordinary German contractors and other small-business people.
On a deeper level though, some analysts said, the German obsession with the Schneiders' disappearance and capture reflects a distrust of the high and mighty and a delight at seeing them get their comeuppance. In the land that coined the term Schadenfreude, or taking pleasure in someone else's troubles, the sight of Mr. Schneider returning in captivity gives some cause to celebrate.
"There is always a fascination with people who seem to have everything going for them, and then all goes wrong," said Richard Reid, chief economist at the Union Bank of Switzerland's Frankfurt office. "This is a society that tends to lean toward the cult of personality. Schneider was once someone who could do no wrong. Now he is fallen from grace."
This Schadenfreude takes on a special edge these days, when the German economy is under severe strains. Unemployment is at record postwar levels, with big corporate layoffs announced almost weekly. Germans struggle under high taxes, the economy has come almost to a standstill and most fear that beloved Government programs will eventually be slashed.
At the same time, the Schneider case is certain to focus attention on one of the institutions that Germans love to hate, Deutsche Bank A.G., Germany's largest bank and the symbol of the German corporate establishment.
Deutsche Bank was Mr. Schneider's largest creditor, and in the wake of the 1994 collapse, many accused it not only of encouraging high-flying real estate speculation, but also of paying insufficient attention to such a huge real estate operation.
Though the Schneider trial is not likely to start until 1997, it is certain to be one of the most celebrated in recent years, particularly because of the insights it should provide on how Deutsche Bank did business right after German reunification. In those heady days, the Government and investors poured billions of dollars into the former East Germany to rebuild it.
A number of scandals over fraud, mismanagement and misappropriation of funds have emerged, but the Schneider case is by far the biggest.
Mr. Schneider's lawyer, Christoph Ruckel, said his client would probably mount what could be called a David versus Goliath defense, placing most of the blame with the management of Deutsche Bank.
Such an approach is likely to resonate with the man in the street. While most Germans interviewed believed Mr. Schneider was guilty, they also felt the bank bore a lot of blame.
"Schneider could not have done all this by himself," said Gregor Schultz, a civil servant in Frankfurt. "I mean the negligence of the banks is fairly obvious."
Added Gundula Zischner, a bookkeeper in Wiesbaden: "I think the banks have their share of the guilt in what happened with Schneider. But he is certainly a crook."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Germans have been fascinated with Jurgen Schneider, the real estate magnate turned fugitive. Mr. Schneider, accompanied by two German border guards, returned with his wife to Frankfurt yesterday from a Miami jail. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Service for 8 In Job Corps Fills Some With Anger

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: HARPERS FERRY, W.Va., Feb. 23

 BODY:
Families of four of the eight Job Corps trainees killed last week in a Maryland train crash joined the victims' classmates here today for a memorial service that paid as much tribute to the Job Corps program as to the dead.
After the hourlong service, at the Harpers Ferry Job Corps center, where the victims had been in training, some trainees said the emphasis had been all wrong. And Charon Rothmiller, a cousin of one of those killed, felt so strongly about it that she spontaneously asked during the middle of the service whether she could speak. 
 "They wanted to sugar-coat it," Ms. Rothmiller told reporters later. She said she wished the service had focused more on who the victims were than on the Job Corps itself.
"They wanted to sugar-coat it," she repeated, "and I couldn't let them do that."
The eight trainees remembered today were among 16 who were on a commuter train that plowed into Amtrak's Capitol Limited outside Washington last Friday night. Officials say seven of them died in a fire caused by the crash, the other on impact. Three crewmen on the commuter train were also killed.
Eager to honor those eight trainees, officials from the Labor Department, which oversees the Job Corps, asked administrators at the Harpers Ferry center to arrange a service for today. At least one center official, Jennifer Mobley, the youth programs coordinator, objected, insisting that the victims' families had not had sufficient time to arrange for funerals. In fact, only one funeral had been held by today, and families of four of the dead were not represented at the service.
More than 300 people attended the service, held in the gymnasium. They included most of the center's trainees, who are learning to become carpenters, bricklayers, nurses' aides and clerical workers, and also scores of local, state and Federal officials with some connection to the Harpers Ferry center, other Job Corps sites or the national program.
But for a good deal of the service, speakers focused as much on the character- and skills-building benefits of the program as on those killed, leaving some listeners to conclude that eight deaths were being used as a political tool even though the $1-billion-a-year Job Corps has been spared the budget ax in Congress.
"I don't give a damn about government organizations," said one trainee, Cliff Wilfong of Clarksburg, Va. "The focus should have been the students."
Mary Silva, the acting national director of the Job Corps, who attended the service, was asked later about that and similar criticism. "I didn't hear any of that personally," she replied. "The families I spoke to were filled with comfort. They said they felt it was wonderful."
The eight trainees who lost their lives were Carlos Byrd, 18, of Baltimore; Diana Hanvichid, 17, of Woodbridge, Va.; Claudius Keesoon, 20, of Landover, Md.; Thomas Loatman, 23, of Vienna, Va.; Lakeisha Marshall, 17, of Capital Heights, Md.; Ka'ris Rudder, 17, of East Elmhurst, Queens; Dante Swain, 18, of Baltimore, and Michael Woodson, 17, of Philadelphia.
All were cited by name at the start of the service, when one candle was lighted for each. And Ms. Silva mentioned them in reading letters from President Clinton and Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich.
But Senator Barbara A. Mikulski of Maryland was the only speaker who described any of them, noting Ms. Marshall's smile, for instance, and Mr. Keesoon's dream of serving in the military.
In an emotional address that included a strong pitch for continued financing of the Job Corps, however, Senator Mikulski mentioned only seven of the eight trainees, omitting one from her own state, Mr. Byrd, who had been studying health occupation trades.
Ms. Mikulski won a standing ovation when she praised the national program's job placement rate for exceeding Harvard's. But the Senator's personal tributes left Ms. Rothmiller -- a cousin of Mr. Woodson, the Philadelphian who was killed -- unsatisfied.
Ms. Rothmiller, herself a 26-year-old graduate of a Jobs Corp center in Philadelphia, asked to speak after Ms. Mikulski and, given permission, took the next few minutes putting events of recent days in painful human terms.
She described fitful nights of sleep, and nightmares of fire and burning bodies. Some of the victims were burned so badly in the fire that followed the collision that their bodies could be identified only through genetic testing or dental records. Ms. Rothmiller said Mr. Woodson's mother, Veronica Woodson, was still too anguished to attend the service, doubly grieved by "knowing her son is never going to come home and that the casket has to be closed."
Speaking to reporters later, Ms. Rothmiller told of how disappointed she had been with what she had heard.
"I got a little upset," she said. "There was not enough said about the families. They all said they were giving us their deepest sympathies. But that's not enough, and nobody added anything. I had to do something."

HEADLINE: The Overselling of Carlos Salinas

 BODY:
It was 1988 and everyone believed that it was morning again in Mexico. Carlos Salinas, a young, articulate, American-trained economist, had just been elected President of Mexico. He promised a brave new era of privatization, free trade and cordial relations with Washington. The old days of debt crises, money-losing state enterprises and anti-yanqui nationalism would be banished. Surrounded by like-minded technocrats with Ivy League connections, President Salinas would yank Mexico out of Latin America and drag it into the first world.
Washington believed. Wall Street believed. Media cheerleaders believed. Eventually, most of Mexico believed. But things did not work out quite the way all those believers thought they would. 
 
Mr. Salinas did align Mexico's economy far more closely with that of the United States, capping that achievement with the North American Free Trade Agreement. He sold off hundreds of publicly owned companies, including the phone company, the national airline and leading banks, using some of the proceeds to reduce foreign debt.
By stemming the red ink from these companies, while using pro-government unions to keep wage settlements low and short-term foreign borrowing to keep the peso high, Mr. Salinas dramatically reduced inflation. For most of his term, international confidence in the Mexican economy soared and living standards, at least for the upper and middle classes, rose.
But almost as soon as he left office, much of his economic achievement unraveled. Reckless short-term borrowing had set up the peso for a precipitous fall. Foreign lenders took fright. Growth ground into reverse and living standards sharply declined. It has taken Mr. Salinas' less flashy successor, Ernesto Zedillo, more than a year to halt the slide.
Mr. Zedillo is also an American-trained technocrat, and he has been carrying out an even more far-reaching agenda of reforms than his predecessor. But no one in Washington, Wall Street or Mexico City is now in any mood to tout new Mexican miracles.
Carlos Salinas was a genuine economic reformer. But he was also a privileged product and protector of Mexico's ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI. He never challenged the PRI's taste for electoral fraud. In fact, PRI shenanigans may have given him his narrow victory margin in that 1988 presidential race. Mr. Salinas declared that his principal mission was to fix the economy and that cleaning up the political system could and should be put off to another day.
The United States business community, delighted with his economic policies, happily bought his line. The Bush and Clinton Administrations, eager to lock in Mexican economic reforms by getting Congress to ratify Nafta, ignored or downplayed issues like electoral fraud, corruption and police tolerance of narcotics trafficking. Nafta gives American companies fairer access to Mexican markets and will continue to encourage the modernization of Mexico's economy. But Washington foolishly promoted it as a fast-acting cure-all that would instantly add jobs, lower trade deficits and prevent cross-border migration. Worse, Nafta became an excuse for overlooking America's equally strong interest in Mexican democracy.
Ignoring Mexico's political problems became harder after an armed peasant rebellion broke out in Chiapas in early 1994 and even more difficult after two of the country's leading political figures were assassinated later that year in cases that are still under judicial investigation. With Salinas business associates no longer protected by a friendly Government, Mexicans are learning that many were corrupt, pocketing fabulous sums from privatization and favoritism. Even worse, the former President's brother, Raul Salinas, has now been imprisoned on charges of commissioning political murder.
Mexico has learned some hard lessons from the Salinas episode; Washington must learn the same lessons. Supporting economic reforms in countries like Mexico obviously makes sense. But to do so uncritically, without paying attention to political reform, does not serve our interests or theirs.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
Duckman Going on Leave
 
Lorin Duckman, the Brooklyn Criminal Court Judge who has been under harsh attack recently for his handling of two domestic violence cases, will take an unspecified amount of time off from his duties on the bench, a spokeswoman for the state court system said. For nearly two weeks Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Gov. George E. Pataki and other officials have called for the removal of Judge Duckman because of his decision to release from custody a convicted rapist who went on to kill his former girlfriend at a Queens car dealership. [Page 23.]
 
Dragnet Smashes a Gang
 
Taking aim at the network of alien smugglers who have brought hundreds of illegal Chinese immigrants to New York in recent years -- and who often use kidnapping, torture and extortion to bolster profits -- Federal prosecutors said that they had smashed a violent organized-crime gang that had terrorized Chinatown for years. HEADLINE: Economy Slowed in Late 1995 As Growth Rate Dipped to 0.9%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23

 BODY:
The economy grew at a meager annual pace of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the final three months of 1995 as consumers kept a tight grip on their wallets, Government spending fell and investment by business slackened, the Commerce Department reported today.
For all of 1995, the output of goods and services advanced 2.1 percent over the previous year, the smallest gain since 1991, when the gross domestic product fell 1 percent. 
 Going into this election year, the Clinton Administration conceded that economic weakness might continue through the early months of 1996. But White House officials contend that springtime should bring a reawakening of growth.
Joseph E. Stiglitz, the President's chief economic adviser, noted "several kernels of good news for 1996" in the unexpectedly dismal numbers. He pointed to evidence that business efforts to reduce the stock of unsold goods, which depressed growth during much of 1995, appear to be near an end.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told Congress this week -- before the Government's figures were compiled -- that the economy was going through a "significant soft patch." He said the risk of continuing subpar performance prompted the Federal Reserve's last round of rate cuts on Jan. 31 and he said that further doses of monetary stimulus might be required if conditions continued to deteriorate.
But Mr. Greenspan predicted that the stumbling economy, nearing its fifth anniversary of expansion, was more likely to rebound than to slide into recession. The next meeting of the central bank's policy-making Open Market Committee is scheduled for March 26.
In a separate report today, the department said that builders broke ground on new homes at a surprisingly solid pace in January, largely offsetting a previously unreported skid in December.
Investors seemed torn in interpreting the contrasting sets of figures, with bond prices, after a brief rally, sagging throughout the day. Stock prices, as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average, gyrated nearly 100 points before closing with a moderate gain. [Page 37.]
The partial shutdown of the Government late last year also acted as a drag on the economy, which was just 1.4 percent higher in the October-December period than in the corresponding 1994 period.
Interpretation of both reports was made more difficult by furloughs of Government statisticians and other workers and by the January blizzard that made the housing figures particularly suspect.
"This report is somewhat incomprehensible," Joel L. Naroff, a senior economist in Philadelphia for the First Union Corporation, said of the housing report. "The blizzard of the century apparently did not deter builders in the Northeast," where houses were started at a pace 5.6 percent faster, seasonally adjusted, than in December. Activity in the Northeast, however, remains far below that of any of the other three regions.
For the country as a whole, housing starts ran at a pace of 1,446,000 in January, 4.4 percent above the December pace. But starts in December, at a 1,385,000 pace, were 5 percent below November.
Analysts also noted that the January rebound was dominated by apartments and other multifamily buildings, a category that moves erratically.
The initial estimate for fourth-quarter gross domestic product -- the value of the total output of goods and services within American borders -- showed that expansion slowed to a pace one-quarter as rapid as the 3.6 percent recorded during the July-September period. The 3.6 percent figure was a revision from an earlier estimate of 3.2 percent. As for the sluggish fourth-quarter pace, it was about half as much as had generally been expected.
While analysts paid the figures somewhat less attention than usual since they were delayed a month by the partial Government closing, a common observation was how decisively consumers, who account for two-thirds of G.D.P., had pulled back.
Personal spending climbed at a pace of just eight-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter, compared with 2.8 percent during the summer.
Everett M. Ehrlich, Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, said it was still too early to predict whether the current quarter, which runs through the end of March, was likely to show any significant strengthening.
But Mr. Stiglitz, the White House economist, saw at least a few favorable portents in the figures. "The slowing of the rate of inventory investment suggests that most of the long-awaited inventory correction is behind us," he said in a statement. The pause in consumer spending, along with marked growth in incomes, he added, has raised the savings rate and this, combined with soaring stock prices, "should allow consumers to resume their spending."
Besides pinch-penny spending by consumers and scaled-back building of inventories, the fourth-quarter G.D.P. was characterized mainly by buoyant exports, a second consecutive quarterly gain in the building of single-family homes, an advance in fixed investment and a sharp decline in Government spending.
The department estimated that the furloughs of Government workers subtracted about one-quarter of a point from G.D.P. and added that amount to the price index for gross domestic purchases, reflecting the fact that Government workers were paid for not working. The price index rose at a 2 percent rate compared with 1.7 percent in the third quarter.
Some analysts contend that international trade, which was a major factor in sustaining growth during the fourth quarter, may fade as a contributor to economic output. "I'm negative on the export sector," said Fariborz Ghadar, director of the Center for Global Business Studies at Pennsylvania State University.
Expressed in current dollars, G.D.P. rose at a 2.7 percent rate in the fourth quarter, according to today's report, down from 5.8 percent in the third quarter.
The housing report showed that starts last year totaled 1,350,500, or 7.3 percent below the 1994 level. This was the first annual decline since 1991.
For January, permits issued for new homes moved opposite to starts, declining 7.1 percent from the December pace.
Data included in the gross domestic product for the fourth quarter of 1995 follow, with all dollar amounts in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Data are computed using the new "chain weighted" system, which tries to accurately reflect real changes in the economy by accounting for inflation in a continuous manner. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates.
