HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Still Exceeds U.S. Average

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 23

 BODY:
New Jersey lost thousands of jobs last month as the state's unemployment rate remained above the national average, suggesting continued sluggishness in the local economy, according to data released by state and Federal officials today.
Using a new method to estimate unemployment figures, officials calculated New Jersey's jobless rate at 6.5 percent in January. They revised the December rate to 6.6 percent, from 7.3 percent, easing concern among some economists that an apparent spike in December unemployment figures had signaled the beginning of a sudden downturn in the state economy. 
 Economists and analysts said that the latest employment data showed that New Jersey could expect slower job growth this year as corporate layoffs continue. For example, the impact of the decision by AT&T, the state's largest employer, to eliminate 7,000 jobs this year has yet to ripple through the state's economy.
The national unemployment rate was up to 5.8 percent in January, from 5.6 percent the month before, officials said today. New York State and Connecticut are scheduled to release their figures for January next week. December's unemployment rate was 6.4 percent in New York and 5.1 percent in Connecticut.
The Federal Government acknowledged that its previous monthly reporting methods, based on a sampling of 2,300 households in New Jersey, sometimes produced distortions in the data. Even so, the apparent sharp rise in New Jersey's unemployment rate from November to December worried regional economists and the administration of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, because overall job growth had begun to slow in the final months of last year.
State officials said today that January's data, which showed a loss of 28,200 jobs, were skewed by severe snowstorms, which forced many businesses to close or call in fewer workers.
"That is a very large number, but the events in January were so extreme, we really have to wait for another month to see if we are witnessing a deterioration or what I expect will be a bounce back," said Joseph Seneca, chairman of the New Jersey Council of Economic Advisors, and a professor of economics at Rutgers University.
Officials used the new methodology to calculate unemployment rates for all of 1995, which produced monthly projections that were slightly different from those under the old formula. But after further adjustments, the state's average unemployment rate under either method would be 6.4 percent last year, said John L. Wieting, regional commissioner for the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.
As a result of Federal budget cutbacks, the Bureau of Labor Statistics no longer issues monthly unemployment data based on monthly surveys for the 11 large industrial states, including New York and New Jersey. While the surveys sometimes produced fluctuations in unemployment figures for those states, they allowed the Federal Government to promptly report employment data, which economists used to project economic trends, Mr. Wieting said. Now, the Federal Government will use a statistical model for the 11 industrial states similar to models being used in all other states.
In New Jersey, the model is based on payroll data from 12,000 employers and unemployment claims, along with a smaller monthly survey of households. "The result of this modeling approach is less volatility in the estimation of monthly labor force unemployment levels for the state," said Mr. Wieting, who traveled to Trenton today to join New Jersey labor officials in releasing the new unemployment figures.
Governor Whitman said that she had requested Mr. Wieting's attendance at today's news conference so that New Jerseyans would understand that the Federal Government was using a new formula to determine unemployment rates.
"I didn't want it to look like we were trying to play with the numbers now that there is this new system," Mrs. Whitman said.
But Democrats suggested that the Whitman administration was seeking more optimistic forecasts. Bernard F. Kenny Jr., the assistant Senate minority leader and a Democrat from Hudson County, said: "The Whitman administration's 'new math' doesn't mask the fact that nearly 300,000 New Jerseyans are out of work, the state leads the nation in announced layoffs and our unemployment rate is significantly higher than the U.S. rate."

HEADLINE: ALBANY'S TAX CUT FACING CHALLENGE

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 23

 BODY:
With the state facing its potentially worst fiscal crisis in years, a growing number of labor leaders, municipal officials and Democratic legislators are openly advocating what was once considered politically unthinkable: delaying or scaling back an income-tax cut scheduled to take effect in just five weeks.
What has made the groundswell of support for modifying the tax cut particularly surprising is that it involves not just New York City legislators but also more conservative lawmakers from central and western New York. Democrats from those regions are considered the most vulnerable to Republican challenges this year, and therefore least likely to support rolling back the tax cut, which would typically reduce a family's taxes by $19 a month but would cost the state $1.7 billion. 
 Gov. George E. Pataki, who pushed the tax-cut plan through the Legislature last year after making it a centerpiece of his campaign, has repeatedly said that he would oppose any efforts to scale it back. So have Speaker Sheldon Silver of the Assembly, a Democrat of Manhattan; and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican of Rensselaer County.
"We made a commitment to voters, and we have to keep that commitment," Mr. Silver said recently, echoing a phrase used by the others.
But critics of the tax cut are preparing a major lobbying campaign to pressure the leaders to reconsider the tax cut in future budget negotiations. The fight is likely to mirror similar debates between 1990 and 1994, when the Legislature postponed income-tax cuts five times because of state fiscal problems.
The second phase of a three-year tax-cut plan enacted last year is to take effect on April 1. Under that plan, new withholding tables will be mailed to employers in early March showing that a family of four making $50,000 a year will get back $226, or $19 a month, from the 1996 phase of the tax cut.
Until now, almost no one, including even liberal Democrats, has been willing to openly discuss freezing or scaling back the tax cut, in large part because this is an election year when Republicans are planning to attack Democrats across the state for tax-and-spend policies.
But the state is facing a $4 billion shortfall for the fiscal year that begins April 1, and that gap will grow as much as $2.5 billion more if the Federal Government does not enact major changes to welfare and Medicaid programs -- actions that have grown increasingly likely.
Mr. Pataki has proposed closing the $4 billion shortfall with a broad array of reductions to health care, welfare and educational services. And he has said that he will have to deepen those cuts significantly if he does not get the policy changes he needs from Washington.
Consequently, an increasing number of lawmakers are asking: Do New Yorkers really want a tax cut typically worth $19 a month if it means large reductions in government services in exchange? The alternative, postponing the second phase of the tax cut, would provide the state $1.7 billion in additional revenue, enough to close almost half the anticipated shortfall and, in the view of some, tone down the annual budget fight between the Governor and the Legislature.
"This is controversial, but if we did it we could close the budget down in a matter of days," said Assemblyman Scott M. Stringer, a Democrat of Manhattan who has introduced legislation to reduce the size of the tax cut. "Once you did this, there would be nothing left to fight over."
Republican legislators are more circumspect about the tax cut, saying they believe the state can overcome its fiscal problems by cutting health and welfare programs more. Still, some of them say they would welcome a debate over the tax cut, provided the Governor or the Democrats raise it first.
"If things get worse and Washington backs out on their pledges to change Medicaid and it throws us into another $2.5 to $3 billion hole, then you have to look at everything," said Senator Robert J. DiCarlo, a Republican of Brooklyn.
Mr. Stringer and his allies contend that the state, by reducing services and cutting aid to local governments, has already forced local school districts and municipalities to increase property taxes. Additional state tax cuts will cause those local taxes to rise even more, they say.
"The reality is that people have not seen a reduction of taxes," said Edward C. Farrell, executive director of the New York State Conference of Mayors. "They've seen an increase in property taxes. We think it makes a lot of sense to discuss delaying or rolling back the income tax cut."
But proponents of lower taxes say they are confident that only a tiny handful of legislators will be willing to oppose a tax cut in an election year, particularly when Mr. Pataki is expected to veto any changes to the tax-cut plan. Still, they also say that if the Federal budget impasse continues through the elections, the political tide could shift quickly.
In an indication of the growing legislative concern about the tax cut, even Democrats who represent districts where Mr. Pataki won in 1994 have begun questioning the tax cut. Assemblyman Richard J. Keane, a Democrat from the Buffalo area, for example, said he believed that his constituents would rather forego the additional tax cut than see their property taxes increase or tuition at state colleges rise.
"People want to believe we've got a gold mine in the backyard and can give them increased spending and tax cuts, too," he said. "But once it hits home what it will cost them in terms of reduced services or higher property taxes, then their song changes."
The Governor has said that the tax cut will spur economic growth and job creation by putting more spending money in people's pockets. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has agreed with that argument.
Mr. Pataki also contends that the plan reduces taxes more for low- and moderate-income people than for the wealthy. By 1997, 452,000 lower-income New Yorkers would no longer pay state income taxes under the plan, state tax officials say.
But several major labor unions are taking issue with his arguments in a statewide lobbying campaign. They include the Civil Service Employees Association, the Public Employees Federation and the New York State United Teachers, which together represent over half a million government workers who, their officials fear, could lose their jobs.
In newsletters, letters to legislators and television and newspaper advertisements, the unions have attacked Mr. Pataki's budget as cutting services for the middle class while cutting taxes for the wealthy. They have also circulated studies showing that 40 percent of the 1996 tax cut will go to the wealthiest 5 percent of the population.
"You don't go buy a new Mercedes when you can't balance the books, and that's what they are doing here," said Danny Donohue, president of the Civil Service union. "To talk about a tax cut when you're talking about a deficit budget is ridiculous."

HEADLINE: U.S. Chicken in Every Pot? In Russia, Apparently Not

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 23

 BODY:
A nasty little skirmish between Russia and the United States is brewing here over a threatened trade barrier.
But this fight is not about manufactured consumer goods or high technology, but about American chicken, which has flooded the Russian market. 
 To the frustration, and considerable anxiety, of American companies, the Russian Government has threatened to ban further American poultry sales effective March 19.
The threatened move, which American poultry producers protest amounts to protectionism, comes at the same time Russia has agreed with the International Monetary Fund on a $10.2 billion loan to further the country's efforts to develop a free-market economy. The loan was made with the strong support of the White House.
Today, the White House voiced its opposition to the Russian ban. "We take this issue very seriously," said David P. Johnson, a White House spokesman, adding that the Administration was raising the issue with senior Russian officials.
In an odd twist of international trade and domestic politics, among the biggest losers in an import ban would be Tyson Foods of Springdale, Ark., which has been a longtime supporter of President Clinton.
American producers exported more than $500 million in frozen poultry to Russia last year, and Tyson accounted for roughly a third of that.
But a spokesman for Tyson, which has annual sales of $5.5 billion, said today that its sales in Russia were "relatively insignificant."
The ostensible reason for the Russian Government's warning is health -- a seemingly strange concern in a country with a generally lax record in observing safety standards, where virtually every able-bodied man and woman smokes.
Today, no less an authority than the Veterinary Department of the Russian Agriculture and Food Ministry said the ban was needed to protect consumers here against infected poultry until the United States improved its standards.
But the real agenda, American producers contend, is old-fashioned protectionism.
Agitated Russian producers, whose birds, Russian consumers say, have no match for their American competition in terms of quality and price, have repeatedly complained that the United States is trying to destroy the Russian poultry industry and capture the market. And now American companies fear the Russian producers are striking back.
"We are treating it as a trade issue, rather than as an inspection or food safety issue," said Toby Moore, a spokesman for the United States Poultry and Egg Export Council, an industry trade association in Atlanta. "We firmly believe that there is a political motivation behind it. It's getting kind of weird."
American chicken was not always considered a threat to the Russian motherland.
The first big invasion of frozen poultry came during the Bush Administration, when Washington provided loan guarantees to American exporters to stimulate the sale of dark meat to Russia.
The export proved to be very popular with Russian consumers, who dubbed them Bush legs.
After the demise of the Soviet Union, American poultry exports continued to soar. Russian poultry production, meanwhile, fell 40 percent, the result of rising grain prices and declining subsidies.
Astoundingly, a third of all American exports to Russia is poultry, American officials say.
But while Russian consumers have been generally very pleased with the quality of the American poultry, there have been problems.
Conagra Inc., the world's fourth-largest food processing company, sold some spoiled chicken to Russia last year, American officials said. The poultry had thawed and then been refrozen. Conagra officials could not be reached for comment.
That dispute was worked out, but the episode appeared to have given protectionist-minded Russian producers here the opening they were looking for.
Russia demanded, and received, the right to conduct inspections of American poultry processing plants. And Russians specialists later complained that health and safety standards in the United States were wanting, citing the problem of bacteria and chemical residues in the meat.
Vyacheslav Avilov, the chief Russian veterinary inspector, believes that "U.S. experts do not make necessary analyses that would guarantee the product's quality, which is why Russian consumers take risks when buying the poultry," the Russian news agency Interfax reported today.
To the further consternation of the Americans, the Russians have also decided to effectively double the tariff on imported poultry.
Some American poultry executives say that the dispute, in part, represents a misunderstanding of how the capitalist world raises and processes meat.
They say the Russians are accustomed to a rigid system of government oversight, however laxly it might be enforced, and simply do not understand how American companies can take steps to police themselves.
"We are optimistic that any differences can be resolved so there will be no disruption in product flow," the National Broiler Council, a Washington-based trade group, said in a statement.
But American officials, invoking cold war images of stonewalling Soviet diplomats, are less encouraging and complain that Russian officials have not been forthcoming in recent talks held in Washington and Moscow.
"Every time we try to address some of their concerns, they pull up another list," said an American official, who asked not to be named.
The Clinton Administration has been hoping that the Russians would suspend their threat to ban the poultry while negotiations continued. But so far, the Russians are holding firm.
"There are some hints of flexibility, but we are not yet at resolution," added another American official close to the talks.
If the confrontation continues, the United States has a number of possible recourses, including arguing that the Russian action is inconsistent with Moscow's bid to join the World Trade Organization.
Some experts, however, believe there is an important countervailing force here that may lead to a softening of the Russian position: namely Russian customers.
Russian consumers favor the American birds, which despite the dire warnings of the Russian Government, have come to symbolize quality. And they vote, too.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: TRADE;
President Shows Political Muscle on Visit to California

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: SANTA MONICA, Calif. Feb. 23

 BODY:
 In a state crucial to his re-election prospects, President Clinton today displayed the political power of incumbency.
As aerospace workers in Long Beach whooped and cheered and waved minature American flags, he announced that he was seeking Congressional approval to buy 80 more C-17 cargo planes, a move the Administration said would create 4,700 jobs there. 
 Proclaiming that "we have to break down walls, not build them up," Mr. Clinton also used his appearance at the McDonnell Douglas plant there to underscore the benefits of free trade and set himself apart from the views of Patrick J. Buchanan, the Republican Presidential candidate, who has appealed to workers with a message of protectionism and economic nationalism.
Mr. Clinton, who did not mention Mr. Buchanan by name, made his remarks hours before he met here with Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan, the former Trade Minister, to prepare for the President's state visit to Tokyo in April.
During the hourlong get-acquainted session between the two leaders at a Santa Monica hotel, Mr. Clinton identified areas in which the United States wants to see more progress in opening Japanese markets: semiconductors, insurance, photographic film and civil aviation.
But throughout the day, Mr. Clinton also cited the 20 trade agreements his Administration has reached with Japan as signs of an improving trade relationship.
"In California, more than a quarter of a million jobs depend on trade with Japan," he said earlier in Long Beach, speaking to thousands of aerospace workers. "For the first time in history, rice farmers in California can sell rice in Japan.
"If you want your country to lead for peace and freedom and prosperity, the answer is neither to be uncritically in favor of free trade, nor to be pulling up the rug and closing our borders. The answer is to be for trade that is free and fair so everybody has a fair chance to grow in the global economy."
With his stop at the plant that manufactures the C-17, Mr. Clinton began a marathon two-day swing through California and Washington State. It was his 22d visit as President to California, the state with 54 electoral votes, which Mr. Clinton has ministered to through earthquakes and floods, recession and the disruption caused by military base closings. The trip, six weeks before the primaries in California and Washington, was paid for by the Clinton-Gore re-election campaign.
Mr. Clinton himself fought to save the C-17 cargo plane from Congressional critics who had complained of cost overruns and production line delays. The Air Force now has two dozen C-17's in its cargo fleet and Mr. Clinton used one in January for his trip to Bosnia.
Mr. Hashimoto's visit came as America's relations with Japan emerged as an issue in the Republican Presidential race. In a debate on Thursday night, Mr. Buchanan said that Japan was worried that he might become President. If elected, he said, he would tell the Japanese Prime Minister that unless the two countries worked out the balance of trade he would "unilaterally" end Japan's trade surplus. Another Republican Presidential candidate, Former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, has also vowed to be tough on trade with Tokyo.
As he began his session with Mr. Hashimoto tonight, Mr. Clinton pointed to the declining trade deficit with Japan as evidence that the trade pacts and policies he has pursued are working. At the same time, the President acknowledged ongoing problems in opening up Japan's markets to American products. "We are moving in the right direction," Mr. Clinton said. "Other countries should do as well."
In their brief meeting, described by United States officials as warm, the two leaders also discussed security concerns, which became a major issue between the two nations after a schoolgirl was raped on the island of Okinawa in September. Three United States servicemen are on trial for the crime, which caused an outporing of resentment against the United States military presence.
While the United States has said it would consider relocating some troops elsewhere in Japan, Mr. Clinton tonight reaffirmed that the United States would maintain its force levels in Asia, Assistant Secretary of State Winston Lord said.
Mr. Hashimoto, who as Trade Minister helped bring about the United States-Japan agreement on auto trade, sidestepped a question from reporters about whether he feared Mr. Buchanan. "Concerning the election," he said, "that's a decision the American people have to make."
But Mr. Clinton said, "Let me say that I hope that the Japanese Prime Minister would never be afraid of any American President. We have a partnership." As Mr. Clinton spoke, Mr. Hashimoto feigned fright.
But at the plant today, the workers barely reacted to Mr. Clinton's comments about trade, instead brightening with enthusiasm when he praised the military cargo plane they build.
Regaling his listeners with the story of his flight into Bosnia last month on a C-17 to visit American troops, Mr. Clinton said the plane had ferried not only him but two Army wide-bodied cargo carriers, Humvees, lots of bags of mail, 210 cases of Coke and 5,000 Hershey bars.
"And there was a lot of room to spare," he said. To roars of laughter, he added, "Not only that, even with all the press and politicians there, the plane carried all the hot air that we could generate in that flight."

HEADLINE: Dorothy Maynor, 85, Soprano and Arts School Founder, Dies

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
Dorothy Maynor, a highly regarded soprano recitalist who founded the Harlem School of the Arts, died on Monday at the Chester County Hospital in West Chester, Pa. She was 85 and lived in Kennett Square, Pa.
Miss Maynor, whose career helped open the way for black artists like Marian Anderson and Leontyne Price, possessed a voice that the New Grove Dictionary of American Music describes as "a soaring, belllike soprano capable of exquisite musical effects, supported by a sincere and ardent temperament." She took New York by storm in a sold-out recital at Town Hall in 1939 and pursued a successful recital career. 
 Although she committed more than 100 operatic roles to memory, she never appeared on an opera stage; there were no such opportunities for a black artist in the late 1930's and the 1940's, when she was in her prime. (Miss Anderson, the first black singer to appear at the Metropolitan Opera, did not make her debut there until 1955.)
Miss Maynor was born in Norfolk, Va., and as a child she sang in the choir of her father's church. She entered Hampton Institute (now Hampton University) in Hampton, Va., intending to become a teacher of home economics, but she also joined the renowned Hampton Choir, with which she toured Europe in 1929. On the advice of the choir director, R. Nathaniel Dett, she changed her major to music and earned a bachelor's degree in 1933.
After being awarded a scholarship, she studied choir direction at the Westminster Choir College in Princeton, N.J., where she received a second bachelor's degree in music and choral conducting in 1935. While on tour in New England with the school's choir, she was encouraged by several wealthy benefactors to pursue a concert career. Three years of private study in New York followed, with Wilfried Klamroth and John Alan Haughton. At this time she changed the spelling of her name from Mainor.
After hearing her sing at the 1939 Berkshire Symphonic Festival at Tanglewood in western Massachusetts, the conductor Serge Koussevitzky reportedly jumped up and down, shouting: "It is a miracle! It is a musical revelation! The world must hear her!" Koussevitzky, who called Miss Maynor "a native Flagstad," immediately used her in recordings with the Boston Symphony Orchestra.
She made her formal debut at Town Hall in Manhattan later that year, on Nov. 19, in a widely anticipated event that was sold out more than a week in advance. Olin Downes, reviewing the concert for The New York Times, hailed her as "one of the most remarkable soprano voices of the rising generation," called her voice "phenomenal for its range, character and varied expressive resources."
Miss Maynor began touring extensively in the United States, often appearing as a soloist with leading orchestras. She made her Carnegie Hall debut in 1940 with the New York Philharmonic, conducted by John Barbirolli. In the late 40's she toured Latin America and Europe. She often performed at benefits to aid the war effort and black causes.
She sang at the Presidential Inaugural galas for Harry S. Truman in 1949 and Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1953. In 1952, by special permission of the Daughters of the American Revolution, she appeared as a soloist with the National Symphony Orchestra at Constitution Hall in the first commercial appearance there by a black artist since Miss Anderson had been barred from performing at the hall in 1939. (Miss Anderson subsequently gave benefit performances at the hall.)
Miss Maynor recorded popular arias and songs for RCA Victor. Although she never appeared on the opera stage, she recorded the role of Leonore in "Fidelio" under Arturo Toscanini.
In 1963, she retired to work with her husband, the Rev. Shelby Rooks, at St. James Presbyterian Church at West 141st Street and St. Nicholas Avenue in Harlem, where he was pastor. That year she founded the Harlem School of the Arts. The school offered classes in music, ballet, modern dance, drama and art to poor children for minimal fees, sometimes as little as 50 cents a lesson, and lent or rented instruments to students who did not own one.
"In most schools, if you don't have a piano, you can't take lessons," Miss Maynor told one interviewer. "But we say, 'Good, you come here and practice.' " She served as executive director of the school until 1979 and also taught there. In 1977 she raised more than $2 million to build a new facility for the school, which originally served 20 children and now has more than 1,000 students.
"What I dream of is changing the image held by the children," she said on another occasion. "We've made them believe everything beautiful is outside the community. We would like them to make beauty in our community."
Her work with the school is recounted in "Dorothy Maynor and the Harlem School of the Arts: The Diva and the Dream" (Edwin Mellen Press, 1993), by William F. Rogers Jr.
She received honorary doctorates from many schools, including Howard University, Westminster Choir College, Oberlin College, Carnegie-Mellon University and Bennett College in Greensboro, N.C..
In 1975, she became the first black member of the Metropolitan Opera board.
She is survived by her husband.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 2, 1996, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary last Saturday about the soprano Dorothy Maynor credited her with one recording incorrectly. She did not record the role of Leonore in "Fidelio" with Toscanini.

HEADLINE: Film Redux In Europe: Action!;
New Signs of Life After a Long Decline

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
At the big Shepperton Studios west of London, work progresses on "101 Dalmatians," a version with live actors of Walt Disney's animated classic. At nearby Pinewood Studios, cutting was just finished of "The Michael Collins Story," a tale of Irish independence by Ireland's brightest young director, Neil Jordan. In Berlin, a $230 million investment is well under way to revive the old Babelsberg Studios that produced classics like Fritz Lang's "Metropolis" and "The Blue Angel," with Marlene Dietrich.
After decades of decline, film making in Europe is reviving. Investment in film production, while still about one-third that of the United States, is edging up after several flat years. The number of films produced in most European countries is now climbing: In Britain, 81 feature films were produced in 1995, up from 70 in 1994; in Germany 84 films were made last year compared with only 57 in 1994. And on a continent struggling with unemployment rates double those in the United States, the production of films and audiovisual products last year employed more than 850,000 people, compared with 630,000 a decade earlier. 
 Yet Europeans call the blessing a mixed one. For what is sparking the growth is investment by the big American film studios like Walt Disney and Warner Brothers, a unit of Time Warner. Now, Europeans increasingly fear the American presence could crush domestic productions.
"By the year 2010 films and multimedia and television will be the largest single employer in Europe," said Jeremy Thomas, one of Britain's leading independent film producers and the chairman of the British Film Institute. Yet America's film industry, he cautioned, is increasingly behaving "like when you have a predator fish in a pond."
But while European intellectuals may bemoan the fact that American film distributors control the biggest chunk -- roughly 90 percent of major European film markets like Germany and Britain -- investment in film making continues to flow.
Last year, for example, Shepperton was bought for $18 million by the British film directors Tony and Ridley Scott, who began a $15 million modernization. This year, Warner Brothers will open a new film animation studio in London; in Germany, Warner will open its $270 million Warner Brothers Movie World film studio theme park and recently announced plans for another in Britain, to cost $344 million. At Babelsberg, a new $4.5 million sound studio, financed in part with German Government funds, is attracting international clients like Turner Entertainment, a unit of the Turner Broadcasting System.
Most of the studios' newfound activity stems from the arrival of American film makers in ever larger numbers, and the reason, according to Roy Button, the director of Warner Brothers Productions at Pinewood, is cost.
"England has changed phenomenally in the last four to five years," Mr. Button said as he sat beneath posters for recent Pinewood productions like Sylvester Stallone's "Judge Dredd."
He estimated the cost of producing a film in Britain to be about 35 percent lower than in the United States, in part because of favorable currency exchange rates, but mainly because of weakened labor unions, a legacy of former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Studios are thus able to employ fewer people, and pay lower fringe benefits. In Spain and Portugal weak local currencies sharply reduce the cost of film making when calculated in dollars.
Most industry experts say part of Europe's film revival is also a result of the overhaul of European cinemas, led in part by American companies like Warner Brothers Theaters and American Multi-cinema, which is fast replacing single-screen movie houses with multiplex theaters. American Multi-cinema is owned by AMC Entertainment Inc.
"There's a big market all over Europe, east and west," said Joost Bert, whose Brussels-based theater chain Kinepolis opened a 4,200-seat, 14-screen multiplex in Metz, France, last March and is building another in Lille, in northern France, with 23 screens and 7,600 seats.
The new wave of film theaters has reversed the trend in movie viewing. In Germany, admissions reached 124 million last year, compared with 102 million in 1990. In France, Europe's largest film-viewing market, admissions in 1995 were 130 million, compared with 122 million five years earlier. In Britain, admissions in 1995 were 115 million, compared with 97 million five years earlier.
Recently at the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France led a fresh attempt to counter American dominance by imposing quotas on American television programming. Yet the French zeal is increasingly questioned by industry experts and government leaders in other countries, including Britain, Germany and Italy, who are concluding that to compete culturally, Europe must compete commercially.
Business is arguing with money. This week, the Kirch Group, one of Germany's biggest media conglomerates, clinched deals to buy American film material from Columbia Tristar, a Sony subsidiary, and from Hearst Entertainment. The deals are believed to be worth more than $700 million.
"It is hard to mix business and culture," said Mr. Thomas of the British Film Institute. "Business is going to win."
At this point, Britain is leading the way.
Though Britain's film studios enjoyed a brief renaissance in the early 1980's with box office hits like "Chariots of Fire" and "Gandhi," by the middle of that decade they were faltering. In 1989, Britain's studios produced only 30 films and four years later the most venerable of the studios, Elstree, built in 1924, where Alfred Hitchcock directed the first British talkie, "Blackmail," closed. By last year, however, the number of films made in Britain had risen to 81 and studio space was so tight that Eon Productions transformed a former airplane hangar near London into a temporary sound stage to film the latest James Bond thriller, "GoldenEye."
"We're right on the crest of a wave," said Paul Olliver, the studio manager at Shepperton, where Walt Disney recently made "The Muppet Christmas Carol."
The boom at Britain's studios is a result, in part, of government action. In 1993, Ireland enacted tax rebates for film production, and by last year the number of films made in Ireland rose to 20, including hits like "Braveheart," Mel Gibson's Scottish epic, from one film four years earlier.
Not everyone, of course, is able to cash in on the American presence, and in the meantime many European studios, like Munich's Bavaria Studios and Rome's Cinecitta, which is owned by the Italian state, are staying alive with television work. But while Bavaria is turning a profit, Cinecitta, once the terrain of giants like Federico Fellini, has suffered from lackluster government management and is losing more than $6 million a year. Plans to revive the studio by selling it to private investors have been hamstrung by Italy's never-ending political crises.
If Italy is looking at privatization to lure investment, Germany is pouring subsidies into Babelsberg.
In 1992, Babelsberg was bought for $150 million by the French conglomerate Compagnie Generale des Eaux S. A. from the German Government agency responsible for privatizing the industries of formerly Communist East Germany. Jurgen Schepers, the director of marketing, whose office looks out on what is probably Europe's biggest construction site, boasted of how Babelsberg last year attracted a television pilot called "Star Command," produced by Paramount, and "The Ogre," a feature film starring William Hurt that was directed by the German director Volker Schlondorff. Yet Babelsberg had pretax losses in 1995 of $6.2 million, on revenues of $32 million, and does not expect to break even until 1997 at the earliest.
Of course, whether Babelsberg ever becomes profitable will depend largely on its ability to attract lucrative film productions, including some from the United States.
Encouragement comes from European television. If American series and soap operas long ruled the European airwaves, European-made products are increasingly competing. Indeed, Babelsberg's recently completed $25 million television center is busy turning out popular German programs like the soap opera "Good Times, Bad Times" and a hospital drama along the lines of "E.R." called "Dr. Bruckner" that compete head on with American shows.
"Our goal is to be a European studio," Mr. Schepers said. "The trend is rising toward our own film identity, one with our own style."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 2, 1996, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day last Saturday about an increase in European film production misidentified the German company that recently agreed to buy American films from Hearst Entertainment. It was ZDF, the German television network, not the Kirch Group.

PUB-DATE: February 25, 1996

SECTION: Section 2; Page 39; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 816 words

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
Posters That Once Stirred a Nation

BYLINE: By RITA REIF 

 BODY:
Long before Glasnost, Merrill C. Berman, a New York investor, had pioneered in the collecting of Soviet propaganda posters. In 1975, when such posters were still considered anathema in the West, he ignored the advice of a museum curator who, he says, told him to "focus on Russian film posters and forget the political ones."
When a Paris dealer offered him 30 Russian posters, he couldn't resist. As an undergraduate at Harvard, he had studied 20th-century economics and European Government and never lost interest in Soviet history. Besides, he added, the posters were visually compelling with their bold colors, mix of photographs, striking typography and heroic images of leaders and workers. 
 "I was moving away from Art Nouveau and Art Deco posters and was searching for something with more meaning," he said. "The Russians were very advanced in their use of photo-montage, abstract forms and typography. Words and pictures were combined to communicate and indoctrinate. I soon became obsessed with these kinds of images."
Now Mr. Berman, 57, owns several thousand posters and related ephemera, one of the pre-eminent private collections of Soviet graphic material in the world. It is part of his larger collection of 20th-century Modernist design works -- books, posters, photocollages and photomontages in a variety of styles: Austrian Secession, Bauhaus, Dada, de Stijl, Art Deco, Pop and abstract.
An exhibition featuring 120 of his Russian pieces, "Building the Collective: Soviet Graphic Design, 1917-1937, Selections From the Merrill C. Berman Collection," is on view at the art gallery in Schermerhorn Hall at Columbia University through March 30.
Like most collectors, Mr. Berman says he cannot remember a time when he was not acquiring something, starting with the baseball cards and coins that he bartered as a boy. As a teen-ager, he collected American campaign memorabilia.
In the late 1960's and early 70's, Mr. Berman bought 20th-century paintings. "After the bear market of 1973-74, I had a developed eye, and not as developed a pocketbook," he said. "So I sold the art and began buying 20th-century Modernist graphics."
He was searching for such graphics when he happened on the Russian posters in Paris. "You couldn't look for these posters because no one had these things then," he said. Mr. Berman bought 20 more Soviet posters when they turned up in The Hague a few years later. By 1980, as Russian Jewish immigration to the West increased, the market awakened and he has bought steadily ever since.
Eventually, Soviet propaganda art began to attract the attention of dealers and museums in New York. Mr. Berman lent posters to both the 1992 show "The Great Utopia: The Russian and Soviet Avant-Garde, 1915-1932" at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and "Russian Jewish Artists in a Century of Change: 1890-1990," which closed last month at the Jewish Museum.
The show at Columbia was organized by Leah Dickerman, a graduate student in art history, who also edited and wrote part of the catalogue ($35), published by Princeton Architectural Press. Mr. Berman met Ms. Dickerman in 1994 at the opening of a poster exhibition at the Sander Gallery in Manhattan. That show featured the frequently witty news and propaganda posters produced by Rosta, the Russian telegraph agency.
Ms. Dickerman, a consultant to the Rosta show, had visited the Soviet Union several times and knew that Mr. Berman owned many Russian posters. After viewing his collection, she proposed doing the current exhibition.
AMONG HIS FINEST PIECES, SHE SAID, ARE posters made during a period of rapid industrialization, beginning in 1928, under what was called the Soviet's first five-year plan. "There was such a radical rethinking, and many Russian artists began to work in graphic design for the first time in that period," she said. "That meant there was a whole new social role for artists."
Mr. Berman's posters include some by artists who were little known in the West, including Viktor Deni and Dmitri Moor, two pre-Revolutionary cartoonists whose works depicted capitalists as greedy fools in top hats. He also owns works by masters of the period, Aleksandr Rodchenko, El Lissitzky and Gustav Klutsis. A Rodchenko poster shows a plane aloft with a message urging citizens to buy stock in the state-run airline.
Among his prized posters are several by the Brothers Georgii and Vladimir Stenberg, including one showing workers and soldiers reading the literary journal Novyi Mir (New World). Another, depicting a fragmented industrial site reflected in a man's eyeglasses, was used to promote "The Eleventh," a film celebrating the 11th anniversary of the 1917 revolution.
As dated as the political messages on these posters may seem, the graphics are still fresh today. Witness the the neo-Constructivist ads for Stolichnaya vodka that recall Stenberg's style.
